HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Stumbles Against Yen; Pound Surges on Rate Hopes

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar's rally against the Japanese yen faltered yesterday as the bond market fell unexpectedly and demand surged for the British pound, which hit a four-year high against the United States currency.
But traders said that the thin market exaggerated price movements and that the forces that pushed the dollar higher in 1996 remained firmly in place. Japan's market was closed and will remain so until Monday, and many traders in Europe and the United States quit early for the New Year's holiday. 
 "The only people in the market were the speculative accounts," said Steve Skillman, a vice president at Westdeutsche Landesbank in New York. "People are still fairly bullish on the dollar."
In New York, the dollar stood at 115.93 yen, off from 116.15 yen Monday; it was the dollar's first drop against the yen in a week. But the dollar still ended 1996 with a 12.1 percent gain against the yen, and many traders expect it to test its 45-month high of 116.18 yen, which was reached on Monday.
The dollar traded at 1.5415 marks, off from 1.5555 marks on Monday. But the dollar still ended the year with a 7.3 percent gain against the German currency.
The pound surged to $1.7125 in New York, up from $1.6915 Monday and the highest level since mid-October 1992. Demand for pounds picked up as speculation intensified that British interest rates were likely to rise on Jan. 15, the date of the next policy-making meeting between Eddie George, the Bank of England's governor, and Kenneth Clarke, the Chancellor of the Exchequer. Higher interest rates would give securities denominated in pounds higher returns, making the currency more attractive.
Traders said part of the dollar's weakness yesterday came on a drop in the bond market, which was hurt by data that showed an unexpectedly strong gain in new-home sales in November and a surge in consumer confidence in December to the highest level in seven years.
"Most people were ill prepared for such strong data, which shook everybody up a little bit and gave people an excuse to sell off," said Elliott Dix, assistant vice president of foreign exchange trading at the Signet Banking Corporation in Richmond.

HEADLINE: A Powerful Final Quarter Makes Wall Street's Year

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
Stock and bond underwriting roared back in the final three months of 1996, ending a year on Wall Street that left many rubbing their eyes with disbelief.
It is perhaps difficult to remember, but the securities industry entered the fourth quarter on a somewhat hesitant note. Activity shriveled in the summer from earlier in the year, largely from uncertainty over the direction of the stock market and interest rates. 
 That all changed in the fourth quarter, when a rally of such power was unleashed that the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, wondered whether investors might not be becoming "irrationally exuberant."
Still, compared with the third quarter, "there were clearly more positives for financial markets," said Eric S. Dobkin, a partner at Goldman, Sachs & Company, who is in charge of global equity capital markets.
"Interest rates stabilized, the dollar rallied significantly, and some of the economic statistics came through better than expected," Mr. Dobkin said. "And markets are willing to extend as long as they think the underlying fundamentals are going to be there."
In the quarter, the securities industry underwrote $251.6 billion worth of domestic debt and equity issues, according to Securities Data, a 22.5 percent increase from third-quarter levels, and 29.2 percent more than was underwritten in the fourth quarter of 1995.
For the year, Wall Street stock and bond underwritings totaled a record $953.4 billion, up 33.6 percent from a year ago.
"It's been a great year," said Sallie Krawcheck, a Sanford C. Bernstein & Company analyst. "It was one of those years when almost everyone in the business did well, with the exception of municipal bond underwriting."
But even though a number of municipal underwriters left the business, those who remained were not entirely displeased.
New tax-exempt debt volume was just over $180 billion, well down from the record-breaking years of 1992 and 1993, when new issues exceeded $225 billion, but 15 percent over 1995.
A rising tide may have lifted all boats, but the biggest boats got the biggest lift.
Merrill Lynch, the world's biggest securities firm, once again topped the combined debt and equity underwriting chart.
Mostly familiar names rounded out the top five, with Goldman, Lehman Brothers and Salomon Brothers finishing behind Merrill. But J. P. Morgan & Company, which its rivals like to call a commercial bank, inched out Morgan Stanley, its investment-banking cousin, for fifth place.
For the year, however, Morgan Stanley placed fifth.
And together, Morgan and the four other "bulge bracket" firms accounted for more than 56 percent of the stock and bond underwriting market for the year.
The boom in mergers and acquisitions continued to help drive the underwriting business, particularly on the equity side.
"A major factor throughout this merger-and-acquisition cycle, which began in 1993, has been corporate restructuring or strategic business combinations," said Bruce Fiedorek, global head of mergers and acquisitions at Morgan Stanley.
"Many of these have been accomplished with equity as a form of consideration, or have been encouraged by positive reaction in the equity market."
Mergers involving substantial amounts of equity that were announced in the fourth quarter include the Boeing Company's planned acquisition of the McDonnell Douglas Corporation for stock now worth $14 billion, and the the CSX Corporation's $9.3 billion offer to buy Conrail.
For the year, nearly $650 billion worth of merger and acquisition transactions were announced, according to Securities Data, up nearly 25 percent from a year ago.
Morgan Stanley was the clear winner in the global advisory business. The firm captured more than 24 percent of the market, outdistancing Goldman, Sachs, with 17.5 percent. Merrill Lynch, CS First Boston and J. P. Morgan rounded out the top five. Morgan Stanley was also the leading firm for domestic merger and acquisition transactions.
Not surprisingly, those deals, plus a booming market for initial public offerings, as well as in other aspects of the investment banking business, generated record fees.
Fees disclosed totaled $2.5 billion in the fourth quarter, up more than 50 percent from the third quarter. And for the year, Securities Data figures show that the industry charged a record $9.2 billion in fees, just above the $9.16 billion charged in 1993.
The surge in stock prices during the quarter led to a barrage of initial public offerings: 257 issuers raised more than $14.6 billion. But a number of big deals, including $2 billion of Deutsche Telekom offered in the United States, accounted for the bulk of the dollar volume.
Still, by virtually any measure the entire year was extraordinary: 869 issuers, roughly 50 percent more than in 1995, raised nearly $50 billion, 66 percent more than a year ago.
Once again, Goldman, Sachs dominated the initial public offering market. For the year, Goldman raised nearly $10 billion for 51 issuers. Morgan Stanley, its closest competitor, raised just under $7 billion for 42 issuers.
Compared with the booming equity market, conditions in the debt market were fairly quiet. But positive fundamentals, including largely stable interest rates and low inflation, were incentive enough for corporate treasurers to float a significant number of new issues.
During the quarter, Wall Street underwrote $85.5 billion worth of straight debt, up a bit less than 25 percent from the comparable period a year earlier. And for all of 1996, straight debt underwritings amounted to $330.8 billion, a 21.7 percent increase from 1995.
"It was a strong year," said John C. Qua, co-chief of global debt capital markets at Merrill Lynch. "Not as good as 1993, but as close as you can get."
Perhaps the biggest change over the last few years, Mr. Qua said, were the issuers offering debt in the capital markets.
"Among investment-grade corporate issuers, 25 percent to 30 percent of our activity is now foreign names," he said. "Two years ago, the comparable percentage was 10 percent to 15 percent."
As they looked toward the new year, a number of bankers said they were cautiously optimistic that 1997 would be another solid, if not necessarily record, period.
"We have a benign macroeconomic environment," said Ernesto Cruz, a managing director for equity capital markets at CS First Boston, "with interest rates and inflation under control, justifying or rationalizing the exuberance Mr. Greenspan is concerned about. For that reason, we think 1997 will be a year of good, constructive markets."

HEADLINE: Swiss President Says Pleas for a Holocaust Fund Are 'Blackmail'

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: ZURICH, Dec. 31

 BODY:
President Jean-Pascal Delamuraz today dismissed as "blackmail" calls to set up a compensation fund for Jews who might be entitled to money left in Swiss banks during the Holocaust.
He also accused foreign critics of trying to undermine Switzerland's role as a world financial center by charging that the Swiss had profited cynically from World War II. 
 "Economic competition is fierce and this affair proves it," he said. The remarks were published today after an interview with a French-language Swiss newspaper, Tribune de Geneve.
The World Jewish Congress, which has urged the creation of such a compensation fund, said the Swiss President had shown "shocking insensitivity" and that the comments presented "an assault and challenge to the very soul of Switzerland."
Mr. Delamuraz, in some of the strongest public statements made so far by a Swiss politician, brushed aside demands by international Jewish groups for speedy compensation to Holocaust survivors and their heirs, who say they have been denied money left in Swiss banks as a safe haven from the Nazis.
He rejected the creation of a $250-million fund that he said had been proposed to Switzerland's special ambassador, Thomas Borer, who met in December with representatives of the World Jewish Congress and the Senate Banking Committee chairman, Alfonse D'Amato.
The World Jewish Congress had suggested that Switzerland set up the fund as a gesture of "good faith" toward elderly Jews pending the outcome of investigations.
"This is nothing less than extortion and blackmail," Mr. Delamuraz said. "This fund would make it much more difficult to establish the truth. Such a fund would be considered an admission of guilt."
He repeated the Swiss Government's stance that any compensation should await the findings of a nine-member panel appointed by the Cabinet two weeks ago to open a "sweeping study" into Switzerland's financial dealings during the war.
Mr. Delamuraz, who turns over the rotating one-year presidency to Justice Minister Arnold Koller as of Jan. 1, said the initial Swiss reponse to the criticism had been naive.
"Apart from dogged research into historical truth there is also a strong political desire to destabilize and compromise Switzerland," he said.
Swiss politicians and bankers have long argued privately that bad publicity over missing Holocaust accounts and purchases of Nazi gold by the Swiss National Bank were aimed in part at weakening the growing global role of Swiss banks.
While estimates of the accounts, which included cash, art and other items, vary widely, some experts say they may have held more than half a billion dollars in 1946.
Switzerland set up the nine-member panel of Swiss and international historians, including an Israeli and the director of the Holocaust Museum in Washington, to open Swiss banking records and investigate the amount and fate of the deposits.
The panel is to issue its findings in a report after no more than five years. The inquiry is separate from an international panel set up by Swiss banks and Jewish groups last May to search for individual Holocaust accounts and to help return the assets to their rightful owners.

HEADLINE: North Korea's New Message

 BODY:
North Korea's apology Sunday for attempting to infiltrate South Korea by submarine-borne commandos last September was remarkable enough, coming as it did from a country whose past statements have been largely limited to apocalyptic military threats and crude ideological belligerence. But Pyongyang's expression of "deep regret" for the submarine episode and its promise to make sure that such infiltrations will not be repeated turns out to be part of an even broader and more promising diplomatic breakthrough.
For years, North Korea has tried to freeze out South Korea by seeking an exclusive dialogue with the United States. But in the process of negotiating the apology for the still-mysterious submarine incident, which left 24 North Korean commandos and several South Korean civilians dead, Washington has won the North's agreement to meet jointly with Seoul and Washington as a prelude to talks on officially ending the Korean War. 
 This is an impressive diplomatic triumph, turning a crisis into a chance for peace. It may also signal a significant easing of North Korea's dangerous isolation from the rest of the world. The Clinton Administration and its individual negotiators deserve high marks.
North Korea did not apologize directly, as it should have, to South Korea, which Pyongyang ritually denounced on Monday. Nevertheless, the wording, carefully negotiated between North Korea and the United States, was designed to meet Seoul's minimum conditions for resuming pragmatic cooperation with the North.
That cooperation will now occur on several levels. There will be the proposed peace talks, which are meant to include the United States and China as well as the two Koreas. South Korea will help replace North Korea's nuclear power reactors with models less likely to produce potential bomb fuel. Finally, Seoul should now also feel sufficiently mollified to resume humanitarian food assistance to alleviate a flood-produced famine in the North.
For its part, North Korea accompanied its statement of apology with an agreement to maintain storage safeguards on its spent reactor fuel and Washington indicated that it will now unfreeze export licenses for commercial food shipments to the North.
North Korea's actions this week suggest strongly that the long-isolated Communist regime may indeed be nervously seeking to re-enter the community of civilized nations. No outsider can be sure about what goes on in Pyongyang's inner circles. But the apology and the agreement to meet jointly with Washington and Seoul seems to support the Administration's hopes that careful diplomatic engagement could encourage steps toward North-South peace.
Ever since the Bush Administration, American policy has been based on the assumption that North Korea fears deeply for its future in a world where it can no longer count on the support of its two giant neighbors, Russia and China, for support. Both of those countries have strengthened their ties with the more prosperous South Korean regime at Pyongyang's expense. North Korea has also been suffering from severe food shortages following two years of disastrous floods.
Washington fears that these adverse developments could tempt Northern leaders into rash military adventures or precipitate a sudden and disastrous economic collapse. But it also believes that careful diplomacy can avert these dangers. That is why, despite the impatience of some critics, Washington has moved deliberately and delicately to reach an accommodation on issues like nuclear safeguards, food assistance and the submarine affair. That strategy has now been rewarded with two quick successes, the submarine apology and the promise of wider talks.
It is important for the two Koreas to build on this week's achievements, the South by moving ahead with food relief and the new nuclear reactors, the North by entering formal peace talks and permanently suspending its propaganda attacks on South Korea and its elected leaders.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Now, What About Lilco's Debt?

 BODY:
The proposed merger of Brooklyn Union Gas and the Long Island Lighting Company should provide Long Island residents some modest financial relief. But those residents will still pay more for their utility bills than most Americans do. The solution to their problem is for state leaders to put aside partisan bickering and agree on a plan that would allow the state to assume Lilco's huge debt.
A merger would allow the companies to cut administrative and other costs. It would also bring Brooklyn Union's highly regarded management skills to bear on Lilco's gas operations. Most experts agree that the merger could produce savings of about $1 billion over 10 years, knocking a few percentage points off utility rates. But the major reason that Long Island rates are high is that Lilco makes exorbitant interest payments on money it borrowed to build a $5.5 billion nuclear plant, Shoreham, which Gov. Mario Cuomo refused to open following intense opposition by nearby residents. 
 The problem could be solved by engaging in what amounts to a legal tax dodge. A state agency, the Long Island Power Authority, would take over part of Lilco. The state-owned utility would no longer pay Federal taxes on income or dividends to shareholders. It could borrow money at tax-free, therefore low, interest rates. Replacing high-cost debt with tax-free debt and other savings would cut utility rates by perhaps 12 percent. In effect, the state would be shifting hundreds of millions of dollars of interest payments each year onto the Federal Treasury.
Democrats and Republicans agree that a partial state takeover is the answer. But some Democratic leaders want the state to take over almost all of Lilco, including its transmission wires and power plants. Under this plan, the newly formed Brooklyn-Lilco would keep only Lilco's gas operations. Republican leaders would transfer control of only Lilco's transmission and distribution facilities, permitting Brooklyn-Lilco to keep Lilco's power plants as well as its gas operations. By controlling the transmission lines, the state could invite utility companies around the country to compete to sell electricity to Long Island customers.
Either plan could work as long as the state makes sure there are additional transmission lines to the Island so that other power companies can compete for business. Once Albany resolves how to take over Lilco's debt payments, then Brooklyn Union and a pared-down Lilco can complete merger plans. But if the companies merge without a state takeover of Lilco's debt, Long Islanders will reap little more than scraps.

HEADLINE: Reports Show New Strength In Economy

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Boding well for continued economic strength in 1997, reports issued yesterday showed consumer confidence at a seven-year high and sales of new homes up sharply.
The Conference Board, a business research group in New York, said its Consumer Confidence Index for December rose 4.3 points from November, to 113.8, its highest level since November 1989, when it reached 115.1.
The Commerce Department reported that sales of new homes surged 14.2 percent in November, the steepest rise in three and a half years.
Both reports were well above economists' expectations.
"Consumers in general are feeling pretty good about the state of the economy," said Gary Thayer, a senior economist at A. G. Edwards & Sons in St. Louis. "That means we should head into next year in pretty good shape."
But bond prices fell sharply on the news, as traders were disappointed by the surprising strength and worried that substantial growth could spur inflationary pressures. The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond, which moves in the opposite direction to the price, rose to 6.64 percent from 6.54 percent on Monday. The drop in bond prices hurt the stock market, and the Dow Jones industrial average tumbled 101.10 points, to 6,448.27.
"All the reports were stronger than expected, and the bond market hates nothing more than growth," said Alan Levenson, a money market economist at UBS Securities Inc.
Measures of consumer confidence are watched closely for indications of future consumer spending, which accounts for about two-thirds of the nation's economy. The report was also one of the earliest economic indicators for December.
The confidence index, calculated from a 1985 base of 100, is derived from responses to questions sent to 5,000 households nationwide, polling them on matters ranging from job availability to home-buying plans.
A separate index showed that consumers' opinions of current business conditions rose to a seven-year high, gaining 3 points from November. Also, their expectations for the next six months climbed 5 points.
In the main index, consumer optimism was widespread across much of the nation, with the biggest gains seen in the Rocky Mountain region. But confidence in New England fell by 20 points in December after showing big gains in the three previous months.
In the report on home sales, the Commerce Department said sales of single-family homes totaled a seasonally adjusted 772,000 annual rate in November, up from a revised 676,000 in October, when sales were initially estimated at a 714,000 rate.
It was the highest level since an 820,000 rate in August and the biggest increase since sales rose 16.6 percent in April 1993. The dip in October had pushed the rate below 700,000 for the first time in 1996.
Each of the four regions of the country -- the Northeast, the South, the Midwest and the West -- shared in the gain, posting double-digit increases, led by a 40.3 percent jump in the Northeast.

HEADLINE: Gabriel Lewis Galindo, 68, Veteran Panamanian Diplomat

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

 BODY:
Gabriel Lewis Galindo, the Panamanian diplomat and businessman who helped negotiate the Panama Canal Treaties, spearheaded efforts to overthrow Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega and served until recently as his country's Foreign Minister, died on Dec. 19 in Denver, where he had been undergoing medical treatment. He was 68 and suffered from fibrosis of the lungs.
Within Panama, Mr. Lewis was regarded as his country's leading expert on foreign policy. But perhaps more than any Latin American diplomat in the last three decades, Mr. Lewis, a round, bald figure with an exuberant nature and a raspy voice, had an understanding of the political process of the United States and how to make it work to his country's benefit. 
 A wealthy member of one of Panama's most prominent families, Mr. Lewis had business interests that included real estate, a bank and a brewery. But when Gen. Omar Torrijos came to power in a coup in 1968, he was one of the few figures from the elite to immediately support the new populist Government, and he quickly became a friend and confidant of General Torrijos.
When Jimmy Carter entered the White House in 1977, General Torrijos appointed Mr. Lewis as Panama's Ambassador to the United States in hopes of reaching an agreement under which Washington would transfer control of the Panama Canal to Panama. Mr. Lewis not only proved to be skilled and imaginative during those negotiations, but his outgoing, back-slapping nature were later credited with winning over several senators who had been dubious about ratifying the resulting treaties.
During the Iranian hostage crisis in 1979, Mr. Lewis again came to the aid of the United States. When the Carter Administration had difficulty finding a country where the Shah of Iran and his family could take refuge, Mr. Lewis, with the approval of General Torrijos, offered his own home on the island of Contadora, where the deposed Iranian ruler remained until just before his death.
But after General Torrijos died in an airplane crash in 1981, Mr. Lewis's relationship with the military dictatorship eventually deteriorated. In 1987, when opposition to General Noriega erupted into civil disobedience and street protests, Mr. Lewis urged the military strongman to resign and fled into exile in the United States after the military responded with threats against his family.
Drawing on his broad network of contacts in Washington, Mr. Lewis soon emerged as the opposition coalition's chief representative abroad. He not only financed some of their activities, but vigorously lobbied State Department officials and members of Congress and the press and devised several ways for the United States to exert economic pressure on Panama, which led the Noriega Government to call for his arrest on charges of treason.
Neverthless, when the Democratic Revolutionary Party, the party of Torrijos and Noriega, returned to power in Panama in September 1994, the new President, Ernesto Perez Balladares, once again turned to Mr. Lewis. Aware that many in the United States were deeply suspicious of the new Government's intentions, the new President named Mr. Lewis Foreign Minister and asked him to repair relations with Washington.
Once again, Mr. Lewis proved skilled in earning Washington's gratitude. In what was almost his first official act, he agreed to allow the United States to intern up to 10,000 Cuban refugees, who had fled their country on rafts a month earlier, in camps in the former Panama Canal Zone until the crisis could be solved.
Thereafter, even as his health was deteriorating, Mr. Lewis devoted much of his time to reassuring Asian and European countries that Panama will be able to manage the Canal once it gains control in 2000 and to discussions with the United States about maintaining a military presence in Panama. But this summer, his illness finally forced him to step down, and he spent most of his last months at his apartment in Miami.
Mr. Lewis is survived by his wife, Nita, six children and 21 grandchildren.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Gabriel Lewis Galindo (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: A Banking Dynasty on the Move;
Spain's Santander Hopes to Become No. 1 in Latin America

BYLINE: By JOHN TAGLIABUE 

DATELINE: MADRID

 BODY:
What Spain's monarchs lost in the 19th century, Emilio and Ana Patricia Botin are determined to reconquer in the waning years of the 20th: Latin America.
Mr. Botin, the 62-year-old chairman of Banco Santander, Spain's biggest bank, is on the move all over the globe. But recognizing that Europe is overbanked and Santander will never be more than a second-tier player in Asia and North America, he is devoting most of his energy to expanding in Spain's former colonies in the Western Hemisphere, where, he believes, Santander has a shot at being No. 1. 
 And, breaking with Spain's patriarchal tradition, Mr. Botin has enlisted Ana Patricia, his 35-year-old American-educated daughter, to help lead the charge. Together, they orchestrated an acquisition binge by Santander throughout Latin America in 1996. In April, the bank paid $495 million for a 51 percent stake in Banco Osorno y La Union, the largest bank in Chile. In October, it took control of Mexico's fourth-largest bank, Banco Mexicano, for $425 million. And just before Christmas, it snapped up a 90 percent share of Banco de Venezuela, that nation's second-largest bank, for $338 million, and simultaneously acquired 55 percent of Banco Comercial Antioqueno of Colombia for $151 million.
While the father-daughter pairing may be unusual for Spain, the lure of Latin America is not. The cream of Spanish business, sensing the same opportunity to exploit cultural and linguistic ties, has been rushing in as governments have liberalized their economies. In recent years, Spain's national telecommunications giant, Telefonica de Espana S.A., has cut a broad swath through the region, forging joint ventures and buying shares of local companies. So have some of the country's biggest television companies, including Television Espanola S.A., one of the world's largest producers of Spanish-language programming.
And other Spanish banks have pushed in hard on Santander's heels. In December, for example, Banco Bilbao Vizcaya, the No. 2 Spanish bank, took over Venezuela's largest bank, Banco Provincial, in a deal worth $300 million.
"Our policy is, ultimately, to have 50 percent of earnings through Latin America," Mr. Botin said over breakfast at the bank's Madrid headquarters. "In 1996, it was near 20 percent, and in 1997 we expect it will be 25 percent; by 1998 and 1999, I hope, it will be 30 percent."
Ana Botin also heads Santander's ambitious push into the highly profitable, if extremely competitive, world of investment banking. There, the Botins hope to carve out a Latin American niche in a business dominated by American and European giants. In just the last five years, investment banking's share of Santander's total net income has climbed to nearly 12 percent from less than 3 percent. Santander has become the No. 1 money-market and pension-fund manager, as well as the leading stockbroker, in several Latin American countries, including Argentina and Chile.
Its New York-based brokerage operation, Santander Investment Securities, ranked second among firms trading in Latin American stocks in the 11 months ended Nov. 30, with nearly 14 percent of the market, after Merrill Lynch, with 16 percent, according to Datablock, a Boston statistics company. In 1995, Santander ranked seventh.
"We like fee income," said Juan Rodriguez Inciarte, the head of Santander's global banking division. "That's the strategic way forward."
Mr. Botin had long been grooming his daughter, one of six children, for a career at Santander, despite Spanish banking's overwhelmingly male culture. He sent her to the United States in the late 1970's to earn a degree in economics at Bryn Mawr College and to put in a seven-year stint at J. P. Morgan, the New York investment bank, specializing in risk management for corporate clients and debt conversion for Latin American governments. In 1988, she left J. P. Morgan to become chief executive of Santander's investment banking subsidiary, from which she has engineered much of the bank's Latin American invasion.
Father and daughter are both dark and handsome, and both are impeccable dressers, but their personal manners differ. He is serene, takes the large, philosophical view and harbors a deep interest in music and art. His wife, Paloma, is an accomplished pianist, and paintings from the family art collection, which he oversees, adorn Santander's headquarters, including a magnificent Holy Family by El Greco, which hangs in the lobby. He is also an avid golfer (though he will not betray his handicap); his youngest daughter, Carmen, is married to Spain's golfing hero, Seve Ballesteros.
Ms. Botin shares many of her father's passions, but unlike him, she is fast talking, hard driving, a good saleswoman -- traits she probably honed at J. P. Morgan. A fluent English speaker who lives in Madrid with her husband, also a Santander banker, and her three children, she travels endlessly, spending lots of time in the financial centers of London and New York but also frequently darting off to Latin America.
Moreover, while Mr. Botin has always been known for his discretion, almost never granting interviews, Ms. Botin is outspoken, publicly declaring that one of Santander's weaknesses may be failure to communicate and make itself better known, for example.
Some bankers say that, like most of Mr. Botin's investments, the bet he placed on his daughter has more than paid off. "She really worked hard, and has very clear ideas, and what's important, she understands Wall Street, which a lot of Europeans don't," said Alberto Sanchez, a former Madrid banker who is now part of the Bear, Stearns emerging markets group in New York. Ms. Botin, he added, "spends a lot of time explaining to colleagues, 'be patient, it's going to cost money'; she knows it."
In some ways, the drive into Latin America represents a return to Santander's past. Founded in 1857 in the northern Spanish port of the same name, the bank cut its teeth financing trade between Spain and its colonies. Mr. Botin's father and grandfather were important shareholders and bank executives.
The family dynasty has flourished even as ownership of the bank has spread outside of Spain, with nearly half the bank's equity now held by foreign shareholders, mainly large British and American funds. Ms. Botin's younger brother is an executive in the commercial banking division, and the chairman's younger brother, Jaime Botin, sits on Santander's board. Jaime Botin is also president of Bankinter, a Spanish retail bank that Santander founded in the 1970's with Bank of America, but is now independent. "People like to say that at Santander, Botin is first, Botin is second, and Botin is third, and that after Botin, there is Ana Botin," said Jesus Rivases Cabbarus, the editor of the financial newspaper Negocios.
That may be something of an exaggeration. In 1996, Mr. Botin hired a powerful outsider, Francisco Luzon, the former head of Argentaria, the Government-controlled banking group, to help formulate Santander's global strategy, and some see him as a possible successor as chairman to Mr. Botin. Asked what Mr. Luzon's future role might be, Mr. Botin replied, "The sky's the limit."
Santander's expansion beyond its borders began in earnest in the 1980's. Awash with profits in Spain's industrial rebirth after the death of the dictator Francisco Franco, and the country's entry into the European Community, Santander first forged a strategic alliance with the Royal Bank of Scotland. In the early 1990's, Mr. Botin set his sights on the United States, acquiring gradually a 23 percent share of First Fidelity, a New Jersey bank. When First Fidelity was snapped up shortly thereafter by First Union of Charlotte, N.C., Mr. Botin was left with a 9 percent share of First Union, and a profit of more than $1 billion.
Santander is also looking to other growing markets. It opened offices in the Philippines in 1996, and Mr. Botin said the company hoped to generate 10 percent of its worldwide revenues in Asia by 2000. In Eastern Europe, it is using its German consumer banking subsidiary, CC Bank, to expand consumer loan services into formerly Communist countries, where consumer demand is vigorous for everything from cars to homes.
Nor is Mr. Botin neglecting the home front. Santander's takeover of Banesto, the troubled Banco Espanol de Credito, in a 1994 deal worth $2 billion nudged it into the position of Spain's market leader. Besides its links with the Bank of Scotland and its flourishing consumer-credit business in Germany, Santander recently acquired a 3 percent stake in Italy's No. 1 bank, Istituto Bancario San Paolo di Torino.
To be sure, the Botins know their global ambitions are not without risks. For all Santander's elevated position in Spain and Latin America, it is a relative dwarf in investment banking. With its limited resources, it must compete against European giants like Union Bank of Switzerland and Deutsche Bank's Deutsche Morgan Grenfell subsidiary, as well as against Wall Street firms like Merrill Lynch, Salomon Brothers and Bear, Stearns. Some of its rivals, in fact, say they doubt Santander's claim that it is making a profit in global investment banking.
Moreover, for all Latin America's recent embrace of democracy and free-market capitalism, many countries remain vulnerable to political instability and economic upheaval. And Jose Sevilla, an analyst at Merrill Lynch in Madrid who follows Santander, said the bank had a big job on its hands in adapting its management style to differing national customs and cultures.
In addition, Mr. Sevilla said, "they have to take a strategic decision about Brazil," a huge and vigorous Portuguese-speaking country where Santander, like many other Spanish banks, remains virtually absent.
Ms. Botin brushes aside such concerns. About six years ago, she said, Santander made a decision to make Latin America its big priority because that is where it holds the best cards. "We have a universal banking approach; we've been in the region for 50 years," she said. "We believe we have key advantages. One of the them is timing, which in these places is critical, since business cycles are much more pronounced. Another is people on the ground.
"Over all," Ms. Botin added, "I personally am very bullish."

HEADLINE: Dow Falls 101, Closing Out A Generally Exuberant Year

BYLINE: By REED ABELSON 

 BODY:
The last day of the year disappointed investors looking for the stock market to end 1996 with a last burst through the finish line.
After sprinting to a record close of 6,560.91 on Friday, the Dow Jones industrial average stumbled backward yesterday, falling 101.10 points, or 1.54 percent, to close at 6,448.27. 
 Concern over the possibility of an overly robust economy and some end-of-the-year selling by investors helped push the Dow down.
While small-company and many technology stocks managed to avoid much of yesterday's retreat, large-capitalization stocks like General Electric, which fell $2.75, or 2.7 percent, and I.B.M., which dropped $2.125, or 1.4 percent, gave up ground.
News of stronger-than-expected sales of new homes and high levels of consumer confidence caused some investors to worry about the coming year and whether it would bring higher inflation and interest rates, which hurt both stocks and bonds. Yesterday, the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond fell 19/32 points, its yield rising to 6.64 percent.
Many investors also ushered 1996 out by tidying up their portfolios, either closing out their positions or doing some last-minute selling for tax purposes.
While few market watchers put too much emphasis on the activity of the last two days, investors have little reason to look at 1996 with anything but appreciation. Leading the way, the Dow gained 26 percent in the last 12 months. The Standard & Poor's 500 index, a broader measure of big-company stocks, was up 20 percent for the year, while the Nasdaq composite index rose nearly 23 percent.
"Basically, the year was one when almost everything went right for the equity market," said Arthur A. Micheletti, chief economic and investment strategist for Bailard, Biehl & Kaiser, a money management firm in San Mateo, Calif.
The combination of strong corporate earnings early in the year and faith in interest rates remaining low sent many stocks into record territory. Proving the caution of some forecasters wrong, the market's stellar performance also came on the heels of an even stronger year in 1995. The S.& P. 500's back-to-back gain of roughly 54 percent is a performance not experienced in decades, according to Arnold Kaufman, editor of the Standard & Poor's Outlook newsletter. The index returned 51 percent in 1975-1976 and 71 percent in 1954-1955.
This year's market has been adept at defying skeptics. After shrugging off summer doldrums, stocks have made substantial gains over the last three months. The Dow has returned 9.6 percent since Sept. 30, with stocks like Philip Morris, American Express and I.B.M. posting returns above 20 percent. Even the jitters caused earlier last month by remarks by Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, seem to have been forgotten as investors who continue to put money into the market after declines are rewarded. "It has reinforced investor confidence," Mr. Kaufman said.
Not everybody had as much reason to celebrate, of course. Large-company stocks were the clear favorites during the year as investors sought the security and safety of well-known names in large multinational companies like Coca-Cola as protection against the whims of the economy. Small stocks, as measured by the Russell 2000 index, fared less well after this summer's downturn. The Russell ended 1996 up 14.76 percent, to close at 362.61 -- near where it was trading in May.
The year's exuberance has made some pause and wonder. "Investors have to be very happy," Mr. Kaufman said. "They're surprised, shocked and a little concerned because they didn't expect this and don't know what to make of it."
And as they did at the end of 1995, some experts are warning investors not to expect more of the same. The last decade has blessed stocks with all the right ingredients: the slashing of interest rates and inflation, tax-cutting and the fattening of corporate profit margins, Mr. Micheletti noted, adding, "A lot of forces behind the bull market are mature, long in tooth and unlikely to repeat."
Still, investors may not want to make the kind of contrarian bets that have paid off in the past. While some are betting on a resurgence in smaller stocks, which showed some signs of occurring early in December, these stocks may not be outperformers in 1997.
"The economy is brutal in terms of competitiveness," said Thomas McManus, a strategist for Morgan Stanley & Company, who cautions investors not to discount the strength of large companies, which have proved more profitable than some of their smaller counterparts.
The market's future remains murky even as yesterday's decline was a reminder of just how anxious investors are. While some forecasters say the economy could heat up enough to warrant interest-rate increases by the Federal Reserve, others are convinced that the economy is slowing down. "People have been swinging back and forth on the economy," Mr. Kaufman said.
Among individual issues yesterday, shares of the Zitel Corporation, which plunged on Monday, rebounded slightly. The stock gained 3 3/8, to 44 3/8. Zitel, a software company, had risen last month, partly because of speculation that the financier George Soros was buying shares.
Gillette rose 2 1/8, to 77 3/4, a day after shareholders approved the company's purchase of Duracell International. Yesterday, Merrill Lynch repeated a "buy" recommendation on Gillette shares.
Olympic Steel surged 2, to 25 3/8. The company was named the "single best idea" for investors by Prudential Securities, which raised its 12-month price target to $52 a share from $42 previously.

HEADLINE: Girls in White Dresses;
The Debutante Returns, With Pearls and Plans

BYLINE: By MONIQUE P. YAZIGI 

 BODY:
The invitation to the International Debutante Ball was addressed to Mr. and Mrs. David Eisenhower. Tucked into a pink envelope with silver writing, it rekindled bright memories for Julie Nixon Eisenhower, who recalls her sleeveless white dress, her long kid gloves, the series of deb "pre-parties" and, most of all, her date: David, the grandson of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, a young man she had met as a child playing in the White House.
"He was dating other people at college," she said. "I knew we'd generate a lot of publicity and he knew if he accepted he was basically burning all his bridges with the others." 
 Despite the invitation's Proustian quality, Mrs. Eisenhower did not even think to ask Jennie, her daughter, an 18-year-old freshman and theater arts major at Northwestern, if she wanted to participate.
"I never thought she'd want to do this," she said.
She was wrong. Jennie loved the idea. And so Ms. Eisenhower became part of a wave of young women between the ages of 17 and 22 who have spent the last several months attending gown fittings (mostly at Vera Wang and Bergdorf Goodman), lining up escorts, sitting for Bachrach portraits and ordering engraved calling cards. All to partake in this year's debutante season, which started at Thanksgiving and runs through this week in New York City.
Hard to imagine, but being a debutante is back. Cotillion chairmen in New York say they have not seen this many young women participate in a decade. Popular in the 1950's, the debutante ball fell on hard times in the 60's, sustained mostly by Southerners ("I came out in the 60's -- my mother insisted -- but I went barefoot in protest," said Kathleen S. Bingham of North Carolina, whose daughter, Sarah Stroh, was presented at this year's International).
There was a comeback in the boom of the 80's, but then a backlash, due in part to the quest for publicity by the socialite Cornelia Guest, who took the title Deb of the Year and, many felt, made a mockery of the institution.
But, in contrast to the excess spending of the 80's, when the debutantes were "overdone," with lavish dresses and huge diamonds around their necks, this time the entry is more subtle, the gowns are simpler (of imported silk and lace), and what looks like grandmother's pearls are back around the girls' necks.
Some say all this is tied to the economy, others say it is a yearning for a romantic period, as the end of the century approaches, and still others see the return of the cotillion as a quest for civility.
"It's fine that she has a career, but I want her to have some polish -- it just makes life more pleasant," said Christian Swiers, the mother of a debutante, also named Christian, who was being presented at the International on Saturday night.
Based on an 18th-century English ritual of families introducing their young daughters, all primped and proper, into a class-restricted marriage market, the balls have become, in recent decades, more of a networking tool for parents to socially connect (and escalate) both their daughters and themselves.
"It's just like pre-school in New York," said Margaret Hedberg, the director of the International Ball, whose aunt founded it in 1954. "It's not about the kids, it's about the parents."
And there are plenty of opportunities for the parents to connect, with a lot more daughters of doctors and small businessmen mingling with the old-money progeny, although the cost for a single event can run over $10,000.
"In the past, there would have been an almost perfect congruent, everyone would know each other," said Nelson W. Aldrich Jr., author of "Old Money: The Mythology of America's Upper Class" (Knopf). "It was a seamless texture of life from the summer place to the school to the parties on the holidays back to the summer place. "Money and desire seem to be the prime determinant here. Now there are no reliable indicators of social or economic status except perhaps for your income tax return."
As Mrs. Eisenhower remembers 1966, two years before her father became President: "Though my father was in politics, we would have never gotten into the other New York balls. We were from Whittier, Calif. Those others were always so closed to anyone who wasn't from old New York families."
Leading up to the International ball, starting the day after Thanksgiving, there were pre-parties, after-parties, lunches, brunches and teas all over town, including the suites of the Waldorf-Astoria, where most guests took rooms.
Then there was the ball.
At the grand ballroom of the Waldorf, 800 guests dressed in black tie greeted the 36 debutantes lined up in the Basildon room of the hotel for two and a half hours.
Mr. and Mrs. Eisenhower stood at the head of the line with their daughter, while the other debutantes stood in place around the room. It was a sea of white silk, Shantung and tulle. Each guest met each deb, shaking their white gloved hands as they introduced themselves.
"Hi, I'm Sarah Stroh from New York City, so nice to meet you," Ms. Stroh said, over and over and over. The debs smiled the entire time and kept up those firm handshakes.
As her mother had done before her, Ms. Stroh took off her shoes. "We all did, we figured no one was going to see our feet," she said, adding that the gesture was about hurt feet and not about making a political statement.
Then it was on to dinner, debutantes with their two escorts (one military, in uniform, and one civilian, in white tie and tails) on the balconies, guests seated around the dance floor. Champagne was flowing, filet de boeuf was served and business cards were flying. The premiere society band leader, Lester Lanin, did not take a break for six hours, passing out his signature hats periodically.
Curtsies were practiced everywhere: in the bathroom, in the hallways, even on the steps. When the debs are presented to the room, each one is expected to curtsy twice.
Texas debutantes have the hardest job. Tradition calls for them to perform the Texas dip, a to-the-floor curtsy with a bow of the head that could certainly topple a nervous deb.
From 11 P.M. to midnight, the debs were presented. No one toppled, though one cadet did faint from standing too straight for too long under the lights.
Each deb walked across the dance floor with her two escorts by her side. The announcer stated the names of the parents and the deb and where they were from. She curtsied as she entered and again as she completed the walk. Her civilian escort brought her up to the stage, while her military escort walked off to the side holding the flag of her state or country.
Ms. Eisenhower went first. Her curtsy seemed extra special: she added a bow of the head after dipping smoothly to the floor.
"A former debutante just taught me that trick in the bathroom," she said. "Since I have a full dress on I didn't have to cross my legs in the back. I just went straight back with my leg and no one could notice. Then she told me to add that head bow at the end.
"I'm so happy I got through it," she said, holding onto the arm of her civilian escort, Dante Bradley.
Ms. Eisenhower attended her senior prom with Mr. Bradley, who is a pre-medical student at Villanova and also her boyfriend of nine months. But for the debs without boyfriends, at this ball the dates are assigned -- by committee. An escort who does a good job is called a "Deb's Delight" and is invited back, party after party.
One escort, Graham Stroh, a 21-year-old sophomore at Bard College and the brother of Sarah Stroh, had mixed feelings about participating in his second ball.
"Well, I wasn't completely into it, though I have to admit it was fun," he said. "People are always worried about how other people will see them. You're almost a little afraid to tell them that you're doing this deb thing. It's so far from what you consider right.
"If you look at it as a major kind of aristocratic and exclusive thing, which in some cases it is, then it's horrible, if you look at it that you're meeting people from around the world that you'd never normally meet, then it's O.K."
Some New York cotillions do still have heavier social requirements, much like Park Avenue co-op boards, with finicky committee members choosing (carefully) who will be allowed to make her debut at their cotillion. But connections can be worked.
And is it all worth it?
Christopher Forbes, who held the pre-cocktail party for the International at the Forbes Magazine Gallery with his niece Catherine Forbes, encouraged both his daughter Charlotte, who is a senior at Princeton, and his niece to "come out."
"I launched them two years ago," said Mr. Forbes, the son of the late Malcolm Forbes. "It was a great way for them to meet people and to be introduced around."
Did they meet anyone?
"Oh, Charlotte met someone at school -- she actually spent Christmas with his family," he said, clenching his teeth.
But, marriage is not what this is all about, insisted Mrs. Hedberg, the head of the International.
"For this to be a marriage market now," she said, "we'd have to do this when the girls are in their 30's."
 
Five New York Debutante Parties
 
DEBUTANTE COTILLION AND CHRISTMAS BALL, called the Infirmary, Waldorf-Astoria: Combination of Old New York, Greenwich, Conn., Tuxedo Park, N.Y., and certain New Jersey suburbs. Debutantes have to perform intricate cotillion figures while carrying candles and singing Christmas songs.

MAYFLOWER BALL, Plaza Hotel: Debutantes must be descendants of those who arrived on the Mayflower. And she cannot just say she is; she must have the paper work. Some years, this ball presents only one or two debutantes.

JUNIOR ASSEMBLY, Plaza Hotel: Old New York family ball. This one is like a country club party. Debutantes are not presented. They just get up and dance with their fathers, because everyone is expected to know everyone else. This one is not about wealth so much as social connections.
INTERNATIONAL DEBUTANTE BALL, Waldorf-Astoria: This one is the most democratic. Debutantes range from French princesses to daughters of small businessmen. Girls are presented with two escorts, one military and one civilian.

JUNIOR LEAGUE, Plaza Hotel: Mothers are members and basically bring their daughters into the league with this party. But the league does not like to use the words cotillion or debutante, calling it a winter dance instead. Girls are presented, and this year carried big green feathered fans.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Consumer Confidence And Home Sales Surge
Exceeding economists' expectations and boding well for a strong 1997, consumer confidence surged to a seven-year high in December, and sales of new homes showed their steepest advance in three and a half years during November.
The Conference Board said its consumer confidence index rose 4.3 points, to 113.8. The Commerce Department said home sales surged 14.2 percent. [62.]
 
Concern over the possibility of an overly robust economy, as well as end-of-the-year selling by investors, caused stocks to plunge. The Dow Jones industrials fell 101.10 points, or 1.54 percent, to close at 6,448.27. But the index still rose 26 percent for the year. [65.]
 
Bond prices fell sharply, ending a year in which they dropped during much of the first six months, recovered most of their losses and then turned down again. The 30-year bond yield rose to 6.64 percent from 6.54 percent. The yield ended the year nearly three-quarters of a percentage point higher than the level, 5.96 percent, at which it started the year. [64.]
 
Underwriting Roars Back in Quarter
Stock and bond underwriting roared back in the year's final quarter, despite a somewhat hesitant beginning, to end a year that left many on Wall Street rubbing their eyes in disbelief. During the quarter, the securities industry underwrote $251.6 billion worth of domestic debt and equity issues, Securities Data said. That was a 22.5 percent rise from the third quarter and a 29.2 percent gain from a year earlier. [64.]
 
Lilco Stock Windfall Possible
Long Island Lighting shareholders will get a stock price bonus if the state takes over $4.5 billion in debt for the company's defunct Shoreham nuclear plant, according to Lilco's merger agreement with Brooklyn Union Gas. If the bonus is included, analysts said, Lilco owners are likely to see their long-troubled stock rise a third in value. [45.]
 
Northeast Utilities has mismanaged its nuclear plants for a decade, and if the company cannot turn its operations around in the next year, it may not survive, an audit ordered by Connecticut indicated. [45.]
 
Heating and Crude Oil Prices Up
With freezing temperatures and snow blanketing much of Europe, the prices of heating oil and crude oil jumped in a shortened session on expectations that higher European prices could reduce American supplies. Natural gas and copper prices also rose. [71.]
 
British Pound at Four-Year High
Demand surged for the British pound, which hit a four-year high of $1.7125. The dollar's rally against the Japanese yen faltered in thin trading, with the dollar settling at 115.93 yen, down from 116.15 yen on Monday. [71.]
 
Fraud Accusation Against Schott
Marge Schott, whose ethnic comments have undermined her position as managing partner of the Cincinnati Reds baseball team, faces potentially more serious trouble over accusations of fraudulent sales reports that General Motors has lodged against her concerning actions at her Chevrolet-Geo dealership. [58.]
 
Travel Costs Expected to Rise
Travel industry consultants see higher 1997 costs. They expect hotel rates to climb 5 percent, domestic air fares to go up 5 percent, international fares 7 percent, and car-rental rates to rise 4 percent to 5 percent. They also see more women and more upper-echelon executives on the road. Business Travel. [63.]
 
A Call for Belt-Tightening
French and German leaders urged their restive citizens to keep making sacrifices so their countries could meet increasingly tough global economic competition. [4.]

SECTION: Section 1; Page 1; Column 3; Foreign Desk 

LENGTH: 1230 words

HEADLINE: Reporter's Notebook;
Islamic Militancy vs. Money-Making in Iran

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO 

DATELINE: ISFAHAN, Iran

 BODY:
Isfahan, wrote Jean Chardin, the 17th-century French traveler, "was expressly made for the delights of love."
With its richly decorated domes and lush gardens, the royal city is a sensual delight, a place where shifting light and shadow caress the turquoise-and-cream-colored tiles of the mosques and where long arcades and soaring vaults spellbind even the most jaded tourist. 
 It is the splendor of Persian treasures like Isfahan, 200 miles south of Teheran, that Iran has begun to use to lure foreign tourists.
As part of its campaign, Iran announced last August that it would issue visas within 24 hours to foreigners seeking to visit the country. Even Americans, with a bit of persistence and pull, can get a visa within two weeks, although the State Department's official warning on Iran urges Americans to stay out "because of the generally anti-American atmosphere and Iranian Government hostility to the U.S. Government."
But nearly a generation after the ayatollahs seized the palaces of kings, Iran is still locked in a fierce and bitter struggle over how hospitable it should be to the non-Muslim world.
Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, the revolution's late spiritual leader, used to rant about "the Western sickness among us." But the reality is that in a country with raging inflation, 20 percent unemployment and little foreign investment, hard currency counts. And tourists from places like Germany and Japan spend more than twice as much money as devout pilgrims from other Islamic countries.
With rulings that ban alcohol, forbid any display of affection among nonmarried couples and require women to cover their heads with scarves and wear clothing that hides the curves of their bodies, it is not all that easy being a tourist in Iran.
"I'm incredibly hot," complained one middle-aged female British teacher dressed in a flowered kerchief and long wool coat, who was part of an organized group of British high school students touring Isfahan. "Our guide keeps telling me to pull my scarf down over my hair, and I keep pushing it back."
Another obviously foreign female visitor who tried to check into a hotel with a man who was not her spouse (separate rooms, of course) was greeted with a look of terror by the receptionist at the front desk.
In the holy city of Qum, women dressed in scarves and trench coats but not the standard long black chador are such a curiosity that they can stop traffic. And the men of Qum -- even the turbaned clerics -- do not lower their gaze as required by a strict interpretation of Islam when the women walk by.
Not all of Iran is ready for a foreign invasion. In the southern city of Kerman, the public baths tucked away in the 300-year-old bazaar do not beckon. The colored tiles are broken; paintings on the ceilings are largely worn away. Floors are grimy; there are more cockroaches than bathers in the changing rooms.

Scoring a Caviar Connection
There was a time, in the days before Iran's revolution, when the thing to do on a sleepy afternoon in Teheran was to lunch at Leon's -- the upscale Russian restaurant in the heart of the capital that served double orders of rich beluga on paper-thin blinis accompanied by a bottle of Russian vodka encased in ice.
But Leon's closed soon after the Government turned Islamic. And since then, Iran's caviar market has been rocked by pollution, corruption and the disintegration of the Soviet Union. Poachers in the four former Soviet republics bordering the Caspian Sea that produce 90 percent of the world's black caviar are both overfishing the sturgeon and saturating the market with caviar of questionable quality.
To make matters worse for Iran, the Caspian Sea has been rising for more than a decade, submerging hatcheries and blocking the sturgeons' spawning areas.
Since Iran exports most of its caviar for hard currency, there is none in the markets of Teheran these days and few of the better hotels and restaurants that list caviar on their menus actually stock it.
This scarcity has created a cottage industry for middlemen, who turn up at embassies and businesses with sacks full of contraband small-grained sevruga, at considerable risk, for as little as $80 a pound. "Caviar," said a food dealer in one market, "is more dangerous to sell than heroin."
One European ambassador acknowledges that he sometimes expedites tourist visa requests for his caviar vendor and his family. "He gets the papers he needs from the Embassy," the Ambassador said. "We get the caviar."

Uncle Sam Slips Through
The hunger in Iran for things Western, particularly American, seems insatiable -- from books and videos to clothing and foodstuffs.
The Clinton Administration's economic embargo against Iran has not made American goods disappear, just made them more expensive. Under Iranian customs regulations, Iranians entering the country are allowed to bring in one appliance, which has led to a lively importation of items like refrigerators. In a country where a mid-ranking civil servant's salary is less than $200 a month, a 27-cubic-foot General Electric refrigerator costs more than $5,000, a slightly used General Electric washing machine about $1,200.
In the Behjeatabad indoor food market in central Teheran, L'Oreal hair spray and a small jar of six German sausages sell for about $18 apiece, a bar of Dove soap for $4.
The Iranian Government remains deeply uncomfortable with foreign influences. Parliament recently passed a law banning Iranian companies from using Western names, and there is a move to purge the Farsi language of English words.
But schoolchildren routinely study English as their second language. English words (computer, fax, electronic, mechanic, secular, program, police, fluorescent, telephone, intellectual) are hard to translate. And a typical English lesson in the English-language daily, the Iran News, illustrates the pervasiveness of American culture: "A dime is an American coin. A dime is equal to ten cents. Ten dimes are equal to one dollar."

Freedoms That Come and Go
Iran is a country of fitful repression and unsettling unpredictability intended to keep the clergy in power and the population at bay.
Since last spring's parliamentary elections, the Government has tightened restrictions on the media and book publishing, intensified its confiscation of illegal satellite dishes and pressured artists and writers with arrests and ominous denunciations on television.
The system is still loose enough that Iranians routinely hold parties where women wear no veils and Armenian-made vodka flows freely. But many outspoken Iranians who have felt a layer of protection under the anarchy that has pervaded the country since the revolution suddenly have begun to ask foreign visitors not to call them at home.
Even diplomats are not immune. Last summer a dozen security police from the Ministry of Security and Information broke up a dinner party for six Iranian writers and intellectuals held by Jens Gust, the German Embassy's cultural and press attache. Mr. Gust was not allowed to call his embassy; the guests were interrogated and jailed for the night.
The Foreign Ministry apologized the next day; Germany, which as Iran's largest trading partner and closest friend in the West, is reluctant to antagonize the Iranians, responded by temporarily reassigning Mr. Gust to Bonn.

HEADLINE: Iran Contributed $500,000 to Bosnian President's Election Effort, U.S. Says

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31

 BODY:
Even as the United States was trying to roll back Iran's influence with the Muslim-led Government of Bosnia, Iran contributed at least $500,000 last summer to boost the election campaign of Bosnia's President, Alija Izetbegovic, Administration officials said today.
The contributions, delivered by the Iranians in at least two suitcases full of cash, came on the eve of the national elections in September, in which Mr. Izetbegovic won a seat on the three-member presidency that is now to govern Bosnia after four years of war, the officials said. 
 The Central Intelligence Agency informed the White House and the State Department about the contributions shortly after they occurred around June, the officials said, speaking on condition of anonymity. But the Administration concluded they did not explicitly violate Bosnia's pledges to sever ties with Iran as part of the peace accords negotiated in 1995 in Dayton, Ohio.
The Administration was nonetheless troubled enough that it raised its objections directly with Mr. Izetbegovic, the officials said. One declined to discuss Mr. Izetbegovic's reaction except to say, "He got our point."
The campaign contributions, first reported in the Los Angeles Times today, provided still more evidence of Iran's efforts to influence the Muslim-led Government, which relied heavily on Iranian military assistance, arms and even troops during its civil war with the Bosnian Serbs and Croats.
Iran's presence in Bosnia has exposed President Clinton to sharp criticism, particularly from Republicans on Capitol Hill, who have argued that the Administration opened the door for Iran when it decided not to object to the flow of Iranian arms into Bosnia in 1994 in violation of an arms embargo.
Officials at the State Department and the C.I.A. said today that Mr. Izetbegovic's Government was now complying with its commitments to end military and intelligence cooperation with the Islamic Government in Iran. But the State Department acknowledged that cultural, economic and diplomatic relations, highlighted by the campaign contributions, continued despite repeated American protests.
John R. Dinger, a spokesman at the State Department, said that the United States strongly objected to any relations with Iran, which it brands an outlaw nation that sponsors terrorism.
Mr. Dinger said the United States would "remain watchful" of economic and diplomatic contacts between it and Bosnia.
"We clearly object to any ties with Iran, cultural or economic, as we would with any country," Mr. Dinger said. "But fundamentally we have to leave that to the Bosnian Government to decide."
Mr. Dinger and a spokesman for the C.I.A., David Christian, declined to discuss the campaign contributions, saying it was an intelligence matter. But the officials who spoke on condition of anonymity said they were an example of Iran's continuing efforts to aid the Muslims in Bosnia.
It was not clear how the money was used in the campaign or whether it had any real impact, since Mr. Izetbegovic handily won the seat in the three-member presidency set aside for a Muslim.
During the last year, the United States has pressed the Government in Sarajevo to end its cooperation with Iran. In June, President Clinton certified that Bosnia had cut off Iran's supply of arms and expelled thousands of Islamic guerrillas who fought beside Bosnia's army, clearing the way for some $200 million in aid for training and equipment.
In October, the Administration held up $100 million worth of tanks and other weapons intended for the military of the Bosnia and Croat Federation until Mr. Izetbegovic dismissed his Deputy Minister of Defense, Hasan Cengic. The Administration accused Mr. Cengic, a fervent Muslim nationalist and friend of the President, of having very close ties to Iran. Mr. Izetbegovic eventually dismissed him a month later.
Those steps have persuaded the Administration that Mr. Izetbegovic had carried out his pledges, although it has acknowledged in the past that some of the foreign volunteers have settled in Bosnia. "The analysis indicates that Iranian arms shipments have stopped and that military and intelligence links have been broken," Mr. Christian, the spokesman at the C.I.A., said today.
At the same time, Iran appears eager to maintain a presence in Bosnia. It has an embassy in Bosnia, and, as one official put it, "they do try to make diplomatic and cultural inroads."
The United States, the official and others said, continues to raise its objections with Mr. Izetbegovic, through diplomatic channels and through a commission it created with the Bosnian Government last fall as a forum to address its concerns.
"It's a serious problem," one official said. "It's one that we have addressed and continue to address."

HEADLINE: It's Jan. 1? Where Could Clintons Be?

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: HILTON HEAD, S.C., Dec. 31

 BODY:
Why, for the love of Pete, does President Clinton keep coming back to "Renaissance Weekend," the annual, deeply earnest, invitation-only intellectual and spiritual chaternalia held during the New Year's holiday?
Participants are assigned to read Kierkegaard and Pascal for half-day seminars devoted even on sun-kissed days to topics like "Moral Compasses for Modern Leaders." (Mr. Clinton arrived the day after that one.) They cluster indoors late into the night, listening to mild jokes about aging -- when you're 91, why go outside when there's the Weather Channel? -- while their adolescent offspring, giggling and unchaperoned, pile into the steaming whirlpool. The adults are seen wearing loafers when they walk on the beach. 
 And they unwind by networking, a pursuit from which Mr. Clinton, having just nailed his second Presidential election, can surely afford to retire as world champion.
Oh, sure, there's golf. In fact, when Mr. Clinton arrived on Monday afternoon, he headed straight for the links without stopping at the beachfront home he is borrowing here.
But Mr. Clinton, fellow weekenders say, also prizes the retreat for what Philip Lader -- who founded it in 1981 with his wife, Linda LeSourd Lader -- calls its commitment "to the premise of the incredible transforming power of ideas and relationships."
This is Mr. Clinton's 13th Renaissance Weekend, and as usual he came with his wife, Hillary, and their daughter, Chelsea. At a dinner on Monday night, he stayed until midnight, chatting with all comers, said participants and White House staff.
This morning, Mr. and Mrs. Clinton spent more than an hour in a panel discussion on "Spiritual Life in a Secular Society." The Clintons just listened, people who were present said.
The panelists included Rabbi Harold S. Kushner, author of "When Bad Things Happen to Good People," and Sister Charlotte Rose Kerr, identified in the official program as a "Catholic nun/acupuncturist."
Some 450 families are attending Renaissance Weekend, the overwhelming majority of them repeat visitors like the Clintons. The weekend costs $550 for a family and $500 for a couple, not including lodging. The Laders run four such weekends a year.
Guests may choose among 311 panel discussions or seminars running from 8 A.M. to 11:30 P.M. Described as generally freewheeling, they range from "Skepticism and Faith" to "Money Matters" to "What I've Learned About Love," with panelists drawn from the guest list. Children can attend the adult panels or ones designed for them, like "How Grade-A Professionals Can Avoid F's as Parents."
Outside the panels, the attendees bunch in hotel hallways and restaurants, throwing off conversational sparks that titillate uninitiated passers-by.
Urgent, booming voice: "Religion in the schools, prayer, teen-age pregnancy!"
Milder, slightly awed voice: "It's funny how we all come from immigrants in this country."
Agitated voice: "AND I'm supposed to have a book done by May."
Q: "Did you know all that stuff?"
A: "Kind of."
Much is made of the absence of titles and formality among the distinguished guests. From toddlers up, all but Mr. Clinton wear names tags on loops around their necks, presenting a first name in large letters and the second name in much smaller ones (BUD Zumwalt, for example, on the chest of Adm. Elmo R. Zumwalt, the former Chief of Naval Operations).
Many see the sessions as a model for the country.
"Renaissance captures the civil discourse that ought to be normative in America at large," said Tony Campolo, president of the Evangelical Association for Promotion of Education.
The attendees include Lady Bird Johnson; Gail Sheehy, the author; Ron Silver, the actor; Stephen L. Carter, the Yale law professor, and Jim Rogers, the investment adviser.
It is a crowd where Barbra Streisand could be found empathizing with Senator Larry Pressler about his recent election defeat. Mr. Pressler said Ms. Streisand cited the setbacks suffered by the heroine of her recent movie, "The Mirror Has Two Faces."
Mr. Pressler, a frequent participant over the years, confessed to doing a little networking of his own this time.
"I'm looking for a job," he said. But the South Dakotan added that networking was far from his chief goal. "You have to be kind of a semi-searcher for the truth," he said.
The panels are all off-the-record. But many journalists are attending the retreat, including Thomas Edsall of The Washington Post, Paul Goldberger of The New York Times, and several from the newsmagazines.
On Monday morning, Jonathan Alter, the Newsweek columnist, was spotted trying to talk Clay Felker, the founder of New York magazine, into attending a panel on charter schools. They went to one on the budget instead, with such high-profile panelists as Joseph E. Stiglitz, Mr. Clinton's outgoing head of the Council of Economic Advisers, and Lawrence H. Summers, the deputy secretary of the Treasury. Mr. Alter cheerfully explained that, while the sessions are off-the-record, he got valuable story ideas from them.
Other journalists seem less comfortable discussing their presence here.
"No comment," said Howard Fineman, also of Newsweek, when asked if he was enjoying the conference. But as he walked away, Mr. Fineman allowed over his shoulder that he was having a good time.
Mr. Lader said that the weekend retreats -- which often, like this one, spill into midweek -- help the high-achieving attendees put their lives in perspective. Many of them, he said, juggle many balls, most of which are made of rubber and bounce if dropped.
"But some of the balls -- marriage, family, health, faith -- are made of crystal, and if you drop one of those balls it might crash and be lost forever," continued Mr. Lader, who is Mr. Clinton's administrator of the Small Business Administration. "Renaissance Weekend is an opportunity for gifted people who are very busy to spend time learning from each other, to help think through on their own and to reflect on which of the balls are made of rubber and which are made of glass."

GRAPHIC: Photo: President Clinton, in South Carolina for the Renaissance Weekend, waited to tee off yesterday at the Old Tabby Links on Spring Island. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Safe and Sound

BYLINE: By James Chace; James Chace teaches international relations at Bard College and is the editor of the World Policy Journal at the New School.

 BODY:
The hallmark of the Clinton Administration's foreign policy over the past two years has been the low cost and low risks of its activism. Although critics charge that the Administration is prone to dangerous, wholesale interventions, a close look at the record shows that the military operations it has initiated have been discretionary and largely successful.
In Haiti, Bosnia, Macedonia and the Taiwan Strait, the use of limited force for limited ends was the correct approach for a great power to take. A selectively activist foreign policy -- the approach advocated by Secretary of State-designate Madeleine Albright -- has generally proved to be the most effective way of achieving American goals. 
 Such success seemed unlikely just two years ago. In the crises that faced the new Administration -- most of them legacies of the Bush years -- the Clinton national security team appeared hesitant and uncertain. There was the embarrassing initial aborted landing in Haiti, while in Bosnia the Administration at first threatened to use air power and to arm the Bosnian Muslims before it had a comprehensive plan.
Moreover, the Administration was stifled by Gen. Colin Powell, who as chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff was consistently unwilling to deploy American troops abroad except in overwhelming numbers, making any mission politically infeasible. It was not until General Powell retired in 1993 that the Pentagon could be counted on to provide forces commensurate with American goals.
Then the Clinton foreign policy started to take hold. In the three most difficult cases inherited from the Bush years -- Somalia, Haiti and Bosnia -- Mr. Clinton succeeded in furthering American interests without locking us into a military quagmire.
In Somalia, where President Bush had committed troops even though it was of no strategic importance, Mr. Clinton had to find a way to withdraw. It was a messy operation -- 18 American soldiers died -- but it removed the issue from the agenda.
The United States invasion of Haiti in September, 1994, made possible a free election. It is a shaky democracy, but it is better than anything Haitians have known in their tragic history. No one is being murdered by government thugs, and the corrupt old guard is in exile in the nightclubs of Panama City.
After the deployment of 30,000 troops, the uncertain peace negotiated by the Clinton Administration endures in Bosnia. Yes, Defense Secretary William Perry has announced that about 7,500 American soldiers will have to stay in the region well beyond the deadline originally set for December. But it is only because of the American presence in Bosnia that a long-term settlement has even a prayer of coming to pass.
And a few hundred United States troops insured that Serbian expansion did not extend into Macedonia, a strategically important fledgling nation.
American gunboat diplomacy defused the crisis in the Taiwan Strait in the spring of 1996 when the Chinese were conducting missile tests off Taiwan's shores. By sending the warships, President Clinton reassured the Japanese that the United States was an ally to be counted on and respected. Shortly thereafter, Tokyo backed off its threat to kick the American military out of bases in Japan and Okinawa.
To build on these triumphs and define a foreign policy for the next decade will mean dealing with more than the debris of the cold war. It will also require more than brandishing high-tech weaponry and airlifting troops to troubled regions. The United States must face up to the issues of growing global economic inequities, cultural and religious attacks on modernity, looming environmental disasters, terrorism and a world financial economy increasingly beyond the control of traditional nation-states.
We will surely not be able to solve these problems alone; only a truly internationalist foreign policy -- not an isolationist one nor a unilateral one -- could even come close to doing so.
Nonetheless, there will be occasions for the use of limited force for limited ends, and an American foreign policy team that vacillates over the use of United States armed forces would undermine our power to further larger strategic goals. Of course, it would be equally dangerous to stage an ideological, neo-Wilsonian campaign to be the world's policeman enforcing a Pax Americana.
Ms. Albright would do well to follow the tradition of pragmatic realism as forged by two of her most illustrious predecessors, John Quincy Adams, architect of the Monroe Doctrine, and Dean Acheson, who established the cold war policy of containment. Her record suggests that she understands this tradition of activism at its most sophisticated and unhesitating.

SECTION: Section C; Page 6; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk
