HEADLINE: OUTLOOK '97: ECONOMY & INDUSTRY;
Expansion Control Helps Smooth Airlines' Wild Earnings Ride

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT 

 BODY:
The airline industry has made remarkable progress in recent years in smoothing out its historically wide-swinging business cycle. For a lot of consumers, that is too bad.
After all, it has long been one of the industry's failings that in good times, the airlines as a group would order far more aircraft than they really needed. By the time the planes were delivered, traffic growth had typically fallen off, leaving too many planes for too few passengers. And because an empty seat is worthless to the airlines, they would start bruising fare wars -- to the cheers of travelers -- to fill their seats. 
 The most recent such bonanza occurred in the summer of 1992, when airlines cut fares as much as 50 percent on many routes.
That fare sale and the effects of the Persian Gulf war on oil prices and travel were some of the many problems that contributed to the American airline industry's cumulative losses of more than $13 billion between 1990 and 1994.
These losses apparently taught the industry a lesson about overexpansion: Profits are more important than market share. It was an obvious lesson in hindsight, but required the airlines to discard a long-cherished notion that size and market share were the paths to profits.
After a couple of years with a good economy and the tight control maintained by airlines over the number of seats in the market, the industry is expected to report record profits for 1996. This discipline has given the airlines a rare ability to set fares at profitable levels.
This means that fares have been going up. Tom Parsons, editor of Best Fares magazine, keeps a running tally of fare increases, and said that the industry had raised fares more than 35 times since 1992. Now, those same round-trip tickets for flights between New York and the West Coast that sold for less than $200 in 1992 cost at least twice that much, even at sale prices.
Mr. Parsons said that fare increases could be attributed to more than tighter airline capacity and a healthy economy. Airlines now have a more sophisticated understanding of traffic patterns on their routes, and know more precisely what travelers are willing to pay.
"When the airlines are doing well, consumers are going to have to work harder to get the big savings," Mr. Parsons said.
However, consumers still hoping for the industry to return to its self-defeating ways were given new reasons to be optimistic about fares recently. Shortly after the industry appeared to be on its way to an unusual run of sustained profitability, it resumed the old habits that had led to excess capacity and had exaggerated the effects of the broader economic cycles.
The USAir Group, for example, placed an order in early November for up to 400 aircraft from Airbus Industrie. That order, however, is contingent upon USAir management's getting an agreement from its labor groups to lower its costs, currently the highest in the industry.
Two weeks later, American Airlines, a unit of the AMR Corporation, placed a firm order for 103 new jets from the Boeing Company, and said that it might order several hundred more planes from Boeing as part of a deal in which it committed itself to making Boeing its sole supplier of aircraft for the next 20 years.
But the new planes do not necessarily mean more capacity. Because of tough Federal noise standards that go into effect in 2000, many of the new planes will simply replace older models that will be sold outside the United States because the cost of modifying them to meet the tougher standards is too great. And despite the large orders from American and USAir, aircraft orders and scheduled deliveries for the industry last year still remain below earlier peaks.
Even so, the new orders are prompting many industry analysts on Wall Street to re-evaluate their estimates of capacity growth.
Samuel C. Buttrick, an airline analyst at Paine Webber, said that his estimate for the airlines' total capacity growth for 1997 is 4.3 percent. Two years ago, he had projected 3.5 percent. The capacity growth, he said, suggests that airline executives are losing some sense of self-discipline. "There is no question they are losing their religion," Mr. Buttrick said.
Will that mean a return to the kind of fare wars that prompted so many spontaneous trips in 1992? With the airline industry's notorious unpredictability, no one is willing to guess. But for now, the industry is enjoying the rare thrill of profitability.
"There is nothing more exciting," David A. Swierenga, chief economist at the Air Transport Association, said, "than making money."

SECTION: Section C; Page 3; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1198 words

HEADLINE: OUTLOOK '97: ECONOMY & INDUSTRY;
Conditions Are Right for a Takeover Frenzy

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
Growth is steady, but slow. Suppliers are not raising their prices, but nobody else can either. Costs have been cut deeply in a decade of downsizing, leaving few easy options for improving the bottom line.
What is a chief executive hungry for greater earnings to do?
In 1996, the answer was to eat somebody else's company. 
 Mergers and acquisitions soared to more than $647 billion in value, almost three times the 1993 level. Looking ahead, analysts say the biggest obstacle to the wave's continuation is the number of big targets that have already been bought.
But the forces behind the surge that has helped to reshape corporate America remain: frustration over anemic growth, global competition and a soaring stock market that put money in the pockets of those looking to buy.
And over the last two years one big deal has served to spur another. Last fall, the Rite Aid Corporation of Camp Hill, Pa., reached across the country to acquire Thrifty Payless Inc., the largest drugstore chain in the West, and create a bicoastal giant with 3,800 stores.
At the same time, Martin Grass, chairman of Rite Aid, announced he was pulling out of Florida and Alabama, selling 190 stores to a competitor, Thrift Drug Inc., a division of J. C. Penney, that promptly announced its own bid for greatness: a $2.5 billion merger with the Eckerd Corporation, a drugstore chain spread across the South.
Mr. Grass said this "strategic realignment" would result in $65 million in savings and more influence with suppliers as Rite Aid sought to dominate 21 of the top 50 metropolitan markets in the country. Although the numbers change, the strategic reasoning has driven reshufflings in transportation, health care, banking, broadcasting and aerospace as well.
"Companies can no longer rely on raising prices to increase their earnings," said Stanley A. Nabi, chief investment officer for DLJ Investment Management. "They have to find other ways of improving their profit margins, expanding their unit growth and controlling costs. They can buy market share or enter related businesses. All of that spells M.& A."
Such consolidations accounted for nearly two-thirds of last year's merger and acquisition activity.
But Wall Street analysts are clearly of two minds about whether this rapid pace can be sustained. The television broadcasting industry, like the hospital industry, has gone through a round of combinations and may have finally exhausted itself. But takeover specialists expect that the consolidation of commercial banks and electric utilities will continue unabated and that competition in the telecommunications and pharmaceutical industries will increasingly be played out on a worldwide stage.
"Companies and industries will be more global and that will require a great deal more M.& A.," Mr. Nabi said. "You're going to have industries consolidating, where the No. 4 or No. 5 company will disappear. They'll either be absorbed, or they'll give up the ghost."
The stock market is near an all-time high, the economy is growing slowly and inflation and interest rates are low, so all the factors contributing to the merger boom remain in place, said Brian Finn, co-head of the mergers and acquisitions department at CS First Boston. But he was more cautious in looking forward.
"The level of activity is so enormous that it's hard to forecast that it will stay this high," Mr. Finn said.
In the meantime, combinations abound. The number of takeovers jumped to more than 10,150 in 1996, from 6,307 in 1993.
As the number of commercial banks slowly shrinks, the Nationsbank Corporation has announced a $9 billion-plus agreement to buy Boatmen's Bancshares Inc.
The military and aerospace industry, pushed by the Pentagon, is also undergoing a huge consolidation. The Lockheed Martin Corporation's $8.7 billion agreement to acquire the Loral Corporation last summer was followed by the Rockwell International Corporation's announcement that it would sell its aerospace and weapons divisions to the Boeing Company for $860 million.
Those deals were dwarfed by Boeing's agreement to buy the McDonnell Douglas Corporation for $14 billion, bringing the total value for military industry mergers to more than $40 billion the last four years.
Deregulation and the dissolution of international trade barriers are fueling a white-hot level of activity in telecommunications, broadcasting and utilities, which together accounted for 27 percent of all the deals. The largest deal of all in 1996 was the proposed $21.3 billion merger of the Bell Atlantic Corporation and the Nynex Corporation. But no industry was immune, be it used-car sales operations or insurance.
The Microsoft Corporation, the Oracle Corporation and other companies have developed a new appetite for acquisitions, yet the information technology industry continues to grow by about 15 percent a year. "In 1996, there were more than 1,500 transactions in information technology, 4 or 5 a day," said Charles Federman, chairman of Broadview Associates, a merger adviser. "There's a realization that the information technology market is global and respects no geographic boundaries, coupled with technological innovations."
With shares trading at 20 times earnings and better, many chief executives are flush with a currency for transactions: company stock. According to figures compiled by J. P. Morgan, three-quarters of the takeovers of public companies involved stock swaps, or a combination of stock and cash.
Whether stock prices stay at record levels or not, is, of course, the great unknowable. But analysts say that even if a correction makes it harder to support stock swaps, there is money on the sidelines, in the hands of the financial buyers waiting for prices to come down.
But much of the reasoning behind the deals stands in sharp contrast to the last merger boom -- in the late 1980's. Conglomerates were all the rage then on Wall Street. In pursuit of a higher rate of return, chief executives collected widely disparate companies under one corporate umbrella, culminating in the $24.6 billion leveraged buyout of RJR Nabisco by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company.
That approach was "pure financial engineering, and it has not proved to be very successful," Mr. Nabi said.
Now, by contrast, the focus has gone from conglomerates to "core" businesses. Investors are rewarding companies that buy with an eye to expanding activities that they are already successful in and that offer greater potential for savings and economies of scale. Mergers to build core businesses are being accompanied by brisk activity in selloffs of divisions once valued for diversity but now viewed as diversions.
After peaking in 1988 at $353 billion, merger activity declined sharply with the recession. Companies instead hacked at administrative and operating costs to improve the bottom line. Then the stock market came back with a vengeance.
"We went through a long period where companies squeezed efficiencies out of their own companies," said Rick Escherich, head of the policy analysis group in the M.& A. department at J. P. Morgan. "The next logical thing is to squeeze it out of a combination."

HEADLINE: OUTLOOK '97: ECONOMY & INDUSTRY;
Casino Giants Roll, but It's No Sure Thing for the Others

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD 

 BODY:
The ups and steep downs of the gambling industry in 1996 -- and the prospect of tough sledding ahead -- were perhaps best captured by two large casinos in Las Vegas, Nev., that opened last year, the Stratosphere and the Monte Carlo.
The Stratosphere, an intensively promoted $550 million 1,149-foot tower built by the small Stratosphere Corporation, opened, only partly completed, at a poor location, and it bombed. The company is flirting with bankruptcy. The Monte Carlo, on the other hand, is on the Strip, is well managed by its two owners, the giant Mirage Resorts Inc. and Circus Circus Inc., and its 3,000 rooms have remained largely full since the spring opening. 
 "I think the lessons are that this is going to be a year fraught with very high levels of competition," Jason Ader, an analyst at Bear, Stearns & Company, said. "I don't have high hopes over all for the market. The big must-see properties in Las Vegas, like the Mirage, Circus Circus and the operations of MGM Grand Inc., they'll do O.K. But it takes a very solid business to do that in this environment."
W. Bruce Turner of Salomon Brothers, added, "It's been the march of the giants pretty much, and that is likely to continue."
That message is proving true across the country. Atlantic City, which appeared early in 1996 to be on a trajectory of sizzling growth, has been stalled by a promotional war among the casinos and delays in the development of some huge new resorts in the Marina District.
The casinos in Atlantic City are giving away rolls of quarters to lure in slot players at the rate of $1.5 million a day, David Wolfe of Oppenheimer & Company estimated.
One of the victims of the weak environment has been Donald J. Trump's gambling concern, Trump Hotel and Casino Resorts Inc. The company has seen its stock plummet from a high of $35.50 in June to $12.
In addition, riverboat gambling, which swept the Midwestern states several years ago, was hit with greater competition and far greater selectivity among both gamblers and investors. The Bear, Stearns index of riverboat company stocks has fallen 46 percent from its peak in early June.
"I'm very concerned about the riverboats in the year ahead," Mr. Wolfe of Oppenheimer said. "It takes something really special and very good management to beat the competition out there."
And even in Las Vegas, a continuing supply of new hotel rooms and casinos is likely to maintain pressure on smaller companies. A total of 6,400 hotel rooms and 7,700 gaming positions were added in Las Vegas in 1996. In 1997, another 5,000 hotel rooms and nearly 10,000 gaming positions will be added, according to Salomon Brothers.
Over all, America's recently acquired ardor for gambling remains fairly strong; gambling concerns are believed to have taken in more than $45 billion in revenue in 1996.
But investors' fascination with the industry has dropped from the giddy heights of early 1996. The Bear, Stearns gambling stock index has tumbled from its peak in June despite the rise of the broader market indexes.
The wave of mergers that some analysts had predicted would shore up stock prices never materialized, aside from a few big transactions, like the Hilton Hotels Corporation's $3 billion purchase of Bally Entertainment.
"Massive consolidation is not going to happen," Mr. Wolfe said. "The better players can borrow from the banks and build without paying a premium for an existing property."
Lee Isgur, the gambling analyst at Jefferies & Company, said: "The rich are getting richer, and the poor in the industry are getting poorer. Don't expect the magic of consolidation to change that."
Brian D. Egger, the gambling stock analyst with Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities, said his favorite stocks for the year were three of the largest companies: Circus Circus, Mirage and Primadonna Resorts Inc.
Mr. Isgur predicted that Hilton Hotels might surprise the industry by making another big acquisition in 1997, perhaps even making a run at Circus Circus.
His picks for 1997 include Station Casinos Inc., which is completing a big new riverboat in Kansas City, Mo.; Rio Hotel and Casino Inc., which is working on a renovation of its Las Vegas operation; Mirage, and Circus Circus.
"I look at it as a transitional year," Mr. Isgur said. "I think 1998 is going to be more exciting, and toward the end of 1997 that will start to get through to people and help these stocks."
Mr. Ader's principal picks for 1997 are Circus Circus and Mirage. Hilton, he said, will benefit somewhat from the cost savings as it absorbs Bally. The ITT Corporation, which owns Caesars Palace, is in a transition year because it is pouring more than $2 billion into renovating and expanding its casinos in Las Vegas and Atlantic City, and thus would be unlikely to improve before the latter part of the year.
Mr. Wolfe picked Circus Circus, MGM Grand and Sun International Hotels Ltd., which is managing the Mohegan Sun Casino in Connecticut and which owns Paradise Island in the Bahamas.

HEADLINE: OUTLOOK '97: ECONOMY & INDUSTRY;
The Link Grows Cloudy Between Jobs and Prices

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
The current economic recovery is nearly six years old, and the annual inflation rate is a meager 3.2 percent -- the lowest level since World War II for an expansion this old. Economists are coming up with all sorts of explanations for the unusual milestone. And gradually many are concluding that inflation has become harder to explain.
The most striking aspect of this milestone is the scramble it is provoking among economists to repair the theory that they use to link unemployment and inflation. The theory, a keystone of economic policy, says that when the unemployment rate falls below a certain flash point, inflation soon accelerates. But the flash point foreseen in theory, 6 percent, was breached months ago, and nothing happened. The unemployment rate went as low as 5.1 percent, and still nothing happened. 
 "What we have had is a magical belief that we can arrive at an unemployment number that will tell us about inflation," said Richard Rogerson, a University of Minnesota economist, at a conference convened to figure out what had gone wrong with the theory. "We can't."
The theoretical concept, known as the natural rate of unemployment, holds that at a certain level, the unemployment rate is just high enough to avoid labor shortages that would push up wages, prompting companies to raise prices to cover the additional labor costs. This equilibrium level, at which the inflation rate neither rises nor falls, has varied from decade to decade, but when the unemployment rate moves below what the Federal Reserve and the economists consider the natural rate, a series of responses develops that usually end in recession.
The Federal Reserve raises interest rates to discourage business activity. The unemployment rate then rises as people lose jobs, and the inflation rate falls. But instead of stopping at the natural rate, restoring an equilibrium, the unemployment rate often keeps rising as the economy slows. This sequence in the 1960's and the 1980's, the two other periods since World War II when a recovery has lasted as long as the current one, culminated in recessions. But with the natural rate theory so much in doubt today, the odds of a repeat performance are less.
"This is a time to leave everything alone," said Edward S. Hyman, president and chief economist at ISI Group Inc., a Wall Street firm.
The trade-offs were much clearer in December 1966, when the 1960's recovery was also three months short of being six years old. The unemployment rate had fallen to 3.8 percent on average for that year, from 4.5 percent in 1965, and as it fell, the annual inflation rate, as measured by the Consumer Price Index, rose to 3.5 percent from less than 2 percent in 1965.
The Vietnam War was a big factor, of course, pushing down the civilian unemployment rate and raising wages as working-age people entered the armed forces, leaving labor shortages at home. But with interest rates rising, the economy slowed and recession came in late 1969. Two years later, the unemployment rate, having reversed direction, was 5.9 percent, while the inflation rate had been cut almost in half.
The 1980's recovery reached 69 months, the age of the current expansion, in August 1988. Just about then the inflation rate began to edge up from 4.4 percent, while the unemployment rate, true to theory, fell from 6.2 percent on average in 1987 to 5.5 percent in 1988 and 5.3 percent in 1989. In response, the Fed pushed up interest rates and the unemployment rate changed direction, reaching nearly 7 percent during the recession that started in 1990.
This 1980's experience brought many economists to the conclusion that 6 percent was the natural rate of unemployment, or equilibrium level. So when it fell below 6 percent in the summer of 1994, the great expectation was that prices would rise, in response to the rising cost of wages and benefits. That did not happen. Indeed, as the unemployment rate inched steadily downward to less than 5.5 percent (it is now 5.4 percent), neither labor costs nor the inflation rate changed much.
Still, many forecasters and economists, particularly on Wall Street, where nervousness about inflation is part of the landscape, insist that the natural rate thesis remains valid and will show itself in 1997 in rising prices. "It is as important as ever," said Albert M. Wojnilower, senior economic adviser for Clipper Asset Management, "but no one is so sure anymore where the natural rate is."
That uncertainty is very evident among economists in academia, where the natural rate theory originated in the 1960's. One problem is that theoretical work on the natural rate is too often divorced from gathering concrete evidence in the field, some economists argue. So they are listing numerous possible reasons for the breakdown in what once seemed a predictable relationship linking unemployment, wages and inflation. Steep declines in computer prices and health care costs, for example, help slow inflation, says Robert Gordon of Northwestern University. To offset this drag, the natural rate of unemployment must fall. Until recently, Mr. Gordon had put the natural rate at 6 percent; he now puts it at 5.5 percent or less.
Others argue that because Europe and Japan are suffering from weak economic growth, they are quick to use their idle industrial capacity to produce merchandise inexpensively for export to the United States. That undercuts corporate America's efforts to raise prices in response to low unemployment and wage pressures.
Downsizing, weaker unions, new technology that makes old skills obsolete, reduced expectations about wages and a growing reluctance to quit a secure job when raises are not forthcoming -- all weaken workers' bargaining power, even when the unemployment rate is low, economists say. So does the huge contingent of temporary workers who often take slots once held by higher-paid regular employees.
The caveats have grown so numerous that a few economists, including James K. Galbraith of the University of Texas at Austin, have concluded that the natural rate of unemployment is a useless concept. "This may mean reconstructing one's thinking from the ground up," he said.
Most economists and policy makers, however, say they still believe in the natural rate as "a useful theory to understand inflation," as Joseph Stiglitz, chairman of President Clinton's Council of Economic Advisers, has put it. But they cannot quite figure out what the current level is. That has made many economists more willing to experiment, to let the unemployment rate fall, even at the risk of a slightly higher inflation rate for a while.
"You would get an additional expansion of the economy," said Dean Baker of the Economic Policy Institute, "and you might create an additional 800,000 jobs."

 Unlike previous steady expansions, in the 1990's the "core" inflation rate -- changes in consumer price index excluding food and energy -- has not increased even after more than five year growth. Graph tracks the core rate after the recessions in the 1960's, 1980's, and 1990's. The 1970's are not shown because inflation fluctuated at much higher levels. (Source: Merrill Lynch & Company)

HEADLINE: OUTLOOK '97: ECONOMY & INDUSTRY;
Debate Over Taxes in '97 Is Likely to Stress 'Relief'

BYLINE: By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

 BODY:
Goodbye, tax reform. Hello, tax relief.
A year ago, scrapping the income tax system and replacing it with a flat tax, a national sales tax or just about any other tax was a leading topic in Washington. This year, the focus is on handing out tax goodies. 
 The dividing line between the White House and Congressional Republicans is whether to tie tax breaks to specific conduct, such as earning B's in college, or to make across-the-board rate cuts and let taxpayers decide how to use the money.
The change can be seen in the statement that Representative Bill Archer, the Texas Republican who is chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, issued right after President Clinton's re-election. It said nothing about tax reform.
Mr. Archer, in an interview, said he still wanted to "tear the income tax out by its roots." But for the time being, he added, he will focus on more practical aspects.
"Tax reform was in style last year," observed Donald C. Alexander, an Internal Revenue Commissioner in the 1970's and now a tax lawyer at Aiken, Gump, Strauss, Hauer & Feld. "But what's in style for 1997 is, regrettably, ideas that will louse up the tax code even more than it is and make things more complicated."
Max B. Sawicky, an economist at the labor-backed Economic Policy Institute, said that in terms of tax law changes in 1997, "We're back to small potatoes."
Here are some of the tax favors being proposed for the coming year:
CAPITAL GAINS Congressional Republicans want a broad cut in capital gains taxes, under which the current 28 percent maximum rate would be reduced to perhaps 20 percent and as little as 7.5 percent for people in the lowest tax bracket.
Some kind of capital gains tax cut has good prospects for a number of reasons, not the least of which is that it might help cool down the stock market, where many people are holding on to stocks they regard as overvalued just to avoid paying capital gains taxes that would be owed if they sold.
President Clinton, who during the campaign, said, "I'm not philosophically opposed to all capital gains cuts," said last month that he would consider the issue "only in the context of balanced-budget negotiations." He said he would judge any proposed capital gains tax change by a simple standard: "Does it give you jobs and incomes?"
Reducing capital gains rates temporarily, say for three years, should bring more money into Government coffers in the first two years, as people cash in appreciated investments, especially stocks that they had not sold to avoid a big tax bill. If investors believe, however, that any temporary reduction in capital gains rates might become permanent, then the effect of a tax "sale" on Government revenues -- encouraging people to cash in and pay the taxes before rates go back up -- could be much less significant.
"I think the President has already signaled that he is willing to consider reductions in the capital gains tax rate," Mr. Archer said. "The question is simply, how will it be done?"
HOMEOWNER CAPITAL GAINS President Clinton has proposed exempting up to $250,000 in capital gains on home sales ($500,000 for married couples), which would cost the Treasury perhaps $600 million annually. Current law grants a one-time $125,000 exemption for those aged 55 or older. Capital losses on homes are, and would continue to be, nondeductible under the President's proposal.
"The last thing we need is more tax subsidy for residential real estate," said Lee A. Sheppard, a tax attorney who critiques methods of avoiding taxes for Tax Notes, a weekly magazine about taxes.
Grover Norquist, president of Americans for Tax Reform and an adviser to Speaker Newt Gingrich, said House Republicans would oppose treating homeowners separately in a capital gains tax rate bill. "Bill Clinton said he was for a capital gains cut on people who own houses," Mr. Norquist said. "So why discriminate against farmers and small-business owners?"
AIRLINE TICKETS In a bit of tax deja vu, the 10 percent tax on airline tickets expired at the end of 1996, just as it did a year earlier. The tax was reinstated for most of 1996, but only temporarily, because of a quirk in Federal budget rules. A special bill to reimpose the airline tax is unlikely.
Lapse of the tax is a boon for airlines, but the tax is almost certain to come back in some form eventually, because it finances the air traffic control system.
EDUCATION President Clinton won applause on the campaign trail when he proposed letting parents or students deduct up to $10,000 in annual college expenses and when he offered a tax credit of up to $1,500 for community college students who earn B's or better and stay off drugs. Critics warn that the plans could drive up tuition without significantly helping bright, but poor, students get a college education.
NONPROFITS Hearings into political activities by tax-exempt organizations appear likely, although Mr. Archer warned that this is a "very delicate area."
Representatives John R. Kasich of Ohio, the House Budget Committee chairman, and Dan Coats of Indiana are promoting a tax credit to cut income taxes dollar-for-dollar on donations to charities that spend 75 percent of their funds to help the poor.
ESTATE TAX House Republicans still favor raising the exemption from estate tax to $750,000 from $600,000, although to fully adjust for inflation since 1987, when the exemption was last changed, would require raising the exemption to more than $800,000. Mr. Clinton has indicated he supports some modest estate tax breaks.

HEADLINE: OUTLOOK '97: INTERNATIONAL;
Hong Kong Isn't on Edge Despite China Takeover

BYLINE: By EDWARD A. GARGAN 

DATELINE: HONG KONG

 BODY:
With scarcely six months remaining before Britain relinquishes Hong Kong to China after 150 years of colonial sovereignty, the anxiety among the general public seems to have missed much of the territory's business community.
Even though China is dismissing Hong Kong's elected legislature, promising harsh new laws on subversion and treason, and challenging the status of hundreds of thousands of Hong Kong residents who have British citizenship, Hong Kong's economy, at least for the moment, seems unperturbed. 
 "I think from where we stand the way it looks is moderately positive," Miron Mushkat, the chief economist for Asia at Lehman Brothers, said. "We are arguing that the recovery from the slowdown of '94, '95 and into '96 is returning to trend, and the recovery is coming from the domestic arena."
Since midsummer, Hong Kong's stock market has been on an uphill run, slowing only in recent weeks. And Hong Kong's economic growth, while slower than in the last two years, is continuing at a rate of 4.7 percent a year.
"When we look at the trends of G.D.P. growth, we can see it is rising all the time," Tang Kwong-yiu, a Government economist, said. "It reached the bottom in the first quarter of this year," when the growth rate was only 3.3 percent annually.
But despite the surge in economic growth, worries do remain for the future. Exports, according to the Government's quarterly report, are likely to remain weak, and imports, battered by a strong United States dollar and weakening demand in China, have continued to shrink. Chinese demand for imports has a big impact on Hong Kong, which is a conduit for much of that trade.
Even so, one of the pillars of Hong Kong's economy, the property market, has bounced back significantly, with housing prices shooting up 30 to 50 percent the last year. One component in the sharp rise in office and apartment prices, according to David Faulkner, a partner at the property consulting firm Brooke Hillier Parker, is the influx of Chinese companies to Hong Kong.
"They're all looking to position themselves here after 1997," he said, referring to July 1, 1997, when the Chinese flag is to be raised here.
"The consequences of the Chinese coming," Mr. Faulkner continued, "is that it will create a lot more demand for office property here, and I'm not sure there's enough on the supply side of the equation. On the residential side, Chinese companies are buying quarters for staff, and at the moment, the supply side of residential is not sufficient. The only real alternative is inside China."
At the moment, the Government's parsimonious doling out of land -- a practice that has created the giant real estate conglomerates headed by many of the territory's well-known tycoons -- has produced an economy that many see as disproportionately driven by unrealistic real estate prices. The stock market, which is now 30 to 35 percent property stocks, must inevitably shift and is certain to do so under Chinese rule, according to Peter Churchouse, the managing director of Morgan Stanley Asia Ltd.
But Mr. Churchouse sees an even more fundamental shock awaiting Hong Kong as it slides into the grasp of Beijing. "In 15 years, Shanghai will be the financial capital of this country," he said. "The climate and nature of what Hong Kong does will change. It will become the capital of a subregion of China of 100 million people."
While that may be true, foreign investors are generally bullish on Hong Kong's prospects, at least near term. Mark Michelson, the chairman of the American Chamber of Commerce here, said that 95 percent of American businesses are either "favorable or very favorable" toward Hong Kong in the years leading up to the new millennium.
"I think there's fairly good confidence in the Hong Kong economy," Mr. Michelson said. "Coupled with this is the fact that politically things look a bit better" both within China and in its relations to the United States and Taiwan.
At the same time, Mr. Michelson said, "there are some issues of concern." He went on: "To no one's surprise, the rule of law is seen as very important. Another thing is the unrestricted flow of information, which is an issue for business people as well as for those in the media. People here have to make business decisions based on a variety of information about the region and Hong Kong and need to be able to continue to do that. The other concern is corruption, the implication is that it could move in this direction."
Despite the confidence of investors, a recent Government report found that the number of companies planning to leave Hong Kong in the next year had risen to 7 percent from 3.8 percent a year ago. Still, the Government was careful to point out that soaring rents, not concern over political changes, are pushing companies out.
Yet, many economists say they believe the transfer of sovereignty will be relatively uneventful. "The economy will go through largely unscathed." Mr. Mushkat of Lehman Brothers said. "Generally, I'm positive, but I would not go overboard."

HEADLINE: OUTLOOK '97: MEDIA & TECHNOLOGY;
Do Computers Lift Productivity? It's Unclear, but Business Is Sold

BYLINE: By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN 

 BODY:
The Dell Computer Corporation has designed its newest factory without room for inventory storage. The Chrysler Corporation can increase vehicle production without building new factories. And the General Electric Company expects to save millions of dollars by buying spare parts for its plants over the Internet.
On the surface, these are manufacturing stories. At heart, they are among the thousands of new business practices made possible by technology. 
 But the question remains: Just how have the changes wrought by computers and software affected the overall economy? Have they helped to smooth the bumps in the business cycle by enabling companies to be more efficient? Or is technology's principal contribution to be found in the hardware and software those companies buy and sell?
That America is deep in a love affair with the computer is not in doubt. As of last year's third quarter, the annual rate of spending on information technology in the United States was $251 billion, or 3.6 percent of the nation's total output of goods and services. That compares with an annual rate of $47 billion, or 1 percent of gross domestic product, in the third quarter of 1980.
Louis V. Gerstner, chief executive of the International Business Machines Corporation, recently predicted that the global information technology industry would grow to $1.2 trillion in annual revenue by 2000 from $800 billion today.
"The fact is that corporate America's appetite for technology now shows no bounds," said Stephen Roach, the chief economist at Morgan Stanley.
Which is odd, because what statistical evidence there is suggests that computers have had a relatively small impact on improving productivity, particularly in services.
Mr. Roach and other economists say the lack of statistical evidence does not much matter. What is important, they argue, is that the corporations that are buying the technology are convinced it is helping them.
"Because that perception is real, irrespective of what the verdict is, it is safe to say that technology has played an increasingly powerful role in driving capital spending and in reshaping the overall business cycle contour in the United States," Mr. Roach said.
There is no doubt that the vast amounts of money being spent on technology have helped the economy maintain its steady growth rate, and have made up for the relative weakness in some areas of the economy, like personal consumption, during the current expansion.
"There is always something that is growing fast, and it happens to be high technology right now," said Alan Blinder, a former vice chairman of the Federal Reserve Board who is now an economics professor at Princeton University.
But technology boosters insist the economists are failing to grasp the important changes that computers and software are bringing to thousands of companies.
"To say that the results aren't there asserts a level of unsophistication about the economy," said Michael Hammer, the management guru and co-author of "Re-engineering the Corporation," the 1993 best seller that became required reading for many chief executives. "The payoffs have been enormous."
 Information technology has allowed businesses to streamline their operations in revolutionary new ways, Mr. Hammer added. Retailers can monitor sales at the checkout counter and restock their shelves even before a popular product is sold out. And when demand surges, heavy manufacturers can squeeze additional output from existing plants more quickly and less expensively than by adding new factories.
Wal-Mart Stores Inc., the country's largest retailer, 16 months ago began recording every sale in every one of its 2,268 stores in a giant "data warehouse." The company uses the data to fashion targeted marketing strategies while distributing products to the stores where the most people are likely to buy them.
The German software company SAP A.G. has grown rapidly by selling sophisticated programs that automate and seamlessly link all aspects of a company's operations. The system processes orders; schedules and tracks manufacturing; dispatches and tracks goods, and makes sure they are invoiced properly so that the bills sent to customers match the orders.
"It is difficult to overstate the amount of unproductive work that was going on in large organizations until the 90's," Mr. Hammer said. "It would be common for 90 percent of the time it took for something to happen to be wasted time."
Dell Computer, which has doubled in size to $8 billion in annual revenue in the last two years, is perhaps the purest example of the efficiencies made possible by information technology. Unlike the rival Compaq Computer Corporation, which uses a vast network of resellers, Dell sells all its systems directly to its customers. The company waits until it has received an order before it begins to build a machine.
"We don't have to guess what our customers are going to buy," said Michael S. Dell, the company's 31-year-old founder and chairman. "They tell us every day."
Dell recently redesigned its computers so that each model incorporates as many of the same component parts as possible. The company minimizes the number of parts it holds at any one time by relying on its suppliers to stock its factories in much the same way as packaged goods companies stock their products on supermarket shelves.
At the end of September, the company had 12 days of inventory, Mr. Dell said, meaning that it replenishes its parts stocks some 30 times a year. That allows Dell to respond quickly to new technology, shifts in customer demand and changing prices.
But Mr. Dell wants to go further. In a bold experiment, the company's new factory in Austin, Tex., is designed to drive inventory levels even lower. The new plant will have no storage space. "We believe that if you don't have any place for inventory, then you won't have any inventory," Mr. Dell said.
Such efficiency, Mr. Hammer and others say, has helped insulate the national economy from the waxing and waning of the business cycle. If businesses no longer overproduce during booms, they won't be forced to cut production and lay off workers when demand slackens.
On the other side of the equation, information technology has also allowed companies to produce more with less. When Chrysler decided to increase car production, it used computers and overtime to squeeze more cars out of its existing operations rather than build a new plant.
"I do share the hunch that information technology has improved inventory management and hence muted one of the important short-term movers in the business cycles," Mr. Blinder acknowledged. But he said it was a hunch rather than a conviction because hard evidence of a connection did not yet exist.
Indeed, even high-technology companies have not managed to immunize themselves from traditional inventory bloat. Another computer maker, the Digital Equipment Corporation, stumbled badly in early 1996, when it was caught with thousands of unsold personal computers that were built before a plunge in memory chip prices. When PC prices followed chip prices lower, Digital sustained heavy losses, forcing a revamping that cost 7,000 jobs.
Nevertheless, technology proponents say that world is in the beginning of a process that will accelerate with the rapid adoption of the Internet as the primary means of commercial communication.
General Electric, the diversified industrial and financial giant, is converting its entire supply chain from paper to the Internet, a shift executives say will save hundreds of millions of dollars a year.
G.E.'s lighting division has already begun using the Internet to solicit bids for spare parts for its factories overnight instead of over two weeks. The solicitations go out over the global network to a selected group of suppliers, who reply with their bids the next day.
Orville A. Bailey, a G.E. executive involved in the Internet project, said he was aware of the so-called productivity paradox, according to which little gain has been seen from the widespread use of personal computers. But he added that he believed that the Internet would change that dramatically. "For the first time, we are able to leverage the investment that has been made in computer technology, because for the first time, everyone can talk to everyone else," he said.
And that should fuel continued steady growth, right?
"It could be true," Mr. Blinder observed skeptically. "But the only thing I know about seers is that they are always wrong."

HEADLINE: OUTLOOK '97: INTERNATIONAL;
In Mexico, an Uneven Recovery

BYLINE: By JULIA PRESTON 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY

 BODY:
A few of the Mexicans who will help determine how the economy performs this year were milling one holiday afternoon outside the display windows of a famous department store in Mexico City's central square.
Some, like Humberto Navarro, a 38-year-old lawyer, studied the store's offerings and came out with arms brimming with packages. 
 "My personal economy allowed me some room to maneuver," Mr. Navarro said, describing how the revival of his law practice in 1996 convinced him that Mexico was on its way back to sustained growth after the disastrous slump that followed the 1994 devaluation of the peso.
Others admired the windows but left the store empty handed.
"Things are just going from bad to worse. Wages aren't going up but everything else is. We hardly can afford to put dinner on the holiday table," said Maria Ceja Zambrano, a 60-year-old homemaker, with the melancholy of one whose holiday is dampened by want.
One test of success for Mexico this year will be whether consumers resume sustained spending. Economists generally agree that President Ernesto Zedillo's tight-money policies, bolstered by the $28 billion used from a bailout program led by the United States, achieved an unexpectedly rapid turnaround for Mexico's overall economy.
But the recovery remains limited and fragile. Driven by a surge in exports, it has been felt mostly in the exporting industries of the north and among the middle class. Wage workers from Mexico City to the south are still wavering on the edge.
And as citizens like Mr. Navarro and Mrs. Ceja consider their own economic realities, they will vote in midyear elections that could change the course of Mexican politics for the first time in more than 60 years. Voters angry with the governing party could hand the opposition a majority in the Congress, which controls the nation's budget and the influential Mexico City mayor's office. In 1997, the economy depends more than ever on the political transition, analysts said.
The elections "will be the prime source of the news events that will control expectations about the future of Mexico," said Abel Beltran del Rio, the top Mexico analyst at Ciemex-WEFA, an economic consulting group. The expectations will govern the foreign capital flows, the stability of the peso and interest rates.
Mexico finished 1996 with healthy gross domestic product growth of about 4.5 percent and 29 percent inflation, numbers that vindicated official projections which were widely scoffed at when Finance Minister Guillermo Ortiz made them in November 1995. The peso defied the pessimists by slipping gently over the year and finishing at about 7.88 to the dollar, staying below the psychological watershed rate of 8.
For 1997, most economists expect the Government's projection of a 4 percent increase in gross domestic product to prove conservative and inflation to continue declining to below 20 percent.
Wall Street investors who were furious at the Banco de Mexico, the central bank, for setting off the devaluation in 1994 by letting foreign currency reserves dip so low, ended last year with grudging praise for light-handed moves by Miguel Mancera, the bank president, that helped ease interest rates downward.
"My biggest concern is the Mexican consumer," Ernest Brown, senior economist for Latin America at Morgan Stanley, said. "There has been a lot of unemployment, a lot of shifting of workers from higher-paying to lower-paying jobs. Now that we've got recovery started, where are the new rings on Mexico's tree going to come from?"
There are signs that Mexicans are becoming more confident about opening their wallets. In the auto industry, which all but died in 1995, production for the domestic market was up 71 percent in November compared with the November a year earlier. Official third-quarter figures showed overall consumer demand up 5.1 percent, the first sign of life in this indicator since the crisis began.
Although the Government has pledged billions of dollars to save the banking system from implosion, many Mexicans are still overwhelmed by old debts and are crying out for new credit. Only solid-gold corporate customers are getting loans.
In 1996 direct foreign investment dipped by about $1 billion from a record high of $7 billion the year before. Still, Mexico is riding a wave of long-term investment set in motion by the 1994 North American Free Trade Agreement.
What the midyear elections hold is hard to predict. Recent electoral seasons have been agitated, marked by intrigue and even, in 1994, two high-level political assassinations. Although the confidence of portfolio investors has been somewhat restored, in part by the healthy performance of the Mexican stock market last year, they could remain skittish if political unrest appears again.
Mr. Zedillo staked his presidency on moving Mexico toward a more open political system. But in recent weeks he has moved closer to the old guard in his Institutional Revolutionary Party, giving the impression that insuring victory may have become more important than leveling the field for the opposition.
The main legal opposition group is the National Action Party, which draws its strength from the business in northern Mexico and is committed to conservative economic policies. The election's effect will depend on whether any big players, in Mexico or abroad, lose their nerve.
"Mexicans are not used to how noisy democracy is," Mr. Brown said. "In all likelihood, once people get used to it, they will realize it doesn't have much to do with the course of the economy."

HEADLINE: OUTLOOK '97: ECONOMY & INDUSTRY;
U.S. Sales Of Autos Expected to Keep Pace

BYLINE: By ROBYN MEREDITH 

DATELINE: DETROIT

 BODY:
For decades, few industries have been as cyclical as the automobile business, with sales soaring in good times and plunging so deeply in bad times that the very survival of some auto makers has been threatened.
But for the last three years, sales have been on a somewhat strong and remarkably steady plateau, with buyers snapping up sport utility vehicles, mini-vans and pickup trucks in particular. Auto executives concur that 1997 will turn out much like 1996. 
 In December, Alex Trotman, the chairman, chief executive and president of the Ford Motor Company, issued precisely the same sales forecast for 1997 that he had given a year earlier for 1996: overall industry sales of 15 million to 15.5 million passenger cars, pickup trucks, sport utility vehicles, mini-vans and heavier trucks. Sales totaled 15.1 million in 1995 and 15.4 million in 1994 -- both figures well up from 1993, when auto makers sold just 14.2 million vehicles in the United States.
"We expect it will be more of the same for the auto industry, which would be great," Mr. Trotman said. He added that his optimism for continued strong sales in 1997 was based on an assumption that unemployment and inflation would remain low and the American economy would continue to produce jobs at a brisk pace, because the auto market often tracks closely the performance of the overall economy.
The General Motors Corporation echoed his forecast, while the Chrysler Corporation said it expected industry sales to hit 15.2 million.
Japanese auto makers were slightly more cautious. "We hope it would get to 15 million to 15.5 million vehicles next year, but that is very optimistic," William C. Duncan, general director of the Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association, said.
This unprecedented stability in sales is saving the industry billions of dollars, mostly by avoiding the kind of inventory gluts that come with downturns. "Cycles are very, very costly," Van Bussmann, Chrysler's top economist, said, because "you get whipsawed in this kind of high-fixed-cost industry." He added that over a decade the steadier path would increase Chrysler's profits by 25 percent.
But getting off the roller coaster has created a few problems for the industry. Low inflation has left customers more resistant than ever to auto makers' efforts to raise prices. Ford, in particular, has been hurt by that sentiment. A year ago, Ford created an expensive new design for the Taurus, only to watch customers choose less expensive, if less sophisticated, midsize cars made by its rivals.
Low inflation has also made the United States a much more attractive place to invest. The result has been a torrent of investment that has helped push up the value of the dollar and made Asian and European cars less expensive here.
In the first two months of the 1997 model year, which began on Oct. 1, the Big Three lost 2.1 percentage points of market share to Japanese and European auto makers. G.M. lost the biggest share. While 2.1 percentage points might not sound like much, if that pace persists for a full year, it would amount to 315,000 cars and trucks and about $5.7 billion in lost sales.
"Exports from Japan have picked up already," said Jaime D. Seguino, a research economist at Ford. "Certainly, it is something we're concerned about."
Together, the rising dollar and the reluctance of American consumers to pay higher prices have put pressure on auto makers to cut costs to increase their profits.
Despite fairly strong profits, Ford is eliminating 6,000 jobs in its car development division. G.M., Chrysler and Honda are helping their bottom lines by leaning heavily on their suppliers to reduce costs.
To the extent that there are concerns about whether auto sales will stay strong, the worries are focused overseas. Auto executives and economists for the Big Three said they did not see a downturn on the horizon, though they expect that one will come eventually. When it does, it will most likely be caused by something unexpected, like the outbreak of a war or a shock to oil markets, they said.
"Business cycles are created not just by policy management, but by external shocks to the economy," said G.M.'s chief economist, G. Mustafa Mohatarem.
Economists and executives said the threat of economic turbulence caused by unpredictable events remained. "I expect there will be, in the next five years, a downturn," Mr. Trotman said.
All three have been stuffing cash into their reserves against such a rainy day. Chrysler, which is seen as most vulnerable to an oil shock because of its heavy sales of mini-vans and sport utility vehicles, has an $8.7 billion cushion. Ford has set aside $13 billion, below its reserve target, and G.M. $14.5 billion, more than its target.

HEADLINE: OUTLOOK '97: MARKETS & INVESTING;
Merger-Hungry Banks Find the Pickings Slim

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL 

 BODY:
Like children whose summer vacation dreams turn to snow, some of America's leading bankers occasionally will confess that nothing would make them happier than a good recession.
"I can hardly wait for problems to come," said Richard M. Kovacevich, chief executive of the Norwest Corporation, the Minneapolis banking giant. 
 That may sound shocking, six years after a recession sounded a death knell for hundreds of banks. In the slow-growing and rapidly consolidating banking business, however, many bankers see artful mergers as the best source of growth.
But all bankers look like geniuses when the economy is good, and the soaring stock market is inflating the prices of even the most undistinguished banks. Bad times expose bad loans, and bankers like Mr. Kovacevich long for the days when losers were clearly separated from winners and an ailing fixer-upper bank could be bought for a song.
"A lot of our best acquisitions were made when the industry had problems," he said wistfully.
Bankers, moreover, cautiously hope that another recession will show the many skeptics that they, at least, have learned something from their past follies and will not be drowning in bad loans the next time the economy hits a bump.
"If we get a cycle where banks don't have big declines in earnings, the companies will be viewed as less cyclical and will get overall higher valuations," said Moshe A. Orenbuch, a bank stock analyst with Sanford C. Bernstein & Company. Bank stocks currently sell for about 12 times their earnings, far less than the 18 times earnings the average company fetches.
"I would like to see the industry manage through a cycle better than we had in the past," said David A. Daberko, chief executive of the National City Corporation of Cleveland. Even so, he is not so mean spirited as to call for the bears. "From a mergers and acquisitions standpoint, a down market would be better, but you never hope for that," he said.
Indeed, as best as bankers can tell, there is no economic or lending crisis brewing. Lending standards are slipping, experts say, as bankers provide more money to companies at ever lower rates, for longer terms, on looser conditions. But these loans are widely dispersed geographically and by industry. No one can see a particular buildup -- like oil-patch loans in the mid-1980's -- that might set off a disaster.
Consumer loans, especially on credit cards, do show all the classic signs of a bubble, with rapid growth in the face of rising delinquencies and losses from personal bankruptcies. But while the pain could well increase this year, it will not lead to a crisis in the absence of a serious economic downturn.
"The scary thing is we have low unemployment now; God help us when it goes up," Mr. Kovacevich said, somewhat hopefully.
Yet, in the face of what promises to be a steady time for banks and with stock prices rising, some bankers think they cannot wait for the next down cycle before looking for other banks to buy.
The $9.1 billion deal to buy Boatmen's Bancshares Inc. of St. Louis by the Nationsbank Corporation of Charlotte, N.C., last year is considered a turning point.
Hugh L. McColl Jr., Nationsbank's chief executive, is seen as the banking industry's ultimate power shopper, having built the North Carolina National Bank into what is now the country's fourth-largest bank by buying big, ailing banks that other bankers were too scared to touch. By last year, Mr. McColl decided he could not afford to wait any longer for more bargains and agreed to buy Boatmen's at full retail price.
That deal, however, was the anomaly in a year that saw far fewer mega-mergers than 1995, when giants including the Chase Manhattan Bank, the First Chicago NBD Corporation and the First Fidelity Bancorporation were absorbed by rivals. In 1996, bankers either turned up their noses at bank prices, as Mr. Kovacevich did, or they were busy dismissing people, closing branches and doing the other dirty work necessary to make the previous year's deals pay off.
And some big banks started to wonder whether those deals were worth the bother.
"I don't think that most of the acquisitions that have been done made sense for the acquirer," said David A. Coulter, chief executive of the BankAmerica Corporation.
Nonetheless, merger experts predict that even without a recession to cut prices, the volume of bank mergers will pick up in 1997.
"A lot of people who are on the sidelines looking at their prospects are not going to be content to sit out another round of consolidation," said Edward D. Herlihy, a merger lawyer at Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz.
One reason is that the buoyant equities market has affected buyers as well as sellers. Most bank acquisitions are paid for with stock, rather than cash; thus, the rising market effectively has put more money in buyers' pockets.
Salomon Brothers recently analyzed potential suitors for 42 banks. The study found that at current stock prices, there was at least one buyer for most of the targets studied that could afford to buy the bank at a premium to its current market price.
"A year ago, there were very few possible deals," said Carole S. Berger, a bank analyst at Salomon. "Now, there are a lot."
Meanwhile, many medium-sized banks are more willing to sell because the business is becoming more difficult. The profits of recent years have come from cost-cutting and mergers, but many bankers realize that unless they can increase revenue, the party is over.
"Our objective is earnings growth of 10 percent a year," Mr. Daberko of National City said. "Our traditional corporate and consumer banking business is only generating 6 or 7 percent increases."
To make up the difference, his bank is pushing into new areas, from asset-based lending to riskier auto loans. "We have 15 initiatives to increase revenues," he said. "In 1997, they have to work."

HEADLINE: OUTLOOK '97: MARKETS & INVESTING;
Rising Dollar Has U.S. Executives a Bit Concerned

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
The dollar's rally last year against its two main rivals -- the Japanese yen and the German mark -- pushed the American currency up far enough that American executives have begun to worry anew about its impact on competitiveness, sales and profits.
The dollar was bolstered in 1996 by lower interest rates in Europe and Japan and better economic performance in the United States than abroad, both of which attracted foreign capital here. The outlook for this year is mixed. But even forecasters who see the dollar treading water this year think factors already in place could well move it higher toward the end of the century. 
 And that raises a question: Are American companies ready to deal with a stronger dollar?
Van Bussmann, chief economist at the Chrysler Corporation, thinks American auto makers have become quicker on their feet, a change seen throughout the country as American companies revived their competitiveness over the last decade.
But Mr. Bussmann is not sure that Americans are as nimble as the Japanese, who have made an art of surviving a strong yen by cutting costs and holding back price increases. "Maybe on average we cannot change as rapidly as the Japanese," he said, adding that most American companies would have a hard time matching the Toyota Motor Corporation's recent cost-cutting turnaround with its Camry model.
And he is worried that a weaker yen will augment Japan's cost-cutting advantage, adding to profits from sales in the United States and making it even easier for Japanese auto makers to avoid raising prices.
"If that nimbleness to reduce costs is supplemented by a depressed currency, that is a double whammy," Mr. Bussmann said.
Jerry J. Jasinowski, president of the National Association of Manufacturers, is also worried, both that American companies may have trouble with a stronger dollar and that despite the association's own forecast the dollar still might move higher in the year ahead.
"I think that despite the revolutionary changes American manufacturers have made to put them in a low-cost position, they are not adequately prepared to deal with a yen of 115 and higher," he said.
The dollar hit 116.18 yen on Monday, its highest since March 1993, and some forecasts for this year have it continuing to rise. It finished 1996 at 115.93 yen, up 12 percent for the year.
While Mr. Jasinowski is less concerned about the dollar's rise against the mark, which finished the year up 7.2 percent at 1.5415, he said a further strengthening would pressure American companies.
And the Clinton Administration should pay close attention to exchange rates, Mr. Jasinowski added. "Both Japan and Europe are looking to export their problems to the United States by manipulating their exchange rates," he warned. He said Japan, Germany and other European countries, especially France, were trying to bolster the dollar to kick-start their own economies by making their exports cheaper.
These concerns and jawboning by the Clinton Administration come at a time when the dollar has rallied 13.9 percent against the mark since its all-time low of 1.3534 and 43.8 percent against the yen from its all-time low of 80.63, clearly reducing a competitive advantage that helped earnings at many American companies.
If the dollar moves higher this year, American companies could try to press the Clinton Administration to help them out.
The National Association of Manufacturers is forecasting a decline in the value of the dollar, but Mr. Jasinowski said he saw "considerable risk on the upside."
Many Wall Street forecasters expect the dollar to rise at the beginning of 1997 but fall enough later to finish the year lower, easing the pressure on American companies.
That is the case at Goldman, Sachs & Company, where economists forecast rates of 105 yen and 1.45 marks to the dollar at the end of this year. The move down, according to the Goldman forecasters, will be propelled by a rising United States trade deficit and an expected increase in the outflow of United States capital as other countries' economies begin to pick up in 1997.
But Jim O'Neill, Goldman's chief currency economist, said he now expected the current strength of the dollar "will remain longer," taking the currency to 1.60 marks and 116 yen early this year.
The chief economist at Salomon Brothers, John Lipsky, said the dollar may not move much this year but is poised to go higher over the next several years.
"There are two good arguments to think that the dollar is in a period of longer-term recovery," Mr. Lipsky said.
Foreign investors, he said, still have higher inflation expectations for the United States than they do for Germany and Japan, and those expectations depress the value of the dollar. But this perception is likely to change if the current moderate rate of inflation here continues.
The second force is the expected buildup in the national savings rate as individuals invest more for retirement and the Clinton Administration and Congress move to cut the budget deficit.
Michael Rosenberg, head of international fixed-income research at Merrill Lynch & Company, forecasts that the dollar will shoot higher this year against both the yen and the mark and continue to rise thereafter. By the end of 1997, he forecasts rates of 120 yen and 1.70 marks to the dollar.
Similar forces are driving the dollar against both currencies, Mr. Rosenberg said. In Japan and Germany -- as well as most of the rest of Europe -- central bankers will keep interest rates low while governments cut spending (in Europe) and raise taxes (in Japan) to bring down their deficits. Such a policy mix, he said, is a prescription for a weaker currency, which means the dollar moves higher. Citing one example, Mr. Rosenberg said economic growth in Germany remained weak enough to prompt the Bundesbank, the German central bank, to cut key interest rates one more time, a move that could strengthen the dollar.
But Mr. Rosenberg, whose view is one of the most bullish on Wall Street, is less worried than others about the impact of a stronger dollar. "One reason the U.S. is so strong is that the dollar has been undervalued," he said, arguing that at 1.70 marks to the dollar, the American currency is still "undervalued by our calculations."
The strong dollar does not necessarily mean United States companies will lose market share, he said. "But the profits won't be so good," he added.

HEADLINE: OUTLOOK '97: MEDIA & TECHNOLOGY;
Even if Times Get Tough, the Technology Industry Is Expected to Shine

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER 

 BODY:
With the United States seemingly mired in a cycle of steady but slow growth and hundreds of companies struggling to eke out even small profit increases, the technology industry is a standout.
And at the companies that make computers, software and high-tech drugs, rising demand and increasing exports suggest strong growth will continue, largely independent of the overall economy. 
 The information science industry is currently benefiting from a convergence of technological advances: the release of the Microsoft Corporation's Windows NT, the operating system awaited by business customers; ever more powerful Pentium and Pentium Pro processors from the Intel Corporation; the shift to Intranets, which model internal computer networks on the technology of the global Internet, and compelling new software applications that need all that power and connectivity.
At the same time, the customer base has become far more global, while the United States has remained the dominant supplier. Even the poorest countries see a need to invest, while stronger economies in Asia and Latin America can help balance swings in demand at home.
Medical technology moves at a different pace from information science; product development times and product life cycles are measured in years rather than months. Nevertheless, growth is still driven by product innovation, which continues at a rapid pace. A handful of biotechnology companies became profitable in 1996 as their first drugs gained regulatory approval, and this exclusive club could grow rapidly in 1997, with as many as 30 new drugs nearing the market.
Innovative drugs and devices also drive double-digit growth at established companies like Pfizer Inc., Merck & Company and Johnson & Johnson. These concerns in effect have become large biotech companies, working in partnership with researchers in smaller companies and academia. Since one new drug for a major disease can rapidly generate $1 billion or more in revenue, the growth potential here is enormous.
"We really do have a profound change in our economic model, from a mass-produced, consumer-based economy to a global, technology-based economy," said Michael Murphy, publisher of the California Technology Stock Letter.
Analysts say that if growth slows in 1997, there would inevitably be some reduction in capital outlays, but history shows that most companies continue to invest in new technology, because it is a strategic asset. Suppliers with hot new products can thus maintain growth even in a recession.
"The deployment of information technology infrastructure is a solution to becoming more efficient," said Thomas A. Thornhill, director of technology research at Montgomery Securities. "Not doing it becomes a competitive issue; companies that fail to invest through the down cycle will emerge in a relatively weaker position on the other side."
A new breed of corporate software applications that can help increase sales has proved especially compelling, according to Mr. Thornhill. These applications in turn have driven sales of larger computers as well as new operating system software and networking equipment. These programs, like a sales management application from Siebel Systems Inc. called Sales Enterprise, do more than just reduce costs. "Because it's a revenue-generating product, there's a substantial willingness to pay for it," Mr. Thornhill said.
In addition to product cycles, economic, political and demographic shifts are driving growth for technology companies. The transition to an economy based on information and communications from one based on manufacturing means even small companies can address a global market. Meanwhile, the fall of Communism has opened new countries to American goods.
Roger McNamee, a principal in Integral Capital Partners, said the United States now faced an opportunity unmatched since 1946, when its powerful manufacturing base supplied the rebuilding of Western Europe.
"For a long time, the politics prevented you from selling to a lot of countries, even if they wanted to buy," Mr. McNamee said. "Now every country is on a market economy, and they need infrastructure to attract capital. You find third world countries putting in wireless telecom systems often before they put in running water and roads.
"We've gone from being able to sell to one-third of the world to selling to everybody." Mr. McNamee said, adding, "I believe technology will rise to about 15 percent of gross national product from about 8 or 9 percent now."
Young customers just entering the marketplace will also lift technology sales, according to Mr. McNamee. "Everyone in college today was born after the Apple II shipped; they don't know a world without computers," he said.
At the same time, their aging baby-boomer parents are ever more voracious consumers of health care. But with the continuing drive to push health care costs lower, the products that create sales growth must meet previously unmet needs, improve outcomes and lower costs -- and possibly produce phenomenal growth.
"When you have a breakthrough therapeutic agent in an underserved disease, most of the time people underestimate the impact," said Viren Mehta, an analyst with Mehta & Isaly. He notes that before the introduction of SmithKline Beecham P.L.C.'s Tagamet, the first modern ulcer drug, in 1979, the worldwide market for the previous therapy, mostly antacids, was just $150 million. Today, the market for Tagamet and other drugs like it is about $9 billion, with an additional $9 billion worldwide for a later generation of ulcer medications. "New classes of drugs quickly transform the way things are done," he said.
Mr. Mehta said the Warner-Lambert Company's new drug for diabetes, Rezulin, could rapidly become a multibillion-dollar product, and he pointed to as many as 30 new drugs in the late stages of clinical trials that could enter the market in 1997. These include cancer therapies from British Biotech P.L.C., the Idec Pharmaceuticals Corporation and Biocryst Pharmaceuticals Inc.; a platelet-cell generating drug from Genetics Institute Inc.; a new drug for CMV retinitis in AIDS patients from Isis Pharmaceuticals Inc., and a new drug for Lou Gehrig's disease developed jointly by the Chiron Corporation and Cephalon Inc.
"Compared to 16 companies that were cash-flow positive in 1995, we expect 50 in 2000," Mr. Mehta said.

HEADLINE: OUTLOOK '97: MEDIA & TECHNOLOGY;
Payoff Still Elusive In Internet Gold Rush

BYLINE: By SETH SCHIESEL 

 BODY:
Before corporate America's recent dash into cyberspace, the last time so many people went so far and spent so much to get so little was perhaps the gold rushes of the 19th century. In 1996, Internet lucre proved as elusive as the mother lode.
At least for the prospectors. Just as the stampedes to Sutter's Mill and the Yukon yielded far more broken hearts than bonanzas, the quest to make money on the Internet has been, for many entrepreneurs, as frustrating as navigating the World Wide Web. 
 And while the digital miners are meeting with spotty success, the real winners are those who sell axes, sluice pans and mules.
Ever optimistic, the companies betting on the Internet sales are sure success is just around the corner.
"The people who thought '96 was the gold rush were chasing fool's gold," said Kate Delhagen, an analyst at Forrester Research, a market research company in Cambridge, Mass., which estimated the Internet economy at $14.8 billion in 1996.
"Ninety-seven will be the first real year of action on line," she added.
Analysts, of course, were saying the same thing about 1996 a year ago. But at least a few more of the thousands of companies that have opened doors in the electronic shopping mall seem likely to turn the corner this year, if only because the heavy start-up costs required to become serious Internet merchants will recede farther behind them.
There are three main ways that companies (and individuals) are trying to make money on the Internet. The first is to develop content so compelling that people will pay to see it, a strategy that has succeeded mostly in the pornography market, but is also being followed by Encyclopaedia Britannica (http:// www.eb.com/) among others.
The second, and far easier, path is to sell advertising, generally consisting of little banners at the top of popular Web pages that with one click will take the user away to a Web site for, say, a taco. Many observers question the effectiveness of banner ads, and many users complain about finding sales pitches everywhere. But a few companies are attracting solid, if not spectacular, revenue from advertising.
Take the Starwave Corporation. A creation of Paul Allen, the other Microsoft billionaire, Starwave developed ESPNET Sportszone (http:// espnet.sportszone.com/), one of the most popular sites on the World Wide Web, as well as official sites for the National Basketball Association and the National Football League.
On an average day, Sportszone alone attracts about 400,000 people, who make almost 3 million visits to pages within the service, according to Michael B. Slade, Starwave's chief executive.
Starwave charges Sportszone advertisers $22.50 per thousand page visits, and so the company takes in at least $65,000 a day in advertising from Sportszone alone. Another 25 percent of company revenue comes from subscriptions from serious fans who are willing to pay for even more services, including sports news, statistics and fantasy leagues.
But even that is not enough. As a private company, Starwave is not required to release financial information, but Mr. Slade gave no indication that the enterprise is in the black. "I would be very surprised if any company in our realm is profitable," he said.
"It's probably reasonable to assume a business like ours, if it doubled, would be looking pretty good. And that will probably happen in the next year."
Advertisers seeking heavily used trails have clustered on the sites of the big World Wide Web search engines. Excite Inc., the Infoseek Corporation, Lycos Inc. and Yahoo Inc. all sell advertising. They all went public last year, though none has yet reported a profitable quarter.
The third road to Internet riches is taking orders on line for real-life products, a $518 million market in 1996, Forrester Research estimated. When experts talk about on-line retailers, one of the first names that comes up is Virtual Vineyards (http://www.virtualvin.com/), which is based in Palo Alto, Calif., and has shipped tens of thousands of bottles of Internet-ordered wine since early 1995.
Venture capitalists have invested about $3 million in the company, said Cyndy Ainsworth, the company's director of marketing. But are they profitable? "Not yet." How about next year? "Optimistically, I hope so." One reason that profits remain only virtual is that Virtual Vineyards had to make huge investments in both hardware and software to get its system up and running, Ms. Ainsworth said. Tack on a direct-mail promotional campaign that included offers of free biscotti, and starting an Internet business can get pretty expensive, she added.
Preview Travel Inc. (http:// www.previewtravel.com/), based in San Francisco, sold more than $1 million worth of airline tickets on the Internet in the first week of December. "Profitability for companies like ours is a late '97 event," said the company's chairman, Jim Hornphal.
But Jeff P. Bezos, founder and chief executive of Seattle-based Amazon.com (http://www.amazon.com), which bills itself as "Earth's biggest bookstore" and is generally regarded as one of the big Internet success stories, with sales increasing by more than one-third each month for the last 18 months, put things in a different light.
"We are not profitable," he said. "We could be. It would be the easiest thing in the world to be profitable. It would also be the dumbest. We are taking what might be profits and reinvesting them in the future of the business. It would literally be the stupidest decision any management team could make to make Amazon.com profitable right now."
So who is making money on the digital frontier? Wilderness guides and hired guns. Data networking companies like Cisco Systems Inc. and the 3Com Corporation are flush, as are a growing number of the designers who put Web sites together. They reap the investments other companies must make to join the on-line marketplace.
"I wouldn't say '97 is the year of the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow," said Starwave's Mr. Slade. "I'd say it's the year when things continue to improve.
"As a commercial medium, it is maybe 20 months old." he said. "That would be like cable TV in 1977, the magazine industry in 1800, radio at the turn of the century. Yet the pace of what's happened in 18 months is amazing."
