HEADLINE: Essay;
I Remember Larry

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
One of the unheralded spies of the postwar era was Larry Wu-tai Chin. As an agent of Chinese Communist intelligence, he penetrated the C.I.A. and served as Beijing's "mole" for more than two decades.
After his arrest in 1985, the spy -- true to his training -- foiled his captors and protected his superiors by using a plastic bag to commit suicide in his cell. Spymasters from Langley to Yasenovo agreed: Larry Wu-tai Chin was one great spy. 
 Memories of Larry are triggered by an unexamined facet of Clinton's Asian money scandal.
Chinese intelligence operations are sophisticated, patient, disciplined, and underrated by a C.I.A.-F.B.I. counterintelligence culture still transfixed by Primakov's disciples in Moscow. China's primary intelligence priority is no longer to steal military or nuclear secrets, as in Larry's day, but is now politico-economic espionage.
You don't have to be a conspiracy nut to recognize that China needs not only to learn trade secrets, but also to discover -- perhaps even influence -- U.S. Government trade policy and negotiating positions that directly affect the $35 billion balance-of-trade surplus essential to the growth of China's military and economic power.
This might fit that strategy:
* An Asian financial empire named Lippo shares ownership of a Hong Kong bank with Beijing known to be used by Chinese intelligence;
* the Lippo banking family, ethnic Chinese named Riady, climbs aboard the Clinton 1992 campaign;
* the family gives its former Hong Kong bank officer a $900,000 bonus and places him in a top-secret post in the newly elected President's Commerce Department, where he is privy to the development of policy ending restrictions on trade with China;
* the Lippo banker placed in Commerce continues frequent local and international telephone contact with his previous employers;
* on Sept. 13, 1994, James Riady and his Beijing-traveling lawyer (a founder of Little Rock's Rose Law Firm) agree with the President himself, in the Oval Office, to reassign the family's man from Commerce to the job of chief Asian fund-raiser for the 1996 Clinton campaign, and
* the Chinese-American banker channels in millions, and only newspaper exposure of illegal fronts for huge donations forces a reluctant Justice Department to investigate and a triumphant campaign to return some of the money.
Other strands: A Chinese-American restaurateur in Little Rock who travels frequently to Beijing raises over $600,000 in money from fronts for the Clintons' legal defense, is then able to bring Wang Jun, the most notorious Beijing arms dealer, inside the White House to meet the President for a reason as yet unexplained. Meanwhile, another illicit contributor from Asia is given substantial Presidential face time to deliver her pitch for trade preferences for China.
Is this a pattern of aggressive fund-raising, corrupt influence peddling -- or part of an intelligence operation?
The possibility of economic intelligence penetration is beyond the depth of Mark Richard, now trying to contain the investigation within Clinton Justice. Another person who should be on this job is Paul Redmond, the C.I.A.'s counterintelligence chief.
Redmond got the Angleton mole-hunting chair at Langley because he developed a distaste for Aldrich Ames before it was popular. But because Redmond's central experience was with the Soviet East European division, his mind is not set Asiaward, and he is in danger of becoming what David Cornwell calls an "espiocrat." His bosses are loath to unearth Clinton embarrassments, especially if the White House's Tony Lake is to be their new Director.
But House and Senate Intelligence Committees should be asking: have any of our assets in Asia been tasked to learn of penetrations of the Clinton Administration? Has the National Security Agency been "walking back the cat" -- putting its computers to work on miles of stored tapes, tracing overseas telephone or E-mail conversations of White House, Commerce, D.N.C. and Ex-Im Bank aides and Arkasian middlemen with foreign officials or cutouts?
Such evidence could not be used in court. But on national security matters, as Larry Wu-tai Chin's macabre victory taught us, it is sometimes more important to learn the extent of the damage than to put possible agents in jail.

HEADLINE: OUTLOOK '97: INTERNATIONAL;
China's Demand for Control Pits Ethics Against Profits

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
For China watchers, the first warning that Beijing was linking politics and trade in new ways came in 1994, when it demanded that Rupert Murdoch pull the BBC's news from Star TV, his direct broadcast venture based in Hong Kong.
Alarmed, Mr. Murdoch, who had boasted that his venture's small satellite dishes "posed an unambiguous threat to totalitarian regimes," immediately complied in the hopes of winning access to China's booming market. 
 More recently came Disney, which was warned in the fall that if it wanted to bring Mickey Mouse to Chinese children, it had better rethink its forthcoming film about the Dalai Lama of Tibet. Disney said it would ignore the veiled threats.
And China is still wrestling with Western news organizations, including Reuters and Dow Jones, over whether all of their products must flow through a Government-controlled spigot -- a plan that may be rooted as much in China's desire to skim a slice of the profits as to control the information that traders see on their desktop screens.
None of this should have been surprising; from Saudi Arabia to North Korea, governments around the world are trying to figure out ways to attract Western investment while still weeding out undesirable ideas.
But China has taken the balancing act to new levels. Its sheer size and rate of growth give it enormous leverage in dictating the terms under which it will open its markets to specific businesses. And Washington is uncertain whether it is willing to confront the political restrictions China is imposing -- just at a time that it has delinked trade issues from human rights concerns.
"We don't know how to tackle this one," one of President Clinton's most senior economic advisers acknowledged here recently. "It's one thing if a country insists that you build airplane parts on their territory in return for buying a bunch of Boeings. We understand the politics of how to handle that. But everything gets a lot stickier when they insist that if you want access to their market, you have to help maintain their dictatorship."
China doesn't portray the issue that baldly, of course. But more and more it is asserting a right to open its market -- especially to new investment -- only to those companies that are willing to accept China's view of itself and the world.
In fact, the politics of dealing with that problem are enormously complex. Companies are forced to make the agonizing choice of whether to bend to China's wishes, or to risk future access to a multibillon-dollar market. Should software vendors bend to China's demands for "filtering" features that would cut off access to anything in cyberspace that Beijing finds politically incorrect? Should providers of news programming tailor their offerings to Beijing's demands, or simply walk away from a huge potential market?
Critics of China on Capitol Hill point to China's effort to intimidate the likes of Disney or Star TV to bolster their argument that the Administration was foolish to draw an arbitrary distinction between trade issues and human rights. Mr. Clinton may have "delinked" China's trading rights from its human rights performance in 1994, they argue, but the Chinese themselves are relinking those issues in 1996.
If Beijing feels free to link Disney's right to build theme parks in Southern China to the kind of movies it makes about the Dalai Lama, these critics argue, why should the United States fear to link China's rights to sell goods in America to how it treats its dissidents?
"It's a tempting bit of logic," said Robert Zoellick, who was James A. Baker 3d's chief strategist at the Treasury Department and later at the State Department. "And certainly the Chinese would be wise to be careful about the kind of links they create. But we have to be careful, too. The key to credibility when you threaten to use trade sanctions is that you really have to be willing to pull the trigger in the name of human rights and other democratic concepts." Sometimes, of course, the United States is willing to pull the trigger and cut access to American markets -- but usually when the economic stakes do not amount to much. Washington has cut off nearly all trade with the repressive Government of Myanmar, but Myanmar, formerly Burma, does not exactly rank among the world's great trading nations.
But when it comes to China, the political and financial stakes are far greater, and Washington still walks on egg shells. It has quietly protested the effort to force Dow Jones & Company, Reuters and others to funnel all their news services to China through the state-run news agency, Xinhua. But American officials almost never talk about the problem on the record and try to cast it as a commercial dispute -- whether Xinhua has a right to part of the revenues for the torrent of information flowing into China's trading rooms -- rather than a free- expression issue. And it is on difficult ground protesting China's restrictions on direct-broadcast television; after all, broadcasters here are licensed by the Federal Communication Commission.
"There are some issues of enormous political sensitivity that you are better to deal with privately, quietly," Charlene Barshefsky, the acting United States trade representative, said.
So can China achieve its goal: Keep the investment money pouring in, while keeping a tight rein on the investors? Its model is Singapore: one of the world's freest trading ports, but a country that filters CNN broadcasts, bans private ownership of direct-broadcast television dishes and regularly drags Western newspapers, from The Asian Wall Street Journal to The International Herald Tribune, into court.
But the battleground for this contest of wills is Hong Kong. For a century the city-state has enjoyed its status as one of the world's great commercial centers in part because it married free trade with an open society. And it is there, this year, that China will truly test its thesis that you can enjoy the benefits of the first without enduring the discomfort of the second.

SECTION: Section C; Page 24; Column 3; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1227 words

HEADLINE: OUTLOOK '97: MARKETS & INVESTING;
Some Big Rewards and Some Letdowns Overseas

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
A year ago, many stock market pundits were urging American investors to plumb foreign markets for returns that they said were unlikely to be matched at home.
The sharp run-up in American stock prices during the 1990's was due to peter out, the argument went, and lagging overseas markets were overdue for a strong rally. 
 The logic may have been impeccable, but the timing was wrong.
"In general, it was a pretty good year for people investing in overseas markets, which, with the exception of Japan, posted returns in the mid-teens," said M. David Testa, chairman of Rowe Price-Fleming International, a unit of T. Rowe Price that manages more than $25 billion in foreign equities. "That would look very nice were it not for the fact that the United States did better."
Indeed. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 26 percent and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index was up 20.3 percent in 1996. By comparison, investors who put their money into an international fund weighted along the lines of Morgan Stanley's broad Europe, Australia and Far East (EAFE) index would have posted returns of just 3.8 percent.
But the EAFE index, which includes the major global markets and is weighted by market size, tells only one piece of the story.
"When you compare the U.S. market to the international benchmark, the American market wins hands down," said Jeffrey Russell, a managing director at Smith Barney and manager of the firm's $1.3 billion International Equity Portfolio.
"But that benchmark is heavily weighted to Japan, which has been the poorest market of all for a dollar-based investor," Mr. Russell said. "A number of not insignificant markets, like Hong Kong, Ireland, Sweden and the Netherlands, were all up more than 20 percent for a dollar-based investor."
A rise in the value of the dollar against a number of major currencies also cut into returns. But portfolio managers note that a rising currency is not always an unmitigated disaster, especially for funds that hedge their investments.
Further, since a slew of major foreign corporations earn big chunks of their revenues and profits in the United States, a stronger dollar generates bigger numbers when the money is repatriated. That, in turn, tends to increase local equity values, especially in the stocks that are most likely to attract foreign investors.
"It may sound perverse, but you make a little bit more money in a slightly firmer dollar environment," Mr. Russell said.
Strategists argued further that while all major markets, including the United States, benefited from favorable fundamentals like falling interest rates and low inflation, two additional factors were uniquely American: huge inflows of capital and the pressure on corporations from investors that led to the corporate mergers and reorganizations that played a leading role in the big earnings of recent years.
Similar pressures began to reach a number of European markets last year, with positive results.
In Germany, for example, companies like Daimler-Benz and BASF saw their stock prices move sharply higher as they set out to cut costs. Analysts said the theme of corporate restructuring was a big reason the German DAX index of 30 stocks rose 19.7 percent last year, in dollar terms. "German companies who are enhancing shareholder value are being rewarded," said Nicholas Horsley, co-manager of the $6 billion International Equity Fund at Warburg Pincus.
The wave of revamping barely lapped at France last year, but prices on the Paris Bourse nevertheless advanced 16.2 percent.
While corporate reorganization was a dominant theme in European markets, political concerns were paramount in Asia.
That was perhaps most true in Japan, where a lack of political will to address longstanding problems in the country's economy and financial system pushed stock prices down yet again, continuing a precipitous decline that began in 1989.
For the year, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 12.9 percent in dollar terms, even though the Bank of Japan pushed down interest rates to rock bottom levels.
And the value of the yen, which fell against the dollar throughout most of 1996, did not do much to restore a positive attitude among international portfolio managers about Japanese equities.
Despite its steep descent over the last seven years, that market is still far from cheap, many investors say.
"The stock market is off 50 percent, and it is still more expensive than the United States," said Mark G. Holowesko, manager of the Templeton Foreign Fund, which has $9.6 billion under management. "And if the market dropped another 30 percent to 50 percent, it would still not be abnormally cheap."
Hong Kong, even in the face of China's coming takeover, performed well last year.
"Hong Kong has been a good steady up market all year long," Mr. Testa of Rowe Price Fleming said. "People are quite optimistic about how the China takeover will play out."
For the year, the Hang Seng index was up 33.5 percent in dollar terms.
Political instability in countries like South Korea and Thailand hit those markets hard, and both posted significant declines. But in Taiwan, where stock prices took a nose dive early last year in response to saber-rattling by the Chinese, the market rebounded sharply once that crisis evaporated. As measured by the Taiwan weighted index, Taiwanese stocks rose by more than 33.4 percent in dollar terms.
"It has been a great year in Taiwan," Mr. Horsley of Warburg Pincus said. "It is no longer a cheap market."
Markets in Latin America continued to climb out of the deep hole created by the Mexican peso devaluation in late 1994, a crisis that plunged Mexico into a deep recession and cast a pall over the entire region for much of 1995.
Of the major Latin markets, Brazil did the best by far last year, rising about 50 percent in dollar terms. Mexican stock prices also improved, but less than stock prices in Brazil. For the year, Mexican stocks rose 18 percent.
"Mexico has been more volatile, because people are still nervous about the peso," Mr. Testa said. "But the economy seems to have bottomed, stocks appear cheap and money is going in."
The region's most spectacular performer was Venezuela. Stock prices in this small, highly volatile and generally illiquid market skyrocketed by nearly 100 percent, in dollar terms, as fears that the country might go into default receded.
"A large part of the equity revaluation is about the elimination of credit risk, not prospects for earnings growth," Mr. Horsley said.
Looking ahead to 1997, analysts said they were confident that their broad predictions would finally come true and foreign markets would outperform America's.
With the exception of France, which has high unemployment and an apparent unwillingness to cut government spending, the analysts are almost uniformly optimistic about Europe. And while Latin America holds promise, selected Asian markets like South Korea are a far better comparative value, they said.
"The market is fairly valued in Europe right now, assuming the Europeans do nothing," said Albert D. Richards, the head of European equity research at Salomon Brothers in London. "That gives you a free option on the benefits from restructuring, and I kind of like free options. The potential of unlocking value in some of these companies is enormous."

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: OUTLOOK '97: ECONOMY & INDUSTRY;
Those Vicious Business Cycles: Tamed but Not Quite Slain

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
THE stock market was booming. Companies were fighting their way into fast-growing foreign markets. Technology was transforming many industries.
A blue-chip panel of business leaders, economists and government officials hailed "the dynamic equilibrium of recent years," and the "organic balance of economic forces." Their report on the nation's economic outlook concluded: "Our situation is fortunate, our momentum remarkable." 
 The time was mid-1929.
Economists have never displayed much skill in predicting recessions. But one thing is common, historians have found, to most periods just before a downturn -- the emergence of a widespread belief that this time we have found the magic elixir to produce an extended period of prosperity.
So it may be tempting fate now that so many economists, policy makers and business executives, looking out over an economic landscape defined by years of moderate growth and low inflation, are willing to judge the business cycle tempered if not tamed. But for all the risk of incurring the wrath of the economic gods -- and with the important caveat that recessions can never be completely ruled out -- it is clear that the economy has undergone such sweeping changes that it is arguably better equipped to maintain its long-run equilibrium.
"I have felt for a long time that the business cycle was diminishing in its severity, but it has not by any means been vanquished," Geoffrey H. Moore, the director of the Economic Cycle Research Institute in New York, said.
"The length of expansions has tended to increase, and we're certainly having another exhibition of that in this case," he said. "The severity of the contractions or recessions that happen during the next phase of the cycle has been diminishing."
The National Association of Business Economists recently surveyed its members, and found few who saw anything but sustainable growth and low inflation ahead.
"While all business cycles eventually end, almost all of the 44 economists who responded to the survey expect economic expansion to continue for the foreseeable future," the association said. "That conclusion may not be precisely what Ludwig van Beethoven had in mind in his cantata 'Calm Sea and Prosperous Voyage,' but the approximation appears to be close."
In March, the current expansion will be six years old. It is the third-longest recovery on record, and if a recession does not strike in the next three years, it will become the longest peacetime expansion, overtaking the 92-month recovery in the 1980's.
Just after the turn of the century, if growth continued apace, the expansion would break the 106-month record set in the 1960's when the Vietnam War gave the economy a boost. And if that is still a bit far off to contemplate seriously, there is still little to suggest that the economy will deviate any time soon from its path of moderate growth and low inflation.
The Federal Reserve seems to have hit on just the right monetary policy formula, with unemployment low but wage and price increases showing no acceleration. Congress and the Clinton Administration are pledging fiscal responsibility.
By continuing to invest in new equipment and squeezing more efficiencies from their work forces, companies have managed to maintain profit growth. Despite a veiled warning about the dangers of a speculative bubble from Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, the stock market has so far held on to nearly all of its huge gains the last few years. And there is an increasing consensus that faulty statistics have led us to overstate inflation and understate improvements in growth, productivity and other indicators of economic well-being.
Still, to the extent that bumps along the economic road have been smoothed over, stability has come at a substantial cost. Improvements in productivity in recent years have come in part from wide-scale layoffs, creating a new level of anxiety in the work force. And among business and political leaders, there are those who argue that stability has been bought at the price of forgone growth and opportunity.
"We're taking a low-risk approach to policy," said Tracy O'Rourke, chairman of Varian Associates, a health care and semiconductor equipment company in Palo Alto, Calif. "I can increase my production significantly faster than I can sell units."
Moreover, a more moderate business cycle does not necessarily foster progress in dealing with other deep-rooted problems, like income inequality. Most emphatically, it does not mean that individual companies or entire industries will escape upheaval.
Indeed, some of the same forces that are dampening the economy's ups and downs, most notably the globalization of competition, are speeding the life cycles of products and technology in other industries. That puts more pressure on companies and their employees and creates an environment in which political pressure to "do something," such as erecting trade barriers or providing a special tax break, erupts regularly.
Still, to the degree that it averted painful downturns and created an environment in which businesses could make plans with some degree of certainty about future conditions, a long-term moderation of the business cycle would be one of the great economic achievements of this half century.
Of course, the economy's true resilience will be determined only as it is tested by imbalances of one kind or another. But a recent study by the National Association of Manufacturers, a leading proponent of the idea that the economy can grow faster, sought to calculate what would happen if any one of several big problems afflicted the economy in coming years. In no case did the group's study show the economy going into recession, or anywhere near it.
If consumer spending fell by $40 billion over six months, or less than 2 percent, the growth rate of the overall economy this year would be trimmed to 2 percent from the association's current projection of 2.4 percent, the group said. If Congress and the Clinton Administration fail to agree this year on a plan to balance the budget and long-term interest rates rise by half a percentage point as a result, the economy would grow about half a point more slowly than expected.
Similarly, the group found that a half-point increase in inflation would knock less than half a point off the growth rate.
Even a rise in oil prices, which have been highly volatile in the last year, would barely budge the economy. The manufacturers association said that a $5-a-barrel increase in oil prices would cut growth by half a point.
Economists generally agree that expansions do not die of old age. They end because of a policy mistake -- allowing inflation to get out of hand or stepping too hard on inflation and extinguishing growth -- or because of an external shock, like a surge in oil prices or a war, that is too powerful for even good policy to contain.
The chances of being thrown off track by an external shock are by definition unknowable, and in that sense, a downturn is always a possibility. On the other hand, the Federal Reserve has brought the nation closer to price stability than would have been imaginable 20 years ago. And the Federal Government, after a spasm of fiscal irresponsibility 15 years ago, is no longer debating whether austerity is necessary and achievable, but how much the nation should sacrifice to achieve it. As a result, the likelihood of a whopping policy blunder seems relatively low.
Moreover, many economists said, policy stability is only the beginning.
"Are we guaranteed that forever and in all ways the Fed will continue to get it right in the future?" asked Mark Dadd, the president of the National Association of Business Economists and the chief economist at the AT&T Corporation. "Certainly not. But there is reason to believe that there are other things going on that could reduce the severity of any downturn."
On the most sweeping level, inflation is arguably less of a threat than it has been in decades. The reasons go beyond just tight monetary and fiscal policy. Some economists -- and many business executives -- contend that ever-increasing global competition and the changing nature of the relationship between employer and worker has constrained if not broken the old pattern of wage-price spirals.
Executives in many industries report being caught in a pricing stasis. They cannot raise prices for their products, so they refuse to pay higher prices for raw materials and supplies.
"We've been resisting any price increases from our suppliers because it's very difficult for us to pass those along to our customers," said Ronald D. Bullock, the chief executive of the Bison Gear and Engineering Company, a maker of electric gear motors in St. Charles, Ill.
At the same time, the declining power of unions, the willingness of workers to accept pay raises at or below the inflation rate, slower growth in health insurance costs, layoffs and the fear of them and new wrinkles in employment, such as using contract workers, have conspired to keep compensation costs down.
On a more mundane but no less important level, companies have achieved better control of a nuts-and-bolts business issue -- managing inventories -- that has always played a critical role in the economy's stability, or lack thereof.
In the past, the economy often tipped into recession when companies had built up inventories of products or supplies when demand had slowed, forcing them to cut back production or new orders, thereby reinforcing the slowing or the contraction of the economy.
But now, all along the supply chain, companies are ordering only as much as they can use or sell immediately. In the personal computer industry, for example, companies like Dell and Compaq manufacture a machine only when they have an order in hand, and they buy components accordingly. Taking advantage of technology to give them up-to-date information about stock levels and consumer demand, retailers are keeping minimal inventory on hand, and are demanding quick turnaround times from suppliers when they do make an order.
"Our customers are not placing orders with us except on an immediate-ship basis," said Warren Batts, chairman of Premark International, which makes small appliances. "They're not overstocking at all, not taking any chances of overstocking. This is new."
For all the positive structural changes, however, economists warned that the economy's apparent equilibrium should not be taken for granted.
"There is nothing structural that eliminates the possibility of business accumulating inventories too rapidly, then having to disgorge them," Richard D. Rippe, chief economist at Prudential Securities, said.
More broadly, he said, there is no assurance that wage increases and commodity prices will remain level and that financial markets will continue their upward march.
"The picture right now looks very good," Mr. Rippe said, "but the notion that it couldn't turn for the worse is too optimistic a view."

GRAPHIC: Chronology: "An Easier Economic Climb"
 Historically, economic growth, as measured by changes in the gross domestic product, generally moved from one extreme to another. But recently, the peaks and valleys in the business cycle have diminished. A number of experts, while warning that recessions will still occur, argue that broad economic changes should help ease the ups and downs of the path ahead.
 
FALL '81 -- 4.4 percent growth in G.D.P.
 
SPRING '84 -- 8.2 percent growth in G.D.P.
 
FALL '96 -- 2.3 percent growth in G.D.P. (Source: Datastream)
 
OCTOBER 1973 -- Arab oil embargo begins and oil prices soon double, setting off an inflationary spiral. Recession begins shortly after, lasting until March 1975
 
AUGUST 1975 -- Paul A. Volker is appointed chairman of the Federal Reserve and raises interest rates to curb inflation of more than 13 percent. Prime rate eventually surpasses 20 percent.
 
JULY 1981 -- Congress passes Reagan tax cut. That, along with a rise in mililtary spending and a sharp recession, send the budget deficit soaring. Unemployment soon hits postwar high of 9.7 percent.
 
NOVEMBER 1982 -- An economic expansion, the second-longest of the postwar era, begins, lasting until July 1990.
 
AUGUST 1987 -- Alan Greenspan takes over as chairman of the Federal Reserve. On Oct. 19, Dow falls 508 points, or 22.6 percent.
 
JULY 1990 -- Iraq invades Kuwait, sending oil prices above $40 a barrel, worsening a recession that began a month earlier.
 
MARCH 1991 -- Current economic expansion, now the third longest since World War II, begins.
 
OCTOBER -- Interest rates reach 20-year low. Yield on 30-year Treasury bond hits 5.75 percent.
 
SEPTEMBER 1996 -- Moderate economic growth continues, unemployment and inflation remain low.

HEADLINE: There's Little Hope in Sight For Treasures of St. Louis

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: ST. LOUIS

 BODY:
The Ambassador Theater. The Arcade/Wright Building. The Statler Hotel. The Fur Exchange.
St. Louis's rich trove of mid-19th-century office buildings is crumbling, the victim of a downtown economy that has seen better days. Intricate brickwork is falling apart, copper cornices are deteriorating, and fine terra cotta details are eroding from many facades. Some of the most neglected buildings have been demolished. 
 But preservationists here say many remaining buildings, some of which have city or national landmark status, could be saved if city officials helped developers interested in transforming them into apartments and stores.
"The architecture represents St. Louis, its history and its heritage," said Doris Danna, president of the Landmarks Association of St. Louis. "If we care about our history and our roots, we have to have the physical manifestation. Otherwise, we look like any other place on earth."
Mrs. Danna and others argue for preservation out of more than just a respect for the past. They say restoring old buildings in the city's downtown would draw people to work, shop and even live there. In short, they say, renovation will help eliminate the reason for the buildings' deterioration.
But while other cities, including Denver, Baltimore and Cleveland, have restored older buildings as part of downtown revitalization projects, officials here say St. Louis is choked with too many unusable old structures. They contend that revitalization here depends on quickly getting rid of buildings that do not have an immediate use and developing the new structures that will make the downtown thrive.
"To have real progress, some of this stuff has to come down," Mayor Freeman R. Bosley said in an interview. "We do not have the people for all this infrastructure."
Mayor Bosley said the city's revitalization plans did not include preserving all of its older buildings, no matter how beautiful or historically important, because the St. Louis of the 1990's was so different from the St. Louis of the 19th century.
Many older buildings date from an era when employment in downtown St. Louis was 300,000, at least three times as much as now, he said.
Indeed, large swatches of downtown are dominated by boarded-up retail stores; a shopping mall that opened in 1985, the St. Louis Centre, still has vacancies. On some streets, it seems as though little more than parking lots are open. There are few pedestrians, except office workers at lunchtime, and the area is nearly empty at night. Less than 1 percent of the city's population of 360,000 lives in the downtown area.
"People don't realize this region went through a terrible time economically from 1970 to 1985," said Richard C. Ward, a local economic consultant. "We were one of the few metropolitan areas that actually lost population from the metropolitan area, not just from the city to the suburbs."
A few architectural treasures have been renovated, including Union Station, now a shopping mall; the Wainwright Building, by the architects Adler and Sullivan, which is now a state office building, and the domed courthouse where Dred Scott sued for his freedom from slavery in 1847, a suit that he lost 10 years later. The city also has a glistening, newly restored riverfront section, Laclede's Landing.
But most of these projects date from the 1970's and early 80's, when there was abundant Federal support, through tax credits and urban development money, for renovation. That money dried up in the mid-1980's.
Richard Baron, a St. Louis developer who is president of McCormack, Baron & Associates, said that in recent years local business leaders had generously supported big-ticket items like new athletic stadiums, a convention center and museums.
But business executives neglected the city's infrastructure, Mr. Baron said, neither making commitments to put offices in historic buildings nor investing in downtown housing.
"The kind of things that have happened in places like Cleveland just haven't happened here," he said. "Executives have basically said, 'Give me a glass box and I'll be happy.' "
In the preservationists' view, glass boxes do not help rejuvenate an area.
"Look at Union Station," Mrs. Danna said. "People come to visit those kinds of things in cities. They don't come to see generic office buildings they can see anywhere."
Richard C. D. Fleming, president and chief executive officer of the St. Louis Regional Commerce and Growth Association, who was formerly involved with revitalization efforts in Denver and Baltimore, said St. Louis had all the ingredients for the same kind of invigorated downtowns as those cities.
What St. Louis has lacked, Mr. Fleming said, is a partnership between government and business.
"We need a common game plan," he added. "In Denver, we would have killed for the architectural character we have to work with in St. Louis. But you can't turn around 50 to 75 years of disinvestment overnight."
Mr. Ward faults both the preservationists and the business community.
"We've been stalemated," he said. "Historic preservationists have been unwilling to participate in a compromise strategy. The business interests haven't had the stomach to take it on, because they get painted as scoundrels if they raise the issue, so nothing happens."
Preservationists tried to strike a compromise with city and business interests in a two-year planning initiative that ended in 1994, said Carolyn H. Toft, executive director of the Landmarks Association of St. Louis.
But Ms. Toft said city officials had ignored that plan, which called for a mix of old and new architecture.
Mayor Bosley said that without more businesses moving downtown, renovation projects were useless. Noting that two office buildings renovated in the late 1980's are now sitting vacant, with no takers for their office space, he said that it made no sense to invest limited city money in such projects.
And as much as a revitalized downtown is desirable, the Mayor added, the city's prosperity depends at least as much on other initiatives: the expansion of Lambert International Airport, a search to attract 100,000 jobs to the region by the end of the year 2000, and a $127 million public-private partnership to build homes on the site of a former high-rise public housing development.
"There is a lot to be said about the historic buildings," Mr. Bosley said. "Let us identify those that need to be saved. And let us agree to make room for other buildings and get on with it."

HEADLINE: OUTLOOK '97: MEDIA & TECHNOLOGY;
Year of Intense Activity Looms for Phone Industry, Experts Say

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER

 BODY:
After a year of historic legislation, heated litigation and no fewer than four multibillion-dollar mergers, even the most confident are reluctant to venture an opinion about what changes 1997 will bring to the roiling telecommunications industry.
"It's hard to predict 100-year floods," said Pierce J. Roberts Jr., an investment banker at Bear, Stearns & Company who has advised the Nynex Corporation on its planned $22 billion merger with the Bell Atlantic Corporation, last April. 
 With deregulation now the law of the land, most experts believe that the telephone business can only become more competitive this year. The tougher economic realities that competition will bring also suggest that more phone companies will pursue mergers or takeovers.
But the onset of competition will be a messy, hard-fought process -- with the long-distance and local carriers haggling over every nuance of the rules of engagement. And those detours into court could further delay the free-market free-for-all that the Telecommunications Act of 1996 was meant to uncork.
"Our early experience is that it takes a long time to get even a modest, controlled rollout of competition," John D. Zeglis, general counsel of the AT&T Corporation, said. Already, the GTE Corporation and other local phone companies have persuaded a Federal appeals court to suspend new Government regulations on how the local phone companies must open up their local networks to AT&T and other rivals. GTE contends that the Federal Communications Commission has no jurisdiction to set these so-called interconnection rules.
The next phase of rule-making -- in which the F.C.C. will revamp the web of subsidies that guarantee universal telephone service -- could ignite fresh legal challenges.
"This could be as contentious, or even more contentious, than the interconnection rules, since universal service is about real money," said Scott Cleland, managing director of the Schwab Washington Research Group, a consulting firm.
Among other things, the Clinton Administration is pushing for the phone companies to pledge to wire the nation's schools and hospitals for high-speed access to the Internet -- an ambitious program that could add $2.25 billion to the cost of providing universal phone service.
The trouble is that under the new rules the 50 states will be responsible for collecting the subsidies that guarantee universal service. So if the F.C.C. were to make such a provision part of the new universal service regulations, Mr. Cleland predicted that at least one state government would immediately challenge the rules in court.
New kinds of competition will not necessarily wait for all these court cases to be settled. AT&T is already offering local phone service to a small number of customers in Sacramento, Calif., Mr. Zeglis said. And the Ameritech Corporation, which offers local service in five Midwestern states, plans to file for permission to offer long distance next week.
"We can start competing in spite of the court case," said Richard C. Notebaert, chairman of Ameritech, which has signed interconnection agreements with about a dozen would-be competitors, including the MFS Communications Company and Time Warner Inc.
As the long-distance and local carriers invade each other's markets, they will probably continue to seek partners -- extending a wave of consolidation that began last year with the back-to-back mergers of Bell Atlantic with Nynex and SBC Communications Inc. with Pacific Telesis Group.
"You'll see more mergers because you've still got several companies hanging out there," said Alex J. Mandl, the former president of AT&T, who stunned the industry last August when he left to take over an obscure wireless company, Associated Communications.
Some of the most obvious pairings, like the two Bell deals, were done in 1996. Even the takeover of the MCI Communications Corporation by British Telecommunications P.L.C. was not completely unexpected, since British Telecommunications has owned 20 percent of MCI since 1994.
Still, investment bankers sketched out several other deals that would put together long-distance and local carriers. GTE, which explored an alliance with MCI before the British Telecommunications merger was announced, is still eager to join forces with another major carrier, according to people familiar with the company. AT&T looms as the most obvious candidate, since its long-distance network would mesh well with GTE's sprawling local presence.
Companies that provide alternative local phone service could also prove alluring to long-distance carriers seeking to expand into the $90 billion local phone business. The largest of these companies, Teleport Communications Group, has been rumored to be a takeover target for months.
And while the British Telecommunications-MCI combination may raise thorny regulatory issues, analysts predict it will not be the last cross-border alliance. They suggest that Sprint could eventually be acquired by its European partners, Deutsche Telekom and France Telecom, each of which currently owns 10 percent of Sprint.
What does all this activity portend for consumers? Experts said the rise of competition -- and even the spate of deals -- could reduce certain phone rates. Indeed, there are signs that the creation of a trans-Atlantic telephone company in British Telecommunications-MCI could erode the system of artificially inflated calling rates between the United States and Europe.
Yet in the domestic local phone business, where the most revolutionary changes were supposed to occur, the outlook for consumers is murky. The regional Bell companies are zealously defending their local franchises. And long-distance carriers like AT&T and MCI are focusing on business customers ahead of the less profitable residential market.
"The real disappointment of the telecom act is that there is going to be very little residential competition," Mr. Cleland said.
That may be overly pessimistic. But given the raft of lawsuits that seems likely to tie up the process in the courts through this year, it is possible that this new era of telecommunications will be known for now less for its cheaper monthly bills than for its expensive wheeling and dealing.

HEADLINE: OUTLOOK '97: INTERNATIONAL;
Sellers in Search of Buyers in a Global Marketplace

BYLINE: By GLENN COLLINS

 BODY:
Just try to find a news release or an earnings report from a major United States consumer-products company that does not cite international growth as the panacea for future profits.
 
 There are compelling reasons for companies to seek happiness "offshore," as American chief executives like to say, mainly that revenues and profits are modest at home and in much of the industrialized world, while spending on consumer goods is rising significantly in many other parts of the globe.
 In the United States, intense competition in many product categories and a rise in private-label and store brands are taking their toll on profits.
 And in a time of low inflation and consumer fickleness, American companies can no longer raise profits by routinely raising prices. After years of restructuring to raise the bottom line, some companies are in danger of "cutting into muscle instead of flab, if they're not careful," said Terry Bivens, an analyst at Donald & Company Securities.
 To help fuel their profit engines, United States companies are aiming for double-digit growth in developing markets. But these days, going global is really the "duh" strategy: everybody is there already. And trying to Americanize the world is not such an easy layup.
 For starters, foreign competitors are becoming leaner and meaner as they imitate American companies' compulsion to downsize, said Nomi Ghez, an analyst for Goldman, Sachs.
 "The trend that started in the United States is now expanding into European companies," Ms. Ghez said. "They are becoming more shareholder oriented as they learn the new language of shareholder value."
 Moving into foreign markets can prove difficult for newcomers from the United States. For example, distribution can offer daunting logistical challenges in places where mom-and-pop stores, not Wal-Marts, are the norm. The optimum delivery vehicle may have two wheels rather than 18, as in China.
 Then there are the cultural differences. The Owens-Corning Fiberglas Corporation had to conduct expensive market testing before introducing its Pink Panther cartoon mascot in Europe. The worry was that Hollywood's bumbling French detective, Inspector Jacques Clouseau, protagonist of the "Pink Panther" movies, might be perceived as insulting to Europeans. They did not take offense.
 And local taste preferences dictated to Pepsico Inc. that it remove the cheese from its Cheetos in China: the snack-food equivalent of removing, says, the cola from Pepsi-Cola. And so, the Chinese were given a choice between cheeseless Cheetos with a teriyaki taste and Cheetos with a butter popcorn flavor.
 Finally, as always in foreign ventures, a company could use a little luck. Upon arriving in China, Pepsico's Cheetos team happily discovered that the Chinese characters "qi duo" (pronounced CHEE dwaugh) meant "new surprise" instead of - well, some phrase "that might offend people," a Pepsico spokesman said.

HEADLINE: New '97 Laws On Drinking, And Driving And Divorce

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Florida lawmakers who take gifts in the form of food and drinks from lobbyists in 1997 had better report them. In Michigan, should parents divorce and neglect child support payments, their driver's licenses may be revoked.
Across the country, thousands of ideas that made their way from committee to governor's desk became law yesterday. 
 Chemical castration, race track card games and mandatory bicycle helmets are in. Drunken hunting and children's driving high-powered boats are out.
Florida, Indiana and Kansas are among those getting tough on underage drinking and driving. Those states now label any young driver with a blood-alcohol content of 0.02 -- about one drink -- legally drunk and subject to a license suspension.
"This no-nonsense, anti-D.U.I. law will meet its potential as the most powerful preventative measure possible against teen drinking and driving," said State Representative Bob Casey, a Gainesville Republican who sponsored the measure in Florida.
New mothers, who had been hustled out the hospital doors at the behest of insurance companies, now have the option of longer hospital stays in New York and New Hampshire. New York guarantees a two-day maternity stay for mothers who want it and a four-day stay after Caesarean sections. A similar Federal law takes effect in 1998. New Hampshire's new law lets mother and doctor decide when to go home.
Other notable laws included these:
*North Carolina, by way of a constitutional amendment, became the last state to give veto power to its governor.
*Florida now requires children under 16 to wear helmets while bicycling and to allow race tracks and jai alai frontons to set up low-stakes card rooms. The state also added food and drink to the list of gifts that lawmakers must report.
*Michigan and Wisconsin may strip fathers of their driver's or occupational licenses if the men are 90 days late in paying child support.
*Arizona eased its ban on fireworks to allow the sale of sparklers, poppers and other non-explosive devices. Also, the state now requires divorcing parents to take a course on the impact of divorce on children.
*New Hampshire will now subject anyone convicted of boating while intoxicated to the same penalties imposed for driving drunk, including license revocation. It also mandated up to seven years in prison for hunters who hurt someone while drunk.
*Minnesota will bar children under 12 from operating motorboats of more than 75 horsepower. They can still drive less powerful boats, as long as an adult is near the controls.
In California, Gov. Pete Wilson signed into law 1,171 bills that, among other things, require some child molesters to undergo chemical castration with injections of the drug Depo-Provera, which dampens sexual desire.
California also increased prison terms for vehicular manslaughter from 4-to-10 years to 15 years to life under "Courtney's Law," named for a Roseville teen-ager who was killed by a drunken driver who had four previous convictions.
On the Federal level, too, the turn of the new year activated a variety of laws, from the arcane to the widely felt. They included these:
*A tax credit of up to $5,000 for most adoptions, $6,000 for adoption of a hard-to-place child, available to families with incomes below $115,000.
*Higher fees at many national parks, as part of a plan to raise fees at 100 parks in stages.
*A 2.9 percent cost-of-living increase in Social Security and Supplemental Security Income benefits.
*A 3 percent raise for the military.
*The lapsing of a 10 percent Federal tax on commercial airline tickets. Airlines are planning to pocket the savings, however, rather than pass them on to travelers.
*Allowing people ages 65 to 69 to earn $13,500 a year without losing any Social Security benefits, up from $12,500.
*Allowing small-business owners to deduct 40 percent of the cost of their health insurance premiums, up from 30 percent.
*Allowing penalty-free withdrawals from Individual Retirement Accounts to cover health insurance premiums, available to the unemployed. Penalty-free withdrawals to cover medical expenses for certain workers with high health bills.
The tax breaks are for 1997 and will be claimed in the next tax season, but many people who adopt, for example, can have the amount of tax money deducted from their paychecks lowered sooner in anticipation of the credit.

CORRECTION-DATE: January 4, 1997, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
An article by The Associated Press on Thursday about new state laws that took effect on Jan. 1 referred incorrectly to legislation in Arizona that would have eased the state's ban on fireworks to allow the sale of sparklers, poppers and other nonexplosive devices. Although such a change was approved by the Arizona Legislature, it was vetoed in April by Gov. Fife Symington.

HEADLINE: Think Again Before Slicing Social Security Pie

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "Trying to Slice the National Pie and Mend Social Security, Too" (Business Day, Dec. 27), you cite the idea that individual Social Security accounts would make the goal of increasing national savings "far more palatable."
What you really mean is that individual Social Security accounts would make it easier to raise taxes. There is no economic connection, however, between individual Social Security accounts and raising taxes to increase national savings. 
 National savings can be increased by raising the payroll tax and maintaining a larger Social Security Trust Fund, as you advocated in a Dec. 10 editorial. Since a single large trust fund has lower administrative costs than millions of individual accounts, the trust fund would earn about 1 percent more per year than individual accounts would.
Your Business Day article also cites the argument that individual accounts may exacerbate tensions over redistribution and further increase our growing income inequality. You do not mention that some proposals for individual accounts would make it far more expensive for individuals to buy annuities.
This would lead to more poverty for those who live a long time after retirement. The poverty rate for this group, primarily widows, is already very high.
 
PETER DIAMOND
Lexington, Mass., Dec. 30, 1996
 
The writer is an economics professor at M.I.T.

HEADLINE: Dividends Rise, but Not as Fast as Stocks

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
American companies raised dividends at a rapid rate last year, but the increases did not come quickly enough to keep up with share prices.
Data released by Standard & Poor's yesterday showed that 2,171 American companies increased their dividend payouts in 1996, up 13.8 percent from the prior year and the most for any year since 1980. 
 At the same time, the dividend payout on the stocks in the Standard & Poor's 500 stock index rose 8 percent. That was the largest increase in the dividend payout since 1990, when it rose 11.5 percent, but the increase did not even come close to the 20.3 percent price rise shown by the S.& P. 500 during 1996.
As a result, the dividend yield on the index -- once watched by many as a barometer of market valuation -- fell to a record low of 1.97 percent in November, though it has since risen a bit, as some companies raised payouts and share prices slipped a bit. At the end of 1996, it was 2.02 percent. Before the current bull market, that figure had never gone below 2.5 percent. Historically, when the yield has been low, the value of stocks has often been considered too high.
Dividend changes historically are a lagging indication of corporate profitability and at the same time a sign that corporate boards have confidence in the future. Because dividend reductions are seen as a very bad sign, companies hate to raise payouts to an unsustainable level.
There was a slight, and statistically irrelevant, increase in the number of companies that provided bad news for shareholders by either reducing or eliminating their dividends. There were 130 such announcements last year, up from 128 the year before. But that was still the second-lowest total since S.& P. began collecting the data in 1955, and it was less than one-third the number recorded in 1991, after the most recent recession.
The generally good economy no doubt is one reason why few dividends are being cut these days, but another one is that dividends are simply not being raised as they used to be. In this buoyant stock market, companies have seen relatively little demand for higher payouts from shareholders who, after all, have been seeking and getting capital gains. And many companies argue that they are effectively returning money to shareholders by repurchasing their own shares.
Arnold Kaufman, the editor of The Outlook, the S.& P. newsletter that reports on dividends, said he thought that if price gains were harder to come by this year, investors might push for dividend increases.
There would seem to be plenty of room for such increases. The payout ratio -- the percentage of corporate profits returned to shareholders through dividends -- is likely to be around 40 percent when final earnings figures for the year are recorded, Mr. Kaufman said. That is down from 41 percent in 1995 and not far above the record low of 38 percent, set in 1979.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Eases vs. Mark and Yen But Is Up Some Against Pound

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar ended slightly lower against the yen and mark yesterday after unexpectedly strong economic data rattled the American stock and bond markets on the first trading day of 1997.
But the dollar was mixed in other foreign-exchange dealings and retraced its Tuesday decline against the British pound, which fell broadly on profit taking after rising to a four-year high. 
 Light trading distorted price movements, with many currency dealers still out for an extended New Year's break. Many financial markets around the world were closed on Wednesday and Japanese markets do not reopen until Monday, which made it hard to discern any hints of change in the dollar's upward movement in 1996. The dollar ended the year with a 12.1 percent gain against the yen and a 7.3 percent gain against the German mark.
Nonetheless, some traders said the losses in United States stock and bond markets were a sign of vulnerability for the dollar.
Although stocks recovered somewhat in the afternoon, bond prices fell sharply. "The bullish psychology for the dollar has definitely taken a major dent," said Stephen Flanagan, senior foreign-exchange trader at Credit Agricole in New York. "People are reassessing where the dollar is and where it's going."
Late in New York yesterday, the dollar settled at 115.52 yen, down from 115.93 on Tuesday and at 1.5410 marks, down from 1.5415 marks. The pound fell to $1.6929 from $1.7125.
The dollar initially weakened with stocks and bonds after the National Association of Purchasing Management reported an unforeseen acceleration in manufacturing in December. The report, pointing to stronger growth and a possible need for higher interest rates, scared bond traders and in turn depressed stocks.
The pound's weakness reflected big sell orders aimed at locking in profit from its strength last week, when speculation about a new rise in British interest rates increased demand for sterling. Traders, back from the holidays, used the opportunity to sell pounds they had bought more cheaply. "A good part of the market walked back in after several days and said it really doesn't belong there, so they sold," Mr. Flanagan of Credit Agricole said.

HEADLINE: GRADING THE SCHOOLS: THE BACKGROUND;
Prerequisite for Better Education: Accurate Report Cards on Schools

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME 

 BODY:
In the often-contentious world of educational politics, almost everyone seems to agree on one thing: American education has done a poor job of assessing the performance of students and schools.
So when New York State's Education Commissioner, Richard P. Mills, unveiled a new report card for all the public schools in the state yesterday, his action reflected the growing recognition nationwide that improving education and schools almost has to begin with finding better ways to determine and convey how schools are performing. 
 One reflection of that is the rush by districts and states across the country to come up with report cards and other measurements of how individual schools and entire districts are doing.
In New Jersey, where school financing is a major issue, the report cards have played into local debates about how best to spend available funds.
According to the Council of Chief State School Officers, as of August 1995, 46 states had at least one annual report on school performance. Of those, 42 published at least one report providing statistics at the district level, and 35 reported statistics at the school level.
"This is a long-term trend that's here to stay," Mr. Mills said. "Parents insist on it, particularly because it's what they expect in every other area of life. If you buy a pair of snow tires, you go to a consumer guide expecting to find all kinds of comparative data. When we look at schools, we've been going by anecdotal evidence alone. That doesn't make sense, and it has to change."
As far back as 1969, the school district in Columbus, Ohio, started issuing report cards on school performance.
In the late 1980's, Illinois became the first state to offer report cards systematically on individual schools.
But three things have turned report cards and other assessments into a major growth field.
The first is the anxiety over student achievement dating to the 1983 report, "Nation at Risk," which painted an alarming -- some now say too alarming -- picture of educational decline as a major economic and social worry for the nation. The Federal report began a movement for school improvement whose main thrust now is a focus on new ways to set achievement standards and to assess how schools and students are performing.
The second is the rise of computer technology and data bases that make it much easier than in years past to compile and distribute information on everything from attendance to test scores to demographics to financing.
The third factor is the growth of the Internet. Mr. Mills said that information was now so easy to spread over the Internet that, if states and school districts did not find a way to provide assessments of school performance, the information would probably be distributed willy-nilly over the Internet anyway.
Still, coming up with the right report card and making it a source for positive change rather than mere hand wringing is no easy task. When report cards began, many in education worried that they would do more to stigmatize poor-performing schools than to improve them.
"The skepticism was based on the idea that report cards could cause someone -- a newspaper writer, a parent or some group -- to make a decision on information that doesn't tell you everything you need to know," said Chris Pipho, a spokesman for the Education Commission of the States in Denver.
To compensate, most states are adjusting and readjusting their reports to add information, expand comparisons and, in general, provide richer, more balanced, more useful assessments.
Mr. Mills, for example, said one of the things he wanted to do in New York was to be sure that performance at individual schools was measured over a three-year period so that the school performance could be determined more clearly. Similarly, New York compares schools with similar socioeconomic backgrounds.
On the other hand, Connecticut this year scaled back the information provided on the 1,003 schools in its Strategic School Profiles begun in 1994 to 4 pages from 11 in the belief that the smaller form was more manageable.
New Jersey schools have been providing annual reports since 1989, but they were standardized in 1995 in a program that provides annual report cards on the state's 2,200 schools.
New Jersey has the nation's highest per-pupil spending. And although the report cards play somewhat into the debate about school financing, Leo F. Klagholz, the New Jersey Commissioner of Education, said they had most often played into the local debates about where to spend available dollars rather than the statewide debates about the general level of education financing.
One major issue that has not been addressed is how to provide information to parents and officials that compares schools in different states. Right now, there are only the periodic state comparisons that show up on standardized tests like the National Assessment of Educational Progress.
The idea of a national test remains politically volatile, caught between forces pulling, on the one hand, for better assessments, and on the other, against efforts to shift any power in education to the national from the local level.
"I think it would be immensely valuable to be able to compare performances across the nation," Mr. Mills said.
 
Results by Region
Comprehensive school-by-school results from the state's report will be published on Sunday in the Westchester and Long Island Weekly sections and in The City.

HEADLINE: Gen. Winston P. Wilson, 85, National Guard Leader, Dies

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON 

 BODY:
Maj. Gen. Winston Peabody Wilson, the architect of the United States' modern Ready Reserve -- ready to join the regular forces swiftly on overseas missions -- died on Tuesday at Baptist East Hospital in Memphis, where he was taken after a stroke. He was 85 and lived in Forrest City, Ark.
General Wilson, a combat pilot, came to the Pentagon's attention in the 1950's when he took charge of the Air National Guard as a deputy chief of the National Guard Bureau. Within years he whipped what insider critics after World War II debunked as a glorified collection of tax-supported clubs into disciplined tactical and transport squadrons. 
 Under his leadership, the wings of the National Guard proved themselves during the 1961 Berlin crisis, when their units bolstered American airborne might.
After that mobilization, General Wilson steadily built the muscle of the force and became known as Mr. Air National Guard around the Pentagon. In recognition of his performance, he was appointed in 1963 as chief of the National Guard Bureau, the Pentagon liaison office to army and air guard units nationwide. He was the first air officer in that job, was reappointed four years later and retired in 1971.
The bureau he headed was unusual in the military establishment in that it dealt with militias that were legally autonomous and under state command -- barring a national emergency. The Pentagon's sway over such far-flung command structures came with the Federal tax dollars that provided over 90 percent of their upkeep.
Among General Wilson's first concerns were efficiency, economy and preparedness for national contingencies. He began by ordering the guards to upgrade their accustomed weekly drills to monthly weekend training with field exercises.
In the end the reserves, including members of the guards, trained side-by-side with regular troops. The reservists are also regularly used for humanitarian and rescue missions as well as some combat, airlift and air-refueling assignments.
Orders from Presidents John F. Kennedy and Lyndon B. Johnson removed vestiges of racial discrimination in the military, which had officially been integrated under President Harry Truman. General Wilson issued the directives to make the Guard finally follow suit.
He used his friendship and considerable influence with recalcitrant governors, adjutants general and other guard officials in the South and elsewhere where guard units routinely barred blacks. Where persuasion failed, he bluntly told those concerned that they had to accept all standards set by the Pentagon, which held the purse strings.
Winston Wilson was born in Arkadelphia, Ark., but grew up in Little Rock, where his high-school mates shortened his name to Win. A coach's yell for "Win P. Wilson" to take to the field prompted them to corrupt that into Wimpy, which stuck for life.
He began his military career as an airplane mechanic with the Arkansas National Guard in 1929 and received his pilot's license in 1936. In World War II he served in the Far East and on mapping missions in South America and Alaska.
He re-enlisted in the Arkansas Air National Guard immediately after the war and made his mark with innovative training programs for its flying outfits, now amply equipped with P-51 fighters. He was recalled to active duty in the Korean War, from which he emerged as a full colonel.
In the Korean War, the Air Guard units had little say over how they were used by the regular Air Force. The experience gave General Wilson and an old friend, Brigadier Earl T. Ricks, head of the Arkansas National Guard, the conceptual underpinnings for overhauling that state unit the moment it was demobilized.
General Wilson's wife, Margaret, died in 1994 after 52 years of marriage; they had no children. He is survived by a brother, Robert M., and a sister, Jean Wilson Anthony, both of Little Rock.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bonds Slide, Pushing Yield Up to 6.73%

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
A stronger-than-expected increase in manufacturing activity sent bond prices down sharply yesterday and confirmed that investors remain nervous about the economy, inflation and the Federal Reserve.
The market was reacting to the report by the National Association of Purchasing Management that its index of manufacturing activity rose to a reading of 54 in December from 52.7 in November. Economists had expected a modest decline in the index and the news pushed the yield on the long bond up to its highest level since Oct. 4. 
 The benchmark 30-year bond fell 19/32 to a price of 9631/32 ; its yield, which moves in the opposite direction of the price, jumped to 6.73 percent, from 6.64 percent on Tuesday, the last trading session of 1996. For bondholders, the day's loss came to about $12.81 for a bond with a face value of $1,000.
The market's slide was the second in two trading days. On Tuesday, a report of unexpectedly strong home sales helped spur a selloff. In the last two sessions, a bond with a face value of $1,000 has lost nearly $26.
Donald Fine, the chief market analyst at Chase Asset Management, said that while the manufacturing index did indeed defy expectations, what disturbed the bond market even more was the prices-paid component, which rose to the highest level since July 1995.
"Coupled with the sharp jump in both consumer confidence and the new-home sales released on Tuesday, market participants are beginning to develop a sense of unease about the potential inflationary consequences," Mr. Fine said.
The market was particularly nervous, Mr. Fine said, "in light of the fact that the December-over-December Consumer Price Index for 1996, when released on Jan. 14, is likely to show a rise of approximately 3.3 percent, a noticeable increase over 1995's 2.6 percent."
The market also reacted to a Labor Department report that showed the number of initial weekly jobless claims last week rose by 22,000, to 366,000. The increase suggested that the labor market could be softening and that economic activity could be slowing. Prices rose on the news as traders decided the Fed was less likely to raise interest rates soon.
But the rally ended when the manufacturing report was released. Light post-holiday volume seemed to exaggerate market movements.
A manufacturing activity index of more than 50 suggests that manufacturing is expanding, prompting concerns about inflation, and raising the chances that the Fed could raise interest rates at the February meeting of its policy-making panel, the Federal Open Market Committee.
"The payroll and unemployment rate figures, of course, will be primary determinants of the direction of interest rates during the month of January," Mr. Fine said. "But having just made a significant adjustment, bond-yield movements are likely to be considerably less pronounced going forward."
Donald H. Straszheim, chief economist at Merrill Lynch & Company, believes that the economy continues to give off mixed signals. "Remember, the Christmas selling season was not especially strong," he said. "But mixed data provide something for the optimist and something for the pessimist. We expect the bond yields to continue in a roughly 6.25 percent to 6.75 percent trading range during the next few months."
While he does not expect the Fed to raise interest rates next month, Mr. Straszheim said, January wage rate and employment data will be key.
Yesterday's Treasury auction of new one-year bills saw the average discount rate come in at 5.31 percent, up from 5.16 percent last month and the highest discount rate since Oct. 10, when it was 5.34 percent. Analysts said that the results were as expected, with little retail interest.
