HEADLINE: The Nuclear Power Puzzle;
Who Will Pay for a Generation of Expensive Plants?

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Jan. 2

 BODY:
The nation's nuclear power plants are delivering record quantities of electricity and doing it more efficiently and safely than ever before, according to industry statistics. But the never-ending debate about nuclear power's future is once again heating up, this time fanned by fears that many nuclear plants could become financial albatrosses as deregulation gives business and residential consumers choices about where they buy power.
The issue: How will investors, taxpayers and consumers share in paying for the $70 billion or so in debts piled up to build the plants and the billions more that will eventually be needed to retire them? 
 While the issue is far from settled, the new economics of competition is already driving the most basic strategic decisions at many utilities, ranging from the giant Commonwealth Edison Company, which supplies 70 percent of this region's power from 12 nuclear plants, to the Long Island Lighting Company, which never sold a kilowatt of power from its Shoreham nuclear plant but is struggling with the $4.5 billion debt left over from that abandoned project. The high rates that Lilco charges to pay off that debt helped push it into a merger with the Brooklyn Union Gas Company.
Most nuclear utilities want a transition to free markets that could take as long as a decade. In that time, they want to be allowed to recoup their investment in nuclear plants from rate payers, even from those who switch to lower-cost competitors. Those who leave would be dunned in the form of so-called exit fees or surcharges on their new bills.
Some nuclear utilities say they could be bankrupted or, at the least, badly punished on Wall Street if the transition comes too quickly and shareholders are asked to pick up more of the tab, in the form of reduced profits and dividends. The pressures to close marginal plants years before their licenses expire are already intense, as demonstrated by the decision in November of Northeast Utilities in Hartford to shut its troubled Connecticut Yankee plant 14 years ahead of schedule.
The fallout from early closings, nuclear supporters say, often includes layoffs, huge tax losses in some communities, more air pollution from increased reliance on fossil fuels and less overall capacity to meet energy demand.
Consumer groups and some nonnuclear utilities pushing for a much quicker transition say that forcing consumers to continue paying for plants they are not using will give electricity users choices but no real savings.
Taxpayers may well be nicked in the crossfire; utilities are pushing for tax breaks to give them more financial flexibility in cutting rates.
With more than 100 nuclear plants from Maine to California generating nearly a quarter of the nation's electricity, every region has a stake in the outcome. Vermont got almost 80 percent of its electricity from nuclear plants in 1995, Connecticut just under 70 percent and New Jersey and South Carolina almost two-thirds.
So far, legislatures and regulators seem disinclined to let electricity consumers off the hook for nuclear investments that look wastefully expensive in hindsight. A handful of states, including California and Pennsylvania, have already adopted a variety of rules that give utilities several years to recoup their investments from consumers. Typically, they have softened the sting with related measures that result in freezes or even reductions in overall rates.
What happens in most of the nation, though, is a question this year in state legislatures and public utility commissions. Those decisions may in turn hinge on whether Congress and Federal agencies like the Nuclear Regulatory Commission weigh in with rules of their own affecting how fast the $220 billion industry is opened to competition.
The spotlight in the debate may soon shift here to northern Illinois, home of Commonwealth Edison, a subsidiary of the Unicom Corporation and the industry's largest and most experienced nuclear power generator. Com Ed charges customers up to 60 percent more than utilities in neighboring states, making it an obvious target for competitors.
Com Ed's nuclear portfolio is efficient enough that the excess energy it produces on weekends is easily sold on the open market. But some of Com Ed's plants are among the worst performers in the industry, others face huge renovation expenses and rates must cover accumulated debts of more than $10 billion. Com Ed says it welcomes competition but deserves time and financial breaks from regulators to prepare for it.
"If we can't figure out a way to make nuclear power a competitive advantage, no one can," Thomas J. Maiman, Com Ed's senior vice president for nuclear operations, said.
Com Ed, which has been a pivotal power in the state's politics for more than a century, has plenty of influence to make its case.
"There isn't a reservoir of good will, but everyone understands that putting them out of business won't do anyone any good," said Al Musur, energy manager at Illinois-based Abbott Laboratories, who warily backs a deregulation proposal by a coalition of users and utilities that includes Com Ed. "I'm more afraid we are going to take the 800-pound gorilla and make it a 2,000-pound one."
In the Com Ed-backed proposal, like many around the nation supported by high-cost utilities, the transition period to open competition stretches into the next century. Some of the arguments for moving cautiously are technical -- new billing systems need to be developed and tested, for example. Moreover, it is still unclear how parts of the system that will remain regulated, like long-distance transmission lines, will be managed.
But the utilities also argue that customers should not be allowed to duck paying for the existing plants and other assets like huge transmission systems built to provide reliable power.
In the traditional regulatory system. those investments were made only after regulators had agreed they were necessary to meet anticipated growth. The utilities were then guaranteed that users would shoulder all design and construction costs the regulators found to be "prudent" over the lifetime of the plant. Customers have been forced to pay for such investments even if it turned out that another type of power plant -- or purchases of power from other utilities -- could have met their needs much more cheaply.
Here, as elsewhere, the debate about nuclear power is part of a larger battle over what are widely called "stranded costs," which include a broad range of utility expenses that might make it hard for them to compete in a free market.
Com Ed, for example, has programs to subsidize electricity for low-income customers that would be "stranded" costs in a competitive market unless regulators ordered all electricity consumers to pay for them.
Another significant family of stranded costs, common in California and the Northeast, is known as "purchase power" agreements. These agreements force utilities like the Consolidated Edison Company of New York to buy energy from independent power generators, even if it is more expensive than power being sold by other utilities or power the utility can generate itself. Many such programs were created to support the development of solar energy and other "alternative" energy programs. Purchase power contracts are threatening to bankrupt the Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation, an upstate New York utility.
Nationwide, utilities face somewhere between $45 billion and $400 billion in stranded costs as they try to gear up for competition, according to various studies. Investments in big power plants, mostly nuclear, account for 40 percent of the total, taxes and other regulated subsidy programs another 40 percent and uneconomic "purchase power" from independent producers about 20 percent, according to David K. Owens, senior vice president for finance, regulation and power supply policy at the Edison Electric Institute, the industry's Washington-based trade group.
The controversial history of nuclear power, though, makes it the most visible stranded cost. A number of nuclear plants were built before costs soared, enabling those operated by better-managed utilities to provide some of the least expensive power around. But many of the nuclear plants that have come on line the last decade or so, even those that operate efficiently, are likely to become white elephants in the age of competition if investors in Com Ed's parent and other utilities have to pick up too much of the tab.
More than profits for investors are at stake: the N.R.C. has already served notice that it wants to make sure that deregulated nuclear utilities are financially healthy enough to sustain spending on safety. And some environmental groups want to make sure that utilities in the Northeast are not given any incentive to close down nuclear plants and rely more on electricity bought from Midwest coal plants, which cause acid rain and other forms of pollution.
Com Ed's proposed transition program includes a five-year freeze on rate increases that began in 1996, annual rate cuts of 1.5 percent starting in 2000 and a completely open market for residential users by 2005.
By that time, Com Ed estimates, its rates will have been cut 35 percent, after adjusting for inflation. That will put huge pressure on the company to become more efficient to avoid an earnings collapse, Leo Mullin, Com Ed's vice chairman, said.
"It's coming at the same time we have to build up," added Samuel K. Skinner, the company's president and a former chief of staff under President George Bush, citing a number of big development projects.
Shareholders will help bear the load under Com Ed's proposal for accelerated depreciation of the nuclear plants -- an accounting measure that will not affect cash flow but will reduce net profits.
"Our shareholders have already paid dearly," Mr. Skinner said, noting that the dividend had been slashed from $3 to $1.60 four years ago after repeated delays in getting regulatory approval to charge consumers for nuclear plants that began supplying power in 1987 and 1988.
But they have not paid enough, according to critics like Howard A. Learner, executive director of the Environmental Law and Policy Center. The Chicago-based research and advocacy group has battled Com Ed over rate increases for years and expects to campaign to shift more of the transition burden to investors. According to Mr. Learner, "The public and the political leaders of the state have to say, 'Get real,' to Com Ed to force a reasonable deal."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Utilities face tough financial decisions resulting from nuclear power, at plants like Commonwealth Edison's at Byron, Ill. (Steve Kagan for The New York Times)(pg. D1)

Chart: "The State's Answers"
As states move to allow competition among utilities, some must face dealing with costly nuclear plants, many as yet unpaid for. Here are some proposals being considered or in effect around the country.
 
CALIFIRNIA -- A law allowing deregulation was passed in September. A special charge of about one-third of an average monthly bill will be levied to pay for $29 billion in power plant debt.
 
CONNECTICUT -- Three state reports have urged deregulation. To pay for existing power plants, a charge on monthly bills has been recommended for consumer who switch providers.
 
MASSACHUSETTES -- Most of the state's utilities have agreed to accept competition by 1998. Utilities will add a surcharge of 3 to 3.5 cents per kilowatt hour to pay for $12.5 billion in debt for existing plants.
 
NEW JERSEY -- The utility control board wants competition in the wholesale market. It has not addressed how to pay for power plant debt.
 
NEW YORK -- The Public Service Commission wants to deregulate by 1998. Last October, it asked utilities to submit recommendations.
 
PENNSYLVANIA -- A new law allows deregulation to be phased in by 2001. Utilities can add a surcharge to consumers' bills for existing power plant debt, but the amount will be decided case by case.
 
RHODE ISLAND -- The law passed in June deregulates utilities starting July 1997. Full deregulation will occur by July 1998. To pay for existing plant debt, a surcharge of 2.8 cents per kilowatt hour will be levied the first three years, dropping gradually to 0.5 cents after 12 years and ending in 25 years.

HEADLINE: Manufacturing Pace Shows Unexpected Increase

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The nation's manufacturing economy accelerated in December, the National Association of Purchasing Management reported yesterday, surprising financial analysts. Most economists had expected the index of the manufacturing pace to drop slightly last month after its unexpectedly strong November.
In another sign of economic strength yesterday, the Conference Board, a nonprofit business research organization, said help-wanted advertising rose in November. 
 "I think everyone had discounted too much all the good news about the economy," Kevin Flanagan, money market economist for Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., said. "Growth will come in stronger than expected, though not runaway growth or inflation."
Like many other economists, Mr. Flanagan is predicting that the current economic expansion -- which began in March 1991 and is already the third longest in the country's history -- will continue through 1997.
Yesterday's purchasing managers' index rose to 54 percent last month, from 52.7 percent in November. Economists had been expecting a reading of about 51.5 percent. A reading above 50 often signals an expanding economy and one below 50 can be a sign of a contraction. This sign of a jump in industrial supplies could raise prices in stores. A pickup in manufacturing activity could also lead to higher wages, pushing up prices further.
Some economists took the report as a sign that the Federal Reserve might have to raise interest rates slightly by next spring to keep inflation in check.
"The incoming data does support my view that the economy is, after a summer slowdown, gathering renewed momentum again and will remain fairly strong the first half of 1997," Richard Berner, chief economist of Mellon Bank, Pittsburgh, said. "That renewed steam runs counter to most expectations in the marketplace."
Yet there also were signs of moderation in the economy. The Government reported yesterday that first-time claims for unemployment benefits rose unexpectedly by 22,000 to the highest level since last summer, suggesting a moderating labor market.
The Labor Department said new applications for unemployment insurance totaled a seasonally adjusted 366,000, up from a revised 344,000 during the week ended Dec. 21, when claims fell by 6,000. The figure was the highest since the week ended July 13, when it was 367,000.
The less volatile four-week moving average of new weekly jobless claims rose by 9,000, to 352,500, the highest since 360,500 on July 13.

HEADLINE: Drift to Dictatorship Clouds Armenia's Happiness

BYLINE: By MICHAEL SPECTER 

DATELINE: YEREVAN, Armenia

 BODY:
This should have been a glorious winter for the troubled people of Armenia. For the first time in years peace has taken root. It is no longer necessary for anyone to burn furniture or park benches to keep warm. The longest lines at stores are of shoppers clamoring to buy microwave ovens to use in kitchens that last year had no electricity and little food.
Suddenly there are cafes, restaurants, banks and a currency worth holding for more than an hour. Inflation is plummeting and real incomes, while still low, are slowly on the rise. Boutiques sell French shoes and Italian suits. After years of decline, the birth rate -- a raw indicator of hope and determination -- has started to edge up. 
 But there are no celebrations here this season. Once regarded as an oasis of civility and democracy among former Soviet republics, Armenia has drifted toward dictatorship.
Presidential elections this fall were found to be so deeply flawed that the United States, which provides more foreign aid to Armenia per person than to any country except Israel, declined to offer routine congratulations to the winner, Levon Ter-Petrossian. It has been a year of diminishing press freedom and rising human-rights violations. Most of all, it has been a year in which Mr. Ter-Petrossian, once revered as the man who brought democracy to Armenia, appears to have completed a journey from liberal intellectual to stony autocrat.
Mr. Ter-Petrossian rarely speaks in public. He has no tolerance for opposition. His meetings are few and many of his decisions are made in secret. Despite the large and influential Armenian diaspora in the United States, he has not given an interview to a Western reporter for at least two years because, Gerard J. Libaridian, his senior adviser, said, "They only use a short quote and they take him out of context." (Mr. Ter-Petrossian, a philologist who was jailed by the Soviets as a dissident and speaks 10 languages with relative fluency, initially agreed to be interviewed for this article. He then said through an aide that he was too busy.)
"We had a marvelous dream of freedom a few years ago," said Berj Zeytountsian, a prominent writer who was the independent country's first Culture Minister. "And here we believe in our dreams. But now they are gone and we are left wondering what we have in their place. Peace is nice; we all love it. But peace of mind, that is even better."
Long animated by a sense of justice and idealism that Armenians say set it apart from its neighbors, the country today is fighting simply to keep a grasp on the unique sense of solidarity it once held dear.
Not everyone cares, of course: working people want food on their table and this year, for the first time in recent memory, most Armenians are able to buy it. But politically and emotionally, a country that had been remarkably unified is now split.
Leading opposition members of Parliament usually do not even bother to attend sessions. Opposition politicians and members of the news media were beaten and jailed after the disputed elections that Mr. Ter-Petrossian won by a few percentage points. And the man he so narrowly defeated, the former Prime Minister Vazgen Manoukian, has only recently emerged from hiding.
Armenia may be more open and accessible than Azerbaijan, the oil-producing neighbor that Armenia has been fighting since the Soviet Union started to crumble. But people here do not want to be compared with their neighbors. They want to be compared with the West. And even at the highest levels, there is anger and fear that this has become a country where the Defense Minister could state on national television that he would never have accepted Mr. Manoukian's victory, "even if he won 100 percent of the vote."
Armen V. Sarkisyan, the new Prime Minister, who openly and with regret acknowledges the frailty of his country's democracy, said, "We cannot tolerate people like that."
"We must now move back from the precipice," he continued in an interview. "Somebody has to speak to the opposition rather than blaming them for everything that is wrong with Armenia. Somebody has to say that the press is truly free and then stand by to guarantee it. Somebody has to convince our enormous diaspora that they are welcome and needed here, not just once for a visit but as often as they can come. Somebody has to make it clear that we will not just tolerate dissent, we will welcome it."
They are noble words and by all accounts he means them. But only one man rules Armenia today, and while he insists in speeches and statements that democracy is sacred to him, Mr. Ter-Petrossian does not act as if it is.
The President's turn away from democracy began in 1994, when he banned a major opposition party and imposed restrictions on the press. Even now, with many of those restrictions lifted, there is a combined daily press run of only 31,000 copies for all newspapers in the country, which has a population of 3 million. The fairness of Parliamentary elections last year was questioned sharply by international observers, and a new Constitution gives the President unusually sweeping powers.
"The situation in our country has become better," said Nagor Avedikian, editor of Azg, which means The Nation, an independent daily paper. "The economy is not as desperate as it once was. There is no war. But as that has happened, our President has become more remote and autocratic. The truth is that he is a democrat only in the most Platonic sense."
For more than six years, Armenia has been unofficially at war with Azerbaijan over the ethnic Armenian mountain enclave of Nagorno-Karabakh, which is in Azerbaijan. Azerbaijan is much bigger, far richer and backed by its Muslim ally, Turkey. Yet the tenacious Armenians won in a rout. While a fragile peace holds, the political questions have never been settled, and most countries officially oppose Armenia's position.
"Many countries think we are being unreasonable about Karabakh," said Mr. Libaridian, who has taken an energetic lead in trying to negotiate a settlement. "But I would rather have a problem of perception, and even of being isolated than the problem of 1915. We had one genocide in this century. It was enough for us. It will never happen again."
He was referring to the event that still defines the nation: in 1915 vast numbers of Armenians, perhaps more than a million, died at the hands of the Ottoman Turks, through forced resettlement, starvation and massacres. It is the fundamental fact of modern Armenia and it still governs the people's complex political and psychological world views. Many are defensive, combative and convinced that the moment they relax, they will again be annihilated.
Today, Turkey and Azerbaijan have imposed a total import blockade on Armenia. That leaves Iran and Georgia as neighboring trading partners. Iran is an ally but it is not an ideal one. Its economy is not that strong and any relationship with Iran angers Armenia's most powerful patron, the United States.
Not that any of that matters to average people. Many are beginning to have what they care about: food, energy (after the recent reopening of a nuclear power station that sits on a geological fault line) and the sense that maybe their children will not die in a war for their survival.
"I don't really care what the President does," said Armina Nagosian, 28, a saleswoman in the Samsung electronics store in downtown Yerevan. "Look at this place. People are buying things they never even thought they would see in this country."
All around her men and women were choosing among color televisions, microwaves and fancy new vacuum cleaners.
"This store didn't even have electricity until a few months ago," she said. "And that is what people care about. Not who sits in Parliament."
Although the economy has improved in the last two years -- real annual growth was up 7 percent in 1995 and has been growing at almost the same rate this year, the International Monetary Fund says -- trade accounts for the improvement. There is no robust banking system, so nobody earns interest, few people pay taxes and nobody has money to invest in long-term projects like factories and communications systems.
Despite an official monthly average income of about $20 and few natural resources, Armenia has one of the highest literacy rates in the world. It is a society of talkative, independent people.
"When we were part of the Soviet Union, we had no voice or vote," said Vahan Barseghian, 47, a shepherd who lives outside of the capital but often comes to the bustling central market to sell his meat. "The point of independence was really to give us the right to live the way we want. Now we have an Armenian leader who treats us like the Russians did. I don't really know if that is better or worse than before."

HEADLINE: F.D.A. Proposal Would Ban Using Animal Tissue in Feed

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE K. ALTMAN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2

 BODY:
The Food and Drug Administration today proposed a ban on the use of any tissue from a wide variety of animals in feed to prevent the spread of mad cow disease if it ever occurred in this country.
No case of mad cow disease has been detected in the United States in 10 years of monitoring. But the agency's precautionary step is being proposed because of strong evidence that the disease can be spread through animal feed contaminated with rogue proteins known as prions. 
 Mad cow disease has created havoc with the economy in Britain, where it has affected more than 165,000 cattle since the neurologic ailment was first detected in England in 1986. The source of the bovine disease is thought to be animal feed from processed offal and other parts of slaughtered sheep.
Panic followed the British Government's announcement last year of a tentative link between mad cow disease and an untreatable and incurable human version of an ailment known as Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease, which occurs in about one in a million people in the world. British experts have reported 14 confirmed cases of a variant form of Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease and French doctors have reported 1 case.
There has been no proof that mad cow disease can jump species, from cattle to humans, and there has been no evidence of an explosive outbreak of the new form of Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease in humans. Federal health officials have found no evidence of the variant form of Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease in the United States.
The proposal, to be published in The Federal Register on Friday, would prohibit using protein from any ruminant animal in the manufacture of ruminant feeds. Ruminants are animals that chew their cuds and among them are cattle, sheep, goats, deer and elk. Mink are included in the ban because they can be affected by an ailment similar to mad cow disease.
The public will have 45 days to comment on the proposal, and then the agency expects to put the ban into effect this year, Dr. David A. Kessler, the Commissioner of Food and Drugs, said in an interview.
Mad cow disease is also known as B.S.E., for bovine spongiform encephalopathy. It is so named because it produces holes in various areas of the brain, giving it a pitted appearance like Swiss cheese. Similar spongiform diseases affect a variety of animals. The diseases generally takes years to develop silently. But then it progresses from initial symptoms to almost certain death in a relatively short time.
Because such diseases have not been transmitted through reprocessed feed to poultry, swine and pets, such feed would be exempted from the proposed American ban, Dr. Kessler said.
Other exemptions include blood from cattle and ruminant-derived milk and gelatin, he said, because the agency has no information suggesting that milk proteins, gelatin or bovine blood proteins can potentially transmit mad cow-like disease.
The proposed ban, he said, "will make sure that cattle and similar animals will not get fed any products that could cause this disease."
"We are creating a fire wall, a barrier," he said. "If a case occurred in this country, the steps would confine the disease to the individual animal and prevent secondary spread. We know the strategy works because it did bring down the number of cases in England dramatically."
The proposed rules create a flexible system of controls to insure that ruminant feed does not contain prohibited tissues from any animal parts. Agency inspectors will be able to trace all records of shipment of meat and bone meal at the 150 rendering plants in this country, Dr. Kessler said.
The agency estimates the annual costs at $21 million to $48 million, compared with some industry estimates as high as $1 billion a year.
The National Cattlemen's and Beef Association said in a statement that it applauded the proposed ban as "appropriate" and that "we would expect it to have little effect on the cost of producing beef and milk."
Today's action is consistent with a similar but voluntary ban established 10 days after the British Government's announcement last March. That ban was established by American livestock industry and veterinary medical groups and with recommendations issued by the World Health Organization last spring, Dr. Kessler said. The action also follows his agency's analysis of comments from 600 individuals and organizations requested last May when it signaled its intention to act.
Dr. Kessler said the proposed ban also reflected new scientific information that a team headed by Dr. John Collinge, a British expert on Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease, reported in the journal Nature in October. Using laboratory methods to "fingerprint" the prions involved in bovine spongiform encephalopathy and the form of Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease reported by British officials last March, Dr. Collinge found that the new variant of the human disease resembles B.S.E. more than other forms of Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease.
The agency also reiterated requirement for drug manufacturers to document that animal tissues used in making drugs did not originate in a country where native cattle have been found to be infected with bovine spongiform encephalopathy. The animals must be inspected by the source country's veterinary authorities, before and after slaughter. And the animals must be suitable as food for human.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Stocks Fall Sharply, Then Regain Most of Loss
Before a late rebound, the stock market almost opened 1997 the same way it ended 1996 -- with a big drop. The Dow Jones industrial average, down more than 88 points at 3:29 P.M., regained nearly all of that by the end of trading. The index ended the day down 5.78 points, at 6,442.49. That followed a 101-point drop on Tuesday.
There was no obvious cause for the turnaround, but traders said it came with strong program buying that helped to push up large stocks across the board. [Page D6.]

Dividends rose rapidly last year, but not enough to keep up with share gains. [D4.]

Bank of New York Stake in Rival
Bank of New York said that it would seek to raise its stake to 9.9 percent in State Street Boston, a rival in the business of processing securities. Analysts speculated whether it was the start of a takeover bid. [D2.]
 
Morgan Stanley Names Fund Chief
Philip N. Duff, Morgan Stanley's chief financial officer, has been tapped to be chief executive and president of Van Kampen American Capital, the big mutual fund company that Morgan Stanley acquired last fall, company executives said. [D3.]

Purchasing Management Index Up
Manufacturing picked up strength in December, the National Association of Purchasing Management reported. Its index rose to 54 points from 52.7 in November, surprising economists. [D3.]
 
That report sent bond prices down sharply. The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond jumped to 6.73 percent from 6.64. [D15.]

De Beers to End Russian Pact
De Beers Consolidated Mines of South Africa, which sells about 75 percent of the world's diamond production, confirmed that it would end a marketing agreement with Russia, the largest diamond producer. [D2.]
 
Malone's Move to Control Liberty
Watchers of John C. Malone, left, say the king of convoluted cable deals is at it again. He wants to obtain control of Liberty Media by gaining access to shares owned by the estate of Bob J. Magness, Liberty's largest shareholder, without putting up cash. To that end, the board at his behest has authorized a stock dividend.
Market Place. [D6.]
 
Canada's Wheat Board Criticized
A number of Canadian farmers think that the Canadian Wheat Board, which has a monopoly on selling wheat and barley from Western growers, has too much power. [A4.]
 
F.D.A. Steps on Mad Cow Disease
The Food and Drug Administration proposed a ban on the use in feed of tissue from a wide variety of animals to prevent the spread of mad cow disease, should an outbreak occur in this country. [A14.]
 
A Sport-Utility Printer?
In a new ad campaign for printers, Hewlett-Packard gently pokes fun at its own engineers in an effort to make its technology seem more accessible. In one ad, an announcer jokes that the only thing the printer cannot do is mow the lawn. But engineers reconfigure it and soon it zips around a field. Advertising. [D4.]

HEADLINE: CHRONICLE

BYLINE: By NADINE BROZAN 

 BODY:
ROSINA K. ABRAMSON, a lawyer who has been president and chief executive of the Roosevelt Island Operating Corporation and executive director of the City Planning Department, began the new year with a new job yesterday, but it is one to which she has very old ties.
She is the national executive director of Women's American ORT, a fund-raising arm of ORT. ORT, which stands for Organization for Rehabilitation Through Training, provides vocational and technical training in more than 60 countries. 
 "My father was educated by ORT in Kovno, Lithuania, in the 1930's," Ms. Abramson said yesterday. "He learned to be a textile mechanic, and when all the Jews were herded into the ghetto in Kovno, he created a work crew there. The Lithuanians needed to keep textile mills running, so dozens of Jews who would have been sent to concentration camps were kept alive. He and the people who worked for him smuggled food and guns into the ghetto."
As a result, Ms. Abramson, who came to the United States with her family in 1950, said, "I grew up hearing that ORT was what gave my father the ability to stay alive and make a living."
In October, a headhunter called her about the position. "They said it was with an organization I had probably never heard of," she recalled. "It was 'beshert,' " she said, using the Yiddish word meaning "It was meant to be."

HEADLINE: Many Voters Say Yes To Environment Taxes

 BODY:
To the Editor:
A footnote on the self-help efforts of residents of West Windsor, N.J., who voted for a 2-cent property tax increase to buy threatened open space (news article, Dec. 29):
West Windsor's initiative, while commendable, is not so unusual. Last Election Day saw voters around the country approve more than $4 billion of state and local funds for parks, farmland protection and environmental enhancements to improve water quality, restore the natural functions of lakes and rivers and revitalize urban brownfields. The measures range from New York State's $1.75 billion bond, which targets $150 million for open space protection, to a $500,000 bond for Mashpee, Mass. 
 In a survey for Greensense, a national newsletter on state and local land conservation finance, I identified more than 130 environmental financing measures. More than two-thirds of these were approved, even though they typically called for a small property tax, a sales tax increase or varied other taxes.
Although these communities are, as you report, in the minority, their numbers are growing as people seek ways to revitalize local economies and enhance the quality of neighborhoods and town and city centers. Voters are tax-averse, but they are rebelling against environmental degradation and saying yes to well-written measures that will pay for visible improvements to the places where they live and work.
 
PHYLLISMYERS
Washington, Jan. 1, 1997
 
President, State Resource Strategies

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Gets Powerful Help From a Surge in U.S. Stocks

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
A rally in the United States stock market lifted the dollar yesterday, as currency traders bet that Asian and European investors would continue to buy American securities and the dollars needed to buy them.
"The gains are being fueled by the surge in the stock market, with some help from what's going on in bonds," said John Duffy, a currency trader at Bayerische Vereinsbank A.G. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average surged 101.60 points, to 6,544.09 yesterday, just shy of a record. On Thursday, it rebounded from a loss of as much as 95 points to close down just 5.78 points.
"The fact that the stock market only closed down 5 points after being down nearly 100 points made people feel a lot better" about the dollar's prospects, said Thomas Benfer, director of foreign exchange at Bank of Montreal/Harris Bank.
The dollar rose as high 116.75 Japanese yen, before settling in late trading in New York at 116.43 yen, up from 115.52 yen Thursday and the highest level since March 1993. The dollar traded at 1.5644 German marks, up from 1.5410 marks and the highest since late December 1994.
The dollar also rose to a two-and-a-half-year high against the Swiss franc, settling in New York 1.3576 Swiss francs, up from 1.3454 Swiss francs on Thursday. It rose sharply against the French franc, settling at 5.2845 French francs, up from 5.1920 francs.
The strength in stocks prompted speculation that Japanese investors would step up investment in the American market after they return from a weeklong New Year's break on Monday.
Traders said investors in Japan had little incentive to put their money into yen-denominated assets, with the country's economy still sputtering, interest rates at record lows and the stock market looking shaky.
"There aren't very high expectations for any of the Japanese markets," said Lizbeth Goldberg, a currency trader at Bayerische Hypotheken und Wechsel Bank.
A rebound in the British pound against the mark also bolstered the dollar, as traders sold marks for dollars and used those dollars to buy pounds, traders said. The pound rose to 2.6417 marks from 2.6161 marks. Against the dollar, the pound slipped to $1.6901 from $1.6929.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Gold Drops to a 3-Year Low; Natural Gas Prices Recover

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The price of gold fell more than 1 percent yesterday, to a three-year low, leading other precious metals prices lower.
On other markets, natural gas prices surged. 
 Traders said gold prices, which have slumped in recent weeks, have been hurt by a strong dollar and by speculation about gold sales by European central banks. "The rise of U.S. bond yields in recent days, which reduces the attractiveness of holding physical assets, and the surge in the dollar, which weakens demand for gold in other currencies, are the latest factors to weigh on precious metals prices this week," said Tim Porter, an analyst with Refco New York.
On the Comex division of the New York Mercantile Exchange, gold for February delivery tumbled $4.60 -- its largest one-day drop since March -- to close at $362 an ounce.
"With the U.S. stock market still strong, there's just no investment demand for gold," said Edward Kempf of the industry consultants CPM Group.
In addition, uncertainty about the role of gold in the planned single European currency system, and the potential for more European central bank gold sales in 1997, continued to weigh down gold prices, analysts said.
European central banks hold about 460 million ounces of gold, more than 40 percent of all official holdings worldwide. But they have not decided what to do with their reserves when they surrender their monetary policy powers to the planned European central bank.
The decline in gold dragged other precious metals lower.
The March silver contract fell 4.7 cents, to $4.685 an ounce, while on the New York Mercantile Exchange, April platinum closed down $3.20 at $367.90 an ounce.
Natural gas prices recovered somewhat from a recent selloff, bolstered by forecasts for colder weather in the Eastern United States.
On the New York Mercantile Exchange, February natural gas settled at $3.106 for 1,000 cubic feet, a gain of 21.6 cents. The contract, which stood at $3.595 on Dec. 26, was as low as $2.612 as recently as Tuesday.

HEADLINE: The Brash Prince of Wine Country;
Californian Wins Middle Market and Ruffles His Rivals

BYLINE: By FRANK J. PRIAL 

DATELINE: SONOMA, Calif.

 BODY:
A rooster tail of dust billowing out behind it, the gold Lexus climbed into the rugged Mayacamas Mountains. "Don't be nervous," said Jess Jackson, pulling deftly through another hairpin turn. "I know this country."
He should; it's the Gauer Ranch, some 75 miles north of San Francisco, one of the last great land holdings in Sonoma County, more than 5,000 acres of mountains, meadows and, yes, vineyards. And Jess Jackson owns it all. 
 "I often read about the Gallos," he said as he drove along, ignoring a 3,000-foot drop just inches from the car. "Everyone talks about how much land they own up here. Well, we own a lot more than they do."
What Mr. Jackson owns is nothing less than the fastest-growing and arguably most successful wine-making business to appear in California in 20 years. From a few acres of grapes in the early 1970's, he now controls more than a dozen wineries -- including his flagship, Kendall-Jackson -- stretching from all the choice growing regions of California to Europe and South America. Though still dwarfed by the E.& J. Gallo Company, the industry giant, Mr. Jackson's empire is now among the top 10 wine businesses in the country, with sales of about $200 million in 1996 from Kendall-Jackson alone, according to Jon Fredrikson, an industry economist. The smaller wineries produced another $30 million, Mr. Jackson said.
In the process, he has managed to change the way fine wine is made and marketed in the United States, leaving many in the business to marvel at his highly lean, efficient and integrated operation, which includes a barrel-making business and a distribution company. At the same time, the pugnacious Mr. Jackson, an experienced lawyer, has become the object of envy as well as admiration, and has generated a bumper crop of speculation and controversy.
Mr. Jackson's story combines the good fortune of a novice who has stumbled onto something new with the calculating eye of a master marketer who has found his magic niche.
An early mistake in the fermentation process of his Vintner's Reserve chardonnay created a surprise hit whose slight sweetness has inspired others to offer similar products. The competition also followed in his footsteps when Mr. Jackson carved out a new middle market for fine wines after carefully analyzing the existing price structure.
He has been largely alone, however, in bringing a lawyer's hardball style to the traditionally genteel wine business. Mr. Jackson took advantage of an industry downturn in the late 80's to snap up unprofitable vineyards and hire away well-regarded wine makers. And he has been involved in several high-profile legal battles, even taking on Gallo.
Now, as his business is poised for still more growth, the 66-year-old Mr. Jackson is clearly a major force to be reckoned with, even though, as he proudly says, he is still not part of "the old boy system."
"Jess came into the business as a real estate lawyer, and he still thinks like a lawyer," said one winery owner who has known Mr. Jackson for 20 years. "That's why wine people can't figure him out; they're not lawyers."
Rodney Strong, the founder of another Sonoma winery, Rodney Strong Vineyards, added, "He's not an insider in the wine business, but he's taught the insiders some valuable lessons about making and selling wine."
The original Jackson vineyard was a weekend hobby. By the late 1970's, Mr. Jackson, then a San Francisco lawyer, was selling grapes to several wineries.
"I never planned to get into the wine business," he said recently, "but there was a grape glut around 1978 and I couldn't sell what I had grown. So I had it made into wine."
His first vintages were called Chateau du Lac. By 1982, the name had been changed to Kendall-Jackson -- Kendall is the surname of Mr. Jackson's first wife -- and a winery was under construction.
While making his 1982 chardonnay, Mr. Jackson ran into a problem. At a crucial point, the fermentation stopped before all the sugar in the grapes was converted into alcohol and carbon dioxide.
Efforts to restart the process failed, and the wine was bottled with the unfermented sugar -- just a touch -- still in it. Vintner's Reserve was an instant success, and it has stayed that way. The reason, experts say, is that the new product legitimized the sweet taste of jug wine, attracting an army of drinkers willing to pay a few dollars more for the status of a better label.
From 18,000 cases that year, total Kendall-Jackson shipments rose to an estimated 2.6 million cases in 1996, with Vintner's Reserve accounting for 64 percent. No threat to Gallo, which produced an estimated 55 million cases in 1996, but impressive for a 14-year-old upstart.
"Jess is a genius at calculating price points," one of his competitors said. "In his early days, wineries like Sebastiani were going for the low end; $3, $4 a bottle. Others, like Chateau St. Jean, were developing the $9 category. Jess saw a space between the two and filled it."
Mr. Jackson concurred. "We sold out the '82 vintage in six months and price was certainly part of it. We started just under $5, then we raised it 12 times in 12 years." Vintner's Reserve now retails for around $12.
Besides Kendall-Jackson, now based in Santa Rosa here in Sonoma County, Mr. Jackson's holdings include 11 wineries in California, a winery and vineyards in Italy, a leased winery in Chile and two square miles of vines in Argentina. The wineries other than Kendall-Jackson are grouped under the name Artisans and Estates and produce small batches of higher-priced wines. [Mr. Jackson's operations were not affected by this week's flooding in some parts of California's wine country.]
Still to come are five new wineries in California.
"We are always looking for good properties," Mr. Jackson said.
Tall and rangy, with a shock of silver-white hair tumbling into his eyes, Jess Jackson bears a resemblance to Charlton Heston. Invariably dressed in jeans and boots, his face tanned from long exposure to the California sun, he looks every inch a man of the soil.
In fact, he is a city person, born in Los Angeles and raised in San Francisco. As a boy, wine was a part of his life. "San Francisco had a rich wine culture," he said. "I had an Italian uncle who made wine, and we drank it regularly. During the war, when they needed people in the vineyards, I picked grapes."
Mr. Jackson went to law school at the University of California at Berkeley, paying his way by working on the San Francisco docks and as a Berkeley policeman. While still a student, he did research for the late Pat Brown, then California's Attorney General and later Governor.
As a young lawyer, Mr. Jackson worked for the state, specializing in real estate law, invaluable training for a man who would become the state's busiest vineyard buyer.
Indeed, in California's wine business, which nurtures its laid-back image, Jess Jackson's drive and combativeness stand out.
He garnered considerable attention five years ago, for example, in a legal battle with Jedidiah T. Steele, his longtime wine maker.
At the heart of the dispute was the accusation by Mr. Jackson that Mr. Steele had revealed "trade secrets" about the process for making Vintner's Reserve shortly after leaving to start his own business. When Mr. Jackson stopped making severance payments to him, Mr. Steele sued, and Mr. Jackson countersued.
The fracas further separated Mr. Jackson from the wine establishment. Robert Mondavi and other prominent wine makers testified on Mr. Steele's behalf, saying that there was nothing really secret about the process. A ruling against Mr. Steele, they said, could stifle the cooperation that they maintained had enabled the California wine industry to make great strides in a relatively short time. The court ordered Mr. Jackson to pay Mr. Steele the balance of the severance agreement, but also found that Mr. Jackson's winery was entitled to keep the process to itself.
As his business expanded, Mr. Jackson roiled the industry's seemingly placid surface here by hiring away some of the competition's best people, then roiled it again when he announced that the Federal Government's labeling regulations, accepted by the rest of the industry, needed to be tightened -- a grandstanding move, critics said. (The Government is still reviewing his petition.)
Currently, Mr. Jackson is locked in a legal battle with Gallo over trademark infringement, accusing Gallo of copying a Kendall-Jackson label for its Turning Leaf line.
This is his second courtroom tussle with the Gallos. In 1986, in his previous life as a lawyer, Mr. Jackson represented Joseph Gallo Jr. in his unsuccessful attempt to wrest a share of the company from his older brothers, Ernest and the late Julio.
Kendall-Jackson's dramatic expansion at a time when other wineries were experiencing serious economic problems gave rise to some equally dramatic talk about the company's financial circumstances.
Mr. Jackson brushed off his critics with an impatient wave of the hand. "We are in excellent financial condition," he said, "and it gets better all the time. Why, we are the Bank of America's favorite winery."
In recent months, Mr. Jackson's hiring of a Los Angeles financial public relations firm gave rise to talk that he was about to take the company public.
"We reserve that option," Mr. Jackson said, "but we have absolutely no plans to do it now."
Jean-Michel Vallette, who watches the wine industry as a partner in Hambrecht & Quist, a San Francisco investment bank, agrees with the upbeat assessment.
"In the early days, Jess clearly needed outside help and was certainly highly leveraged," Mr. Vallette said. "But today he can attract the highest-quality lenders and get the most attractive financing terms. People have always underestimated just how profitable Kendall-Jackson is."
Mr. Jackson releases no precise figures but doesn't argue with an industry estimate that Kendall-Jackson has profits of about $40 million a year just from Vintner's Reserve.
At last count, at least 14 members of Mr. Jackson's family were working in the business. His second wife, Barbara Banke, also a lawyer, is president of one of the wineries.
The Jacksons live in a small frame house that stands in stark contrast to the palaces owned by some of his competitors. The house is just across the road from the winery where he keeps his office. His Lexus is six years old.
"I prefer to put my money in the business," Mr. Jackson said, sounding something like a man on a mission.
"I want to broaden the consumption base" of wine, he said, "and that means educating people. Wine is made out to be foreign, as opposed to beer, which is made to be American. We've got to make it more American. It's not going to blossom in American culture until we take the mystique out of it."

HEADLINE: Barnes & Noble to Move Into Yale Co-op Store

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE VAN GELDER 

 BODY:
The 111-year-old Yale Co-op has been left homeless after the university announced yesterday that Barnes & Noble would take over the Eero Saarinen-designed store that has been the co-op's home for 35 years.
The university announced that it had chosen Barnes & Noble College Bookstores, a sister company of the company that runs the nationwide book superstores, to occupy the co-op's current home at 65-77 Broadway on the edge of the Yale campus in New Haven when its lease expires on June 30. 
 Harry W. Berkowitz, the president of the co-op, said: "Let's say we're terribly disappointed. We have been looking at possible other sites for a number of months. We absolutely intend to continue in operation. I think the thing that's important is that we will be in business when the semester opens in the fall."
For the last few years, Yale and the city of New Haven have been revitalizing and renovating the Broadway area, and some students have joked that the university was hoping to remake the site in the image of trendy, bustling Harvard Square in Cambridge, Mass.
"The lease for the property was going to expire," said Tom Conroy, the deputy director of public affairs for the university. "And the university would have been remiss not to explore whether another business could better serve its students and faculty and New Haven neighbors."
In announcing its decision to replace the Co-op with Barnes & Noble on the Broadway site, the university also said that it was attracted by the company's willingness to keep its store open six nights a week, until 9 P.M., for the first two years of the agreement. The university said the night hours would give it an opportunity to build a base of shoppers and diners in the area in the evening. The new store will include a cafe.
The Co-op is now open until 5:30 P.M. Monday through Saturday and until 5 P.M. on Sunday.
The university also said that Barnes & Noble had committed $1.5 million to renovations and that Yale would realize an increased economic return from the property.
Yale owns 97,000 square feet of retailing space in the Broadway area. Mr. Berkowitz said the Co-op occupied 42,000 square feet in its four-level, flagstone building adjacent to Ezra Stiles College on the Yale campus.
He said the store had annual sales of almost $15 million and added, "We are the largest retailer in the city of New Haven." The Co-op, he said, carries everything from 130,000 books to Calvin Klein accessories, Timberland shoes and Crane stationery.
According to the university, the Broadway site is the seventh to be occupied by the Co-op since it was established by a group of students and professors in 1885 to provide goods and services to Yale students and faculty.
Mr. Berkowitz said the Co-op was the second-oldest university store in the country, behind Harvard's.
The Yale Co-op, essentially a nonprofit organization, has 15,000 members, Mr. Berkowitz said. Membership, at $5 a year or $15 for life, is open to Yale undergraduate and graduate students, Yale faculty and staff and employees of any school in Connecticut.

HEADLINE: Harried Shoppers Turned to Gift Certificates

BYLINE: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER 

 BODY:
During this past Christmas shopping season, a miracle did occur. Retailers offered something at full price, and customers bought it in droves. It was gift certificates, and they sold in record numbers, retailers and those who follow them said yesterday.
Sales of gift certificates -- those plain pieces of paper that guarantee a recipient will spend at least 10 fewer moments on the return line this month -- were up at least 5 percent in 1996 among dozens of retailers, and the trend was likely to continue, experts said. 
 Last year was particularly strong, they added, because of the five fewer shopping days between Thanksgiving and Christmas, which left many shoppers short on time and frantic for gifts. This was good news for retailers, many of which did not have a stellar season, because gift certificates offer them at least a few days with extra cash on their books to spend as they wish.
In a poll of 1,000 shoppers taken by the National Retail Federation before the holiday season, 34 percent said they intended to give gift certificates for Christmas, the highest number since the trade group began its survey 10 years ago.
Yesterday, retailers from Wal-Mart Stores Inc. to Barneys New York and the Sharper Image said that sales of gift certificates enjoyed a healthy increase this season, as harried shoppers chose to let loved ones select their own Kathie Lee Gifford sweater, lipstick or odd household gadget.
"Gift certificate sales have been growing every year," said Dan Horne, a professor of marketing at Providence College, who has been studying them for five years. "People are becoming geographically dispersed and they just don't understand the needs and wants of people far away, yet, they are required to give the gifts."
While many retailers are not releasing their Christmas sales figures yet, several said yesterday that sales of their gift certificates rose anywhere from 4 percent to 65 percent this holiday season. Barneys New York executives said their gift certificate sales increased 15 percent this year over last, and the Sharper Image reported a 10 percent gain. At the Kmart Corporation, gift certificate sales for all of 1996 were up in the "mid-single digits," a spokeswoman said. At Guess Inc. sales of certificates increased 21 percent.
Professor Horne said he expected that $8 billion to $10 billion worth of gift certificates changed hands in 1996.
That amount was likely to increase, he said, as people in a time-pressed culture stop thinking of gift certificates as the easy way out of shopping. "Gifts are sacred and money is profane," Professor Horne said. "But a gift certificate moves money into a domain that is more personal."
Also contributing to the increase, is a rise in corporations giving gift certificates as gifts. For example, Quality Food Centers Inc., a grocery store chain based in Bellevue, Wash., said that its gift certificate sales during the 1996 holiday season increased 65 percent over the previous year, principally as a result of corporate clients.
"Companies like to put them in employee gift baskets," Mike Barnhart, the vice president for marketing at Quality Food, said. "It is more or less the convenience factor. A company can call us up, we can turn them around in a day and their gift for their employees is done." Indeed, a survey of 300 malls by the International Council of Shopping Centers found that 60 percent of their gift certificates sales came from corporations.
Gift certificates benefit both consumers and retailers. The giver does not have to worry about things like color and style, and will not have to live through that shameful moment when the size 4 recipient unwraps the size 12 pants and learns how the giver really sees her.
For the recipient, there are equal perks. No return lines. No need to freeze a smile on the face and belt out, "Oh gee, a snowflake sweater!" Better still, gift certificates are money in hand to hit the sales racks with this month.
For retailers, gift certificates represent cash that can be spent freely, perhaps without having to give away a stick of merchandise. About 6 percent of gift certificates sold at major retail outlets are never redeemed, Professor Horne said, while at small retailers, that percentage climbs to as high as 30 or 40. Further, about 25 percent of shoppers buy more than their gift certificate is worth once they get into the store, according to the International Council of Shopping Centers survey.
"Gift certificates are a very good thing for a retailer," Arnold H. Aronson, a former chief executive of Saks Fifth Avenue, said. "Because they get their share of the profits up front. Certainly, a lot of people forget them. But if they are in your wallet, you always have a top-of-mind reason to go into the store. It is almost like a shopping bag in your wallet that you always see."
This is how the accounting part works: Retailers book a sale of a gift certificate as cash with a liability of the same amount. Once the gift certificate is redeemed, the liability is washed off the books and added to the revenue line. This means that in December, a retailer is walking around with extra cash that it can use, interest free, until the certificate is redeemed. Unredeemed certificates eventually fall off the liability line, and become a nice chunk of miscellaneous change.
"Retailers are getting the float," said Norman Strauss, the national director of the accounting firm of Ernst & Young. "So economically, they benefit."
Some stores made a special effort to turn shoppers toward the certificates this year. Barneys, for example, sold little black cards that resemble credit cards as chic-looking gift certificates. At Wal-Mart, extra tables were set up to sell gift certificates in $5 increments. The company said yesterday that 45 percent of their 1996 gift certificates were purchased in December, many by military personnel over the Internet.
"There was an extra surge at the end because of the shortened shopping time," Cathy Callegari, a spokeswoman for the International Mass Retail Association, said. "Merchandise is gone at the last minute, and people got desperate."

HEADLINE: Serbia Rejects European Call To Honor Vote

BYLINE: By CHRIS HEDGES 

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Serbia, Jan. 3

 BODY:
The Government of President Slobodan Milosevic today rejected calls by an international organization to reinstate opposition victories in Serbia's key cities.
The Government's decision, which was strongly condemned by the United States, indicated that Mr. Milosevic was stiffening his resolve against the tens of thousands of demonstrators who have taken to the streets for six weeks. 
 It also dashed recent speculation that Mr. Milosevic might be willing to allow his opponents to take power in Belgrade and other large cities, and suggested that the crisis here was deepening.
"This will fuel the conflict between Milosevic and the international community," Zoran Djindjic, an opposition leader, said tonight. "We will continue our protests until the unconditional recognition of the Nov. 17 results. Milosevic will eventually have to yield."
Serbia's refusal to relent came in response to a report by a team sent by the 54-nation Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe, a group that among other things, monitors elections and human rights abuses. Its members include European nations, Canada, the United States, Russia and the other former Soviet republics.
As the protests gathered strength last month, Serbia invited the group to review the Government's decision invalidating opposition victories in 14 of Serbia's 19 largest cities. The mission, led by former Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez of Spain, issued a report last month concluding that the opposition's claims were justified. A senior Belgrade official initially welcomed the findings and termed them constructive.
But today, that same official, Foreign Minister Milan Milutinovic, declined to accept most of the report's findings. He said the opposition coalition, called Zajedno, had prevailed only in the smaller cities of Uzice, Kragujevac and Zrenjanin.
But in Belgrade, the pivotal capital city of Serbia, Mr. Milutinovic said the governing Socialist Party had retained control over most of the seats in the city assembly. He did say the opposition had won 9 of the 16 wards in the race for the less powerful Belgrade local council, which is elected separately.
In Nis, the city were the protests began, Mr. Milutinovic said, it remained uncertain who had won. He called on the Organization for Security and Cooperation to provide more data on six other municipalties that the opposition says it won, and he insisted that no party won a majority in Pirot, Pancevo and Jagodina, the three remaining contested cities.
Meeting today in Vienna, the European organization called for "prompt and complete implementation" of the report, said its chairman, Lars Vissing of Denmark.
In Washington, Administration officials said American efforts to strengthen the group's stance against Mr. Milosevic had been blocked by Russia, which has traditional ly supported the Serbs.
Secretary of State Warren Christopher wrote a letter to Mr. Milosevic warning that his refusal to recognize the opposition's victories would lead to Serbia's further isolation.
Administration officials said Mr. Milosevic appeared willing to recognize opposition victories in some provincial cities, but was unwilling to give up political control over Belgrade, where the local authorities issue newspaper and radio licenses, for instance.
Mr. Burns said Mr. Milutinovic's response "does not go nearly far enough," contained "hollow assurances" of Serbia's commitment to democracy and "fails to address seriously the recommendations" in the European organization's report that could help resolve Serbia's political crisis.
It remains unclear what the organization can do to enforce its recommendations. It suspended Yugoslavia, consisting of Serbia and Montenegro, from its ranks in 1992 because of what it said was Belgrade's role in fomenting the war in Bosnia.
The State Department has raised the possibility of renewing sanctions against Yugoslavia, lifted after Mr. Milosevic's decision to support the Dayton peace agreement. But most Western diplomats say sanctions will be considered only if Mr. Milosevic uses violence to end the protests.
The protests, which mark the first sustained opposition to the Serbian leader in five years, have broadened in recent weeks, with the opposition now demanding Mr. Milosevic's ouster.
Mr. Milosevic, who presides over an economy that has virtually collapsed, is trying to rejoin European organizations and gain admittance to bodies like the United Nations and the International Monetary Fund. He is also seeking to get international credits, blocked by the United States and other Western nations. But he has no hope of achieving these goals as long as he refuses to honor the original vote count, Western diplomats said.
The rejection of the organization's recommendations appears to have fueled the resolve of the opposition, now blocked by the police from demonstrating in Belgrade streets and confined to a square in the city center.
"One of the measures we will begin to take now will be a peaceful and legal removal of these police forces from the streets of Belgrade," said Vuk Draskovic, an opposition leader. "This city has become a camp. It is the only city in Europe where people can not walk freely."

HEADLINE: Construction Spending Rises In Sign of Economic Strength

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3

 BODY:
Construction spending rose unexpectedly in November at the fastest rate since March of last year, the Government said today, in yet another sign the economy was heading into the new year on a firm footing.
Spending increased 1.9 percent in November, to $592 billion at an annual rate, the Commerce Department reported. In October, spending rose a revised 1.5 percent, initially reported as a 1.8 percent gain, reflecting growth in nearly all major categories. Analysts had expected a drop of four-tenths of 1 percent in construction spending. 
 Even though the data suggested that the economy grew at a faster pace in the last three months of the year than the 2.1 percent annual rate in the third quarter, analysts said they did not expect the report would help persuade the Federal Reserve to raise short-term interest rates.
The Commerce Department report showed that outlays for public projects -- from schools to roads -- rose 2.5 percent, to a $150.3 billion pace. Spending on private, nonresidential projects surged 1.6 percent, to $152.3 billion. And residential construction outlays rose 1.2 percent, to $247.6 billion in November, as mortgage rates fell.
Single-family home construction fell three-tenths of 1 percent, while spending on multifamily homes rose 5.6 percent in the month.
Still, individual builders expect to see strong demand for houses throughout the new year.
"I am more optimistic today than I was earlier last year," said Robert J. Strudler, chairman and chief executive of the U.S. Home Corporation of Houston. "Stability of interest rates will provide reasons to be optimistic about '97. Demand numbers may not be stronger than in 1996, but it is still an attractive market."
Other recent indicators show continued strength in housing. Earlier this week, the Commerce Department reported that new-home sales rose unexpectedly in November, by 14.2 percent, as all regions of the country reported increases. The gain in November new-home sales to a seasonally adjusted annual sales rate of 772,000 represented a rebound from a revised 13.3 percent decline in October sales.
The jump in new-home sales also corresponded with a 1.8 percent rise in sales of existing homes in November, the first increase in six months and the result of a steady decline in mortgage rates since early September, industry analysts said.

HEADLINE: Treasury Prices End Mixed After Strong Building Data

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities finished mixed yesterday, as a stronger-than-expected construction report led to concerns of a Fed tightening. However, market talk about the possibility that the Japanese would be heavy buyers of Treasury debt next week kept prices up.
The 30-year bond rose 1/32 , to a price of 971/32 to yield 6.73 percent, unchanged from Thursday, with trading volume down 20 percent from the average for a Friday in the first quarter of last year. 
 In currency trading, the dollar rose against the yen, trading near a 45-month high versus that currency. Its strength helped underpin prices in the bond market.
Traders often note that a strong dollar makes United States-denominated investments like Treasury securities attractive to foreign investors, thereby raising prices and, in turn, lowering yields. Also, after two sharp declines in market prices, yields may have reached levels that were too attractive to pass up.
The unexpected rise in November construction spending that was reported yesterday pared some of the early market gains. Investors feared that a spurt in the building sector could force the Fed to raise short-term interest rates to contain inflation; consequently, they sold holdings. According to the Commerce Department, spending in November increased 1.9 percent, to $592 billion at an annual rate. In October spending rose a revised 1.5 percent; the initial report was a 1.8 percent gain. Economists surveyed by Bloomberg Business News had expected a drop of four-tenths of a percent.
Jack Regan, chief derivative strategist at Josephthal, Lyon & Ross, said the bond market's rally from early losses and subsequent failure to maintain those gains had to be considered disappointing and troublesome going into next week, when the December Producer Price Index and December payroll number are released.
"These two statistics have historically given the market fits," he said. "And the uncertainty of these numbers will most certainly be gnawing at traders and dealers as they try to position themselves accordingly.
"You probably won't see any significant move upward in bond prices next week because traders and dealers price in some insurance against surprising data."
That is especially true after signs of economic strength this week that ranged from consumer confidence at a seven-year high to a 14.2 percent surge in sales of new single-family homes in November, he added.
Elsewhere in the fixed-income market, Mexico is to sell a $1 billion 10-year global bond issue through Merrill Lynch and Salomon Brothers as joint lead managers. The securities will pay a fixed rate of return to be determined next week. The bonds will be denominated in dollars, with delivery a week after the sale.

HEADLINE: Pataki and Silver: Political Rift Becomes Personal Antipathy

BYLINE: By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 2

 BODY:
Deals affecting the life of every New Yorker are struck here in the back rooms of the State Capitol as New York's three main power brokers hash out their differences in delicate, often protracted negotiations.
But when two of those three men bear such hostility toward each other that they do not even like to sit in the same back room, it can become excruciatingly difficult for the state government to accomplish much of anything. 
 Many officials here fear that this is exactly what is happening between Gov. George E. Pataki and his main rival in the Legislature, Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, on the eve of the 1997 legislative session -- a session facing issues that would be trying under the best conditions, like rent control, welfare, a projected $3 billion budget shortfall and tougher criminal penalties.
The tensions between them, which spilled into the open in recent days with Mr. Silver leveling a barrage of attacks against Mr. Pataki, have been mounting since the two men clashed during closed-door discussions last month, when the Legislature met for a daylong special session.
With suspicions running high, the nature of negotiating major bills in Albany seems to be changing. More than in the past, Mr. Pataki and Mr. Silver have begun linking fistfuls of bills to each other, refusing to agree to any one until agreement is reached on all. That style of hostage taking was particularly in evidence during the special session when late-morning agreements on half a dozen bills collapsed by late afternoon because of a fight between Mr. Silver and Mr. Pataki over legislative pay, aides to both men say.
The tension has persuaded many legislators, Republicans and Democrats alike, that the 1997 session will be at least as contentious and drawn out as the 1996 session, which produced the latest state budget in the nation's history and saw an array of important pieces of legislation used as bargaining chips by both sides.
In fact, Mr. Silver strongly suggested in a recent interview that he would follow suit if the Governor held issues hostage in next year's budget talks. "Next year, we may live by his rules," he said, referring to Mr. Pataki. "Two can play the same game."
Of course, it is no surprise that Mr. Pataki, a Republican, and Mr. Silver, a Democrat, would tangle on partisan grounds. But the hostilities between them appear to run so deep that many lawmakers say they have engaged in tactics that have gone beyond the bounds of the routine give-and-take of the legislative process.
The bad blood has resulted in more distrust and fewer meetings between the two men, aides to Mr. Silver say. They say the Speaker believes the Governor is genuinely uncomfortable being in the same room with him and therefore leaves critical issues to be negotiated by staff members.
In the process, Mr. Silver has become less guarded in his criticism of Mr. Pataki, saying after the special session that the Governor has not shown leadership and that he speaks out of both sides of his mouth, criticizing New York City to upstate residents, then telling city residents he is their ally.
Beyond the personality clash, the Governor's and the Speaker's attitudes toward Albany-style politics contrast sharply, reflecting their different experiences in Albany. Mr. Silver has been a diligent student of the Legislature's byzantine ways, rising through the ranks of the Assembly to a variety of leadership roles. By contrast, Mr. Pataki has long cast himself as an outsider, even when he was an Assemblyman and a State Senator.
Mr. Pataki says legislative leaders like Mr. Silver simply have too much power. "Even as a legislator," he said, "I was frustrated by the top-down system because I had ideas and principles that would have helped make this a better state."
The rift has even begun to worry the third member of the Albany triumvirate, Joseph L. Bruno, the Republican majority leader of the State Senate. "I am concerned," he said. "I hope that it gets behind us and we start anew."
The latest round of hostilities began a few weeks ago, when the Legislature convened for the one-day special session. Mr. Pataki and Mr. Silver ended the day by publicly accusing each other of refusing to act on several important pieces of legislation as a means of extracting concessions from each other.
Mr. Silver was particularly outraged that the Governor refused to consider a pay raise for lawmakers because the Speaker would not acquiesce on other issues, including a plan to build a maximum-security prison, according to Mr. Silver's aides and legislators with knowledge of the negotiations. Mr. Pataki also refused to consider a bill that would extend existing stipends for members who hold leadership positions in the Assembly, a move that the Speaker's aides denounced as a breach of professional courtesy.
All this left Mr. Silver empty-handed when he returned to his members, many of whom have been quietly pressing him to strike a deal for a pay raise. Mr. Silver said he regarded it as extortion for the Governor to link the question of pay raises to complicated pieces of legislation. Pataki aides denied this ever happened.
More important, many Democrats say they believe that the episode was orchestrated by Mr. Pataki to create dissent among Assembly members and thus undermine Mr. Silver as leader.
"I think they have done a number of things to drive a wedge in the Assembly conference," said Deborah J. Glick, a Democratic Assemblywoman from Manhattan. "I think it was a matter of trying to aggravate individual members."
Privately, there are people close to the Governor who acknowledge that they would like to weaken Mr. Silver's control over the 95 Democrats in the Assembly. That, they reason, might strengthen their ability to build coalitions in the Assembly between conservative Democrats and Republicans.
But others in the Pataki administration contend that the Governor would be best served by trying to reach agreement with the Speaker, not antagonizing him. In fact, many Democrats say that the skirmishes with the Governor may end up strengthening Mr. Silver's hand in the next session.
They say they feel compelled to rally behind him, as they did last year, when Republicans ran television ads aimed at pressuring conservative Democratic Assembly members to break ranks with Mr. Silver, a more liberal Democrat from Manhattan.
"I think the Governor's tactics will backfire," said Martin A. Luster, a Democratic Assemblyman from Ithaca. "I think the conference is solidifying under Shelly, and we will remain united on major issues."
For his part, Mr. Pataki has sought to play down the tensions. "I've read the Speaker's characterizations, and from my standpoint, I will continue to do everything I can to work with the Speaker," he said at a news conference on Monday.
But Mr. Silver's aides say he is disturbed by the disdain he believes Mr. Pataki has shown toward the Legislature during his first two years as Governor. They cite Mr. Pataki's threat last year to withhold the pay of lawmakers if they failed to enact a budget by the April 15 deadline.
"George feels no relationship with his former colleagues," said Assemblyman Richard L. Brodsky, a Westchester Democrat. "He has complete contempt for the Legislature's values and needs."
Aides to Mr. Pataki, however, say he has done what is necessary to change longstanding legislative practices that he believes have hurt New York's economy, among other things.
"The Governor was not elected to protect the status quo," said Michael McKeon, a spokesman for the Governor. "Sometimes, it takes a little convincing to bring people along."
