HEADLINE: A Born Revolutionary's Path To a Living 'Tomb' in Peru

BYLINE: By DIANA JEAN SCHEMO 

DATELINE: LIMA, Peru, Jan. 3

 BODY:
Victor Polay Campos, the jailed founder of the Tupac Amaru Revolutionary Movement, is the son of leftist political reformers whose roots go back to the labor struggles of the 1930's. Mr. Polay's tale of taking up arms is part of a political struggle that meanders through the history of Peru in this century -- a tale whose chapters would look hauntingly like the family's photo album.
The release of the 45-year-old leader and some 400 others of their imprisoned comrades is the core demand of Tupac Amaru guerrillas who continue to hold 74 hostages inside the Japanese Ambassador's residence, which they seized on Dec. 17. 
 Mr. Polay, his vision faltering, his spirits reported nearly broken, lives in a dark concrete box measuring 6.5 feet along each wall. His mother, Otilia Campos de Polay, who owns a hardware store in the working-class neighborhood of El Callao, calls it his "tomb." He has been held in solitary confinement at a maximum security prison at a naval base not far from her store for three years.
Mrs. Polay said in an interview that Victor Polay founded Tupac Amaru in 1983, a year after he returned from university studies in Madrid and Paris. In Paris, he had been a roommate of Alan Garcia, a future President who hailed from the American Popular Revolutionary Alliance, known as APRA.
That left-wing, anti-imperialist party, which started in the 1930's, counted among its founders Mr. Polay's father, Victor Polay Risco. Mrs. Polay said her husband, who died four years ago, was imprisoned from 1930 to 1945 for his political activities. Her own parents, Alfredo Campos and Maria Barcena, were founders of APRA in Cuzco, she said.
After the election of Mr. Garcia in 1985, the first time APRA had won the presidency, Victor Polay said he would give his former roommate a year to fulfill the promises to the poor of the party. By the late 1980's, Mr. Polay had carried out his threat to turn to violence.
Mr. Garcia, whose boyish charm made him the darling of Peruvians for the first two years of his administration, did fulfill many of his campaign pledges, with measures like paying only 10 percent of the foreign debt, instituting price controls and eventually nationalizing banks. The effects were disastrous -- hyperinflation, rampant unemployment and a shrinking economy -- and guerrillas of Shining Path and Tupac Amaru gained ground during his administration.
Mr. Garcia ended his presidency lonely and discredited.
Mrs. Polay said her son's decision to create a guerrilla movement to back his Marxist ideas frightened her. At 68, she is old enough to have childhood memories of APRA's early years of struggle.
"I always thought it was dangerous," she said in an interview. "Like any mother, I was very worried, because I didn't agree with this exaggerated idealism of my son. I had lived through the 1930's, the whole sad story of the APRA party, which had been persecuted and tortured, and so I knew I didn't want the same path for my son but something better.
"We had already suffered so much for the country, because at every moment, we, Apristas, were being locked up, assassinated."
"We had a mountain of dead," she said. "We had 6,000 dead."
The group her son founded, while considered less indiscriminate in its use of violence than the Maoists of Shining Path, is accused of assassinations and bombings. In 1989 it killed the Defense Minister, Gen. Enrique Lopez Albuhar, and it later kidnapped David Ballon Vera, a mining executive who was found starved to death, his body scarred and showing signs of torture.
Tupac Amaru remains one of the last holdovers of the Battalion America, an umbrella group that included the M-19 guerrilla group in Colombia, which laid down its weapons and became a legal party in 1991.
The Peruvians also had close links with other Latin American guerrilla movements that have left off violent confrontations since the fall of Communism in the Soviet Union, including the Sandinistas in Nicaragua and the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front in El Salvador.
Exposed to the political process, those movements fizzled out or proved minor draws at the ballot box. But here, after the killing of more than 30,000 people by the military and guerrillas, Peruvians insist upon the rule of law as the starting point for any discussions.
According to figures supplied by the Andean Commission of Jurists, a human rights organization, of the roughly 4,500 people killed in guerrilla conflict in Peru in 1991, the most violent year, 3,145 were killed by the military, 1,314 by Shining Path and 139 by Tupac Amaru.
President Alberto K. Fujimori has built his political life on an unyielding, avowedly pitiless stand against guerrillas for the violence they promote.
"Nobody can believe that destroying factories, roads, bridges, threatening investors and tourists, and committing bloody crimes will reduce poverty," Mr. Fujimori said in a speech Thursday at the Palace of Justice.
In his cell, Victor Polay's political education has come to an end. Though he is allowed to read novels, prison officials turn away any writing that is remotely political, his mother said. Most recently, the memoirs of Winston Churchill were rejected.
Perhaps because Mr. Polay and other members of Tupac Amaru tunneled their way out of another jail in the final days of Mr. Garcia's presidency, his cell now is a box of reinforced concrete, with just a six-inch hole in the ground for a toilet and a six-inch hole in the ceiling for light and air. With the siege of the Japanese Ambassador's residence, his visiting privileges -- 30 minutes with two people once a month -- have been suspended.
Mrs. Polay, while not defending the Marxism that Tupac Amaru advances, said socialist ideals were not unworkable simply because Communism had failed throughout Eastern Europe.
She said she had been three times to Europe, where Mr. Polay's wife, Rosa, and their three children live, and had also visited Asia, and nowhere had she found the kind of poverty that is endemic in much of South America.
"How can you compare Russia or Germany, one of the countries that have always been so advanced in terms of workers' rights, countries of great men, of great chemical discoveries, to Latin America," she said. "I don't mean Marxism. Please don't put down that I'm talking about Marxism. I mean socialism adapted to the Peruvian reality."
And she believes there is precedent for change, for APRA had been outlawed four times before being legalized for the last time and winning the presidency in 1985. Others say the comparison is disingenuous.
"It ignores history," said Congresswoman Lourdes Flores Nano of the Popular Christian Party. "APRA has always been a political party in terms of fighting democratically."
"The M.R.T.A. are terrorists," she said, using the Spanish initials of Tupac Amaru.
The Tupac Amaru guerrillas in the Japanese Ambassador's residence have not raised the prospect of a peace agreement, and an above-ground political role for them, since the siege began.
Though the group had seemed to be moving in that direction, it is a subject many Peruvians say cannot be addressed as long as they are holding hostages.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Texaco Settles With U.S. To Avoid Discrimination Suit
Texaco, avoiding a discrimination lawsuit by the Government, agreed to a settlement under which the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission will directly monitor the company's compliance with employment laws, lawyers involved in the case said. 
 The unusually broad settlement will allow the Federal agency to scrutinize Texaco's hiring and promotion practices for the next five years to insure there is no discrimination against minority employees. Texaco must report annually to the commission on every job opening and promotion, as well as the race of every candidate. [Page 36.]
 
Apple Expects Quarterly Loss
Apple Computer said it expected to report a loss of $100 million to $150 million for its most recent quarter, a much sharper loss than analysts had expected. [37.]
 
Construction Spending Gains 1.9%
Construction spending increased 1.9 percent in November, to $592 billion at an annual rate, the Commerce Department reported. Analysts had expected a drop of four-tenths of 1 percent. The rise was the fastest rate since March of last year. Following Thursday's report of increased manufacturing activity, it suggested that the economy is moving ahead on a firm footing. [36.]
 
Prices of Treasury securities were mixed. The stronger-than-expected construction report led to concerns of a Fed tightening. The 30-year bond rose 1/32 , to a price of 971/32 to yield 6.73 percent, unchanged from Thursday. [48.]
 
U.S. Gives In to Trading Partners
Hoping to quell the anger of some of the nation's strongest trading partners -- Canada, Mexico and some European nations -- President Clinton announced that he intended to waive indefinitely the most disputed part of the Helms-Burton law, which punishes foreign companies using American property confiscated in Cuba nearly 40 years ago. [1.]
 
Airbus Partners Reach an Accord
The four partners in Airbus Industrie reached an accord on how to restructure the airplane builder to make it more competitive. Ending months of squabbling were: Daimler-Benz Aerospace, of Germany, Aerospatiale of France, British Aerospace and Construcciones Aeronauticas of Spain. [48.]
 
Railroads Win Rate-Setting Right
The nation's railroads have won a fight with their customers over whether the carriers have the right to set the rates on routes they serve exclusively. The Surface Transportation Board ruled that a railroad that exclusively served a short line to a power plant could not be forced to offer a shipper lower prices, even if the shipper used another railway for the long-haul portion of the same coal shipment. [36.]
 
Fraud Charge Expected in Germany
The Frankfurt prosecutor's office is expected to announce on Monday that it has charged the real estate investor Jurgen Schneider with fraud in a spectacular corporate collapse. [48.]
 
Dollar Lifted by Stocks' Rally
The dollar was lifted by the rally in American stocks, settling at 116.43 yen, the highest level since March 1993, and at 1.5644 German marks, the highest since December 1994. [38.]
 
Gold futures fell more than 1 percent to a three-year low of $362 an ounce on the Comex, pressed by a strong dollar and by speculation about gold sales by European central banks. Other precious metals futures also slid. [38.]
 
Italian Financier Flees the U.S.
Giancarlo Parretti, the Italian financier, has fled the U.S. Sentencing was scheduled for Monday for perjury and evidence tampering in the case that cost him control of MGM studios. His lawyer said he had received a fax from Mr. Parretti saying he was in Italy. [36.]
 
The Barnes & Noble Bulldogs?
The 111-year-old Yale Co-op was left homeless after Yale announced that Barnes & Noble would take over the Eero Saarinen-designed store on the edge of its campus in New Haven on June 30. The university said that Barnes & Noble had committed $1.5 million to renovations and that its store would include a cafe and stay open later than the co-op. [29.]

HEADLINE: ONE KEY ELEMENT IN ANTI-CUBA LAW POSTPONED AGAIN

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3

 BODY:
Hoping to quell the anger of some of America's strongest trading partners, President Clinton said today that he intended to waive indefinitely part of a law that punishes foreign companies that use American property confiscated in Cuba nearly 40 years ago.
The President said he did not want the furor that the law has set off in Canada, Mexico and Europe to jeopardize what he described as an emerging international effort to isolate Fidel Castro and his Communist Government. 
 "We must sustain our efforts to hasten the arrival of democracy in Cuba," Mr. Clinton said in a statement issued by the White House as he vacationed in the Virgin Islands. "As a result of increasing international pressure, we have never been closer to that day."
The decision today suspends for another six months the provision of the law that would allow United States citizens or corporations to sue any foreign company using confiscated American property in Cuba. Mr. Clinton first suspended that provision in July after America's trading partners threatened to retaliate.
And Mr. Clinton indicated that he would continue to suspend the provision every six months "so long as America's friends and allies continue their stepped-up efforts" to advocate democratic changes in Cuba.
Although none have joined Washington's 34-year economic embargo of Cuba, the President and his aides here pointed to several steps taken by those allies in recent months, including a vote by the European Union last month urging Mr. Castro's Government to improve its record on human rights and political freedom.
With his decision, Mr. Clinton appeared to be trying to strike a balance between the conflicting demands of Republicans in Congress and of trading partners abroad. Judging by today's reactions, he did not succeed.
Representative Dan Burton, the Indiana Republican who sponsored the law with Senator Jesse Helms of North Carolina, condemned the President's action, saying Mr. Clinton had decided "once again to pass up a perfect opportunity to send a strong message to the Castro dictatorship and to those who prop it up financially."
At the same time, officials in Canada, Mexico and Europe remain critical of the Helms-Burton law. The European Union's envoy to the United States, Hugo Paemen of Belgium, welcomed the decision to suspend the law's most onerous provision, but said that did not resolve the underlying problem with the law itself, which Europeans say attempts to impose American foreign policy on other nations.
Canada's International Trade Minister, Arthur Eggleton, accused the United States of "continuing to hold this sword over the heads of other countries."
Mexico was cautiously upbeat. "The Mexican Government recognizes that the decision of President Clinton marks an effort to take into account the opinion of the international community," the Foreign Ministry said in a statement reported by Reuters.
But the ministry added, "The Mexican Government reaffirms the need to resolve any international differences via open and respectful dialogue, not via unilateral and confrontational methods."
For now, the President's decision appears to avert a trade showdown, including the possibility of tit-for-tat legal retaliation from abroad. Canada and Mexico have each passed legislation that would allow anyone punished by the American law to seek damages in their courts.
Nor did the President's decision resolve legal challenges to the law still being pressed in the World Trade Organization and under the North American Free Trade Agreement between the United States, Canada and Mexico.
The Helms-Burton Act was passed by Congress last March to discourage foreign investments in Cuba and to promote democratic changes.
In addition to allowing the lawsuits, the law requires the State Department to deny visas to the executives of foreign companies that use offices, factories or other properties once owned by Americans but seized after the Communist revolution that swept Mr. Castro to power in 1959.
Mr. Clinton originally opposed the law, but he signed it after the outrage that erupted when Cuban fighter jets shot down two small planes piloted by Cuban-Americans off Cuba's coast last February. He later suspended the provision allowing the lawsuits after America's allies warned of retaliation and officials within the Administration began to fear a trade war.
In the middle of an election year, the President's maneuvering led to accusations that he was putting off a decision while trying to cultivate support of Cuban-American voters in Florida and New Jersey, states with important electoral votes.
In August the President appointed Stuart E. Eizenstat, the Undersecretary for International Trade at the Commerce Department, as a special envoy to try to find common ground with the allies on other political and economic steps to isolate Cuba.
At a news conference today, Mr. Eizenstat said the controversy over the Helms-Burton Act had focused the attention of European and other nations on democracy in Cuba. He noted that the European Union's resolution last month for the first time linked economic relations with Cuba to improvements in Mr. Castro's policies on human rights.
While such efforts appear to have had little effect on Mr. Castro's grip on power, Mr. Eizenstat and other officials said they have had a punitive impact by isolating Cuba politically and by discouraging foreign investors.
Senator Helms denounced Mr. Clinton's decision as "a terrible mistake." In singling out Mexico and Canada for what he called "shameful Cuba policies," Senator Helms said: "I cannot understand why, just as we are beginning to make progress, the President has decided to give up the very leverage that brought such progress about."
Mr. Clinton said the Administration would continue to enforce other provisions of the Helms-Burton Act, including the one denying visas to executives of foreign companies.
The State Department has already imposed that punishment on a Mexican telecommunications company, Grupo Domos, and a Canadian mining concern, Sherritt International. Mr. Eizenstat said today that 12 other companies were under investigation for violating the law. On Monday, he said, the United States notified BM Group, an Israeli company involved in sugar and citrus production in Cuba, that its executives could face visa restrictions.

HEADLINE: Stamford Reinvents Its Downtown Once Again

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

DATELINE: STAMFORD, Conn.

 BODY:
SOMETHING remarkable is happening these days in downtown Stamford, something that has not been seen in years: An office building is under construction.
A decade ago, of course, there would have been nothing at all remarkable about such an event. Stamford was at the crest of an extraordinary construction boom led by the F. D. Rich Company, which held the development contract for the 130-acre urban-renewal district at Stamford's core. Building after building had transformed this industrial town on the Connecticut coast into a corporate center with few rivals. 
 But then shadows swallowed the gleaming cityscape. Among the numerous milestones of decline: In 1988, the Singer Company, which occupied a tower in Rich's Stamford Forum complex, was reorganized and moved to Florida. In 1990, Bloomingdale's closed its 36-year-old store. In 1992, after protracted flirtation, the Morgan Stanley Group gave up its option to build at the critical "gateway" site across Interstate 95 from the train station.
By that time, one quarter of the office space in Stamford stood empty. And F. D. Rich itself, badly overextended in the boom years, gave back most of its properties to its lenders, one after the other, losing even its signature structure (and headquarters), the swooping Brasilia-like Landmark Tower.
The turnaround was subtle at first, as smaller office tenants -- boutique investment banking concerns, venture capitalists, publishers and software developers, reinsurance companies, shippers -- began taking chunks of the vast space left behind by corporate giants.
More dramatic was the announcement in 1994 by the Swiss Bank Corporation that it would build on the "gateway" site. And today, as its vast trading floor and granite-clad office tower take shape next to I-95, the gloom over downtown Stamford seems to have lifted.
"We hit bottom and had the resources to rebound," said Mayor Dannel P. Malloy, a Democrat entering his second year in office. For a mayor, the equation is simple. "I need taxes," Mr. Malloy said, "so I like to see building."
The office vacancy rate is around 12 percent, the lowest rate in 10 years, said Kip Bergstrom, Stamford's director of economic development. And, he added, it's still falling.
"What happened to pull Stamford around was not only the resurgence of New York but frankly a lot of movement out of New York," said Anthony E. Malkin, whose family owns properties in both cities, including Metro Center, the bow-fronted building near Stamford's train station.
Local leaders now envision the city center as a 24-hour-a-day hub, luring more financial giants like Swiss Bank, providing hundreds of new apartments and offering ever livelier choices in dining, shopping and entertainment. They believe Stamford can cultivate a vibrant pedestrian environment, too, having learned from the urbanistic mistake in the last boom of setting new buildings atop parking garages, which created a barren, fortress-like streetscape.
"The community is maturing and seeing itself as a city," Mayor Malloy said. "I'd defy you to find a city of 100,000 that's built 1,000 units of housing in 20 years -- and we've done it in three."
After 37 years of redevelopment, the Rich family takes an even longer view. "What's happening fits in with our plan," said Robert N. Rich, president of the Rich Company. "I always said that the major housing thrust couldn't occur until we changed the character of downtown."
Today, that transformation continues, on the very site that Morgan Stanley abandoned. There, SBC Warburg, the investment-banking division of Swiss Bank, is building a $150 million, 570,000-square-foot North American corporate center that will include what its architects, Skidmore, Owings & Merrill, believe will be the largest clear-span trading floor in North America.
On the Swiss Bank campus, an intricately landscaped park called Gateway Commons will be laid out along Washington Boulevard after the demolition next year of an office building at No. 655. The park is intended as a welcoming pedestrian link to the Stewart B. McKinney Transportation Center, which includes the Metro-North Railroad station. The station will be extended toward the commons next year after the construction of a new concourse, also designed by Skidmore, under the elevated highway.
Drivers will find the garage at Swiss Bank tucked as far out of sight as a 1,400-space structure can be: behind a 13-story office tower and under the 60,000-square-foot trading floor, with its distinctive roof, reminiscent of a giant airfoil. In future phases, one or two more office buildings may be added to the 12-acre campus and the trading floor may also grow in size.
JUST up Washington Boulevard, at Broad Street, the vacant Bloomingdale's has been stripped to a structural skeleton that looks for the moment like the hypostyle hall of an Egyptian temple. After a $40 million transformation, to be completed next year, this will be the Stamford branch of the University of Connecticut.
The 225,000-square-foot academic center, designed by Perkins Eastman Architects, is intended to be the heart of a new UConn campus, which may eventually be linked by parkland to the nearby Rippowam River. The reconstructed Bloomie's will have a three-story, glass-walled concourse along its Broad Street facade, off of which will be entrances to the library and conference center, computer labs, dining areas, book store and art gallery.
Four blocks west on Broad Street, construction is nearing completion on a 402-apartment complex, Avalon Grove, which is being developed by Avalon Properties of Wilton, Conn., and designed by Becker & Becker Associates of New Canaan, Conn. The gable-roofed units are arranged around two courtyards straddling a private center street, reached through an arch at the foot of Suburban Avenue. Rents range from $1,300 for the least expensive one-bedroom unit to $2,900 for the top of the three-bedroom line. About half the apartments are already leased.
South of the UConn site, on Summer Street, Crown Theaters has broken ground for the Majestic, a six-screen, 1,632-seat cinema. "We really feel the area is coming into its own again," said Daniel M. Crown, president and chief executive of the theater chain, based in Norwalk, Conn.
A block away, at the Palace Theater, the stage is being doubled in depth to 40 feet so that the Stamford Center for the Arts can present full-fledged Broadway musicals in the 70-year-old, 1,600-seat house.
"The Palace auditorium is fantastic but the stage is very limiting," said F. D. (Frank) Rich Jr., president of the arts center and chairman of the Rich Company. "It was built for vaudeville and movies, not for 'Phantom of the Opera.' " The second phase of the Palace renovation calls for an expansion into an adjacent site on Atlantic Street once occupied by Il Forno restaurant.
As it is, backstage is now so cramped, said John Hiddlestone, development director for the center, that non-principal dancers in "The Nutcracker" have to get dressed at a ballet school across the street and walk to the Palace in costume.
On a smaller scale, the stately, neoclassical Citizens Savings Bank building reopened four months ago as the Bank Street Brewing Company restaurant. A fermentation tank, brew kettle and mash tun have been added -- giving new meaning to "bank draft" -- but the stained-glass skylight dome, coffered ceilings and angel reliefs remain.
Beyond these visible signs of recovery are any number of ambitious plans for the future. The city has received seven proposals for the residential redevelopment of the 3.4-acre site of the former Burdick School, on Forest Street.
AN $80 million proposal called Park Square West has been chosen by the city for a large swath of two downtown blocks north of Columbus Park, known by their official designation as Blocks 8 and 9.
To be developed by the Corcoran, Jennison Companies and Berkeley Investments of Boston, the first phase of the project would have 140 apartments in a 7-story building on Summer Street and up to 40,000 square feet of retail space. Eventually, there are to be 260 more apartments in a 14-story building on Washington Boulevard, and a total of 75,000 square feet of retail space, including a 35,000-square-foot upscale greengrocer. The architects are Arrowstreet Inc. of Cambridge, Mass.
The Rich family and the United Development Corporation, controlled by the Kahn family, have their own plans for a large parcel they control along Broad Street, adjacent to the Park Square West site. They propose a three-story, 150,000-square-foot Sears store, with a 450-space underground parking garage to be financed by a municipal bond issue.
For the moment, there is a dispute over the extent to which Park Square West departs from previously established development criteria. "Where will people park?" asked Thomas L. Rich, senior vice president of the Rich Company. "Not only did they under-design the parking but they increased the retail with a parking-intensive use."
The project manager for the Park Square West joint venture, Stephanie S. Wasser, said she was hopeful that the city would resolve its differences with the Riches and that construction of the project could begin next summer. For his part, Mr. Rich said the dispute should not impede Corcoran, Jennison's progress.
Another strategically vital site is at Tresser Boulevard and Atlantic Street, a crossroads occupied by the silvery headquarters of Champion International Corporation, the glass-fronted Rich Forum and the curving 300 Atlantic Street office building. On the southwest corner is a one-story "taxpayer" structure.
Here, the Hines Interests envisions a 450,000-square-foot financial center not unlike that being built by Swiss Bank, which Hines served as development and construction consultant. Subject to city approval -- and a tenant's needs -- the project might have a large trading floor atop a parking garage in midblock, connected to an office tower at the corner, with street-level uses at its base to enliven the intersection.
The Hines development would preserve the 82-year-old original Post Office building immediately to the south and generate income for the St. Johns Towers housing project immediately to the west, which is needed for rehabilitation.
"We're very committed to participation in the ongoing revitalization of downtown Stamford," said Thomas M. Craig Jr., senior vice president at Hines. "We think now is a propitious time to be active in that market. We're confident that Swiss Bank will present a compelling case for a relocation by a major securities firm or another firm in the financial services industry."
BEFORE settling on Stamford, Swiss Bank looked closely at White Plains and four buildings in Manhattan: 222 Broadway, at Fulton Street, which the bank owns; 1 Liberty Plaza, at Broadway and Liberty Street; the former Mobil Building, 150 East 42d Street, and Park Avenue Plaza, 55 East 52d Street.
Stamford had several things in its favor, said Markus U. Buergler, director of corporate real estate for the SBC Warburg division. One of them was the opportunity to control a 12-acre site. "For us, it was important to create a campus environment," he said. "Not 200 acres in the back woods but an urban campus. And Stamford allowed us to do that."
Swiss Bank executives liked the fact that the site was so close to public transportation that it afforded the chance to build an enormous trading floor and that it offered the ability to develop in phases, accounting for the corporation's changing needs over time.
There were other inducements. The market value of the site, based on its development potential, was more than $22 million. But the city owned about 30 percent of the acreage, including Beehler Street and Guernsey Avenue, and sold it to Swiss Bank for $1. "That's a good land cost," Mr. Buergler allowed. The city cobbled together the rest of the parcel through its powers of condemnation and closed Beehler and Guernsey.
Swiss Bank benefited further from a state credit that will reduce its corporate tax bill up to 50 percent over 10 years for creating at least 2,000 jobs. The value of the credit is about $120 million. If Swiss Bank has at least 3,000 employees at the end of the 10th year, the credit would be extended five more years at a lesser percentage, with a value of $25 million.
Mr. Bergstrom said the government benefited in its dealings with Swiss Bank from the loss of Morgan Stanley. "It was a blow psychologically," he said, "but the state really learned about the investment banking industry. It was a crash course in what makes them tick."
Construction of the Swiss Bank center is to be completed in July, Mr. Buergler said, and employees will move there from September through December, coming out of 222 Broadway, 277 Park Avenue and the Swiss Bank Tower at 10 East 50th Street.
The heart of the new complex will be the trading floor pavilion. Some 600 traders will sit, without a single column between them, under one roof. And what a roof: a bow-shaped truss tilted to create an expansive clerestory window along the north wall, lined with wave-like baffles to provide indirect lighting and acoustic control.
Dramatic as this space will be, Mustafa K. Abadan, the Skidmore partner in charge of the Swiss Bank project, said, "Ultimately, the landscaping of Washington Boulevard will be the biggest impact of the site."
Mr. Bergstrom agreed. "As important as it is getting 2,000 jobs, biting off a piece of Wall Street and getting it to Stamford, the real value of the project is that it connects downtown to the train station," he said.
Indeed, pedestrians generally are finally getting their due in Stamford.
"I don't think a new building that didn't have a very active street-level presence would be approved in Stamford today," Mr. Bergstrom said. "Stamford has learned from its past, from the old buildings with entrances floating five levels above the street."
Even an old building can be taught the new trick, as the GTE Corporation has demonstrated at its headquarters. The building is a familiar sight to motorists on I-95 and passengers on Metro-North, looking as it does like a glass-skinned, upside-down ziggurat. But along Tresser Boulevard, GTE presented only the formidably stark concrete wall of a parking garage.
In a recent renovation, to designs by Hellmuth, Obata & Kassabaum, the building has been given a more inviting entrance on Tresser Boulevard, clad in blue-gray ceramic tiles, with a lobby, canopy, colonnade and small garden.
CATER-CORNER from GTE is one of the most impressive and critically situated vacant lots of all: a 3.8-acre expanse of virtual marshland, where tall swamp grasses roll like the ocean's surface under winter winds, circumscribed by a long-abandoned concrete foundation.
Known as Parcel 38, it sits across Greyrock Place from the Stamford Town Center Mall and across Tresser Boulevard from the Stamford Marriott. As such, it is a painfully visible reminder of the city's recent economic woes.
It is understood that Citicorp, which controls Parcel 38, has entered into a contract with W. Scott Toombs of the Toombs Development Company in New Canaan, Conn., which has built projects in Baltimore and Philadelphia but is perhaps best known for the Princeton Forrestal Village in Plainsboro, N.J. Citing a confidentiality agreement, Mr. Toombs said he could not discuss the Stamford transaction or any plans he might have for the site.
Mayor Malloy has his own thoughts. "Parcel 38 is large enough that you could have a good mixed-use project," he said. "My best-case scenario would be a company that was prepared to make the kind of commitment that Swiss Bank has, a company in financial services looking for a premiere location."
Faded signs around the perimeter of the site -- "Rich Development Construction" -- still attest to its past. Parcel 38 was to have been a capstone in the Rich Company's redevelopment effort but wound up as more of a last straw.
The company was founded in 1921 by F. D. Rich Sr., a stonemason, and was for many years primarily a construction contractor. But under the leadership of his sons, Robert and Frank, and their close associate and chief counsel, Lawrence Gochberg, the Rich Company won the contract to redevelop the downtown urban renewal district in 1960.
Construction began in 1968 with St. Johns Towers, three silo-like apartment buildings designed by Victor Bisharat. The first commercial project was Landmark Tower, designed by Mr. Bisharat, which was completed in 1972. Five smaller buildings, designed by Moshe Safdie, were built around the tower to form Landmark Square.
Also in the 1970's, the Riches built the GTE building and the Stamford Marriott, both by Mr. Bisharat, and 10 Stamford Forum, by Mitchell/Giurgola. In the 1980's came 4 Stamford Forum, by Cesar Pelli; 6 Stamford Forum, by Arthur Erickson and 8 Stamford Forum, by Hugh Stubbins, which served as Singer headquarters. The company also built the Town Center and expanded the Marriott.
It was in the mid-80's that the Rich Company began to feel squeezed. Like every office owner in that period, its tenant rolls shrank as corporations merged, moved and shed workers.
As a downtown landlord, Rich also found itself competing with office buildings elsewhere in Stamford. "For 15 years, we weren't able to get the land-use boards to limit development outside downtown," Robert Rich said. "They didn't tighten it up until it was too late."
And the Rich Company was compelled to build structures by certain dates or else sacrifice development rights. "The Urban Redevelopment Commission pushed us into building 300 Atlantic Street and 177 Broad Street," Mr. Rich said, "which we did -- unfortunately -- in a declining market."
Parcel 38 was to have been the site of an 800,000-square foot office and residential project called the Stamford Atrium, designed by Mr. Safdie. This would have been linked to other Rich properties by pedestrian bridges, creating a continuous walkway from the Forum, through the Atrium, to the Town Center and Landmark Square beyond -- more than half a mile without crossing a street.
By 1987, however, it was clear that the declining market could not possibly absorb the Stamford Atrium and the project was stopped, leaving nothing but its foundation walls.
EVENTUALLY, lenders took back most of the Rich properties. Parcel 38, 4 and 6 Stamford Forum and 300 Atlantic Street went to Citicorp; 8 Stamford Forum to the Bank of New York; 10 Stamford Forum to the Prudential Insurance Company of America; 177 Broad Street and the Biltmore apartments to Bankers Trust and Landmark Square to the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company.
Three of the Stamford Forum buildings were acquired in 1993 by Zell/Merrill Lynch of Chicago, which renamed them Stamford Plaza and renumbered them. Landmark Square was eventually acquired by Reckson Associates Realty Corporation, which is planning an $11 million upgrade of the complex, including the facade, garage, roof, plaza and heating, ventilating and air-conditioning systems.
The Rich Company kept its half interest in the Town Center, together with the Taubman Company, and remains an owner and the managing partner in High Ridge Park, an office complex north of downtown.
Members of the third generation are also active in real estate and community affairs. Frank Rich's son, F. D. (Rick) Rich 3d, is senior vice president and managing director of Reckson's southern Connecticut office, and vice chairman of Stamford's downtown business-improvement district. Frank Rich's daughter, Susan M. Rich, is a senior vice president of Reckson for leasing in southern Connectictut and Westchester County and the first chairwoman of Stamford's Rotary Club.
Robert Rich's son, Thomas, is pressing the case for Sears and was also instrumental in the Crown Majestic Theater deal. His company, T. R. Hardy L.L.C., acquired the Summer Street parcel at auction from Citicorp and leased it in turn to Crown.
Besides enjoying the fact that the cinema will lure more people downtown at night, Mr. Rich derives some familial satisfaction from the project, given who used to own the property before Citicorp foreclosed.
It was the F. D. Rich Company.

HEADLINE: COMMUNITY;
How a Plane Crash Changed the Trip To Buy Groceries

BYLINE: By GEORGE JAMES 

DATELINE: PORT NORRIS

 BODY:
There are vast spaces between buildings along Main Street where houses and shops used to stand, ghosts of the prosperous past of this tiny Cumberland County town. So, what is most noticeable now is not what's here, but what isn't.
Mostly gone is the oyster industry that boomed in the first half of the century and then was devastated by marine parasites. With it went the doctors, auto dealerships, restaurants, clothing shops, ice cream parlors, the barbershop and the movie theater. The storefront pool hall, which somehow escaped demolition, is boarded up and covered with vines. 
 And now the only food market for miles around is gone too, closed by a problem that literally fell from the sky on Dec. 8, when a single-engine plane crashed through the roof of Newcomb's Supermarket on Main Street.
The accident -- which tore apart the only place that people with cars could buy a quart of milk or a loaf of bread -- has also served to bring the community together.
Two Methodist congregations, one white and one black, have joined forces to produce a short-term solution, a bus to carry shoppers to a supermarket in Millville 18 miles away, and a long-term campaign to bring public transportation to the town of 2,000 people in the sparsely settled southern part of the state.
SUSIE LOPEZ was working at the computer in the back of her store, writing up grocery orders for the coming week, when the small plane came through the roof.
The building, a long hangar-like structure of concrete block that once housed a Chevrolet dealership, shook at the impact. Her two employees were safe, but the pilot, she later learned, was dead.
Mrs. Lopez, who bought the store seven years ago with her husband, Joe, has yet to hear from a contractor about what it will cost to repair damage to one of the trusses that support the store's roof. She cannot say when the store will reopen.
"We don't want to delay anything," she said. "This is my life; this is our income. Besides, a lot of people depend on us."
On Friday, five days after the crash, Chris Miller, the pastor of the First United Methodist Church on Main Street, got a call from Alice Reed, a former resident of Port Norris who had moved to Millville.
"I think you should do something," she said. "There are people in town who don't have transportation. And they don't have any food and no way of getting it."
The pastor was scheduled to speak the next morning to the men's group of the John Wesley United Methodist Church, an African-American congregation, several blocks away. He used the occasion to tell its pastor, the Rev. Joseph L. Scott, about the call.
And the pastors, who had been looking for a project that could involve both congregations, come up with the bus plan.
On Sunday, the two church's councils gave the plan their enthusiastic support and on Monday night about 10 members from the two churches met to work out details.
Neither church has an office staff so David Ennis, assistant minister of Shiloh Baptist, another church in town, volunteered his.
A few days later, Barney Hollinger, a township committeeman, heard about the plan.
"When I went that night to the township committee meeting, I asked what the township could do," recalled Mr. Hollinger, a marina owner and part-time oysterman whose roots in Port Norris go back two generations.
The commitee allocated emergency funding to cover the cost of bus rental: $30 a trip.
SO far the turnout has been low. Since Dec. 20, only nine people have availed themselves of two trips; another was cancelled for lack of riders. The trips will continue until at least mid-January.
"The need is greater than the response so far," said Mr. Miller. "I'm a little disappointed but I don't think we made a mistake."
Neither does Roberta Horton, a woman on welfare who took advantage of the service twice.
"It's really good to have," she said. "If you run out of food or have no milk, there's no little store to run to. Unless you want to live on pizza " she added referring to the lone pizzeria on Main Street.
Mrs. Horton was interviewed on the bus returning from the Pathmark in Millville on Dec. 27. With her was her son, Mark, 21; her 19-year-old daughter, Laura, 19; Laura's 16-month-old son, Jeremy, and Mrs. Horton's friend, Daniel Evans.
"There's a lot of people around who need it," she said. "A lot of people who can't walk and old people who can't shop for themselves."
Mr. Miller, who has a commercial driver's license and was driving the schoolbus, said, "Well, if you know of anyone like that, let us know and we'll shop for them."
Mrs. Horton said a taxi to Millville costs about $20 to $25. Some people with cars make money ferrying people to shop, she said, and she pays one man $15 for a round trip.
Mark Horton said he used to bicycle to work in Millville where he worked in a box factory until he was laid off. The trip took from half an hour to 45 minutes.
"Casinos hire people," Mark Horton said. "But you need a car to get to Millville to get the bus to Atlantic City."
CUMBERLAND COUNTY is economically depressed, compared to much of the rest of New Jersey. And Port Norris is poor, compared to the rest of the county.
The county's unemployment rate is 8.7 percent compared with the state's 5.9, said Glenn Nickerson, public information officer for Cumberland County.
Per capita income in Port Norris is only $10,401 annually, compared to $12,560 in the county as a whole.
The county, which provides buses for seniors, would like to persuade NJ Transit to start a spur service for Port Norris.
But Alan Maiman, NJ Transit's manager of bus service planning for the southern region of the state, said it's difficult to serve rural areas like Port Norris.
"The mass in mass transit," Mr. Maiman said, "means you need a concentration of people who are making similiar trips at similar times for similar purposes in significant numbers to justify a large vehicle like a bus to efficiently operate."
He said he and county officials are meeting early this month to brainstorm solutions, and on Thursday the two churches are holding a public meeting to see what can be done to bring public transportation to Port Norris.
"My hope is that out of the tragedy of the loss of the pilot's life," said Pastor Scott, "that some long-term change can be made."
As the Hortons got off the bus carrying three plastic bags of groceries, Roberta Horton called back cheerily to Pastor Miller, "I'll see you next trip Friday then."
"All right," he replied. "We'll be here."

Scott on the bus that takes shoppers from Port Norris to Millville. (Photographs by Sam D'Amico for The New York Times and, top left, by the Associated Press)

HEADLINE: THE GREAT OUTDOORS;
Developer, Spare That Tree

BYLINE: By DAVID W. CHEN 

DATELINE: EMERSON

 BODY:
THE Fairways here seems like a classic example of Housing Development 101, New Jersey style. The single-family houses, which began appearing in the early 90's, are expensive, modern and uniform, all standing in neat, almost clinical, rows, all forming a bare, almost treeless gantlet through which cars must pass.
"They just came in, plowed and took down every single tree," said Louis Lamatina, an Emerson councilman. "It just didn't look right; it didn't look real pretty." 
 So Mr. Lamatina and other Emerson officials decided one Fairways would be enough. In 1995, they did what about 10 percent of the state's municipalities have done: they passed a tree preservation law prohibiting developers from removing trees indiscriminately.
Now, a proposed 17-unit development called Lake Hollow Estates, to be built on 6.3 acres near Oradell Reservoir, is providing a first test of the law. After a survey of the site two weeks ago, the developer, Rodan Builders of Montvale, said it wanted to remove all but 370 of the site's 1,890 pines, birches, maples and other trees, prompting concerns from environmentalists who say that the area would be a denuded cousin of the Fairways and that trees might be cleared without regard to age or significance.
But Mr. Lamatina is confident the town can work with the developer, thanks to the preservation law.
"Emerson is a suburban town, and people like to look at trees," he said. "So this is definitely a great tool which allows us to shape the developer, as opposed to allowing the developer to do whatever he wants."
Under the ordinance, the developer must conduct a detailed survey and draw a map of trees on the property to be developed. The survey is be reviewed by a tree preservation committee and sent to the local planning board for approval.
Laws like Emerson's illustrate the growing recognition of trees as a means of absorbing pollutants and lowering energy bills by providing cooling shade and wind protection and prevent erosion.
"The laws are getting more stringent because the awareness is definitely building that trees have been neglected in the past," said David L. Johnson, assistant regional forester for the New Jersey Forest Service.
Each year, the state is losing about one-tenth of its undeveloped land, much of it wooded, according to the New Jersey Forest Service. Yet trees have traditionally garnered little attention or money from local government. True, about one-third of New Jersey's municipalities have local shade tree commissions, but they normally determine which trees to plant or prune -- not which to protect from development, said William J. Porter, executive secretary of the New Jersey Shade Tree Federation.
By the early 1990's, though, as concern about trees mounted, several municipalities, including South Brunswick, Sayreville and Hillsdale, drafted tree-preservation laws. Under some of the laws, if trees are to be cleared, they must be replaced in accordance with a formula based on the number and width of trees removed and other factors. (For example, removing a 41-inch-diameter tree might require planting 15 replacement trees at least 2 1/2 inches in diameter.) Or the developer could choose not to replace the trees, instead contributing $100 to $200 a tree to a fund for the planting and maintenance of trees elsewhere in the town.
Such laws are usually limited to new housing developments and do not apply to individual homeowners. Developers who violate the law are subject to fines of up to $1,000 and jail sentences of up to 90 days.
Tree preservation laws have elicited mixed reactions from developers, so long as a law is not excessive, said Joanne Harkins, director of land use planning for the New Jersey Builders Association. Clear-cutting is much more economical than weaving around a thicket of trees, and conducting a tree survey can can cost a few thousand dollars.
Most towns have reported good experiences. Edison's 1995 law has netted $43,000 for the town's tree fund, said Louis Rainone, the township attorney. But now, Edison's law faces a legal challenge from Anda Inc., a developer that wants to build 109 single-family houses on 35 acres. Under the law, the developer would have to plant 2,800 new trees (2,300 more than planned) or pay $230,000 to the tree fund -- conditions the developer says are unreasonable.
"Those kinds of controls to make sure the developer acts in a reasonable fashion -- I can relate to that," said Stephen E. Barcan, an attorney with Wilentz, Goldman and Spitzer in Woodbridge, who represents Anda. "But this goes way beyond that."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Louis Lamatina, an Emerson councilman, at the site of a future development. He holds a map indicating the 1,890 trees there.; The Fairways development in Emerson, built before the law was passed. (Photographs by Norman Y. Lono for The New York Times)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Families Don't End When Marriages Do

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Thank you for your very important article about the legal system of divorce in New Jersey and for your focus on mediation ("The State of Disunion," Dec. 1). 
 Increased public awareness of the mediation alternative, as well as the imprimatur of the legislature, are devoutly to be wished for. In addition to promoting costly and corrosive court battles, the adversarial system advances the myth that divorce is a final event.
In fact, couples with children are forever tied to each other. Divorce ends a legal marriage, but it does not end a family. Ideally, an agreement, especially a mediated agreement, should provide a blueprint for the restructuring of a family, and the process of mediation should be a forum for civilized, respectful problem solving.
However, mediators need to be trained to understand the emotional conflicts that are often the underlying source of conflict, for example, the rage one spouse may feel at being abandoned by the other, or the terror at the prospect of being economically bereft. Another necessity is a sound grounding in matrimonial law, which provides the boundaries within which negotiation takes place.
Ultimately, the success of mediation will depend on the skills of the mediators, their substantive knowledge, their problem-solving skills and conflict-managing skills. Particular attention needs to be paid to the qualifications and training of mediators as this becomes an alternative for more and more people.
 
LINDA P. FISH
Attorney and Family Mediator
Englewood

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: FLORAL PARK;
Greedy Heir or 'Rush to Judgment'?

BYLINE: By CHARLIE LeDUFF 

 BODY:
Two and a half years ago. Amalia Fortuna drew up a will that named her two grandsons as heirs to her half-million-dollar estate. Three months later, the 81-year-old widow was stabbed to death while sleeping in her home in Floral Park.
According to prosecutors, it was a classic case of a shiftless relative who grew tired of criticism and, lured by the prospect of inheritance and fueled by alcohol, resorted to murder. But to the defense, it was a case of law-enforcement authorities' jumping to a hasty conclusion based on flimsy evidence and a questionable statement. 
 Tomorrow, after two years of pretrial maneuvering, jury selection is scheduled to begin in State Supreme Court in Jamaica, Queens, in the trial of Peter De Cianni, 38, who is charged with two counts of second-degree murder. Mrs. Fortuna, said law-enforcement officials and neighbors, often argued with Mr. De Cianni over his slovenliness and alcohol abuse, and the prosecution says he killed her in a fit of rage after a night of heavy drinking.
Mr. De Cianni's lawyer, Marvyn Kornberg, says his client merely found his slain grandmother after a night out and called into question police accounts of statements Mr. De Cianni made after his arrest. If convicted, Mr. De Cianni faces life in prison. If found innocent, he stands to collect his share of his grandmother's estate. He has been held at Rikers Island for two years without bail.
According to the police, Mr. De Cianni admitted that he had spent the afternoon of Sept. 13, 1994, drinking at the Bellerose Bar on Hillside Avenue. He told the police he returned to Mrs. Fortuna's home twice to ask for money for more drinking; both times, he said, they argued, but Mrs. Fortuna relented.
In a signed statement, Mr. De Cianni said he returned to the bar, drank until 3:30 A.M. and spent the rest of the night at a friend's house. When he went home that morning, he found her dead and called the police.
The police, however, said Mr. De Cianni told investigators that he accidentally stabbed Mrs. Fortuna repeatedly with a steak knife and then threw the weapon in a Dumpster, but did not sign a confession. Last June, a judge ruled that the police account was admissible as evidence.
There is also the matter of a $5 bill that was recovered at the Bellerose Bar. The bill, which had Mr. De Cianni's fingerprints on it, carried small traces of blood. Mr. Kornberg described the amount of blood as too small for a definitive match. "The whole thing's an outrage," he said. "First they lock him up for two years on the basis of a made-up confession. Then they try to tag him on some bogus DNA match. Apparently, they got the whole idea from the O. J. case."
Neighbors said Mrs. Fortuna, an Italian immigrant who spoke little English, kept mostly to herself. Often, they said, she would chastise her grandson, complaining of his drinking and unemployment. "She was a rich lady," said Siegrid Muenznek, a hairdresser, who said Mrs. Fortuna was among her clients. "She had just returned from her home in Italy before she was killed. Poor thing." CHARLIE LeDUFF

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS QUARTERLY REPORT;
Pessimism, Yes, but No Retreat

BYLINE: By CAROLE GOULD 

 BODY:
MUTUAL fund investors were big winners in the stock market last year, and they no doubt toasted in the new year hoping for more of the same. But professional money managers running hypothetical portfolios for The New York Times caution investors against being too confident.
"I'm not very optimistic entering 1997," said John Rekenthaler, publisher of Morningstar Mutual Funds, in Chicago. "An enormous amount of good news has been priced into the stock market, and the recent volatility, with the Dow rising or dropping 100 points in an hour or less, suggests a lot of emotion out there." 
 In the fourth quarter of 1996, Mr. Rekenthaler was the top performer among the five investment advisers managing the hypothetical retirement portfolios. Despite being handicapped by its relatively light holdings in domestic blue chips, his portfolio rose 8.40 percent in the last three months of 1996. Part of that gain came from a lack of exposure to emerging markets, whose performance pulled down several other advisers' returns. He was also helped by strong showings in Vanguard Specialized Energy, which benefited from rising oil and natural gas prices, and in Third Avenue Value, a quirky fund focusing on bankruptcy and takeover plays and the like.
Notwithstanding his pessimism, Mr. Rekenthaler is not retreating to cash or bonds. "My portfolio is pretty well diversified," he said, "and while I harbor no illusions that it will hold up that much better than the S.& P. 500 during a decline -- the big blue chips usually fare relatively well during such periods -- neither do I wish to gamble by becoming more conservative."
SIMILARLY, Harold Evensky, an investment adviser in Coral Gables, Fla., is basically sitting tight, changing just one fund, despite the fact that his portfolio's broad market diversification only seemed to reduce returns in a roaring large-cap domestic bull market. In particular, his investments in small-company and international funds all significantly underperformed the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, giving him a 5.79 percent gain in the fourth quarter.
"Of course, that's like blaming an orange for not tasting like an apple," he said, "but in bull markets investors tend to forget the lessons of history."
Foremost among those lessons, Mr. Evensky said, is that the primary factor in successful long-term investing is adequate diversification of assets. Focusing on just one part of the market is a gamble. "It's tough to convince lottery winners that they were lucky and made money on a bad investment," he said.
For the current quarter, Mr. Evensky is merely replacing Pimco Emerging Markets with Matthews Pacific Tiger, thus slightly increasing exposure to the Pacific Rim.
Since the contest began on July 7, 1993, Sheldon Jacobs, who edits the No-Load Fund Investor in Irvington, N.Y., has held the lead among the five managers and retains that position with an overall gain of 75.81 percent through 1996. In that time, the portfolios have risen an average of 59.36 percent, compared with an 82.20 percent total return for the Vanguard Index 500 fund, which mimics the S.& P. 500, and 68.64 percent for all equity funds.
ALL the portfolios made money in the quarter. Even given the strength of large-capitalization stocksand the broad diversification of the managers' portfolios, only one lagged behind the average gain of 4.99 percent for domestic diversified stock funds.
The portfolio performance, tracked quarterly by Lipper Analytical Services of Summit, N.J., excludes sales charges, transaction costs and tax considerations because most retirement money is held in tax-deferred accounts. The five experts can choose any funds open to new investors and can shift money quarterly, although the portfolios are intended to grow for 20 years.
In second place for the last quarter was Eric M. Kobren, president of Insight Management, in Wellesley, Mass. Mr. Kobren, whose portfolio includes only Fidelity funds, posted a return of 7.55 percent. This quarter he is adding two funds and selling Fidelity Value, Fidelity Growth Company and the Fidelity Fund.
"Over the years, it is easy to simply add more and more funds," he said. "But we believe simplicity is also an important benefit of investing in funds, and therefore prefer to reduce the number of fund holdings to a more manageable level."
Mr. Kobren is investing part of the sale proceeds in Fidelity Contrafund, which has "wide investment flexibility," he said. "It can -- and does -- buy stocks found in all three of the funds we are selling," he said. He is also adding Fidelity Dividend Growth, which focuses on companies that were spun off big conglomerates or are undergoing significant structural changes.
Anticipating a market break next year, Mr. Jacobs is reducing risk in his portfolio, which gained 7.41 percent last quarter. "When you have two great years in a row, the next one can be a downer," he said.
He is deleting Strong Growth and Janus Olympus and dividing the proceeds among Fidelity Real Estate, Heartland: Value Plus and the Yacktman Fund.
The portfolio of Jack A. Brill, a San Diego investment adviser specializing in "socially responsible investing," rose 4.06 percent for the quarter. Mr. Brill, who is making no changes in his portfolio, said he believes the large-cap run-up will not continue into next year. His Citizens Emerging Growth fund suffered as the large-capitalization stocks rose, but he said he was retaining it because long-term growth portfolios need to have a small-cap component.
The top-performing diversified fund in the fourth quarter was a socially responsible one, Parnassus, which Mr. Brill had held until earlier this year. Disappointed with its performance, he sold it in the spring. The fund's manager had announced a change in investment philosophy and a portfolio restructuring, but Mr. Brill had had enough. Was he ready to step back in, given the fund's terrific rebound? Not yet. "I want to see if the manager's re-look and change in philosophy will continue to produce good results."
A reader recently asked: How would the five managers be performing if they had stuck to their original portfolios from more than three years ago?
Well, Mr. Evensky would be in first place with a gain of 64.47 percent, compared with 52.84 percent with his quarterly changes, followed by Mr. Jacobs, up 50.74 percent (actual gain: 75.81 percent); Mr. Kobren, up 50.81 percent (actual gain: 65.63 percent), and Mr. Rekenthaler, up 42.39 percent (actual gain: 56.88 percent). Mr. Brill's comparable portfolio performance could not be calculated accurately because one of his original funds was merged out of existence and a second has been liquidated.

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
Supermarket Stocks: The Sale May Be Over

BYLINE: By DANA CANEDY 

 BODY:
AFTER a big run-up last year, the stocks of supermarket companies are starting to look like the week-old melons in the produce section -- a bit overripe.
"The industry, stocks as well as businesses, had a very nice rebound in 1996, so there is not a ton of value left," said Jay Abramson, executive vice president of Cramer, Rosenthal, McGlynn, an investment firm. 
 Stocks of food retailers rose 22 percent on average in 1996. And they are now trading at 18 to 25 times 1996 earnings, roughly comparable to the 21 multiple of the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index.
Even looking ahead, grocery stocks are trading at about 14 to 18 times this year's earnings, according to analysts' estimates. While they don't look so pricey by that measure, many still seem to have gotten ahead of themselves.
Earnings growth for the entire industry has been about 12 to 15 percent a year, and will probably not go much higher, the analysts add.
"I'm not sure the growth rates are sustainable," said Jonathan H. Ziegler, a supermarket stock analyst with Salomon Brothers. "There is not a lot of easy money out there."
Among the stronger supermarket chains are the two biggest, the Kroger Company of Cincinnati and Safeway Inc. of Pleasanton, Calif.
Kroger, the nation's leading grocer with more than 1,300 stores and estimated sales this year of about $25 billion, faces increased competition in its core markets in the Southeast, Midwest and Rocky Mountain states.
But its sales and earnings growth have picked up in the last two years. Sales are expected to come in about 10 percent higher in 1996 than in the previous year, according to Salomon Brothers. This year, Salomon expects earnings to rise to $430 million, up 22 percent from the $352 million expected for 1996.
Salomon rates the stock a hold, and few others are willing to call it an outright buy at its current price of $47.375 a share even though they like the company's long-term prospects.
"I like Kroger because they are a good executer," said Lauren Allan Smith, a stock analyst with Loomis Sayles, which owns a large number of Kroger shares. The company has automated its ordering and shipping departments, invested heavily to refurbish stores and paid down debt incurred several years ago to stave off a takeover attempt.
"They've been spending a lot of money to put assets and procedures in place and need to make a return on that in the next few years," Ms. AllanSmith said.
Kroger's strategy has been to develop lucrative "shops within shops," like floral departments and fish markets, she said. Those high-margin boutiques offset the small profits generated from selling paper towels and soap in bulk at low prices.
Kroger may also be attractive because its stock, at 14 times estimated 1997 earnings, has risen less sharply than its rivals'.
When it comes to pricey stocks, Kroger pales next to Safeway, whose shares soared last year. Largely because of acquisitions, the company has been growing rapidly, attracting so many fans that it is now trading at about 24 times 1996 earnings.
Safeway, which has a strong presence in California and the Northwest, just signed an agreement to acquire the Vons Companies for $1.57 billion. The combined company will be the second-biggest grocery chain, with more than 1,300 stores and annual sales of more than $22 billion.
Like Kroger, Safeway has paid down debt. It has also reduced operating expenses and bolstered sales at stores open at least a year.
But investing in Safeway requires a belief that the company can continue to grow at its phenomenal clip of recent years. "The stock is up 70 percent over the last 12 months," said Ms. AllanSmith, whose company owns a stake in Safeway. "It's been a rocket ship."
Douglas Christopher, a stock analyst with Crowell, Weedon & Company in Los Angeles, expects Safeway's earnings to climb 21 percent this year, to $490 million, from $405 million for 1996. While that would be impressive growth, it would represent a slowdown from the early 90's.
Even though Safeway and many other supermarkets have become leaner, more efficient operators in recent years, Mr. Christopher encourages investors to be patient. "We prefer to buy supermarkets with multiples in the low teens," he said. "We'd rather wait for the market to maybe correct a little bit."
Perhaps no grocery store company has experienced more of a roller-coaster ride than Food Lion Inc., based in Salisbury, N.C., and concentrated in the Southeast.
The company suffered from a scandal involving tainted meat in 1992. After it became the subject of an ABC News expose on "Prime Time Live," it sued the network for fraud for sending reporters undercover to work at the store. Food Lion recently won in a Federal court in Greensboro, N.C., and the court is expected to reconvene on Monday to determine if punitive damages should be paid, and if so, how much.
Last year was generally one of recovery for the company, whose stock rose nearly 80 percent. Like Safeway, it is trading at 24 times last year's estimated earnings, and more than 18 times this year's estimate.
Some innovative marketing strategies have helped Food Lion bolster revenues and improve its tarnished image. For example, it created a frequent-shopper card that provides deep discounts on purchases to people who spend a certain amount in any of its more than 1,000 stores.
Mr. Ziegler of Salomon estimates that Food Lion will earn $265 million this year, up 26 percent from $211 million in 1996.
Kroger, Safeway and Food Lion all win plaudits for their managements. That is not true for some other grocery chains. Winn-Dixie of Jacksonville, Fla., has been cutting prices to counter increased competition. It elicits negative comments from some analysts.
For investors keen on the superstore concept, two companies that are hybrid food stores and general merchandisers might be worth considering at the right price: Fred Meyer Inc. of Portland, Ore., and Price/Costco Inc. of Issaquah, Wash. Fred Meyer, whose stores sell everything from jewelry to Jell-O, generates about 41 percent of revenues from food sales. Price/Costco, operator of 250 membership warehouses, has had consistent growth in sales at stores open at least a year and gets about 35 percent of its revenues from food, analysts say.
Because of their merchandise mix, Fred Meyer and Price/Costco are considered more vulnerable to economic downturns than are their pure grocery counterparts.

LENGTH: 1250 words

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS QUARTERLY REPORT;
Move the Feast to Europe, Some Advise

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

 BODY:
THE New World was a good place to invest money last year, but the Old World was a better one. The average mutual fund invested in European stocks outperformed the average American fund, 23.49 percent to 18.40 percent, according to figures from Morningstar Inc., the fund researchers in Chicago.
Given the economic cycles, some money managers think Europe will remain a good place to be. European economies were more sluggish for most of the last few years but are starting to grow. They could be expanding vigorously just as activity -- and especially corporate profits -- may flatten or ebb in the United States. 
 "We think Europe is in the early stages of earnings-growth expansion that may last for many years," said Denise Downey, a portfolio manager for Bank Julius Baer in New York, which runs several international funds. "We continue to be quite positive on the European markets."
And while some strategists don't share such general enthusiasm, they find no shortage of appealing individual stocks that Europeans themselves may be overlooking because of their traditional "top down," or macroeconomic, approach to investing and an emphasis on the very biggest companies, money managers say. This leaves many niches where value-oriented investors can find bargains.
"The opportunities for small companies there are terrific," said Michael Gerding, portfolio manager for three international funds sponsored by Founders Asset Management in Denver.
Specialists point to several trends -- apart from Europe's potentially more favorable position in the business cycle and lower share valuations -- to support a bullish investment case. Indeed, last year the number of funds focused on this area swelled by nearly 25 percent, according to Morningstar. These trends include corporate revamping and outsourcing, friendlier attitudes toward investors, performance-tied executive pay, rising demand for goods from the former Soviet-bloc countries, improved accounting standards and moves to more fully finance corporate pension plans. Some also take as a favorable sign the arrival in Europe of discount stockbrokers and, in Germany, of tax legislation that should lead to more companies' buying back shares.
Indeed, the general loosening of restrictions and dependence on the state has even reached Scandinavia, contributing substantially to big stock-market gains there last year. Two Scandinavian funds, Fidelity Nordic and Wright Equifund-Nordic, were among the top European performers for both the latest quarter and all of 1996.
These countries "tend to be the most Socialist-oriented of all," said William F. Wendler 2d, vice president of Rowe Price-Fleming International in Baltimore. But they have been forced, he said, to "come to grips with the fact that putting social policy ahead of economic policy was killing them." Now, Mr. Wendler added, less pressure on wages "is keeping the cost side of the equation very subdued."
Then there is the issue of European integration, with planned monetary union at the beginning of 1999. Most managers say they think this will eventually prove a moderate plus for stock markets -- and a welcome step toward simpler hedging of currency.
Mr. Wendler and other managers said that monetary union would require American investors to rethink their exposure to currency fluctuation, which can significantly affect a portfolio's stock-market performance. Germany's Bundesbank, by tying its powerful mark to a constellation of lesser currencies, will be forced to become less hawkish against inflation, Mr. Wendler said. This implies more stability for American investors in Europe and thus somewhat less need to hedge stock positions.
BUT money managers fret that in the short run the need to meet qualifying standards for monetary union has meant policies of deficit reduction and of reluctance to cut interest rates to spur growth.
"It could be a fairly austere year from a government-spending point of view," Mr. Gerding said. He added that he saw only "a decent environment" in 1997, with most European economies "not robust at all."
Still, Mr. Gerding and portfolio managers who are more generally encouraged about prospects for investing in Europe find plenty of interesting corporate situations, especially in France and Germany.
Mr. Gerding is particularly fond these days of Volkswagen, which shows strong revenue growth and expanding operating margins, and Guilbert, a large French distributor of office products whose earnings he expects to climb 25 percent annually for the next few years. He also likes Baan, a Dutch software company.
Carol Franklin, lead manager of the $2.5 billion Scudder International fund, praises the way Hoechst, the German pharmaceutical company, has embraced the idea of spinoffs and job cuts in an effort to please stockholders, whom she called "a new life form" to many hidebound European managements.
"Shareholders have not been the highest priority" in much of Europe, where governments and unions play major roles in business decision making, Ms. Franklin said. But now "this is changing -- because it has to," she said.
Ms. Franklin also likes the way Europeans have begun to outsource various corporate functions, like computer services; one of her favorite companies in this area is Getronics, a Dutch concern. This trend is related to the aggressive selloff of state enterprises that reached a record $43 billion last year and that J. P. Morgan predicts will jump 23 percent in 1997.
To be sure, some of the favorable trends may prove glacially slow, or shy on substance. And perhaps, as Mr. Gerding contends, much of the most appealing privatization has already occurred.
But this has not discouraged stock-pickers like Robert Q. Wyckoff Jr. and his colleagues at Tweedy, Browne in New York. They are adept at finding opportunity regardless of larger trends that might be ominous for the market, like the rising interest rates that some see for Europe in 1997 or the likelihood of a Labor Party victory in British elections.
"We've found more bargains in second-tier stocks in Western Europe than probably anywhere else around the world," Mr. Wyckoff said, noting that he has also been encouraged by more accounting standardization there and a new-found activism among institutional stockholders. About 60 percent of the Tweedy Browne Global Value Fund, not counting the 9 percent in cash, is invested in Western Europe, with particular emphasis on Switzerland.
TWO favorites of Tweedy, Browne are Edipresse, a Swiss newspaper chain selling at eight times earnings and less than half the firm's estimate of its worth, and Franco Tosi, an Italian water distribution and packaging company with a huge bundle of cash equal to more than twice its selling price. Tweedy also has long had a big stake in Nestle, the Swiss giant.
While there are now more than five dozen open-end European funds, one of the more intriguing ways to "play" Western Europe may be the $118 million European Warrant Fund.
This is a closed-end investment company listed on the New York Stock Exchange that soared nearly 50 percent last year but still trades at a 22 percent discount to net asset value. It mainly buys European warrants, either publicly traded ones or those that are custom-designed with the issuer. However, Ms. Downey of Bank Julius Baer, whose affiliate is the investment manager, cautions that European Warrant is speculative and should be considered only by "higher-risk investors."
