HEADLINE: Social Security, As We Knew It

BYLINE: By Daniel Patrick Moynihan; Daniel Patrick Moynihan is the Democratic Senator from New York.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Tomorrow, one year late, the Advisory Council on Social Security is scheduled to report on the finances of our national retirement system. More to the point, there will likely be three reports, with the 13 members divided every which way, and no majority for anything.
In one mode or another, such expert councils have convened regularly since Social Security was enacted in 1935. There have been occasional dissents but nothing like the disarray we now witness. 
 Or do we? Looked at sidewise, as you might say, there is, in fact, a striking accord among the three factions. Each claims that if Social Security is to survive it must be radically changed. Henceforth, if the council has its way, all of the reserves, or much of the reserves, would be invested in the stock market.
It would appear the dream of universal Federal retirement insurance is over. I don't suppose we needed an advisory council to tell us this. For some while now opinion polls have reported that a majority of nonretired adults do not believe they will receive Social Security when the time comes for them to retire.
And this is not a matter of simple misinformation. In August 1994, I introduced a bill that re-established the Social Security Administration as a freestanding agency: The Social Security Independence and Program Improvements Act of 1994. I was virtually alone on the Senate floor when it was called up, and so took my time to explain that over the years the agency had been shuffled from one big department to another and had gradually lost its visibility and much of its energy. Citizens had begun to doubt whether the system would be there for them, when in fact it would be.
As I went on in my comments, I began to sense something strange, unusual. The clerks at the desk were listening. In the Senate, we call them clerks; they are mostly graduates of Georgetown University Law School. They never listen to speeches, having other things to do and having heard it all before.
I put in a quorum call and summoned them to my desk.
"I saw you," I hectored. "You were listening! Because you have never before heard anyone tell you you would get your Social Security retirement?"
Guilty, they concurred.
The problem with Social Security goes back to the decision in the 1930's to finance the system on a pay-as-you-go basis, with the result that there are no "real" assets in the trust fund. But now there is another problem. As a people, we are simply turning away from government.
Bear in mind that we began to dismantle the Social Security Act last year. The welfare legislation repealed Title IV-A of the Social Security Act of 1935, Aid to Families With Dependent Children. This in a sense was the oldest feature of the 1935 bill; the Federal Government simply took over the widows' pensions established by the states at the turn of the century.
Last year, when the Senate was debating "welfare reform," I argued, again on the floor, that to abolish our commitment to children would be the first step in dismantling the social contract of the 1930's, in which we undertook the care of the elderly, the unemployed, the children.
"Drop the last, watch the others fall," I pleaded. "Do not doubt that Social Security itself will be next."
The Senate went ahead anyway. Nor was it a matter of newly unreconstructed Republicans forcing change upon us. On the final vote to repeal A.F.D.C., only 21 Democrats voted against the measure.
Now it seems that all three factions of the Advisory Council on Social Security have effectively agreed to privatize the system in all or part.
One faction, supported by the former Commissioner of Social Security, Robert M. Ball, would permit 40 percent of the Social Security trust funds -- which under current law may be invested only in government securities -- to be invested in the stock market. An independent government body would make investment decisions.
A second plan would create "personal security accounts" into which 40 percent of payroll taxes would be deposited, with investment decisions left to individuals.
The third plan would add a new "pension benefit" for individuals, financed by a 1.6 percent increase in the payroll tax. As under the Ball plan, a government board would decide how accounts would be invested in the private sector.
It would appear to me that once the great majority of citizens found that they would do better in the private investment part of this new system, support for the redistributive aspects of Social Security would quickly erode. It would become a residual relief program for the poor elderly, possibly turned over to the states as is done with welfare.
Pity is this needn't happen. Last month, the Advisory Commission to Study the Consumer Price Index concluded that the index overstates the cost of living by 1.1 percentage points. If we were to make that small adjustment in the annual increase in retirement benefits, the system would be in actuarial balance until 2052. And we could go on to other things.
I don't expect to persuade anyone, but we have known about the problems with the Consumer Price Index for a very long while. Thirty-five years ago, I arrived in Washington with the Kennedy Administration; I became an Assistant Secretary of Labor, with nominal oversight of the Bureau of Labor Statistics. We had just received a report on price indexes from a committee led by a Nobel laureate, George Stigler.
The report read: "If a poll were taken of professional economists and statisticians, in all probability they would designate (and by a wide majority) the failure of the price indexes to take full account of quality changes as the most important defect in these indexes. And by almost as large a majority, they would believe that this failure introduces a systematic upward bias in the price indexes."
No one at the Bureau of Labor Statistics disagreed. The C.P.I. is not a cost-of-living index. The Department of Labor asserts this over and again. But the Government uses it as one and there you are. (A 1.1 percentage point adjustment would bring in $1 trillion in 12 years to the Federal Government.)
Privatizing Social Security would have problems, not least of which would be having the Government pick and choose stocks. (Quick, sell tobacco!)
But a New York Times editorial recently observed that "a good plan can be stitched together from the best parts of two of the three plans" -- those calling for partial privatization. Possibly. But keep in mind the risks.
And could we not fix the cost-of-living adjustment first? That would drain the panic from the system before making big and potentially destabilizing changes.

GRAPHIC: Drawing. (Kevin C. Pyle)

HEADLINE: DIARY

BYLINE: By HUBERT B. HERRING

 BODY:

UTILITIES
Lilco? No, Try a New Name
The name "Lilco" is a red flag to many Long Island residents. Just say the word, and they steam with rage -- at, mainly, the nation's highest utility rates, a legacy of the failed Shoreham plant. So with Lilco saying it would merge with Brooklyn Union Gas, it comes as no surprise that whatever the new giant is named, "it's not going to be called Lilco." Here's a surprise, though: the man who spoke those words is William J. Catacosinos, Lilco's chairman and, as a tireless defender of Shoreham, nearly the devil himself in the eyes of some of the utility's critics. And who will be chairman of the grand new wiping-the-slate-clean utility? Dr. Catacosinos, of course.
 
UTILITIES AGAIN
Nuclear Economics
Utilities can't wipe the whole slate clean, though -- not after the mess left by the national decision to turn to nuclear power. The most terrifying mess, of course: the risk of a devastating accident, every single day. But there's a financial mess, too. Yes, nuclear plants can churn out electricity at a competitive cost, but to look at that pussycat of a statistic ignores the twin monsters lurking just out of sight. Utilities piled up $70 billion in debts to build these plants, and the high rates at utilities like Lilco reflect that. Consumers have had it with the nuclear surcharge, but if they are allowed to shop freely, some utilities could go under. And there's that other monster cost: the billions needed to clean up the plants when they're inevitably mothballed. Where will that come from?
 
THE STOCK MARKET
While You Were Out
There's nothing like having Christmas and New Year's on Wednesdays. Presto! Two weeks wiped out. A two-week breather does wonders for the psyche, you say? What breather? The shopping frenzy segues right into returning what doesn't fit either taste or waist, then into back-to-back overdoses of champagne and football. In case you didn't notice, though, the stock market didn't play by the rules. A week practically guaranteed to be sleepy turned instead into a wild ride, with the Dow industrials ringing out the old with a 101-point drop -- the worst year-end performance ever -- and ringing in the new by plunging 88 more on Thursday before recovering at the closing bell. It was a skeleton crew raising all this fuss, though, for trading volume showed that a lot of people did indeed tune out.
 
CHRISTMAS MOVIES
Hollywood Attacks!
The rest of the business world may have gone into a coma the last two weeks, but the film industry went on a manic fling. For some unfathomable reason, executives all over Hollywood looked at their latest "product," scratched their well-tanned heads, and decreed, "It's a Christmas movie!" As a result, scanning the movie ads these days is a lot like overdosing on chocolate. "Michael." "Jerry Maguire." "Mars Attacks!" "Daylight." "101 Dalmatians." "Space Jam." "The English Patient." "The Crucible." And that's not the half of it. A newspaper's movie section "looks like the Yellow Pages," said one film executive. And guess what? Even if all those had been masterpieces -- sorry, an outlandish supposition -- Hollywood discovered the amazing truth that even at Christmas, human beings can see only one movie at a time. Some big-budget failures are piling up.
 
GIFT MONSTERS
Cabbage Patch Metaphysics
What would John Donne have thought? When he wrote of love as a devouring monster chomping on its helpless prey, he was safely in the land of abstraction, of metaphor. And when people today -- far less poetically, to be sure -- call the Christmas gift orgy another devouring monster, they too are in the land of metaphor. But metaphor has suddenly transformed itself into reality, as one popular gift, the Cabbage Patch Snacktime Kids doll, began literally devouring its human playmates. The dolls, you see, are supposed to crave a diet of plastic carrots and french fries, but they have proved indiscriminate diners indeed, instead chomping on children's hair and not letting go. At least 35 cases have been reported, but no serious injuries. It's so metaphysical.
 
NATIONAL PARKS
Grand Canyon, Sweeter
Quiet is such a rare and fragile commodity these days. Boom boxes and sirens abound. The voices at your elbow seem louder by the day. Even hikers atop glorious mountains have been known to flip out cell phones and bellow, "It's so quiet up here!" Is there no relief? One blow was struck for serenity last week, as the Interior Department put new limits on flights in the Grand Canyon. The clear message: there's only one Grand Canyon, and its mythic spell can be shattered in an instant by a swooping helicopter. Operators of air tours have understandably fought any restrictions, for they fly about 800,000 people a year over the canyon, and they will now be limited to smaller areas and shorter hours.
 
PROMOTIONS
A New Look at Denny's
The Denny's restaurant chain does not, you will recall, have a stellar record on race relations. After being accused of refusing to seat blacks or of forcing them to pay in advance, it paid millions of dollars a few years ago to settle lawsuits by black customers. So it was interesting, to say the least, to hear that Denny's is now a major sponsor of the Harlem Globetrotters. And it's a full-blown promotion, with Denny's giving away 100 tickets to each of 60 games to "deserving children" and selling official Globetrotters mini-basketballs. Has Denny's truly shed its old ways? Is this just good business? It's certainly the latter, and perhaps it's both.
 
ICE CREAM
Six-Gun Garcia, Anyone?
Ben & Jerry's is different. It is the ultimate socially responsible company, with, for the most part, a highly egalitarian approach to salaries. When it needed a new top executive two years ago, it told aspiring corporate chieftains to submit 100-word essays making their case -- and received more than 20,000 responses. But when it finally got its chief, Robert Holland, he stayed less than two years, resigning in September. Still, Ben & Jerry's was still Ben & Jerry's -- sinful only in the high-fat temptation it dangles before a weak-willed populace. This one-of-a-kind company would never, say, hire a rifle-company executive to be its new boss. Or would it? The new year brought a new start indeed, as Ben & Jerry's named Perry D. Odak, a former chief operating officer at U.S. Repeating Arms.
 
CAMPAIGN FINANCE
The Lexus of House Seats
Fed up with out-of-sight campaign spending? Well, if you'd baked your own cookies, you might have stopped some of it. A man named Michael Coles, you see, founded the Great American Cookie Company and became so rich he was able to spend millions in a doomed effort to unseat Newt Gingrich. And political one-upmanship being what it is, Mr. Gingrich -- with no real fear of losing -- felt he had to spend more. In fact, he spent $5.4 million, far more than any other House candidate (Mr. Coles was No. 2, at $3.3 million) and nearly 10 times the average spent on House races. Mr. Gingrich easily raised even more, though -- "he knows how to play the money game," said one campaign finance specialist. The surplus will come in handy -- the Speaker has some legal bills piling up.

HEADLINE: Paper Tiger;
'Asian Money,' American Fears

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
IN the 1980's, the Asian money that fueled scores of conspiracy theories in America was all Japanese. The sale of giant American icons -- Rockefeller Center and Columbia Pictures, the Seattle Mariners and much of downtown Los Angeles -- gave rise to dark warnings that decisions about the country's economic future would be made in Tokyo, not New York or Washington.
Exactly how this power would be exercised was always left a bit vague. Would executives at Sony kill movie scripts about the Emperor's role in World War II or about the dark side of corporate life in Japan? And would Nintendo, the new owner of the Mariners, ship home-run hitters back to Osaka, where power-hitting is in scarce supply? 
 In the short retrospect of seven years, the questions now sound even more paranoid than they did then. The Japanese took a multibillion-dollar bath on most of their investments. If anything, they exerted too little control over their acquisitions, especially in Hollywood, and it cost them dearly.
It seems almost laughable these days to think of the United States as an imminent "techno-colony" of Tokyo, a phrase slung around with great abandon in Silicon Valley until Japan plunged into recession.
 
 
 
The New Bogeyman
 Yet the underlying fear that struck such a chord in late 80's, a fear that Asian economic powerhouses were using their great wealth to buy power and influence in America, has cropped up anew. Now, the money is largely from ethnic Chinese, but -- and the distinction is important -- not from China itself.
The conduit for most of the money was John Huang, a Democratic National Committee fund-raiser who helped conceive and execute a carefully drawn plan to tap a rich vein: the Asian-American community. Mr. Huang appealed to the aspirations of a group eager to have a political voice equal to its accomplishments in American society, and he focused his efforts on those he knew best: the prosperous Chinese-Americans living in the suburbs of Los Angeles and New York.
As long as the donors were citizens or legal residents, those contributions were perfectly legal. But in racing to reach an ambitious $7 million fund-raising goal, he quickly raked in more than $1 million in clearly illegal donations from the wealthy precincts of Taipei, Bangkok, Jakarta and other outposts of the Chinese diaspora.
Now, in the public mind, the legal and the illegal have melded under the imprecise rubric of "Asian money." Just as Japan's investments touched a nerve about American economic impotence, the ethnic Chinese money has fed into today's anxiety that Greater China poses the next great challenge to America, economically and militarily.
This shift in fear from Japan to China is nothing new -- that pendulum has swung many times in the American mind, back to the late 19th century. John W. Dower, a historian at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, noted that "as a nation we can handle only one Asian bogeyman at a time, and these days Japan is down and China is up as the country with the greatest potential and the greatest potential menace."
 
 
 
Murky Motives
 But sometimes the smoke can mask some real fire, and the Democrats' problems clearly have elements of both. "In one sense, we've seen this cycle before," said Representative Robert T. Matsui, Democrat of California, who was 6 months old when he and his parents were placed in a World War II detention camp for Japanese-Americans, during an era when many Asians on the West Coast wore signs that said "I'm Chinese" for fear of being caught on the wrong side of the pendulum. "But this is a particularly difficult case, because there are legitimate issues to be debated here and a lot of questions no one has answered. And still, you'd be deaf if you didn't also hear the tone of racism that's running through a lot of this."
The key question, of course, is what kind of return on investment Mr. Clinton's biggest campaign donors -- who were usually the foreign contributors whose money has since been returned -- were expecting. So far, there is no evidence of a single policy or trade dispute that changed course after one of Mr. Clinton's now-famous kaffeeklatsches with Asia's rich and famous, though every new disclosure of a meeting sends investigators and journalists scurrying to figure out what Mr. Clinton's visitors really wanted.
For example, no one yet understands the real motives of the Riady family, the ethnic Chinese owners of the Indonesia-based Lippo Group, who gave Mr. Huang a $700,000 goodbye present when he left Lippo in 1994 to take a mid-level job in the Clinton Commerce Department. Did they seek intelligence about American Asian policy? Influence from a bureaucrat with regular access to the President? Or, as many suspect, were they simply using their many pictures with the President and their connections in Washington to create an image back home that could be exploited to profitable advantage?
 
 
 
Double Standards
 There are also a host of subsidiary mysteries, including whether it was greed or ignorance that led the White House, on the recommendation of a Chinese-American restaurateur-turned-entrepreneur from Little Rock, Ark., named Charles Yah Lin Trie, to allow the head of China's state-owned arms manufacturer into a campaign-organized meeting with Mr. Clinton about Asia policy. The White House says it had no idea then that the businessman ran the arms operation, or that he held a senior political post in the Chinese Government (a denial that does not instill great confidence in the vetting of Presidential visitors).
There is little doubt that some of the frenzy surrounding Mr. Clinton's meetings with big donors and their Asian business-leader friends has been fueled by the fact that many of the White House visitors have hard-to-pronounce names and run conglomerates few in America have heard about. It's hard to imagine the Washington press corps getting too excited about a White House dinner invitation to the chief of Airbus Industrie, even though the European consortium's profitability -- like the Lippo Group's -- hinges on major issues of trade policy (including China policy) that are decided in the Oval Office. But bring in the Thai-Chinese chief of Ban Chang, the huge Thai conglomerate and one of the largest investors in China, and suddenly accusations fly.
In the last few weeks, though, even some Asian-American business leaders admit to wondering whether they -- with the Democratic National Committee's direct encouragement -- raised the flag of "Asia bashing" too quickly. "No one in the Asian-American community can say this publicly, but in private a lot of the talk you hear is that there are some real problems with the way access was being sold," said one Asian-American banker, who insisted, of course, that he couldn't talk publicly.
But questions of prejudice aside, Americans and Asians clearly hold radically different views about where global power lies. American suspicions of "Asian money" these days are partly rooted in the sense that American jobs are still flowing across the Pacific. Very few people in America may have heard of the rich entrepreneurs whom the President was entertaining at election time, but many share a gut sense that somehow these Asians are pulling the strings of the world economy, building plants in Southern China using family connections (and bribery) that American firms could never match.
The soaring American trade deficit with China, which is quickly overtaking that with Japan, is often cited as proof that this is a battle the United States is losing. In this view, the Asian money flowing into the nation's political system is intended to spread that web of influence -- much like the Japanese investment in the 80's.
But Asian executives at the summit meeting President Clinton attended in Manila last November hardly flaunted their power. They worry about the future of Hong Kong when it reverts to China on July 1, wonder if China and Indonesia will descend into political chaos after their current leaders die, and maintain that America is in command of the world economic system. They talk about the hidden goals of Washington's trade policies in the same tones that some in Washington talk about Lippo's hidden goals in China. And if Washington gets into a prolonged spat with Beijing over human rights, arms proliferation or the pirating of American movies and videos, China's unfettered access to its biggest market, the United States, could be cut off. And that would crush ereryone's plans to export from their new base in China.
So if it costs an Asian company a few hundred thousand dollars to keep lines of communication to Washington open, well, that's fine. After all, that's a fraction of what is regularly paid to keep a provincial governor happy in southern China, or to keep friendly politicians in office in South Korea.
In America, however, it is unclear whether they are getting their money's worth. Perhaps, like the Japanese in the 80's, they will soon decide this is a bad investment. The reality of life in Washington is that many of the policies sought by Asian business executives -- including separating China's human-rights record from trade -- are generally also sought by American global giants like Boeing, I.B.M. and Bechtel.
Of course, American and Asian corporate interests often diverge. But for now, it's still hard to figure out exactly what the Asian executives are buying, beyond intelligence, some nice pictures for the office wall and a lot of publicity they now wish they didn't have.

LENGTH: 1360 words

HEADLINE: Popularity Brings a Huge Canadian Park to Crisis

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA 

DATELINE: BANFF NATIONAL PARK, Alberta

 BODY:
For the better part of a century, the majestic peaks and rugged valleys of this park in the Rocky Mountains have defined the romance of the Canadian West and the rigors of carving a modern nation out of the wilderness.
But times have changed. Now there is a Hard Rock Cafe in the park, on the corner of Banff Avenue and Caribou Street, and a few doors down from a restaurant that serves buffalo fondue is a Ralph Lauren shop. 
 In fact, the crowds of visitors are so thick that their meeting up with elk, moose and grizzly bears has become commonplace -- with danger for the tourists and the animals alike.
With three major ski areas, two communities, 5,600 hotel rooms, 1,300 businesses, the Canadian Pacific Railway, the four-lane Trans-Canada Highway, 27 holes of golf and over five million visitors a year, Banff National Park is more popular than ever. And more endangered.
An extensive study of Canada's oldest national park and best-known World Heritage Site concludes that there is a crisis at Banff so severe that unless something is done soon, it will cease to be a park.
That finding has set off alarm bells in Canada, where the park's bountiful natural beauty and unique place in history make it a touchstone of this country's national identity.
The study, conducted by a team of academics and independent scientists, found:
*Banff's back country is crisscrossed by eroding and heavily used trails.
*Native species of fish are being overwhelmed by stocked trout.
*The growing number of cars and other vehicles in the park is claiming the lives of an increasing number of elk, bears and other animals.
*Road building and other development has artificially divided the herds of animals, raising the problem of inbreeding.
When the study was released in October, its conclusions so alarmed Heritage Minister Sheila Copps that she ordered that no new land be made available for development in the park.
Ms. Copps is expected to take further action in late January and has left the door open for additional restrictions, possibly including limits on access to back-country areas.
"If we don't get our act together today, this park may not exist in 50 years," Ms. Copps said when the study was made public.
The lines have been drawn for a classic battle between use and conservation in one of Canada's most beloved icons. Like Yellowstone and Yosemite National Parks in the United States, Banff stirs strong emotions, and like the natural grandeur that the parks contain, almost everything about the conflict is larger than life.
"What's happening at Banff is that we are losing a fundamental aspect of the Canadian soul," said Harvey Locke, past president of the Canadian Parks and Wilderness Society, a citizens' organization. "It's being sold off to make money."
Brad J. Pierce, president of the Association for Mountain Parks, Protection and Enjoyment, also a citizens' group, countered: "This study was prepared by academics who live in an ivory tower. They have created a doomsday scenario for the park that is totally unjustified."
In the United States, the Interior Department recently restricted flights by helicopters and small planes over the Grand Canyon, harbingers of a long-contemplated strategy that would eventually all but eliminate cars from the Grand Canyon and other popular American parks.
From its inception, Banff was linked to tourism and to Canada's sense of nationhood as well.
A century ago, engineers pushing the Canadian Pacific Railway westward, completing a rail link that the province of British Columbia had made a condition for joining the new Canadian federation, decided to route the new line through the verdant Bow Valley.
When they discovered hot springs and inspired vistas in the valley, the railroad officials immediately recognized the area's potential for tourist development.
The railroaders pushed the Government to declare the hot springs a national park, like the new Yellowstone Park that had been set aside in the United States in 1871. In 1885, 10 square miles around the spring was designated as Canada's first national park, and the railroad built the Banff Springs Hotel to offer comfort in the midst of the wild.
The rest of the town of Banff, and to a lesser extent the nearby hamlet of Lake Louise, grew up around railroad hotels.
Completion of the Trans-Canada Highway in the mid-1960's, and the opening of an international airport in Calgary, about 75 miles to the east, made Banff easily accessible to global tourism.
Although Canada's National Parks Act provided for areas of outstanding natural beauty to be preserved for future generations, tourism took precedence under Prime Ministers Brian Mulroney and Jean Chretien.
To accommodate the boom in downhill skiing, the Banff Springs Hotel was renovated for year-round use. To keep the hotel full, its managers advertised heavily in Japan. The park now brings in $4.4 billion a year to the province of Alberta.
All this marketing success only sharpened the conflict between environment and economy. In 1994 a temporary ban on all new development was imposed while the independent study was conducted.
The study faulted Canada's national parks service, Parks Canada, for allowing too much development. Among its recommendations was one for fencing off the entire town of Banff and another suggesting tearing down several hotels.
Robert Page, dean of the faculty of environmental design at the University of Calgary and leader of the study, said runaway development on Banff Avenue and mile-long lines of recreational vehicles during the summer were only the most visible symptoms of distress.
"We're basically concerned with the character of the park," Mr. Page said. "If levels of development continue to expand at current rates, then characteristics expected in a national park, including the protection of wildlife, will no longer be there in a decade or two."
Although the town sites occupy less than 1 percent of the park's 2,564 square miles, they are in the warmer valley bottoms that wildlife also favor. Besides splitting the Bow Valley in two, the railroad and highway are creating genetically isolated groups of the moose and grizzly bears that avoid crossing the road and rarely use existing underpasses.
Suppressing natural fires, which is necessary to protect human visitors, has made existing forests grow older than they would have naturally, eliminating some species like the trembling aspen.
Rivers have been dammed to form a recreational lake, and an airstrip, an army cadet camp and a penned-in buffalo exhibition all disrupt the normal cycles of wildlife.
Mr. Locke said that by the time that Banff was officially incorporated as a town in 1990, more development had been proposed for Banff National Park, primarily in the town, then existed in all of Yellowstone National Park, which is 900 square miles larger than Banff.
But Banff's current Mayor, Ted Hart, said the community was surprised at the report's conclusions. "There is not a crisis here, in my opinion," he said. "Rather, there's a growing recognition by the people who have an interest here that we cannot let development get out of hand."
Mayor Hart said that before 1990, Parks Canada had approved some projects that the new town council would have blocked, including a three-story mall on the corner of Banff Avenue and Wolf Street.
The federal Government rejected the study's call to shut down hotels, though it limited the population of the town -- which now stands at 7,600 -- to 10,000. Mayor Hart said he doubted that the Government would order the town to be fenced, and he called the proposed back-country limits "ludicrous."
The town is developing its own growth plan, which will become part of the new management plan that Parks Canada must submit to Parliament in the spring.
Professor Page said Banff was so important now because the very nature of Canada as a nation was being threatened by continued separatist agitation in Quebec.
"After the flag and the national anthem, parks are the most important symbol of Canadian identity," he said. "They are part of what ties Canadians together."

HEADLINE: A Disney Cartoon Becomes a Morality Play for Paris

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY 

DATELINE: PARIS, Jan. 4

 BODY:
The French, who managed to find philosophy in the films of Jerry Lewis, are finding a powerful moral lesson in the animated film "The Hunchback of Notre Dame," one that even makes some of them willing to forgive Walt Disney Studios for taking such huge liberties with the Victor Hugo novel that inspired it.
The movie opened in France just as the Christmas shopping season began, months after its release in the United States, and remains the No. 2 box office draw in Paris. 
 Acres of advertising billboards and the marketing hoopla that flooded French department stores with dolls of the film's hero, Quasimodo, and miniatures of Notre Dame Cathedral no doubt helped make it so popular.
But it was an event from last August that gave a mere cartoon moral resonance here -- the dawn raid in which the police beat down the doors of the Roman Catholic Church of St.-Bernard de la Chapelle in Paris and hauled out more than 200 illegal immigrants who had sought asylum from France's tough expulsion laws.
In the Disney movie, the dark-skinned Gypsy Esmeralda seeks asylum in Notre Dame from the evil magistrate Frollo, transformed by the film from the troubled cathedral archdeacon of Hugo's "Notre Dame de Paris." In the novel she dies cruelly, but in the film she is saved by Quasimodo and the handsome Phoebus, the rebel captain of the guards. All three live happily ever after instead of dying, as both Quasimodo and Esmeralda did in the book.
Most critics here pay that no mind.
" 'The Hunchback of Notre Dame' tells nothing less than the story of the illegal immigrants of Saint Bernard," wrote Sibylle Vincendon, an editor of the left-leaning daily Liberation, in a review that went on to compare Frollo's campaign against the Gypsies to the campaign promises of the far-right political leader Jean-Marie Le Pen to send all foreigners in France back to where they came from.
"It is enough to replace the word 'Gypsies' with 'immigrants,' and Frollo becomes a perfect Le Pen," Ms. Vincendon wrote, although there is a complete lack of physical resemblance between the avuncular-looking Mr. Le Pen and the sneering cartoon character.
"The theme of discrimination is explored the whole length of the film," wrote Le Monde, which found that Dumbo also suffered, in the 1941 Disney animated feature, for having ears that were too big.
As for the solidly middle-class conservative newspaper Le Figaro, it noted that while the Disney studios recast Victor Hugo's story, the storyboard was partly the work of two French cartoonists, Paul and Gaetan Brizzi. The Americans, Le Figaro said, had given a remarkably faithful rendition of Notre Dame itself, stained glass windows, statuary and all.
But it's the politics of a movie that interests the French more than anything else, and when the good captain of the guards whispers "Demand the right of asylum!" to Esmeralda, many have said that the asylum-seekers of St. Bernard spring immediately to mind.
"It is difficult not to think of the undocumented immigrants of St. Bernard when Frollo tries to sweep out the 'rabble,"' said Marie-Therese Delboulbes, another reviewer.
Asylum did not work for the immigrants, most of them Africans, in St. Bernard when riot police raided the church last Aug. 23, ending a seven-week occupation and a hunger strike by 10 of them that lasted just as long. Most of the immigrants had been living clandestinely in France for years, had families here and were demanding the right to stay on legally.
Since the raid, 101 of them have been promised legal papers, according to a spokesman for the group, Ababacar Diop, who said that only 13 had been deported until Friday, when authorities put one man and tried to force another onto a plane for Mali. A few others are being held for possible expulsion, but French courts freed the rest last summer, and many melted back into the immigrant underground.
How many illegal immigants there are in a country where more than 3.5 million foreigners live legally is a matter of dispute. But with unemployment at the highest level since World War II -- 12.7 percent in November, according to Government figures issued on Dec. 30 -- the conservative Government is under pressure to deal summarily with foreigners here illegally.
The Interior Ministry has thrown out nearly 12,000 foreigners without proper papers since the beginning of the year, and before its Christmas recess, the national legislature tightened up already strict immigration laws to allow the deportation of legal immigrants if they commit violent crimes.

HEADLINE: Still Missing: Arafat's Nod

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN 

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, Jan. 4

 BODY:
It is three months now since the word went out from Jerusalem and Washington that an agreement on an Israeli withdrawal from most of Hebron was "imminent."
That, paradoxically, may be the reason it has taken so long. Because for Yasir Arafat, a signal that the other side was ready to deal was a signal to get to work. 
 Within weeks of the October summit meeting in Washington, at which the "intensive and urgent" new talks were begun on Hebron, the last West Bank city under Israeli occupation, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu went from haughtily predicting a quick deal on his own terms to the humiliating position of waiting day after day for a nod from the Palestinian leader to seal a deal that a growing number of his conservative Government regarded as a sellout.
In the end, Mr. Netanyahu's terms for withdrawal were almost the same as those proposed by the former Labor Government he succeeded in May. But now it was Mr. Arafat -- backed by the Palestinians, the Arabs and much of the world -- who took the haughty tone, telling the American mediator, Dennis Ross, "There are more burning issues than signing the agreement."
It was a bold and dangerous ploy. The "burning issues" Mr. Arafat spoke of were nothing less than a commitment from Mr. Netayahu to comply with far more difficult provisions of the Israeli-Palestinian agreements than Hebron -- namely, those calling for the staged withdrawal of the Israelis from much of the West Bank beyond the Palestinian towns.
Mr. Arafat's demand has put the entire Hebron agreement in danger with the Israeli Cabinet, where one minister after another has declared opposition to a deal that includes further troop withdrawals. Although a pullback from Hebron does not technically require Government approval, Mr. Netanyahu has pledged to bring his first Palestinian agreement before his coalition.
In failing to sign, Mr. Arafat was also defying the Americans. Mr. Ross had returned to Israel on Dec. 21 armed with letters from President Clinton and intent on moving past Hebron. And though he maintained his tactful public silence, his expression grew grimmer after every session with Mr. Arafat.
But then brinkmanship has always a primary tool of Mr. Arafat. In the Israeli-Palstinian equation, he has never had much military or economic leverage. He has had no constant international patron, no real skill for getting his message out over the news media, not even wholehearted support from the other Arabs.
What he does have is three decades of experience in exploiting the slightest advantage, and, unlike the ideologically divided Israelis, a clear notion of his goal -- a Palestinian state with East Jerusalem as its capital.
Mr. Arafat has also had the advantage that it is Mr. Netanyahu who has been on trial, not he. The conservative Prime Minister was elected on a platform that sharply criticized the Israeli-Palestinian agreements of 1993 and 1995, known as the Oslo accords, and at the same time pledged to comply with them. Mr. Arafat, by contrast, was a certified partner in the peace.
Thus, both in Israel and abroad, everything Mr. Netanyahu did and said was scrutinized for a sign. And in the first six months he managed to please no one: neither his conservative constituents, who did not find a solid commitment to expand what they call the "Land of Israel," nor among supporters of the peace, who viewed with anxiety the growing frustration of the Palestinians and neighboring Arabs.
Mr. Netanyahu has argued, with justice, that the former Labor Government was at least as delinquent in complying with the Oslo accords. The very first Israeli obligation, the release of female Palestinian prisoners, has never been fulfilled, nor has a "safe passage" road to connect the Gaza Strip and the West Bank.
But Mr. Arafat was largely prepared to close his eyes to these oversights in the faith that Prime Minister Shimon Peres, the Labor leader, shared his commitment. Mr. Netanyahu was given no such leeway, either by Mr. Arafat or the world.
In the explosion of violence that followed the opening last September by Israel of a new tourist tunnel exit near Muslim shrines in Jerusalem, it was Mr. Netanyahu who bore the brunt of international reproach. And when a soldier with a history of mental problems opened fire on the Arab market in Hebron this past week, the Israeli clamor for greater security for the handful of Jews in the city came to sound even hollower.
The impression it left was that it was not the Jews in Hebron who needed to be protected from the Palestinians, but vice versa.
The problem for Mr. Netanyahu, and for Mr. Peres and for Yitzhak Rabin, the Prime Minister before him, was that, unlike the Palestinians, who know their goal, the divided Israelis have never shaped a consensus on theirs.
As The Jerusalem Post wrote in an editorial on Friday, Mr. Peres lost the election last May because he failed to define the limits of the peace. But Mr. Netanyahu has fallen into even greater political trouble, the newspaper wrote, "because he has not yet succeeded on either front -- neither in convincing the world that he is committed to peace nor convincing his voters that he will enforce" those limits to Israeli concessions.
Thus Hebron became not only a step on the way to peace, but a test of the entire peace. That was what Mr. Arafat meant when he told Mr. Ross that "there are more burning issues than signing the agreement."
Contrary to the new Israeli Government's perception that Mr. Arafat would be overjoyed once it gave way on Hebron, the Palestinian leader in fact soon demonstrated that he views the city not as an end in itself, but as a way station on the road to Palestinian statehood.
In any event, most of the city is already effectively under Mr. Arafat's control, since the Palestinian Authority dispenses most services, and the Palestinian police maintain a covert control -- and an effective one, as it proved when Mr. Arafat gave the word that Wednesday's shooting not turn into rioting. The Jews of Hebron never venture beyond its heavily guarded center any more.
Moreover, both the Palestinians in Hebron and elsewhere have rallied behind Mr. Arafat's refusal to take the city without exacting some guarantees for the future. Their fear has been that after once Mr. Netanyahu withdrew from Hebron, there was no guarantee that he would, or could, go beyond.
The fear was heightened by Mr. Netanyahu's declaration last year that he preferred after Hebron to go directly to "final status" talks, which are to tackle the final shape of the Palestinian autonomy and critical issues including Jerusalem, Palestinian refugees and Jewish settlements.
To the Palestinians and Egyptians, this sounded as if Mr. Netanyahu wanted to avoid the three further withdrawals called for in the Oslo agreements. Though the exact parameters are not included in the agreement, the pullbacks were to begin last September and end next September, and the Palestinians hoped to gain control over as much as 85 percent of the West Bank.
In the end, probably before long, Mr. Arafat will give way, as will the Israeli Cabinet. For one thing, neither side can afford to defy the Americans to the end.
But perhaps more important, the past seven months have demonstrated that the Oslo process has its own inherent pace. Mr. Netanyahu has learned the price of trying to stall it, and Mr. Arafat has learned that the Israelis can only move so fast in their tortuous search for consensus.

HEADLINE: Papal Visit Signals Cuba's Eased Stand on Church

BYLINE: By CELESTINE BOHLEN 

DATELINE: ROME, Jan. 4

 BODY:
Pope John Paul II's trip to Cuba, in the works for several months now, has at last acquired its missing key element: a firm date, now set for late January 1998, a senior Vatican official confirmed today.
Although several months later than originally expected, the importance of the fixed date -- first announced late Friday in Havana by Jaime Cardinal Ortega -- goes beyond a mere planning detail. It means that the Vatican has been able to pin down President Fidel Castro on an invitation that Cuba had issued several times, but never before on terms acceptable to the Pope. 
 With agreement on the date, the stage is set for a visit that could have dramatic consequences for the Catholic Church in Cuba and the island's Communist Government.
At a meeting at the Vatican in November, Pope John Paul II, the veteran anti-Communist crusader from Poland, and Mr. Castro, one of the world's last remaining Communist leaders, put their personal seals on negotiations that have been under way for several years.
In the years since the collapse of Communism in Eastern Europe, relations between the church and the Cuban Government have been improving incrementally, as Mr. Castro seeks new sources of support inside and outside the country. The Cuban church, which was repressed after the Communist revolution of 1959, has been allowed greater freedom to operate, although Cardinal Ortega and Vatican diplomats hope to use the papal visit to win still more rights.
In the meantime, Mr. Castro has found an ally in the Vatican in his campaign against the American trade embargo against Cuba. The Vatican, which almost always opposes international trade sanctions on the ground that they are more likely to harm ordinary people than the governments at which they are aimed, has been particularly outspoken in the case of Cuba. It has lashed out against the Helms-Burton law passed by Congress last year that would penalize foreign companies doing business with Cuba.
On Friday President Clinton renewed his suspension of parts of the law.
For Mr. Castro, the Pope's presence in Cuba still represents a gamble, as it was for Communist authorities in Poland in 1979 when John Paul made his first papal visit to his homeland. For the church, there is still a risk that the Communist authorities will try to limit the Pope's access to the population and to the press.
The official announcement from the Vatican today gave no further details on the trip, such as how long the Pope will be in Cuba, and where he will go besides the capital city, Havana. But diplomats here assume that the Vatican has been reassured that the visit will take place with few restrictions.
In Havana on Friday, Cardinal Ortega said the Pope had hoped to make the trip in 1997, as was originally announced after his meeting with Mr. Castro in November. But having decided that Cuba should not be a stop on the way to a long-planned papal visit to Brazil in October, it was decided to slide the date into 1998, he said.
Pope John Paul has three other trips planned for 1997: to the Czech Republic, Poland and Paris.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL: NOTEBOOK;
Though Luxury Tax Looms, Marlins' Spending Keeps Pace With Yankees'

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
Not surprisingly, the Yankees hold the early lead in the luxury tax race. With only 17 players signed, they have already exceeded the $51 million threshold that could trigger the new tax next season. But the Yankees were expected to be there. The Florida Marlins were not, and they are right there with the Yankees.
Following a flurry of expensive free-agent signings, the Marlins have already qualified for a visit from baseball's new tax man. Based on current payrolls, the Atlanta Braves, the Cleveland Indians and the Baltimore Orioles are the other top contenders for the maximum contingent of five teams that will pay a luxury tax in its first season. 
 With $5 million in benefits costs included, the Yankees already have a payroll of $52.8 million and are followed by the Marlins at $51.2 million, the Braves' $50.9 million, the Indians' $49.4 million and the Orioles' $49 million. Just behind that group are the Toronto Blue Jays at $46.6 million and the Chicago White Sox at $44.8 million.
Although the lawyers who are drafting the final language have not settled on all of the details of the key components of baseball's new collective bargaining agreement, the basics of the luxury tax have been established. In the first year of the new economic system, the teams with the highest payrolls -- up to a maximum of five teams -- will be assessed a 35 percent tax on the portions of their payrolls over $51 million.
Until now, payrolls were calculated based on players' salaries for that particular year. Now the tax mavens will use the average annual value of each player's contract. And instead of using the 25 players on the major league roster, plus those on the disabled list, as of Aug. 31, the payroll people will use a club's 40-man roster throughout the season.
If the new method had been in effect last year, the Marlins would have had a $36.7 million payroll, which would have been 16th among the 28 teams. But that was before Alex Fernandez, Moises Alou and Bobby Bonilla added nearly $18 million to the Marlins' mix. Their current total of $51.2 million is for only 16 players.
Fortunately for their treasury, the Marlins are not expected to have any high-priced players among the other 24. The only unsigned starters, the middle infielders Luis Castillo and Edgar Renteria and catcher Charles Johnson, are not eligible for salary arbitration.
Andy Pettitte and Derek Jeter are not eligible either, but Bernie Williams is, meaning the Yankees can figure on adding more than $5 million to their payroll for their star center fielder, through arbitration or a negotiated contract. Last year, Williams won a $3 million salary in arbitration.
The Braves, whom the Marlins are trying to catch in the National League East, have signed only 11 players and face arbitration with Mark Wohlers, Javier Lopez and Ryan Klesko. The Indians, on the other hand, have signed virtually all of their front-line players and have no one eligible for arbitration among the 24 unsigned, younger players.
Mike Mussina's yet-to-be-determined salary will send the Orioles beyond the tax-triggering threshold. One of 27 unsigned Baltimore players, Mussina earned $4 million last season when he won 19 games.
The Texas Rangers are a team with a top-10 payroll that faces the addition of several sizeable salaries. With 13 players signed, the Rangers have a $39.4 million payroll, and they still must sign Ivan Rodriguez, Dean Palmer and Roger Pavlik, whose 1996 salaries totaled $7.25 million.
The White Sox, who have 11 signed players and a $44.8 million payroll, still must sign Roberto Hernandez and Wilson Alvarez, whose eligibility for salary arbitration will enable them to raise their combined $4.93 million income significantly.
Under the new system, the Yankees would have had a $66 million payroll last year. They will break $60 million this year, but do not figure to reach $66 million unless they trade for one or two high-salaried players during the season. They could, on the other hand, reduce their payroll by trading Cecil Fielder and the $7,237,500 average annual value of his contract.
No one wants to take on Fielder's contract, but the Yankees would be ahead of the tax game if they agreed to trade him and pay some portion of his salary. That average annual value plus 35 percent, an additional $2,533,125, would cost the Yankees just under $10 million.
Toronto included $5 million in its deal with the Mets to offset John Olerud's $6.5 million salary, but they will not be charged for the amount. Instead, Olerud's $6.5 million will be borne entirely by the Mets.
In effect, that kind of deal serves as a tax shelter for richer clubs. They can afford to pay part of a traded player's salary, and they get rid of the whole salary so it does not affect their tax standing. Next they'll be using cows.
 
 
 
Abbott Comes Up Short
 This is what has happened to Jim Abbott since he rejected a four-year, $16 million contract from the California Angels four years ago:
The Angels traded him to the Yankees, who two years later made him a free agent by not offering him a contract. The Chicago White Sox signed him, then traded him to the Angels, who signed him as a free agent.
Abbott pitched a no-hitter for the Yankees in 1993. Last season, he lost 18 games (winning twice), was sent back to the minor leagues for a few weeks and compiled a 7.48 earned run average, highest in the major leagues for any pitcher who pitched 100 or more innings.
His record for the four seasons is 33-48. His income for the four seasons totaled $10.1 million. Add in the remaining two years of his three-year contract, and the total of $15.3 million still falls short of what the Angels wanted to give him in 1992 but which he and his agent, Scott Boras, declined.
 
 
 
Explaining the DeShields Deal
 Seeking a second baseman, the St. Louis Cardinals acted quickly. Delino DeShields was among the first free agents signed in November, despite having had the worst of his seven seasons last year. In his first two years with Los Angeles he had slipped from his good seasons in Montreal, but then he declined even more, batting .224 last season.
"Look at his early years with Montreal," said Tony La Russa, the Cardinals' manager, in explaining the decision to sign DeShields. "He was one of the most exciting players in the league. As far as talent, he's a plus-plus guy at that position. He can win a lot of games with his tools.
"His experience in L.A. was not a good one. He admits it; it was there for everyone to see. He had a lot of aches and pains. They kept him from being the player he could be. You get in a rut and escalate in the wrong direction. We feel a change of scenery will help him. We were looking for someone at the top of the lineup who could ignite our offense. We feel he can do that."
DeShields did not ignite the Dodgers' offense. As a leadoff batter, he had a .273 on-base percentage, which according to Stats Inc. was by far the worst leadoff on-base percentage in the majors. Next lowest was Thomas Howard's .292 for Cincinnati.
 
 
 
The Arbitration Watch
 The traditional dates for salary arbitration have been altered slightly. Instead of filing from Jan. 5 through Jan. 15, the 101 eligible players may file from Jan. 7 through Jan. 17. As has been the practice in recent years, virtually everyone will wait until the last day. Players and clubs will exchange salary figures Jan. 21.
Among the most interesting figures to watch, barring negotiated settlements, will be those coming from Bernie Williams and the Yankees, Todd Hundley and the Mets, Mike Piazza and Eric Karros and Los Angeles, Mark Wohlers and Ryan Klesko and Atlanta, Mike Mussina and Baltimore and Ivan Rodriguez and Texas.
 
 
 
The Longevity Factor
 If Phil Niekro and Don Sutton, 300-game winners both, are not elected to the Hall of Fame when the results of the voting are announced tomorrow, voters will have to think twice before automatically voting for Eddie Murray when he becomes eligible.
The primary argument against Niekro and Sutton is that they were never dominant pitchers, but won 300 games through longevity. Murray is one of only three players (Willie Mays and Hank Aaron are the others) to hit 500 home runs and get 3,000 hits, but he has never hit 35 home runs or collected 200 hits in a season. His career highs are 33 and 186.
The only time Murray led a league in either category was in 1981, the strike-shortened season, when he tied three other players for the A.L. home run lead with 22.
Of the 15 players who have hit 500 home runs, he is the only one never to hit 35 in a season or be the sole league leader. Among the 20 players who have amassed 3,000 hits, only Cap Anson, Dave Winfield and Robin Yount join Murray in having had no 200-hit seasons. Other than Murray, only Winfield, Lou Brock and Eddie Collins never led a league in hits.

HEADLINE: Learning Gap Tied to Time In the System

BYLINE: By PAM BELLUCK 

 BODY:
New school performance reports have exposed a confounding puzzle about the failings of the New York City schools: why do children perform worse the longer they stay in the system?
Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew says that overcrowded classrooms and ill-equipped schools are part of the reason that New York City students persistently lag those in the rest of the state, with gaps in reading scores that become apparent in the third grade and grow to double digits by high school. 
 Other education experts have their own ideas.
Some say it is money: high schools in the city receive less per student than junior high and elementary schools. Some blame the anonymity and stress of urban life. Some say it is the constant disruption of students arriving or leaving in the middle of the year, especially new immigrants with big adjustments to make.
Others say that city teachers need better training or that schools are too eager to embrace instructional fads, never finding a classroom method that works and sticking with it. Others say the problem has been the Chancellor's lack of control over elementary and junior high schools, something the State Legislature recently changed.
All these things could play a part.
But most important, school officials and education experts agree, the numbers provide clear evidence that educational disadvantages have a cumulative effect as children move on to higher grades.
"Certainly a youngster who can't read at the third grade is going to get the message pretty soon that school is not working for him or her," said Richard P. Mills, the State Education Commissioner, who released the school-by-school reports last Friday.
"It's desperately important for children to become fully literate, learn to read very early. These tests that show performance declining in the third grade are late in the game. The problem needs to be resolved early, in the first grade."
Whatever the causes, the effects are strikingly clear. New York City's third graders scored 3.4 percentage points lower on reading tests than third graders elsewhere in New York State, even when students' poverty level is factored out and children of similar backgrounds are compared. Sixth graders lagged further, scoring 6 percentage points lower on reading tests. And by high school, New York City students score almost 15 points lower in English.
Other numbers show New York City children have been behind for years. While third-grade math scores in the city have gone up in the last eight years, they still fall below scores in the rest of the state. And third-grade reading scores have gone down.
"There's kind of this traditional notion that kids have learned to read in the lower grades, that reading is a set of decoding skills," said Frank L. Smith, a professor of educational administration at Columbia University's Teachers College.
"And so in junior high school, the teachers teach content. If the kid has a science teacher, very often the teacher doesn't think it's his or her obligation to teach comprehension, but just to teach biology.
"English teachers believe an eighth grader should now be learning how to use figurative language, how to make inferences, but if nobody's teaching them how to read, that won't work."
At Louis D. Brandeis High School in Manhattan, only 1 percent of graduating students met the academic standards for a Regents diploma, rating Brandeis among the 10 worst schools in the state by that measure. The principal, Marlene Lazar, said the school received so many students who were unprepared for high school work that teachers were working against tremendous obstacles.
"You have to remember," Dr. Lazar said, "a school such as Brandeis unconditionally accepts everyone. We are a zoned neighborhood high school. There are no limits on who can come in."
Dr. Lazar said that only 20 percent of incoming ninth graders read at or above the grade level and fewer than that were at or above the grade level in math.
"Considering that, in four years, we have a 30 percent graduation rate," she said. "We know that aiming for a Regents diploma is a real stretch for many of these children."
Principals at several low-performing schools said they faced similar problems. They said their students not only came in ill prepared, but many came from other countries, often in the middle of a semester, forcing them to adjust to a new education system in classes that were already well into the year's curriculum.
In addition, in schools with immigrants from many different countries, there may be only one or two teachers who speak a given native language, making the adjustment for students more difficult.
"It's clear that the composition of any student body in New York is probably more complicated than anywhere else," Dr. Smith said. "We are a port of entry and we get people who may have very little tradition of schooling."
Robert Berne, the vice president for academic development at New York University, cautioned that the high school performance numbers might not accurately reflect the achievement of every student in a high school because they sometimes took the Regents exams in different grades or not at all. He also said it was harder to factor out the effects of poverty on the high school level since fewer students chose free school lunches, the best measure of poverty in the system.
But he said that it was clear from the numbers that student performance deteriorated steadily as students got older. One factor, he said, could be that middle schools and junior high schools, already faced with students who are at a fragile age, were beset with even more difficulties in New York City.
"It's the most difficult age for kids, both in terms of maturity and just in terms of teaching and learning," Mr. Berne said. "Educationally, we've gone back and forth between K through 8, 6 through 7, 6 through 8. We never really got ourselves set."
Many experts said that better elementary schools would help mitigate some of the problems in the upper grades.
Principals of several elementary schools said it was a struggle to make sure that instruction was consistent within and among schools, so that fourth-grade classes set the stage for what is taught in fifth grade, even if a child transfers from one school to another.
"Our approach to reading is based far more on fad and fancy than it is on empirical data which really would reflect substantial approaches that work or do not work," said Lorraine Skeen, the principal of Public School 171 in East Harlem, where students performed well on the tests. Ms. Skeen said her school tried to avoid such fads but said there was too great a tendency in many schools to latch on to the latest reading or math teaching method without knowing its effectiveness.
"We develop new teaching approaches that sound very appealing but don't work," Ms. Skeen said. "Without any testing at all to see if these methodologies work, we adopt them systemwide. We lose credibility with teachers. Too many radical changes just really confuse children. Children like to know what's going on."
Sheila Hurdle, the principal of P.S. 113 in Harlem, said more consistency in curriculum and instruction could help her school. P.S. 113 ranked near the bottom in third-grade reading scores, when the scores were presented without adjusting for the low income of its students. The school performed better in third-grade math.
"We've left a lot up to individual teachers," said Ms. Hurdle, who said that the school had recently begun trying to standardize classes and curriculum by, for example, providing remedial reading programs and reading help in the lower grades.
Mr. Mills, who has made a crusade of raising student standards across the state, said the State Legislature's recent move to give the Chancellor control over who runs elementary and junior high schools would help increase consistency in the classroom.
"The system just wasn't put together right," Mr. Mills said. "To boost reading performance, for example, you need to have a chain. Where the Chancellor talks about it and expects the superintendents and local boards to do it, and expects the principals to talk about it, and expects there to be a system-wide set of standards and system-wide direction in curriculum -- all of that has to be in place. And it hasn't been."
 
Results by Region

HEADLINE: Clinton and G.O.P. Are Unlikely To seek Medicare Premium Rise

BYLINE: ByBy ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4

 BODY:
Administration officials say President Clinton has made a significant decision about budget strategy for 1997: he will not propose any increase in costs for Medicare beneficiaries, but will try to cut back payments to hospitals, doctors and others who provide health care to the elderly.
Congressional Republicans say they too are unlikely to seek any increase in premiums or other charges for beneficiaries because, in last year's elections, they were pummeled by Democrats for having supported such proposals. 
 But another battle is looming this year over Mr. Clinton's proposal to solve some of Medicare's most conspicuous financial problems by shifting the cost of home health care from one account to another. The home health benefit is the fastest growing component of Medicare.
Mr. Clinton plans to send his budget to Congress early next month. If there is no change in current law, the Medicare trust fund that pays hospital bills will, by his estimate, run out of money in 2001. That is 10 years before the first baby boomers reach 65, the age of eligibility for Medicare.
A bipartisan group of experts summoned to the White House recently to advise the President's budget director, Franklin D. Raines, said Mr. Clinton's home health care proposal -- one of his main proposals to keep the trust fund afloat -- was little more than a bookkeeping gimmick.
Under Mr. Clinton's proposal, most of the cost of home health care for the elderly or disabled would be shifted from the Hospital Insurance Trust Fund to a separate Medicare account with unlimited access to general revenue.
Medicare spending on home health services has exploded in recent years, exceeding $18 billion and accounting for nearly 10 percent of Medicare benefit payments in 1996. Mr. Clinton wants to exclude these costs from the computation of Medicare premiums, so beneficiaries will not have to absorb the cost.
When Mr. Clinton suggested a similar change last year, Republicans said it was not a serious proposal. After the November elections, they told him that they wanted a good-faith gesture on the budget, and that a repeat of his earlier recommendations would not do the trick.
In an interview on Thursday, Representative Bill Archer, the Texas Republican who oversees Medicare as the chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, said: "We're looking for a signal from the President as to how real his budget will be. I want to work with him on a bipartisan basis, but this proposal on home health care is a shell game, an artificial solution. It may help the trust fund, but creates enormous problems in the general Treasury and for future generations."
Among the experts who met recently with Franklin D. Raines, the budget director for the Clinton Administration, were Charles L. Schultze, the chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers under President Jimmy Carter; two former directors of the Congressional Budget Office, Rudolph G. Penner and Robert D. Reischauer, and Dan L. Crippen, a White House aide under President Ronald Reagan.
Mr. Schultze said the home health care proposal was "accounting shenanigans," and added: "It doesn't save the Government any money. It doesn't save any money for the Medicare program. It just shifts costs out of the hospital trust fund." Mr. Reischauer and Mr. Penner called it a "gimmick."
White House officials say that because many users of home health services have not been hospitalized recently, there is no reason for the Hospital Insurance Trust Fund to pay for those services. Increasingly, they say, Medicare's home health benefit is used by homebound people who have chronic illnesses or need long-term care for other reasons.
Medicare finances health care for 38 million people who are elderly or disabled. Its costs grew 10 percent a year in the last decade, reaching $191 billion in 1996.
Many Republicans and health policy experts say Medicare beneficiaries should pay more for their care, through premiums, deductibles or co-insurance, because such payments would generate revenue and curb the unnecessary use of services.
Chris Jennings, a White House aide who coordinates health policy for President Clinton, summarized the conventional wisdom: "In the eyes of a lot of people, we are not real men unless we hit beneficiaries with significant increases in out-of-pocket costs." But Administration officials note that the elderly already spend 21 percent of their family income, on average, for health care.
Medicare was a central issue in the Presidential election, as Mr. Clinton and Vice President Al Gore asserted that the Republicans' budget plan could force hundreds of hospitals to close. Now Mr. Clinton must explain why his plan to balance the budget will not have similar effects.
Bruce C. Vladeck, who heads the Federal Health Care Financing Administration, which runs Medicare, defended the decision to seek big savings from health care providers. Medicare, Mr. Vladeck said, has been less aggressive than private insurers in demanding discounts.
"There are now many markets for many services in which Medicare is paying more than the most effective private purchasers." he said. "That is very hard to defend or justify."
Richard J. Pollack, executive vice president of the American Hospital Association, said "it was pretty clear from last year's election campaign that most, if not all, of the savings in Medicare" would come from hospitals, doctors, nursing homes and suppliers of medical equipment. The savings sought by Congress and the President are so large, Mr. Pollack said, that hospitals and doctors may face "real cuts, not just a reduction in the rate of increase," in their Medicare payments.
He said such cuts were inevitable as long as Congress focused on Medicare's immediate fiscal problems rather than on the long-term changes needed to finance the program for the baby boom generation. The hospital association espouses the idea of "shared responsibility," meaning that beneficiaries, especially those with higher incomes, should pay more, Mr. Pollack said.
Some lawmakers have suggested that the Government increase Medicare premiums for beneficiaries with incomes above a certain level, like $75,000 a year. But Marilyn Moon, an economist at the Urban Institute who is a public trustee of the Medicare trust fund, said such proposals would not raise much revenue because they would affect relatively few people. Census Bureau data show that fewer than 7 percent of the elderly have household incomes above $75,000 a year.
President Clinton, like many Republicans, wants to encourage the use of health maintenance organizations, in the hope that they will save money for Medicare. Nearly five million Medicare beneficiaries are in H.M.O.'s, and enrollment is growing by more than 80,000 a month.
But a summary of the President's budget proposal says the use of H.M.O.'s "does not reduce Medicare costs" today because the Government's method of calculating payments is flawed. Medicare officials said they believed that their payments to H.M.O.'s were 5 percent to 7 percent too high, and they want Congress to correct the formula to eliminate such overpayments.
H.M.O.'s give comprehensive care for a fixed monthly premium. For each Medicare beneficiary in an H.M.O., the Government pays roughly 95 percent of the average cost for a patient in the traditional Medicare program. But Federal officials said that Medicare patients in H.M.O.'s tended to be healthier than the average beneficiary and therefore had lower medical expenses.
H.M.O. executives disagree. They say many of their elderly members have chronic illnesses. And, they say, if the Government cuts Medicare payments to H.M.O.'s, it will reduce their ability to offer prescription drug coverage and other benefits that attract new members.
