HEADLINE: RUSSIA THWARTING U.S. BID TO REMOVE A NUCLEAR CACHE

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON 

DATELINE: TBILISI, Georgia

 BODY:
The United States has been making a quiet effort to have a cache of nuclear material moved out of this volatile region of the former Soviet Union, according to American and Georgian officials.
But the operation to get the material out of Georgia, which is part of a broader program to stem the theft of nuclear bomb ingredients from Russia and its neighbors, has thus far been thwarted by months of diplomatic impasse between Russia and the United States. 
 The effort, which was intended to be a model of three-way cooperation, has been the subject of intense negotiations between senior American and Russian officials for much of the last year. The United States had wanted to keep the operation secret, but Georgian officials now openly discuss their predicament.
"Indeed we have several kilograms of uranium," President Eduard A. Shevardnadze of Georgia acknowledged in a recent interview. "We need to get rid of it. But we can't do it independently," he said, alluding to financial and technical constraints.
Stored in an obsolete nuclear reactor outside Tbilisi, the Georgian capital, the highly enriched uranium and spent reactor fuel would provide an aspiring nuclear power with a significant amount of the material needed to make a nuclear bomb.
The cache has been of growing concern to American officials, who fear it is vulnerable to theft by Iranian agents, terrorists from the neighboring secessionist Russian republic of Chechnya or arms traffickers.
Georgian officials disclosed here that the material was virtually unguarded in the early 1990's, when war engulfed this newly independent Caucasian nation.
Roving bands of militiamen approached the reactor during that time. But officials said the marauders were apparently more interested in stealing cars than uranium.
"During the years of civil war in Georgia," said Peter Mamradze, "the physicists at the institute had many sleepless nights. They were afraid some paramilitary group would come and take it away." Mr. Mamradze, a physicist by training, is Mr. Shevardnadze's chief of staff.
It was just such a scenario that prompted American officials to seek tighter control over the hundreds of nuclear laboratories, power plants and institutes spread throughout the former Soviet Union. During the cold war, the Soviet Union produced about 1,300 tons of highly enriched uranium, Western analysts estimate, and much of it remains scattered widely over the former Soviet republics in poorly guarded sites.
In recent years, several middlemen peddling nuclear material stolen from the former Soviet Union have been arrested in Europe. But there has been no confirmed case of countries or terrorist groups obtaining the ingredients for a bomb through theft.
The United States and Russia have publicly embraced the goal of controlling what some experts term "loose nukes." At a meeting last April in Moscow, Western leaders and President Boris N. Yeltsin pledged to work together to stem trafficking in nuclear materials.
[Such talks, in Washington's official view, have borne fruit.
[In a statement late Saturday, Lynn E. Davis, Under Secretary of State for International Security Affairs, said: "The United States Government has been fully successful in its efforts to insure that the Georgian H.E.U., or highly enriched uranium, has not fallen into the wrong hands. There is still more work to do, and we will continue to engage closely with Russia and Georgia to find a long-term solution by moving this material to a secure facility in Russia." Russia refuses to accept the fuel.]
 But the Georgian reactor is a case study in how good intentions can be snarled by bureaucratic politics, foreign policy concerns and environmental regulations.

Crumbling Legacy Of an Atomic Past
 Housed in a weather-beaten building a 20-minute drive from Tbilisi, Georgia's reactor is an eerie and decrepit monument to the lost days of Soviet science, when vast state resources were channeled into nuclear research.
On its inauguration in 1959, this research reactor was the pride of Georgia's Institute of Physics. Similar ones were built in other parts of the Soviet Union, in Bulgaria and in Iraq. Dr. Shucury Abramidze, the head of the institute's Center for Applied Research, which oversees the reactor, said he led the team that established the Iraqi complex.
After the 1986 Chernobyl disaster in Ukraine, Georgia's reactor was closed for safety improvements. The temporary shutdown became permanent after environmentalists complained and the Soviet Union collapsed, leaving Georgia with a troubling legacy.
Like other reactors of its generation, Georgia's used highly enriched uranium, a tempting target for would-be nuclear powers or terrorists hoping to build a bomb. Even the reactor's spent fuel, which was stored in a cooling pond, posed a danger, because such material can be refined into bomb ingredients.
The physics institute has never had any desire to retain the nuclear material, its director, Giorgi Kharadze, said in an interview.
But Mr. Kharadze, who greeted visitors wearing a winter coat in an office heated by a small kerosene stove, said Georgia's economic collapse had forced his country to seek outside help for disposal.
During the Soviet era, Georgia periodically sent its spent fuel to a Russian nuclear center at Chelyabinsk, in the Ural Mountains. The last trainload -- 44 rod-shaped pieces of spent fuel -- left for the center in March 1991.
Five extra rod-shaped pieces containing spent fuel could not be accommodated on the train and were left in the reactor's cooling pond, a minor complication at the time that emerged as a major headache.
A few months later, the Soviet Union collapsed, leaving the institute with the five rods, or nearly two pounds of spent fuel, and, more worrisome, an additional 22 pounds of highly enriched uraninum.
Georgia fell into civil war, and after the fighting eased by 1994, the institute began again to whittle down its supply. It sent about 11 pounds of highly enriched uranium to Uzbekistan, which has a similar reactor. The material was shipped in August 1995 at a cost of about $6,000.
That still left Georgia with about 9.5 pounds of highly enriched uranium and 2 pounds of spent fuel.
Estimates vary about how much is needed to make a nuclear bomb; it depends on the skills of the bomb maker and the intended size of the explosion. One American official said the material left in Georgia, while substantial, would not be enough to make a bomb. But some private experts said a proficient scientist could use it to do so.
"I would worry if it was in the hands of Iran or Iraq," said Thomas B. Cochran, senior scientist at the Natural Resources Defense Council, a private research group. "They could amass a technically competent scientific team to fabricate a weapon with a yield of a kiloton." A kiloton is the equivalent of 1,000 tons of TNT.
 
'Bad Neighborhood' For a Nuclear Cache
Although the instability in Georgia had subsided, last year the cache of nuclear fuel began to attract the attention of American officials, who worried about its proximity to Chechnya and Iran. Washington has asserted that Iran is determined to produce nuclear weapons.
"The problem was basically one of physical security," an American official said. "The fuel was located in a bad neighborhood."
But as concerned as American experts were, arranging the removal of the uranium and spent fuel would prove a long and painful diplomatic exercise.
In January 1996, specialists at the United States Energy Department sent the White House a classified letter proposing a simple solution: Strike a deal with the Georgians and move the highly enriched uranium to the United States.
There was a precedent for such a move, and it was a successful one. In 1994, the United States had carried out "Operation Sapphire," hauling more than half a ton of bomb-grade uranium from Kazakstan to the nuclear complex at Oak Ridge, Tenn.
The American envoy to Georgia, William H. Courtney, was the perfect man to oversee such an operation. He had served as Ambassador to Kazakstan during Sapphire.
The Energy Department's proposal left unresolved the issue of what to do with Georgia's spent reactor fuel. Although the United States has the technology to handle such material, officials said the Department of Energy was afraid that accepting it would mean protests and lawsuits from environmentalists.
And there were foreign policy concerns. The State Department and the White House, with an eye on the broader relationship with the Russians, argued that Moscow should be given the chance to resolve the problem itself. By the spring of last year, American officials decided to ask Russia to accept all of the spent fuel and enriched uranium.
Under the arrangement, the United States would pay Georgia about $100,000 for the material -- its market value, American officials calculated.
 
Missed Meetings, Sluggish Progress
By all accounts, however, the diplomacy with Moscow was an exercise in frustration. In early summer, American officials received the first indications that the Russians were not so eager to tackle the problem.
A meeting was arranged in Tbilisi for American, Georgian and Russian experts, but the Russians did not show up. Moscow ascribed this to a simple mix-up.
Higher-level efforts were no more successful.
The Georgian reactor was discussed when Vice President Al Gore and other senior Administration officials visited Moscow in July for talks with the Prime Minister, Viktor S. Chernomydrin. Russia's Minister of Atomic Energy, Viktor N. Mikhailov, assured his American counterparts then that Russia would take the cache of Georgian fuel in August.
But August came and went, and instead of taking the nuclear material the Russians voiced new concerns.
At first, they insisted that the canisters to be used for transporting the fuel to Russia had to be approved by Russian nuclear regulators. Washington offered to supply the canisters. The Russians rejected that offer and dropped the issue. Then Moscow voiced a concern about money, expressing reluctance to advance any of the costs of moving the fuel. Eager to carry out the operation, Thomas R. Pickering spent his last week as American Ambassador to Russia in secret negotiations on a compromise.
Eventually, officials said, a deal appeared to have been reached. America would advance Russia $1 million, to be returned minus any fees paid to Georgia for packing and handling the shipment.
Once again, the operation hit a roadblock. Russian officials balked at accepting the spent fuel, saying they had their own environmental laws to worry about.
The officials said that under Russian law, spent fuel taken from foreign countries must be reprocessed and the waste returned to the nation it came from.
Even though the reactor had been built by the Soviet Union and its fuel supplied by the Soviets, the officials noted that Georgia was now a foreign country. The waste would therefore have to be returned there after reprocessing.
That proposal was doomed from the outset. As Mr. Kharadze, the director of the physics institute, pointed out, Georgia has no place to store such nuclear debris safely.
American officials said they hoped this issue would ultimately be finessed by having the Georgians sign over legal ownership of the material to Russia.
During the course of the three-way negotiations, the United States sent specialists to Georgia to improve the security of the reactors. An alarm system, television surveillance cameras and a brick barrier were installed to protect the highly enriched uranium.
Reactor guards now work in 24-hour shifts. They are armed but are not always at the highest state of vigilance. A foreign visitor who recently quizzed them about their defenses and schedules was never asked to identify himself. Instead, he was asked for matches.
American officials acknowledged that the new precautions were only a stopgap and said the only remedy was removal of the cache.
A year after Washington began to focus on the Georgia reactor, when or how that will happen remains unclear. The Clinton Adminstration, which says it has put control of nuclear proliferation at the top of its agenda, is still hoping to persuade the Russians to take the material.
"It has been a more deliberate, touch-all-the-bases approach," one frustrated American official said. "The whole thing has been very bureaucratic."

HEADLINE: A Star in His Own Right Falls From Giuliani's Universe;
Time Warner Official Breaks With the Mayor

BYLINE: By ELISABETH BUMILLER 

 BODY:
In the old days, they had a relationship born of politics and mutual self-interest that grew into something resembling friendship. There were small dinners at Gracie Mansion, and one-on-one lunches in the Mayor's private dining room at City Hall. Richard D. Parsons, the schmoozy president of Time Warner, had, after all, known Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani for more than two decades, from their days as ambitious young Washington lawyers -- Mr. Giuliani worked at the Justice Department, Mr. Parsons at Gerald Ford's White House -- through their years at the same New York law firm.
By 1993, Mr. Parsons had become Mr. Giuliani's most prominent black supporter, and had turned down an offer to be deputy mayor. Mr. Parsons instead chose to be an economic adviser to the friend he admired as "a lawyer's lawyer" who was "not a typical pol." 
 But now, as Mr. Giuliani's 1997 re-election campaign begins, the two old friends are not speaking. The Mayor is heading into the race without Mr. Parsons, who says he is "disappointed" in the Mayor and fed up with his staff.
"The Mayor doesn't necessarily surround himself with the creme de la creme," Mr. Parsons said in an interview in his Time Warner aerie 29 floors above midtown Manhattan. "They're well-meaning, but I'm not sure terribly long on judgment. It's kind of like if the Mayor says, 'Hey, let's all drink the Kool-Aid,' they all go 'bottoms up.' "
The source of the fight is the October war between Mr. Giuliani and Mr. Parsons's employer, Time Warner, whose chieftains became enraged when Mr. Giuliani tried to force Time Warner to add the new 24-hour Fox News Channel to Time Warner's New York City cable line-up. Mr. Parsons was the conciliator in the middle who tried but failed to make peace. By Oct. 11, when the city refused to back down, Mr. Parsons quit in protest as chairman of the city's Economic Development Corporation. Mr. Giuliani had not called him once during the crisis, and sent word through his press secretary that he would not speak about him now. Neither would anyone in Mr. Giuliani's inner circle.
But Mr. Parsons is far more than the latest political exile of a Mayor well known for turning out a police commissioner and schools chancellor. He is also a Rockefeller Republican who has had one of the more unlikely routes to success, from the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn to the University of Hawaii to the legal staff of Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller and a home, for a time, on the Rockefellers' Pocantico Hills estate. Now he is the much-in-demand man about town, over-extended by his own admission on charity committees and corporate boards, a master of the Rolodex who says he is "still learning the ropes" at Time Warner while he oversees no less than the economic revival of Harlem as chairman of the Upper Manhattan Empowerment Zone.
"Trying to fit everything in and not doing everything badly is an issue," he said.
Mr. Parsons, 48, has friends among the city's black financial elite -- he shoots clay pigeons with Kenneth Chenault, a vice-chairman of American Express, and John Utendahl, the founder of Utendahl Capital Partners -- but he is often the only African-American at corporate board meetings and East Side dinners. Although he says he was by choice not especially visible during Mr. Giuliani's 1993 race because "I didn't want to be positioned as the Mayor's black guy," he insists that he never feels the stresses of other high-level black professionals who work in a white corporate world.
To illustrate, he tells a story he has often told before, about a white liberal woman who asked him in the 1960's to describe himself.
"And I started by saying, 'Well, I'm a lawyer,' and she said, 'Wrong! The defining quality for you is that you're black. And you refuse to acknowledge that.' " Mr. Parsons shrugged, crediting his father, who was an electrical technician at Sperry Rand on Long Island, for his own views.
"I can remember him saying to me when we were talking about the slogan 'I'm black and I'm proud,' 'Now Richard, wouldn't it strike you as odd if somebody said, 'I'm Irish and I'm proud?' I said, 'Well, people do say that.' He said, 'Yeah, but think about that. If you're going to take pride in anything, take pride in something you've accomplished. Don't take pride in an accident of birth.' So, hey, what can I say? For a lot of people, race is a defining issue. It just isn't for me . . . It is, it is" -- he pauses -- "like air. It's like height. I have other things that I'm focused on."

A Top Position In a Complex Hierarchy
The neurocenter of Time Warner, near the top of a 51st Street building that people call 75 Rock, is a silent retreat of white orchids, photographs by Henri Cartier Bresson and a corporate bathroom well-stocked with pencils and notepads. Mr. Parsons, who made $3 million in salary and bonuses in 1995, his first year as president of the company, has a large corner office up there, with Oriental carpets, a basket of fresh fruit and a view uptown. "I have just a slice of Central Park," he said.
Mr. Parsons stands a commanding 6 feet 4 inches but turns out to be a relaxed presence, a corporate executive with the loose, regular-guy manners of the college fraternity social chairman he once was. "I was the worst college student in the history of the University of Hawaii," he said, with perverse pride.
Mr. Parsons's job description at Time Warner is to be the junior partner to Gerald M. Levin, the chairman and chief executive, helping to oversee company strategy and relations between its cable, entertainment and publishing divisions. But Time Warner's powerful division heads report to Mr. Levin, not to Mr. Parsons. Complicating the hierarchy is Ted Turner, who in the merger of CNN and Time Warner became the Time Warner vice chairman, answering to Mr. Levin but not to Mr. Parsons, and intent on playing a large role in his new job.
Mr. Parsons knows that people speculate about the reasons for his own appointment. "Some people would say Dick's there because he's the most talented guy in all of America," he said. "Some people say Dick's there because they needed a black guy. And some people would say Dick's there because he has colossal luck." Mr. Levin says he chose Mr. Parsons, the former chairman of Dime Savings Bank, and a member of the Time Warner board since 1990, because of his judgment, presence and easy style.
"I can be very aggressive," Mr. Levin said. "Dick is a good antidote to that."
Mr. Parsons was born in Bedford-Stuyvesant, of what he calls middle-class roots. "Now we would be part of the lower middle class," he said. When he was 7, he moved to the South Ozone Park section of Queens, where he went to the New York City public schools of the 1950's. He says he got a fine education, was wait-listed by Princeton, and went instead to the University of Hawaii, which he had applied to as a lark.
"I had a wonderful time," he said. It took a fellow student, Laura Bush, to focus him, and they were married in Hawaii in 1968. "I sort of settled down," Mr. Parsons said. "The old wife said, 'Enough of this foolishness.' "
Mr. Parsons went on to Albany Law School in New York, where the former party giver finished first in his class, and then first among the 3,600 lawyers taking the state bar exam in 1971. As he was graduating, Mr. Parsons presented himself at the office of Governor Rockefeller, staffed by the brightest from Harvard and Yale. He says he had no particular politics at the time -- he just wanted the job.
"I looked at his resume and saw that he'd gone to the University of Hawaii, and that was sort of bizarre," recalled Robert R. Douglass, then the Governor's counsel. "But he had superb grades, and he was very, very smart." Nelson Rockefeller's office was an important training ground for talented young blacks of the era, and Mr. Parsons soon had a job as one of Mr. Rockefeller's eight assistant counsels. Within a year, he had become what he calls a moderate Republican -- a "fiscal conservative" and "social liberal" who did not believe in the "welfare mentality" of the Democrats. "The way you deal with social inequity is not by giving people things," he said.

Off to Washington With Mr. Rockefeller
Mr. Rockefeller took Mr. Parsons to Washington when he became Vice President in 1974, then lent his protege to the White House, where Mr. Parsons became general counsel of what was then called the Domestic Council, a policymaking group. Mr. Parsons worked almost daily with Harold R. Tyler Jr., the Deputy Attorney General, whose 29-year-old assistant was a bright star from Manhattan: Rudy Giuliani, the former assistant United States Attorney whose police corruption cases yielded the book and movie "Prince of the City."
Mr. Parsons and Mr. Giuliani quickly established a good professional relationship. "At that point in time, we didn't 'hang,' as they say," Mr. Parsons recalled. But in 1977, after Jimmy Carter won the presidency, Mr. Tyler brought them both into his law firm, Patterson, Belknap, Webb & Tyler. They worked on cases together, and became friends.
"Rudy would always work late, and then afterward he'd collect up anybody who was still at the office and we'd go out for dinner," Mr. Parsons said. "He was a party guy."
Mr. Giuliani's best friend at the firm was Michael B. Mukasey, now a Federal judge, but Mr. Parsons describes his own relationship with Mr. Giuliani as "fairly close." If the two didn't discuss personal matters -- "Guys don't talk about that stuff," Mr. Parsons said -- they did go to Yankee games.
Soon after arriving in New York, Mr. Parsons had moved to Briarcliff Manor in Westchester, where he and his wife were raising three children -- a responsibility that he says allowed him to keep pace with his friend Rudy's social schedule only "some of the time." Mr. Parsons had remained close to the Rockefellers, who had provided him with a house on the Pocantico Hills estate as he settled in New York.
"It was like living in Disneyland," Mr. Parsons said. (In a twist of fate, Mr. Parsons's grandfather had lived there too, as the estate's head groundskeeper.) Today, Mr. Parsons is still close to the family.
"He's a very respected adviser and counselor," said David Rockefeller, Nelson Rockefeller's brother. "All generations in the family feel enthusiastic about him."

A Hope to Revive A Broken Friendship
Mr. Giuliani left New York to become the associate attorney general in Ronald Reagan's Justice Department in 1981, but by 1989 he and Mr. Parsons had teamed up again for Mr. Giuliani's first run for mayor -- even though Mr. Parsons, by now the president of Dime Savings Bank, had supported Ronald Lauder, his friend and client, in the Republican primary.
"Whether he understood or not, people put things in the past behind them," Mr. Parsons said. "He may have been upset but he never said anything to me."
By late 1993, Mr. Parsons was running Mr. Giuliani's transition team, but over breakfast one morning turned down his friend's offer to be a deputy mayor in charge of fiscal affairs.
"It isn't the right time for me," he told Mr. Giuliani. At the time, Mr. Parsons was making $750,000 a year at Dime, and was just coming out of a long climb in bringing the bank to solvency.
Today, he is hopeful that his breach with Mr. Giuliani can be mended. "This is a very bright, thoughtful and interesting person, particularly one on one," Mr. Parsons said.
Mr. Parsons pointed out that there are many kinds of friendships, and that the most sacred are those with old classmates who would not necessarily be the stars of his Rolodex.
"There's nothing we want out of each other except companionship," he said. "But with most other people I know, that's not the basis of the friendship. There is a reciprocity -- I can do things for you, you can do things for me. Those are different kinds of relationships. They're easier to abandon, and they're easier to glue together."
His friend Rudy, Mr. Parsons said, "did what he thought he had to do."

Chronology: "Growing Careers, Friendship"
 
1975, WASHINGTON: Mr. Parsons, general counsel of the White House Domestic Council, meets Mr. Giuliani, former hot shot New York prosecutor turned assistant to Harold R. Tyler Jr., deputy attorney general. Mr. Giuliani's title is associate deputy attorney general.
 
1977, NEW YORK. Mr. Parsons and Mr. Giuliani join Judge Tyler's firm, Patterson, Belknap, Webb and Tyler. They work and party together.
 
1981, WASHINGTON: Judge Tyler recommends Mr. Giuliani to Attorney General-designate William French Smith. Mr. Parsons, serving on Ronald Reagan's transition team, puts in a good word for Mr. Giuliani. Mr. Giuliani becomes associate attorney general.
 
1989, NEW YORK: Mr. Parsons supports his client and friend, Ronald Lauder, in the Republican primary, then backs Mr. Giuliani when Mr. Lauder loses.
 
1993, NEW YORK: Mr. Parsons supports Mr. Giuliani, leads his transition and turns down an offer to be deputy mayor. He agrees to be chairman of the city's Economic Development Corporation.
 
1996, NEW YORK: Mr. Parsons and Mr. Giuliani split. (pg. 17)

HEADLINE: Flat-Tax Plan Wouldn't Let Investors Off Hook;
Still Progressive

 BODY:
To the Editor:
When compared with the base-broadening reforms of the 1986 Tax Reform Act, the "expanding loopholes" cited in the Dec. 29 Week in Review article may not be worth mentioning. 
 You say that tax shelters are chipping away at the principle that the American tax system should be progressive. However, such loopholes were common planning techniques for all the years featured in your graphic showing tax progressivity as a percentage of income both before and after the 1986 reform.
As for progressivity in real terms, reference to the 1995 tax tables show that, comparing incomes of $35,000 and $350,000, the tax borne by the $35,000 income (family of four, standard deduction) is about $2,800, while that of the $350,000 income (family of four, $35,000 itemized deductions) is about $101,000 (36 times as much). (This calculation disregards Social Security and Medicare taxes, for which future benefits are received.)
As a tax lawyer for 28 years, I would be aware of any legitimate means of reducing that burden, and I am not.
Despite deferred compensation arrangements, deferred securities sales and the few remaining techniques to reduce estate taxes, the system is still progressive for incomes in the mid-six figures.
If you are looking for reasons for growing economic inequality, blaming the tax system is unjustified.
 
NICK DEBERRY
Dallas, Dec. 29, 1996

SECTION: Section 4A; Page 14; Column 1; Education Life Supplement

HEADLINE: College and Money;
British Students Face Loss of Free Tuition

BYLINE: By SARAH LYALL; Sarah Lyall reports for The New York Times from London.

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
Free tuition for all university undergraduates has long been one of the underlying assumptions of British life, as much so as free health care. But with more students attending college at the same time as Government aid per student is declining in real terms, it is becoming more likely that in the future, college students may well have to pay for at least part of their education.
 "Things have come to a head," said Ted Nield, a spokesman for the Committee of Vice Chancellors and Principals of the Universities of the United Kingdom, which represents the top officials of 106 universities throughout Britain. "We're going through the throes of impressing on people that the Government just can't foot the bill any longer, so you're probably going to have to pay for part of your education yourself." 
 No overall change is likely to come in the next couple of school years, in part because Britain is facing a general election sometime before next May, and neither political party wants to commit itself to a particular education budget that might force the universities to charge tuition. An independent panel, led by Sir Ron Dearing, an authority on educational issues, is studying the tuition issue and is expected to make its report in late summer, but the writing already seems to be on the wall.
To Americans resigned to paying close to $30,000 for a year at an Ivy League institution, the British system seems like a throwback to an old-style socialist state. Currently, all college students who are from Britain or another European Union country are awarded free tuition at any British school for which they meet admittance requirements. The Government also pays maintenance grants directly to students for living expenses, based on need; the amount depends on such factors as where the students are enrolled and whether or not they live at home. The most any student gets is 2,340 (the equivalent of $3,740) a year. If the fees are imposed, it is unclear how much money a British student would have to pay.
About 30 to 40 percent of British university students are awarded the full maintenance grant for which they are eligible, said Iain Crawford, a member of the London School of Economics' education funding research team. But many students find that the grants, which are meant to cover room, board, books and all miscellaneous living expenses, are not enough to account for even basic costs. As a result, they're forced to do what students in the United States have long done: take out interest-free student loans, albeit for much smaller sums than their American counterparts.
"The grant has been frozen for several years," said Liz Llewellyn, a spokeswoman for the National Union of Students. "Already some students are leaving university with debts of 6,000 (nearly $10,000)."
Mr. Crawford agreed. "The package is about 25 percent lower than the absolute bare minimum of expense," he said.
At the same time, universities are increasingly hard pressed to meet all their own costs with the Government-allotted tuition money. The money is paid to the universities on a per-student basis, according to a complicated funding formula that, for example, pays out more for pre-med students and less for liberal-arts students.
According to figures provided by the vice chancellors' committee, in the last school year, the average amount paid by the Government for each student was $7,195, far less than the universities say they need.
Since the 1988-89 school year, the number of students attending universities has increased dramatically, to 1.7 million from 830,000 students. (The Government made an effort to increase the number of students by adding schools and expanding existing schools.) But at the same time, Mr. Nield said, per-student Government funding has decreased by 30 percent in real terms, in large part because Government funding -- in the current fiscal year, its entire higher-education budget is $10.3 billion -- hasn't kept pace with the increase in students.
 The financing situation, Mr. Nield said, has left universities with a cash crisis, forcing them to make choices between cutting capital programs or slashing recurring expenses. In most cases, said Mr. Nield, capital programs have been the most heavily hit.
"The reason universities haven't gone bankrupt is that they've deferred maintenance on buildings," he said. "The buildings have gotten more tatty and out of date, the universities haven't invested in infrastructure and equipment, and there's a growing obsolescence problem, particularly in the sciences."
Universities have also frozen teachers' salaries and stopped spending on things like libraries, classrooms and dormitories. "What we are seeing is a falling off in the standard of the student experience," Mr. Nield said. "The classrooms are becoming overcrowded and there are fewer books and fewer places to study in the libraries -- the number of workstations, for example, hasn't risen in line with student numbers."
The vice chancellors' group met in early December to consider whether to advise its members to consider imposing tuition fees on British and European Union students (foreign students already pay roughly between $10,000 and $24,000 a year, depending on their discipline, according to the vice chancellors' committee). In part because of the Tory Government's last-minute decision -- felt by many to be politically motivated -- to pump an extra $160 million into the system over the next two years, the group put off a decision on the issue until next fall, after the Dearing panel makes its report.
But while the universities say that the extra funds are just a stopgap measure that hardly settles future funding problems, the Government itself, understandably, argues that the money should be enough to prevent the politically damaging imposition of tuition fees.
"Our position is that we don't think the universities need to charge these fees, that they already get enough money from their own sources and from the central Government," said David Peale, a spokesman for the British Department of Education.
Still, educators estimate that at least seven British universities are seriously considering having to charge tuition within the next few years. One of these is the London School of Economics, which recently announced that it will probably charge fees for some students in the realm of $800 to $1,600 starting with new students in the 1998 school year.
Currently, about one-third of the school's 3,000 or so undergraduates are from countries other than Britain or the European Union. The school needs their tuition payments -- which can go as high as $14,055 a year per student -- to subsidize the cost of educating its British and European Union students, for whom the Government pays only about $4,100 to $5,000) a year each.
"We are concerned about the current U.K. funding situation," Mr. Crawford said. "A lot of university governing bodies are putting themselves into a position where they will be able to make contingent decisions," such as being able to charge tuition should the next budget be unfavorable.
A serious consideration for the London School of Economics and other universities, Mr. Crawford said, would be to make sure that any imposition of tuition would not deter eligible students from attending the schools. "The question that needs to be answered is to what extent do you insure that someone who is bright enough to go to L.S.E. is backed by loans or scholarships of some sort," he said.
Ms. Llewellyn of the students' union, though, warned that charging tuition would deter many poorer students from attending a university at all -- even if the Government was able to set up a favorable loan program.
"Students now have to pay to live and eat and house themselves, so the least they can expect is for their education to be paid for," she said. "If tuition fees were charged, a lot of people you would think of as middle class would be priced out of going to university."

SECTION: Section 4A; Page 30; Column 1; Education Life Supplement 

LENGTH: 5425 words

HEADLINE: CORPORATE CLASSROOMS AND COMERCIALISM

BYLINE: By Deborah Stead; Deborah Stead writes the Off the Shelf column in the SUnday business section of The New York Times

 BODY:
To cope with its latest budget crisis, the Seattle School Board passed a new policy just before Thanksgiving: It voted to accept corporate advertising in the city's middle and secondary schools.
 "We're viewing this more as sponsorship, though we will have visual ads," said Joseph Olchefske, the school district's chief financial officer. A typical sponsorship, he speculated, might result in "the cheerleaders, brought to you by Reebok" or "the McDonald's gym." 
 If Seattle schools put the advertising policy in place this fall, as planned, they will be joining another large school system, Colorado Springs, that took a similar step three years ago. Students there have been riding in school buses adorned with corporate logos and walking in hallways dotted with advertising billboards.
 Throughout the nation, meanwhile, almost 40 percent of schools have homerooms that start the day with news and commercials transmitted by Channel One, the Christopher Whittle creation that has attracted much criticism since it began in 1989.
 And commercialism has worked its way into schools in other forms as well:
 *Classroom packets that promote Hershey's chocolate or Kellogg's Rice Krispies.
*Third graders practicing math by counting Tootsie Rolls.
 *Young children learning to read with software that uses corporate logos like Kmart, Coke, Pepsi and Cap'n Crunch.
 *Prozac representatives giving a talk at a high school assembly on National Depression Screening Day.
 Over the last decade, corporate America has dramatically increased its involvement in education, from pre-kindergarten to post-graduate research. Practically every Fortune 500 company -- and virtually every local chamber of commerce -- has a school project. In part because of "A Nation at Risk," the 1983 Federal Government report that linked declining schools with the country's economic future, many business leaders are genuinely concerned about how their future employees are being educated these days. Indeed, business-led education summits -- like the one attended by 44 governors as well as President Clinton last March at International Business Machines Corporation's conference center in Palisades, N.Y. -- are helping to set the educational agenda.
 The companies come bearing precious dollars and other resources sorely needed in the nation's public school system, now struggling -- with dwindling public funds in some regions -- to educate a near-record 45.9 million children. Businesses donate money and materials, help wire schools for the Internet and mobilize employees to volunteer as tutors.
 But along with this philanthropy, schools are also receiving increasing doses of hucksterism. And public school advocates, educators, parents and even students are concerned that commercialism in the classroom could overshadow corporate good will.
 "It's an ethical issue that people don't talk about enough, and there is a big cause for concern," said Edward Miller, an education writer and former editor of the Harvard Education Newsletter. "By and large, educators are aware of these ethical issues, but the fact is that they are incredibly squeezed when it comes to resources and materials -- and they'll take help where they can get it."
 Indeed, these days, cash-strapped school administrators seem to be less content to be mere recipients of corporate largesse -- or of marketing and advertising disguised as free educational material. Some, like the Seattle School Board, are actively looking for commercial partnerships to stay afloat -- deals that make corporations pay for the privilege of entering the schoolhouse door.
 
'THAT'S WHERE THE KIDS ARE'
 Classroom commercialism isn't new. Most Americans have memories of the world of commerce being mixed into their school days occasionally.
"It's something that's gone on in the United States for the better part of this century," said Alex Molnar, an education professor at the University of Wisconsin, Milwaukee, and the author of "Giving Kids the Business: The Commercialization of America's Schools," recently published by West View Press.
 In the 1920's, for instance, Ivory Soap sponsored school soap-carving competitions -- a gimmick masterminded by Edward L. Bernays, one of America's first public relations men. (The company donated the soap.) In that era of emerging consumer goods, "children were seen as ambassadors, bringing back home the idea of packaged products," said Stewart Ewen, professor of media studies at Hunter College in New York and the author of "PR! A Social History of Spin."
Bankers, who still have an active outreach program in schools, began establishing those links after their image plummeted during the Depression. And in the late 1930's, the National Association of Manufacturers distributed a weekly gazette, Young America Magazine, to 70,000 schools. Typical articles: "Your Neighborhood Bank" and "The Business of America's People Is Selling." The association sent similar messages in its filmstrip and sound-recording programs. (It provided the equipment free to the schools.) "And by the late 1940's and 1950's, Junior Achievement was well in place, to get kids interested in entrepreneurialism," Professor Ewen said.
 By 1979, Sheila Harty had published "Hucksters in the Classroom," which focused mostly on commercially sponsored teaching kits about nutrition, the environment and economics. The book was considered the first comprehensive look at the subject.
 Since then, companies have gotten bolder in their efforts to bring commercial messages into the schools. "In the past, there was maybe more of a feeling that shameless promotion in school wasn't right, that you should keep education separate," said Gene Newman, associate editor of Youth Markets Alert, a marketing industry newsletter published by EPM Communications in New York. "I think in today's business climate, that's definitely beginning to change."
 At the same time advertisers are finding it harder to determine which media are the best avenues for reaching the 6- to 19-year-old consumers whose spending power and influence add up to $485 billion a year.
 "Kid TV viewership is down a lot on the traditional Saturday morning programs and on weekday afternoons," said Julie Halpin, senior vice president of Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising's Kid Connection, its youth marketing unit. From 1995 to 1996, she said, overall TV viewership in those time slots has dropped an average of 6 percent, as children watch videos or play computer games instead.
Classrooms, therefore, look more attractive than ever, Mr. Newman said, because "that's where all the kids are."
 And marketers see a green light when they contemplate the school system's troubles. "As the price of books, computers and other teaching aids outstrips school budgets, corporations and their marketing messages are more welcome in the schools," a recent article in Youth Markets Alert reported.
 The messages are proliferating, said Marianne Manilov, executive director of the Center for Commercial Free Public Education, a nonprofit advocacy group based in Oakland, Calif. "It's a flood," she said, because for corporate advertisers, "there are so many ways into the schools."

 LESSONS IN THE MAIL
The "Chocolate Dream Machine" appeared out of nowhere, not long ago, in Lisa Becerra's mailbox at the Washington Middle School in Seattle.
 "I laughed when I saw it," said Ms. Becerra, who teaches English and social studies at the school, which has 1,200 students, many from lower-income families. "It's about chocolate's place in a balanced diet, with Hershey's mixed in there."
 "The Chocolate Dream Machine" is a video and curriculum guide developed by the Mazer Corporation in Dayton, Ohio, for the Hershey Foods Corporation.
 In the video, four young people use a computer to learn how chocolate is made. Along the way there are a few vocabulary, math, geography and science lessons. (The nutritional advice -- that chocolate should be eaten only occasionally, as a treat -- seems sound.) But there is also footage featuring Hershey products, as well as a few other nuggets. A sample: "I didn't know they used real whole milk in chocolate," one teen-ager in the video says. "Mr. Hershey did," another replies. "His company still does today."
 The written guide and suggested classroom activities are also full of references to Hershey: its founder, its philanthropies, its products.
 The "Chocolate Dream Machine" was created about a year and a half ago, after the company received teacher requests to make a previous program more appropriate for students of middle-school age, said John Long, Hershey's director of corporate communications. After the kit went out, he said, "we received 400 response cards from teachers, and they've universally been positive." The lesson's "primary purpose is not marketing," he said, but "it's hard to answer the interest in Hershey and chocolate and not mention the company name."
 The "Dream Machine" is an example of what is called "sponsored education material." And many companies provide such materials to schools at no cost. Besides food companies, education material may come from Hollywood studios, trade groups, energy conglomerates and newspapers. (The New York Times and The Wall Street Journal, for instance, publish special classroom versions of their newspapers for secondary schools. Distributed quarterly and monthly, respectively, they contain advertising.)
Kellogg's offers nutrition posters with pictures of Rice Krispies boxes. MCA International sends out material for young children featuring Casper the Friendly Ghost and The Little Engine That Could -- both characters from the company's current video catalogue.
 "There is a proliferation of this 'shadow curriculum,' free material related to product placement that teachers are using in the classroom," said Arnold F. Fege of the National P.T.A. in Washington, which represents 27,000 member organizations. "We still don't know the magnitude of it."
 Because the materials usually arrive unsolicited and rarely undergo curriculum reviews, it is difficult to know how many teachers use them. But the independent developers of these learning kits estimate that their products reach up to 2 million teachers from kindergarten through college at practically every school in America.
 "We get them every day," said Janice R. Nicholas, principal of the River Terrace Community School, an elementary school in Washington, which she describes as "middle class in values but not in funding."
 A few years ago, schools were receiving the "Prego Thickness Experiment," sponsored by the Campbell Soup Company. The classroom kit -- containing a slotted spoon and a Prego poster -- explained the scientific method students could use to "prove" that Prego was thicker than Ragu. Campbell has since discontinued the program.
 These days, teachers from kindergarten to third grade are finding "Tootsie Roll: The Sweet Taste of Success" in their mailboxes. "The Sweet Taste of Success" includes, among other things, lessons in simple math (counting Tootsie Rolls), geography (linking map sites where Tootsie Rolls have been produced to events in American history), a writing exercise (creating a story from a poster history of Tootsie Rolls) and a suggested follow-up activity (interviewing family members about their memories of Tootsie Rolls and Tootsie Pops).
The lesson plan was developed by Lifetime Learning Systems, a unit of K-III Communications Inc., which also owns Weekly Reader and, now, Channel One. Lifetime Learning currently has about 20 curriculum projects, said Dominic Kinsley, its editor in chief. A decade ago, there were only five or six.
 The emphasis on the candy, as an American icon, is intentional, Mr. Kinsley said. The premise "is to use the feelings people have about Tootsie Rolls and to teach a variety of skills to young children." The interviewing, he said, is "a link between parents and children."
 Ms. Becerra in Seattle, who has been thinking lately about the subject of advertising in the schools (she opposes the school's new policy), said she "definitely" planned to use "The Chocolate Dream Machine" in a food unit later this year. But she said materials like these were also excellent vehicles for teaching something else: media literacy, the art of seeing behind the image being presented.
 Ms. Becerra said she would ask students what they thought about the purpose of the Hershey's program. "I'll say: 'Why do you think Hershey's sent this to me? Why would they send this to teachers?' "
 
Tattoos and Textbook Covers
 As he was sitting down to dinner one night last fall, Christopher St. John, an accountant from Staten Island, N.Y., noticed temporary tattoos on the arms of his two daughters. The decals bore the initials "CK," for Calvin Klein.
 Where, he asked, had his girls, ages 7 and 10, picked up these corporate logos?
 School, they told him. The tattoos were included with free textbook covers that featured young models dressed in Calvin Klein clothing.
 "I was livid," Mr. St. John said. "First of all, I don't like Calvin Klein's advertising," he said. "I think it's exploitive. And the tattoos I find very, very hideous." Beyond that, he said, "my kids shouldn't have to have all this peer pressure for clothes and image. You're trying to get the kids ready in the morning, and for them to worry about their fashion -- it just goes too far. To have the school handing out this stuff, it really outraged me."
 Mr. St. John complained directly to the principal at the girls' school, Public School 23, and the covers were removed from the school. No more ad-bearing book covers will be accepted, said Diane Alvaro, president of the P.T.A. "The kids can use brown paper bags or buy covers at the store."
 The textbook covers and tattoos given to Mr. St. John's daughters are produced by Cover Concepts Marketing Services Inc. in Braintree, Mass., an eight-year-old company that distributes free book covers each semester to 31,000 schools and almost 25 million students across the country. (Cover Concepts also sends consumer product samples for some of its clients.)
 Told of Mr. St. John's complaint, Steven Shulman, the president of Cover Concepts, said that his company "listens to every concern," but he defended the Calvin Klein book cover, which he said depicted "conservatively dressed" young people. "We have schools that sent thank-you letters for the Calvin Klein cover," he said. A spokesman for Calvin Klein, Robert L. Triefus, said his understanding is that the covers are being distributed with "the permission of the relevant school authorities."
 According to Mr. Shulman, "Most of our covers have a positive message." Indeed, a number of his company's textbook covers feature discreet logos amid colorful designs and public service messages (Michael Jordan and Spike Lee, for instance, on staying in school).
 But make no mistake: this is advertising.
 Corporate clients pay $129,000 per million covers for a semester's exposure. "We do business with every major kid advertiser in the country," Mr. Shulman said. According to the company's promotional materials, students' tested "unaided recall" of the logos and brand names on their covers is 60 to 80 percent. "In traditional print media, if you get 4 or 5 percent, the client is satisfied," Mr. Shulman said.
Like all advertisers, Mr. Shulman's clients use demographics to target their markets. Nike distributes to inner-city schools, Mr. Shulman said. Lego goes to middle-income areas. Gatorade has three covers -- one for predominantly black schools, one for Hispanic students and one for predominantly white schools.
 In its pitch to advertisers, Cover Concepts points out that the target market is a "captive" one, since most schools require students to cover their textbooks. But Mr. Shulman said he did not see that as unfair leverage. "The students don't have to use our covers," he said. "And there's such a need for this program. The average textbook costs $50."
 Ms. Nicholas, the Washington elementary school principal, is one educator who says she is glad to have the textbook covers. If she finds a cover is "too commercial," she said, "we tell the teachers, turn it over on the clear side." Her school has few resources, she said, and "we make use of what comes in."
 
LEARNING HOW TO HUSTLE
These days, many schools are actively going after commercial relationships when public dollars dwindle -- deals that they hope will yield more than the usual logo-emblazoned athletic scoreboards or the media equipment supplied by Channel One.
 Florida's Hillsborough County school district -- with 145,000 students in and around Tampa -- recently signed on with Adopt-A-School Inc. in Winter Park to place logo-bearing posters in the corridors of its 160 schools within the year. Already, said Terry A. Boehm, executive director of the Hillsborough Education Foundation, the nonprofit fund-raiser for the district, "there are a lot of logos floating around on materials. If we're going to have advertising in the schools, it should be associated with revenues."
 Under the deal, brokered through the foundation, county schools will get 50 percent of the ad revenues. Jerry Coleman, Adopt-A-School's president, said the signs would carry "positive" messages as well as the logos ofnational and local advertisers that produce "mostly student-type consumer products." Such posters could eventually yield $450,000 a year for the district, he said.
 Mr. Boehm, who said that businesses accounted for 60 percent of the $3 million his group raised for the district schools last year, said he did not expect the Adopt-A-School program to produce more than 10 percent of Mr. Coleman's estimate. But he said he hoped it would "be a model for how things will be done with logos."
 As Seattle's school system begins its foray into the commercial realm, however, it may find, as some others have, that the results can be quite modest.
 *New York City's Board of Education has already signed contracts with companies that will advertise on the sides of school buses. The board hopes to bring in $53 million over nine years. That is a tiny percentage of the school system's $8 billion annual budget.
 *In 15 states, about 100 schools have signed up with Star Broadcasting in Bloomington, Minn., which beams 48 minutes of music (rock, country, oldies and "fiesta") and 12 minutes of local and national commercials every hour into school corridors, cafeterias and courtyards. Schools are encouraged to teach students how to solicit local advertising for the broadcasts. Star gives 40 percent of the resulting ad revenues to the schools. Its goal, said Pat DiPlacido, the company's president, is to make $5,000 to $10,000 a year for participating schools.
 Russell Goff, principal of Eldorado High School in Albuquerque, N.M., has been using Star broadcasts for three years in the courtyards of his 2,000-student school. In that time, he says, the school has made a total of $100. Still, he said, "overall it's been good." The music makes the students happy and calm, he said, and he hopes that maybe the advertising situation will improve.
 Colorado Springs, whose District 11 school system began in-school advertising three years ago, has learned its share of lessons, too.
 Its 33,000 students are "not enough to entice a Nike," said Tracy Cooper, a spokeswoman for the district and the manager of the advertising program. In the first two years, the school system netted a total of only $73,150. In 1996-97, as the program was expanded into elementary schools and a new ad agency was hired, the district sold $121,808 worth of ads for buses and hallways. After the agency is paid, the schools will be left with $85,265. That's less than $2.60 per student -- and a tiny percentage of the system's $155 million annual budget.
"It's a drop in the bucket," Ms. Cooper acknowledged. "It allows us -- this doesn't look big -- to buy one more violin or something for a school."
 Still, in Seattle, Mr. Olchefske, the system's chief financial officer, is optimistically projecting ad and sponsorship revenues of $1 million a year, "and frankly we hope for more than that," he said.
 
Corporate Conscience, Corporate Clout
 Critics of in-school advertising, like Professor Molnar of the University of Wisconsin and Ms. Manilov of the Center for Commercial Free Public Education, say that corporate America has contributed to the funding problems that lead schools to search for commercial solutions.
 In many areas -- particularly urban ones with overwhelmingly poor minority populations -- when businesses left or asked for special tax breaks, it meant the loss of local tax revenuesthat could have helped shore up those cities' school systems, they say. And giveaways and even intense philanthropic efforts, they add, are not adequate substitutes.
 Education-related corporate philanthropy last year added up to $1.3 billion, or 20 percent of the $6.5 billion corporate giving overall, according to Craig Smith, director of Corporate Citizen, a research group based in Seattle. A decade ago, education accounted for only 5 percent of corporate giving, Mr. Smith said. He defines the education category as "K-to-12 education plus school-related nonprofits like the P.T.A.'s or Junior Achievement."
 But that amount is still just a fraction of the estimated $293.7 billion nationwide public school budget for the 1995-96 school year.
 Many companies have chosen education as a cause for "strategic" reasons, Mr. Smith said. "There are various motives that attract companies to nonprofit places like schools. Some involve marketing, some involve research and development, some involve public relations and some involve employee relations."
But whatever its motivation, business has achieved tremendous clout in the national debate over education, Mr. Smith said, noting that "it is significant that the governors came to I.B.M.'s turf" last year for the national education summit.
Hugh Price, president of the National Urban League in New York, attended the summit, and he echoed the sentiment: "I think the business community can be a very important source in all of this, by saying, 'We expect the educational system to get the young people up to the levels,' and then looking at what's required."
K-III Communications, the owner of Channel One and Lifetime Learning Systems, was recently the prime organizer of a drive among New York City publishers to donate a million reading books to New York City school children, according to Lisa Belzberg, president of Pencil, the nonprofit group that coordinated the effort.
Last March, Sun Microsystems coordinated about 200 companies and 20,000 volunteers in California for "Net Day," wiring schools around the state for the Internet. The concept caught on state by state.
John Gage, Sun's chief science officer and Net Day's architect, said the only "strategic" interest for Sun -- whose Java programming language is used by Internet software developers -- is in getting "smart employees" in the future. Still, on the "Net Day 96" page that Mr. Gage created for the event on the World Wide Web, he listed some "self-serving" reasons other companies might want to ante up for some $500 wiring kits or devote some time to the project: everything from "good public relations" and morale-building among employees to possible "benefits later" (wiring-maintenance contracts, for example).
But there are problems with projects like Net Day, said Professor Molnar, who cautioned against its use as a model for improving education.
"Who's going to criticize a bunch of people rolling up their sleeves and wiring a school?" he said. "But why should that be a way that schools get on the Internet? It's crazy public policy to have a school system that relies on individual acts of good will."
Are students in needy schools ultimately helped by businesses that sponsor free curriculum guides or even out-and-out advertising?
Some of the sponsored teaching materials are not commercial, according to Consumers Union, the Yonkers, N.Y.-based advocacy group, but they are the exceptions.
In "Captive Kids: A Report on Commercial Pressures on Kids at School," published in 1995, Consumers Union evaluated more than 75 of these learning materials. Nearly 80 percent, it found, were biased in favor of the sponsor's product. And more than half were deemed "commercial" (with prominently displayed logos or product promotions) or "highly commercial" (defined as "basically an ad").
Some teachers avoid using sponsored educational materials altogether.
"A lot of it I look at and toss," said Dan Otter, a fifth-grade teacher at McKinley Elementary School in Corona, Calif., about 65 miles east of Los Angeles.
Others find it helpful to have other sources to consider.
"I just really appreciate having it available; it beefs up my curriculum," said Pamela Smith, who also teaches fifth grade at McKinley.
Ms. Smith said she still uses art activities she picked up from a Crayola packet more than eight years ago. And every year, she teaches a food unit using materials from the California Dairy Council. "It's not at all heavy on the dairy side," she said. "It's a balanced approach."
This year she is using a teaching unit sent by another trade group, the Mushroom Council. "It's not commercial," she said, adding that she is alert to the possibility of promotion. "If something came over my desk that was more commercial than educational I wouldn't use it, because I won't advertise in my classroom."
The sponsors and developers of these learning kits argue that their materials have real education value.
"The materials are strictly educational," said Karen Kafer, a spokeswoman for Kellogg, though they occasionally show products that "fit with the message." She added that Kellogg's materials follow nutritional guidelines recommended by the American Heart Association. Roberta Nusim, director of Youth Marketing International, which developed the Casper and Little Engine That Could materials, defends the materials' educational content as well. "Entertainment is very much part of our culture," she said. "Why not use what our children are interested in to teach them?" And Mr. Kinsley, of Lifetime Learning says that a recent kit developed for Fine Line Productions' new movie "Twelfth Night" discusses Shakespearean character development.
At the same time, the developers' own promotional materials, aimed at potential sponsors, tend to talk about "product awareness" and "consumer recall." And Ms. Halpin of Saatchi & Saatchi noted that if material has been "paid for by the marketer for the purpose of getting kids' eyeballs on it, it's marketing for kids."
(The Read-A-Logo software, developed for teachers by Tony Domenech, president of Teacher Support Software in Gainesville, Fla., was not sponsored by advertisers. Mr. Domenech defends its "rebus" reading method, which uses corporate logos instead of some words. "We can be more effective teachers if we teach from what the child knows," he said.)
The Society for Consumer Professionals in Business, whose membership comes from corporate consumer affairs departments, has issued a set of guidelines for their members' sponsored materials that say such learning guides should be accurate, objective and non-commercial -- with no logos or brand-names in the text or illustrations.
T HE National Education Association has also passed a similar, "Preserve Classroom Integrity," pledge.
But such guidelines are just recommendations.
Mr. Fege of the National P.T.A. said that his group "has a strong position that whatever material is used in the school, it should go through a public adoption process." Does that happen? "Absolutely not," he said.
Now some educators, public school advocates and even sponsored-curriculum developers say it is time for these materials to be regulated by school authorities, preferably at the district level. And such regulations should have teeth, they say.
"I don't blame businesses for putting out a business spin," said Diane Berreth, deputy executive director of the Association for Supervision and Curriculum Development in Washington, a group representing teachers, principals and school superintendents. "It's incumbent on educators to have policies for review."
Young students, especially, need protection, some educators say. Mr. Miller, the writer and former editor of the Harvard Education Letter, said that promotional materials and in-school advertising raise some basic developmental and psychological questions. "I think it's pretty bad when it comes to young children," he said. "It's insupportable, because the developmental truth about children is that in the early years, the elementary grades, they are simply not able to look analytically and critically at things like advertising and separate out a commercial message. A young child inherently believes in the authority of adults."
But there is also concern about older students. Parents were furious in October 1994, when two representatives of Eli Lilly, which makes Prozac, spoke at an assembly devoted to depression at Walter Johnson High School in Bethesda, Md. After the scheduled speaker, a psychiatrist, failed to arrive, the Lilly duo talked, in part, about how medication (but not Prozac specifically) could help depression. They also gave out Prozac pens, pads and brochures to the students. (The two were disciplined, an Eli Lilly spokesman said, and the company subsequently apologized to the high school.)
Meanwhile, in Seattle, debate is focusing on the planned advertising contracts.
"Our financial situation is forcing us to be entrepreneurial," said John Stanford, the city's superintendent of schools, when he introduced the measure. "If we were getting what we should be getting from the state legislature, we wouldn't be looking at this kind of approach."
THE advertising initiative is sorely needed, said Mr. Olchefske, the district's chief financial officer, because Seattle's 97 schools and 47,000 students are currently losing $35 million in state funds over a three-year period -- 12 percent of the system's annual budget.
"We've already cut custodians; classrooms only get cleaned once every third day," he said. "And we've reduced funding for special-needs kids -- tutoring programs and that sort of thing. And there are more cuts to come."
For Ed Reed, a math teacher at Seattle's Washington Middle School, more cuts seem unimaginable. Already, he hustles for the most basic equipment in his classes, collecting filing cabinets from Boeing. "And some extra chairs -- we had a record number of kids this year, and I had kids standing in the classroom," he said.
Mr. Reed has also received a donation of basic arithmetic calculators from G.T.E., but he points out that "in the suburban systems, the kids are working in math with graphic calculators." He supports the new advertising policy, and is making his wish list for the funds that might come in. At the top: more math teachers, to reduce class sizes in his department.
But Brita Butler-Wall, a parent of two public school children and an official of the Seattle council of parent-teacher groups, said she completely opposed the plan.
"No matter how low-key it is, it is fundamentally wrong," said Ms. Butler-Wall, who organized a community meeting about the new policy on Dec. 6, a few weeks after it was passed. (About 120 people attended, mostly those opposed to the policy). "I'd rather have my child go to a school with very little in the way of activities -- but with integrity -- than have sports, music, whatever, with a McDonald's label on it."
Even if the school district did make $1 million each year from the ads, she said, how much impact can it have on a $35 million shortfall over the next three years? It may turn out that in the end there is not much difference in class size or teacher salaries, she said. Instead, "we may just end up with a lot of ads."
Darnell Edmon and Ahmed King, both seniors at Seattle's Middle College High School, which has many lower-income students, also oppose the initiative. "Shouldn't schools be the one place we can get away from advertisements?" Mr. Edmon asked. Mr. King added that he feared the move would have "a domino effect. First the Nike cheerleaders, next thing you know, it'll be the Nike school."

HEADLINE: On Campus;
Fighting the Rankings of a College Guide

BYLINE: By Peter Applebome; Peter Applebome is the national education correspondent for The New York Times.

 BODY:
An unlikely revolt of students against grades -- not their own, but the ones their colleges and universities get from a national magazine -- is becoming a cause celebre on a growing number of campuses.
 At its root is a simple question: Does U.S. News & World Report provide a useful consumer service each year with its closely watched numerical ranking of the nation's colleges and universities, or does it deliver a cynical, misleading product whose main contribution is to the magazine's bottom line? 
 The dispute also touches on the broader topic of how best to judge and measure the quality of a university education and how to make sure parents and prospective students get helpful, accurate information about one of the biggest financial and personal decisions they will ever make.
 At the center of the dispute is U.S. News's annual "America's Best Colleges" guide -- the best-selling one in the nation -- which gives a numerical ranking to 1,422 accredited four-year schools. Among them are 400 national universities and liberal arts colleges. The ranking has become a huge annual event, but one that is widely reviled by many educators and students, who say ranking colleges and universities like toasters or football teams does more harm than good.
 So far, student governments of the university systems of California and Oklahoma and at least 17 other colleges and universities, from Stanford to the University of Pennsylvania, have passed resolutions asking U.S. News to halt the numerical ranking. They argue that the ranking is misleading and inaccurate and that it contributes to a kind of status hysteria that is undermining the real goals of higher education in the United States. Fifty to 100 other campuses are debating the issue.
 Many university administrators credit U.S. News with being careful, diligent and flexible enough to make its rankings as fair as possible. But even so, many say it is impossible to rank universities in any meaningful way, and that the U.S. News ratings have become prime culprits in turning the choice of a college from an essentially educational issue to a high-stakes economic and social transaction.
 "We don't like to see education reduced to a horse race, which is essentially what this amounts to," said Fiona Rose, student government president at the University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, which recently passed a resolution condemning the rankings.
 Schools that have passed similar resolutions include the University of California, Berkeley, Smith College, Rice University, the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and Wesleyan University.
In December U.S. News met with a group of students critical of the rankings and says it has consistently worked with university administrators to improve its system.
 "We're very forthright that the ranking should be used only as one tool to help someone make an informed decision," said Bruce Zanca, director of communications for U.S. News. "It's something we do for our readers to help put in context in a reader-friendly, digestible form this huge amount of data and information."
 Guidebooks, including ones that broadly rank universities in categories like "most selective," "very selective" and "selective," have long been part of the process in which high school students consider colleges.
 But in recent years the guidebooks have proliferated, and none have prospered more than U.S. News's. The magazine bills its rankings as the "No. 1 Selling College Guide." Its latest issue with the rankings had newsstand sales 56 percent above the norm.. In addition, the magazine sells about a million copies of its paperback book version of the college guide.
 The U.S. News rankings are based on a number of factors. The single biggest factor -- academic reputation -- is based on surveys sent to 4,200 college presidents, deans and admissions directors, who are asked to rate schools in the same category (like regional liberal arts colleges) as their own. Academic quality counts for 25 percent of the total ranking. Other categories include selectivity, faculty resources, financial resources, retention (graduation rate), alumni giving and "value added" -- the school's record of graduating students, this time taking into account their backgrounds and entering qualifications. Then the ratings are converted to a score, with 100 at the top and many schools separated by only 0.1 or 0.2 of a point.
 The magazine gets most of the information from the colleges and universities, but says it uses computer analysis and comparisons with information given to financial rating services, like Moody's and Standard & Poors, to cross-check data provided by the schools.
 The current revolt against the ranking began at Stanford University, which U.S. News this year ranks the sixth-best national university, behind Yale, Princeton, Harvard, Duke and M.I.T.
 Nick Thompson, a Stanford senior, helped form the "Forget U.S. News Coalition," or FUNC, which helped mobilize attention elsewhere. Students initially considered asking their universities to withhold data from U.S. News, but decided the approach was unrealistic because of the fear that schools would be penalized in the rankings.
 And Gerhard Casper, president of Stanford, has been among the most outspoken university administrators criticizing the magazine. In fact, the stinging memo he wrote to the new U.S. News Editor, James Fallows, in September, has made the rounds of university administrators around the country as the most succinct statement of the case against the rankings.
 "I hope I have the standing to persuade you that much about these rankings -- particularly their specious formulas and spurious precision -- is utterly misleading," Mr. Casper wrote in September to Mr. Fallows. Prior to becoming the editor of U.S. News this fall, Mr. Fallows himself emerged as a prominent media critic by lambasting the media's excessive focus on so-called "horse race" journalism.
 Critics say the ratings are arbitrary and favor private institutions over public ones. In his letter, Mr. Casper cited the lack of logic in ranking a school like Johns Hopkins University as the 22d-best national university two years ago, the 10th-best last year and the 15th-best this year. Similarly, he cited Harvard, which customarily places first in the ratings, but this year suddenly dropped to third. And he questioned why great public institutions like the University of Michigan or the University of California, Berkeley, could not crack U.S. News's top 20.
 And some students say the rankings are leading universities to adjust policies (or fudge figures) to please the rankers, and leadingstudents to pick a school based on its ranking rather than its suitablity.
 "We've had students come forward on the Internet, like one from Carnegie Mellon, who said he was miserable there, but was basically required to apply because it was the highest-ranked of the schools he could seriously consider," said Jebediah Purdy, a Harvard senior. "Any effort to quantify educational quality is going to be distortive and is going to end up leaving a lot of people less well matched and less well satisfied and less well educated than they ought to be."
 Other critics concede that they may be seen as griping about their own schools' ratings. They also acknowledge that students at the top-rated schools may see little incentive to complain.
 "It's obviously more difficult to get this passed at Yale, because the student body as a whole is not necessarily convinced that U.S. News is doing anything bad for them," said Phyllis Thompson, a senior at Yale, which placed first in this year's rankings.
 Mel Elfin, editor of the guide since its inception 10 years ago, said that the volatility in the rankings reflects the guide's willingness to listen to critics, and that the differences between the top schools are so small that focusing on the changes in numerical ranking misses the degree to which the rankings have been consistent and accurate. For instance, in the current rating of best national universities, Yale ranks first at 100.0, Princeton second at 99.8 and Harvard third at 99.6.
 "We've produced a list that puts Harvard, Yale and Princeton, in whatever order, at the top," Mr. Elfin said. "This is a nutty list? Something we pulled out of the sky?"
 Instead, he said, the changes reflect the magazine's willingness to fine-tune its ratings, while giving readers a product they obviously want.
 "When you buy a VCR for 200 bucks, you can buy Consumer Reports to find out what's out there," he said. "When you spend 100 grand on four years of college, you should have some independent method of comparing different colleges. That's what our readers want, and they've voted at the newsstand in favor of what we're doing."
 Still, while few administrators want to criticize U.S. News too publicly, and many feel the information in the report is valuable, they also say that the rankings do more harm than good.
 "I wish these rankings would go away," said an administrator at one university in the magazine's top 10, who asked not to be identified, "because in the final analysis, they generate more heat than light. Parents and students need more information, but the ratings just produce more anxiety."
 A broader concern is for the accuracy of the information in the various rating guides. Arthur J. Rothkopf of Lafayette College in Easton, Pa., has spearheaded an effort to develop standardized questions and criteria to make sure that colleges accurately report comparable data to guidebooks, including the one by U.S. News. An article in the Wall Street Journal in 1995 detailed the ways colleges manipulated the data they provided to guidebooks, often excluding large numbers of academically poor or foreign students from their statistics in order to inflate performance.
 Mr. Rothkopf, too, thinks U.S. News's rankings are too misleading to be valuable.
 "This is consumer information, and people make very important decisions based on it," he said. "They ought to have accurate information and be able to view a level playing field."
 A ranking of the rankings has also been critical of U.S. News.
Alma College in Alma, Mich.,recently released what it said was a survey of 158 college administrators, who ranked U.S. News's last in quality among college guidebooks, giving it a paltry 1.97 -- a C- -- on a 4.0 scale.
 Some 90 percent of respondents said the magazine's ranking was important, but only 7.6 percent surveyed said it was the one that most accurately described their school.
 Mr. Fallows, who notes that the rankings preceded his tenure as editor, said that he is eager to meet with critics. He declined to comment on whether the magazine was open to doing away with the numerical rankings.
 But Mr. Zanca said: "I'd never say never, but I don't see us stepping away from the numerical rankings. It's something our readers expect from us."
