SECTION: Section 4A; Page 35; Column 1; Education Life Supplement 

LENGTH: 2165 words

HEADLINE: BURNING MIDNIGHT OIL, NOT THE SAUCE

BYLINE: By ERIC ASIMOV; Eric Asimov writes the $25 and Under restaurant reviews for The Times.

 BODY:
With perhaps the most famous surname in culinary history, you might assume that Garry Escoffier Jr. was born to be a chef. In fact, Mr. Escoffier, 25, cooks West Indian food by day at Joy's Cafe in Brooklyn. But by night, after grabbing a full two and a halfhours of sleep, Mr. Escoffier goes after something more. He travels to downtown Manhattan to attend the late-night Culinary Skills Program at the New York Restaurant School, where the philosophy is that chefs are made, not born.
"What I cook is just the bottom of the horizon," said Mr. Escoffier, who, as far he knows, is no relation to the revered French cooking god Auguste Escoffier. "I want to work in large restaurants where I can learn many different styles of cooking." 
 Of more than 1,000 students enrolled this year at the restaurant school, almost 200 are in the night program, learning how to dice onions and whisk a hollandaise from 11 P.M. to 6 A.M., four nights a week, hours once reserved for third-shift toilers and insomniacs. The figure seems even more surprising considering that the overnight classes -- possibly the only such program in the country -- began just four years ago, directed at maybe a couple dozen people a year who were already in the restaurant industry and looking for further training.
"It evolved into something different," said Stephen Tave, the school's director of admissions. "It was pretty unbelievable to see how many students could function all night in school, and some of them even hold jobs during the day."
In fact, quite a few of them do, like Melissa Gowan, 33, who works full time as a photographer and has two children, 10 and 14. She says she can squeak by on one and a half hours of sleep a day. "Sometimes I come in here like a zombie," she said. "But you do what you have to do. I really want to work in a restaurant."
A lot of people do, and the demand for restaurant workers is growing rapidly. According to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, the number of people working as cooks in restaurants has risen by 59 percent in 12 years, from about 452,000 in 1983 to 714,000 in 1995.
"There is a tremendous demand for these graduates," Mr. Tave said. "Our placement rates are over 90 percent."
Those rates are in line with other such training schools. The Culinary Institute of America in Hyde Park, N.Y., for example, generally places 92 to 94 percent of its graduates. For 1,000 graduates last year, 7,000 cooking, baking and management jobs were available, said Ray Wells, the institute's director of career services.
This prospect of steady, interesting work drives the students to pay the $11,106 tuition, which is slightly less expensive than the day classes'. Most of the students take out loans or have some form of assistance.
About 60 other students joined Mr. Escoffier and Ms. Gowan in the late-night program on a recent Tuesday night. They filed into the school, situated 16 floors above Canal Street, around 11 P.M. to attend one of the night's three classes, each at a different stage of the nine-month-long curriculum.
Fueled by caffeine and ambition, they spent the next seven hours in one of the school's five teaching kitchens, trying to master skills, from the rock-bottom basic (holding a knife properly) to the sublime (the proper construction of the classic French sauces) to the ridiculous (sculpting pates and mousses into fish or a row of tumbled dominoes, garnished by flowers carved from carrots and squash).
Their first step was to change into uniform: a white double-breasted jacket, black-and-white checked pants, an apron and a white paper toque. The uniform requirement is not only practical for the kitchen, but also helps to instill reverence for the work, as does the respectful title "Chef" by which students are required to address their instructors.
Some of those in the classes are, like Mr. Escoffier, already in the food industry, but feeling stuck in their jobs. They are hoping that the certificate of completion given at the end of the course will be their ticket upward.
"There's such a hierarchy of corporate ownership that I get lost in the shuffle without any sort of certification," said Mitchell Schnee, 25, as he chopped onions and carrots in Chef Brendan Sheehan's section, which this night was focusing on sauces. Mr. Schnee is already a chef at O'Doyle's, a steakhouse with a medieval theme in Jersey City. His ambition is to own his own place in five years.
"I already know the theme, the decor and the menu, and now I have five years to get funding," he said of the restaurant he envisions, which he wants to call the Enchanted Dreams Cafe. "I enjoy mystical and magical things," he said, displaying a tattoo of a unicorn on his forearm. Mr. Schnee said he was lucky to get three hours' sleep a night, but was willing to pay the price. "I have a burning desire to excel," he said.
Though Chef Sheehan's class began in October, the students, who were divided into three- and four-person teams, moved with methodical efficiency, as if they had been in the kitchen for years. The scene was much different in a neighboring kitchen in Chef Gregory Dalton's section, which began just a few weeks before. There are no restaurant professionals in Chef Dalton's class; just restaurant ambitions.
"I always liked cooking, and I understand it's a profitable medium," said Andre Greenberg, 35, as he sat at a big table, going over his notes on recipe conversion before class began. He said that his routine of going directly from class to his job as a maintenance worker for the Park Service was rough, but that he was hoping for a payoff.
The schedule was not as difficult for his classmate Joe Aversa, 39, who said he's loved cooking his whole life. "Recently I got lucky and lost my job," said Mr. Aversa, who had been in sales. "I'm looking at this as an opportunity."
Unemployment had also given him the chance to catch up on his sleep, unlike Simon Kim, 28, who puts in time at his family's dry-cleaning establishment in the Bronx during the day. Mr. Kim, who attended the Fashion Institute of Technology, said he couldn't find a steady job in the fashion industry and was hoping to learn specific skills that he could fall back on. "I never cooked in my life before," he said. "I burn eggs."
Mr. Kim still hadn't cooked. In the few weeks since his section began, Chef Dalton had covered the subjects of professionalism, food safety, sanitation and equipment. Scattered around the table were bags of potato chips, candy bars and cans of Coca-Cola. Clearly, nutrition was a topic for future discussion. On this night the subject was knife skills, not necessarily what any sensible person wants to be experimenting with late at night with an artificially heightened attention span.
"I'm not a coffee drinker, but I'm drinking six or seven cups a day," said Mr. Kim, his knee jiggling as he sat on a stool before class. "It makes me very nervous."
But Chef Dalton was prepared. "I've got my little boo-boo bag right here," he told the class in his stentorian voice, pointing to his first-aid kit and warning them that cuts were inevitable in the kitchen. "These things happen," he said. "It's like getting on a bicycle."
As Chef Dalton segued into his discussion of knives, the students reached into sturdy black nylon equipment bags, which they'd been issued on admission, along with a full set of equipment, the chef's uniform, black steel-toed shoes and a 1,080 page textbook, "On Cooking," by Sarah R. Labensky and Alan M. Hause (Prentice Hall, 1995). There are daily homework assignments and frequent quizzes.
A student who had forgotten his apron was given a lecture on professionalism by Chef Dalton. "Remember what I said about mise en place!" he said, using the French term for the proper assembling of all equipment and ingredients. "Come to class prepared!"
He lectured the class in a voice of absolute authority, like John Wayne building a platoon of marines in basic training. In fact, like marines who must learn to operate as a team in a matter of weeks, the students must cram into nine months a base of knowledge that used to be acquired through years of apprenticeship in restaurant kitchens. "Keep your street stuff and lingo out on the street," he ordered one student, who had begun to strut with his knife. "Here we're professionals."
He dressed down another student who arrived unprepared, like the platoon cut-up. "You're gonna bring your knives from now on. Your knives, your apron, your toque. Mise en place! Or you'll be sent home."
It was easy to tell the newer students, like those in Chef Dalton's class, from the veterans: their uniforms were spotless. In Scott Keats's class on the presentation of pates, mousses, terrines and the like, the uniforms of the students who began in September were stained and creased. But their spirits were as high as the new students'.
"It's tough but I love it," said Denzel Richards, 38, a cable-television installer by day, who said he manages on four hours of sleep a night. "Ultimately, I'd like to get into catering."
Atiyah Watson, 20, of Staten Island, was not exactly clear on what she wanted out of the course, though she knew exactly why she was in it.
"I was kind of a party fanatic, so now my mother knows where I am," she said, as she teamed with Mr. Richards to make a roasted tomato coulis. Chef Keats stopped to advise her on applying olive oil to the split tomatoes on a roasting pan, and he examined Mr. Richards's vegetable pate. "Very nice, excellent job," he said.
Ms. Gowan, the photographer, said that she's tried the day classes, but prefers the night course because it draws a more dedicated brand of people. "It's a big group effort," she said, as she meticulously carved a carrot into rabbit ears to use as a garnish. "People have to work together, and they are closer."
Myra Turpin, 35, who works in the cookware department at Bloomingdale's, agreed. "You're only here if you really love it," she said as she carved a carrot into a sunflower to garnish her seafood mousseline. "Who else would be here at 1:15 in the morning?"
Another enthusiast is Karim Thornhill, 22, who had just finished the meticulous preparation work in Chef Sheehan's sauce class. "I love coming here, I think about it all the time," said Mr. Thornhill, who was unemployed. "Being a chef is the best thing in the world you could do. It's fun, you meet people, it's teamwork."
Back in Chef Dalton's class on knife skills, the platoon mentality was still building.
"I want all of you to give your knife a name," he said. "It's your best friend. If you have good knife skills, you will never be without a job."
Such motivation made some of the students a little enthusiastic. "Hey, that's not a sword!" Chef Dalton told one as he led the class through the rocking motion of basic chopping. "Now, some of you are going to develop blisters. I suggest you just let it go. It's part of life in the kitchen."
So are cuts, the class was reminded, after Chemin Terrero, 19, sliced his thumb. "It's not going to discourage me at all," he said, clutching the bandage that Mr. Dalton had applied. "I'm going to fight the good fight."
Mr. Terrero, from Brooklyn, was unemployed, but he said he sees his future clearly. "I was a confused individual, but now, I want to be a chef," he said. "I just hope I don't bleed to death."
Just a few weeks before, Sean Reed, 26, was himself learning how to use a knife. But now, in Mr. Sheehan's sauce class, he was slicing his way through a tray of roasted tomatoes with verve and elan.
Mr. Reed, a musician, said he was planning on moving to Paris after the course, where he hoped to stay with a friend and intern in a restaurant. "I'm a little nervous," he said. "The French are known for their cooking, and I don't want to make any mistakes."
Of course, mistakes are as much a part of the kitchen as they are anywhere else, a point Chef Sheehan made as he introduced the class to the pantheon of French sauces. The names -- bechamel, veloute, sauce Robert -- whizzed by as the chef demonstrated each, along with methods for recovery if the sauce is too liquid, for example. Each student took a taste before moving on to the next sauce.
In Chef Keats's class on pate displays, the students had already ingested the idea that they will make mistakes. "As Chef told us, you don't leave here as a chef, you leave ready to rise," said Rogesta Chisholm. "I can accept that."
It was 4 A.M., and the class was near its culmination as the students laid out the displays of mousses and pates on mirrored surfaces layered with gelatin. Gazing at a seafood mousseline molded into the shape of salmon, Denzel Richards could not contain his enthusiasm. "This is the reason why I come here!" he said. "This is how you make the money."
Ms. Gowan, though, could barely stifle a yawn. "You get used to it," she said. "On weekends when everybody else is sleeping, I sit up watching TV all night."

HEADLINE: Sunday January 5, 1997;
QUESTIONS FOR: Sherman Alexie

 BODY:

Sherman Alexie, a 30-year-old Spokan-Coeur d'Alene Indian, was named among the "Best of the Young American Novelists" by Granta last summer. His latest book is "Indian Killer."

Q: In "Indian Killer," white men in Seattle are cut down by a murderer, possibly Indian, whose identity we never learn. One victim is stabbed repeatedly, eye-gouged and scalped. Why have you been hailed for the type of graphic violence that got Bret Easton Ellis into so much trouble?

A: Ellis took no moral stance about any of it. In my book, everybody is guilty of something. People have said I vilify whites and make Indians so heroic and sympathetic, but the Indians are screwed up, too. 

Q: True, but you're clearly pretty angry with whites, especially ones who try to "connect" by immersing themselves in Indian culture. How would you have whites treat modern Indians?

A: No. 1, recognize that we are sovereign entities, with absolute political, social and economic rights on our land. No. 2, that's all I care about. Other than that, leave our culture alone.

Q: You perform on your own blues C.D. Since blues is a black cultural form, isn't that cultural appropriation?

A: The C.D. is Indian blues. There's a difference. I am trying to be Crazy Horse with a slide guitar.

HEADLINE: Sunday January 5, 1997: YOU ARE THERE;
A Town That Needs Pity

 BODY:
When asked to define what ails their hometown, residents of Lefors, Tex. -- a dusty Panhandle burg of 652 people -- tend to cite the flat local economy and the flatter landscape. Whatever the cause, serious worries about Lefors's future last year prompted Norman Baxter, the local school superintendent (pictured below), to propose a public-land giveaway. The prize: 14 small city-owned lots, winners to be chosen from a national lottery. Conditions: To claim their land, victors would simply have to live on it. Outcome: Discouraging. Since the November drawing, only five of the winners have accepted ... tentatively. Can Lefors really be that bad? We sent a native Texan to find out.
The Overview Virginia Maples and Ben Watson, cheerful city officials both, provide the get-acquainted tour on a chilly Saturday, pointing out local sights like the town cemetery and the bleak, weedy giveaway lots. Lefors's "urban core" consists of a small grid of streets, a few civic buildings and a business or two, and there's not much residential scenery. Trees are eerily fixed in a brushed-back sweep thanks to punishing prairie winds; old tires dot trailer-home roofs. "As you can see, it's ... it's kind of trashy," Watson says. Maples winces. "I mean, that's just being honest about it. But you can go in and clean these old houses up." True, and the prices are hard to beat. Watson's four-bedroom home cost $12,000. "There just isn't any other place in this country," he says, "where you would pay that." 
 Shopping The fluorescent-lighted Taylor E-Z Serve, on Second Street, is a greasy spoon, gas station and convenience store all in one. It is also Lefors's only store. Inside, Carol Preston and Jo Wilemon, outfitted in the E-Z's baby-blue smocks, talk up the town. "It's a nice, quiet, peaceful place," Wilemon says. "You don't lock your door, you don't take keys out of your car." "Yes," Preston concurs, then pauses. Then they both reach the same conclusion and declare together: "And it's only 12 miles to the Wal-Mart in Pampa!"
Family Values Boyd's Garage is a Main Street fixture owned by Derl Boyd, 66, a former Texaco employee. The area's oil and gas business went away in the 80's and never came back, and the men gathered here believe that the sluggish economy is Lefors's worst plague."This damn plan they got to give away land won't work -- there's no jobs," says H. R. Cates, 72. Dennis Boyd, Derl's 42-year-old son, notes that, all the same, Lefors is a good place to raise children and offers "quiet" fun, like community barbecues. "It used to be a fun town," Cates scoffs. "We had bars, whorehouses, all that stuff. Then the town went dry because all the drinkers were drinking instead of voting!"
Night Life Over at J. C. Curley's gas station, at the corner of Second and Main, a gaggle of old-timers agree that the economy stinks, but blame "the Baptists" just as much. In 1965, religious teetotalers pushed through a city law banning the sale of liquor and beer. Discussing the nonexistent local night life, the cantankerous R. C. McPherson, 83, says, "The pool halls left and the churches stayed." Curley agrees, saying that what Lefors really needs is a good, stiff civic drink. Lots of them. "We used to have two little bars, a picture show, three pretty big grocery stores and, gosh, I don't know, I think four service stations," he says in a nasal yelp. "I'd vote a hundred times to make it 'wet' again, and I don't even drink. That would definitely help."

SECTION: Section 7; Page 20; Column 3; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 975 words

HEADLINE: Crime

BYLINE: By Marilyn Stasio 

 BODY:
Piece of cake. That's what Michael Connelly makes it look like in his terrific new police procedural, TRUNK MUSIC (Little, Brown, $23.95), when a Los Angeles loser named Tony Aliso pops up dead in the trunk of his car. Aliso was a nonplayer ("probably the last guy in Hollywood who hadn't traded in his Rolls on a Range Rover") who laundered dirty money through his soft-core movie company, and his execution-style murder has all the earmarks of a mob hit. Case closed. Finito. Yawn.
The thing is, Harry Bosch, the L.A.P.D. homicide detective who is the headstrong hero of this bruising action series, doesn't like all the loose ends in the case, especially the ones snaking back to certain law enforcement agencies. He heads for Las Vegas, where Aliso had connections, and disrupts so many criminal transactions that he makes everybody's hit list, including the F.B.I.'s. Targeted as "this year's Mark Fuhrman," Harry goes rogue. 
 Like his righteous cop, Mr. Connelly looks for God in the details. (Watch what he does with a tube of Preparation H.) Every procedure comes with a diagram, every body blow has a follow-up and every grifter on the strip is frisked for some colorful piece of personal history. Harry doesn't much go for Vegas ("Out here in the desert, he was a fish out of water, flopping on the sand"). But after the initial culture shock, he's in his element.
That notorious misogynist Sherlock Holmes speaks uncommonly well of Mary Russell in Laurie R. King's smartly researched and thoroughly enjoyable historical mystery A LETTER OF MARY (Thomas Dunne/St. Martin's, $23.95). In the eyes of her doting mentor, this emancipated woman is "a brilliant young star on the horizon of academic theology." But then, the great man could be prejudiced. He is, after all, married to her.
After meeting in "The Beekeeper's Apprentice" and mating in "A Monstrous Regiment of Women," the oddly matched pair have settled down by 1923 to a life of dull respectability in Sussex. Here they are paid a visit by a female archeologist who leaves with them an ancient Greek papyrus supposedly written by Mary Magdalene, who calls herself "a lost apostle of Jesus of Nazareth." When someone murders the archeologist and tries to steal this extraordinary artifact, the couple take up the chase in London, where the political climate is fraught with intrigue. Between the Zionists on their soapboxes and the academic subversives in their libraries, the air is thick with spies. For all the disparity of their investigative techniques, the ultra-perceptive Holmes and the super-scholarly Russell make an engaging pair of sleuths. Their quick minds and quirky personalities insure a lively adventure in the very best of intellectual company.
Have you ever heard of "a kind of Scottish mafia at the top of some U.S. businesses, persuading people to locate in Scotland"? Me neither; but Ian Rankin makes a good case for this shadowy presence in LET IT BLEED (Simon & Schuster, $21), another top-notch procedural in a brooding series featuring his Edinburgh police inspector, John Rebus.
According to his wife, Rebus is an Old Testament moralist ("Retribution rather than rehabilitation") of classic Calvinist stock ("Let the punishment fit the crime, and then some"). Even his friends call him "the eternal pessimist." All of which makes this dour detective a charming companion on a gloomy case that opens with the messy deaths of two young punks who take a flyer off the Forth Road Bridge and develops into a complex tale of industrial conspiracy and political collusion. With all these problems, Rebus also has to deal with the pitiless climate of Edinburgh, where a freezing wind blows sideways, the better to cut your face. The bleakness is unrelenting, but it quite suits Mr. Rankin, who does his best work in the dark.
Can it be? Charles Paris, the endearingly unemployable actor who plays the "cynical old ham" in Simon Brett's acerbic theater mysteries, has an actual job. A good job, too. SICKEN AND SO DIE (Scribner, $21) finds Charles typecast as that "crafty drunkard" Sir Toby Belch in a summer festival production of "Twelfth Night." In the same spirit of reclamation, he has also sworn off the sauce and reconciled with his wife.
Happily, our hero's reformation doesn't last long. The show's director falls ill at an Indian restaurant, and his replacement, Charles's old nemesis Alexandru Radulescu, reinterprets the play's theme ("sex, sex, sex") and proceeds to swamp the production in "sheer gratuitous gimmickry." More food poisonings further deplete the company ranks. Coincidence? Criminal sabotage? Cheap melodrama? Although Charles's sleuthing skills will never get him the lead in "An Inspector Calls," his theatrical wit is sharper than a serpent's tooth.
Laurali R. Wright draws pretty views of Sechelt, the little village on Vancouver's Sunshine Coast where Sgt. Karl Alberg keeps the watch. The best scenes in STRANGERS AMONG US (Scribner, $21), however, are set against the inner landscape of troubled minds. The sun doesn't shine for anyone in this disquieting suspense thriller: not for 14-year-old Eliot Gardener, who hacked his father and mother to death with a machete; not for Jack Coutts, who is haunted by the memory of his only child, killed by her crazed mother; and certainly not for Alberg, whose soul is weighted with guilt from having failed to intervene in time to help these desperate people.
Ms. Wright works in subtle ways to connect these individual stories. She creates a sense of urgency by letting Eliot escape from a child detention center, and she escalates the tension by giving Coutts a gun and a grudge against Alberg. But the true drama is a psychological one, a tale of remorse and redemption that is played out on private stages, in those secret places where people go quietly mad.

LENGTH: 1190 words

HEADLINE: Trade You a Wedding for a Hair Transplant?

BYLINE: By GITTA MORRIS 

 BODY:
BARTERED babies? It's not the headline-screaming scandal it sounds. For John and Shari Atwater of Hartford, who had no health insurance, it was the perfect solution. Mr. Atwater swapped the services of his auto body business for his wife's obstetrical care.
"Babies cost a lot of money," he explained. "When it comes out of pocket, it hurts." The couple's second child, due in April, will also be a bartered baby, and the Atwaters hope they can barter the hospital bill as well. 
 Frederick Rau, the Hartford doctor who delivered the Atwaters' first baby, believes his group is the first medical practice in the barter books.
"We've done three deliveries on barter, and we have 10 other barter clients," he said. "It makes sense. There are a lot of people among the 37 million Americans who don't have health insurance, but who have skills they can barter."
His group has bartered its services for catering, recarpeted an office and room at a restaurant for its Christmas party.
People have bartered goods and services probably since the beginning of time, but in the past two decades, particularly through the use of computers, the practice has flourished anew.
Last year, 250,000 companies traded an estimated $1.8 billion worth of goods and services through more than 400 barter networks according to the National Association of Trade Exchanges.
Among small businesses, bartering has grown an estimated 10 percent a year since the early 1980's, and an estimated 65 percent of the Fortune 500 companies barter.
Mr. Atwater and Dr. Rau belong to Barter Business Unlimited, a Hartford-based company that acts as matchmaker, bringing together buyers and sellers on a debit and credit basis. For a $195 fee and 12 percent commission from the purchaser, it negotiates price and functions as accountant and banker, keeping track of each client's barter activity and reporting all transactions to the Internal Revenue Service for tax purposes.
That the concept has caught on big in Connecticut was obvious recently when some 1,600 members swarmed Barter Business Unlimited's sixth annual Expo.
Bicycles, skin care products, motel rooms, dance lessons, sexy lingerie, puppies, massages, legal as well as architectural and dental services were selling like proverbial hotcakes, and not a penny of cash was exchanged. In fact, the entire Expo -- caterer, brewery, space -- was done on barter.
While his wife dove into a rack of fur coats, Ron Huard stood by patiently. "I think she has at least one fur coat already," he said with a shrug. The owner of Ron's Transmission Works in New Britain, he knew he could pay for another coat with his car repair bartering credits. He admitted, however, "You do have to watch yourself to keep from getting carried away."
Leon Skolnak, who owns Albe furs of Westport and Cos Cob, had sold four coats in the first couple of hours. "While the economy was so sluggish two or three years ago, bartering got to be big time," he said, hitting on a key theme. As a supplement, not a substitute, to regular cash business, bartering increases a company's working capital and helps to sell excess, slow-moving or close-out inventory without costly markdowns and liquidations, he said.
Pauline Schenck, who runs River Farms, a riding school in Avon, has been a member of Bartering Business Unlimited only since May, but is certainly a fan. "We had a summer camp coming up, and we bartered slots that would otherwise have gone unused," she explained. Her own bartering credits have been spent on having her dogs dipped for ticks, repairing the muffler on the farm truck and getting her copier fixed. "And we've been out for dinner three times," she added.
Restaurants, indeed, are a popular cash-in. "We used to eat it all," said Susan Thomas of Bristol, who offers Creative Parties for Kids. "And then I got smart. Now I barter for my dentists, my eye doctors, and last year I took my kids for a vacation on Cape Cod."
Michael Rose, trade director for the Fairfield division of Business Exchange International, claims his is the oldest and largest bargaining company in the country. Started 36 years ago, it has 105 offices around the United States, Canada, Australia and the Caribbean.
"We are very strong in networking with other offices," Mr. Rose said. "We may not have something in Connecticut, so we pick up the phone or go to the computer and find out if we have it in San Diego. For example, pallet jacks. Or a certain fabric that only a florist would use. We even have car dealerships. I bought my car completely on barter."
"And you can be very creative with it," he added. "Some of our offices have retailers who buy things on barter and sell it to their customers for cash. That's called cash conversion."
Mr. Rose warned, however, that for businesses that have a very small profit margin -- for example, appliance retailers -- bartering is not a good choice. On the other hand, services, particularly those that are labor intensive or have a high mark-up, do well. Hotels, where a number of rooms usually go begging, are an example of ideal bartering situation, he explained.
Most members plow their bartered windfall back into their business or use it to reward their employees, but others use it for personal treats. Barter Business Unlimited arranges a lot of bartered weddings, said Debbie Lombardi, who founded the company in 1992 after working for other barter exchanges. "You're talking everything," she said. "The flowers, the limo, the caterer. When someone calls and says they're getting married, we're so excited. It's second nature to us now."
Hair transplants are popular. So are media time and space as well as building services. Ms. Lombardi said that one company in Wethersfield that is moving and adding on, is bartering almost everything in that project -- the architect, electrical work and construction services as well as the advertising, printing and phone system for the new location.
One of the most intriguing trades, Ms. Lombardi recalled, took her company in a new direction. "We had a member who got hurt last year, and he owed the hospital to the tune of $20,000," she said. "It was really making his cash flow tighten up. We actually called the hospital, and we worked it out so he paid in barter."
Her company also does collections, she noted. "Let's say you're a corporation and you have a hard time collecting your money. Sometimes we can arrange to get it paid off by barter. So for some people, we've made the difference. We've kept them in business."
For many barterers, the experience is more than simply good business. Richard Goldwasser, a psychologist in Manchester and an enthusiastic member of Barter Business, Unlimited, thinks it's the camaraderie that makes bartering so appealing.
"I've met wonderful people. When you barter with people, your backgrounds are kind of the same," he explained.
"People who barter aren't conventional business people," he said. "They barter because they want to improve their business in more interesting ways. There's also trust. You just feel the person is going to do well by you."

SECTION: Section 9; Page 7; Column 1; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 1190 words

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Pittsburgh;
For a City's Icons, a Shrinking Hometown Presence

BYLINE: By CHRISS SWANEY 

DATELINE: PITTSBURGH

 BODY:
ONE after another over the years, major national industrial companies that grew to maturity in Pittsburgh -- including Gulf Oil and Koppers Corporation -- have moved away or reorganized or changed in a way that has shifted their business from the imposing downtown headquarters buildings that had housed them. Now, such concerns are being raised about the Westinghouse Electric Corporation.
Will Westinghouse's move into the media business lead it away from its 23-story, 420,000-square-foot headquarters building on the Monongahela River, its corporate base since 1970? Already it has reduced its presence at the building to 450 employees from about 1,000 in the early 70's. 
 Westinghouse owns the building, and despite rumors to the contrary, it insists that it has no plans to sell. In the last two months, it has begun to market the six floors of vacant space created by its shrinkage. Renny Clark, executive director of corporate services and community affairs, said that Westinghouse was spending $500,000 a floor to get the space ready for new tenants.
The path that Westinghouse is taking contrasts strikingly with the approach taken by Alcoa as it has trimmed its work force during the last two years. Alcoa had fully occupied a 31-story, 442,500-square-foot tower that it built for itself in 1952 on Sixth Avenue, a prime office location off Grant Street, the main downtown commercial street.
Now it is building a new $40 million 236,200-square-foot headquarters six stories high in Pittsburgh's North Side along the Allegheny River. The building is designed for only 450 employees. It is to be occupied in 1998.
At one time Alcoa had 2,000 employees in its headquarters building. Now it has 1,500. In the last two years Alcoa has been trying to sell the building, which it won't need at all after it occupies its new headquarters next year. But all the offers it received were well below its $18 million asking price.
Paul H. O'Neill, the chief executive, has suggested to his board that the building be donated to the city, for use by the region's several economic development groups. Pittsburgh is expected to tell Alcoa in February whether the gift would be accepted. But whether it is or is not, the building will be available for occupancy by next year.
The moves by Westinghouse and Alcoa come at a time when 25 million square feet of downtown office space is already on the market. The vacancy rate amounts to 16 percent, which is above the average of 14 percent for cities nationwide, according to the Pittsburgh office of Grubb & Ellis, the national real estate firm.
"No one is panicking yet," said R. J. Vulgris, director of research of Grubb & Ellis. "Office space is moving slowly now, and it's too early to tell about the effect of Alcoa and Westinghouse space coming on line."
ONE positive sign is that there was a slight improvement last year in net absorption over the year before, when the overall vacancy rate was 17.6 percent, Mr. Vulgris said. Net absorption is the difference between the amount of space leased and the amount given up through departures. Start-up computer companies, law offices and a variety of high-tech firms are the principal new lessees, brokers and consultants say.
Among the leases that helped the city's absorption figures was the growth of Blue Cross of Western Pennsylvania, which consolidated from several sites into the former Horne's department store on Penn Avenue. The old eight-story, 376,000-square-foot building was renovated by Blue Cross, which bought the property. Other major leases were the National City Bank of Pennsylvania, occupying 158,000 square feet of the former National Steel Building on Stanwix Street, and Harbison-Walker Refractories, taking 66,000 square feet at the USX Tower on Grant Street.
The changes at Westinghouse and Alcoa fall within a long tradition of real estate moves accompanying corporate shifts by blue-chip companies long identified with Pittsburgh.
The Koppers Corporation, an industrial products manufacturer, which was the target of a hostile takeover in 1988, today occupies only 15 percent of the 459,000-square-foot building on Grand Street that once was its headquarters. Koppers was taken over by Beazer P.L.C., a British construction concern, whose main operations are in Europe. Owned now by the Florida-based United Trust Fund, the structure is a general purpose office building, which is 80 percent occupied by lawyers and small service companies, according to real estate brokers.
Next door to the Koppers building is the former headquarters of the Gulf Oil Corporation, which was once among Pittsburgh's biggest employers. The Chevron Corporation, based in San Francisco, acquired Gulf in 1984. The oil company has no presence in the 44-story structure, though the building is still known in Pittsburgh as the Gulf Tower; it is now owned by A & E Stores Inc., a clothing chain owner based in New York City, It is 80 percent leased by Transarc, a computer software subsidiary of I.B.M.
WESTINGHOUSE has been identified with Pittsburgh since 1886, when George Westinghouse began manufacturing air brakes for the railroads. Over the years, the company not only built its headquarters in the city but also developed manufacturing plants for power-generation equipment, research laboratories, training centers and offices for support staff.
Westinghouse's long-term goal is to maintain its headquarters in the building, utilizing about 168,000 square feet, Mr. Clark said. At the same time, Westinghouse has been trying to dispose of many other properties.
The company's 138,000-square-foot training center about seven miles east of downtown is on the auction block, for example. The two-story brick building, along with 12.2 acres of undeveloped land, will be vacant in March 1997. In its heyday, it housed about 450 workers who worked on panel boards for nuclear power plants.
A technology center in the suburb of Churchill with a million square feet has been on the market for several months. A total of 180,000 square feet was taken by the Northrup Grumman Corporation only two months ago.
ALL these real-estate moves accompany Westinghouse's gradual withdrawal from its core business of industrial and consumer-appliance manufacturing, toward a new emphasis on media operations. Westinghouse bought the CBS last summer for $5.4 billion and is now spending $3.9 billion for the huge Infinity Broadcasting radio operation on its way to becoming primarily a media company. In the process, the company has dropped 25,000 employees worldwide since 1993, leaving about 77,800.
One advantage that the Westinghouse building will find in leasing out space is that there is a 450-car garage in the building. "Other large buildings don't have parking garages within the buildings," said Paul Horan, a broker with Grant Street Associates, which is marketing the property.
"We are marketing the Westinghouse building as a great location with easy access to major roads," Mr. Horan said. "But we may get some competition from the Alcoa building when it begins offering similar office space, too."

HEADLINE: Habitats/26 Beaver Street;
A Residential Beachhead In the Financial District

BYLINE: By TRACIE ROZHON 

 BODY:
THEY collect things, but unlike most collectors, they do not display them. Instead, they bring them out gradually, as they grow more comfortable with their visitors, opening drawers and cupboards and closets, producing their treasures like conjurers in front of a large audience.
"You're looking for a watch band?" asked John Yardley, eagerly, already rising from the black-and-white diamond-printed love seat in the center of the huge living room of the loft he and his wife recently purchased in the Financial District. "Come. Look." 
 The group of visitors dutifully followed Mr. Yardley into the bedroom while his wife, Bernice Gordon, stayed behind; she had seen this collection. Mr. Yardley, a tall, rugged-looking Englishman, pulled out the top three drawers of an Art Deco chest and -- presto, changeo -- flung them onto the bed.
A collection of watches! Old men's watches of every different description: watches with faces shaped like fans, with the numbers distorted to embrace the weird shape; standard tank watches, watches with amber faces, with Roman numerals, with no numerals, but tiny gold dots -- everything.
"I think I may have some watchbands here," he said. But the bands are never located, primarily because the watches themselves are so fascinating.
"You should see Bernice's watches," Mr. Yardley said. "Now those are really fine."
And so it goes. Mr. Yardley explained that he and Ms. Gordon, a lawyer, have pretty much given up collecting watches. They are now actively collecting ephemera, the collector's appellation for old paper things.
He swung open one of the dozens of cupboards that came with their loft on Beaver Street, right off Broadway near the southern tip of Manhattan. The shelves are lined with black ring-binders, each neatly inscribed with the subject matter. This one contains old corporate letterheads with delicately engraved pictures of the company buildings.
THEY are wonderful looking, often with red accents, designating an award won by the company or when it was founded. Underneath the letterhead is often a bill for goods, written in the spidery black ink of the turn of the century; black ink fading to a coppery script.
"I haven't found a letterhead for this building yet," Mr. Yardley said, "But I'm looking very hard."
The building is 26 Beaver Street, an imposing stone office building that still says Norton Lilly & Company across its broad facade.
"It's a 1908 building," Ms. Gordon said. "Let's look it up in the book." Mr. Yardley jumped up again, crossed the bare maple floor and grabbed another book, this one the city's business directory for 1915. "We have these going back to 1850."
H ERE it is," she said, holding the thick directory on her lap. "Norton Lilly ampersand Company, steamship agents. Broad 5750 was their phone number." Mr. Yardley fetches another book protected by an old brown paper wrapper; it consists mainly of old black-and-white photographs of Broadway buildings from Bowling Green to Central Park. He finds a photograph of the corner of Broadway and Beaver Street, with the building he now calls home in the background.
"I've got so much information on Lower Manhattan," he said. "Boxes and boxes of ephemera."
"So if you want to know something about Lower Manhattan, ask John," his wife said.
When he is not compiling his collections, Mr. Yardley is a furniture designer and maker, with his own shop at the corner of Greene and Canal Streets. But there are traces of his designs in the loft: a tiny table by the bed, a small but complex mirror on the wall. Mr. Yardley's designs are distinctive: he glues together small pieces of boldly grained wood; the grain creates a striped pattern that, at first glance, appears to be marquetry, a craft in which patterns are created by gluing strips of veneer.
"But this is parquetry," Mr. Yardley explained. "The stripes are actually in the wood, not applied." Asked if he was the only person using this technique, he said he was the only one he knew of, "but you know, they say nothing's ever really new."
That's true, but the arrival of people like Mr. Yardley and Ms. Gordon into the Financial District is fairly new -- and for those who can find a loft to buy, the prices can be strikingly low: the couple paid $275,000 for a 2,350-square-foot loft space with a series of huge near-floor-to-ceiling wood windows facing north onto Beaver Street. (That same space, in TriBeCa or SoHo, could easily be double the price.)
The reason, as the couple know, is that the Financial District is still an area of residential pioneers; with Mayor Rudolph W. Guiliani's tax incentives for developers to transform vacant office space into residential units, reconstruction is rushing ahead but there is still very little available to buy right now, according to agents. And there is still skepticism about whether the bleak canyons of commerce will ever become the hot area TriBeCa is.
Ms. Gordon and Mr. Yardley, who came to this country in 1978, have witnessed the TriBeCa transformation first hand.
"We lived in TriBeCa in the late 70's and early 80's in a shared rental at Murray and Greenwich," Ms. Gordon said.
"Yeah, we thought it was too expensive," added Mr. Yardley, with a wry laugh. "We started out paying $700 a month, and by the time we left, it was $1,000 a month -- for the whole loft."
BY then, it was the mid-80's, and they looked at more than 100 apartments, Ms. Gordon said. "The thing is -- we hadn't really narrowed our search: we looked as far north as Chelsea." They ended up not that far from where they are now: on Nassau Street, near City Hall.
They bought the apartment, a 600-square-foot one-bedroom with wonderful views, and thought they'd stay for a few years and then move on. They did not reckon on the real estate recession of the late 80's and early-to-mid 90's.
"We were stuck there for 10 years," she said ruefully. "We bought it at exactly the wrong time."
Then, about a year ago, they realized that although the sale market for the place had still not improved, the rental market was going through the roof, and they rented it out, using the income to cover their expenses. They began to look for a new place to buy.
They only looked at two other places before they saw the loft on Beaver Street.
"John wanted it the minute we walked in," Ms. Gordon recalled. "But I hesitated, and by the time we called, a few days later, we were told it was gone." She was crushed; she felt it was her fault. But the deal fell through, and they didn't hesitate. They bought it Sept. 24.
At the final inspection, the couple discovered that a leak had destroyed their kitchen counter. They tried to get the sellers, two elderly women who the new owners say had never lived in the loft, to pay for the repairs. The sellers wouldn't budge.
"Then Steve Kliegerman, the real estate agent, did something very unusual," Ms. Gordon said. "He said he'd send somebody down to fix the counter for us. The closing went through, and he actually did fix the counter. Isn't that amazing?"

Mr. Yardley discovered, and uncovered, a window buried in the wall of the loft's bathroom. (Photos by Thomas Dallal for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Bad Listeners

BYLINE: By Margalit Fox; Margalit Fox is an editor at the Book Review.

 BODY:

THE ERROR OF OUR WAYS
By David Carkeet.
275 pp. New York:
Henry Holt & Company. $25.
A linguist by training, David Carkeet is a novelist whose work explores language as the primary instrument of human communication -- and deception. In his dark domestic comedy "The Error of Our Ways," he trains his professional ear on the intertwined fates of two men whose lives, on the surface, could not be more dissimilar. 
 Ben Hudnut, "the Nut King of St. Louis," is a Saab-driving, vanity-plated entrepreneur whose raison d'etre is to "bring a cost-effective, quality cashew to America." A paragon of upper-middle-class virtue, he is a man who can "raise good kids, run a solid business and have an affair."
At the dimmer end of the social spectrum is Jeremy Cook, the linguist hero of Mr. Carkeet's previous novels "Double Negative" and "The Full Catastrophe." Once rakish, cynical and a cutting-edge scholar, Cook is now married, cynical and unemployed. He has fetched up in St. Louis, where his ambitious wife is teaching linguistics at a jerkwater college. Cook, who can unravel knotty theoretical problems quicker than you can say "voiceless palatal fricative," is reduced to studying Hudnut's obscenity-spouting 2-year-old daughter. Quite a comedown for the author of "The Woof of Words."
But Hudnut and Cook have one underlying feature in common: the preternatural hubris that can afflict both the capitalist and the academic. And as Mr. Carkeet's astute, entertaining novel progresses, both men can only look on, helpless, as their respective worlds begin to collapse around them.
If they'd only been better listeners they might have averted calamity, for Mr. Carkeet's text abounds with dire linguistic portents. How can Hudnut, the man who put the cash in "cashew," intone the name of his own enterprise -- Crunch -- and not hear an aural harbinger of economic ruin? How can Cook learn of the existence of a man -- also named Jeremy Cook -- who underwent an involuntary orchidectomy and not worry that his own marriage has unmanned him?
Mr. Carkeet, on the other hand, has an infallible ear for the nuances of speech, and this makes him both an acute social observer and an engaging stylist. He shows us the language of class (in Hudnut's suburban milieu, all anyone talks about is "schools, real estate and grout"); the language of eros (a maidenish 42-year-old secretary discovers sex and knock-knock jokes at the same time); and, above all, language for the sheer auditory joy of it (Cook's favorite composer is Karl Ditters von Dittersdorf; Hudnut's living room is awash in "prints and flowers, doilies and tchotchkes, statues and statuettes, knickknacks and gimcracks"). And, for those of us who feel that a novel without a problem in generative phonology worked into the narrative is no novel at all, Mr. Carkeet thoughtfully supplies one, complete with underlying forms, surface forms and phonological rules.
Ultimately, Mr. Carkeet's fine book, which affectingly portrays the perils of middle-aged manhood, is a study of the subtle anthropology of everyday communication. In the author's linguistically heightened universe, even inanimate objects are invested with the power of speech: a can of spray paint utters the memorable line "gonketa gonketa" when shaken; a leather couch on which a fateful liaison took place sighs slowly back into shape. By the time a husband, conversing with his wife, says in surprise, "This doesn't sound like you," we know with some certainty that the union is doomed.
At novel's end, both heroes have undergone symbolic emasculations -- Cook at the hands of his ruthless wife, Hudnut at the hands of an embezzler who nearly costs him his nut business. The attentive reader, however, will not be surprised at this. For surely a man who uses "quality" as an adjective is bound to pay dearly for it in the final reckoning.

SECTION: Section 6; Page 32; Column 1; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 1581 words

HEADLINE: New Math, Same Story

BYLINE: By Paul R. Krugman

 BODY:
TWICE IN THE LAST YEAR, EXPERTS ON AMERICA'S ECONOMIC statistics startled the public by suddenly declaring some well-known truths about our economy to be, in the immortal pronoucement of Ron Ziegler, Richard Nixon's press secretary during Watergate, "inoperative."
 
 This is not a technical matter, of interest only to policy wonks. Economic statistics have a direct impact on the Governmetn budget - most notably, Social Security benefits, which are linked to the Consumer Price Index.
 But perhaps even more important, statistics play a crucial role in the stories we tell ourselves about ourselves - in the portraits we paint of the state of the nation. With a sweep of their magic wand, it seemed to many commentators, statisticians had changed economic history, turning poverty into plenitude and overturning whole ideologies about where America is going and why.
 Until last year many people - but not most economists - thought that the economic datas told simple tale. On one side, productivity - the output of an average worker - was rising. And although the rate of productivity increase was very slow during the 1970's and early 1980's, the official numbers said that it had accelerated significantly in the 1990's. By 1994 an average worker was producing about 20 percent more than his or her counterpart in 1978.
 On the other hand, other statistics said that real, inflation-adjusted wages had not been rising at anything like the same rate. In fact, some of the most commonly cited numbers showed real wages actually falling over the last 25 years. Those who did their homework knew that the gloomiest numbers overstated the case - for example, because they covered only blue-collar workers, whose pay increasingly lags that of other employees, or neglected the rising share of health and retirement benefits in total compensation.
 Still, even the most optimistic measure, the total hourly compensation of the average worker, rose only 3 percent between 1978 and 1994.
 And so to many commentators, from Pat Buchanan to Robert Reich, the story seemed obvious. In an age of rapid technological progress and corporate re-engineering, they told us, the output of the average worker was rapidly rising; but because workers were cowed by downsizing and job insecurity, the bosses no longer felt any need to share these gains with their employees. Even solid pillars of the establishment, like Business Week magazine, joined the chorus with a cover story in 1995 titled "Wages: They're Stagnant While Profits Are Soaring. Are We Headed for Trouble?"
 But now the experts are telling us that the whole thing may have been a figment of our statistical imaginations.
 The first about-face came at the beginning of the year, when the Bureau of Economic Analysis, the Government agency that calculates Gross Domestic Product, shifted from a "fixed-weight" to a "chain-linked" measure of economic growth. (You don't want to know.) The change had the effect of sharply reducing the estimated rate of productivity growth over the last few years. Then in December a blue-ribbon panel of economists headed by Michael Boskin of Stanford declared that the Consumer Price Index had been systematically overstating inflation, probably by more than 1 percent per year for the last two decades, mainly by failing to take account of changes in the patterns of consumption and improvements in product quality.
 Even the bureau's technical adjustment was controversial, because it seemed to deflate business boasts about a "productivity revolution" in recent years. The Boskin report, however, ignited a firestorm of criticism. Partly this was because of the link between the C.P.I. and Social Security payments, which meant that any downward revision in the index would strike directly at retirees. Many of the Boskin report's harshest critics, however, were outraged because it repudiated a view of the economy on which they had staked their reputations and built their careers. For if inflation has been exaggerated, then the growth in real wages has been understated - and so the whole story about how companies are not sharing productivity gains with their workers evaporates.
 To be fair, there are not many professional economists among those who are wailing and rending their garments. On the contrary, most economists who study the relationship between productivity and wages are relieved at the more or less official admission that some of the published numbers may have been way off, because they already knew there had to be something wrong. When you tried to put the data together into a consistent story about what has been happening to America, you discovered that the supposed facts just didn't fit together.
 As these economists pointed out, if the popular story were true - if the average worker really were producing more and being paid less - then wages must, as a simple matter of arithmetic, have declined as a share of the total economic pie. (Actually, there are some technical qualifications to that arithmetic, but they are not worth worrying about.) The Government, however, collects data on the distribution of income by type - data that are not subject to the technical problems of productivity and inflation estimates. And the implied decline in labor's overall share just hasn't happened - in fact, the share of wages and benefits in national income was just about the same (73 percent) in 1994 that it was in 1978.
 As robot used to say in old science fiction movies, "Does not compute." Like astronomers - whose current estimates inidcate that the oldest stars are older than the universe in which they reside - economists knew that at least one of their numbers had to be wrong; either productivity wasn't up that much, or wages were doing better than reported, or the share of labor in national income was being grossly overstated.
 There are still many details to settle. The Boskin report, in particular, is not an official document - it will be quite a while before the Government actually issues a revised C.P.I., and the eventual revision may be smaller than Boskin and his colleagues propose. Still, the general outline of the resolution is pretty clear. When all the revisions are taken into account, productivity growth will probably look somewhat higher than it did before, because some of the revisions being proposed to the way we measure consumer prices will also affect the way we calculate growth. But the rate of growth of real wages will look much higher - and so it will now be roughly in line with productivity and wages with data that show a roughly unchanged distribution of income between capital and labor. In other words, the whole story about workers not sharing in productivity gains will turn out to have been based on a statistical illusion.
 It is important not to go overboard on this point. There are real problems in America, and our previous concerns were by no means pure hypochondria. For one thing, it remains true that the rate of economic progress over the past 25 years has been much slower than it was in the previous 25. Even if Boskin's numbers are right, the income of the median family - which officially has experience virtually no gain since 1973 - has risen by only about 35 percent over the past 25 years, compared with 100 percent over the previous 25. Furthermore, it is quite likely that if we "Boskinized" the old data - that is, if we tried to adjust the C.P.I. for the 50's and 60's to take account of changing consumption patterns and rising product quality - we would find that official numbers understated the rate of progress just as much if not more than they did in recent decades. (Many observers would argue that the qualitative changes in the way ordinary people lived were far greater between 1945 and 1970 than between 1970 and the present.) The popular impression that the first postwar generation experienced an immense improvement in living standards, while the second did not, is still correct; the American dream may not be dead, but it is certainly not what it was.
 Moreover, while workers as a group have shared fully in national productivity gains, they have not done so equally. The overwhelming evidence of a huge increase in income inequality in America has nothing to do with price indexes and is therefore unaffected by recent statistical revelations. It is still true that families in the bottom fifth, who had 5.4 percent of total income in 1970, had only 4.2 percent in 1994; and that over the same period the share of the top 5 percent went from 15.6 to 20.1. And it is still true that corporate C.E.O.'s, who used to make about 35 times as much as their employees, now make 120 times as much or more. The living standards of most people may be up in absolute terms, but these growing disparities still make it increasingly questionable whether it makes any sense to think of ourselves as a middle-class society. And despite the revisions, there is not much question that the incidence of really severe poverty in America has increased, not fallen, over the past generation. While these are real and serious prolems, however, one thing is now clear: the truth about what is happening in America is more subtle than the simplistic morality play about greedy capitalists and oppressed workers that so many would-be sophisticates accepted only a few months ago. There was little excuse for buying into that simplistic view then; there is no excuse now.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 2; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 2849 words

HEADLINE: Rich, 82, and Starting Over

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER 

 BODY:
WHEN John Kluge was a sophomore at Columbia University in 1935, he flirted with the idea of moving to China to start a competitor to the British East India Company. A scholarship student, Mr. Kluge was earning extra money by working as a private secretary for a classmate, the son of the President of China, Lin Sen.
With his pluck, his classmate's contacts and China's bountiful supply of tea, the 20-year-old Mr. Kluge imagined putting the world's most powerful trading company out of business. But in 1937 the Japanese bombed Shanghai, and the ensuing war between China and Japan dashed the young man's fantasy. 
 Now, six decades older and $7 billion richer, Mr. Kluge is finally making his foray into China -- bringing wireless telephone service to a country where tea is common but talking on the telephone is not. The venture, he contends, is far more than an aging man's fantasy.
"Every country needs two things to develop economically: transportation and communications," Mr. Kluge said recently in a rare interview at the New York offices of his publicly traded telecommunications and entertainment company, Metromedia International Group. "Communications is not a luxury in emerging markets; it is a necessity."
At the age of 82, when even the most restless of tycoons are ready for a silk-lined retirement, John Werner Kluge is starting his most ambitious enterprise. Having amassed one of the world's great fortunes in television and cellular communications in the United States, Mr. Kluge is busy constructing wireless cable television and telephone networks throughout Russia, the Baltic states, Eastern Europe and China.
Metromedia is still a bantam in a world of communications heavyweights. The company has fewer than 200,000 customers for its grab bag of services, which range from wireless cable TV and telephone to paging. Frederick W. Moran, a media analyst at Furman Selz, estimates that the company's overseas wireless operations will generate just $6 million in operating cash flow this year, on $100 million in revenues.
Mr. Kluge is better known for Metromedia's other major asset, Orion Pictures, the respected Hollywood studio with a troubled financial past. His personal holdings also include the Ponderosa and Bonanza restaurant chains; two Manhattan hotels, the Barbizon and the Radisson Empire, and even a professional soccer team, the MetroStars.
Clearly, though, Metromedia's communications division is the crown jewel in Mr. Kluge's empire, and he wants to polish it to a fine luster. Its wireless networks are capable of reaching roughly 100 million people in cities like Moscow and St. Petersburg in Russia; Tbilisi, Georgia, and Riga, Latvia. Metromedia's newest joint venture -- with a Chinese phone company called Golden Cellular -- will enable Mr. Kluge to reach another 70 million potential customers in several major Chinese cities, including Tianjin and Nanning.
Mr. Kluge's strategy rests on a beguilingly simple premise: More than half the people in the world have not yet made their first telephone call. In China, only 4 people in 100 have their own phones; in the United States, 6 of every 10 do. By getting into these embryonic markets and by using wireless technology, Mr. Kluge believes he can establish a valuable beachhead -- before mightier players like AT&T or Deutsche Telekom.
"This is like the United States in the 1800's, when people were staking their claims to land," said Richard J. Sherwin, a bluff, chain-smoking cellular-telephone executive whom Mr. Kluge hired to cobble together his network. "The difference is, you don't mine under the ground," he said, "you mine the airwaves."
OF course, exporting communications to these countries is not as simple as putting up microwave towers and handing out portable phones. In addition to the usual cultural hurdles, there are significant political barriers. In Russia and Eastern Europe, the governments require foreign companies to own communications networks in partnership with local companies. In China, foreign companies must limit their involvement even further, by owning stakes in joint ventures that provide services to locally owned network operators.
Nor is it clear how many people will clamor for Metromedia's services. Signing up just 1 percent of potential customers, Mr. Sherwin acknowledged, would constitute great success. And while Mr. Kluge has sought out less competitive corners of the communications business, he still faces some hefty rivals in those markets, including France Telecom in paging and Motorola in wireless local telephone service.
So far, Wall Street has treated Mr. Kluge's venture with the skepticism it might have shown him had he taken on the British East India Company more than 60 years ago. Metromedia's stock languished in the mid-teens for most of 1996 and closed at $10.625 on Friday, giving it a market capitalization of $702 million.
Signaling how serious he is about the company, Mr. Kluge recently turned over day-to-day control to Stuart Subotnick, the 54-year-old former tax lawyer who is his partner and most trusted adviser. That prompted the resignation of Metromedia's chief executive, John D. Phillips.
"If Stuart is the chief executive, it means that this is where they want to make a public stand," said David J. Londoner, an analyst at Schroder Wertheim & Company.
But the question remains: Why would one of the world's richest men choose this forbidding business landscape for what is very likely to be the last stand of his career?
Colleagues say Mr. Kluge is perpetually driven to devise new challenges and then to surmount them. Sumner M. Redstone, a fellow billionaire who became the chief executive of Viacom last year at 72, said, "You can't measure these things chronologically."
The compact, laconic Mr. Kluge, however, offered a more prosaic explanation: he said he was merely a businessman on the prowl for a good opportunity. Speaking in his characteristically slow, soft cadences even when indulging in a bit of salesmanship, he said, "We don't want to just make progress; we want to make geometric progress."
Mr. Subotnick, who has made an estimated $500 million by investing with Mr. Kluge, puts it another way. "We've never gone where the herd goes," he said. "By the time the herd shows up, it's too expensive."
ZIGGING when the crowd zags has served Mr. Kluge well ever since he came to the United States as a poor immigrant from Germany in 1922. After serving in military intelligence in World War II and working as a salesman for a paper company, Mr. Kluge (the name means "clever" in German) bought his first media property, an AM radio station in Silver Spring, Md., for $15,000 in 1946.
At the time, many experts were predicting that radio would soon be eclipsed by television. But Mr. Kluge acquired more radio stations and used the cash they generated to diversify into TV -- not by buying glamorous affiliates of the Big Three networks, but by buying a string of independent stations.
Mr. Kluge's radio and television outlets became the core of his first publicly traded company, Metromedia Inc., and occupied his attention for more than three decades. From 1959 to 1981, the company's stock rose from 69 cents a share to $569, when adjusted for stock splits.
In the early 1980's, Mr. Kluge expanded into cellular phones. But he did it through the back door: Metromedia spent $300 million to buy radio paging companies in big markets like Boston and New York. The paging companies were then applying for cellular telephone licenses. When the companies got them, Mr. Kluge suddenly owned a fistful of the most valuable cellular licenses in the country for a fraction of what he would have paid if he had pursued the licenses directly.
But Metromedia's stockholders balked at his expansion and fled, pummeling the share price. So in 1983, he borrowed heavily to buy the entire company himself for $1.2 billion. A few years later, when the demand for TV stations and cellular franchises drove up their value, he began methodically selling them off: Rupert Murdoch acquired the stations for $2 billion to form the backbone of his Fox network, while Mr. Kluge sold the cellular franchises to a variety of companies for more than $4 billion.
By the time he finished his gargantuan garage sale, Mr. Kluge was sitting on about $6.5 billion in cash -- enough to catapult him to the top of Forbes magazine's ranking of the 400 wealthiest Americans. (He has since dropped to fourth, after the Microsoft founders Bill Gates and Paul Allen at No. 1 and No. 3, and the investor Warren E. Buffett at No. 2.)
Though Mr. Kluge has the properties and perquisites of the superrich -- a 10,000-acre estate with private chapel in Charlottesville, Va., a sumptuous duplex apartment on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, a 206-foot yacht and a just-completed $30 million mansion in Palm Beach, Fla. -- colleagues say he is a notorious skinflint when it comes to business deals.
In 1988, he waged a fierce battle with Mr. Redstone in negotiating to buy Mr. Redstone's shares in the Orion film studio. People familiar with the talks said the two men had narrowed the price to within 25 cents a share, but spent a whole afternoon haggling over the last quarter. Splitting the difference, Mr. Redstone finally agreed to sell his shares to Mr. Kluge for $18 each.
Given his thrift, it is not surprising that Mr. Kluge was put off by several of the hottest new communications businesses of the early 1990's. He said that direct-broadcast satellite television and personal communications services were exciting, but the costs of entering these businesses were steep, and legions of companies had already entered the field.
Instead, Mr. Kluge focused on wireless cable, a rather unglamorous technology that got its start two decades ago as a way to bring pay TV to rural areas. The technology works by beaming signals from a central microwave tower to dishes clamped to the roofs of houses or apartment buildings. But what Mr. Kluge liked most about it was that it was much cheaper than ripping up streets to lay wires.
Rather than focusing on the crowded American market -- where the Government was auctioning off wireless licenses for billions of dollars -- Mr. Kluge zeroed in on virgin markets like Eastern Europe and China. With their pancake-flat geography and their tall apartment towers, many Eastern European cities are also particularly well suited to wireless transmission.
Using Mr. Sherwin as his advance man, Mr. Kluge scooped up licenses overseas for wireless cable, paging and international toll calling. In all, he collected licenses for 27 cities across 15 countries -- from Moscow to Almaty, Kazakhstan. Other players like U S West Inc. also went after licenses, but they focused on cellular telephone.
WINNING licenses in emerging markets is largely a matter of knowing the right politicians. As Frank Miller, a telecommunications entrepreneur with broad experience in the Russian market, puts it: "You've either got to have ties with the Kremlin or to regional strongmen."
Mr. Kluge has invested considerable time in developing those ties and has not hesitated to use his money as an extra lure. His approach to the Republic of Georgia is a case study in mixing diplomacy and financial largess.
Mr. Sherwin, who is 53, began promoting wireless communications to Georgian Government officials in 1991, when the country was in the throes of a civil war. During one early visit, he recalled, a sniper's bullet whizzed through the lobby of his hotel, narrowly missing him. To demonstrate his commitment to the country, Mr. Kluge donated $250,000 to fuel planes that were flying food and medical supplies to Georgia.
By the time the first round of fighting subsided, in 1992, the Government had awarded Metromedia national licenses for paging and international toll calling, plus a license to offer wireless cable in Tbilisi. Then last summer, Mr. Kluge traveled to Georgia for a private meeting with President Eduard A. Shevardnadze. Shortly thereafter, Mr. Kluge and the Georgian Ministry of Communication signed a deal granting Metromedia a license for its nationwide cellular phone business.
"We don't want to do things through third parties," Mr. Kluge explained. "We want to see the whites of their eyes, and they want to see the whites of our eyes."
In Georgia and other markets, Metromedia's cable customers receive a mix of channels similar to a basic cable lineup in the United States: a handful of local broadcast channels, plus cable channels like CNN, BBC and the Discovery Channel. Metromedia programs a local channel in most markets, according to Mr. Sherwin, and subscribers pay an average of $15 a month.
Now, Mr. Kluge also hopes to offer a new form of local telephone service, called wireless local loop. Like wireless cable, local loop beams a signal from a tower to a rooftop dish. But unlike cellular service, in which the call signal bounces from tower to tower as the caller moves, wireless local loop signals are transmitted to a fixed site.
Wireless local loop is intended to compete with regular local phone service in markets where the wired network is not fully developed. Metromedia is testing it in two Chinese cities, Tianjin, near Beijing, and Nanning, the capital of Guangxi Province.
Despite a wave of early publicity, however, the technology has not caught on among many other telecommunications companies because of concerns about voice quality, said Alexander Kabanovsky, an analyst at Pyramid Research, a telecommunications research firm in Cambridge, Mass.
Metromedia is hitting other bumps, too. The company's joint venture with Golden Cellular has been dogged by misunderstandings between the two companies. On a recent morning, Mr. Sherwin was on the phone with a Metromedia colleague, worriedly discussing the company's relationship with a senior executive at Golden Cellular.
In Russia, Metromedia must battle the perception that foreign companies make lofty promises and fail to deliver. In 1989, U S West was among several big phone companies that teamed up to build a fiber-optic cable in Russia. The project foundered because it ran afoul of laws limiting the export of technology to that country.
But Metromedia's bigger image problem is on Wall Street, where the company is regarded as a hodgepodge of businesses with little obvious connection to each other.
In addition to its telecommunications assets, Metromedia owns three film studios: Orion Pictures, the company that Mr. Kluge gained control of in 1988 for $204 million but that later filed for Chapter 11 after a string of money-losing films; the Samuel Goldwyn Company, which Mr. Kluge purchased last year for $125 million, and the Motion Picture Corporation of America, acquired in 1995 for $22 million. It is a producer of low-budget films including "Dumb and Dumber." Together, the three give Mr. Kluge the world's fourth-largest film library, with 2,200 titles.
Mr. Subotnick said the film studios provide Metromedia with a ready source of programming for its wireless cable systems. But several analysts said they contributed little to Mr. Kluge's broader strategy, and some argued that he ought to sell them. Mr. Moran of Furman Selz noted that Kirk Kerkorian paid $1.3 billion last year for MGM, a once-sickly studio with a library roughly the same size as Metromedia's.
Mr. Kluge said he acquired Samuel Goldwyn to buttress his library and to make Metromedia a more viable player in Hollywood. The studios plan to produce 12 to 14 low-budget movies this year. But after shepherding Orion through a messy bankruptcy, Mr. Kluge seems open to exiting the film business at the right price. "If someone comes up with a figure for the whole company, we'd have to look at it," he said.
Mr. Kluge said he was also anxious to sell some other odds and ends in Metromedia's portfolio, including a maker of lawn and garden equipment and a stake in a sporting goods company.
As for Metromedia's anemic stock price, Mr. Kluge professes to be unconcerned. Although he owns roughly 23 percent of the reconstituted company -- a stake worth $162 million -- Mr. Kluge's Metromedia shares represent a fraction of his total net worth. And he predicted that investors would eventually put a higher value on the company than its current premium of more than two times projected 1996 sales. "It will take time to put flesh on the dream," he said, "It will take time for people to realize that this is a business, not a plaything or a lark."
For Mr. Kluge to take the long view at 82 is testament to how much this new venture has caught his imagination. But he also allowed himself a nostalgic, and uncharacteristically personal, moment -- noting that his foray into China was something of a bookend for a career that began with a college sophomore's quixotic dream.
"If I had gone there after college, I would have undoubtedly married a Chinese woman," said Mr. Kluge, who divorced his third wife, Patricia, in 1990. "Maybe I would have been a lot happier."
