A Passage to Panama
Q. Can one just go back and forth through the Panama Canal and spend a few days nearby, flying there and back? -- Ethel G. Romm, Bedford, Mass.
A. You can book a complete tour from the United States, including a full or partial transit of the canal, or make your own way to Panama and arrange a canal trip there.
But if you do it on your own you will still have to arrange accommodations and a flight, so it might be cheaper and simpler to take a package after all. 
 Transits of the canal are made on ships operated by Argo Tours of Panama: the Islamorada, which holds up to 125 passengers, and the 500-passenger Fantasia del Mar.
Argo's agent in the United States is Panama Discovery Tours, which describes itself as the only exclusively Panama tour company in North America. Its most popular packages are Panama Discovery Tours, which run from three to eight days.
The three-day package consists of two nights in a hotel and either a partial transit of the canal and a guided tour of Panama City or a full canal transit. Prices for a double range from $260 a person in economy to $383 in deluxe. Prices for a single go from $326 to $530.
Meals and air fares to Panama are extra, but the company offers special air fares of $548 round trip from Kennedy International Airport and Newark International Airport. The New York flight connects through Houston; the Newark flight is direct.
The longer tours, which include a full transit of the canal, add such features as a trip through the rain-forest canopy in the Anton Valley. Visitors are lifted to the canopy and brought down again by a system of ropes and pulleys.
Prices range from $380 for a double in economy for the four-day tour to $1,318 for a deluxe double on the eight-day trip. Singles run from $488 to $1,832. At least one meal a day is included.
Tours will run next year from Jan. 23 to 30, March 27 to April 3, May 29 to June 5, July 24 to 31, Sept. 25 to Oct. 2 and Nov. 27 to Dec. 4. Starting this year, from Dec. 23 to 30, the company will offer a "Christmas on the Isthmus" tour starting at $1,015 for an economy double to $1,445 for a deluxe double. An economy single is $1,246 and the deluxe single $1,960.
More information: Panama Discovery Tours, Post Office Box 130, Clarita, Okla. 74535; (800) 813-3115, fax (405) 428-3499. The company can be reached on the Internet at http:// www.panamacanal.com.
Argo's two ships make full transits every other month from Dock 17 in Balboa, on the Pacific Ocean, to Cristobal, on the Atlantic. Passengers are taken back to Balboa, a distance of about 45 miles, on an air-conditioned bus. The trip takes from six hours to eight hours or more, depending on canal traffic, and costs $90, children 12 and under $69.
Partial transits cost $45 a person, $25 for children 12 and under. The price includes brunch.
More information: Argo Tours, Apartado 9662, Panama 4, Republic of Panama; 011 (507) 228-6069, fax 011 (507) 228-1234.
 
Staying in Mexico
Q. I would like to stay in Zihuatenejo, Mexico, this winter for a month to six weeks. Any suggestions for finding a long-term rental overlooking the beach? -- Leslie Gregg, Charlottesville, Va.
A. This type of property is still relatively rare in Zihuatenejo, a Pacific fishing village that offers a quiet beachfront alternative to the next-door glitz of Ixtapa. The best choice is among time-share houses, which in Mexico still usually refers to the rental of hotel rooms for a particular week of the year over several years.
Nonetheless, there are a few other options.
A beachfront house with three rooms, a kitchen and a patio rents for between $500 and $1,200 a week in the low season and $900 and $1,500 a week from Dec. 15 to Easter and from July 1 to Aug. 31. But if you plan to stay for a month or more, considerable discounts are available.
A typical property might have an ocean view and a five-minute walk to the beach. Many condominiums have access to a pool.
A one-bedroom condominium rents for between $300 and $1,000 a week, depending on the season, while a four-bedroom villa tends to start at $1,500 a week in the high season and $1,000 in the low season.
There are a number of brokers who can help explain the options: Elizabeth Williams, APDO 19, Zihuatanejo, Guerrero, Mexico; (52 755) 4.26.06, fax (52 755) 4.47.62.
Tim Sullivan, 229 Paseo de las Golondrinas, Colonia Campo de Golf, Guerrero 40880, Zihuatanejo, Mexico; (52 755) 3.14.18.
Condo and Villa Authority, 305 North Pontiac Trail, Walled Lake, Mich. 48390; (810) 669-7500, (800) 831-5512; fax (810) 669-7506.
Villas International, 605 Market Street, San Francisco, Calif. 94105; (415) 281-0910; fax (415) 281-0919.
Residential Condominiums International (Georgina Velasco or Marlene Marin) 1855 Homero, Colonia Los Morales Polanco, Mexico, D.F. 11510, Mexico (52 5) 283-1081.
 
Russian Medical Help
Q. I will be visiting Moscow and St. Petersburg next year. Where can I get medical help, with English-speaking doctors, if I need it? -- Paula Eisenstein Baker, Houston
A. There are at least three places in Moscow where foreign visitors can receive medical aid, and one of them has a branch in St. Petersburg.
The American Medical Center opened in Moscow in 1991 and offers full 24-hour emergency services for members of its medical plan and a full array of medical and dental care. The center, at 2d Tverskaya-Yam skaya Street, Building 10, telephone (7 095) 956-3366, fax (7 095) 956-2306, offers a $50-a-month individual plan that is open to tourists. Each visit costs from $160 to $215, depending on the service. The centers are open Monday to Friday from 8 A.M. to 8 P.M. in Moscow and 8:30 A.M. to 6 P.M. in St. Petersburg. Its St. Petersburg center is at 77 Fontanka Street, (7 812) 325-6101, fax (7 812) 325-6120.
European Medical Center, 10 2d Tverskaya-Yamskaya Street, (7 095) 251-6099, offers consultations by English-speaking European doctors. A visit to a doctor is $80, a visit to a specialist $100, with no membership fee. Open Monday to Saturday from 9 A.M. to 7 P.M., with a night emergency phone at 229-6536.
International Medical Clinic, 31 Grokholsky Street, (7 095) 280-7138, fax (7 095) 280-8677, charges from $80 to $105 for a doctor's visit. A two-month membership costs $50. TERENCE NEILAN

HEADLINE: FRUGAL TRAVELER;
Making Time Fly in Preseason Sarasota

BYLINE: By SUSAN SPANO 

 BODY:
A HOODED black wool coat and ankle boots are anything but de rigueur in Florida. I figured this out the minute I landed at the Tampa International Airport (on a USAir flight, round trip from New York for $194) one warm, sunny afternoon in late November. At the airport office of Alamo Rent-a-Car I made a quick change into a sun dress, then stashed the coat and boots in the trunk of an economy-class gray Corsica ($22 a day), where they stayed, like a corpse in one of the paperback mysteries I always take along when I go to Florida.
I was reading John D. MacDonald mysteries on this trip, because the author lived in Sarasota, where I was headed -- about an hour-and-a-half drive south of Tampa. I took the scenic, watery route, west on Highway 275 over flat, glistening Tampa Bay, south to St. Petersburg, and then back over the bay on the 4.1 mile long Sunshine Skyway ($1 toll), a stunningly futuristic suspension bridge with two long arching piers that look like bug tentacles, probing the Gulf of Mexico. Halfway across, I tuned into a radio station playing Otis Redding's "(Sittin' on) the Dock of the Bay." And when I swung south onto Route 19 in Palmetto, I found the only thing my arrival in the Sunshine State lacked -- seafood, in the form of a crab burger to go (for about $10) from Lee's Crab Trap I, composed of pure white meat. 
 I could have made straight for my destination by taking Highway 41, the old Tamiami Trail, which cut a cement path across Florida from Tampa to Miami in 1928 and now serves as Sarasota's main thoroughfare. But I wanted to see the thin ribbon of barrier beach islands that lines the Gulf Coast, especially during the quiet, uncrowded and affordable off season. So I turned west in Bradenton near the spot on the Manatee River where the Spanish explorer Hernando DeSoto landed in 1539, and crossed the Intracoastal Waterway. Then I cruised down slender Anna Maria Island and Longboat and Lido Keys, which are connected by drawbridges where brown pelicans ride in the water like misshapen gondolas and snow birds drive slowly, hunting for winter rentals. Modest Beach bungalows yielded to ritzy high-rise condo complexes halfway down Longboat Key. When I rounded St. Armands Circle, a chic shopping district developed in the 1920's by the circus impresario John Ringling, I caught my first sight of the shining city on Sarasota Bay, fringed by palm trees, golf courses and the sort of grandiose Mediterranean-style mansions you rarely see on the Mediterranean.
But I still had about 10 miles to go before I reached the Crescent House Bed-and-Breakfast, where I'd booked a single with a shared bath for two nights at a bargain rate of $45 a day. Then I planned to indulge myself by spending two days in an apartment at the Banana Bay Club for $90 a day. Both places lie on Siesta Key, a six-mile-long island at the south end of Sarasota Bay, with a quirky, casual ambiance and a beach renowned for its fine white sand. I could have reserved a hotel room (for an off-season rate of about $75) on Longboat or Lido Keys, which are more centrally situated, or really economized by staying in one of the mainland motels splayed along Highway 41 (with rates as low as $50). But as I'd planned it, my accommodations came to about $68 a night, which seemed reasonable, and I liked the sound of Siesta Key.
As I crossed North Bridge from the mainland the fat red sun looked about ready to plop into the gulf, and at the white frame Crescent House on Beach Road the owner's black standard poodle licked my hand in welcome. Built in 1914, before the Mediterranean craze struck in the 20's, the place has an old Florida feeling -- a comfortable enclosed front porch with louvered windows, strategically placed space heaters and four bedrooms on two floors. Mine was a tidy chamber at the side of the house with a patchwork quilt on the double bed and an old TV, up a long set of steps from the small, dark bath. The sound of traffic on Beach Road occasionally intruded, and the buffet breakfast (of cereal, rolls and fruit) didn't really tempt me. But the price was perfect, as was the location -- just across the street from Beach Access No. 8.
The gulf water was too chilly for swimming, but in the mornings after breakfast I jogged the half mile of pillowy sand at Siesta Key Beach, among sea urchins and healthy-looking retirees. Then I'd amble into Siesta Village, about five minutes away from the B & B, to restock my MacDonald paperbacks at the Used Book Heaven (yellowing, but for half the cover price) and stop at the Broken Egg or the Patisserie Cafe Continental for a second breakfast, which along with happy hour is what village restaurants do best.
My first full day was a beautiful Saturday, which started off like a mystery novel, with me waiting on a stone bench in front of a ramshackle pink frame house on the slightly seedy north side of Sarasota. I'd read in a guidebook that Mango Walking Tours of downtown (for $4.95) start at this unprepossessing address, led by a former member of the city's Historic Preservation board. No other tour-takers arrived, however, and when the guide, Whit Rylee, appeared he wasn't the wizened old Sarasotan I'd expected -- but young and tanned, wearing sandals, a Hawaiian shirt and a straw hat.
 TOGETHER, we strolled past the handsomely restored Sarasota Opera House and boarded-up John Ringling Towers Hotel, which opened with great fanfare on New Year's Eve 1926, but closed when the Sarasota real estate boom went bust and even rich Mr. Ringling felt the pinch. All the while, Whit elucidated the city's architecture (from Dwight James Baum's Art Deco to the stark Sarasota School) and spun stories about turn-of-the-century Sarasota, when the first mayor was a Scottish golfer.
Afterward I lunched downtown on the patio at the Lemon Coast. There the peel-and-and-eat shrimp appetizer (for $4.75) comes with a moist towelette and I noticed that the label on my bottle of Tommy Bahama Bungalow Blonde (for $3.25) said, "Life is one long weekend."
So it seemed up Highway 41 near the Convention and Visitors Bureau, where I picked up brochures full of coupons. At the far side of the parking lot the Sarasota Lawn Bowling Club, established in 1927, was packed, and on a bench outside the Sarasota Visual Art Center an elderly man sat with an alligator chained to his leg. On second look, I realized that they were part of a sculpture by Jack Dowd, a Sarasota artist who is a practitioner of a style you could call Florida Absurdism.
But I didn't stay long, because I was headed to the John and Mable Ringling Museum of Art, which lies on the grounds of the Venetian Gothic Ringling mansion, Ca' d'Zan, constructed in 1926 by Mr. Baum, near an airplane hangar of a building that houses the Ringling Circus Museum (admission $8.50 for all three sites, but I got $1 off with a coupon). Mr. Ringling's taste in art, as evidenced by the museum's dour Dutch portraiture and lugubrious religious painting, failed to transfix me; and his eclectic winter home is in the midst of a three-year renovation, with rooms denuded of furniture and scaffolds shrouding the facade in a manner that is truly Venetian. But I adored the Circus Museum, with its vintage bandwagons, costumes, posters and displays on stars of "The Greatest Show on Earth," like the diminutive General Tom Thumb. When he met lanky Abe Lincoln in 1863, the President remarked, "Here we have the long and the short of it."
Later, the bar at Marina Jack's in Bayfront Park looked to me like a good place to watch the sun set and sip a Bombay gin martini (for $4.50). Outside a bride dressed like something out of "Gone With the Wind" was posing for her wedding pictures, while inside, the man next to me complained about his second divorce, which had left him with little more than a yacht. This was getting depressing on a number of levels, so I polished off my olives and moved on to dinner at a restaurant called Turtles on Little Sarasota Bay. It is bayside, near the south tip of Siesta Key, and specializes in "killer shrimp," which I tried in red sauce over linguine (for $10.95) and finished off with a slice of creamy Key lime pie to go (for $2.50) from Captain Curt's Crab and Oyster Bar just up Midnight Pass Road.
To sum up my last two extremely busy days in Sarasota you could borrow the caption from a 1929 poster in the Circus Museum that describes "The Human Projectile," Hugo Zacchino, as "A living person shot through space with violent velocity from the mouth of a cannon." I watched live sea horses bound across a tank in the Mote Marine Aquarium (admission $8) on Lido Key, toured the pens of disabled egrets, herons and pileated woodpeckers at the Pelican Man's Bird Sanctuary (admission free, though a donation is requested), and learned from a plaque in the Marie Selby Botanical Gardens (admission $7) that Alexander the Great's whole army camped beneath a spreading banyan tree during the India campaign in the fourth century B.C.
I also moved to the charming, immaculately kept, seven-unit Banana Bay Club, on Heron lagoon between Crescent and Turtle Beaches. There I swam in the pool, canoed on the lagoon, bicycled on Midnight Pass Road and cooked -- because I was tired of eating out and my one-bedroom apartment, decorated in Caribbean colors, had a well-equipped kitchenette. I got tomatoes and oranges from Albritton Fruit, a bottle of California chardonnay from the Crescent Market and $10 worth of precracked stone crab claws from the Siesta Fish Market -- all of which made an excellent repast.
But on my last night in Sarasota I cooked something really special for dinner -- three little gray snappers I caught myself on a six-hour fishing trip aboard the Flying Fish II (for $30), berthed at Marina Jack's. I told the captain that I was no angler, so he stationed me next to a tall retiree originally from Hoboken who called himself Lucky Duff and who took the trip several times a week. As soon as the boat reached deep water, Duff taught me how to bait my hook with chopped squid, cast out my line and wait patiently -- which I did, while others around me pulled in porgies, red and black groupers and an ugly dogfish. Meanwhile, Duff exchanged his golf hat for his lucky fishing hat, told me about his son who won a $500,000 lotto jackpot and threw back little fish saying, "Go tell your grandpa I set you free."
He never caught the big sea bass he wanted and on our way back to Sarasota Bay a gust of wind stole his fishing hat. But I still say he was lucky. And I'm thinking it could have rubbed off on me, which is why I just bet $2 on the New York Lotto.
 
The bottom line for a Florida trip
 I spent an average of $108 a day while in Sarasota. My rental car (almost always a necessity in Florida) from Alamo, (800) 327-9633, cost $111, including tax but not insurance, and gas cost $14.
To reach Tampa I flew on USAir, (800) 428-4322, from New York, with a change of planes in Washington, for $194 round trip. The Sarasota-Bradenton International Airport is much more convenient, being just a few miles north of downtown Sarasota on Highway 41; but at the time I booked my ticket, flights there were either full or too expensive.
Information about Sarasota is available from the Sarasota Convention and Visitors Bureau, 655 North Tamiami Trail, Sarasota, Fla. 34236, (800) 522-9799; for Siesta Key maps and brochures, contact the Siesta Key Chamber of Commerce, 5100B Ocean Boulevard, Sarasota, Fla. 34242; (941) 349-3800, fax (941) 349-9699). Or refer to Steve Rabow's Official Guide Book on Sarasota, Bradenton and Venice, with a coupon insert; to get a copy contact Steve Rabow's Official Guide, Post Office Box 15332, Sarasota, Fla. 34277; (941) 927-1771.

Where to Stay
The Crescent House Bed-and-Breakfast, 459 Beach Road, Sarasota 34242, (941) 346-0857, has four guest rooms, two of which share a bath; shared bath rooms cost $82 and private bath rooms $110 from Dec. 1 to May 10, but the owner is flexible about pricing in the off season.
The Banana Bay Club, 8254 Midnight Pass Road, Sarasota 34242, (941) 346-0113, has a pool, dock, canoe, bicycles, and seven units that range in price from $125 to $185 Dec. 15 to May 15, and $90 to $150 May 16 to Dec. 14; a two-night minimum stay is required, as is cash.
Also on Siesta Key, I quite liked the Sara Sea Inn at the Beach, 6760 Sara Sea Circle, Siesta Key, 34242, (941) 349-3244, fax (941) 349-4999, near Crescent Beach, with a pool, volleyball and shuffleboard courts. Rates: $79 to $179 from May 1 to Nov. 30, $69 to $199 from Dec. 1 to Jan. 31, and $129 to $249 from Feb. 1 to April 30; and the Tropical Breeze Inn, 140 Columbus Boulevard, Sarasota 34242 (941) 349-1125, fax (941) 349-0057, with a pool, Jacuzzi and cottages, suites, and town houses scattered around Siesta Village, priced from $99 to $199 from mid-December to January, and $109 to $225 from February to mid-May.

Where to Eat
Lee's Crab Trap I is on Route 19 near the Terra Ceia Bridge, (941) 722-6255; the Lemon Coast is at 35 South Lemon Avenue downtown, (941) 316-0235; Turtles on Little Sarasota Bay is at 8875 Midnight Pass Road, (941) 346-2207; and the Siesta Fish Market is at 221 Garden Lane, (941) 349-2602.

CORRECTION-DATE: February 16, 1997, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
The Frugal Traveler column on Jan. 5, about Sarasota, Fla., referred incorrectly to John Ringling Towers. A reader's letter received on Jan. 29 points out that the building did not close for good when Ringling felt the pinch of a sharp decline in real estate. Further research shows that the building, first opened in 1926, was known under a series of names: first El Vernona, then the John Ringling Hotel and finally John Ringling Towers; it closed permanently in 1980. It was never known as the John Ringling Towers Hotel.

HEADLINE: Russia Must Do More For Foreign Investors

 BODY:
To the Editor:
While Daniel J. Arbess (letter, Dec. 31) is correct that there are a multitude of foreign investment opportunities in Russia today, consider that the primary barrier to the influx of foreign capital in the past five years has been the Russian Government's inability or unwillingness to create a more hospitable investment climate, specifically in the area of corporate tax reform, the enforcement of private property rights and currency convertibility. 
 Until recently, foreign investors have steered clear of Russia because of instability in the investment environment. Most who have ventured into the brave new world of Russian business have met with frustration at the hands of the tax, legal and regulatory institutions.
Privatized businesses and entrepreneurs have made a great contribution to reforming the Russian economy and must continue to be the agents of growth and development. But they cannot establish mechanisms for enforcing contracts, institute tax incentives for investments and insure that the ruble becomes fully convertible.
In any economy, this is government's role. You reported on Dec. 28 a sharp increase in the level of foreign investment in Russia in 1996. This is attributable to perceptible progress by the Russian Government in addressing these areas of investor concern..
Mr. Arbess is correct that Russian industry needs Western investment. But before that investment will flow freely, the Government must do more to persuade investors that Russia is a good place to put their money.
 
ROBERT MONYAK
Stamford, Conn., Jan. 2, 1997
The writer is program manager for the Commonwealth of Independent States at the International Executive Service Corps.

HEADLINE: Washington, D.C., Needs Money Management

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your Jan. 1 editorial "Staying Afloat in D.C." makes a bow toward the real problems in the District of Columbia's government -- massive mismanagement and excessive spending -- but then falls into the usual trap of writing about how the city's woes are also very much a revenue problem. 
 You cite familiar arguments: If only the District could levy a commuter tax, or if it received the money it deserved from the Federal Government's occupancy of 41 percent of the city's land, it could right itself.
Yet, despite its economic problems, the District has higher per-capita income than any state in the nation. Because of this wealth, a reasonable tax system could finance needed services. And the problems you cite notwithstanding, from 1980 to 1990 the city's annual revenues from Federal and local sources increased by $1.3 billion.
But more important, consider the spending side of the District government equation. From 1980 to 1990, Washington saw a 54 percent increase in operating costs. In Washington's schools, while the national average for spending per pupil was $5,717 in 1990, the District spent at least $9,377 per pupil.
No, the problem is not that the District government can't get enough of the citizenry's money. It is that government has deeply violated the public trust in deciding what to do with it.
 
JOHN E. BERTHOUD
Vice President
Alexis de Tocqueville Institution
Arlington, Va., Jan. 2, 1997

HEADLINE: For Financial Printers, It Is Adapt or Die

BYLINE: By STACY LU 

 BODY:
At first glance, the financial printing industry appears to be facing an uphill battle in surviving the digital age.
After all, the industry has received increasing warnings of the imminent demise of its traditional business: printing reams of government-mandated forms, brochures and securities prospectuses. 
 Since May, companies have been required to make electronic filings of initial public offerings with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Moreover, the S.E.C. announced in 1995 that companies could meet Federal disclosure regulations in many cases by delivering financial information electronically.
Investors can now find plenty of information on line. And a site on the World Wide Web is becoming an increasingly important corporate brochure.
So what is the financial printing industry to do? Why, embrace the very technologies that are threatening its core business, including the electronic S.E.C. filing system known as Edgar (for electronic data gathering analysis and retrieval), Web publishing and CD-ROM's.
As a result, financial printers are surviving, even flourishing.
The three industry leaders, Bowne & Company of New York; R. R. Donnelley Financial, part of R. R. Donnelley & Sons Company of Chicago, and the Merrill Corporation of St. Paul, had combined sales exceeding $1.1 billion in their most recent year. Bowne alone reported sales of $501.4 million, an increase of 28 percent over the previous year.
Because different printing jobs require various expensive presses, the industry is specialized. As well as offering competitive ink-on-paper printing rates, financial printers must know how to handle the many particulars involved in producing S.E.C.-approved documents, including timing, paper and typeface sizes, and confidentiality requirements, as well as proofreading and other services.
This expertise, printers say, includes electronic communications. Of the 63,064 filings made in the first four months after Edgar went on line in May 1996, 12,138 of them were handled by Bowne, with the three industry leaders together filing 40 percent of all electronic submissions.
In addition, there are numerous sites dealing with initial public offerings on the Web, calling for Internet publishing expertise that printing companies are eager to offer.
"How do you think these I.P.O.'s get on the Web?" asked Tom Vos, marketing vice president for Bowne.
"People come to us and say, 'We still need those 100,000 paper copies to distribute to our clients, but we now need the electronic version,' " he said. "In the last year or so, those same clients are saying, 'We still need those 100,000 paper copies, we still need the electronic distribution, and we now need a version suitable for the Web.' "
The industry is still struggling to overcome setbacks it has faced since the mid-1980's. Commercial printing employment has declined 34 percent in New York since 1989, according to the New York City Economic Development Corporation.
The introduction of computers in the production process obliterated some segments of the industry like typesetting and photo engraving. Expensive New York real estate drove plants to Connecticut and New Jersey. And in the aftermath of the 1987 stock market crash, many financial printing companies disappeared.
Such warning signals encouraged companies like Bowne, founded in 1775, to begin adapting to new technology.
"We've had to set up a lot of computer applications worldwide," Mr. Vos said. "Maybe we were lucky when Edgar came in when it did, and alerted us that we needed to get ourselves more literate in some of the new technologies. The retraining has been going on almost constantly."
Of course, the big financial printers have the edge of experience in dealing with sensitive financial information. For decades, they have helped clients satisfy the painfully detailed labyrinthine Government disclosure requirements.
Investment bankers, lawyers, auditors and representatives from an issuing company may spend days sitting in a printer's offices making last-minute changes to a hefty prospectus booklet for an initial public offering, which perhaps must be forwarded to other experts worldwide for proofreading, then back to the printer, and so on.
"It's a very involved, sensitive, highly confidential and emotionally charged process," said Carol Robbins, vice president for marketing and product development at Donnelley Financial.
Financial printers are also familiar with tight deadlines and global demands. For example, Ms. Robbins said, Donnelley Financial once had to print 200,000 copies of a 600-page prospectus in 72 hours, from scratch.
Yet some of the changes from the digital age may close in on the big printers faster than they can counter them. Electronic financial publishing needs more expertise than equipment, making it easier for law firms, smaller printers and clients themselves to join the fray.
"The competition is out there quite strongly," said Ivan Obolensky, a vice president and printing industry analyst at Shields & Company in New York. "There are an awful lot of mom and pops who can do something and chip away at the margins. And there are a lot of very good hotshot high-tech companies."
Companies that routinely offer debt offerings often have their own in-house Edgar filing systems, said David Rosenstein, a Bowne spokesman.
Printers also face competition from on-line initial public offering services. For example, IPO Data Systems Inc. of Elmhurst, Queens, sells -- for $100 a year -- a subscription to one-page profiles of initial public offerings, including company descriptions, financial basics, the primary underwriting groups, filing ranges or prices, uses of offering proceeds, and more. Alert-IPO! from Ostman of Torrance, Calif., sends information and analysis via E-mail on pending offerings for $34.95 a year. The Renaissance Capital Corporation of Greenwich, Conn., which has about 1,000 visitors a day to its free Web site (www.ipo-fund.com), also provides information on some initial public offerings.
Still, printers have made inroads by acquiring or investing in similar products. Bowne has a minority interest in Cybernet Data Systems of Wilton, Conn., developers of Edgar Online, a Web site that provides real-time Edgar filings for a monthly fee of $9.95.
In November, Bowne also acquired IDOC Inc. of Los Angeles, which provides language translation services for the computer industry.
In December, Donnelley Financial started IPO Prospectus, an interactive data base with information on all initial public offerings over the last three years (except for small-business corporations), with IPO Crossroads of San Francisco, a portfolio analysis company. Donnelley Financial also teamed up in May with Prospectus Plus of New York to offer multimedia CD-ROM's, on which financial information can be presented with video, animation and sound.
But paper still remains important in initial public offerings. According to the Securities Data Corporation, companies filing initial offerings from Jan. 1 to Oct. 1, 1996 (except for small-business corporations) spent more than $100 million to print prospectuses.
Still, it is no secret where growth potential in the initial public offering market lies. "The use of print will increase as the use of electronic information does," said Dick Vinocur, editor of Dick Vinocur's Footprints, a printing industry newsletter published in Fort Lee, N.J. "But I tend to believe that printing won't grow as fast as the electronic product. If you want information on any company, it's a lot easier going on the Net than calling up the company and getting a 10-K and a prospectus sent to you."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Despite the abundance of corporate information that is available on line, the leaders of the financial printing industry are flourishing. At the Secaucus, N.J., plant of one of the leaders, Bowne, a printer checked for flaws in a sheet from a prospectus being produced for a municipal fund client. (Norman Y. Lono for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Moving From the Card Catalogue to the Internet

BYLINE: By KATE MURPHY 

 BODY:
What is the gross national product of Belize? Who invented polyester? How smart is the average pig?
Five years ago, the best way to find answers to questions like these was to go to a library and ask the librarian for help in finding the appropriate books and periodicals. Today, the same information is available on the Internet, but finding it may still require the assistance of a librarian. 
 As technology has made more data available than can be bound in books or catalogued by the Dewey decimal system, the field of library science has changed drastically. While it is still a discipline dedicated to finding, filtering, organizing, evaluating and presenting information, it now requires a great deal more technical expertise with electronic information and computer networks. These new demands, in turn, have opened a raft of new career opportunities, attracting considerably more people to the profession over the last decade.
In response, many universities have converted their schools of library science into schools of information and library science or, increasingly, just schools of information.
"Information has always been the focus of library studies, but recent technological developments mean that there are now vast stores of information beyond what is contained within the walls of libraries," said C. Olivia Frost, associate dean of the University of Michigan's School of Information in Ann Arbor.
As a result, becoming a degreed librarian these days means taking courses like Implementation of Distributed Information Systems, Web Site Design and Network Management.
"A third of the titles currently on our list are about the Internet; that's up from zero six years ago," said Patricia Glass Schuman, president of Neal-Schuman Publishers Inc. in New York, a supplier of textbooks to library and information science schools.
With their technological expertise, fewer recent graduates of library and information science programs are actually becoming librarians. Take John Powell. After graduating from the University of Michigan School of Information last year, hebecame data base manager and Webmaster for the State Appellate Defenders Office in Detroit. "The field is rapidly expanding to include a wide range of career opportunities," he said. "It's not just cataloguing books anymore."
Mr. Powell's duties include maintaining a World Wide Web site linked to a data base of legal research as well as conducting Internet training seminars for defense lawyers throughout the state.
Although there are no comprehensive job placement statistics for graduates of library and information science schools, officials at the American Library Association have noticed a marked increase in the number of professionally trained librarians pursuing nontraditional, technologically oriented careers. "More and more, we're hearing titles like cybrarian, information specialist, Webmaster, knowledge navigator and data base manager," said Elizabeth Martinez, the association's executive director.
Administrators from top library and information science schools report a similar trend. "A growing percentage of our students graduate to work outside traditional library settings," said Brooke E. Sheldon, dean of the Graduate School of Library and Information Science at the University of Texas in Austin.
She estimated that nearly 25 percent of last year's graduating class went on to nontraditional library jobs like information brokers and network managers, while her counterparts at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, the University of Michigan and the University of Illinois at Champaign-Urbana gave numbers of 30 percent and 40 percent. In the late 1980's, only 2 percent to 9 percent of library science graduates took such nontraditional jobs.
"There is high demand today for people who understand how to find, organize and distribute knowledge," said Lois Remeikas, who as director of knowledge and information management for Booz Allen & Hamilton, a consulting firm, has watched her department double in the last two years.
Indeed, companies like Monsanto, Ford Motor, Microsoft, Intel and CNA Insurance have begun to intensively recruit library and information science graduates to fill such positions as scientific searcher, configuration manager, records management analyst and graphic multimedia designer.
In a shift from the past, corporate representatives now show up regularly at library and information science schools to attract students and, in the case of CNA Insurance, have even set up special internship programs.
"Industry has come to realize the competitive advantage of hiring professionals who not only know how to find strategic information quickly, but how to evaluate its validity and present it coherently," said Lynn Eastabrook, dean of the University of Illinois School of Information and Library Science.
The recent increase in job opportunities for library and information science specialists has inspired more people to enter the field. The American Library Association's figures indicate that this year's total enrollment at schools of library and information science in the United States and Canada is up 47 percent from 1986. And membership in the association itself has swelled to 58,112 in 1996 from 42,361 in 1986 -- an increase of 37 percent.
The trend is even more striking at some individual institutions. For example, the University of Texas has twice as many library and information science students now as it did in 1990. And applications for admission to the University of Michigan's School of Information are up 50 percent for the latest class over the previous year's class.
Also, more men are showing interest in what was once considered a woman's career. Most library and information science schools report a 10 percent increase in male students within the last five years.
Mr. Powell, at the Appellate Defenders Office in Detroit, said the field's new emphasis on information technology, particularly related to computers, had changed the image of library science. No longer is it seen as the occupation of spectacled spinsters who delight in telling people to hush.
"Because of the important and crucial role they are able to play in this complex information age, there's new zip to the stereotypical profile of a librarian," Dean Sheldon at the University of Texas said.

Librarians are now being referred to as information specialists, cybrarians, data base managers and knowledge navigators. (Peter Yates for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: America's Obligation to the U.N.

 BODY:
When the Clinton Administration announced last May that it would veto Boutros Boutros-Ghali for a second term as United Nations Secretary General, American officials said his removal was necessary to persuade Congress to pay the billion or so dollars in dues the United States owes the U.N. Washington got its way and Mr. Boutros-Ghali was replaced by Kofi Annan, who is highly respected in Washington and elsewhere.
Yet some Congressional Republicans are unwilling to pay the debt until Mr. Annan carries out major structural reforms. The Administration rightly expects that Mr. Annan will be a more effective advocate than Mr. Boutros-Ghali for reforming an organization that is patronage-ridden, bureaucratic and still keyed to a world dominated by the cold war. But withholding the dues is counterproductive. The Administration, while continuing to press vigorously for reform, must make good on its implicit promise and persuade Congress to pay up now. 
 The man who has taken the dues hostage is Senator Jesse Helms, the chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee. Mr. Helms advocates cuts that would truly cripple the U.N., which is not surprising considering his view of the U.N. and most international agreements and treaties as dangerous infringements on American sovereignty.
Mr. Annan deserves the benefit of the doubt. He has an excellent record as an administrator and detailed knowledge of the U.N. He has repeatedly said that reform is his top priority. Clinton Administration officials say the failure to pay up undercuts their own efforts to press for an end to waste and inefficiency at the U.N. Anger over the debt cost the United States its place on the committee that oversees the organization's budget. An early retirement program for a few hundred U.N. staff members considered less productive was stalled by a lack of funds. When Administration officials try to enlist Western European allies in reform programs, they get a lecture on the American debt.
Although more needs to be done to reform the U.N., Mr. Boutros-Ghali did more than any other Secretary General. He cut the New York staff by one-third. He created the office of inspector general, which has uncovered and corrected inefficiency. He installed Joseph Connor, an American who formerly led the accounting firm of Price Waterhouse, as chief financial officer. Mr. Connor has greatly improved administration of the U.N.
Mr. Annan's task is to build on these achievements. There are, for example, six different organizations working on economic development that might be consolidated. More important than simply shrinking the U.N., however, is making it more effective in a world where the end of the cold war changed many things. The U.N.'s development organizations must be reoriented toward the challenges posed by the now-widespread acceptance of market economics. The end of East-West conflict allows the U.N. to more effectively control regional arms races and threats like chemical and biological weapons.
Mr. Annan brings considerable strengths to the task of reform. The U.N. staff trusts him and member states respect him. He has spent decades acquiring an intimate knowledge of the organization in several posts, including controller.
But Mr. Annan's reach is limited. He has no power to touch independent agencies like Unesco. On big reforms he can only make suggestions that must be approved by member states. His commitment to reform is only as good as theirs, and many nations have balked at changes that threaten their use of the U.N. as a patronage pit. The United States has been as guilty of this as any other nation. The solution is for all countries to join in allowing the Secretary General to choose quality candidates for U.N. posts, rather than pushing their own nationals.
Reforming the U.N. requires the cooperation of its members. The United States, which has done more than any other nation to foster reform, can help now by paying its dues.

HEADLINE: Free Trade Goes South With or Without U.S.

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: MIAMI, Jan. 5

 BODY:
Just over two years ago, President Clinton emerged from a meeting with 33 Western Hemisphere leaders and made an ambitious pledge. By 2005, he promised, a "Free Trade Area of the Americas would stretch from Alaska to Argentina" and "will be the world's largest market."
Since then, barriers to trade and investment have indeed begun to topple, thanks to the dozens of agreements that Latin American and Caribbean countries are signing with one another. 
 For its part, though, the United States has mostly been sitting on the sidelines, hobbled by what Latin American officials and trade experts describe as a lack of will, leadership and commitment.
"What we are seeing is the consequences of two years of drift," said Robert A. Pastor, director of the Latin America and Caribbean programs at the Carter Center in Atlanta. "Every previous administration was hungry for an opportunity like this, but Latin America wasn't ripe for it. Now that Latin America is genuinely interested, the United States has been out of focus."
The resulting vacuum, largely the product of American electoral politics and the Mexican financial crisis, has quickly been filled by countries like Brazil and Argentina.
Putting aside their historic rivalry, South America's two giants have aggressively taken the lead by forging a four-nation market called Mercosur -- a Spanish contraction of Common Market of the South -- with more than 240 million people, a total annual output of $1 trillion and a definition of free trade somewhat different from Washington's.
Already the world's fourth-largest unified market, Mercosur is deep in negotiations with the European Union and with neighboring groups in Latin America.
In addition, the Prime Ministers of Japan and China and the President of South Korea have all made state visits to Latin America in the last few months, looking for opportunities in an area they long viewed as a United States preserve. Taiwan's Prime Minister is scheduled to do the same soon.
"What is in fact in the making is a South American Free Trade Area," said Marcos Rodriguez Mendoza, a Venezuelan economist who is the chief trade adviser to the Organization of American States. Economic integration is becoming a "reality," he said, with or without Washington.
In Central America and the Caribbean, a similar process is under way, driven largely by the Clinton Administration's failure to keep its promise to extend to those regions the benefits enjoyed by Mexico and Canada, Washington's partners in the North American Free Trade Agreement.
As a result of Washington's inaction, the regional groups to which those small countries belong are now seeking agreements of their own with Canada and Mexico, as well as with Mercosur, the European Union and East Asia.
"I think everybody in the hemisphere is keeping all options open," said Richard Bernal, Jamaica's Ambassador to the United States and chairman of the working group for small nations set up at the Miami meeting. "While the United States is the main trade partner, if Nafta does not look like it's going to permit accession in the foreseeable future, then countries have to keep other countries in mind, including relations outside the hemisphere."
Even a cursory glance at trade figures reveals that Washington's economic stake in Latin American and the Caribbean, the fastest-growing market for American exports, is enormous. United States trade within the Western Hemisphere is not only much larger than trade with Europe or Asia, but consistently registers a surplus that helps offset large deficits elsewhere.
An American trade official who deals with Latin America said the Clinton Administration viewed the spread of regional agreements that excluded Washington not as a challenge to American leadership but as something that "can be very helpful to the Free Trade Area of the Americas process."
When Latin American nations link up among themselves, he added, "it makes it easier for them to go the last step," when the time comes to deal with the United States.
"Frankly," the official continued, "we would be doing that ourselves if we had the authority. We are not as far along in the process as we would like to have been."
Chile, which has emerged from military dictatorship to have the fastest-growing economy in Latin America, provides perhaps the best example of United States disengagement and the resulting shifts in economic strategy.
At the 1994 Summit of the Americas meeting here in Miami, the leaders of the three Nafta countries announced plans to expand their group to include Chile through a "fast track" process, with that country's President, Eduardo Frei Ruiz-Tagle, looking on.
"We have been the Three Amigos," Prime Minister Jean Chretien of Canada proclaimed. "Now we will be the Four Amigos."
But a week later, the Mexican peso collapsed. That forced the United States into a controversial bailout of its Nafta partner and made fast-track membership for Chile politically unpalatable. Then the American election cycle began, killing any chance for bold measures on trade.
In response to what it perceived as America's lack of interest, Chile has negotiated a free trade agreement with Mercosur and revived its ties with the five-member Andean Pact, which this fall began separate talks with Mercosur. Chile recently signed a free trade agreement with Canada to supplement a similar accord it has with Mexico, which had already reached free trade agreements with Colombia and Venezuela.
"The Chileans have been kept standing at the church, waiting for the groom to arrive," said Bernard W. Aronson, who was Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs during the Bush Administration. "After a while, to maintain your own dignity, you take off the wedding dress and go find another boyfriend."
With Mr. Clinton about to begin a second term, the next few months will be crucial to bringing the United States back into the process, government officials and economists throughout the hemisphere said. "We can no longer postpone taking decisions on certain important things," said Ambassador Bernal of Jamaica.
Latin American and Caribbean countries will be looking, their leaders make clear, for evidence of American commitment to reviving the fast-track process, either in the President's State of the Union Address or when President Frei visits the United States in late February.
"If you say no to Chile, you have said no to free trade," said the Foreign Minister of one medium-sized Latin American country. "It is a litmus test." The 2005 deadline remains attainable, the official added, "that is, if you are still interested."
At a conference in Miami on Thursday, Thomas F. McLarty, the former White House chief of staff who is Mr. Clinton's point man on Latin American issues, said the Administration remained committed to free trade and would "continue to lay the legal and economic framework for Chile's accession to Nafta, including fast-track."
If the hemisphere fails to build on the principles of the Miami conference, he said, "we may lose this moment forever."
But Foreign Minister Jose Miguel Insulza of Chile said membership in Nafta no longer "has either the urgency or the importance it had in 1994." Over the last two years, he added, "our country's position has consolidated internationally and we have signed agreements of great scope."
As a result, government officials and trade analysts say, it is more likely that negotiations will take place between two or more blocs or regions than that Latin American countries will come hat in hand, one after another, asking permission to join Nafta.
One indication of Latin America's growing confidence came recently when President Carlos Saul Menem of Argentina jokingly said before heading off for a visit to Washington that if the United States and its Nafta partners wished to join Mercosur, they would be welcome to do so.

HEADLINE: Abroad at Home;
Immune to Reason

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS 

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
Why are Americans so cynical about government these days? Scholars and commentators deplore the phenomenon, but sometimes the public has reasons for its feeling. Consider what has just happened on the issue of marijuana use for medical purposes.
The voters of California and Arizona, by large margins, approved ballot initiatives to let doctors recommend marijuana for pain relief and other medical purposes. The Clinton Administration's response, announced last week, was to say that the referendums would be overriden by the Federal policy on marijuana: total prohibition of its possession or use for any purpose. 
 The reasons given by Administration officials for their decision were so thin as to evoke cynical reactions. Gen. Barry R. McCaffrey, the White House drug czar, said many voters in California and Arizona were "asleep at the switch" in approving "hoax referendums." In other words, voters can be disregarded as fools when they disagree with us.
The most regrettable aspect of the Administration response was its dismissive treatment of the medical issues. General McCaffrey said that marijuana had no demonstrated medical benefit that was not available from other drugs. "America has gone way beyond smoking dope to manage pain," he said.
Many doctors -- and patients -- disagree. They claim that marijuana eases the nausea that may accompany chemotherapy, and controls vomiting that may cause dangerous weight loss in AIDS patients. Another use is to treat the eye disease glaucoma.
In fact, the Federal Government has approved an anti-nausea medicine, dronabinol, that includes marijuana's active chemical ingredient. But some of the patients who have tried it say it is less effective, and far more expensive.
The medical claims and counter-claims are just that: claims. They have never been resolved by approved scientific methods. And the Administration response effectively blocked what could have been a highly useful test of the claims in Arizona and California.
"The door is open to examine any drug," General McCaffrey said, including marijuana. Donna E. Shalala, Secretary of Health and Human Services, said, "The National Institutes of Health will continue to review the claims about the possible benefit of smoked marijuana for a small number of indications."
But there was cold comfort for scientists in those statements. Indeed, it is not unfair to label them hypocritical. For the Government has done all it can, over many years, to prevent any fair test of the medical claims for marijuana.
Senator Orrin Hatch, Republican of Utah, who organized a quick Senate hearing last month to scorn the two state referendums, said that the Drug Enforcement Administration had looked into the claims in 1987-88 and found "no legitimate medical use for marijuana." Its inquiry, he said, had been "under the guidance of an administrative law judge."
But in a perceptive commentary in The New Yorker last week, Hendrik Hertzberg noted that Senator Hatch had left out a rather important fact. The administrative law judge, Francis L. Young, had reached the opposite conclusion.
"The evidence in this record clearly shows that marijuana has been accepted as capable of relieving the distress of great numbers of very ill people," Judge Young found, "and doing so with safety under medical supervision." The D.E.A. overruled him.
The Clinton Administration was not alone in its reaction to the state referendums. Conservatives who usually talk about states' rights cheered the Clinton decision to override state law.
The reason is no secret. Drugs arouse paranoia in politicians. That is why, for many decades, drug policy has been immune to examination in the light of reason and experience.
"Instead of demonizing marijuana, America's Government should take the opportunity to find out if it has any medical value." That statement was made not in some radical paper but in The Economist of London. It said the issue should be approached scientifically, and the way to start was "not to crush the experiments in California and Arizona but to monitor them." For our political leaders, that is too rational.

HEADLINE: Reporter's Notebook;
Glimpse of the President Through a Tinted Glass

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: SMITH BAY, St. Thomas, V.I. Jan. 5

 BODY:
His woes have made Fatman almost slender, but they did not stop him from trying to brighten President Clinton's vacation here.
"Hail To The Chief Love Fatman Family," read the construction-paper sign in black marker, one of the few greetings along Mr. Clinton's motorcade route here. 
 "I was welcoming the President of the United States," Fatman said simply, as his chihuaha, Chi Chi, cautiously sniffed a stranger's toes on Saturday morning.
Fatman, a six-footer whose given name is Richard Husband, weighs about 210 pounds. "I was 300 pounds, man," he said sadly, in a gentle Caribbean accent. "Look at me. Stress."
"Fatman's," his nightclub, never recovered from Hurricane Hugo in 1989. Out back, boards from the roof of his band shell are still scattered on the ground, and the only entertainment on display before the empty wooden bleachers is an aged Chevy Nova, rusting away on cinder blocks.
Mr. Husband has been unable to get any Government help to restore his club, and has gone into default. He did not appear to expect help from Mr. Clinton, who is vacationing here. But he said he liked the President because "he means well."
"Of all the Presidents, to me, it seems like he gives everybody a chance," he said.
Mr. Husband said he had watched as Mr. Clinton's motorcade swept past his sign one day, and he was pretty sure that he glimpsed the President through tinted glass. Someone, he remembered with a smile, even tooted the horn.

A Peripatetic President
As President, Mr. Clinton, who returned to Washington today after four days here, has proved a rootless vacationer.
Unlike George Bush, he cannot escape to a beloved ancestral estate like Kennebunkport, Me. Nor has Mr. Clinton found a cherished, if borrowed, retreat, like Harry Truman's "Little White House," the commandant's residence on the Key West naval base.
Instead, Mr. Clinton and his family have roamed the land, passing through a series of borrowed and rented homes and hotel rooms.
Mr. Clinton came to St. Thomas, aides said, because the Gores recommended it. They stayed a couple of years ago in the same home that the Clintons used this time, the Sand Dollar Villa, overlooking a 30-yard stretch of private beach on Magens Bay. Mr. Clinton plans to report the value of the stay on his income taxes as a gift.
The surroundings may have been unfamiliar, but the Clintons easily made themselves at home. They spent their four days here swimming, playing cards and reading, with the President occasionally vanishing for a round of golf. Mr. Clinton, his aides said, declared that a day spent snorkling from a catamaran had been "perfect."

The Clintons' Night Out
Most efforts by merchants to tempt Mr. Clinton out of his family cocoon for a visit failed. But he caught at least one local proprietor completely off guard. At about 10 on Saturday night, Secret Service officers poured into Eunice's Terrace ("A West Indian Dining Experience").
Eunice Best, the owner, thought as they vanished into her bathrooms and kitchen that they were just protecting the President's motorcade route, which passed her door. Then a man in a tie walked up and told her the Clintons were coming.
"I just went to pieces," she said. "I started crying." While the Clintons ate, she telephoned her mother with the news.
Sitting beneath a squealing ceiling fan, the Clintons shared some conch appetizers. Mrs. Clinton had a vegetable plate, while Mr. Clinton ordered the catch of the day, a fish called the "Old Wife."
Mr. Clinton declared that he loved the Old Wife.

A Model News Program
Sorry, but culinary bulletins were the kind of details that the White House Press corps, biting its nails in paradise, had to make do with here. Guiltily responding to the tug of work amid parasailing and snorkeling expeditions, reporters scratched for news, with meager results. When one Clinton aide announced that "there's an unconfirmed report that the President saw a barracuda yesterday," Bill Plante, of CBS, interjected: "CNN has interviewed the barracuda."
But one reporter has found more than enough exciting news in the Presidential visit: the "Good News Guy," Alexander Randall 5th. Mr. Randall broadcasts Good News Headlines on WSTA, an AM radio station here. "We don't do fires, we don't do murders, and we don't do a lot of other dumb stuff that's typically news," said Mr. Randall, who described his four-minute, daily segment as "upbeat, positive, hero-oriented news."
Mr. Randall started his program after Hurricane Marilyn ripped through the islands in September 1995, because residents needed a pick-me-up, he said, and because so many heroic volunteers poured out of the woodwork.
The result is a program that any vacationer, and particularly any vacationing President, would love.
This was the opening of Mr. Randall's Jan. 2 report: "Good morning, Mr. President, here's your special report. Bosnia is O.K.; Peru is better. Israel and the Palestinians are not O.K., but you can't fix that today. The American economy is O.K., the American people are O.K., too. Weather today should be clear and sunny, with a high around 85 degrees. Take another round of golf, and go for a swim."

GRAPHIC: Photo: President Clinton on the beach at Magen's Bay in St. Thomas, V.I., on Saturday. The Clintons wound up a five-day vacation yesterday. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: A Hint on Rates By Fed Official

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 5

 BODY:
The economy is growing slowly enough, and with inflation sufficiently in check, to keep the Federal Reserve from raising the Federal funds rate on overnight bank loans anytime soon, a Federal Reserve governor suggested today.
"We're looking at measures of core inflation which are still declining," Laurence Meyer, the governor, said. "So while there may be some danger in the forecasts, it's enough to keep us on alert, but not enough to take us off the sideline." 
 After expanding at close to a 3 percent annual rate in the fourth quarter of 1996, growth should slow to a rate of 2 percent to 2.5 percent this year and next, Mr. Meyer said at the American Economic Association conference here.
Forecasts by Fed officials of 2.5 percent or slower growth, unaccompanied by inflation warnings, are usually interpreted by analysts as signals that rates will not be changed.
The Fed's Open Market Committee, which sets interest-rate policy, next meets for two days beginning Feb. 4.

HEADLINE: World Helps to Rebuild Bosnia, but Work Is Slow

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5

 BODY:
A year after the United States and other donors pledged nearly $2 billion to rebuild Bosnia, most of the country remains in tatters, international aid organizations and Clinton Administration officials say.
But as the World Bank and the European Union, which are overseeing the rebuilding effort, prepare to ask countries this week for $1.4 billion to keep the work going for another year, they say that the process so far has gone as well as can be expected and that Bosnians should see better living conditions this year. 
 The European Union, the United States, dozens of other countries and aid groups pledged $1.8 billion last year to a projected four-year, $5.1 billion plan to get Bosnia's economy working, repair the worst of the war damage and set up a government.
Two-thirds of the $1.8 billion has been spent or soon will be, and the rest is expected to be used this year.
Officials involved in the effort said that considerable progress had been made in developing programs to fix roads, bridges and housing, and that the decimated economy was twitching back to life.
But they acknowledged that the progress had only partly filtered through to most Bosnians, especially those who had been forced from their homes and now have no houses or jobs to return to.
Unemployment is estimated by the World Bank to be 50 to 60 percent. Many houses still do not have heat. Most of the biggest industries are dormant, the central bank is not yet operating and officials have limited skills in managing a market economy, since the country was part of Communist Yugoslavia.
The reconstruction work under way is only a fraction of what is needed. "Despite the first results that are now beginning to emerge, the reconstruction needs remain vast," says a report prepared by the World Bank and the European Union for a two-day meeting of donors that is to start on Thursday in Brussels.
"Industrial production is still only at 10 to 15 percent of its prewar level, unemployment is unbearably high, hundreds of thousands of people are without permanent housing and many communities continue to lack basic social services," the report says.
Since fighting ended in 1995, American and European officials have said a lasting peace would be possible in Bosnia only if economic and social stability could be restored quickly. When he announced two months ago that American troops would remain in Bosnia through the middle of next year, President Clinton cited the need to see more economic progress as a main reason for his decision.
"Quite frankly, rebuilding the fabric of Bosnia's economic and political life is taking longer than anticipated," Mr. Clinton said. "Economic activity is only just resuming. Its pace must be quickened and its reach extended."
Despite some grumbling from the United States and other countries about the pace of the rebuilding effort, American and European officials said they expected to be able to reach the target of $1.4 billion in international donations for 1997.
But they said that most countries would be less willing to contribute in future years and that it was unclear whether the formerly warring parties in Bosnia would be able to continue the process effectively on their own as international aid dried up.
International officials remain dismayed by the squabbling among the Bosnian Muslims, Croats and Serbs, which delayed the formation of a government by several months last year and led to disagreements over specific projects.
Plans to patch up the phone system stalled because of the unwillingness of the ethnic groups to share control or even to agree on a single international dialing code for telephone calls. The rail line between Sarajevo and the Adriatic port of Ploce was repaired, but disagreements between Muslim and Croatian officials kept regular service from being resumed.
But officials said that in general the work was proceeding as fast as could be expected, given the complexities of formulating rebuilding plans, coordinating the efforts of the many donors and creating almost from scratch the institutions necessary to support a market economy.
"It's a process both of having to reform Tito's socialism and undertake the physical reconstruction of a decimated place," said one senior American official involved in the process. "It's inherently difficult, and it's all being undertaken at a time when the three parties are not cooperating."
Indeed, American and other international officials said the current four-year aid program would be only the start of a long and slow process.
The $5.1 billion that donor countries plan to spend would cover only a quarter of the estimated war damages. And officials at the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund said that even if all went smoothly in the next few years, they would expect per capita income to reach only two-thirds of its prewar levels by 2000.
Although unemployment is as high as 60 percent, it is down from 90 percent at the end of the war. For those Bosnians who are working, wages have tripled, to an average of a little more than $100 a month. The Government is negotiating an agreement with the International Monetary Fund for long-term financial support, and other governments and international banks are expected to give Bosnia a break on its prewar debts this year.
The economic situation is best in Croatian-controlled areas, where the European Union and the World Bank report that industrial production is running at 85 percent of its prewar level and wages now stand at more than $200 a month. It is bleakest in the Serbian-controlled region, which has so far received little international assistance because its leaders have intermittently defied the terms of the Dayton peace accords.

HEADLINE: Leaders Meet But Can't Lift Hebron Crisis

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN 

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, Jan. 5

 BODY:
Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, met covertly in the predawn darkness today, but failed to keep the meeting secret and to overcome remaining hurdles to a Hebron deal.
The meeting at the Erez Checkpoint to the Gaza Strip reportedly lasted four hours and was attended by close aides and by Dennis Ross, the special United States envoy for the Middle East. 
 Mr. Ross was said to have arranged the extraordinary session in an attempt to crack the disagreements that have bedeviled efforts for three months now to arrange an Israeli withdrawal from most of Hebron.
Israeli and Palestinian officials say the remaining disputes are less over Hebron than over a blueprint for subsequent Israeli troop pullbacks from the West Bank outlined under existing Israeli-Palestinian agreements. The plan, known among the negotiators as the "road map," is to be drafted by the United States and appended to the Hebron agreement.
In a speech to Israeli businessmen in Tel Aviv this evening, Mr. Netanyahu acknowledged that he had hoped to keep the meeting a secret.
"I met, last night, with Yasir Afafat at the Erez Checkpoint," he said. "I had hoped that the meeting would remain confidential since it seems to me that it is paramount that there also be meetings which help build trust and working relations.
"I believe there are meetings which do not have to withstand the lightning flash of cameras, that these matters have their time and place," he said. "At the moment, we have to solve problems. It was with the attempt of solving these for which this meeting, which to my regret was leaked, was held."
Mr. Netanyahu told the businessmen that he hoped in his next meeting with them to show progress both in the economy and in the peace, adding that "perhaps there will be a few surprises in this process." He gave no further clue.
The acknowledgment of the secret meeting could well prove an embarrassment to Mr. Netanyahu, whose election campaign last spring focused heavily on accusing his opponent, former Prime Minister Shimon Peres, of too close a relationship with Mr. Arafat. Mr. Netanyahu has officially met Mr. Arafat three times, all in the past four months, and they are not known to have held any previous secret meetings.
The fact that Mr. Netanyahu was prepared to meet with Mr. Arafat under cover of darkness reflected how far the conservative Israeli Prime Minister had come in accepting the Palestinian leader as an unavoidable partner in forging a peace.
Mr. Arafat's spokesman, Nabil Abu Rudeineh, issued a brief statement confirming that a meeting had taken place from 2 A.M. to 6 A.M. "Both leaders discussed all disputed issues but the leaders were unable to bridge all gaps," he said. "Contacts and efforts will continue until we close a deal."
Mr. Ross continued his mediation efforts today, and there were rumors that Mr. Netanyahu and Mr. Arafat would meet again. But officials denied it, and there was no indication of a followup meeting.
The main remaining difference is said to be Mr. Arafat's insistence on firm dates for further Israeli withdrawals from the West Bank, which under the existing agreements were to take place in three stages ending next September. Mr. Netanyahu has agreed to set a date for the first stage, but not for subsequent ones.
Instead, Israeli television reported this evening, Mr. Netanyahu has offered Mr. Arafat a firm date for releasing Palestinian women prisoners, as well as a schedule to open discussion on a Palestinian airport, a seaport and a transit route between Gaza and the West Bank. The women were supposed to have been released and the "safe passage" route was to have come into being with the signing of the Israeli-Palestinian agreement of September 1995.
In another development, the chief Palestinian negotiator, Saeb Erekat, said that despite the delays on the Hebron redeployment, an agreement would be signed on Monday in Jericho to station 210 international observers in Hebron once Israeli troops pull back. He said the observers are to come from Denmark, Italy, Norway, Sweden, Switzerland and Turkey.
Observers from Norway are already stationed in Hebron, but their presence has not made a perceptible impact.
Also today, Jewish settlers removed mobile homes from a hilltop in the West Bank, peacefully concluding a demonstration to back their demands for new settlement construction. The settlers had moved the trailers onto a hilltop near their settlement, Beit El, on Friday, briefly raising the possibility of a conflict with the Israeli police.
The protest was the first direct challenge to Mr. Netanyahu by the settlers, who have been frustrated by his failure to authorize a large-scale expansion of Jewish settlements like the ones set up by previous Likud governments. The demonstration was led by Yoel Tsur, a Beit El resident whose wife and son were killed by Palestinian gunmen last month.
The protest was defused when Defense Minister Yitzhak Mordechai, whose ministry is responsible for authorizing any settlements on occupied Palestinian lands, agreed to meet with the settlers.
"It was a very good meeting," Mr. Mordechai said. "I came to hear their essential needs, which will be discussed in a serious manner."
Mr. Tsur said Mr. Mordechai had promised an answer "tomorrow or in two days" on the question of expanding the settlement. One proposed compromise would be to allow the settlers to move into parts of an Israeli Army base near their settlement. But even that would be certain to meet strong resistance from the Palestinians, who view any expansion of the Jewish presence in the West Bank as a provocation.
Since taking office, Mr. Netanyahu has authorized some growth within existing settlements, but he has not allowed building on any additional land.

HEADLINE: Korean-American Exodus Continues in Los Angeles

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 5

 BODY:
Business was slow on New Year's Day at Peter and Nancy Park's budget clothing stall in South-Central Los Angeles, the morning after a gang fight several stalls away left one brawler dead of a gunshot wound.
Surveying piles of $10 shirts and $15 trousers in the middle of a yellow, cinder block warehouse full of other vendors, Mr. Park described the arson that devastated his business in the 1992 riots here, and the $41,000 debt that prevents him from opening a business elsewhere. 
 "If we could, we would go, of course," Mr. Park said.
Korean-Americans are continuing to move or close their small businesses in South-Central Los Angeles nearly five years after riots destroyed hundreds of their stores in neighborhoods mainly occupied by black and some Hispanic people. Small furniture outlets, groceries and other shops are increasingly being opened by Korean-Americans in the city's relatively prosperous northern and western neighborhoods, even as similar businesses are sold or closed in the city's blighted center.
And many Korean-American business owners who have managed to rebuild riot-scarred stores still express a desire to leave the area, suggesting that the exodus may continue for years to come.
The riots broke out on April 29, 1992, after a largely white jury acquitted four white police officers of assault charges in the beating of a black man, Rodney G. King. But Korean-American business owners bore the brunt of the looting in South-Central Los Angeles. A white judge two weeks earlier had given probation to a Korean grocer convicted of manslaughter in the shooting death of a 15-year-old black girl. And Korean-Americans ran the bulk of the grocery and liquor stores in the area, making them vulnerable.
Rioters burned 700 Korean businesses, inflicting $150 million in damage to property, almost none of it insured. Of the 53 people killed in the rioting, one was Korean.
While there are few statistics on Korean-American businesses, community leaders and economic development experts say that the number of businesses owned by Korean-Americans in South-Central Los Angeles has dropped by a quarter to a half since the riots, and is still falling.
Some say that the exodus may limit future problems.
"The black-Korean controversy has dissipated because the fuel has been removed," said Ronald K. Wakabayashi, the executive director of the Los Angeles County Commission on Human Relations, a county government agency.
But many community leaders remain worried that relations between blacks and the remaining Korean-Americans are still poor. "There's just this kind of guarded relationship that I don't think anybody can claim has improved since 1992," said Joe R. Hicks, a former co-chairman of the Los Angeles Black-Korean Alliance, a group that broke up a few months after the 1992 riots.
Korean-American business owners and economic development experts cite several reasons for the continued exodus. Fears of renewed violence linger.
The area's population and buying power are eroding as thousands of middle-class and working-class blacks are moving out to the city's eastern suburbs or to the southeastern United States. While many Hispanic people are moving into South-Central Los Angeles, particularly the more eastern neighborhoods, they are not as numerous as the blacks who are leaving. And the new Hispanic residents have tended to patronize Hispanic merchants.
Uichin Ho, who emigrated from Seoul in 1977 and now owns four laundromats in gritty neighborhoods in South-Central Los Angeles, said that a drop in the area's population was a big problem. Pausing on New Year's Day while cleaning one of his laundries, several miles west of the Park family's clothing stall, he gestured at a row of recently installed dryers and complained that they had not increased his business at all.
"A lot of people, not only Koreans, left here," Mr. Ho said. "Before the riot, when you try to occupy an apartment, they want you to bring an application -- now they say one or three months' free rent."
Yet the riots do not appear to have hurt the long-term economic strength of the Korean-American community in Los Angeles, which holds almost 400,000 of the nation's 1.5 million people of Korean descent. The neighborhood popularly known here as Koreatown, which lies between South-Central Los Angeles and the city's more affluent northern and western neighborhoods, has recovered from looting in the riots and is now packed with two-story mini-malls.
A profusion of business signs in both English and Korean is spreading north and west from Koreatown, and Korean-Americans have been opening businesses in adjacent communities like Hollywood.
Many of the remaining Korean Americans in South-Central Los Angeles are trying to save money as quickly as possible so they can move elsewhere. Mr. Park even objected to a recent police crackdown on drug dealers in his area, saying that it had hurt his men's clothing business.
"The government starts squeezing, squeezing, squeezing, and one by one they go," he said. "Guys used to come in with bundles of $100 bills and buy everything."
