HEADLINE: CONGRESS IS POISED FOR FRUITFUL YEAR AFTER SOME TESTS

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5

 BODY:
As a new Congress convenes on Tuesday vowing to cut taxes, tame Medicare spending and balance the Federal budget, many in the Capitol believe the elements of success are in alignment for the first time in years, but only if the lawmakers can first deal with explosive ethical issues involving campaign finance and Speaker Newt Gingrich.
The path of the new Congress is likely to be charted in its first weeks, when the House is expected to hold extraordinary public hearings and debate the fate of Mr. Gingrich. Perhaps a month later, in late February or early March, the Senate Governmental Affairs Committee will publicly investigate possible campaign-spending abuses by the Democratic Party, the White House and, probably, by Republicans as well. 
 But if Congress can address such combustible issues without burning all bridges between the two parties, it could be extraordinarily productive, some leaders say.
"The President has now said, 'Look, I've got all my politics behind me now; I don't have to operate from a political point of view,' " Representative Dick Armey of Texas, the majority leader, said today on the "Fox News Sunday" program. " 'Let's get down to the legislative work.' And he's anxious to do it, and we're anxious to get back to it as well."
At the top of a legislative agenda nearly as ambitious as the one Republicans brought with them two years ago are a balanced-budget amendment to the Constitution, a binding plan to erase the deficit by 2002, an overhaul of the Federal health-care system, and tax cuts for families, small businesses and investors.
Democrats would add the partial restoration of welfare benefits cut by legislation that President Clinton signed into law last summer. Some in both parties demand an overhaul of campaign-spending laws.
Much in the new Congress augurs well for optimists. There are lots of new faces: 1 of every 5 members is a freshman, nearly as many as in 1994. Excepting those House members who rose to the Senate, none carries scars from the last four years of political garrotting on Capitol Hill.
The timing is also right. At the White House, President Clinton has been transformed from election-year rival to lame duck in need of Congress's help to win a place in history. In the Capitol, the populist fires that led Republicans into disastrous confrontations in 1995 and 1996 appear banked.
The politics have changed, too. The balance of legislative power has shifted to the Senate, where the Republican majority leader, Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, likes to cut deals. The House, where the November elections cut deeply into the Republicans' dominance, is a chastened place where moderates of both parties may comprise the margins of victory or defeat.
"You can do one of two things with a smaller majority," said Representative David L. Hobson, an influential Republican from Ohio. "You can try to force all your people in line, which is very difficult to do. Or you can build more consensus-oriented legislation and move it through."
He added, "It'll be less confrontational this time, it appears."
That remains to be seen. In the House, many Democrats believe little can be accomplished as long as Mr. Gingrich remains Speaker.
In the Senate, Mr. Lott's bent toward bargaining may be more than offset by the November election results, which vastly widened the ideological gulf separating Republicans and Democrats.
Republicans not only increased their majority by two seats, to 55, but also replaced a throng of moderates who had retired with conservatives from Mr. Gingrich's take-no-prisoners school of politics. Several come directly from the Speaker's House ranks, including Senators Sam Brownback of Kansas, Wayne Allard of Colorado and Tim Hutchinson of Arkansas.
Democrats not only lost some moderate seats to Republicans, but also replaced some of their own moderates with more liberal members in states like Georgia, Louisiana and New Jersey.
All that suggests that the 1997 Senate will look a good deal more like the 1994 House -- more partisan, more ideological and less obliging to the dying tradition of comity.
Another open question, at least in Republican minds, is what will come of Mr. Clinton's pledge to cooperate and compromise. Republican leaders have made it clear that they will not attempt politically difficult initiatives like changes in Medicare or the cost-of-living index, unless the White House takes the lead; memories of Mr. Clinton's virulent attacks on the Republicans' Medicare plan last year are too fresh.
The budget, both sides say, will be the proving ground for many promises. Fiscal issues dominate the list of items that are likely to be addressed early.
If tradition holds, Mr. Clinton will offer his proposed budget in early February for the 1998 fiscal year, which begins on Oct. 1. Unlike the last two years, Republicans may not dismiss it out of hand, because both parties purport to see a chance this year for agreement on a credible plan to erase the Federal deficit, perhaps by 2002.
Republicans believe they have a hammer in the negotiations this time: a constitutional amendment ordering the Government to keep balanced books. A proposed amendment sailed through the House in 1995 and missed Senate passage by a single vote; this year the House vote may be closer, but the Senate could have a vote or two to burn.
Even if a hammer worked, it might not be needed. Mr. Clinton has already promised to submit a balanced-budget plan, as he did last year. And while Republicans spurned it then, partly because it employed an economic forecast they regarded as too rosy, much of that forecast has since come to pass. Indeed, the Congressional Budget Office, the Capitol's economic seer, is expected to issue similar projections in a few weeks. That would close an $80 billion gap between the two parties' budget proposals.
"You could see us coming out with budgets much closer to each other," said Mr. Hobson, a member of the House Budget Committee. "Maybe we could even make a deal."
Still, the hardest parts of a deal -- tough choices over where to spend and how much -- remain unsettled.
Republicans argued last year that Mr. Clinton's budget relied on vague spending cuts that were unlikely to occur and "temporary" tax cuts that were sure to become permanent.
A similar dispute haunts Medicare, the single biggest source of potential savings, where the fund for paying hospital bills is nearing insolvency and costs for non-hospital care have ballooned. Last year, the White House proposed $120 billion in savings through 2002, mostly through accounting changes and reduced payments to doctors. Republicans argued for $160 billion in savings, partly by overhauling the system.
They still want an overhaul, but are not likely to get it this year. Democrats are expected to call for a financial "fix" to prop up the hospital fund while politicians -- or better still, a bipartisan commission -- devise a permanent solution. In fact, the White House and Democrats in Congress may propose to expand the Federal health-care mandate by extending the guarantee of health insurance to all children.
Many in Congress and the White House privately support another huge cost-cutter, a proposal last month to refigure the Government's Consumer Price Index to correct a supposed overstatement of the inflation rate. That would modestly slow increases in Federal benefits and pensions that are tied to the index, saving hundreds of billions of dollars in the next decade.
But Republicans will not publicly support legislation to change the index unless Mr. Clinton proposes it first, and the President is widely expected to leave any changes to the Labor Department, where the index is prepared. The chances of any legislative change are slim unless it is made part of a more sweeping agreement on spending cuts.
The same is true of Mr. Clinton's pledge to roll back some of the cuts in welfare spending that he signed into law in the campaign season. Mr. Clinton wants to restore about a fourth of the $55 billion in reductions planned in the next six years, primarily cuts in food stamp spending and benefits to legal immigrants.
But many Republicans are unsympathetic, and few give the proposal much chance unless it is part of a larger agreement.
One fiscal proposal seems almost a certainty: Congress and Mr. Clinton both want to cut taxes for families with children, probably through a $500-per-child credit that shrinks as a family's income rises.
The dark horse of legislative issues may be the overhauling of Federal campaign-finance laws.
Democrats blocked the passage of campaign legislation when they controlled Congress, and Republicans have blocked it since. The Democrats, out of power this year, plan to revive their version early this year, partly as a defense against the aura of scandal that now surrounds their party's fund-raising practices.
Senator John McCain of Arizona, the major Republican sponsor of campaign legislation, said that legislation might fail again in a normal year. But with regular disclosures of both Democratic and Republican fund-raising excesses, he said, this year might prove the exception.

HEADLINE: Is the Fed Too Heavy at the Switch? Or Asleep?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Those Vicious Business Cycles: Tamed but Not Quite Slain" (Business Day, Jan. 2) gives the Federal Reserve Board too much credit for taming the business cycle and inflation. Instead, the financial markets deserve that credit, for increasingly the markets are ignoring the Fed's often erroneous interest rate signals. 
 The high inflation of the 1970's and early 1980's was caused by a severe Fed "policy mistake," signaling excessively low and at times negative real or inflation-adjusted interest rates in the late 1960's and 1970's that triggered inflationary credit demand. One side effect of the Fed's subsequent efforts to squeeze that inflation out of the economy: the two worst recessions of the last 50 years.
Perhaps because of their growing internationalization, the financial markets increasingly are pursuing their own self-interest, which is to set interest rates that produce steady, noninflationary credit expansion and stable economic growth. The early 1990's evidenced this phenomenon. In 1992 and 1993, the Fed signaled excessively low short-term rates, which created a bubble in the stock and bond markets. Rising short-term rates burst that bubble in 1994. Fortunately, the financial markets ignored the Fed and held real long-term rates in the 4 percent range. This prevented a rerun of the boom-bust of the 1970's.
The threat of Fed policy mistakes will continue to diminish as the financial markets understand more clearly that they can, and should, ignore Fed rate signals.
 
BERT ELY
Alexandria, Va., Jan. 2, 1997
The writer is a financial consultant.

GRAPHIC: Drawing. (Paul Corio)

HEADLINE: An Appointment That Draws No Fire

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

DATELINE: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 6

 BODY:
Four years ago, some of America's most prestigious economists fought like cats to be chairman of President Clinton's Council of Economic Advisers. And when Laura D'Andrea Tyson got the job, she was openly criticized by several of her peers as unqualified and unconventional.
Now President Clinton has tapped Janet Yellen for the job, making her, in title at least, his chief economist. Like Ms. Tyson, she is an economics professor from the University of California at Berkeley. But Ms. Yellen's appointment last month barely made news and there was almost no cocktail party buzz among the 2,000 or so professional economists gathered here for the annual convention of the American Economic Association, which ended today. By contrast, Ms. Tyson had been Topic A at the 1993 convention. 
 The shift says a lot about the attitude of economists toward the Clinton Administration. Four years ago, they were agitated, divided and uncertain about the newly elected President and his entourage. Now they view his economics as rather mainstream and predictable.
"Four years ago, people did not know what 'new Democratic philosophy' meant in terms of policy," said Joseph E. Stiglitz, a Stanford University professor who succeeded Ms. Tyson in 1995 as the council's chairman and is scheduled to yield the job in late January to Ms. Yellen. "They knew it wasn't Reaganomics, and it wasn't Roosevelt's New Deal. But that left a wide middle ground."
That middle ground has narrowed to a rather standard set of views about the economy that most of the economists gathered here reaffirmed in their sessions and conversations. It emphasizes deficit-cutting and balanced budgets, rather than the increase in public spending that was an initial Clinton impulse. Free markets, minimally regulated, are the order of the day. So is free trade, not the experiments in managed trade that Ms. Tyson was thought to favor.
The result, no matter who is in the White House, has been rather uniform economic advice for the last 20 years from the President's chief economic advisers. "Two-thirds to three-quarters of all the advice given by the Council of Economic Advisers has turned out to be very similar in Republican and Democratic Administrations," said Roger Porter of Harvard University, an economic and domestic policy adviser in the Reagan and Bush Administrations.
When President Clinton unexpectedly named Ms. Tyson as the first woman to lead the council, several of her colleagues among economists close to the Democrats publicly criticized her credentials. They had been waiting 12 years for a Democratic administration and a shot at being chairman of the council, often considered the most prestigious government job for an academic economist. Some said that she lacked expertise in economic theory.
That criticism is gone now, replaced by praise for Ms. Tyson. For Ms. Yellen, the issue is not so much her stand on the issues, but whether she can master the necessary personal relationships inside the Administration.
"You have to have allies on the team," said Martin S. Feldstein of Harvard, who led the council for a time under President Ronald Reagan.
By all accounts, Ms. Tyson, whose economic views turned out to be very much in line with the mainstream approach, had regular access to the President, and also strong support from Robert E. Rubin, who quickly emerged as the key economic player in the Clinton Administration after he was named to lead the National Economic Council that Mr. Clinton established to coordinate domestic policy advice. Mr. Rubin is now the Treasury Secretary and still Mr. Clinton's most important economic adviser.
"It is the structure of decision-making that gains authority in the White House," Ms. Tyson said in a telephone interview.
She later succeeded Mr. Rubin as chief of the N.E.C. and now has returned to Berkeley. But whether Ms. Yellen will have the same access to Mr. Clinton, or sufficient influence among his other economic advisers, is uncertain. The circumstances of her appointment raise questions.
The chairmanship of the Council of Economic Advisers was offered first to Lawrence H. Summers, now Mr. Rubin's deputy at Treasury, a senior Administration official said. Mr. Summers, on leave from Harvard, had been among those jockeying for the council chairmanship when Ms. Tyson was unexpectedly named four years ago. Now he has decided to stay on as deputy to Mr. Rubin. Mr. Summers also was given a seat on the National Economic Council, along with Ms. Yellen, Gene Sperling, who is the new N.E.C. chief, and a couple of others.
In selecting Ms. Yellen to lead the council, a key issue was how well she would get along with Mr. Summers, Administration officials said. Alan S. Blinder of Princeton had been considered for the job, but was eliminated from consideration, a senior Administration official said, because he and Mr. Summers had "personality conflicts" in the past.
Mr. Blinder returned to Princeton last year after serving as a member of the council under Ms. Tyson and as vice chairman of the Federal Reserve. He said recently that he was offered the council chairmanship and turned it down. But Administration officials say that a formal offer went only to Ms. Yellen, who has been a governor of the Federal Reserve for the last three years.
"The people who know Janet well say she is very analytic, very bright, and she works very well with independent-minded people," Mr. Rubin said in a telephone interview.
Ms. Yellen, who is 50 and who describes herself as a "pragmatic, mainstream economist," declined to comment on her appointment, other than to note that she taught economics to Mr. Summers when he was a student. "I have enormous respect for Larry," she said. "He is an extraordinarily fine economist and I am happy to be on the same team."
That relationship, and Ms. Yellen's influence, will be tested in policy debates in the coming months. "Given the profusion of economists in Government in recent years," Mr. Porter said, "is the Council of Economic Advisers as important or necessary as it once was? From the viewpoint of the President, it is. The C.E.A. is in the best position to give unbiased analysis and advice, while other economists argue from the special interests of the agencies or departments they represent."
That requires "face time" with the President, as Murray Weidenbaum of Washington University, President Reagan's first council chairman, put it. Ms. Tyson had a special weekly session with the President in which she laid out the pros and cons of a particular economic issue, but under Mr. Stiglitz, her successor, those meetings stopped last year.
Ms. Yellen, who has met the President only once or twice, has been assured that the weekly meetings will resume, giving her more of an opportunity to build up her influence.
"You cannot draw these things on a blackboard," said Herbert Stein, who was council chairman in the Nixon Administration, and for a time under Gerald Ford. "So much depends on personal relations."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bond Prices Slip Ahead Of New Data

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
As the bond market braced for key economic reports this week, prices of Treasury securities sagged yesterday, dragged down by a weaker dollar and the higher cost of energy.
It appeared yesterday that traders and dealers had already started pricing a risk premium into the costs of Government securities, in case the economic data signal that the economy is growing at a fast enough pace to set off inflation, which would erode the value of fixed-income securities. Also, the dollar declined on world currency markets, making the value of dollar-denominated investments like Government securities less attractive to foreign investors. 
 The price of the 30-year bond fell 16/32, to 96 18/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, rose to 6.77 percent, from 6.73 percent on Friday.
Bill Gamba, senior vice president and head of taxable fixed-income trading at Cowen & Company, noted that although trading volume yesterday was up from the recent holiday volume, it was still not back to full strength, leading some market participants to feel that price fluctuations may be exaggerated.
"The fact is that last week there was some unexpected strength in economic data," Mr. Gamba said, "and the current concern is that we will again see some strength" in this week's data. The Producer Price Index for December is due out on Thursday, and the monthly nonfarm payroll report for December will be released Friday.
Mr. Gamba said that in addition to economic data, the market was also concerned about the resumption of corporate debt issuance as the new year begins, and by the weaker dollar and a jump in crude oil and energy prices.
"The thought of supply is weighing on the market, with rumors of issuance coming from Argentina, Italy, Mexico, and corporates like U S West," he said, adding that "few market participants are going to be willing to take on any new positions in the face of important economic numbers and secondary market supply as well."
The Producer Price Index on Thursday is expected to be tame, but the fear of a stronger-than-expected increase in the nonfarm payroll numbers in December after a small 118,000 increase in November has kept buyers away. The market consensus if for a gain of 150,000 to 170,000, although some are leaning toward a number well above an increase of 200,000.
Jack Guynn, president of the Atlanta Federal Reserve, said that "it looks like another year of moderate growth." These comments may have been interpreted as indicating that the central bank was not panicked by the pace of economic growth. However, he also said that tight labor markets and consumer spending would remain a concern this year, which seemed to suggest that as a new voting member on the Federal Open Market Committee, he would vote to tighten if price pressures were evident.
Yesterday's weekly Treasury bill auction went as well as expected, with rates mixed. The average discount rate for the three-month bills was 5.02 percent, down from 5.08 percent a week ago, while the six-month bill rate averaged 5.11 percent, unchanged from the previous auction.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Remarks by Japanese Official Lead to Broad Drop in Dollar

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar weakened broadly yesterday, hurt by a senior Japanese official's warning about its recent rise.
It was the first full day of global foreign exchange trading since a prolonged holiday break in Japan, giving dealers their first sense of the dollar's true value in nearly two weeks. 
 The thin market since Christmas had distorted currency rates and by the end of last week had helped pushed the dollar to a 45-month high against the Japanese yen, a 2-year high against the German mark and 2 1/2-year high against the Swiss franc.
"A lot of people were excited about the dollar and how it closed on Friday," John Hazelton, chief currency trader at the Manufacturers and Traders Trust Company, said. "But it was a Friday, and it was a holiday week, so how much credence can you put in a move of that nature?"
In late trading in New York yesterday, the dollar fell to 115.68 yen from 116.43 yen on Friday and to 1.5632 marks from 1.5644. The British pound rose to $1.6941 from $1.6901.
The dollar fell sharply in early Asian dealings after Tadashi Ogawa, a Vice Minister of Finance, said, "Excessive weakening of the yen isn't desirable."
It was the first time any senior Japanese official had commented publicly about the dollar'ssurge, which began in mid-December and pushed it up nearly 2.3 percent against the yen in a few weeks.
"Mr. Ogawa threw a little bit of caution into the dollar's rise against the yen and stopped the rally in its tracks," Dennis Pettit, foreign exchange manager in New York for the Long-Term Credit Bank of Japan, said.
The yen's continued weakness has contributed to an exodus of investment from Japan and played a role in a tumble in the Japanese stock market last year. Japanese officials are also worried about the weak yen's effect on on the politically sensitive Japanese trade surplus with the United States, which recently started to increase again.
Although the dollar recovered somewhat later in the day, it weakened again after a rally in the United States stock market faded in the afternoon.

HEADLINE: Dow Sets a Closing High as Stocks End Mixed

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The Dow Jones industrials and the Nasdaq market stumbled to closing highs yesterday, but a broad follow-through to Friday's rally faltered as the bond market, from which stock traders took their direction, continued to sputter.
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 23.09 points, to 6,567.18, surpassing Dec. 27's close of 6,560.91. The new high came despite a retreat from a 75-point gain earlier in the session that had lifted the Dow to more than 6,600 points for the first time. 
 Broader measures ended mixed, falling with bonds as rising oil prices aggravated inflation concerns.
Bonds' interest rates, which move in the opposite direction of the price, jumped last week after some unexpectedly strong economic data raised concerns that the economy has not slowed enough to contain inflation and keep the Federal Reserve from raising short-term interest rates.
"We have a bond market that is continuing to give up on this slow-growth scenario," said Peter Canelo, chief investment strategist at Dean Witter Reynolds, citing last week's robust readings on home sales, factory activity, consumer confidence and construction spending. "Things are obviously starting to pick up."
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 16/32, to 96 18/32. Its yield rose to 6.77 percent, from 6.73 percent on Friday.
Compounding investors' inflation worries was the cold snap crossing the nation, which sent energy prices soaring in commodities trading.
Despite the concerns about an accelerating economy, the early indications on the holiday shopping season remained discouraging, with two more high-profile names reporting disappointing results.
Toys "R" Us slid 4 5/8 a share, to 26 1/8, as the most active issue on the New York Stock Exchange after the retailer warned that lower-than-expected sales for the season will hurt its earnings growth for the fiscal year ending Feb. 3.
Apple Computer Inc., meanwhile, fell 3 7/8, to 17 7/8, as the Nasdaq's most active issue. Prudential Securities and Bear, Stearns downgraded the stock after Apple's announcement late on Friday that sales in the quarter ended Dec. 27 were hurt by weak demand for the company's Performa computers and shortages of new PowerBook portables.
Advancing issues outnumbered decliners, 1,434 to 1,1139, on the Big Board, where volume was heavy at 527.3 million shares.
The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks fell 0.38 point, to 747.65; the New York Stock Exchange composite index rose 0.22 point, to 394.28, and the American Stock Exchange composite index fell 0.39 point, to 572.06.
The technology-rich Nasdaq composite index rose 5.72 points, to 1,316.40, surpassing its Dec. 9 close of 1,316.27, even as computer-related shares succumbed to profit taking.
Intel, which jumped 8 points on Friday after an upgrade from Salomon Brothers, gave back much of a 3 3/8-point gain, rising 1/2 a share, to 138 7/8.
I.B.M. rose 2 1/8 a share, to 161 1/4, as the Dow's strongest issue, but was up as much as 4 earlier in the session.
The jump in crude oil prices also helped the Dow: Texaco rose 1 3/8 a share, to 102; Exxon rose 1 3/8, to 100; Du Pont rose 7/8, to 99, and Chevron rose 3/4, to 66 7/8.
AT&T, down 1 7/8 a share, to 39 5/8, was the Dow's weakest issue after Salomon Brothers lowered its earnings estimates for the company. General Motors rose 1 3/8, to 59 1/4, after an upgrade by Smith Barney.
Banking stocks were pressured by rising interest rates. Chase Manhattan fell 7/8 a share, to 87 3/8; Citicorp fell 3/4, to 103 3/4, and First Union eased 5/8, to 74.
 Autozone Inc., a car-parts retailer, fell 3 7/8 a share, to 20 1/8, after analysts cut their opinions on the stock.
Hilton Hotels shares fell 1 1/4, to 26, after the casino company said its earnings will fall short of analyst expectations for the fourth quarter.

HEADLINE: Advocacy Group Seeks to Undo School Financing Plan

BYLINE: By NEIL MacFARQUHAR 

DATELINE: TRENTON, Jan. 6

 BODY:
A motion filed today by a legal advocacy group for poor children asks the State Supreme Court to declare unconstitutional the elaborate changes in school financing that the Whitman administration just pushed through the New Jersey Legislature and that the Governor expects to make a cornerstone of her re-election bid.
The group, the Education Law Center, has led the 26-year court battle to close the spending gap between the state's richest and poorest districts. It said the new law's emphasis on a standard curriculum that the law estimates should cost $7,200 per pupil would not guarantee that students in the poorest districts would get the same education as that offered in the wealthy suburbs. 
 "This law is a message to those children that all you are entitled to is a second-rate, basic skills education," said David G. Sciarra, executive director of the center, which is based in Newark.
Gov. Christine Todd Whitman defended the law, which if upheld will be a major piece of her resume for re-election, while other Republicans accused the center of trying to undermine the state's best schools by taking money for urban districts. They said that pouring money into poor districts had not significantly improved test scores.
Instead of setting the amount of spending per student, the new law requires that the Department of Education develop an elaborate list of curriculum guidelines that all schools must meet.
"In past decisions, the State Supreme Court has indicated that they were asking for financial parity because no standard for educational parity existed," the Governor said in a statement. "For the first time in state history we have a public education funding law that is based on the provision of an educational program, not simply on the available dollars."
Center officials said the law would effectively ossify the poor districts at the $7,200 spending level while the richer districts could continue to spend whatever they want.
"What we have is a law that takes us back in time," Mr. Sciarra said. "It takes us back to when urban districts lacking the property taxes to afford education are frozen, while suburban districts can raise the money that they need for a quality educational program. What you wind up with is a two-tiered funding system."
There was no immediate indication as to when the court might start reviewing the motion.
Center officials estimate that the spending gap for next year will be roughly $250 million, down from $400 million in 1994, when the court ordered the state to meet the guarantee enshrined in the State Constitution that all children get a "thorough and efficient" education.
The motion asks the court to overturn the law and to determine officially by April 1 the exact gap in spending between the richest and poorest districts.
It also asks the court to order the State Legislature to pass a law by June 30 that would close the spending gap, and if the law is not enacted, for the court to step in and take whatever is required from the state's $4.3 billion education budget to guarantee parity.
New Jersey already spends more per pupil than any other state, and the new law would spend roughly $286 million for all districts.
In addition, the motion asks the court to order the legislature to fix aid for the poorer districts at $208 million, the current level adjusted for inflation, and to appoint a Superior Court judge or a special master to decide by Sept. 30, 1997, what programs were needed in the poorer districts to make them equal to the richest.

HEADLINE: Quiet Funeral Is Planned for Helmsley, as Truce Is Sought on Lawsuit

BYLINE: By N. R. KLEINFIELD 

 BODY:
When Harry B. Helmsley is buried this afternoon in a small private funeral, his body will be put to rest in New York's fabled Woodlawn Cemetery inside a mausoleum whose stained-glass side windows are decorated with -- what else? -- an abbreviated skyline of the city where a one-time office boy made a name buying tall buildings.
Among those planning to attend the funeral are Irving Schneider and Alvin Schwartz, Mr. Helmsley's longtime partners and top lieutenants, who are enmeshed in a nasty lawsuit against Mr. Helmsley's widow, Leona. And yesterday, both parties in the dispute offered encouraging words about the prospects of a peaceful resolution. 
 Mr. Schneider and Mr. Schwartz contend that Mrs. Helmsley has been fraudulently stripping assets of Helmsley-Spear Inc., the real estate management firm that stands at the center of the Helmsley empire, to render it insolvent and avoid paying them millions of dollars.
The two men each called Mrs. Helmsley yesterday to express their condolences. According to Howard J. Rubenstein, a spokesman for Mrs. Helmsley, she told them that she was hopeful that they could now reconcile their problems in an amicable fashion.
Mr. Helmsley died Saturday in Scottsdale, Ariz., at 87, leaving an indelible imprint on New York's real estate landscape. His wife flew back to New York with his body Sunday evening. Eschewing the grandeur of a large public funeral, she has decided to hold a short ceremony at the Woolworth Chapel at the Woodlawn Cemetery in the Bronx before about 25 close friends and relatives. No public officials or journalists are invited.
In memory of her husband, Mrs. Helmsley has turned off for a week the colored lights that decorate the Empire State Building. The building is the best-known of the array of skyscrapers that Mr. Helmsley controlled. The flags at the six Helmsley-owned hotels have been lowered to half-staff.
In the Helmsley Building at 230 Park Avenue, a picture of Mr. Helmsley was put on display in the lobby yesterday, encircled by some of the elaborate floral arrangements that had been received.
The real estate titan's death may spur a swifter conclusion to what has been an acrimonious feud between the Helmsley-Spear partners.
"I think everyone is very shaken by his death," said Howard Squadron, a lawyer who is representing Mr. Schneider in the case. "Sometimes when these things happen, people have a different perspective on what is important and what is not important."
In 1970, Mr. Helmsley granted Mr. Schneider and Mr. Schwartz an option to buy Helmsley-Spear at a bargain price (essentially its book value) upon his death. If they choose not to, they can receive a cash payment estimated at about $10 million each. And then Mrs. Helmsley, assuming she inherits her husband's stock, would own the company.
But under the buyout agreement, Helmsley-Spear has 120 days to provide Mr. Schneider and Mr. Schwartz with a valuation of the company. After receiving that, the two men have 60 days to exercise the option.
Lawyers for the partners said that no decision has been made on the option. Reached at his office, Mr. Schneider said:
"You must understand it's a very difficult time for me. I spent 50 glorious years here. But I make no comment on your question. Please, I make no comment."
Associates of the two partners said that they would not decide on the option until there is a resolution of the lawsuit against Mrs. Helmsley.
Whatever the result, associates said, there is a real possibility that Mr. Schneider and Mr. Schwartz might decide not to buy the company. One factor is their age. Mr. Schwartz is 84 and Mr. Schneider is 76.
Much in the vast Helmsley holdings, however, is not expected to change in any material way in the wake of Mr. Helmsley's death. Mr. Helmsley, given his frail health, had been inactive in his business activities for years, and Mrs. Helmsley has assumed his role.
Helmsley Enterprises, the parent company that owns the Helmsley properties, including its hotels, is uninvolved in the sparring among the partners.
Over a prolonged buying spree, Mr. Helmsley managed to buy a vast trove of real estate properties in more than 100 partnerships with other investors. Mr. Schneider and Mr. Schwartz were his partners in dozens of these.
The partnership agreements vary in what they prescribe in the event of the death of a partner. Some permit the heir named in the will to assume the same partnership position. Others allow the heir to receive the economic interest but not the power of a partner. Still others contain buyout clauses.
Peter Malkin, a sizable landlord and partner in many Helmsley buildings, said, "I don't think any of the partnerships I'm involved with will change because of Harry's death."
It is possible that, in resolving their dispute, the partnerships involving Mr. Schwartz, Mr. Schneider and Mr. Helmsley will be reconfigured such that Mrs. Helmsley would swap the Helmsley interest in some buildings for their interest in others.
Not until Mr. Helmsley's will is probated, however, will the precise effect on all these partnerships be clear. This could be weeks or months from now.
Mr. Helmsley had no children, and expectations in the real estate community are that the bulk of the estate will go to Mrs. Helmsley and the Harry Helmsley Foundation, a charitable organization, but no one seems to have any reliable knowledge of the will's contents and of how the estate will be parceled out.
It is also not clear when Mr. Helmsley last updated the will. He has been incapacitated for several years.
Though it is known Mr. Helmsley's holdings are worth a great deal of money, the precise value of his estate has attracted a rather large range of guesses. A few months ago, Forbes magazine put his worth at $1.7 billion and ranked him 67th among Americans.
Helmsley-Spear has faded as a competitive force in recent years, though it still has a significant portfolio. A number of the buildings are in need of refurbishment, and some of the less choice ones have vacancy rates as high as 30 percent.
Re/Locate, a real estate research firm, said that of 127 buildings for which Helmsley is the leasing agent, the average vacancy as of December was 16.49 percent, compared to 18.8 percent in December 1992. For the considerable cross section of buildings involved, it said that the vacancy rate was not much different from the market in general.

HEADLINE: Despite a Slow Final Month, Year's Auto Sales Were Up

BYLINE: By ROBYN MEREDITH 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Jan. 6

 BODY:
The auto industry ended the year with a 4 percent drop in sales, figures released today showed, but even with the December slowdown, auto makers sold more cars last year than in 1995.
Auto makers sold 15.1 million cars, mini-vans, pickup trucks and sport utility vehicles last year in the United States. That is slightly better than many Wall Street analysts expected, and it beats 1995 sales of 14.8 million. Sales above 15 million are considered healthy. 
 "Over all, the industry had a pretty good year," Ross H. Roberts, a Ford Motor Company vice president and manager of its largest division, said. Ford reported today that its sales rose 10.6 percent last month to eke out a gain for the year of 1.1 percent. Ford was the last of the large auto makers to report December sales.
Economists said they expected sales this year to continue their steady, relatively strong pace for the fourth year in a row. The chief economists at Ford, the General Motors Corporation and the Chrysler Corporation predicted today at the North American International Auto Show here that auto makers would sell 14.7 million to 15.2 million light vehicles in 1997.
W. Van Bussmann, Chrysler's chief economist, noted that sales had been remarkably flat for the last three years. In fact, he said, there was no three-year period in the industry's history in which the overall level of sales had showed so little change.
In December, auto sales dropped 4 percent compared with December 1995. Car sales slid 7.4 percent while sales of mini-vans, sport utility vehicles and pickup trucks rose three-tenths of 1 percent.
The industry as a whole sold light vehicles at a 14.5 million annual pace in December, slightly down from the 14.84 million annual pace in November.
"December certainly ended up being weaker than people thought," David M. Garrity, an auto analyst at Smith Barney, said. That was partly because there were five fewer days between Thanksgiving and Christmas, he said, and people were too busy shopping for holiday gifts to visit showrooms.
Ford executives said last month's sales gains gave it a push into 1997. Robert L. Rewey, group vice president of marketing and sales for Ford, said, "The market will remain fiercely competitive, but we enter the new year with momentum, prepared to meet the challenges."
Ford sold 3.84 million cars, mini-vans, pickup trucks and sport utility vehicles last year. The company's car sales fell 3.6 percent for the year, while light-truck sales rose 19.4 percent.
The nation's largest auto maker, General Motors, reported on Friday that its sales for the year fell 2.1 percent, to 4.79 million. Its car sales dropped 5.8 percent, while its truck sales rose 3.5 percent.
G. Richard Wagoner Jr., an executive vice president of General Motors and president of its North American automotive operations, said that G.M.'s results fell below its expectations for the year because two strikes reduced the company's output by 300,000 cars and light trucks. "Once that happened, the die was basically cast," he said.
Mr. Wagoner said that with many new models now beginning to reach the market, he expected G.M. to recover at least some of the market share it lost in 1996. "I have hopes for this year," he said.
Chrysler, by contrast, had a banner year. It sold 2.45 million cars and trucks, up 13 percent from 1995. Its car sales rose 5 percent while its truck sales jumped 17 percent.

SECTION: Section D; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: Services Becoming The Goods In Industry;
Not Enough Profit In Making Things

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
It gives "post-industrial" a whole new meaning: From General Electric to Wang, from Xerox to Hewlett-Packard, companies that a few years ago got almost all their profits from selling widgets are rapidly transforming themselves into service providers.
Computer companies like Unisys and I.B.M. are designing, installing and running other companies' computer operations. Document processors like Xerox and Pitney Bowes now run mail rooms and copy centers and distribute documents electronically. 
 Honeywell redesigns refineries. Hewlett-Packard not only designs and operates data systems, but pays for the whole package and then leases it out. "Customers want to finance a solution, not a little piece of it," said Ann M. Livermore, vice president for service operations at Hewlett-Packard.
The move to services is one of the hottest strategies in business, and it is driven by changes at the very foundations of manufacturing. Intense competition has made equipment margins sliver thin, while the trend for customers to outsource many of their internal systems has put a premium on expertise. And, perhaps most important, "Services generate huge cash flows, and today's businesses are run for cash flow," said Nicholas P. Heymann, an analyst with NatWest Securities.
Enough manufacturers are switching to services these days to pose a real threat to Electronic Data Systems, Andersen Consulting and other technological consultants. And the competition is getting nasty, with the pure consultants saying that equipment makers cannot be trusted to be objective advisers.
"An awful lot of manufacturers are in services just to pull through their hardware," said John R. Harris, an E.D.S. vice president.
The technology consultants are fighting back with more than innuendo. E.D.S. has been hiring "people who understand business, not just technology," Mr. Harris said. "Our emphasis has shifted from solving technology problems, to using technology to solve business problems."
Still, the potential rewards are so rich that few manufacturers are scared away. No one has amassed statistics about all the disparate service businesses. But most experts say the largest is global information technology services, which encompasses designing, maintaining and installing information systems. According to the market research firm Data Quest, that business reached about $234 billion last year, and should top $400 billion by the end of the decade.
Although independent consulting firms still rule that market, the manufacturers are gaining. Xerox's revenue from services went to $1.5 billion from $1 billion in 1995 -- maybe not much compared with the $13 billion that E.D.S. clocked last year, but still a formidable 50 percent increase. Michael J. Critelli, the chairman of Pitney Bowes, expects his company's mail- and copier-related services to grow 15 percent a year through 2000. "We know mail better than anyone outside the post office," Mr. Critelli said.
Services are growing even faster for computer companies, which increasingly design and run a client's entire computer operations, from payroll to tracking orders. Hewlett-Packard's 1996 service revenues were $5.3 billion, 20 percent above 1995. About $20 billion of I.B.M.'s $70 billion in 1995 revenues came from services, and Lloyd G. Waterhouse, a general manager of IBM Global Services, says services are growing faster than hardware or software.
General Electric derived $7 billion of its $70 billion in 1995 revenues from such services as repairing and maintaining locomotives, aircraft engines, power plants and medical equipment, and it expects such services to top $15 billion by 2000. The company just formed a services council, where representatives from all its manufacturing businesses share tips on how to expand the services business.
For example, G.E.'s medical division, which uses its own equipment to interpret diagnostic test data that have been electronically transmitted, has taught the aircraft engines division to use the same technology to figure out what might be wrong with an airplane at an airport thousands of miles away.
"I can expand a lot faster by upgrading or maintaining the equipment I have installed than by trying to sell more units," said John F. Welch Jr., G.E.'s chairman, who says product-related services are growing at "two to three times the rate of products themselves."
For G.E., a hugely profitable company, pursuing services is just a way to grow. For many computer companies, it is a survival strategy. Competition has intensified, product life cycles have shortened and the advent of "open architectures" -- systems that allow companies to mix and match components from rival manufacturers -- is enabling customers to shop around when they want to upgrade or expand.
The situation is most dire for companies that make personal computers, mainframes and other equipment that has become so standardized that their "variations no longer matter as much as the services that need to be attached to them," said Peter J. Kolesar, a professor at the Columbia Business School.
A result is that manufacturing gross margins, which once went as high as 75 percent, now rarely exceed 30 percent. For services, gross margins can exceed 50 percent.
"Consulting margins were never as high relative to manufacturing as now," said Patrick T. Harker, a professor at the Wharton School.
That is what the most beleaguered computer companies are banking on. At Unisys, which has faced vanishing profits on mainframes and PC's, computer-related services now represent 63 percent of revenues and 100 percent of hopes. "Equipment margins are so low that services are the only way to improve our bottom line," Dewaine Osman, a Unisys senior vice president, said.
Similarly, Wang Laboratories has been bailing out of its ailing office computer businesses since emerging from bankruptcy in 1993. It now concentrates on designing and running local and wide area networks.
"Services provide a high return on assets without plants, property or equipment," Joseph M. Tucci, Wang's chairman, said.
The push into services has not, however, come solely from manufacturers' woes. It has roots in customers' needs, too.
For one thing, customers are increasingly outsourcing operations, including maintenance, that do not fit their core businesses. "If you're already providing the equipment portion of the solution, it makes sense to provide the rest of it, too," said Thomas J. Dolan, senior vice president for the business services division at Xerox.
Customers also want to deal with fewer and fewer suppliers, which means the customers want each supplier to handle multiple needs.
Honeywell, which in 1991 got less than a quarter of its revenue from services, now gets nearly a third from helping oil refiners improve profitability, say, or designing energy systems for factories or school districts. Michael R. Bonsignore, Honeywell's chief executive, readily concedes that in the past, customers might have hired a consulting firm to do a feasibility study, and then put needed equipment out for bid.
"When customers still insisted on three bids for everything, our move into services wouldn't have worked," Mr. Bonsignore said. "But now, who supplies the hardware is less important than who can handle the entire application."
The need to provide a full range of services has sent many vendors on acquisition sprees. E.D.S. recently bought A. T. Kearney, a manufacturing consultant. Wang bought I-Net, a telecommunications services firm, a move that enables Wang to supplement its computer-related services with video conferencing. Honeywell purchased companies that provide emergency shutdown procedures for oil rigs, set up integrated computer networks and fine-tune chemical processes.
Still, the most comprehensive menu of services cannot help a manufacturer refute claims that it remains partial to its own equipment.
"We are independent from the hardware and software companies, and that makes customers comfortable," Mr. Tucci of Wang said.
Stephen D. Sprinkle, a managing partner of Deloitte & Touche's Consulting Group, is more blunt. "Clients want to buy advice and services from someone they perceive as more objective than the provider of an associated product," he said.
Hogwash, countered Mr. Waterhouse of I.B.M., who said that I.B.M. manages systems that include more than 500,000 non-I.B.M. computers -- many of which, he says, I.B.M. recommended. "Everyone realizes that these days, one PC is much like another," he said. "It is more important to our customers that we know how to implement business applications because we had to adopt so much technology to solve our own financial problems."
Indeed, many manufacturers hammer home the point that they identify with their customers' problems far more than a consultant whose only product is expertise.
"Impartiality is a great big fat red herring," Ms. Livermore of Hewlett-Packard said. "Customers just care that you know enough to make the solution work."
Autodesk, a fast-growing manufacturer of animation software, recently chose Hewlett-Packard over E.D.S. and Andersen to run its data center. What tipped the scales was that Autodesk was struggling with S.A.P., a complex software system for tracking materials, orders and finished products. Although both Andersen and E.D.S. had vast experience consulting with S.A.P. users, Hewlett-Packard was in the process of installing the system for its own use. "H-P really understands firsthand what is needed to make the S.A.P. system run most efficiently," said William H. Kredel, Autodesk's chief information officer.
Still, to ward off the semblance of bias, many manufacturers, including I.B.M. and Unisys, have given autonomy to their manufacturing and services arms. But, paradoxically, such a "Chinese wall" may prove to annoy as many customers as it reassures.
"If I'm buying equipment and services from a company, I should be able to leverage that clout," said Joseph J. Campbell, executive vice president of Risk Enterprise Management Limited, an insurance services company that recently hired Unisys to run its multivendor PC network. "I don't want people telling me they can't control what another division does for us."

HEADLINE: SOCIAL SECURITY: NEWS ANALYSIS;
The Ultimate Insider

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6

 BODY:
Every week a President and Cabinet members make decisions, large and small, that move markets. Should the United States go to war against Saddam Hussein to protect Kuwait and maintain access to oil? Should it agree to a series of spending cuts that make a balanced budget within six years more likely? Should it agree to cut the capital gains tax?
Now, the recommendation that the country place a large part of the Social Security trust fund in the stock market, where it should be able to reap greater returns and avoid a revenue shortfall early in the next century, raises a host of questions about how such decisions of state might be affected. Under the most modest investment plan suggested yesterday by the Advisory Council on Social Security, a trillion dollars in Government money could be placed in the stock market by 2015. Under the most aggressive plan, the figure would exceed $4 trillion. 
 Could any President -- or a Treasury Secretary or Federal Reserve head -- ignore that fact in making decisions that could send the markets into the tank, imperiling the returns on funds in which, as the committee noted, "every American family would have a stake?"
That is only one of the many questions prompted by the conclusions of the Advisory Council, which was sharply divided on whether investing in the market was necessary to save the system -- and, if necessary, whether Social Security beneficiaries should be given broad powers to manage their individual accounts.
The most dramatic recommendation would turn the system into something akin to a national 401(k) plan, the tax-deferred retirement accounts that millions of American workers now manage for themselves, with the savviest investors reaping the biggest rewards when they reach 65.
The lobbying will be fierce. Wall Street is ecstatic at the idea that billions upon billions of dollars that today are invested only in Government securities might suddenly fuel the stock market. Its enthusiasm is hardly without self-interest. If fund managers are permitted to skim just 1 percent in management fees, it would mean new Wall Street revenues of $10 billion to $40 billion a year in 2015, and far more in the next century.
Labor unions say that it is not only risky to rely on volatile markets, but that it is also a surrender of the guarantees that the Social Security system has come to represent. And the American Association of Retired Persons declared today, "There is no need to rush to radical reform."
But what of the conflict of interest inherent in any system that places the most influential single market force, the Federal Government, in the position of being the single largest investor? Some officials say the conflict of interest is more theoretical than real. After all, billions in state pension funds, and even some Federal pension money, are already invested in the stock market.
And so is the future of any politician who can count electoral votes. Just ask President Clinton, who abandoned many of the promises of his first campaign when it became apparent that the markets were demanding fiscal discipline.
It was a risky strategy that, his aides said, paid off in November. "People dismissed Bob Dole's argument that the economy was in terrible shape," a top aide said, "because they knew that everyone was making money in the market."
But others around Mr. Clinton note that pouring Social Security money into the markets would turn what has for decades been a close interconnection between Washington and Wall Street into an iron link.
Market reactions, they say, are always a consideration in major Government decisions. But they could loom over such decisions if the President, for example, was advised that the cost of sending troops to secure the peace on the Korean Peninsula might be a selloff that every American worker would see reflected on quarterly statements that spelled out the value of their "Personal Security Account."
"If you have the national Government making decisions that will influence financial markets and if the Government is directly involved in investing in those markets," said an economist at Salomon Brothers, John Lipsky, "it will undoubtedly affect decisions."
Mr. Clinton's top economic advisers agreed today to say virtually nothing about the report.
The details of the report aside, there are some areas of broad agreement whenever Washington policymakers take up the electric issue of messing with Social Security. The first is that the system needs to be fixed. The only question is whether a small repair will do the job -- adjusting the consumer-price index, for example, to reflect the fact that inflation, and the Social Security benefits tied to inflation statistics, is overstated -- or whether a much bigger repair is needed.
The second agreement is that America needs to increase its savings and investment rates, which pale in comparison to the savings rate in Japan and many of the world's most dynamic economies. Forced investment would be a big step toward that goal.
But as soon as the subject turns to stock investment, the consensus falls apart. Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin, the former investment banker whose opinion counts most in the Administration's internal debate on the subject, has said many times he has "substantial concerns" about putting a large chunk of the Social Security trust fund at the mercies of the stock market. White House officials say he has expressed that view in private in stronger terms.
Mr. Rubin made his considerable fortune in a long career at Goldman Sachs & Company and needs no tutorial on the arguments that make the investment strategy so appealing to those trying to repair the system. Today, the Social Security trust fund earns a rate of return of about 2.3 percent after inflation. Historically, the stock market has a rate of return of 7 percent. The difference, compounded over decades, is enormous.
But to some degree the national psychology is affected by the fact that the market has risen so dramatically, with only one major interruption, for 15 years. That psychology could be radically changed by a prolonged downturn. And if Social Security recipients were losing billions for several years, the pressure on the recipients of Government bailouts would undoubtedly mount.
Some on the commission, including Thomas W. Jones, president of T.I.A.A.-CREF, which manages $180 billion in retirement money for professors and researchers, wonder whether the Government or Social Security recipients should be put in that bind. "To me the bottom line is that half of America's workers have no other pension plan," Mr. Jones said today. "Those are the people who absolutely need Social Security, with a guarantee. How reasonable is it to take away the guarantee, but say to them, 'You can make it up with investing acumen?' It's just not appropriate to put them at risk."

HEADLINE: How U.N. Chief Discovered U.S., and Earmuffs

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

 BODY:
Kofi Annan's discovery of America took shape in the turbulent 1960's, on a Midwestern college campus that flew a United Nations flag. It was an era of civil rights protests and passionate policy debates over a world of causes.
Now, as as Mr. Annan takes over as the seventh Secretary General of the United Nations, America seems to him a different place, estranged from the international organization, more wary of involvement in the outside world. 
 His election owed much to American antipathy toward his predecessor and skepticism over the organization's performance. One of his biggest challenges, he says, will be to help repair the relationship.
Few would dispute that Mr. Annan has the credentials to do so. No Secretary General has known the United States as intimately or for as long as this Ghanaian, the first black African elected to the job. And unlike his predecessors, Mr. Annan has not only enjoyed diplomatic society in New York, but has also nurtured a deep, decades-long fascination with African-American life across the United States.
It began, he says, in 1959, when this student from newly independent Ghana began to watch as "the African diaspora in America woke up and embraced Africa."
"It was an exciting period," he said in an interview on Friday evening, after his first two hectic days in his new office atop the Secretariat building. "I had come from Ghana, and we had just gone through our own struggle for independence. Ghana became independent in 1957, only two years earlier. People of my generation, having seen the change that took place in Ghana, grew up thinking all was possible.
"When I came to the States, the social upheaval reminded me of some things that had gone on there," he added, sitting in an office still largely undecorated except for a bowl of flowers, an African woodcarving and an abstract painting by his wife, Nane, a Swedish lawyer-turned-artist.
Mr. Annan arrived in the United States in the summer of 1959 on a scholarship from the Foreign Students Leadership Project of the Ford Foundation, which scouted the world for promising future leaders. Mr. Annan, then a student at Ghana's University of Science and Technology and vice president of the Ghana Students' Union, was spotted by a talent scout at a meeting of African student leaders in Sierra Leone.
He also remembers 1959 as the year of the earmuffs.
"I entered the United States at Boston, and did a summer program at Harvard," he said. "I then moved on to Macalester College in Minnesota. It was my first winter ever, and that was quite an experience.
"Intellectually, I knew about the seasons," he said, his elegant English softened by a lilting West African cadence. "I knew about snow. I knew about winter. But I had never experienced it until I got to Minnesota." Unwillingly, he bundled up in cumbersome clothes, he said. But he drew the line at earmuffs, which looked ridiculous.
"I resisted as long as I could, until one day, going to get something to eat, my ears nearly froze," he recalled. "So I went and bought the biggest pair I could find. But even in that I learned a very important lesson. You never walk into a situation and believe that you know better than the natives. You have to listen and look around. Otherwise you can make some very serious mistakes."
Mr. Annan got his first look at the rest of the country the following summer from a new Rambler station wagon filled with students -- Sri Lankan, Greek, British and American -- and a faculty guide.
"We stayed with families that were very comfortable," Mr. Annan said. "We stayed with sharecroppers. We even attempted to stay in jail at Dodge City just to see the conditions." Turned down by a warden who said that in his 32 years on the job nobody had ever asked to be locked up, they slept at the Salvation Army instead.
"We did get into situations in some of the Southern states where they did not want to serve us because of the mixed group," he said. "In Las Vegas, the Sri Lankan was told he couldn't use the pool. He was extremely upset. But generally people were hospitable.
"In the 60's, I saw a very generous people," he said. But now, he added, "when I see groups emerging that are so self-centered, so determined to keep out everybody, in a nation of immigrants -- this distrust of people who are different -- it is difficult to explain."
Mr. Annan is also critical of his native continent. On a visit to Ghana with his family over Christmas, he lectured the Ghanaian Parliament on the importance of the rule of law and the careful exercise of power.
"I will try very hard to solve the problems of the continent," he said. "But for assistance to be effective, these governments must get their own house in order. They should open their political systems. They should take steps to reduce if not eliminate corruption. In a way, I think that comes with the opening of the economy."
Mr. Annan, 58, who was born into a prominent family among the Fante people of Ghana's Ashanti region, has a reputation at the United Nations, where he has worked as an international civil servant for most of his career, as a level-headed and humane administrator who makes a point of wishing the children of his colleagues a happy new year.
Mr. Annan, who has a master's degree in management from M.I.T., said he would take his time in putting together a new team to guide the United Nations through his five-year term. But he intends to move quickly to open access and encourage discussion in the organization, which was run in a more hierarchical style by his predecessor, Boutros Boutros-Ghali. "The building will breathe with information," said his spokesman, Frederic Eckhard.
Life will also change for Mr. Annan's wife, the former Nane Lagergren, 52, a cosmopolitan but shy woman whose mother was the half-sister of Raoul Wallenberg, the Swedish diplomat who disappeared in 1945 while rescuing Jews from the Nazis in Eastern Europe. Her family continues to hope that he is alive despite reports to the contrary, and he is "a very constant presence -- and absence" in their lives, she said.
The Annans, who have three grown children from previous marriages, met in 1981 in Geneva, where she was a legal officer for the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees. They were married in 1984 at the United Nations chapel in New York. Settled here, she turned to full-time painting while her husband, most recently Under Secretary General for peacekeeping operations, undertook difficult assignments: in Iraq, where he negotiated the release of United Nations staff members in 1991 during the Persian Gulf war, and in 1995 in the Balkans, where he turned over a peacekeeping operation to NATO.
Mr. Annan describes their time together as "fascinating," even though there were some early cultural wrinkles -- none too serious, since he was well acquainted with Europe and she had lived and traveled in Africa as a child.
"At the beginning it was very difficult," he said. "We would organize a dinner. Nane being a Swede -- that's a country where if you invite them for 8 o'clock, they will get there at 5 or 10 to 8 and circle the block, and ring the bell at 8 -- was used to punctuality. The Ghanaian or the African guests would come about 30 minutes to an hour late, and she used to get furious. So I said just don't do souffles.
"I'm more punctual now," he said. "And she's more relaxed."
"I'm a quick study," she said.

HEADLINE: Will State Dept. Rights Advocate Get a Bigger Role?

BYLINE: STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3

 BODY:
When he was elected four years ago, President Clinton promised to be a human rights President and refuse to "coddle dictators."
As a sign of that intention he named John Shattuck -- with a background as a top official at Amnesty International and the American Civil Liberties Union -- as the State Department's point man for promotion of human rights abroad. 
 The human rights record of the first Clinton term was mixed, however. Mr. Clinton's reluctance to get tough on the abuses of big trading partners like China, Saudi Arabia, Nigeria and Indonesia left rights advocates frustrated, even as they applauded the Administration's encouragement of democracy in places like Haiti and Bosnia.
Many proponents of human rights agreed with Aryeh Neier, president of a private foundation called the Open Society Institute, who said Mr. Clinton had embraced a new post-cold-war double standard:
Before, Washington excused repressive anti-Communist allies while attacking the ample abuses of Communist countries. Today, Mr. Neier notes, the new dividing lines are trade and security, with Washington ready to denounce or sanction "pariah states" like Iraq or Iran and "governments of countries that are not considered politically or economically important."
Now, the prospect of a more outspoken and forceful human rights advocate in Secretary of State-designate Madeleine K. Albright -- whose confirmation hearings before the Senate begin on Wednesday -- has heartened human rights lobbyists.
It has also raised the prospects, officials say, that the often disheartened Mr. Shattuck will stay on for a second term, and play a more central part in American foreign policy.
Mr. Shattuck has spent considerable time this week helping to brief Ms. Albright for her Congressional hearings, and he worked closely with her on Bosnia, Haiti and Burma while she was permanent representative to the United Nations.
Human rights advocates expect to have a strong ally in Ms. Albright, whose confirmation is a virtual certainty. She is expected to be "more willing to excoriate dictators as dictators," said Thomas Carothers, a senior associate at the Carnegie Endowment. A former refugee from Nazism and Communism, she believes in the power of the American example.
By the standards of human rights advocates, Mr. Clinton had notable, if fragile, achievements in Haiti, where American troops overthrew a military dictatorship and restored an elected President; and in Bosnia, where belated but robust American intervention stopped the killing and imposed a peace that has at least given democracy a chance to grow.
But more often, Mr. Shattuck found himself forced into a sort of "human rights ghetto" in a larger State Department bureaucracy, and lost many arguments to powerful advocates for trade and jobs in the Commerce and Treasury departments or because of national security concerns in the Pentagon.
Perhaps the biggest disappointment of human rights proponents is China. The President flip-flopped on policy, first insisting that China's trade privileges be tied to its willingness to improve its human rights record, and then changing his mind. The decision undermined his credibility with Beijing, and China's rights record worsened, if anything, as it rearrested political opponents and tried to stamp out public dissent.
Critics accuse the Administration of abandoning its moral goals in the face of pressure from American businessmen and hot rhetoric from the Chinese.
In general, officials acknowledge, human rights concerns under Mr. Clinton have had a bigger effect on policy in smaller, more obscure countries like Burma than in places like China, Russia or Saudi Arabia, where moral issues were subordinated to larger security, trade and economic concerns.
But better than others before him, even critics agree, Mr. Shattuck, 53, has pushed back. He says he has had to learn to fight his corner, seeking allies and biding his time, even within the State Department itself.
He has had some institutional successes, enlarging the area in which he can operate. Countries' human rights records can now be used as criteria for granting them loans and aid.
And in the former Yugoslavia, Mr. Shattuck sees an important change in a newly re-elected Administration's willingness both to confront President Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia over election fraud and to consider more seriously, officials assert, using the military to hunt down war criminals in Bosnia.
Adrian Karatnycky, president of Freedom House, which monitors democracy and human rights worldwide, said: "China is the one great counter-example and an important one. But in Haiti, Bosnia, Burma and now in Serbia, there's a decent and credible record. This is an activist Administration that looks for opportunities to press things in the right direction, when we can exert influence and lend our voice to ongoing events, like Serbia."
While acknowledging that human rights have often taken a back seat, senior Government officials say there are strong arguments that countries like Saudi Arabia and Russia may be too fragile to weaken further by making human rights an overriding priority, outweighing America's thirst for oil, regional security or, as in Russia's case, the prospects for democracy itself.
There, the Administration was slow to highlight Russian abuses in the breakaway province of Chechnya, both at the beginning of the war in December 1994 and during its resurgence last spring, while Boris N. Yeltsin was seeking re-election. In Russia, the twin aims of human rights and democracy promotion came into conflict.
It was China, however, that encapsulated the first two years of foreign-policy confusion under Mr. Clinton, and it marked the officials involved.
After Mr. Shattuck and Mr. Christopher took a hard line on human rights in Beijing and China rearrested a noted dissident, Wei Jingsheng, President Clinton backed down, succumbing to pressure from American businesses, which were eager to press forward with investments in China.
"In China, the Clinton Administration sabotaged itself, and has no one else to blame," said Kenneth Roth, executive director of Human Rights Watch, formerly Helsinki Watch. "Christopher and Shattuck climbed way out to the end of the limb in China, and President Clinton chopped it off. And they learned not to climb out on that limb again."
Mr. Shattuck prefers to discuss accomplishments, not setbacks. "This Administration," he said, "has produced a dramatic change: the willingness to use combined diplomacy and military force in the defense of human rights."
The United States had other interests in Haiti and Bosnia, he admits, ranging from illegal refugees and immigration concerns to the preservation of NATO. "But underlying these crises were crises of human rights that captured attention and forced the issues," Mr. Shattuck said.
Mr. Shattuck pointed to the landmark inclusion in the Dayton Accords, signed by all the parties to the Bosnia conflict, of the War Crimes Tribunal.
"It's the first agreement in history, despite its flaws and failures of implementation, where all parties agreed in writing to respect a war crimes tribunal," said the main Bosnia negotiator, the former Assistant Secretary for European Affairs, Richard C. Holbrooke.
But the Clinton Administration was late getting into Bosnia, after many thousands died, and has not been willing to take military risks to enforce the human rights aspects of Dayton, like freedom of movement, the return of refugees and especially the capture of those indicted for war crimes. The last is again a live issue. Despite Pentagon reluctance, there is renewed talk of putting force behind the tribunal, which will otherwise wither.
Mr. Shattuck hopes the worm is turning. "Part of the job," he said, "is to draw attention, both here and abroad, to abuses, to give us leverage and often a seat at the decision-making table. You have to have a good sense of timing -- bide your time and keep the issue alive."
