HEADLINE: SOCIAL SECURITY: THE OVERVIEW;
PANEL ON SOCIAL SECURITY URGES INVESTING IN STOCKS, BUT IS SPLIT OVER METHODS

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6

 BODY:
A Federal advisory panel suggested today that the nation consider investing part of its Social Security revenues in the stock market to insure the solvency of the retirement program. But panel members disagreed on whether workers or the Government should decide how the money is invested.
Seven of the 13 panel members recommended compulsory private savings through individual investment accounts. Labor unions said they would fiercely resist the use of such accounts to replace any part of the Federal program. 
 Under current law, Social Security payroll taxes not needed for today's benefits are invested exclusively in Government securities, mainly long-term bonds. In its final report, issued after more than two years of work, the advisory panel agreed that Social Security could obtain a much higher return by investing some of the money in stocks.
"Private investment is the key to bolstering the return on workers' very substantial tax payments," said Carolyn L. Weaver, a panel member who is an economist at the American Enterprise Institute. "Our proposal could produce larger retirement incomes for workers and boost national saving and economic growth."
But panel members disagreed over what level of financial risk was acceptable to workers and retirees. And they could not agree on whether workers should be allowed to choose the stocks and mutual funds in which their money would be invested.
In view of these disagreements, no major changes in Social Security are likely any time soon. But the panel's report sets the stage for a national debate on retirement policy. [Excerpts, page A14.]
The report represents a possible turning point in the history of Social Security, which was created in 1935 and is the nation's biggest, most successful social insurance program. It could also prove a boon to Wall Street by funneling billions of dollars into stocks. [Article, page A14.]
The panel, the Advisory Council on Social Security, was appointed in June 1994 by Donna E. Shalala, the Secretary of Health and Human Services. She asked the members to take a long view of Social Security's financial health. The chairman of the panel was Edward M. Gramlich, a professor of economics at the University of Michigan.
As they completed their work, the 13 members of the panel found themselves agreeing in groups of 6, 5 and 2. Each faction advanced its own plan to guarantee the solvency of Social Security over the next 75 years. Seven of the 13 members favored compulsory private savings through individual accounts, but they disagreed over whether workers should have limited or complete control over them.
The six other members said that the Government itself should consider investing part of the surplus in the Social Security trust fund -- up to 40 percent -- in stocks.
This group of six included three labor union officers and was led by Robert M. Ball, who worked at the Social Security Administration for more than three decades and was Commissioner from 1962 to 1973.
The amount of money that would be injected into the stock market varied under the three plans. In 2015, for example, stock holdings would range from $1.2 trillion to $4.2 trillion. These totals, expressed in terms of today's purchasing power, range from $601 billion to $2.1 trillion.
Panel members estimated that these totals would be equivalent to 5 percent to 15 percent of the total market value of stocks. (By contrast, the assets of 401(k) plans quadrupled from 1984 to 1990, when they reached $385 billion, and they totaled $525 billion by the end of 1994.)
Mr. Ball said there was no need for radical change. "Social Security is not in the emergency room and does not require radical surgery," he said. "To maintain its long-term health, it requires only a series of moderate adjustments to revenues and expenses."
Clinton Administration officials and senior Republicans in Congress, knowing that Social Security is an explosive issue among voters, reacted with utmost caution. They said that they wanted to study the proposals before taking action, and that action would not come for several years, at the earliest.
Administration officials and members of Congress said that Medicare, the health insurance program for the elderly, faced much more urgent financial problems. Its Hospital Insurance Trust Fund is expected to run out of money in 2001, assuming no change in current law.
Labor representatives were more vocal. Gerald M. Shea, a panel member who is assistant to the president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., denounced the proposals to replace part of Social Security with compulsory private savings that would be invested in stocks and bonds. He said that labor unions were organizing a campaign to "prevent these ideas of radical reform from getting beyond the fantasy stage."
Mr. Shea said that the proposals would "divert large amounts of money to Wall Street" and could be a boon for stockbrokers, mutual funds and investment advisers. Companies involved in financial services are already trying to whip up support for such plans, he said.
Sylvester J. Schieber, a panel member who helped draft the proposal for personal savings accounts, said that financial service companies "did not influence our thinking." Moreover, he said, "this is a highly competitive industry," and added that the competition among investment managers would prevent them from "reaping undue or exorbitant profits." Mr. Schieber is a vice president of Watson Wyatt Worldwide, a management consulting concern that specializes in employee benefits.
Proponents of personal savings accounts rejected the characterization of their proposal as radical. "There was a time," they said, "in the early 1930's, that Social Security was considered radical. We must get beyond such politically charged words."
Social Security pays monthly cash benefits to 44 million people: 31 million retirees, 7 million survivors and 6 million disabled people.
The first baby boomers will reach the age of 65 in 2011. The Social Security trust fund now has assets of more than $550 billion, and the surplus is expected to rise to $2.8 trillion in 2018. But then, the Administration says, the assets will begin to decline, as the payments to retirees begin to exceed the revenues paid by workers. By 2029, if the system is unchanged, the trust fund will be depleted, and revenues will cover only three-fourths of benefit costs.
Council members expressed surprising agreement on the importance of the annual cost-of-living adjustment, which is intended to preserve the purchasing power of Social Security benefits and offset the effects of inflation.
Benefits are now increased each year to reflect changes in the Consumer Price Index. The advisory council said that the cost-of-living adjustment could be reduced to reflect corrections that might be made in this index by the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics.
But the panel said Congress should not dictate changes in the cost-of-living adjustment because such action would set "a bad precedent" that could be used to cut benefits unfairly.
A panel of five economists appointed by the Senate Finance Committee said last month that the index overstates the cost of living by 1.1 percentage points. Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, has said that Americans need not make immediate changes in the structure of Social Security if they agree to corrections in the cost-of-living adjustment.
Representative Bill Archer, the Texas Republican who supervises Social Security as chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, did not endorse any specific recommendation, but said he hoped that President Clinton would display "bold leadership."
Mr. Clinton's press secretary, Michael D. McCurry, offered a noncommittal response to the council's recommendations. At Mr. McCurry's regular briefing for journalists today, this exchange occurred:
Question: "What does the President think of investing some of the Social Security money in the stock market?"
Answer: "He believes that there are a number of ideas that have surfaced as part of this debate -- and certainly in the report of the advisory council itself -- that merit further discussion. He is not wedded to any of the suggestions made by any of the separate groups of members of the council itself, but agrees that many of these ideas will have to be discussed further and will have to be an element of the bipartisan process that would lead to resolution of questions about the future of Social Security."
Horace B. Deets, executive director of the American Association of Retired Persons, said: "Social Security is not in crisis. There is no reason to rush to radical reform proposals that would undermine the stability of the program."
Mr. Deets said that the proposals to channel a part of payroll taxes into individual investment accounts would be "especially risky for poor and middle-income elderly who rely on Social Security" as their main source of income.
These families, he said, "would have significantly less to invest than wealthy investors, would pay more in administrative fees and would be less able to protect themselves against downturns in the stock market."
Edith U. Fierst, a lawyer and member of the advisory council who specializes in women's pension rights, said: "Privatization is a threat to American women. The money accumulated in a personal savings account would belong to the person whose earnings were taxed, not to the spouse. Men are still earning more than women, so their accounts would be larger. If the man is not required to buy an annuity, he could take the money to Las Vegas or use it to support a girlfriend or buy a business."

HEADLINE: Federal Encroachment Or New Opportunity?

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: TWENTYNINE PALMS, Calif., Jan. 4

 BODY:
As an outspoken City Council member active on county and Federal land-use committees and a witness at Congressional field hearings, James Bagley has made himself this town's voice on environmental issues. And when it comes to the creation and expansion of several national parks and wilderness areas in the surrounding desert, he has been a loud and energetic critic.
"It's the new socialism," Mr. Bagley said, sitting in his real estate brokerage on the northern edge of town, near the huge military base that has long been the community's economic mainstay. "We're nationalizing the public lands." 
 But while Mr. Bagley may fit a popular image of small-town Westerners as sagebrush Republicans who distrust the Federal Government and want more control over nearby land, he does not speak for everyone here. While some people in the local cafes and bars agree with him, there is a wide range of views here on land use, with some residents holding a vision very different from Mr. Bagley's for the future of the Federal property that nearly surrounds this town, 150 miles east of Los Angeles.
William J. Garvin, a 41-year-old construction contractor and high school friend of Mr. Bagley, strongly opposed the decision by Congress in 1994 to preserve nine million acres of nearby land by creating new national parks and designating a patchwork of new wilderness areas.
But Mr. Garvin said he had since changed his mind about the move, which was led by Senator Dianne Feinstein, Democrat of California. What made the difference, he said, was seeing the extra tourism that seems to have followed the upgrading of nearby Joshua Tree National Monument into a national park. Now Mr. Garvin is converting an abandoned motel into apartments for would-be artists who want to supply the town's gift shops.
"I would have helped lynch Dianne Feinstein three years ago," Mr. Garvin said at the end of a lunch at the Finicky Coyote, a local cafe. "I didn't think it out far enough; I didn't think it out three years to now."
While precise tallies for tourists are scarce, the city's tax revenue from them has been rising. Municipal receipts from a tax on hotel and motel guests grew to $171,000 in the fiscal year that ended on June 30, 1996, from $155,000 in the previous fiscal year, said Ronald Peck, the city finance manager. And the increase came despite the temporary closing of national parks for a total of three weeks as budget battles were waged in Washington early last year.
B. K. Wiederhold, a broad-shouldered, retired Marine major and high school football coach, nursed a bottle of Coors Light at an oasis bar while describing his support for the National Rifle Association, his 40-year habit of keeping guns in his vehicles and his recent application for a concealed weapons permit. But after expressing dismay at Federal plans to store nuclear waste in the desert, Mr. Wiederhold voiced some enthusiasm for the recent expansion of federally protected areas and strong support for Federal limits on off-road driving in the desert.
"If they don't protect it," he said, "we'll find a way to mess it up."
And at the nearby office of the Twentynine Palms Inn, Paul E. Smith, who owns the inn with his wife, said he had no complaint when rangers at the new Mojave National Preserve 40 miles northeast of here had posted signs closing access to one of his favorite dirt roads.
"The funding for that park is so short that I wouldn't even ask the rangers why they did it," Mr. Smith said.
Mr. Smith, who grew up in the Los Angeles suburb of La Canada Flint ridge, spends half his time here and half his time working as a lawyer in Pasadena, another Los Angeles suburb. Recent arrivals here have tended to be more understanding of restrictions on Federal land than longtime residents, who remember when it was easier to tear across the desert on a dirt bike or build camp fires far from any ring of already blackened stones, and who more often agree with Mr. Bagley's views.
At the smoke-filled Stars Way Out bar, a popular hangout for rural miners and retired members of the military, David Wiesner, George Yoakum and Dale Satterfield sat near the pool table playing seven-card stud for quarters on Saturday afternoon. They had nothing good to say about Federal restrictions on land use, particularly on mining.
"What are they going to hurt out here in the desert?" asked Mr. Weisner, the bar's owner. "Nothing."
It is difficult to gauge the precise number of people here who support recent Federal restrictions on land use and who oppose them. Local elections do not provide a signal because they tend to be fought over law-enforcement and economic-development issues that local groups can influence, not over Federal land policies. The city continues to favor Republicans in national elections.
But what does seem clear is that while the image of small-town Westerners furious with Federal land restrictions has become part of popular American political wisdom, the residents of Twentynine Palms hardly fit that stereotype.
Mr. Bagley, who is now criticizing Federal acquisitions of private land in connection with the expanded parks, acknowledged when pressed that the town was divided on land use policy.
"You have the whole spectrum" of views, he said, before changing the subject to his memories of bygone days spent driving across the open desert, exploring every cave and canyon, without any fear of being ticketed by park rangers.

HEADLINE: A MOVE TO SHIFT BALANCE OF POWER IN NEW YORK CITY

BYLINE: By VIVIAN S. TOY 

 BODY:
Barely seven years after voters approved a sweeping set of City Charter revisions that gave broad new power to New York's City Council, the Speaker of the Council said yesterday that it was not nearly enough.
Complaining that the current balance of power unfairly favors the mayor's office, the Council Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, announced yesterday that he would form a commission to put before the voters another set of Charter revisions aimed at further expanding the Council's role in running government. 
 Specifically, Mr. Vallone said he wanted the Council to have more say over the city budget and land-use policy. And in a very clear attempt to gain more control over the executive branch, Mr. Vallone proposed a Charter change increasing the Council's powers to approve the Mayor's cabinet-level appointments.
Mr. Vallone said that the commission that proposed the 1989 Charter changes, which were enacted in 1990 after a citywide vote, had not fully anticipated how the mayor's office and the City Council would evolve. As a result, the relationship between the executive and legislative branches has grown bitter at times, leading to several opposing lawsuits by the Council and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani. Mr. Vallone called the situation a "syndrome of government by litigation."
Responding to Mr. Vallone, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said he was satisfied with the balance of power, adding that he thought the Council should leave the Charter alone.
"We just had a Charter revision," the Mayor said. "We're still experiencing some new things under it, and I think it should be left alone for a while."
State law gives the Council the power to empanel a new Charter review commission and choose all its members without the Mayor's approval. This commission would, in turn, recommend Charter changes that would have to go before voters for final approval.
Mr. Vallone said the Council planned to appoint the new panel this year, adding that he anticipated a vote on Charter revision in 1999.
The commission would be required by law to review all aspects of the Charter, but a panel appointed by the Council would be likely to favor the Speaker's recommendations. But getting the voters to approve them is another matter. Last November voters rejected a measure that Mr. Vallone pushed to extend term limits for city officials.
The 1989 Charter changes produced the biggest overhaul of municipal government since the Greater City of New York was created in 1898. Under the changes the Board of Estimate was abolished and its powers divided between the Mayor and the City Council. Mr. Vallone urged Mr. Giuliani yesterday to work with the Council on revising the Charter, but the Mayor gave no indication that he intended to participate.
"I think that the balance in the City Charter is an adequate one and a good one and has served us well," Mr. Giuliani said. "And I don't know that I'd agree that there has to be the kinds of changes that he's talking about. It would almost create a very different kind of government."
Mr. Vallone argued that the Council's failure to extend term limits for elected officials last fall made Charter revision even more important. He has long argued that term limits will turn out virtually all of the Council's members at the end of 2001, creating a rookie legislative body that would also be much weaker than the executive branch.
"For a democratic government to endure, that government must be balanced," Mr. Vallone said in his annual speech to the Council yesterday. "Its powers must be equally distributed between the executive at the top, and the legislative branch closest to the people. If that balance cannot be struck, if it cannot be maintained, then democracy itself is in danger and slowly slips into government by executive decree."
Despite the resounding defeat the Council suffered last fall when voters refused to extend term limits to 12 years from 8 for the Council and other elected officials, Mr. Vallone said he believed voters would be willing to approve increased powers for the Council. When the current Charter was drafted in 1989, he explained, "there was a distrust that was held for the Council. Now, seven years later, I don't think anyone can objectively say that the Council as an institution has been irresponsible when it comes to adopting the budget or anything else."
Mr. Vallone said he was most interested in obtaining more control over the budget.
As it is, "we can always refuse to adopt the budget and budget modifications, but that's only the power to destroy," he said. "And legislatures should have the power to create as much as the Mayor does."
The Mayor and Mr. Vallone have usually tried to work out their differences quietly, and the Democratic Council has usually chosen to adopt city budgets with relatively little fuss.
But Mr. Giuliani and the Council have disagreed regularly over the legislative body's institutional power.
For example, the Council filed lawsuits seeking a role in mid-year budget modifications and in the creation of an independent police review board. The Council also sued to win final approval rights over the sale of city hospitals.
The legal wrangling over the budget ended in a split decision, and the other lawsuits are pending. Thomas V. Ognibene, the Council's minority leader from Queens, predicted the Speaker's Charter proposals would not become a partisan issue.
"It'll be an institutional issue between the executive and legislative branches," he said.
Eric Lane, counsel to the 1989 Charter Revision Commission and now a law professor at Hofstra University, said the authors of the City Charter deliberately chose to tilt the balance of budget-making power toward the Mayor. After the fiscal crisis of the 1970's, the commission decided that the Mayor's office would be a better check on runaway spending than a broader legislative body that did not have as much direct accountability.
"The commission fully believed that the power to estimate revenues was one that should remain with the Mayor," Mr. Lane said. "Legislative bodies tend to be inflationary because you try to satisfy people by providing them with benefits for their constituents. Coming out of the near bankruptcy of the mid-70's, everyone was very wary about creating another opportunity to inflate the budget."
But Mr. Lane said another point raised by Mr. Vallone -- that the Council should have more of a role in determining what agencies' budgets are cut, had more validity. Because the Charter was revised in an era of rising revenues, he said, the commission did not fully anticipate the kinds of massive mid-year budget cuts made by both former Mayor David N. Dinkins and Mr. Giuliani.
Representatives from some advocacy groups, who have often criticized the Council as an ineffective counterweight to the Mayor, nonetheless welcomed Mr. Vallone's proposal. "Charter revision has its risks," said Chris Meyer, a senior attorney with the New York Public Interest Research Group. "But the Speaker is right. The city needs a more balanced government. The City Council is not a fully co-equal branch under the current City Charter."
Penelope Pi-Sunyer, executive director of the City Project, a liberal fiscal policy group, agreed. "There is more they could be doing with the power they have now," she said. "But they indeed are not equal partners with the Mayor. They can't do their own budget if they can't make revenue estimates.'
The 1989 Charter revision gave the Council new power over the budget and land-use policy. But the Council has never rejected the Mayor's budget, opting instead to negotiate compromises which critics have said amounted to little more than tinkering around the margins.
The Council accepts most mayoral initiatives after making only minor adjustments. But the legislative body has occasionally shown that it has the will to derail proposals in order to respond to community concerns. Last year, the Council rejected Mr. Giuliani's plan to remove fire alarm call boxes from the city streets after neighborhood groups complained bitterly.
On land use issues, the Council has been more assertive, most recently rejecting Mr. Giuliani's proposal to bring more megastores into the city.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
New Warnings About Dollar Help Yen Pick Up Strength

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar fell for a second consecutive day against the yen yesterday, after senior Government officials in Japan intensified warnings about the yen's weakness and called for currency stability.
Currency traders said the dollar also declined after Gail Fosler, chief economist for the influential Conference Board research group, said the dollar was 15 percent overvalued against the yen. The dollar was little changed in most other foreign-exchange dealings. 
 "We had a group of officials in Japan trying to talk down the dollar," said Robert Gilmartin, a dollar-yen trader at First Union National Bank in Charlotte, N.C.
He said Ms. Fosler's comments, made at a National Economists Club speech in Washington, "helped lead the final move down."
In late trading in New York, the dollar settled at 115.23 yen, down from 115.68 on Monday. The dollar rose to 1.5640 marks from 1.5632. The British pound was unchanged at $1.6941.
The dollar began the trading day on a weaker note from the residual effects of comments on Monday by Tadashi Ogawa, a Japanese Vice Minister of Finance, who called the yen's recent rapid weakening against the dollar undesirable.
That was the first official Japanese comment on the dollar's series of 45-month highs reached against the yen the last few weeks.
The official comments from Japan broadened yesterday, with warnings from Finance Minister Hiroshi Mitsuzuka, Trade Minister Shinji Sato and the Economic Planning Agency Director General, Taro Aso, that the yen's weakening could pose problems for Japan. All three spoke at news conferences in Japan.
Mr. Mitsuzuka added that the ministry would take unspecified steps in response to any yen decline deemed to be excessive. His comments in particular helped bring the dollar as low as 114.92 yen during the day.
"Now you've got three guys speaking with a little bit more veiled threat," Bob Near, vice president for foreign exchange at the Bank of New York, said. For that reason, he said, "the market is very wary of buying the dollar at these levels. There's a healthy dose of caution in the marketplace."

HEADLINE: Swiss Offer To Start Fund For Victims Of Holocaust

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL 

DATELINE: BONN, Jan. 7

 BODY:
Seeking to defuse the crisis over its financial dealings during the Nazi era, the Swiss Government offered today to use money from unclaimed bank accounts dating to World War II to set up a fund "in favor of Holocaust victims and their descendants."
But the offer failed to deflect a tide of Jewish anger over recent remarks by a high Swiss official who called Jewish demands for compensation from Switzerland "extortion and blackmail." 
 Jewish groups have demanded an apology for the remarks by the official, Economics Minister Jean-Pascal Delamuraz, but the Government statement today offering to set up a Holocaust memorial fund made no reference to an apology. Last week Mr. Delamuraz said he had been "misunderstood" and was sorry for any grief he might have caused.
The public confrontation between Switzerland and Jewish groups in the United States and Israel has been building since last year, fueled by assertions that Swiss banks profited from wartime dealings in Nazi gold and subsequently hoarded bank deposits belonging to Jews who had been killed in the Holocaust.
But in recent days the conflict has assumed new overtones for Switzerland, with talk among Jewish groups of an organized boycott of Swiss banks and the first tangible indications of financial repercussions on Monday when Swiss bank shares dipped in stock market trading.
Switzerland's banks -- and their reputations as havens of security and confidentiality -- are central to its economic well-being. The insistent clamor, particularly from the United States, for disclosure of their activities during and after the Nazi era has worried Swiss bankers.
After 90 minutes of telephone conversations, the seven ministers in Switzerland's Cabinet issued a statement today saying the 40 million Swiss francs, or $29.5 million, discovered so far in dormant accounts should be "put to proper use."
The Cabinet said it was "ready to immediately take up discussions with the banks and the interested organizations regarding the creation of a fund in favor of Holocaust victims and their descendants."
A Government spokesman, Achille Casanova, told reporters that there was no apology for Mr. Delamuraz's contentious remarks because "they were misunderstood and led to excessive reactions."
The developments in Bern, the Swiss capital, drew an angry response from Avraham Burg, the chairman of the Jewish Agency in Jerusalem, who is supposed to be part of an investigative panel set up under Paul Volcker, the former head of the United States Federal Reserve, to search for money belonging to Holocaust victims in dormant Swiss accounts.
"The Swiss are again playing with words, attacking marginal issues and ignoring the central issues," an aide quoted Mr. Burg as saying. "They're trying to buy us with money that's not theirs."
After a meeting with Swiss officials in Jerusalem, Mr. Burg said a decision would be reached within four weeks on whether to urge a boycott of dealings with Swiss banks -- an unparalleled move against the notion of integrity that is the Swiss banks' stock in trade.
As both sides depict it, the confrontation is not just about money. Switzerland fears that as Mr. Delamuraz said, the establishment of a compensation fund from Switzerland's own resources would constitute a damaging "admission of guilt" that its financiers profited illicitly from the Holocaust and its aftermath.
But Jewish groups insist that Switzerland must face the moral issue of whether the descendants of Holocaust victims suffered because of Swiss greed. "We are going to settle once and forever the moral and economic commitment that we have to families, fathers, mothers who have perished in the Holocaust," Mr. Burg said today. "Not even one dime or dollar or Swiss franc" that was acquired "in an unjust way will remain in their safety vaults."
After Hitler came to power in 1933, many Jews, risking prosecution in Germany, exported their assets to neutral Switzerland for safety as the Nazi authorities embarked on ever-greater persecution.
Switzerland expanded guarantees of bank confidentiality to protect these new customers. But those same bank secrecy laws have now been invoked in Switzerland to prevent full disclosure of the details of dormant accounts.
The Swiss Bankers Association said today that not all of the $29.5 million found in dormant accounts in recent months could be traced back to depositors who later died in the Holocaust. Therefore, the association said, not all of that money could be used in the Swiss Government's proposed Holocaust memorial fund until the title to it had been established.
"The legal rights of individuals must be guaranteed," the association spokeswoman, Silvia Matile, told Reuters.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Dollar's Slide Hurts Prices Of Treasuries

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
The Treasury market turned down yesterday in response to a slide in the dollar and continued concern that the economy might be growing at a fast enough pace to accelerate inflation and drive interest rates higher. But the market bounced off the day's lows on a weak retail sales report.
The weekly Lynch, Jones & Ryan Inc. Redbook retail sales index showed retail sales up just seven-tenths of a percent for the week ended last Saturday, slightly above the six-tenths of a percent the previous week. 
 At the market's close, the 30-year bond was off 5/32 , to a price of 9612/32 to yield 6.78 percent, up from 6.77 percent on Monday. That is the highest yield since Oct. 28, when it was 6.83 percent.
Market participants basically ignored a factory orders report for November, even though it was not as weak as had been expected. The Government said factory orders slid four-tenths of a percent in November, a little stronger performance than the decline of seven-tenths of a percent economists had expected after a 1.1 percent increase in October.
Many traders and managers cited the dollar weakness as the cause of the market's downturn yesterday. Tony Crescenzi, head of government bond trading at Miller, Tabak, Hirsch & Company, said comments by Japanese officials had not been helpful. The dollar's drop against the yen came after senior Japanese officials suggested they would oppose further declines in their currency.
"An excessive decline in the yen against the U.S. dollar would be undesirable," the Finance Minister, Hiroshi Mitsuzuka, said. He also said the Japanese Government would take "appropriate measures as necessary" in the foreign exchange market.
A strong dollar makes dollar-denominated investments like Treasury securities more attractive to foreign investors.
"These are threats," Mr. Crescenzi said, adding they may be causing Japanese investors to sell American investments. Mr. Crescenzi pointed out that the decline in the Japanese stock market had meant that Japanese banks could not draw on that capital to write off loans.
Patrick R. Ledford, senior fixed-income portfolio manager at Citibank Global Asset Management, said of the market, "The fundamentals are still intact, with moderate growth and low inflation."
But, he added, "Technically, it is obvious the market is weak, and susceptible to rumors of central bank and hedge fund selling."
Mr. Ledford said that between the weaker dollar and potential supply buildup, the market technical factors were not good over the near term.
Larry Berman, senior fixed-income analyst with Technical Data in Boston, said that unless there were bullish data in the Producer Price Index and employment report this week, the market was likely to see 7 percent yields in short order.
"The upside targets continue to be lowered as the technical condition continues to deteriorate," he said. He predicted it would take several months of favorable economic data to repair the damage that has been done in the last several weeks.

HEADLINE: The Neediest Cases;
Ex-Secretary Sees Bureaucracy From the Other Side

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN 

 BODY:
For 13 years, Eunice M. was a rivet in New York City's vast bureaucratic machine. She worked as a secretary at a municipal agency in lower Manhattan, processing a flow of paperwork that remained constant even as the agency repeatedly changed its name and purpose.
Now, sick and unemployed, forced to live with a grown daughter because she has no home of her own, Eunice spends her days slogging through bureaucracy but from the other side. She is awaiting a hearing on whether she qualifies for disability benefits. She hopes to get an apartment in a public housing project. 
 Caught in a wave of downsizing more than two years ago, Eunice, 49, accepted a buyout offer that gave her six months of unemployment benefits and health insurance. She took a course to become a medical assistant and had hoped to move south to be near relatives in North Carolina. The plans fell apart.
She did not have enough money to move. She hoped to get another job and save up. "I wanted to work in a doctor's office or a hospital," she said. "I was out there for at least two years trying to find full-time employment. I took my resume all over."
But she could not find a job.
Last year, her chronic asthma and arthritis worsened, preventing her from continuing the job search. "My knees get weak," she said. "I have a difficult time getting up and down the subways."
She could not keep up with the rent for the apartment in Corona, Queens, that she shared with her youngest daughter, a college student, and she put her belongings in storage to prevent them from being seized during eviction. The daughter dropped out of Baruch College and got a job in a vitamin store. The two left the apartment to live with Eunice's oldest daughter and two grandchildren in the Astoria Houses, a dilapidated public apartment complex in the far northwestern tip of Queens.
Late last summer, the storage company threatened to sell off Eunice's belongings -- furniture, a television, lamps, dishes, linens and other personal effects -- because she had not been paying the monthly storage fee of $207. Anxious not to lose her things, Eunice called the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies, one of seven charities supported by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.
Now in its 85th annual appeal, the Neediest Cases Fund assists seven of the city's largest and oldest social service agencies in extending a helping hand to New Yorkers who need one. The Times pays all administrative expenses so readers' donations go directly to services and cash assistance for the poor.
The federation gave Eunice a $627 grant to keep her belongings from being auctioned. But she still does not have an apartment and her possessions remain in storage. She has sought the help of Claire Shulman, the Queens Borough President, and City Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone, whose district includes the Astoria Houses and who wrote a letter on her behalf to the Housing Authority.
She is hoping to be assigned an apartment that will keep her close to her family and her doctors in western Queens. And she still hopes that someday she will be able to move south. "I have to try to be strong and have faith, to know things are going to be better someday," she said. "This is just a temporary setback."

HEADLINE: In Election Year, Giuliani and Vallone Compete on Tax Cuts

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY 

 BODY:
With municipal elections coming up in November, both Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and the City Council Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, are advancing proposals to reduce local taxes, trying to give voters a bit of relief even though the city still faces severe budget problems.
The Mayor is expected to call this month for a basket of cuts in sales and business taxes when he issues his preliminary spending plan for the 1998 fiscal year, which begins on July 1. The cuts could total as much as $200 million in a $34 billion budget, his aides said. 
 Not to be outdone, Mr. Vallone, a Queens Democrat, announced on Monday a proposal to reduce four municipal taxes, including the sales tax on household items like diapers, soap and toilet paper. Mr. Vallone said the cuts would total $65 million in the 1998 fiscal year, rising to $305 million annually in 2001.
But the Mayor said he wanted to go even further. "There is almost no level of tax reduction that the City Council would propose that I wouldn't support, and then more than that," Mr. Giuliani said.
The Mayor and Mr. Vallone have said that the city can afford the cuts, though they acknowledge that they must close a projected deficit for 1998 that could be as high as $1.8 billion. But it is unclear whether Gov. George E. Pataki and state legislators, who must approve any cuts in city taxes, agree.
Similar proposals by the Mayor and the Council have foundered in the Legislature in recent years. For example, city officials have often asked Albany for cuts in the municipal sales tax on clothing, but last year the Legislature passed only a one-week repeal of the state and city sales tax for clothing under $500.
The one-week cut, which legislative leaders characterized as an experiment, begins on Jan. 18. Yesterday, some of the Democrats who control the Assembly said they were wary of approving the new plans from the Mayor or Mr. Vallone, saying city officials had to show how they would close their projected deficit without major service reductions before the Legislature weighed new tax cuts. In the State Senate, the more fiscally conservative Republican majority responded favorably, saying that the proposals would probably encounter little opposition.
Even if the cuts are blocked in Albany, though, the Mayor and Council members can still take credit for pushing them. So they involve little political risk, administration and Council officials said. Either way, city officials hope to garner the benefits when they seek re-election.
The interplay between Albany and City Hall is further complicated by the debate over the city's personal income tax. Mr. Giuliani in recent months has strongly lobbied the Legislature to extend a 12.5 percent surcharge on the income tax to help him close the next budget deficit. That surcharge, which expired on Dec. 31, would bring in about $500 million for the city in the 1998 fiscal year, officials said. Governor Pataki and legislative leaders failed to reach an agreement on renewing the surcharge during a one-day special session of the Legislature last month.
Legislative leaders have promised to take it up again before the end of this month, but they may find themselves in an awkward position -- being asked to continue the surcharge while cutting other taxes.
Mr. Giuliani has said there is nothing wrong with reducing some taxes while keeping others high, asserting that the city needs to tinker with its mix of taxes to spur its economy. He has said he is very interested in reducing the sales tax, which he says hurts poor people the most.

HEADLINE: Real Estate;
14 sound stages will be built on speculation southwest of downtown Los Angeles.

BYLINE: By Morris Newman 

DATELINE: MANHATTAN BEACH, Calif.

 BODY:
A DEVELOPMENT partnership has acquired a site in this ocean front city 15 miles southwest of downtown Los Angeles with plans to build 14 motion picture sound stages.
The project is a sign of both the strong demand for such centers in the Los Angeles area and the changes in the Southern California economy being wrought by the entertainment industry. 
 The partners are Shamrock Holdings Inc. of Burbank, Calif., and CFN/Flesch & Neuhauser of Los Angeles. They say they will start construction in July on the $77 million Manhattan Beach Studios project, with completion set in July 1998.
In all, the studios project is expected to contain 550,000 square feet of sound stages, ranging in size from 18,000 to 30,000 square feet, a free-standing office building of 58,000 square feet and a commissary.
The 22.5-acre site is in an industrial area of the city traditionally devoted to aerospace-related manufacturing.
Shamrock Holdings is a closely held investment company owned by the Roy E. Disney family. It controls a diverse group of companies with involvements in real estate, cable television, telecommunications equipment, and electronics, food manufacturing and footwear. Together, those concerns generate about $6 billion in revenues, according to the company.
Shamrock's commercial real estate activities include the acquisition and renovation of a four-building office complex in West Hills, Calif., in partnership with Regent Properties, as well as the acquisition of two renovated historic buildings in downtown Los Angeles and the development of three other office buildings in the Los Angeles area.
The project represents an unusual example of sound stages being developed as speculative real estate. Although major studios lease such stages to film and television production companies, the demand for them far exceeds the supply, and companies frequently lease warehouses and aerospace hangars for film production. Before the Manhattan Beach project, however, few developers had undertaken to build new sound stages.
The Manhattan Beach studios will have advantages over the existing choices of sound stages available to film companies, according to Richard Gentilucci, vice president of real estate for Shamrock Holdings. "Most of the other facilities have only one, two or three sound stages, and they are old and antiquated," Mr. Gentilucci said.
Although the developers intend the buildings to be suitable for all kinds of film production, they are tailoring the structures for television production. Each building is large enough to accommodate the space requirements of a television series, including several permanent sets, and sites for multiple cameras at each set.
The stages will offer high ceilings of 35 feet and column-free space favored by film companies, as well as soundproof concrete walls. The site will also provide parking for 1,800cars.
Southwestern Los Angeles, known as the South Bay, is a pioneering area for sound stages, according to Robert P. Dubbins, an industrial real estate broker in the Century City office of CB Commercial Real Estate Services. Filming has tended to cluster near the established centers of the entertainment industry in the West Los Angeles area and in Burbank.
Most buildings being used as sound stages are near Burbank, the home base of the Walt Disney Company and Warner Brothers, which is about 20 miles northeast of Manhattan Beach.
On the other hand, the start of construction on the delayed DreamWorks SKG campus at Playa Vista, which is about five miles north of Manhattan Beach, may make the South Bay area more acceptable to the entertainment industry, Mr. Dubbins said.
The site, which is close to the ocean and an affluent residential community, will be attractive to the movie industry, said Ronald M. Flesch, principal of CFN/Flesch & Neuhauser. "Studio people like to work in low buildings with a very quiet atmosphere," he said. "They don't like a bustling environment."
Out of an inventory of about 13 million square feet of industrial space in the West Los Angeles area, currently an entertainment stronghold, about one million square feet is currently devoted to film production and related businesses, with studio space currently leasing from about $7 to $10 a square foot annually, Mr. Dubbins said.
"You can't get away from these movie people," he added. "They're taking over the market."
That does not seem to worry officials of cities in the South Bay, which suffered the heaviest job losses in the Los Angeles region in the early 90's because of a decline in the aviation and military businesses. "The last few years have been difficult," said Geoff Dolan, city manager of Manhattan Beach. "To bring a new industry here to help diversify the economy would be a great addition to the South Bay."

HEADLINE: U.S. Factory Orders Slipped in November

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 7

 BODY:
Orders to American factories slipped in November for the first time in three months, the Commerce Department reported today, but analysts said the report did not alter their view that the economy was growing moderately at the end of the year.
"Economic growth in the fourth quarter exceeded growth in the third quarter, but it was nothing out of bounds," said Stuart G. Hoffman, an economist at the PNC Bank Corporation in Pittsburgh. 
 The Commerce Department reported that orders for both durable and nondurable goods fell four-tenths of 1 percent in November to a seasonally adjusted $320.5 billion from $321.9 billion in October.
It was the first drop since orders fell 2.1 percent in August. Orders are considered an important gauge of the nation's manufacturing strength. Continued declines could result in decreased production and fewer jobs.
The decline was in large part a result of softer demand for electronic equipment and came after strong gains of 1.1 percent in October and 2.6 percent in September.
Factory orders for durable goods -- items like tractors and television sets expected to last more than three years -- slid 1.5 percent.
But the drop included a 9.1 percent decline in electronic and other electrical equipment, including semiconductors and communications equipment. This category had surged 17.2 percent the previous month, an increase analysts had said was unsustainable.

HEADLINE: Mail Bomb Is Linked To a Later Suicide

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: CLIFTON PARK, N.Y., Jan. 7

 BODY:
A bombing that injured a 10-year-old girl on Dec. 24 and a suicide five days later were the final acts of an unemployed salesman who nursed a five-year-old vendetta over losing his job, investigators said today.
State and Federal law enforcement officials said that the salesman, Christopher P. Gilson, 58, aimed his rage not at the man who dismissed him, but at the man's twin brother and his family. Five days after the bomb detonated, Mr. Gilson killed himself with a shotgun, an incident that was at first thought to be a hunting accident but that has since been ruled a suicide. 
 Investigators said that Mr. Gilson left the bomb in the mailbox of Jude Reardon, 41, of Clifton Park, about 15 miles north of Albany. The package was addressed to "Mr. Jude Reardon and family," and his daughter, Jordan, opened it. After the explosion, she spent six days at Westchester County Medical Center in Valhalla. She is expected to recover fully.
Officials said that Mr. Gilson had been a salesman at GE Consulting Services in Colonie, just outside Albany, where John C. Reardon, Jude Reardon's twin brother, was his supervisor. They said that Mr. Gilson had been dismissed in 1991 and had not had steady work since then.
Investigators said they did not expect ever to fully understand Mr. Gilson's motive. Mr. Gilson did not know Jude Reardon and his family, Maj. Peter A. Lawrence of the state police said, yet the package was clearly intended for them.

HEADLINE: SOCIAL SECURITY: THE POSSIBLE IMPACT;
Risks of Many Kinds in Reworking Social Security

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL 

 BODY:
Social Security may not be getting a face lift this year, but the report from a Federal advisory panel released Monday insures that Washington, for the first time in more than a decade, will be forced to look long and hard at what ails the giant public pension system. A host of radically different proposals -- with radically varying effects on the economy, on the financial markets and on the incentives for Americans to save for retirement -- are now on the table.
Each of the plans to shift into private securities some of the money that Social Security now invests exclusively in government bonds would give a lift to the stock market. But the effects would be modest, probably temporary and raise new questions about whether pensioners or taxpayers are prepared to absorb the consequences of market volatility. 
 "Shuffling the ownership of stocks between public and private hands redistributes risk, but not much else," said Barry Bosworth, an economist at the Brookings Institution.
 Indeed, those who see the partial privatization of Social Security and the subsequent flood of cash into private securities as a way to keep the good times rolling on Wall Street may be frustrated.
For one thing, nothing is likely to change in the immediate future. For another, there is reason to doubt the conventional wisdom that money going into 401(k)'s and other private pension accounts is the principal reason the market has experienced its stunning run-up since the early 1980's. Indeed, private savings have not, in fact, increased much in the last few years.
 More plausibly, rising stock prices have been driven by the expectation that American business will continue to increase its profits in the future -- an expectation linked to low inflation and the lack of a recession in recent memory.
"We really don't know what would happen to securities prices" if the stock market began to get Social Security money, said Stephen Ross, a specialist in finance at the Yale School of Management, "but we don't expect the impact would be large."
 After all, the flows of new investment in stocks that could be expected if one of the plans was established would be large but not without parallel. In the early going, each plan would be expected to generate new investment in stocks similar to the amounts now being contributed to 401(k) plans each year -- about $69 billion in 1992, the latest for which figures are available. That is little more than the volume of new public offerings of stock, which was $59 billion last year.
Once a plan is fully established, cash flowing from it into the stock market would resemble the amount investors are now putting into stock mutual funds each year. In the first 11 months of 1996, mutual funds that invest in American stocks took in $165 billion in net new money from investors; none of the three plans outlined by the council would yield a similar volume of new investment until the year 2010 or later. And by that time, inflation and a larger economy would dilute the impact of any additional flow of funds.
More significant, the plans could have a large and not entirely predictable effect on savings and growth. "Increased savings, which yields increased wealth, lies at the core of politically and economically sustainable reform," argues Carolyn Weaver, director of pension studies at the American Enterprise Institute and one of the 13 members of the Advisory Council on Social Security. That panel split into three factions over how to rescue Social Security from future bankruptcy.
In one sense the Social Security crisis is synthetic. Today, with payroll tax revenues far outpacing pension outlays, the Government faces no imminent cash squeeze. Indeed, narrowly viewed as a "pay as you go" system, Social Security is viable for another two decades.
 But seen through the lens of a future retiree, Social Security is wildly askew because the big baby- boom generation is owed some $9 trillion more than following generations are obliged to pay in Social Security taxes. And unless the economic pie grows far more rapidly than is now predicted, the only way to meet the system's obligations will be to transfer trillions in income throughout the 21st century from the young to those who will be old.
 One plausible political solution is neglect. Indeed, "pay as you go" might well be rationalized as a way to focus limited political energies on more pressing budgetary problems -- in particular, the need to raise revenue or cut outlays for Medicare and Medicaid. But delay means even more drastic change down the road. In 2011, projected outlays will equal payroll taxes collected at current rates. In 2025, however, the "pay as you go" deficit would reach 3 percent of national income -- forcing sharp tax increases or raising budget deficits while reducing national savings.
 Another idea, rejected by the panel but popular among many of those who want to preserve Social Security as it is, would be a payroll tax increase today that is large enough to pay for the boomers' retirement and beyond. "A 2.2-percentage-point increase would go a long way," explained Peter Diamond, an economist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. (Currently, workers and employers together pay 12.4 percent on salaries up to about $70,000 to finance Social Security.)
Such a tax increase would certainly shovel trillions of dollars of revenue into Federal coffers over the next quarter-century. And if it reduced the Federal debt by the same amount, it could increase national wealth and lower the cost of private investment. But that's a big "if", Mr. Bosworth suggests. "Would Congress keep its hands off the money?" he asks.
An equally simple fix -- a 1.1- percentage-point cut in annual cost-of-living adjustments for pensioners to reflect the near-consensus among economists that the Consumer Price Index overstates inflation -- is advocated by Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York, the ranking Democrat on the Finance Committee. By restraining benefits, he contends, Washington would largely achieve "actuarial balance" -- insuring that the expected inflow of funds would equal the projected outflow of benefits for several decades.
"If we were to make that small adjustment in the annual increase in retirement benefits," he wrote recently, "the system would be in actuarial balance until 2052."
 But there is no free lunch here. Unless lower-income recipients were protected, the already-serious financial problems of retirees who outlive private sources of income would only worsen. "The poverty rate among elderly widows is far higher than the poverty rate in general," Mr. Diamond, the M.I.T. economist, notes.
 For now, Washington can be expected to tread warily. But when it finally acts, the plans offered by the three factions on the advisory panel may well lead the pack.
The first, the "maintenance of benefits" option, is favored by 6 of the 13 council members. It would apply a handful of technical corrections that add up to modest cuts in benefits for future retirees, a reshuffling of some money now going to Medicare, plus a 1.6-percentage-point increase in the payroll tax in 50 years. The group, led by Robert M. Ball, a former Commissioner of Social Security, also recommends taking a hard look at investing 40 percent of the trust fund in private securities, with an eye toward increasing the return on the system's assets.
 Yet the plan would do little to actually increase savings by more than a token amount, notes Sylvester Schieber, an economist at the Watson Wyatt consulting concern and a member of the advisory council. Every dollar the trust fund invested in stocks rather than government bonds would be a dollar that the Treasury would have to borrow from private investors, leaving the total availability of capital unchanged. "You're just shuffling existing income -- and risk," Mr. Schieber contended.
 The partial privatization plan advocated by Mr. Schieber would redirect 5 percentage points of the existing payroll tax into personal security accounts that could be invested in stocks and bonds. The idea, its sponsors say, is to encourage individuals to plan for their own retirement while leaving the basic pension safety net intact. National savings would be raised more directly through a payroll tax increase of 1.5 percentage points, specifically designated to cover the unfinanced costs of benefits promised to older Americans.
 But here, too, there is ambiguity. If the stock market performed poorly, would Congress bail out retirees at the expense of taxpayers -- or simply by running deficits?
 Edward Gramlich, an economist at the University of Michigan who was the chairman of the advisory panel, championed a third approach. He would use the popular appeal of privatization to transform the unpalatable tax increase into a politically acceptable forced savings. Individual accounts, financed by a mandatory payroll levy and invested in private securities, would sit on top of the existing system.
 But that plan's impact on national savings is debatable as well. If the Government forced households to save in personal retirement accounts, would Americans respond by saving less in 401(k) plans and other existing retirement plans?
 Social Security's problems are well understood. Too well, perhaps. For it is now apparent that successful fixes to an institution so fundamental to the security of the vast majority of Americans are more elusive than many realize.

HEADLINE: Rowland Says G.O.P. Keeps Legislative Power

BYLINE: By JONATHAN RABINOVITZ 

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Jan. 7

 BODY:
The balance of power in the state's General Assembly has shifted toward the Democrats this year, but Gov. John G. Rowland maintains that the agenda is still being set by Republicans.
When the legislature convenes on Wednesday, Mr. Rowland says the focus will not be on whether to cut taxes but on which taxes to cut. 
 "Make no mistake, the whole atmosphere has changed in this body," Mr. Rowland, the first Republican Governor of Connecticut in 20 years, said in an interview. "There aren't two people out there promoting any new spending programs or any expansion of programs. The debate is which taxes to cut, and everybody feels fine about that. It's the property tax or the income tax or the gas tax."
"That's a fight I can have all day long," Mr. Rowland added. "At the end of the day, everybody wins."
Despite that optimism, he is facing a different political landscape than he did in the last two years. Democrats, who controlled the House of Representatives, gained State Senate control in the November elections, perhaps emboldening them to push their own agenda.
State Representative Chris Donovan, a Meriden Democrat, brushed aside the idea that the legislature would not consider new programs. After the "drubbing" that the Republicans took in November, he said, the Republicans' agenda had little credibility. He said he was part of a group of legislators who planned to push for an enhanced safety net for people whose welfare benefits may be cut off, as well as an expansion of medical coverage for uninsured children.
The session is also expected to bring significant changes to the state's educational system. The state is under court order to remedy segregation in Hartford's schools and in its surrounding suburbs, and Mr. Rowland acknowledged that education initiatives will be a top priority.
The House Speaker, Thomas D. Ritter, a Democrat, reiterated on Friday that he was committed to expanding poor children's access to preschool programs, as well as increasing aid to cities, ideas shared by the Senate Democrats.
Today, the Senate Democrats offered an agenda that included increased spending for higher education and for student financial aid, and a host of other initiatives on education, crime, health care, campaign finance and economic development.
Yet perhaps the most striking aspect of their agenda was the many items Mr. Rowland could endorse: the heavy emphasis on tax cuts and on controlling state spending.
The Senate Democrats' agenda called for restraining growth in state spending, cutting the gasoline tax and moving more quickly to reduce the state's corporate income tax.
Dean Pagani, the Governor's spokesman, said, "We agree with most everything they've put on their agenda."
The session, of course, is likely to have some clashes, and today, Mr. Rowland and State Senate Democratic leaders exchanged shots over the centerpiece of the Democrats' tax reduction plan: a tax credit known as the circuit breaker that Mr. Rowland opposes. It would give an income tax deduction to any household that pays property taxes that exceed 5 percent of its income.
Mr. Rowland said the circuit breaker is "social engineering at best." A straight income tax cut, he said, would be easier for the public to grasp and not make the mistake of limiting the tax to a select group.
But State Senator Kevin B. Sullivan, a West Hartford Democrat who will take over as Senate President Pro Tem on Wednesday, said people care most about property tax relief, particularly in the state's cities. "If cutting their most burdensome tax is social engineering, then I think most people in the state of Connecticut will be happy to get that kind of socially engineered tax cut," he said.

HEADLINE: Reversal by Big Stocks Lifts Dow Over 6,600

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
A late turnaround yesterday pushed the Dow Jones industrial average to its first close above 6,600 as bargain-hunting investors shrugged off rising interest rates in another volatile session.
Broader measures also turned positive, with the Nasdaq market closing at a record high for the second consecutive day. 
 The Dow erased a 55-point deficit, rising 33.48 points, to 6,600.66, as several leading components reversed course in the afternoon.
On Monday, the blue-chip barometer held on to a record high after surrendering a 75-point gain. The move above 6,600 marks a 10 percent advance less than three months after the Dow's first close over 6,000 on Oct. 14.
Stocks were hurt from the start of trading by another weak day in the bond market, where interest rates have been rising the last week amid a series of surprisingly strong economic reports. Bonds had rallied through the second half of 1996 amid indications that economic growth might be moderating enough to keep inflation in check.
The renewed inflation jitters were not calmed by yesterday's news that factory orders slipped four-tenths of 1 percent in November. While it was the first drop in three months, analysts had expected a steeper decline of 1 percent.
Bonds trimmed their losses later in the session, encouraging money managers to take advantage of the day's depressed share prices.
"This market has a lot of investors who are using dips to buy; there's a lot of money coming into the market early in the year," Robert Freedman, chief investment officer for the John Hancock Funds in Boston, said, referring to the flows of new capital from year-end bonuses and contributions to retirement plans.
The Dow bounced back with the help of turnarounds by I.B.M., which rose 2 1/8, to 163 3/8, after erasing a deficit of 1 7/8; Procter & Gamble, which gained 2, to 111 1/8, after dropping as much as 1 1/8 earlier, and General Electric, which was off 7/8 before finishing with a gain of 2, at 101.
Advancing issues outnumbered decliners by nearly 3 to 2 on the New York Stock Exchange, where volume was heavy at nearly 538.4 million shares, up slightly from Monday's brisk pace.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 5.58, to 753.23. The technology-rich Nasdaq composite index rose 11.33, to 1,327.73, with the help of Intel, which rebounded from a deficit of 1 7/8 points to finish at 143 3/8, up 4 1/2.

HEADLINE: SOCIAL SECURITY: THE REACTION;
Lawmakers Are Intrigued, But Still Want To Go Slowly

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 7

 BODY:
Senior members of Congress from both parties expressed interest today in proposals to invest some Social Security assets in the stock market, but they said that the idea required much more study.
Initially, lawmakers seemed to be most intrigued by the proposal that the Government should control the investments, deciding how much of payroll tax revenue is invested in which stocks or mutual funds. 
 Soon after Congress convened today, Representative Gerald B. H. Solomon, a Republican from upstate New York who is chairman of the Rules Committee, introduced a bill to let the Government make such investments, as recommended Monday by 6 of the 13 members of a Federal advisory panel.
Mr. Solomon said he wanted to encourage investment of some of the Social Security trust fund in "investment-grade securities, real assets with real investment returns." Since the creation of Social Security in 1935, the trust fund has been allowed to invest only in government securities, which have historically had a lower rate of return than stocks.
Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota and Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the Democratic leaders of the two chambers, said they were willing to test such an approach, but they stipulated that investment decisions should be made by the Government, not by workers.
"The trust fund itself ought to experiment in private investment, with a pilot project allocating a certain percentage of its resources in the market to afford us an opportunity to compare both the security as well as the return on investment," Mr. Daschle said.
But some lawmakers had other ideas. Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York was at the White House today talking to President Clinton about the formula used to compute the cost-of-living adjustment for Social Security. The formula is based on the Consumer Price Index, which many economists say overstates inflation.
Revising the formula would save tens of billions of dollars and could offer a way out of the nation's "protracted fiscal crisis," said Mr. Moynihan, the senior Democrat on the Finance Committee, which has legislative authority over Social Security.
The Senator said that investing payroll tax contributions in stocks would not necessarily increase national savings, because the Government might have to borrow more to make up for the money taken out of the trust fund. The surplus in the trust fund is now, in effect, available to help pay the general operating expenses of the Government.
Republicans say they will not propose changes in the cost-of-living formula unless Mr. Clinton takes up the issue first.
Senator Pete V. Domenici, the New Mexico Republican who is chairman of the Budget Committee, said, "This won't be done unless the President takes the lead and it's done in a bipartisan fashion."
Mr. Domenici was cool to the major proposals offered by the Advisory Council on Social Security. "I'm one of those who say, 'Let's go slow on Social Security investing in the stock market,' " he said.
On the other hand, the House Republican leader, Dick Armey of Texas, said he was pleased that all the council members were willing to consider some such investment. That, he said, was "a vast paradigm shift."
Likewise, Senator William V. Roth Jr., the Delaware Republican who heads the Finance Committee, said: "For the first time, all members of a Social Security Advisory Council have recommended that some of Social Security's funds be invested in the private marketplace to improve the return. This is a very important development and greatly increases the chance that Congress will adopt some kind of investment option."
Mr. Gephardt, the House Democratic leader, said "privatization is not part of the solution," but investing in stocks was "worth looking at."
He added: "Raising the rate of return on the trust fund's investments could reduce the financial pressures on the system. But there are a lot of questions that need to be answered, and we must not rush to adopt a plan. We've got time. Let's recognize that the stock market goes up and down. We must not gamble the trust fund away."


GRAPHIC: Members of a Federal advisory panel agreed that Social Security faces long-term fiscal problems. They were in accord on some steps toward reining in costs, but split on how to increase revenue. Each of the three plans put forward would allow the investment of the system's funds in the stock market, instead of just government bonds, but would do so in very different ways.
Chart: "Sorting Out the Three Plans"
 The Maintain Benefits plan backed by labor unions would keep Social Security basically as it is: A traditional-style pension in which the Government bears all risk. At the other extreme, the Personal Security Accounts plan would limit the Government guarantee to a low flat payment and turn much of the resources and responsibility over to workers. The Individual Accounts plan would combine some of each approach.
 
POINTS OF AGREEMENT
 All three plans would close the threatened fiscal gap by including new state and local government workers not currently covered by Social Security. All three also assume that changes in the way the Government calculates the Cunsumer Price Index will lead to slightly lower cost-of-living benefit increasesin the future.
 Other proposals supported by majorities on the panel include accelerating a raise in the retirement age to 67, and taxing benefits that exceed a worker's contributions. Taken together, these changes would reduce the long-term deficit by about two-thirds; the changes outlined below would account for the rest.
 
Chart compares the three plans.
 
WHAT COMES NEXT
 Few in Washington expect action anytime soon. President Clinton and Republicans in Congress, both expecting a more immediate fight over Medicare's finances, responded cautiously to the proposals. Others in Congress, most notably Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the New York Democrat, have called for moving quickly to make a sizable adjustment to the Consumer Price Index, a step that would slow the growth of Social Security payments. But the longstanding roadblocks to changing Social Security -- senior citizens' resistance to benefits cuts and business' resistance to tax increases -- remain.
 
(Sources: Advisory Council on Social Security Plans; National Academy of Social Insurance)

HEADLINE: In a Blaze of Attention, McCarthy Joins Congress

BYLINE: By DAN BARRY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 7

 BODY:
Her faithful came to the nation's capital today to celebrate the end of one long journey and the beginning of another. They crammed into her Government office, picked at hors d'oeuvres and watched televised images from the House of Representatives, looking for a spot of red -- her trademark color -- in the sea of gray and blue.
"Look for that red ribbon in her hair," someone shouted. Then came applause and cheers, for on a television propped on a desk could be seen the slight woman in red, Carolyn McCarthy, shortly before she was sworn in as Long Island's newest member of Congress. 
 Since the loss of her husband in the 1993 Long Island Rail Road massacre, Mrs. McCarthy's circuitous path to public office has attracted international attention. Still, her first act as a Congresswoman provided little drama. A registered Republican who ran on the Democratic ticket, she dutifully voted for Richard A. Gephardt, a Democrat, and not for the incumbent Republican and eventual victor, Newt Gingrich, in today's volatile contest for House Speaker.
"I wouldn't vote for Newt Gingrich anyway," she said recently, citing what she considers to be his weak stands against gun violence.
Today, Mrs. McCarthy officially moved into Room 1725 in the Longworth Building of Congress; it is the first time in her life that the retired nurse has had her own office. She dislikes both the desk, made from a wood she described as "government issue," and the overstuffed chair. "It's too big," she said. "I can't even put my feet on the ground."
But she has no complaints about the job itself -- only concerns about how she is perceived.
For example, Mrs. McCarthy said she is aware that some, including the leaders of the National Rifle Association, consider her to be a one-issue Congresswoman, a political rube from Long Island who never so much as served on a school board.
She counters by saying her continuing campaign against gun violence has always been broad in scope, searching for roots to the gun problem in the worlds of education and economics. That is why, she says, she is glad to have been appointed to the House Committee on Economic and Educational Opportunities. "It's not about guns alone," she said. "It's about Head Start, it's about drug-free schools, it's about job opportunities."
As for maneuvering through the daunting halls of Washington, she said, "That's where my life skills are going to come in."
But Representative Gary L. Ackerman, an eight-term Democrat from Long Island and Queens, said that he had advised his friend that life skills were not always enough. "That helps, but this is a different planet here," he said. "It's a different life form down here, and I'm not saying whether it's higher or lower."
Mr. Ackerman said he had told Mrs. McCarthy to be prepared to compromise to win support for her legislation, and to stifle the urge to say too much in public. "I told her also to be wary of all the people who are coming to her in an unsolicited fashion and offering advice because -- I know this will come as a shock to you -- some people down here have their own agendas," he said.
Despite these threats to a public official's credibility and effectiveness, Mr. Ackerman said he expected Mrs. McCarthy to thrive in Washington. "For her to have survived the horrors that she's lived through and come out on top, she has to be pretty hardened," he said. "I think that will serve her well."
The hardening began when a gunman opened fire on a Long Island commuter train, killing six people, including Mrs. McCarthy's husband, Dennis, and wounding 19 others, including her son, Kevin. She resolved to fight rather than withdraw, and became a lobbyist against gun violence. When Daniel Frisa, her Republican Congressman, voted to repeal a ban on assault guns last year, she decided to challenge him. Against considerable odds, she won the election. And so begins the rest of the story of Carolyn McCarthy.
The political courtship of Mrs. McCarthy as a public official is in its earliest stages. Her only contact with Mr. Gephardt, the House minority leader, came shortly after her election in November ("There was concern about how I was going to vote," she said. "I assured him I was going to vote for him.") As for Republicans, the majority leader, Tom DeLay, sent her a book of advice about how to balance one's life while in public office.
She appreciated the gesture, she said, adding, "I don't want to get caught up in the Washington scene."
That wish seems destined to be dreamed of, not realized. Reporters and camera crews accompanied her on the flight from New York on Monday, then joined her search for an apartment later that afternoon. Today they shadowed her from sunrise into late afternoon, asking questions about her ongoing battle to quit smoking, about her plans -- if any -- to attend the Inaugural Ball, about the angel pin she wears on her lapel. For the last two days, in fact, that angel pin has had to share lapel space with a small black microphone, courtesy of a television news program.
This afternoon the gaggle of reporters and film crews almost swallowed her and her son as they walked from her office. So tight was the media noose that Kevin McCarthy, whose limp reflects the grave injuries he received in the shooting, was jostled. The incident upset Mrs. McCarthy, an aide said, adding, "You don't mess with Kevin."
The demands continue to pile up. Mrs. McCarthy said that if she accepted every invitation she received, both here and on Long Island, she would be attending four functions a day, seven days a week. Even as she stood on the House floor, waiting to be sworn in, visitors were stopping by her office to say hello, from Congressional staff members to labor union representatives.
Late this afternoon, Mrs. McCarthy closed her office to the media so she could enjoy the moment with her family and supporters. At some point, she cut into a white sheet cake to celebrate her 53d birthday, which was on Sunday.
Mrs. McCarthy said she was also looking forward to the weekend, when she and other freshmen representatives will be attending seminars in conservative philosophy at the Heritage Foundation in Virginia. While others attend evening receptions, she said, she expects to be in her room, working on belated Christmas cards.

Ackerman and Eliot L. Engel. (Stephen Crowley/The New York Times)

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 1; Foreign Desk
