HEADLINE: SERB RULER YIELDS ON VOTE OUTCOME IN 2d LARGEST CITY

BYLINE: By CHRIS HEDGES 

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Serbia, Jan. 8

 BODY:
The Government of President Slobodan Milosevic, in its most significant concession since daily street protests began seven weeks ago, today acknowledged that opposition parties had won control of Nis, Serbia's second largest city.
The announcement, read on the Government-controlled television tonight, appeared to be an effort by Mr. Milosevic to defuse the protests, which erupted after the Government moved to invalidate the opposition coalition's victories in 14 of Serbia's 19 largest cities. 
 It was immediately rejected by the opposition, which pledged to continue the demonstrations until Mr. Milosevic's Socialist Party relinquished local power in Belgrade and the other contested cities.
"The Government is trying to work out a compromise, but that is unacceptable to us," said Aleksandar Krstic, a leader of the opposition reached by telephone in Nis. "This decision is a clear admission by the Government that it carried out fraud during the vote in 13 voting stations. "This is one small step forward in our drive to get the Government to honor the election results in Nis and the rest of Serbia."
A former Communist who swept to power on a platform of Serbian nationalism, Mr. Milosevic has a well-earned reputation as an autocratic and often ruthless political leader. But he has also proved adept at using compromise to maintain his power, both with his domestic opponents and with the outside world.
Mr. Milosevic's concessions to student dissidents' demands in 1992 brought to an end the last major protests against his rule. And he was instrumental in pushing through the Dayton peace accord for Bosnia, although it brought an end to a war he had largely been responsible for starting.
Just last week, in the face of pressure from the United States and Europe, the Government said it would accept opposition victories in three contested cities. It insisted then that the results in Nis were still in doubt.
Opposition leaders said tonight they would not accept the Government's proposed resolution for Nis, under which the ruling Socialist Party would hold 32 of the 70 seats on the local council, twice as many as it appeared to have won in November's elections.
Nis (pronounced neesh), a bleak industrial town where huge Government-owned factories lie nearly idle and unemployment is 50 percent, is where the street protests began. It has proved the most militant city in the country, and opposition leaders there have built what the Government views as a dangerous alliance with local police and military commanders. Military officers, for example, guard city installations in civilian clothes most nights, and protesters are applauded by the soldiers as they walk past the barracks. Opposition leaders in the city praise the work of the local police officials, who they describe as "friendly and helpful."
Western diplomats said the Government, while perhaps willing to concede Nis and some smaller cities, still hopes to hold on to Belgrade, where the opposition also won decisively. As long as Mr. Milosevic insists on retaining control over the local government in the capital, the diplomats said, it will be difficult for him to bring a nonviolent end to the huge street demonstrations, which have seen tens of thousands of people brave the blustery cold to voice their anger and demand for reform.
If the opposition takes control of Nis, it says, it will use the city as a base to try and build independent broadcasting and newspaper outlets to counter the Government's iron grip on the media. But there are signs that the Government is working behind the scenes to circumvent this strategy by giving the Government-run companies in Belgrade control over all of Serbia's local print and broadcast concerns.
Today thousands of heavily armed riot police officers in the capital prevented opposition supporters from driving their cars into the center of the city after protesters staged a traffic jam on Sunday that paralyzed the city.
Cordons of police officers in gray flak jackets and equipped with truncheons blocked cars from entering the city. The police also prevented some 3,000 students from marching.
But the announcement that Nis had been lost appeared to indicate another crack in the Government shell.
"On the basis of documents inspected by the Justice Ministry, the Zajedno political organization won 37 seats, the Socialist Party of Serbia 32 and the Serbian Radical Party 1 seat in Nis local council," reported Tanjug, the state news agency.
Opposition leaders in Nis say the Socialists won only 16 seats in the November vote, with 41 for the coalition, 1 for the Radical Party and 12 that remain in dispute.
"We will not negotiate about these elections," said Miroljub Labus, a senior leader in the Zajedno coalition. "The total electoral decision of the people must be accepted."

HEADLINE: 'Parting Benediction' by Lonely Liberal

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8

 BODY:
One of the lonely liberals of the Clinton Administration, Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich, leaves Washington this week declaring that the Government must lead a campaign to narrow a growing gap between rich and poor and to fight the policies of corporate America.
In a draft of a speech for delivery on Thursday, a day before he leaves the Labor Department, Mr. Reich says he "can't resist a last word." He maintains that the Administration's "unfinished agenda is to address widening inequality." 
 Mr. Reich insists that his focus on an issue that others in the Administration generally avoid discussing is not intended as criticism of his colleagues or of President Clinton, a longtime friend who, he says, "harbors the same convictions as the young man I came to know in our student days."
But it may well be interpreted as thinly veiled criticism of the Administration's drift to the center, because Mr. Reich questions whether the United States is abandoning "the implicit social contract" it has maintained with workers for half a century. And once again, he baits corporate America for its treatment of workers in the pursuit of profits, a tack that other Cabinet members, especially Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin, have persuaded Mr. Clinton not to take.
Specifically, Mr. Reich complains of a growing "benefits gap" in which "top executives and their families receive ever more generous health benefits, and their pension benefits are soaring in the form of compensation deferred until retirement." Meanwhile, he cites statistics showing that only 14 percent of workers earning $10,000 to $20,000 are covered by the most common types of retirement savings plans, known as 401(k) programs, and only 34 percent are covered by a pension plan.
In a phone conversation, Mr. Reich, who is resigning to spend more time with his two teen-age boys in Boston, said today that his speech was "not a parting shot but a parting benediction."
Yet he also seems acutely aware that his departure leaves only Donna E. Shalala, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, as an outspoken liberal voice in the Cabinet. But Ms. Shalala has had little influence on policy and is not as pithy a speaker as the ever-quotable Mr. Reich.
"Bob acted as the liberal conscience," an Administration colleague said, "and in the new Cabinet, you won't find one of those."
That may be by design. To the consternation of Mr. Clinton's political advisers, Mr. Reich often called for far more Government efforts to intervene in the economy on behalf of ordinary workers than others in the Administration, particularly Mr. Rubin, were willing to endorse.
When Mr. Reich called for an alternative tax system that would favor corporations that gave greater benefits to workers, officials called reporters to declare that he was not speaking for the Administration.
Whenever conflict with Mr. Clinton's aides reached a fevered point, Mr. Reich would call his friend of 30 years to ask whether he should tone down his comments. The President, by all accounts, would tell Mr. Reich to go ahead with his views.
Tonight, at a farewell tribute to Mr. Reich, Mr. Rubin joked about their occasional policy clashes but insisted that their many areas of agreement were often ignored by the press. He said that Mr. Reich's influence over Administration policy would continue even after he left Washington and that if he disagreed with the Administration, "he will certainly call and let us know."
At the core of Mr. Reich's speech, to a nonprofit group that deals with economic and labor issues, is an attack on the argument that a growing economy will lift all boats -- and that all American workers will prosper.
"Some deny that inequality is rising," he says in the draft of his speech, clearly addressing his critics but never naming names.
"Simply said, they are wrong. They view widening inequality as a byproduct of structural changes in our economy -- most notably technological advances and global economic integration, both of which tend to reward the best-educated and penalize those with the poorest education and skills. The same phenomenon is occurring the world over, they say. Nothing can be done about it."
But Mr. Reich argues that "denial, resignation and silence" will only worsen a trend that has accelerated since the late 1970's. "We are not merely an economy, but also a culture," he argues. "It has never been economics alone that defines America. If we choose, as a culture, to push back against the economic forces that would otherwise divide us, it is within our power to do so."
Mr. Reich skirts any specific prescriptions to narrow the gap. But he argues that "we need to carry with us the implicit social compact" that American prosperity had to include "almost everyone."
The first principle of that unwritten compact, he argues, is that as companies grow more profitable, wages and health and pension benefits should rise and jobs should grow more secure. He cites statistics, debated at length early in 1996 when "corporate downsizing" was a frequent topic of political discourse, showing that people are being laid off at the same rate as they were in less prosperous times.
Most of those laid off, the statistics show, find new jobs. Mr. Reich's critics say such change is a sign of economic health, because it shows that the economy is dynamic enough to shed workers from obsolete jobs and to hire them in new sectors that need talent. Mr. Reich says he agrees but insists that the system will only work with a far greater commitment to retraining.
Mr. Reich added that he had not clear his speech with others in the Administration. "I came in talking about these issues," he said, "I'm going out talking about them, and I'll keep talking about them."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich was in his office yesterday, wrapping up his final week in Washington. He plans to return to Boston. (Paul Hosefros/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Rowland, in Address, Urges Income and Gas Tax Cuts

BYLINE: By JONATHAN RABINOVITZ 

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Jan. 9

 BODY:
Saying Connecticut was in the midst of an economic recovery, Gov. John G. Rowland urged lawmakers today to stay the course he set in his first two years in office, continuing to cut taxes and hold the line on spending.
In a 25-minute State of the State Address, Mr. Rowland provided few details and offered no bold pronouncements but vigorously reasserted his intention to seek further cuts in the state income tax. While Democrats had hoped he might signal interest in property tax relief, his speech suggested little enthusiasm for compromise. 
 "Make no mistake," he said, "it's the income tax that picks the pockets of the working people of this state every single day and every single week, cutting into the size of their take-home pay, robbing them of disposable income that could be used to fuel our state's economy or maybe to increase savings, or, perhaps, put one of our children through college."
Mr. Rowland also added his voice to the chorus of legislators who have called for cutting the state's gasoline tax, at 39 cents the nation's highest, and said that the legislature should focus on cutting taxes the state imposes, a backhand swipe at those whose priority is the property tax, which is imposed by municipalities.
Speaker Thomas D. Ritter, a Democrat of Hartford, said that he was surprised at the Governor's vehemence about the income tax. "He's setting up a collision on taxes," Mr. Ritter said, arguing that the Governor's insistence on cutting the income tax was fiscally imprudent.
"Any excess reserve we have is because of the income tax," Mr. Ritter said, a reference to recent reports that show the unexpected income tax revenue is largely responsible for the state's budget surplus.
State Senator Kevin B. Sullivan, the leader of the new Democratic majority in the Senate, added that the Governor's remarks about the income tax were likely the start of a full-fledged campaign to pressure the legislature on the issue.
In general, Democrats said they were struck more by what was absent from the speech than what was in it. In contrast to his speech a year ago, when Mr. Rowland made revitalizing the state's troubled cities a central subject of his budget address, today's address made no mention of urban policy.
Both Mr. Ritter and Mr. Sullivan said they were dismayed that Mr. Rowland did not discuss expanding poor families' access to early childhood education, a top Democratic initiative, and were disappointed that Mr. Rowland made only a passing reference to how the Governor and the Legislature should respond to an order from the State Supreme Court to desegregate the schools in the greater Hartford area.
Yet the tone of the speech was decidedly upbeat. And while Mr. Rowland, in the words of one Democrat, may have taken some "poetic license" with his pronouncements about the state's economy, few disagreed with Mr. Rowland's declaring a "Connecticut comeback."
Indeed, Cathy E. Minehan, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston, said in a speech Tuesday that the state's economy "is by many measures in the best shape it's been in nearly a decade."
While there are a host of explanations for the state's economic rebound, Mr. Rowland today offered his. "The Connecticut comeback is under way because we -- as a state -- have decided to reject the free-spending, high-tax ways of the 1980's," he said.
Mr. Rowland praised the bipartisan cooperation of the last two years that led to a $200 million income tax cut and held growth in spending to one of its lowest increases in more than 30 years. The budget he presents Feb. 5 will continue in that direction, he said.
"By the end of this session, everyone's taxes will be lower!" he promised
There already appears to be widespread support in the Legislature to cut the gas tax. While Mr. Rowland did not elaborate on how he would cut it, or how much, a bipartisan legislative task force recently recommended cutting it by 8 cents over the next few years.
The Connecticut gas tax, which Mr. Rowland referred to today as "highway robbery," has been raised several cents over the last year, an increase that was passed before Mr. Rowland took office in 1995. At 39 cents, it is much higher than in other Northeast states, with New York at 21.92 cents a gallon, New Jersey at 10.5 cents, Massachusetts at 21 cents and Rhode Island at 29 cents.
There would also appear to be backing for a proposal by Mr. Rowland to eliminate the state income tax on Social Security income, an idea that was put forward Tuesday as part of the Senate Democrats' agenda for the session.
And many legislators said today that Mr. Rowland's speech, with its promise of fiscal restraint, was an accurate reflection of the moderate mood in the Legislature, even if it offered little new.
State Senator George C. Jepsen, a Democrat of Stamford, remarked that despite the income tax-property tax debate between Mr. Rowland and the Democrats, there was still consensus about tax cuts. "We may be at opposite ends of the same page, but we're on the same page," he said.
State Senator William H. Nickerson, a Republican of Greenwich, said the speech's tone was to be expected. "He doesn't need to drop a bomb on this building to shake it up," Mr. Nickerson said. "The mood of the Legislature is already behind him."
And Mr. Nickerson observed that both parties were moving toward a consensus on fiscal policy. "Bill Clinton could have given that speech today," he said.
 
In His Own Words
 
GOV. JOHN G. ROWLAND
 
"I can make you two promises as I stand before you today:
By the end of this legislative session -- I'll be 40 years old. And I can tell you that I look and feel far older than that. Looking at the news last night, I could see a total difference in my hairline and hair color from the State of the State speech last year.
But, more importantly, by the end of this session everyone's taxes will be lower!
We must focus our efforts -- first -- on cutting the taxes that we impose as a state government. And the cuts we choose to make must benefit as many people as possible.
We all realize the gas tax increases approved by the previous administration are nothing less than highway robbery, and we will make cuts in the gas tax this session.
Our effort to cut the gas tax has got to be responsible, because while the roads and bridges of Connecticut are far better than they were 10 years ago, there is still some work to be done, and that work will continue.
And make no mistake, it's the income tax that picks the pockets of the working people of this state every single day and every single week, cutting into the size of their take-home pay, robbing them of disposable income that could be used to fuel our state's economy or maybe to increase savings, or, perhaps, put one of our children through college."

HEADLINE: Calls for Cuts in State Capitals

 BODY:
Saying that tax-cutting has helped reinvigorate the economies of both states, the governors of New York and Connecticut used their introductory addresses to their legislatures yesterday to urge the lawmakers to continue on that path to assure continued growth.
In his Albany address, Gov. George E. Pataki promised to send the state "roaring into the next century," and vowed to cut property taxes while increasing spending on schools. But Democrats reacted skeptically to his plans, expressing concern that continued tax cuts would only end up hurting education in the state. 
 The speech appeared to give Mr. Pataki some weaponry as he prepares for an expected re-election bid. By calling for property tax cuts, he could be hoping to undercut criticism that his previous cuts in state spending have placed a financial burden on localities.
Mr. Pataki also made a direct appeal to women, calling for tougher penalties in domestic violence cases, and he asked for rules that would assure longer hospital stays for women who have had mastectomies.
In Connecticut, the state's Republican Governor, John G. Rowland, also urged lawmakers to stay on a tax-cutting course. While he offered no new bold initiatives, he urged further cuts in the state's income tax, which was instituted by the previous administration.

HEADLINE: Pataki Vows Property Tax Cut and Rise in School Spending

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 8

 BODY:
Setting an agenda with broad appeal to middle-class and suburban voters, Gov. George E. Pataki today vowed to cut property taxes while increasing the amount of money spent on school textbooks and computers.
In his third annual address to the Legislature, Mr. Pataki said he had a plan to induce school districts around the state to freeze and even reduce property taxes, though the specifics will have to wait until he releases his proposed budget next week. 
 His aides say the Governor's plan would offer the local districts more state money to make up for the loss of property tax revenue.
"Property taxes in New York State are too high," Mr. Pataki said. "The budget plan I will release next week will begin a multi year program to stop the continual increase in school taxes, reverse that trend and actually begin to lower these taxes for every homeowner."
But the Democrats who control the Assembly were quick to say that until they see the Republican Governor's budget, they will not be convinced that property taxes can be cut without hurting education.
"I welcome the Governor, his words, in concept," said the Assembly Speaker, Sheldon Silver, a Democrat of Manhattan. "I await the details of his real property tax plan. But I won't accept a shell game."
Mr. Pataki's 58-minute speech offered several initiatives that fit neatly into potential gaps in his political armor. Indeed, Mr. Silver called it "a campaign speech" delivered in preparation for the 1998 governor's race.
The tax plan could blunt the charge by Democrats in the Legislature that the Governor is to blame for the rapid rise in property taxes in some localities since Mr. Pataki took office.
They argue that, to accommodate the income tax cuts that Mr. Pataki championed early in his administration, the state has not increased school aid fast enough to keep up with expenses, forcing local districts to raise property taxes.
But Mr. Pataki's message dealt with more than taxes. At a time when Republicans fare far better at the polls among men than women, the Governor appealed to the Legislature for tougher sentences and higher bail in domestic violence cases, and for longer hospital stays for women who have had mastectomies. Last year, the state mandated that new mothers be allowed at least two days in the hospital, not one.
And, like Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, Mr. Pataki appears determined to make himself appear more friendly to the public schools. Last year, he proposed what he said was a slight increase in education money, but Democrats in the Legislature charged that at a closer look, it was a decrease. School spending was increased in the budget that was eventually enacted.
The Governor said that this year, he wanted to increase state aid to public schools, which stands at $10.2 billion this year, by $250 million. Much of that money would go toward keeping his promises to double state spending on textbooks, $114 million this year, and triple state spending on classroom computers, now $21 million, over several years. He also said that districts that cut administrative waste would be rewarded, but he did not elaborate.
Mr. Pataki spoke at some length about the Internet, calling it "a powerful and promising tool" for children.
"With private help, labor and volunteer support," he said, "let's pledge today that between now and the turn of the century, we will have a computer available for every student in every school. And that every student will know how to tap into its limitless resources."
But Louis Grumet, executive director of the New York State School Boards Association, said that he, like Mr. Silver, could not be confident until he saw the budget that the Governor's new tax and spending proposals would mean more aid to schools.
The Governor is expected to propose a budget keeping state spending at this year's level, about $65 billion, and he must close a gap estimated at $3 billion, so any new state spending on education would have to come out of other programs.
That could add tension to a legislative session that already promises to be as contentious as last year's, when the budget was passed 102 days late.
Mr. Pataki spoke at length on the achievements of the last two years, stating repeatedly that lower taxes and less business regulation had meant job growth in New York, which he and his aides have said is the ultimate measure of his performance.
He repeatedly cast taxation and big government as enemies not just of prosperity, but also of liberty, saying that his term will be remembered as a time "when freedom prevailed over bureaucracy."
But Mr. Silver charged that the Governor was taking credit that belonged to others for achievements ranging from lower crime to new rights for patients in managed-care programs, and he noted that New York still lags behind the nation as a whole in job growth.
"While the nation has been riding the train of economic recovery for the last two years," Mr. Silver said, "New York is still waiting at that station."
But Senator Joseph L. Bruno of Brunswick, leader of the Senate's Republican majority, said, "I really think the Governor did a remarkable job in putting together a vision, not just for the next couple of years, but literally to lead us into the 21st century."
The Governor urged the Legislature to adopt the proposal he made last year to overhaul welfare programs, which is expected to be one of the most acrimonious issues of the coming session.
A law passed last year by Congress and signed by President Clinton hands over much of the responsibility for setting welfare policy to the states, while mandating that, with some exceptions, families spend no more than five years on welfare.
Under the Governor's plan, each year a family remained on welfare, its benefits would shrink, to barely half the starting level in the fifth and final year. Cash payments to able-bodied, childless adults would be replaced with vouchers for food and shelter.
Mr. Pataki added a new feature today, a program employing welfare recipients to renovate derelict housing, teaching them building trades in the process. He did not say how it would be financed.
Mr. Pataki made a substantial shift in tone, if not in substance, on welfare, perhaps seeking to deflect charges of meanness from advocates for the poor.
In the past, he has derided New York's as the "Cadillac" of welfare systems, a wasteful burden on society and one that drew people to the state for its generous benefits.
Today, he said the true victims are welfare recipients. "The welfare system we are presiding over today is democracy's Berlin Wall," he said, separating "those who are free to pursue and follow opportunities and those who are denied even the chance."
Though he looked worn after staying up until 12:30 A.M. rehearsing his address, Mr. Pataki, dressed in his usual plain gray suit with a yellow tie, showed flashes of wit.
At one point, a state trooper fainted and fell against the Governor as he spoke, and had to be helped from the chamber.
"I didn't think the speech was that long," Mr. Pataki said. It was not clear why the trooper, whose name was not released, collapsed.
When Mr. Pataki's tax cut proposal drew booming applause and cheers from Republicans on the right side of the Assembly chamber but blank-faced silence from the Democrats on the left, he said, "It's great to see clapping from both sides."
 
In His Own Words
 
GOV. GEORGE E. PATAKI
 
"We stand at the edge of a new era, a new century and a new millennium.
There is only one way to enter this new era. We must go roaring into the next century, bold, confident and determined, accepting every challenge that comes before us.
When future generations look back at this period in our state's history, they will recall these years as the years when hope prevailed over fear, when confidence prevailed over cynicism, when freedom prevailed over bureaucracy.
They will know these as the years when the Empire State, led by the irrepressible spirit of its people, roared back to life and laid the foundation for a brighter future.
The past two years have prepared us well for our passage into the 21st century.
A great shift of power has taken place, from the government back to the people. And because this historic transfer of power has taken place, the future of our state is in good hands. It is in the hands of the people."

HEADLINE: Metro Digest

 BODY:

NEW YORK
 
Charting Immigration Trends
European immigration to New York City surged in the 1990's to levels unseen since the 1960's. The Dominican Republic became more entrenched as the city's largest source of immigrants. And more than 4 in every 10 births were to immigrants. These are among the trends to emerge from a portrait of the 563,000 legal immigrants who poured into the city from 1990 to 1994. [Page A1.] 

Pataki Vows to Cut Taxes
Promising to send the state "roaring into the next century," Governor Pataki vowed to cut property taxes while increasing the amount of money spent on school textbooks and computers. He made the comments in his third annual address to the Legislature. [B1.]
 
With many legislators hostile to the Governor's announcement, he faces a tough battle in a pivotal year. News analysis. [B7.]
 
All eyes were on Betsy McCaughey Ross: Would she stand or sit? [B7.]
 
If former Governor Mario M. Cuomo was Hamlet on the Hudson, Governor Pataki is more Polonius from Peekskill. Metro Matters by Elizabeth Kolbert. [B7.]
 
A Gay Magazine Shuts Down
The New York Native, a gay news magazine that was credited in the early 1980's with pioneering AIDS coverage but more recently has been criticized as a forum for conspiracy theories, folded this week after 16 years of publication. [B2.]
 
Police Promotions Ordered
A State Supreme Court judge ordered the police department to promote hundreds of officers to the rank of detective after 18 months of plainclothes work, throwing a wrench into a city anti-drug initiative that had called for almost 900 officers to work temporarily as detectives. [B3.]
 
9th Graders Improve in Math
Nearly 25 percent more ninth graders passed the state's college-prep math exam last June compared with the year before, but their achievement still lags behind the rest of the state. [B4.]
 
4 Wounded in School Shooting
Four teen-agers were wounded, two of them critically, when gunfire erupted on a basketball court outside a high school in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn, disrupting classes and sending students fleeing and ducking for cover. [B1.]
 
Lox, Labor and Liberalism
In typical, Upper West Side fashion, some residents have raised their voices and called for a community boycott of Citarella, an upscale gourmet and seafood store that has been accused of unfair labor practices. But in an untypical response, most of the self-described liberals are ignoring protesters at the store, apparently unable to do without the fancy cheeses and crustaceans. [B1.]
 
Vacco Plea on Assisted Suicide
The New York Attorney General, Dennis Vacco, joined his counterpart from Washington State in appearing before the United States Supreme Court to defend their opposition to physician-assisted suicide. National report. [B9.]
 
50 Brokers Charged in Fraud
In what prosecutors say is the first case of widespread fraud in testing for stockbrokers' licenses, 50 brokers were charged in New York Supreme Court with having paid stand-ins to take their exams. Business Day. [D6.]
 
Some contributors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund have increased their donations, accelerating the fund to its best pace in five year. The Neediest Cases. [B2.]
 
Two investigators for the state police retired after receiving an unusual warning that they could face disciplinary action. [B6.]
 
NEW JERSEY
 
Renting in Hoboken? Good Luck
How hot is the rental market in Hoboken? How about so hot that there are about 10 apartment seekers for every available one- or two-bedroom walk-up near the PATH station? It's so hot that one agency warns readers of its listings that "due to the overwhelming demand for apartments . . . availability changes every day." Our Towns by Evelyn Nieves. [B1.]
 
Move to Try Youths as Adults
Law-enforcement officials said that they would ask a judge to order that three teen-agers charged with sexually assaulting a 14-year-old girl be tried in adult criminal court. If the petition is granted, the three would face considerably more severe prison sentences if convicted. [B4.]
 
CONNECTICUT
 
Rowland Urges Staying Course
In a State of the State Address, Gov. John G. Rowland said Connecticut was in the midst of an economic recovery and urged lawmakers to stay the course he set in his two years in office. [B6.]

HEADLINE: About Real Estate;
From Co-Ops to Rentals To More Like Condos

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

DATELINE: EDGEWATER, N.J.

 BODY:
Built as a cooperative and then turned partly into rental housing, the Grand Cove complex will again be selling apartments next month -- this time to be more like a condominium.
Next month Greenthal Realty Partners, a Manhattan-based real estate and asset management firm, is to reopen sales at the two-building gated waterfront site on River Road in this Bergen County borough, not far from the George Washington Bridge. Some 56 of the 108 one- and two-bedroom apartments remain unsold. Shareholders changed the bylaws to be similar to those of a condo. Owners can buy and sell their units without board approval and will have more flexibility in subleasing them. 
 "Anything that will help sell the units is good," said Richard Dutton, president of the board. After the recession people generally "were left with a bad taste for co-ops" because they could not sell or rent their units, he added.
Greenthal also plans to sell the units, of 1,010 to 1,347 square feet, for $103,000 to $173,000 -- some $10,000 to $30,000 less than the original prices, and with financing for buyers. The apartments, now rented, will be offered first to tenants and then to the public as they become available, said Lance N. West, Greenthal's president. Monthly fees are $783 to $979.
The switch to sales comes 18 months after Greenthal bought for $8.4 million the unsold apartments and two mortgages at the nine-year-old development, which was pushed to the brink of foreclosure after the original sponsor defaulted on its loan in 1991.
Grand Cove also includes 51 town houses, a clubhouse and pool. All the town houses were sold before the market soured.
Since its purchase Greenthal has increased rents and consolidated and refinanced the loan. That has helped reduce monthly maintenance fees by 13 percent to their current level and to restore the co-op to fiscal health. Grand Cove's comeback, in many ways, echoes that of the Hudson waterfront in general and Edgewater's in particular.
New and revived housing projects are advancing up and down the 18-mile stretch of shoreline after a long slump. All told, some 5,000 residences could be built in the next three years, said Robert P. Antonicello, president of the ACI Group, a real estate company in Jersey City.
Most of the apartments are rentals as developers look to take advantage of a tightening market. The vacancy rate along the waterfront is under 5 percent, Mr. Antonicello said.
In Edgewater, three riverfront projects totaling 460 residences are under way or about to start. The largest is a 266-apartment rental now rising called the River Club.
This is Edgewater's "second chance," Mayor Bryan Christiansen said. He pointed to two retail projects that would also produce a total of more than 500,000 square feet of stores and a 14-screen movie complex. And the second half of the expansion to River Road, which runs along the river, could add more, he said, while musing over the possibility of a hotel on the former Hills Brothers coffee plant site.
"It has brought a new economic boom to Edgewater," Mayor Christiansen said of the construction activity which last year totaled $31 million. "A good portion of the tax base lost when industries left also has finally been replaced."
Of the reason his company decided to reactivate sales at Grand Cove, Mr. West said, "With the upward pressures on rents it makes sense to sell the units because the economics of home ownership justify buying rather than renting them."
That prospect is helped by signs that the sales climate in the Fort Lee area, which includes Edgewater, has improved for condos and co-ops. Last year 238 co-ops were sold at an average price of $85,457, up from 221 units sold at an average price of $76,952 in 1995. In that same time 300 condos were sold at an average price of $221,239, up from 198 sold at an average price of $193,385, according to the local office of Murphy Realty Better Homes and Gardens.
The supply of condos has been depleted and prices have risen, said Michele Kolsky-Assatly, a broker at Murphy Realty. "The next step for many buyers is co-ops," she said.
The preferred housing in suburban New Jersey remains the one-family home. Buyers here "have a coolness" to co-ops because they are used to getting a deed, not a proprietary lease, and buying an apartment, not shares in a corporation, said Benjamin Lambert, a Woodbridge-based lawyer who specializes in co-ops. There are 239,491 condos in New Jersey, compared with 27,636 co-ops, according to state figures.
The fiscal woes that arose after the mid-1980's boom deflated hurt co-ops, as did the restrictiveness of that form, he said, adding that more are doing what Grand Cove has done and blending the two forms.
Structuring Grand Cove as a condo will "offer more flexibility to buyers who may later choose to sell or rent their apartments," Mr. West said. That along with providing financing will make the project more competitive, he added.
Mr. Dutton agreed and added, "We will not recoup our full investment initially, but eventually values will rise."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Economic Weakness Abroad Spurs Rally in the Dollar

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar rallied broadly yesterday as fresh signs of economic weakness overseas contrasted with surging stocks and bonds and generally upbeat economic news in the United States.
The dollar rose first against the Japanese yen in Asian trading after the Nikkei 225 stock index plunged more than 3 percent, bringing total losses for the first four trading days of 1997 to nearly 7 percent. 
 That weakness helped drive investment to American markets, lifting the Dow Jones industrials 76.19 points, to a record 6,625.67, and raising the United States 30-year Treasury bond slightly.
Those gains touched off heavy purchases of dollars for yen, currency traders said.
"What's most significant right now is the relative strength of the U.S. stock market compared to Japan," said Thomas Arnold, chief currency dealer at Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank in New York. "There seems to be some sort of asset shift going on between the two countries."
Later in the session a report showing German unemployment had risen to a record high in December sent the dollar to a fresh two-year high against the German mark and a 30-month high versus the Swiss franc.
The dollar rose to 116.34 yen, from 115.76 late Wednesday, and to 1.5778 marks from 1.5743. The American currency rose to 1.3701 Swiss francs from 1.3655.
The British pound rose to $1.6955 from $1.6877. The dollar stood little changed at $1.3512 (Canadian) from $1.3513 (Canadian).
Despite its gains, the dollar failed to hold above 1.58 marks and many traders cited rumors that European central banks had intervened in the market to sell dollars at that level.
As the mark weakens against its European counterparts, exports from other European countries become more expensive, prompting official concern. Traders said there were rumors that central banks were selling dollars at 1.58 marks.
Traders also said an overnight report that Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin had reiterated his oft-stated desire for a "strong" dollar helped bolster the dollar.
Several Japanese officials publicly warned earlier in the week that the dollar was rising too quickly against the yen, fueling sharp dollar losses.

HEADLINE: Semiconductor Index Fell in December

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: SAN JOSE, Calif., Jan. 9

 BODY:
The computer chip industry's monthly book-to-bill ratio, which measures demand, fell to 1.10 in December from November's revised 1.16.
The Semiconductor Industry Association said the decline was caused by a 2.9 percent drop in new orders. Bookings fell to $3.87 billion in December from $3.98 billion a month earlier. 
 The ratio compares the value of chips shipped in the North American market with the value of new orders received. A ratio of 1.10 means that for every $100 in chips shipped, $110 in new orders were received.
Analysts said the decline in the ratio was expected because November is traditionally the strongest month of the year as personal computer makers gear up for the expected holiday rush.
November's ratio was revised up from 1.15.
This month's figure was the final book-to-bill report. The association is dropping it in favor of a measure that better reflects the industry's conditions worldwide, rather that just North America. The association calculated the ratio since 1978. The first report of the new measure, called the Global Billings Report, is scheduled later this month.
Orders for December, based on a three-month rolling average, fell 23 percent from the $5.01 billion reported in December 1995. Billings rose 2.7 percent, to $3.52 billion, from $3.43 billion in November. The month's shipments were 21 percent lower than in the period a year earlier.

HEADLINE: U.S. Prosecutors in 6 Cities File Charges of Smuggling Refrigeration Gas

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9

 BODY:
Federal authorities today charged more than a dozen people and businesses with smuggling into the United States a refrigerant that is banned because it damages the Earth's protective layer of atmospheric ozone.
Clinton Administration officials also vowed to expand their crackdown on illegal imports of the refrigerant chlorofluorocarbons, or CFC's, including the type commonly known by the brand name Freon. Such smuggling has been increasing since the United States, in keeping with an environmental treaty, banned imports and the production of such ozone-depleting chemicals a year ago. 
 A lively and lucrative black market has sprung up, with canisters of gaseous CFC's sold to dealers and service stations that use the chemical mostly to refill air-conditioners in automobiles made before 1994. There is a two-year supply of legal CFC's in the United States, but after that runs out, older cars will need to be modified to use an environmentally benign alternative.
The charges were filed by prosecutors in Houston, Los Angeles, Miami, Philadelphia, San Diego and Savannah, Ga.
In the biggest case, the owner of Refrigerant Management Services Inc., R. Colin Dayton of Bryn Mawr, Pa., was indicted along with several other people, accused of having smuggled about 1.5 million pounds of the refrigerant into the United States in 1994 and 1995. The activity earned profits of $1 million and deprived the Government of excise taxes of $7 million, according to an indictment.
A lawyer for Mr. Dayton, Stanley Arkin, said that the charges were totally unfounded and that they were based on allegations by people under prosecution who were seeking to implicate others falsely.
"This is a trendy prosecution with no substance," Mr. Arkin said.
A typical car uses two or three pounds of the gas, worth $12 to $15 a pound, in its air-conditioning system.
The United States Customs Commissioner, George J. Weise, said that there had been a "dramatic shift" in smuggling from the Miami region to the border with Mexico and that some big smuggling rings appeared to involve Russian organized crime. Other major sources of supply, Mr. Weise said, include India and China.
The indictment in San Diego is that district's 10th case involving the apparent smuggling of CFC's across the Mexican border, and a case filed in Houston was one of several similar prosecutions.
Eighteen people have been convicted of smuggling the chemicals, mostly as a result of a crackdown in the Miami region, and prison terms of up to 57 months have been imposed, along with big fines.
One and one-half million pounds of CFC's have been confiscated, but officials estimated that 20 million pounds illegally crossed into the United States last year.
Although the chemicals end up in cars, motorists are unlikely to share in the smuggling profits. Instead, they are likely to pay full price for the refrigerant, with middlemen reaping the profits. Service stations and distributors are sometimes unaware that the chemicals that they are buying are illegal, officials said.
Attorney General Janet Reno said at a news conference today: "To people who service cars or distribute refrigerants, we say: 'If you're offered something at a price that seems too good to be true, it probably is. Please alert the E.P.A. or your local F.B.I. office if you see such situations.'
"And to CFC smugglers, we say: 'We're going to find you. We will shut you down. We're going to shut down this black market.' "

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
Protest From a Member

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL 

 BODY:
In the mail comes an invitation to a conference sponsored by the Council on Foreign Relations. In news stories, the council's name is usually preceded by "prestigious," "elite" or "influential," and all three are correct.
The title of the two-day conference, in April, is "From Bicycles to Beepers: The Politics and Economics of Business in China." 
 Seminars and workshops will be held on opportunities for investment in the provinces, the future of U.S.-Chinese relations, taxes and accounting, and such specified targeted investment subjects as banking, securities, computers, telecommunications, power and energy, "joint ventures and strategic alliances" and textiles and manufacturing. The fee is $500 for non-members, $250 for members or employees of companies with corporate membership.
Two things about the meeting trouble me. One is in the list of subjects. A few are broad but most seem remarkably like how-to courses. As a member, I do not think it befits the council to help investment in the world's most brutal and dangerous dictatorship.
The second is not on the agenda. When I asked who was paying for the conference, the answer came that much of the money is from American businesses operating in China.
Well, sir, I said, this strikes me as a conflict of interest -- taking money to hold a conference on China trade from companies already in business there and hardly likely to raise such questions as government blackmail, official corruption, slave labor, religious persecution and other matters that might be of interest to Americans contemplating investment in China.
I was told the council would not allow company support to dictate the discussion. Also: If the corporations had not come through, the council could not have afforded the meeting.
I have been a member for 34 years, one of 3,265 other prestigious, elite and influential Americans, among them foreign-affairs specialists, businessmen, former government officials and journalists. Meetings usually are held under the rule that what is said cannot be attributed to anybody.
Now, nobody worth listening to is fool enough to tell a chamber full of people any great secret. But often I profited intellectually from the speakers and discussion. Eventually this helped me journalistically, and thus was of trickle-down benefit to the entire nation.
So I did not want to be rude enough to say that the rationalization for taking money from China-trade companies was the same dreary excuse that journalists, politicians and academics give when they let money create the reality or appearance of conflict of interest. Listen, it won't influence me and I need the money for the good of my work.
But I managed to overcome politesse and said I would print my objections. I rule that the confidentiality condition does not apply to public invitations.
The council, I was reminded, had held similar business-focused meetings on the Mideast, South Africa and other regions. But the meeting on the Mideast did not include Iraq or Libya and the session on South Africa was held after the defeat of apartheid. Also: I had not known that those meetings were sponsored by companies doing business in the regions involved.
The International Herald Tribune goes further. It holds conferences on doing business in China with financial help from companies in the trade -- and also lists the Chinese Government State Commission for Reconstructing the Economic System as co-convener. I doubt the two newspapers that own The I.H.T. would do that themselves -- The Washington Post and The New York Times.
Why pick on the council or I.H.T. when so many think tanks take money from foundations that try to and do influence their agenda or from companies that have commercial interest in what is studied?
Reminds me of when the writer Nick Pileggi called me years ago to say The Times was taking dozens of free baseball tickets every day and, for a story he was doing, how come. I said it was impossible. But the sports editor delightedly told me it was true. He gave them to the printers to get sports copy moved fast.
We stopped it that day. But I grumbled to my colleagues that somebody was always picking on The Times. Then I reminded myself of the reason and I did not feel bad at all. We are prestigious, elite and influential, that's why.

HEADLINE: Triumph Turns Sour for Fund-Raiser

BYLINE: By JANE FRITSCH and DOUGLAS FRANTZ 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9

 BODY:
This should be a time of triumph for a political fund-raiser like Marvin S. Rosen, who as finance chairman for the Democratic National Committee over the last 16 months was responsible for designing the machine that raised $120 million and helped to insure President Clinton's re-election.
Instead, Mr. Rosen, a Florida lawyer whose firm maintains a Washington lobbying office, has had his records at Democratic headquarters subpoenaed by a Federal grand jury, and he is seen little in Washington. His former colleagues are blaming him for some of the fund-raising problems that have engulfed the party and forced the return of $1.5 million in questionable donations. 
 The organization that Mr. Rosen took over with the help of powerful friends in the Democratic Party is now under investigation by the Justice Department and Congress in connection with questionable donations from foreigners and foreign companies and offering access to the White House in exchange for big campaign contributions.
And as questions continue to surface about the Democrats' fund-raising practices, there are indications that Mr. Rosen may have pushed ethical limits in his law practice and business dealings.
Mr. Rosen was accused by Federal regulators of unethical practices that contributed to the failure of a Florida savings and loan he had represented and helped to finance in the 1980's. His Miami law firm, Greenberg, Traurig, Hoffman, Lipoff, Rosen & Quintel, settled the case five years ago by paying $8.15 million to the Resolution Trust Corporation, which oversaw the industry bailout.
Mr. Rosen was among a number of lawyers whose political connections were highlighted several years ago in a controversy that led to stricter regulations for the selection of law firms for state work in New Jersey. Although Mr. Rosen's firm was in Florida, it was awarded lucrative New Jersey bond work after he raised campaign money for former Gov. Jim Florio, a Democrat.
In many ways, Mr. Rosen represents the dozens of lawyers and lobbyists who are the chief generators of money for both Democratic and Republican candidates. They are behind-the-scenes deal makers whose personal and business interests are often intertwined with those of the politicians they court. They are players in a world where money, more than ever, means access. And politicians, desperate for funds as campaign costs skyrocket, have come to view them as indispensable.
Mr. Rosen said today that he had accepted the job at the Democratic National Committee purely because of his belief in the party's agenda. "It's a corny answer, but I truly felt the Republican agenda would be so extreme that it was vital to keep President Clinton in office," he said in an interview.
And he said that he had never lobbied public officials or sought to trade on his fund-raising activities to get help for his clients. "I never called any public official to discuss my client matters," he said.
Mr. Rosen's reputation as a master fund-raiser was a major factor in Mr. Clinton's decision to approve him for the party's top finance position in 1995, as the Presidential race was about to begin in earnest. Mr. Rosen won the post with major support from his longtime friend, Senators Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts, and Senator Christopher J. Dodd of Connecticut, the general chairman of the Democratic National Committee. Mr. Rosen has been a prolific fund-raiser for Senator Kennedy.
Because of his long experience as a Democratic fund-raiser, Mr. Rosen said, no one looked into his background and legal practice before he was offered the unpaid post.
The savings and loan case "wasn't even on my radar screen," he said, adding that the accusations were false and that he had done nothing improper. Mr. Rosen's problems with Federal regulators began in 1989, after the failure of the Royal Palm Savings Bank of Palm Beach, Fla. Mr. Rosen had been an organizer of the savings and loan in 1983 and was also a shareholder and its lawyer. Like other savings institutions that failed in the 1980's, Royal Palm rose swiftly with the booming economy and failed abruptly as imprudent loans and other management failures left it too weak to withstand an economic slump.
When Federal regulators took over, they found a tangle of what they said were improper loans and stock transactions, and they said some of the problems were the fault of Mr. Rosen, his law firm, Greenberg, Traurig, and two other lawyers in the firm.
In a complaint first filed in Federal court in Miami by Royal Palm's board, the directors said that Mr. Rosen and two other lawyers at his firm had been involved in serious conflicts of interest over several years. The Resolution Trust Corporation took over the lawsuit when it became the receiver for the failed savings and loan in 1989.
Harvey Kurzweil, a New York lawyer who handled the suit for the Resolution Trust Corporation, said this week that Mr. Rosen had been named in the lawsuit because he had been the principal lawyer for Royal Palm, having brought the account to Greenberg, Traurig when he joined the firm in the mid-1980's.
The lawsuit said Mr. Rosen and his law firm withheld information from the saving and loan's board of directors and that Mr. Rosen had a conflict of interest because he had personally borrowed $750,000 from the institution's chairman while serving as its lawyer. An analysis by Federal regulators in 1992 said that Mr. Rosen had also prepared stock offering documents and reports for regulators that inflated Royal Palm stock prices. The analysis said Mr. Rosen then sold his own stock in the savings and loan at a profit.
Mr. Rosen denied the allegations today. "I never sold my stock or profited from it," he said. "Substantially all of my holdings in Royal Palm were held until the end and never sold. The basis of the allegation was the transfer of the stock to a brokerage account, so I could borrow money, but I never sold it."
He added, "I never prepared any stock offering for the savings and loan and never aided in any regulatory reports being filed."
Many of the allegations centered on the activities of two other lawyers under Mr. Rosen's supervision, according to the lawsuit. One of those lawyers received $49 million in inadequately secured loans, the regulators said.
In all, the Resolution Trust Corporation sought damages of $38 million from Mr. Rosen's law firm. After three years of negotiations, the regulators settled for the cash payment by the firm of $8.15 million. Mr. Rosen said, "There is not an ounce of truth in any of this stuff and the lawsuit was settled because our legal fees were tremendous."
At the time Mr. Rosen's career seemed unaffected and his legal practice was thriving.
"He understood what people wanted and was able to deliver it to them," said Byron L. Sparber, a partner of Rosen's at his previous law firm. "If someone needed a business partner, he could find them. He has a tremendous talent as a matchmaker, and that was perhaps his unique capacity."
Mr. Rosen had joined Mr. Sparber's firm when he arrived in Miami in the 1977 but moved to the fast-growing Greenberg, Traurig, now one of Miami's largest law firms, early in 1980's. "It had more political presence," Mr. Sparber said. "It was a more mature firm. Perhaps a faster horse to ride."
At Greenberg, Traurig, Mr. Rosen developed an expertise in municipal bond finance, which meant courting and contributing to local politicians, first in Miami and later in New Jersey and other places.
And he was moving from local to national politics, serving as Florida chairman of Senator Kennedy's Presidential primary campaign in 1980, and raising money for his Senate re-election campaign in 1982. In 1983, he signed up as a fund-raiser for Walter F. Mondale's Presidential primary campaign and was finance chairman for the Presidential campaign of Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts.
By 1992, Mr. Rosen was so highly sought-after that Mr. Clinton personally telephoned to ask for his help. Mr. Rosen's fund raising for Mr. Clinton earned him a spot on the stage at the President's inauguration in 1993. Mr. Rosen quickly sought to capitalize on his prominence by opening a lobbying office for his firm in Washington. Among the people he hired for the office were Michael Brown, the son of then-Commerce Secretary Ron H. Brown, and Victoria Kennedy, Senator Kennedy's wife.
Mr. Rosen's move into the finance chairman's office at the Democratic National Committee in 1995 was a natural next step. He was in charge of the President's birthday fund-raiser in Manhattan, which brought in more than $10 million.
Some of Mr. Rosen's associates at the committee said that he made most decisions by himself and rarely held strategy sessions with senior officials. Previously, veteran fund-raisers and staff members might have kept an eye on each other, some of them said.
For instance, few said they had ever met John Huang, the fund-raiser who brought in millions of dollars from American-Asians, and whose activities are now a central issue in the Federal investigation. Mr. Huang, they said, reported directly to Mr. Rosen.
In his position, Mr. Rosen also attended some of the White House coffee meetings with donors whose contributions are now under scrutiny.
Mr. Rosen described his job as ceremonial, and said he did not have direct supervisory responsibility. He said he stopped actively practicing law when he took the job, but did not sever his ties with his firm.
His connections to top politicians remained useful to the firm's clients.
One of them, Carlos Herrera Jr., said today that he was able to get a meeting with Transportation Secretary Federico F. Pena last April 3 after meeting Mr. Pena at a fund-raising party at Senator Kennedy's home in Virginia. Mr. Rosen had helped to arrange the party.
Mr. Herrera is the president of a Florida company that is seeking to lead a $1 billion redevelopment of Homestead Air Base south of Miami. The project, opposed by environmentalists, requires Federal approval. Mr. Herrera said he had discussed it several times with President Clinton and Vice President Al Gore. Most recently, he said, he raised the issue with Mr. Clinton at a fund-raising event in Miami last spring that had been set up by Mr. Rosen and the Democratic National Committee. Before the party. Mr. Herrera contributed $75,000 to the Democrats.
Mr. Herrera said he first made his case to the President at a private White House breakfast in 1994. "When I first met the President I had not contributed a penny," he said. "Any politician who would listen without me giving him a penny gets a lot of respect. Then I did contribute as much as I could."

HEADLINE: Producer Data Show Inflation Still Moderate

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9

 BODY:
Producer prices rose more than expected during December, the Government reported today, but when the cost of energy and food was excluded, the increase was below forecasts.
The Labor Department said that producer prices over all grew half a percent in the month, exceeding analysts' expectations of a gain of three-tenths of 1 percent and above November's increase of four-tenths of 1 percent. However, the so-called core rate, which excludes the energy and food categories, rose only one-tenth of 1 percent, below the forecast of a gain of two-tenths of 1 percent. 
 The small rise in the core rate, which is watched closely because prices for energy and food are especially volatile, cheered the financial markets by adding to speculation that the Federal Reserve would not raise interest rates soon. The good news on inflation helped to send the Dow jones industrial average up 76.19 points, to 6,625.67.
The president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago, Michael H. Moskow -- a voting member of the Fed's policy-making committee -- said today that "we should have another year of respectable growth with low inflation and low unemployment."
In the full year, producer prices rose 2.8 percent, faster than 1995's 2.3 percent increase and the biggest annual gain since 1990, when the Persian Gulf crisis pushed up oil prices. The core rate rose only six-tenths of 1 percent in 1996, well below 1995's 2.6 percent increase and the second-smallest yearly gain on record.
In another report today, the Labor Department said first-time claims for state unemployment insurance fell last week to 361,000 from 374,000 a week earlier, the largest decline since mid-October.
 Today's inflation report showed that producer energy prices, which account for 13.6 percent of the Producer Price Index for finished goods, rose 3.1 percent during December -- the biggest gain in a year. However, wholesale food prices, which make up 22.8 percent of the index, decreased one-tenth of 1 percent. Wholesale auto prices rose three-tenths of 1 percent, as did wholesale tobacco costs.
 The question is whether rising oil prices will lead to higher costs for other goods. Mr. Moskow of the Chicago Fed said he did not expect that to happen.
In a speech Wednesday night in New York, the Fed's vice chairwoman, Alice M. Rivlin, said, "It's hard to remember any time when the overall economic situation looked so good." The economy, she said, showed "no clear signs of overheating or serious imbalance."
The White House spokesman, Michael D. McCurry, said today that the Clinton Administration was focusing on the core rate component of the Producer Price Index "because a large part of the increase reported is due to the home heating oil and gasoline price increases." Given that, he said, the President was not particularly concerned.
To be sure, some prices have moved higher since December. The price of oil for February delivery has climbed back above $26 a barrel from the low $20 range a month ago. And the Goldman, Sachs & Company industrial metals commodity index has increased about 2 percent since the end of December.

HEADLINE: R. L. Nelson, 70, Pioneer In the Study of Philanthropy

BYLINE: By ROBERT McG. THOMAS Jr. 

 BODY:
Ralph L. Nelson, an innovative Queens College professor who helped harness the science of getting to illuminate the practice of giving, died on Jan. 1 at his home in Manhasset, L.I. He was 70 and widely regarded as a father of the economic study of philanthropy.
His family said the cause was a heart attack. 
 Never mind that American philanthropy is a $500 billion-a-year industry, drawing $150 billion a year in charitable donations and providing indispensible support for myriad religious, educational, medical and other causes.
Until recently, economists gave charity short shrift, and for good reason. For one thing, of course, for a field devoted to the study of the creation and acquisition of wealth, the very idea of giving it away seemed downright subversive.
Then, too, until Dr. Nelson came along, the few economists who were interested in philanthropy had virtually nothing to work with, specifically no measure of who gave how much to which charities under what circumstances.
That is because there is no Government clearing house to tally annual giving, for example, and because tax records of deductible contributions are not tabulated and reported until years after the fact.
So in 1984, Dr. Nelson, already a pioneer in the economics of philanthropy, created a complex economic model based on survey data and other variables to produce annual estimates of current donations.
The figures, published annually by the American Association of Fund Raising Counsel, are regarded as so reliable and so indispensable to researchers that they have become the philanthropic equivalent of official Government estimates of employment, inflation and other economic factors.
They have also helped spawn an entire new branch of economics. As recently as the 1960's, only a handful of economists specialized in charities. Today, hundreds are working on research projects that would simply not have been possible before the Nelson model.
Among other things, researchers using Nelson data have established that high tax rates, year-end stock rallies and Republican control of White House all stimulate charitable contributions, as do Government cutbacks in social-service financing -- although never enough to make up for the shortfall.
By the time he helped establish the economics of philanthropy, Dr. Nelson was an old hand at switching gears.
A native of St. Paul, he was majoring in electrical engineering at the University of Minnesota when he decided that the hard science was far too predictable and much too boring. Seeking a greater challenge, he switched to economics, perhaps the squishiest science of them all.
After obtaining a master's and a doctorate from Columbia, he specialized in industrial organization and held a series of teaching posts before settling in at Queens College in 1964.
A 1967 assignment from the Russell Sage Foundation to study the investment policies of foundations helped alter the course of his work and led to a key appointment as consultant to the Filer Commission on Private Philanthropy, whose landmark 1975 report helped point up the inadequacies of philanthropic statistics.
Known as man of unbending integrity who believed foundations had a moral obligation to spend their tax-exempt dollars well, Dr. Nelson was a meticulous researcher who never trusted computer printouts quite as much as the figures he had written down himself on a yellow tablet.
"Give him a spreadsheet," a colleague said, "and he would check every cell." There was no reason, the colleague added, to check Dr. Nelson's figures. "They were always right."
For all his standing in a field he helped create, Dr. Nelson was a modest, unassuming man with such a sure sense of priorities that when a news conference to publicize his findings conflicted with a teaching assignment, he invariably passed up the limelight for the classroom.
As a spcecialist in philanthropy, Dr. Nelson was more than a cold-eyed professional. He believed in charity so much, his wife said, that he gave far more of his income than the 2 percent that has long been the national average.
He gave generously to the headquarters of the Unitarian Universalist Association in Boston; far less to his local congregation. As his wife noted, because of a long-ago bequest of mineral rights on some German land where oil was later discovered, the little church has an endowment of more than $100 million.
At the time of his death, the man who believed money should be husbanded carefully and well was the church treasurer.
In addition to his wife, he is survived by a son, David, of New Orleans; a daughter, Rachel Moeller of Allentown, Pa., and a grandson.

HEADLINE: Pataki Vows To End Taxes On Inheritance

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 9

 BODY:
Gov. George E. Pataki today proposed a three-year plan to end most of the state's taxes on gifts and inheritances, adding them to a rapidly growing list of tax-cut proposals on the Legislature's agenda before budget negotiations have even begun.
Minutes after Mr. Pataki's announcement, the Assembly Speaker, Sheldon Silver, said he expected to push for a plan later this year to reduce or abolish the state's 4 percent sales tax on clothing costing less than $500. But Mr. Silver, a Democrat of Manhattan, said he would not formally endorse such a plan until he studied the results of a one-week suspension of the sales tax on clothing that begins on Jan. 18. 
 Mr. Pataki released his estate tax proposal a day after advocating using state funds to freeze or reduce local property taxes. And it came just two weeks after leaders of the Republican-controlled State Senate unveiled a multiyear plan to reduce property and business taxes by more than $2 billion.
The plan Mr. Pataki announced today would eliminate most state taxes on estates left behind by New York State residents after they die. Currently, the state imposes taxes of 2 to 21 percent on estates worth more than $115,000 -- or $365,000 if they include a home -- one of the nation's highest rates. (There are no taxes on estates left to spouses if they are United States citizens.)
The abundance of tax-reduction proposals being advanced by the leadership of both parties makes it increasingly likely that Albany will agree to some new tax cuts in the coming year, even though they must find ways to close a projected $3 billion shortfall in the state's $65 billion budget. None of the leaders have explained how they would pay for their plans, and critics have warned that new cuts could leave a gaping hole in the budget if the economy turns sour.
The Governor also urged today that the state raise its lifetime exemption on gift taxes to $600,000 from the current $115,000. Under that plan, the state would allow a person to give up to $600,000 in gifts in his lifetime without imposing state gift taxes.
The Governor's plan would reduce state revenues by $10 million in the fiscal year that begins on April 1 and by $400 million when fully phased in by mid-1999. Mr. Pataki also proposed setting aside $50 million in the 1997-98 budget for business tax cuts that would be determined through negotiations with the Legislature.
The Governor said New York's high estate taxes had driven many people to retire in other states, though he could provide no statistics to bolster that claim. "It's not just the weather that makes people go to Florida or Arizona," he said.
He also contended that reducing the estate taxes would, over time, expand the state's tax base by keeping more people in New York so that the state could continue collecting income, sales and eventually estate taxes from them. Mr. Pataki said his plan would eliminate taxes on 85 percent of the 22,000 estates that are charged state taxes each year.
But the Governor flatly declined to explain how he would pay for his latest tax-cut proposal, saying those details would be in the budget he expected to unveil on Tuesday. He has also not explained how he would pay for his property tax proposal, which his aides have estimated would cost the state several hundred million dollars over five years.
Similarly, Mr. Silver and the Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, have not explained in detail how they would finance their proposals. Mr. Silver said today that he thought that abolishing the state's sales tax on clothing items costing less than $500, which would cost the state more than $400 million a year, would eventually pay for itself by generating additional business for New York stores that have been losing out to competitors in nearby lower-tax states.
Mr. Bruno, a Republican of Rensselaer County, said his tax-cut plan, which calls for freezing local property taxes, phasing out a utility tax and eliminating a host of smaller business taxes, would also spur new economic activity, generating new jobs and taxes.
But critics of new tax cuts, mainly urban Democrats and unions, said that, if anything, the Legislature should be thinking about increasing taxes on the wealthy to pay for essential services like education and health care.
"We all want prosperity and fairer taxes, but not at the expense of services people depend upon," said Stephen Madarasz, a spokesman for the Civil Service Employees Association, a public workers' union. State Senator Franz S. Leichter, a Manhattan Democrat, said, "I think the tax fever has abated for everybody but Albany politicians."
But estate lawyers said Mr. Pataki's plan would benefit people on both ends of the economic spectrum. Though a person inheriting an estate worth hundreds of millions of dollars would stand to save millions, people with estates worth a few hundred thousand dollars -- the value of a typical suburban home -- would also save tens of thousands of dollars under the proposal.

HEADLINE: Producer Data Help Initiate A Stock Rally

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
Stock prices rose to new highs yesterday, propelled in large part by an inflation report that caused short- and long-term interest rates to fall sharply.
Led by oil stocks, the Dow Jones industrial average jumped 76.19 points, to 6,625.67, the third closing high it has set this year. Earlier in the session, the Dow was up nearly 108 points. 
 According to analysts at Birinyi & Associates, a market research firm, four big computer-driven program trades were responsible for 66 points of the Dow's advance.
But the advance was not relegated to the bluest of blue-chip stocks. Broader market indexes also registered strong gains.
The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks rose 6.44 points, to 754.85, and the New York Stock Exchange's composite index rose 3.33 points, to 398.58, a level slightly less than its closing high of 398.86.
The Nasdaq composite index rose 5.85 points, to 1,326.20, and the American Stock Exchange composite index rose 5.02, to 581.74.
On the New York Stock Exchange, advancing issues outnumbered decliners, 1,632 to 957. Volume was heavy, at 555.37 million shares.
Analysts said that the catalyst for the rally was a Government report showing that producer prices remained largely in check during December.
While the one-half of 1 percent increase in the Producer Price Index was higher than expected, stock and bond traders seemed to focus more closely on the "core" rate, which excludes the food and energy prices that are given to sharp swings. That rate rose by just one-tenth of 1 percent.
Stock prices have been closely tracking movements in the bond market, where interest rates have risen sharply on fears of stronger economic growth and higher inflation.
But the rise in interest rates in the last three days was virtually erased yesterday; the yield for the Treasury's 30-year bond yield fell to 6.75 percent, from 6.84 percent on Wednesday.
Stocks have not been troubled by the recent increase in energy costs. The rise reflected in yesterday's producer price figures did generate interest, but for bullish reasons.
"The stock market is taking note of rising oil prices, figuring they will push up profits at the oil companies," said David Shulman, chief equity strategist at Salomon Brothers.
"I am very bullish on energy, but while rising oil prices are good for profits at oil and oil-service companies, they will be a negative on profitability elsewhere."
The advance by oil companies was led by Exxon, which gained $3.375 a share, to $102.875, Texaco, up $3 a share, to $105, and Mobil, which rose $2.50, to $128.625.
But most energy stocks did extremely well. The S.& P. 500's list of large oil companies recorded its biggest one-day gain in four years, jumping more than 4 percent.
Oil prices eased slightly yesterday, but at $26.37 a barrel they remain at their highest levels since January 1991.
And while stock traders appear to believe the worst of the rise in oil prices is over, analysts who are pessimistic about the market's prospects said they were concerned about a surge in commodity price inflation.
"Oil inventories are very low, and demand is strong," said Michael Metz, chief investment strategist at Oppenheimer & Company.
"I think this will be the first of many surprises on the upside in commodity inflation," he said. "So far the market has ignored that possibility, but it is something I think it will have to face."
The big market move came the day before December employment data are released, figures that tend to roil financial markets. But the stock market closed its books yesterday in an apparently ebullient mood.
"Both the stock and the bond market are saying the employment figures will show an economy that is growing but not overheating," said Alfred Goldman, director of market analysis at A. G. Edwards & Sons in St. Louis.
Mr. Goldman said that yesterday's rally left stock prices vulnerable to a report that indicatess that payroll employment grew at a more rapid rate in December than the consensus forecast of around 200,000 jobs.
"If the numbers are stronger than that, the market could go down," he said. "But the Dow is up about 400 points in the last month and is entitled to a pause. And if it does decline, I am going to look at it as a buying opportunity. We are in a bull market, and bull markets go up."
