HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

VW to Pay $100 Million To G.M. to Settle Lawsuit
Volkswagen agreed to pay $100 million to General Motors to settle a lawsuit contending that a former top VW executive, Jose Ignacio Lopez de Arriortua, stole trade secrets when he left G.M. The settlement brings to an end a four-year feud between two of the world's largest car companies.
In the agreement, one of the biggest in a corporate espionage case, Volkswagen also agreed to buy at least $1 billion worth of auto parts from the American company over the next seven years. While not admitting any wrongdoing, VW also said that it "acknowledges the possibility that illegal activities" by Mr. Lopezmight have occurred. [Page A1.]
 
Hughes Bids May Top $10 Billion
The two bids for the military businesses of Hughes Electronics are likely to come to perhaps $10 billion, but will hinge less on their face value than tax considerations and estimates of the future value of the stock of the winning company. The bidders, Raytheon and Northrop Grumman, have both submitted packages that come to 500 pages each. [D2.]
 
Producer Prices Rise
Producer prices rose more than expected during December, but when the cost of energy and food was excluded, the increase was below forecasts. Prices were up half a percent over all, but they rose only one-tenth of a percent without the two volatile categories. [D2.]
 
Liggett Seeks Broader Settlement
The Liggett Group, which shocked the rest of the tobacco industry last March by breaking ranks and agreeing to settle several major lawsuits, is now trying to reach an even broader settlement, according to lawyers familiar with the talks. [A16.]

F.A.A. Found More Valujet Flaws
The F.A.A. found problems with Valujet's system for assuring the safety of its planes as recently as December, six months after one of its jets crashed in the Everglades. [A12.]
 
Labor Votes at United Airlines
Mechanics for United Airlines rejected a wage increase proposal, but other workers accepted the plan. [D2.]
 
Norfolk Southern Loses Court Bid
Norfolk Southern lost a bid to have a court strike down an agreement that prevents Conrail from discussing a merger with anyone other than the CSX Corporation. [A16.]
 
Telmex Aims for American Market
Telefonos de Mexico plans to seek authorization with the F.C.C. to offer its own phone services in United States markets that are heavily Spanish-speaking. [D3.]

The Agony of Finishing Second
Ikon Office Solutions, a giant office equipment and technology company with a new name, is urging those who consider business a battle to "Work to win." The company hopes the theme of its $50 million campaign will cut through the technological clutter of office supply advertising. And it will do that with humorous views of the downside of not finishing first. One ad shows a dinosaur skeleton, declaring, "Second place, evolution." Another ad shows a statue of Lenin being pulled from its pedestal; the headline is "Second place, cold war."
Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D15.]
 
Nasdaq Shifts on New Rules
Nasdaq said that it had it scaled back its proposal to reduce the minimum number of shares that can be traded under the S.E.C.'s new order-handling rules. [D2.]

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Stocks Sell Off in Japan, And Worst May Not Be Over

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Friday, Jan. 10

 BODY:
For close to five years, Japan's troubled markets, like its economy, have been trying to climb out of a pit, only to slip back over and over. This week's market drops -- a 10 percent fall for the main market index, including a 3 percent plunge on Thursday and nearly that much again this morning -- suggest that the slide may be far from over.
After falling on Wednesday, the benchmark Nikkei 225 index plunged 606.51 points, or 3.25 percent, on Thursday and closed today at 770.22 points -- 4.26 percent -- to 17,303.65, its lowest level in more than a year. The frenzied selling surprised even stock market bears and fueled jitters that policy makers were not taking effective measures to turn around the nation's faint economy. 
 "As we left our offices on Dec. 30, we had a faint glimmer of hope," said Douglas E. Weirens, head of equity trading at Lehman Brothers Japan, "but after this week, people are thinking that this is going to get ugly. We've had a huge down week, and it has the investment community sitting in shock."
Analysts cited a number of reasons for the long-struggling market's sudden drop, but one stood out: accumulating evidence that the Japanese economy was likely to remain too weak to expand out of the troubles that have weighed down banks and other financial institutions.
Recently, the Government forecast that the economy would grow 1.9 percent in 1997, its lowest forecast since the end of World War II. Some private economists have been more pessimistic, raising the possibility of a slide back into recession.
Added to worries about a weak yen and cuts in public spending, the result has been a spiral of selling, in which worries about the strength of banks in particular, leads to selloffs that further weaken those banks.
Nor is help likely to come from overseas. American investors began pulling money out of Japanese markets last year, particularly mutual funds specializing in Japan, which ranked as the worst-performing category of funds in 1996,
Since trading opened for the new year on Monday, Japanese policy makers have been trying to nudge the bond, currency and stock markets up with optimistic comments. The yen on Monday weakened here beyond 117 to the dollar, its lowest since March 1993, and the declining currency trend has led many to sell their yen-denominated investments, like Japanese stocks and bonds.
The yen has since edged back up to around 116 against the dollar, in part after Tadashi Ogawa, the Finance Ministry's highest-level bureaucrat, reassured the markets earlier this week by saying that a weak yen would not help the economy.
Concerned by tumbling stocks, Finance Minister Hiroshi Mitsuzuka emerged on Wednesday to say that the ministry would "keep a close eye on developments in the market."
After stocks fell again on Thursday, Mr. Ogawa tried to brush aside growing fears that the Government was hurting the economy by trying to rein in the budget deficit. "The Japanese economy is moving in a firm direction, out of the situation where it needed support from a huge amount of public investment," he said.
However, Japan's economic planner seemed to rule out Government intervention in the stock market today. "Interference by authorities will contradict the ongoing deregulation moves," said Taro Aso, director general of the Economic Planning Agency.
Financial shares have been taking the worst beating these last few weeks. The selloff has pushed the shares of some banks, which are struggling to dispose of billions of dollars in sour loans, to precarious levels. And since the Finance Ministry shut down Hanwa Bank, a failing regional institution, investors have focused on other financially pressed banks, sending their shares, and those of the industry, down.
"Investors are worried about the system over all, especially if interest rates start rising," said James P. Fiorillo of ING Baring Securities. "What's going on is a vicious cycle."
As investors dump financial stocks, depressing their prices, this impairs the banks' already thin capital base. And as the capital base weakens, investors no longer want to hold the stocks, and this selling further depresses the shares.
Japanese banks are trying to maintain an international standard of minimum capital of 8 percent of outstanding loans. To do that, they have relied in part on unrealized profits from portfolio shareholdings they bought years ago at much lower prices. But the lower the market drops, the smaller the unrealized profits become and the closer the banks come to slipping below the 8 percent capital standard.
In fact, the nation's banks are making headway in disposing of the bad real estate loans. But they face dim prospects for the future: loan demand is weak, profits from bond trading are dipping, and steady or rising interest rates erase some of the profit they make on lending.
Analysts say that another big reason for the market selloff is that some financial institutions seem to be trying to lock in profits before the fiscal year ends on March 31 by selling their cross-shareholdings, stakes held in friendly companies, which in turn assume shares in the institution.
The market is unlikely to be bolstered by foreign hedge funds, which have pulled out money the last few weeks.
And in 1996, American mutual funds that invest in the Japanese market were the worst performing of 44 categories of funds tracked by Morningstar, losing 11 percent on average and leading many American investors to withdraw their money.
The Japan fund managed by Scudder suffered net outflows of more than $90 million in the first 11 months of 1996, roughly 16 percent of the $550 million in assets with which it began the year.
These came as Americans put a record $28.7 billion into all international stock funds in the first 11 months of the year, much of it into other Pacific Rim countries. According to Morningstar, mutual funds specializing in Pacific markets other than Japan gained 12.4 percent on average last year.
But while the overall Japanese market picture may be grim, the prospects for blue-chip exporters like Toyota and Canon still seem bright. Indeed, their stock prices have held steady or even risen.
This has given some optimism to some market contrarians like Neil C. Rogers, equity strategist at UBS Securities Ltd. Though the rising New York markets seem to have drawn capital away from Japan, Mr. Rogers argues that Tokyo may now offer investors a more lucrative buying opportunity than those that has sailed to record highs for two years.
"I am a bear on Japan by nature," he said, "and I have turned bullish."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Strong U.S. Jobs Report Pushes Dollar Up, Except Against Yen

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar rose against most currencies yesterday after robust December employment figures, reinforcing the view that the United States economy is growing while Japan and much of Europe struggle with resilient weakness.
A sharp selloff in the British pound also fed into the dollar rally. The pound tumbled after optimism for higher interest rates in Britain faded on data that showed an unexpected decline in manufacturing. 
 Demand for dollars pushed the dollar to the highest level against the mark since early July 1994 and the highest against the Swiss franc since mid-June 1994.
"The foreign exchange market was very pleased with the employment numbers, which show the economy is still strong," said Roger Chapin, foreign-exchange manager at Bank One in Columbus, Ohio.
But the dollar eased slightly against the yen, reflecting some fear in the foreign-exchange market that the Bank of Japan would take action to defend its currency, which has been trading at or near 45-month lows against the dollar for the last few weeks. Japanese officials earlier this week warned that the plummeting yen was undesirable.
In late New York trading yesterday, the dollar rose to 1.5855 German marks from 1.5778 marks on Thursday, and to 1.3765 Swiss francs from 1.3701 Swiss francs. The dollar slipped to 116.06 yen from 116.34 yen. The pound fell to $1.6807 from $1.6955.
The main force driving the dollar higher was the stronger-than-expected employment report, which depicted a growing American economy with stable to slightly higher interest rates.
The pound's sudden fall reflected diminished chances for higher rates on Wednesday, when the governor of the Bank of England. Eddie George, confers with Kenneth Clarke, Chancellor of the Exchequer. There have been widespread expectations that Mr. George would nudge up interest rates to thwart inflationary pressures.
But the Office for National Statistics reported yesterday that British factories produced five-tenths of 1 percent fewer goods in November than in October, defying expectations of an increase.

HEADLINE: Cuba Measure Strikes Back At the U.S.

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: MIAMI, Jan. 10

 BODY:
Raising the stakes in its battle with the United States over American legislation aimed at blocking foreign investment in Cuba, the Cuban Government has approved a law that penalizes Americans who seek restitution of their expropriated properties and allows Cuban citizens to sue the United States for damages.
The Cuban measure is clearly intended to counter the law that President Clinton signed in March after Cuba shot down two unarmed civilian aircraft off Havana, killing four Cuban-Americans. Named after its two main sponsors, the Helms-Burton Act allows Americans to file lawsuits against foreign companies that use American property confiscated by Cuba and denies executives of those businesses entry to the United States. 
 The Cuban action preceded Mr. Clinton's announcement on Jan. 3 that he would indefinitely suspend the carrying out of Helms-Burton's most disputed aspect, the provision allowing American citizens or corporations to seek damages in American courts for their expropriated properties.
Significantly, the Cuban measure formally recognizes that American companies and individuals who were United States citizens when Mr. Castro came to power in 1959 have the right to seek compensation for their losses, though only when the United States and Cuba are able to negotiate an agreement to that effect. But any American citizen or company that takes action against Cuba under Helms-Burton is to be excluded from any such indemnification settlement.
"This legislation is significant because it contains a threat to people not to register their claims and separates the big U.S. companies that can afford to wait from Cuban-Americans who were naturalized later," said Pamela Falk, author of the book "Cuban Foreign Policy."
"But the fact they are talking about compensation at all is a significant concession, and sets a bilateral agenda for opening the door on the issue of claims," she added.
The Clinton Administration's closest allies and trading partners in Europe and the Western Hemisphere have erected barriers to the American law. On Jan. 1, for instance, legislation went into effect in Canada that would allow Canadians to seek recovery in their courts of any losses they suffer as a result of the American legislation.
Most of the provisions of the new Cuban law appear to be tit-for-tat responses to American efforts to weaken the struggling Cuban economy. For instance, the law codifies Cuba's offer to assist foreign companies that wish to camouflage their investments in Cuba to evade American sanctions.
In addition, the Justice Ministry is ordered to set up special commissions at which Cuban citizens can bring suit against the United States and Cuban-Americans. These courts would be authorized to hear all claims of "theft, torture, corruption and murder" against officials from the era of the dictatorship of Fulgencio Batista who are now living in the United States.
The law also allows Cubans to pursue damage claims stemming from United States military action, American-sponsored "terrorism" or Washington's 34-year economic embargo against Cuba. In theory, at least, a Cuban will now be able to sue the United States in a Cuban court for damages said to have been caused by the Bay of Pigs invasion in 1961, though obviously there is no mechanism by which a verdict could be enforced.
"Many of those provisions are highly propagandistic, intended basically for domestic political consumption," said a Latin American diplomat in Havana.
But one clause makes it a crime for Cuban citizens to cooperate in any way with news organizations that publish or divulge American Government arguments in favor of Helms-Burton. Another makes it a crime for foreigners, apparently including news reporters, to seek or provide any information, like property registers, that could be useful in carrying out Helms-Burton.
"That's kind of a new twist, and it's something that we are very concerned about," said Sarah DeCosse, who monitors the Caribbean for Americas Watch, a Washington-based human rights group. "I think this kind of repression would undoubtedly create a chilling effect in terms of the willingness of the Cuban people to speak openly and honestly to the press."

HEADLINE: An 'Us vs. Them' Mantra Raises the Balkan Fever

BYLINE: By CHRIS HEDGES 

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Serbia, Jan. 8

 BODY:
The Grand Master of the United Grand Masonic Lodges in Germany, armed with a visa issued to him at the Yugoslav Consulate in Hamburg, planned to spend this Serbian Orthodox Christmas week inaugurating a new lodge in the city of Novi Sad.
But when the Grand Master, Rainer Schieke, arrived at the Belgrade airport last week, his visa was invalidated by customs officials and he was abruptly told, with no explanation, to return on the flight he came in on, according to a letter he faxed to Belgrade. 
 It was a trivial slight in the world of international relations, causing hardly a ripple in the small independent press and being ignored by the state-run media. But it highlighted the bizarre conspiracy theories, purported international plots, prejudices and fantasies that are spun in dizzying complexity by political leaders here.
Political debate has been twisted by a combination of the Communist ideology that gripped the former Yugoslavia for five decades and the nationalist Governments that rule Croatia, Bosnia and Serbia. Diatribes against foreign powers, secret organizations and rival ethnic groups plotting everyone's demise are the stock of public speeches.
The Serbian President, Slobodan Milosevic, and the Croatian President, Franjo Tudjman, have in the last month warned their followers that "foreign enemies" were trying to destabilize their respective countries. The two leaders have accused their political opponents of being financed and directed from abroad. And both have pet lists of human rights groups, religious orders, charitable organizations and foreign powers that they say are arrayed against them. Mr. Tudjman, in one of the more mystifying assaults, recently attacked Croats who he said have sold themselves to "black, green and yellow devils" and receive in return "the pay of Judas."
All sorts of groups, including Amnesty International, the Open Society Foundation run by George Soros, an American businessman, and even the Vatican scheme behind the scenes against Serbs, to name a few forces cited by leaders here. And although Tito actually shut down the Masonic order in Yugoslavia, his history has been rewritten by conspiracy theorists who have portrayed him as the secret international leader of the Masons.
"You know Tito was a Mason," said a 54-year-old Orthodox priest in St. Sava Cathedral one recent afternoon, "and so is the Pope and all the Catholic bishops. After Mahatma Gandhi was killed, Tito became the head of the Masons. And the toughest opponent of the Masonic order, which wants to rule the world, is the Serbian Orthodox church. We know Tito was secretly buried in the Vatican."
The lack of self-criticism, the tendency to always blame the outsider, often cuts short any rational political debate. And even the political opposition within Serbia frequently evokes the image of Serbs as "victims," ignoring the fact that Mr. Milosevic's nationalist campaign to build a "Greater Serbia," a major contributing factor to the war, also got him elected to office and, for a time, saw him lionized by nearly all sectors of Serb society.
"The propaganda of the Communist regime repeatedly told Yugoslavs that there were strong international groups conspiring against us," said Stojan Cerovic, a columnist for the opposition magazine Vreme. "Milosevic achieved power by warning that such foreign groups were behind the disintegration of Yugoslavia. He said the sanctions imposed on Serbia during the war and the economic collapse were all part of the plot. He is again playing on this paranoia to portray his opponents as foreign agents out to destroy the Serbs, although having less success."
For the hapless 150 Masons in Belgrade, part of the Regular Grand Lodge of Yugoslavia, the attacks -- political and sometimes physical -- have nearly wiped out their small organization. The car of a leader of the Belgrade group, Dragan Tanasic, was badly vandalized last year and a steel-tipped arrow was fired through the window of this home.
He has also been accused in the press of working for Mr. Schieke, whom the daily newspaper Politika Ekspres said last month was "the chief C.I.A. official in Germany."
"Not only do people not want to join, but current members want to get out," he said. "After these press attacks, my own neighbors look at me as if I was the devil."
The propaganda campaign, Masonic leaders say, has more to do with the intellectual and political distortions than the beliefs of their organization. The Masons are a secret society and say they promote tolerance, brotherhood and charitable work. But they have found few allies to protest Mr. Schieke's expulsion.
"In this society, we believe that if we fail, someone else is guilty," said Mr. Tanasic. "We live under a regime where all decisions are made in secret. Rulers go behind closed doors and come out to hand down decrees. We never see the process of Government. When you live like this for over 50 years you begin to believe that all political systems operate in the same manner. The secrecy, and the propensity to blame others for our own mistakes, have kept alive these ridiculous conspiracy theories."
As if the conspiracy theories were not enough for Mr. Tanasic's group, they have to contend with another Masonic lodge, known as Grand Lodge Yugoslavia, that they say has close links with Mr. Milosevic's Government. The lodge is not recognized by Masonic groups abroad.
"It is impossible in this country to have an independent civic organization," he said, "even for the Masons. The Government insists on putting its own people in to run every group, no matter how obscure."

HEADLINE: JOB REPORT SHOWS UNEXPECTED VIGOR FOR U.S. ECONOMY

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10

 BODY:
Jobs and paychecks grew with unexpected vigor in December, powerful evidence that the economy was gathering fresh momentum as 1996 ended, Labor Department figures showed today.
Although the unemployment rate was unchanged at 5.3 percent, the 262,000 jobs created last month were far more than economists had predicted, and there was a second consecutive large gain in average hourly earnings. Analysts said the robust report raised the specter of higher inflation and of a decision by the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates to counter it. 
 Both fears combined to cause the bond and stock markets to plunge, although the stock market later recovered strongly.
President Clinton dismissed any worries about inflation, pointing instead to the jobs created in his term. "This is the first time in the history of our economy that over 11 million jobs have been created during one four-year Administration," he told reporters at the White House.
The economy is "on a roll," said Robert B. Reich, the Secretary of Labor, also playing down jitters about inflation. "There's much to celebrate."
While investors in the stock market ultimately agreed, traders in the bond market, which is sensitive to inflation, felt differently. The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond, an important benchmark for corporate and consumer interest rates, rose to 6.84 percent, as prices, which move in the opposite direction, fell.
Interest rates are now nearly a half-point higher than in early December and a quarter-point higher than just before Christmas, when indications of economic resurgence first emerged.
More economists joined the scramble today to raise estimates of economic growth in the final 1996 quarter, which already appeared to be higher than is consistent with steady inflation. They also raised their projections for the first half of this year.
"You're starting off from a much higher platform," said William C. Dudley, a senior economist at Goldman, Sachs, who now figures the economy grew at a 3.6 percent pace, rather than 3 percent, in the quarter that just ended.
But while the chances increased that the Federal Reserve will decide to tighten monetary policy, most analysts also agreed that the central bank would probably not act before its March 25 policy meeting.
At that point, they said, it would be better able to tell whether growth will ebb on its own, helped by higher interest rates generated by the market.
Some analysts predicted just this. "The current strength in the economy will be temporary," said Mickey D. Levy, an economist at Nationsbank in New York. "In the spring we'll see signs that the current rate of growth won't be sustained."
The jump in payrolls of 262,000 was the biggest gain since August and about 50 percent more than the consensus prediction. The Labor Department also raised its previous tally of total job growth for October and November by 46,000.
For the full year, the number of Americans with jobs climbed 2.8 million, split almost evenly between men and women. The labor force grew by 2.6 million, with women accounting for three-fifths of the increase. This has caused the jobless rate for adult men, which a year ago was higher than that for adult women, to fall to 4.4 percent, a half-point lower than that of the women. The unemployment rate for teen-agers last month was 16.5 percent.
A startling development, however, was the large increase in average hourly earnings. Most specialists had expected little change after a huge 9-cent November increase but pay rose instead by an additional 6 cents.
This suggested a hefty rise in the quarterly Employment Cost Index, to be published Jan. 28, an indicator that gets close scrutiny at the Federal Reserve.
For the full year, average hourly pay rose 44 cents, or 3.8 percent, compared with gains of 3.2 percent in 1995, 2.7 percent in 1994 and 2.4 percent in 1993.
One factor in the recent acceleration is the increase of 50 cents an hour in the Federal minimum wage that took effect Oct. 1.
But workers in retail trade, where there is a concentration of the lower-paid employees, had average increases of only 2 cents an hour in December and 4 cents in November after an 8-cent October increase. Secretary Reich said the law had had "possibly a small effect" on wages in general.
Other signs of strength included 18-minute extensions of the factory and private-sector workweeks and 12 minutes more of factory overtime. The measures of factory hours have now rebounded to near-record levels and suggest that employers may need to step up hiring.
Nearly all sectors of the economy added sizable numbers of jobs last month, with business services contributing 45,000 jobs after a small decline in November and retail trade added 48,000 jobs, many of them in restaurants and bars.
Construction employment, aided by milder-than-usual weather in most of the country, rose by 23,000 and manufacturing rose by 19,000 despite a continued decline at factories that make electronic equipment.
Government showed 31,000 more jobs, but most of this reflected the fact that fewer election workers than usual were hired in November and thus there were fewer to be dismissed in December.
The combination of more people at work and longer workweeks drove the index of aggregate weekly hours up nine-tenths of 1 percent, to 139.2, assuring a big increase when the Federal Reserve reports on industrial production for the month next Friday, the payroll data also showed.
The Labor Department's survey of households registered 211,000 more people with jobs last month than in November, enough to keep up with a 191,000 rise in the labor force and thereby hold the unemployment rate at 5.3 percent.
The November rate had initially been 5.4 percent but this was recalculated downward as part of the usual year-end revision that incorporates updated seasonal adjustment factors. The rates for January, March and May were also revised one-tenth of a point lower while August was raised one-tenth of a point, to 5.2 percent.
Regionally, the December jobless rate edged up two-tenths of a point, to 6.5 percent in the West and one-tenth of a point, to 5.6 percent, in the Northeast. The rate eased two-tenths of a point, to 5.2 percent, in the South and one-tenth of a point, to 4.5 percent, in the Midwest.

HEADLINE: Clinton Seeks Business Help On Proposal Over Welfare

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10

 BODY:
Noting that the changes he approved last year to the welfare system "did not put anybody to work," President Clinton embarked today on his post-election campaign to persuade business leaders to hire welfare recipients.
Citing new time limits for most adults receiving welfare benefits, Mr. Clinton said before meeting with business executives at the White House: "Unless we can create new jobs in the private sector within the two-year time line, the welfare reform effort will not succeed." 
 Beginning what his aides said would be a national effort as the changes to the welfare system take hold, Mr. Clinton today brought together executives who are already trying to hire people receiving welfare.
"My single message is the C.E.O.s of America need to step up and recognize this now is a private sector initiative," Gerald Greenwald, the chief executive of U.A.L. Corporation, said as he left the hour-long meeting. "The challenge really of welfare reform is the challenge in the private sector. We're the ones that have the jobs."
He said United Airlines had hired 25,000 people in 2 1/2 years, 15,000 of them at $7 to $10 an hour. "A lot of them have been coming off welfare," he said.
Prodded by reporters asking why the White House was not leading by example, Mr. Clinton's staff is looking into hiring welfare recipients, Michael D. McCurry, the White House press secretary said today. "We have to look very carefully at what Federal guidelines and restrictions are and whether it's possible," he said.
After signing welfare legislation in August over the anguished objections of his liberal supporters, Mr. Clinton met with business leaders twice during his re-election campaign to urge them to hire welfare recipients, while promising to amend the new law to soften its impact. He also proposed $3.4 billion in grants and tax incentives to help provide jobs for people being forced off welfare benefits.
Executives who attended today's meeting said Mr. Clinton had promised Federal help with efforts like worker training, day care and transportation from the inner cities to jobs. But they said they anticipated little new Federal money.
"It's not a question of money, because there's a lot of money going to people on welfare," said Bill Esery, the chairman and chief executive of Sprint. "It's a question of how you can use that money in a different way to get people gainfully employed."
Mr. Clinton also announced today that his Administration had granted waivers for three more states -- Louisiana, Maryland, and North Carolina -- to carry out their welfare plans. In all, 29 states have waivers.
While critics of the President praised him for reaching out to business leaders, some raised concerns about Federal encouragement to hire welfare recipients.
"We must proceed with caution," Representative Bill Archer, chairman of the Committee on Ways and Means, wrote in a letter to Mr. Clinton on Thursday. "Welfare recipients should not be given jobs at the expense of the working poor, who may not qualify for a corporate tax credit but who, nonetheless, still need jobs."
A further obstacle to hiring welfare recipients was suggested by a question put to Mr. Clinton during his appearance today. Citing new jobs data, a reporter asked if Mr. Clinton worried that unemployment had dropped too far.
As Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich left the meeting with executives, he said: "Even at a low unemployment rate of 5.3 percent, there are still some 7 million people unemployed and actively looking for jobs. People who are now welfare beneficiaries are likely to be at the end of any job queue. The ultimate answer is economic growth, and simultaneously, a better match between unemployed workers and jobs."
Another question is how responsive business leaders will be to jawboning from the White House.
Mr. Reich said: "In my experience, it's difficult to get most of the business community to rally behind a request that they do the right thing. Unless they see a direct relationship between profit maximization and doing the right thing, they will not be persuaded."
Some business people at the meeting today said hiring welfare recipients made good business sense. Robert Lowes, the chief executive of Burger King, said one of his franchisees recently opened stores in Federal empowerment zones in the depressed city centers in Baltimore and Detroit, employing "a high percentage of welfare recipients."
Those stores, he said, were averaging $2 million in sales a year, compared with $1.1 million for Burger King restaurants nationwide. "It's not just the right thing to do, it's a tremendous business opportunity," he said.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Japanese Stocks Off 10% in Grim Week

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Jan. 10

 BODY:
After a week in which Japanese stocks tumbled by more than 10 percent -- including a 4.26 percent drop today -- many people still fear the market will continue to sink.
There is no reason to think the pessimists are any more right than the optimists were seven years ago, when the market was trading at more than twice today's level. Still, the revolution in attitudes underscores Japan's profound malaise and the enormous economic challenges the country faces. 
 The Nikkei index of 225 leading stocks ended a dismal week today, closing at 17,303.65, down 770.22 points for the day. It was a hectic session in which 536 million shares changed hands, nearly double the turnover on Thursday. For the week -- and for the year so far, since the Japanese market had its first day of 1997 trading on Monday -- the index has fallen more than 2,000 points, or 10.6 percent.
The drop brought the Nikkei to its lowest point since August 1995, though the index has been as low as 14,300 since it peaked at 38,915 in December 1989. In percentage terms, this was the worst week since the Nikkei lost 11.75 percent in the week ended Sept. 28, 1990, a few months into what has become a seven-year bear market.
By contrast, the United States has not seen a week as bad as this one in Japan since the stock market crash of 1987, when the Dow fell 13.2 percent in the week that ended Oct. 23. The market had dropped 22 percent that Monday, but recovered somewhat later in the week.
The abrupt fall in stock prices here threatens to provoke a banking crisis as well as pose a huge political challenge for Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto. The plunging market could also give new impetus to the calls for sweeping changes in Japan's economy and Government.
"For every politician, the economy is the No. 1 issue," said John F. Neuffer, a political analyst at the Mitsui Marine Research Institute. Referring to Mr. Hashimoto, Mr. Neuffer added, "He needs to say that we finally have to move aggressively on administrative reform and deregulation; otherwise the economy will end up on the scrap heap."
Mr. Hashimoto, who is on a state visit to Southeast Asia, has been unusually silent, prompting speculation that officials are trying to create a plan to address the market plunge.
"The Cabinet will not ignore it, because otherwise another round of political turmoil will develop quickly," said Takashi Kiuchi, an economist at LTCB Research Institute Inc., a research group tied to the Long-Term Credit Bank. "What is missing is some secret trump card."
Other investors, however, are concerned that policy makers have few tools available to retune the economy. A rising budget deficit has ruled out an increase in Government spending and with interest rates already near zero, the Bank of Japan cannot use rate cuts as a stimulus.
 That may explain the market's reaction today when three top Cabinet officials, including Finance Minister Hiroshi Mitsuzuka, emerged in public one by one to try to calm the selling frenzy. After they spoke, the market plummeted further.
Japan's market quagmire may also have sobering lessons for the United States as it sits perched atop a record stock market. Japan, too, was full of exuberance seven years ago. At Japan's market peak in 1989, many analysts argued, as people always have during boom times, that for a host of reasons, stocks would continue to rise and this boom was different from those in the past.
While there are clear differences between the American and Japanese situations -- for one, the American economy is on a solid growth path -- some people see similarities. Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, drew the comparison last month, citing Japan as evidence that stocks fall as well as rise.
"There are lessons to be learned," said Ronald Bevacqua, an economist at Merrill Lynch Japan Inc. "People are justifying the level of the Dow to themselves. I don't hear enough people saying that the Dow is too high."
One puzzling aspect of this week's plunge is that there was no single event that set off the selling, and the currency market was relatively stable today, with the yen settling in Tokyo at 115.92 against the dollar. There are, however severe underlying problems: a dim economic outlook, a rising sales tax and budget tightening by the Government.
Economists say that an increase in the sales tax to 5 percent, from 3 percent, is likely to crimp buying by consumers after it goes into effect in April. Given a tiny increase in fiscal spending and an end to tax breaks, the economy is projected to show little growth in the 1997 fiscal year, which begins in April.
The lackluster economic outlook helped drag down stocks, and the depressed stock market may, in turn, hurt the economy, possibly causing Japanese companies to scale back the spending plans they are drawing up for the next fiscal year.
Moreover, the damage from the stock market is already being felt acutely by Japan's thinly capitalized banks, which are burdened by several hundred billion dollars in sour property loans. The banks are trying to maintain an international standard of minimum capital equal to 8 percent of outstanding loans.
To do that, they have relied in part on unrealized profits on stocks they bought years ago at much lower prices. In today's market, however, those unrealized profits have shrunk so much as to nudge the weakest and even some moderately weak banks below the 8 percent capital standard. The depleted capital makes it even more difficult for those banks to write off bad debt.
For that reason, bank shares took a severe beating today. Sakura Bank was the most heavily traded stock, dipping 49 yen, to 650 yen.
Mr. Hashimoto's "Big Bang" -- his extensive plan for deregulating the financial industry and the overall economy -- in some ways is contributing to the plunge in bank stocks. One crucial result of the Big Bang will be that strong banks will survive, while weak ones will not.
"The move to sell bank shares initially reflected the impact that the Big Bang could bring," said Mitsuhiro Nakano, an equity strategist at Daiwa Research Institute. "Keener competition could create losers in the financial market."
Financially strained banks could sell overseas securities, particularly United States Treasuries and other bonds. A concentrated bout of such selling before the fiscal year ends in March could cause ripples in the American bond market, analysts say, but they added that the American bond market was so huge that no one group of players, even one as large as the Japanese, could sway it too significantly. Also, Japanese financial managers tend not to shift money rapidly around the world.
So, for all the talk about globalization of markets, of how money sloshes between Tokyo and New York, the market crisis here is not expected to knock over any dominoes abroad.
"Capital moves freely around the world, but not all capital," Mr. Bevacqua of Merrill Lynch said. "Japanese have an enormous supply of capital, which doesn't move around the world to where the returns are the highest."

HEADLINE: As Nature and Economics Collide, Some Boardwalks Evolve

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS 

DATELINE: BELMAR, N.J.

 BODY:
It has been more than four years since a ferocious northeaster raked the towns along the jutting chin of New Jersey's coast, the storm's 90-mile-an-hour winds and pounding surf destroying whole sections of boardwalk.
Afterward, some hard-hit towns did what they always did: They simply rebuilt their boardwalks. Not rebuilding was not an option in those towns, which rely on tourists for whom boardwalks are as emblematic of the New Jersey shore as salt water taffy. But other towns, faced with declining state aid and scarcer local tax dollars, began to consider new approaches. The northeaster may have been the worst storm to hit the coast in 30 or 40 years, but the mayors said they realized they were essentially in a losing battle with the sea and the sand. 
 As a result, the boardwalk in Spring Lake is now made of a wood substitute made of sawdust and plastic that requires less maintenance than regular wood. In Bradley Beach, the boardwalk is not really a boardwalk anymore; it is a pathway made with concrete paving stones and built farther inland. And Belmar chose to make its boardwalk removable. Forklifts and backhoes dismantle the boardwalk and take it inland during hurricane season and winters.
"This stuff is expensive, but we couldn't do away with the boardwalk which attracts so many tourists," said Belmar's Mayor, Kenneth E. Pringle. "I guess we accepted the realities of Mother Nature and made a strategic withdrawal. It's what I like to call peace with honor."
Hard-pressed, blue-collar towns reliant on weekend visitors often made different decisions than more affluent communities less dependent on tourism. But in almost all cases, said Norbert Psuty, director of the Institute of Marine and Coastal Sciences at Rutgers University, officials acted with a keen eye toward cost effectiveness and cutting their economic losses over time.
"It's part of the tenor of the times," he said. "They are looking for ways to cut budgets in ways that some of their predecessors were not."
The Mayor of Bradley Beach, Stephen Schueler, said the town had been spending $40,000 to $50,000 a year to maintain its old boardwalk. Even so, he described it as "rickety, fall-down and like a child whose hair had not been combed."
"We know the ocean is rising and coming inland so we decided to retreat as well as get away from the traditional wood solutions," he said. "Now 90 percent of our boardwalk is masonry which is cool to the feet, low maintenance and has 20 times the life of wood."
Many of these Monmouth County shore front towns are looking as well to the promise of Federally financed beach replenishment programs that would replace yards of lost sand and restore the storm-raked dunes that once prevented some of the storm damage to boardwalks and other man-made structures. But dependence on such money has long been controversial among groups which see it as basically throwing tax dollars into the ocean. As a result, some areas to the south, like Avalon and Ocean City, have used their own scarce funds for periodic beach replenishment in tandem with rebuilding boardwalks.
"It's difficult to draw a line in the sand and defend it," Dr. Psuty said. "But the mass of sand from larger beaches and dunes can be a natural barrier that absorbs some of the energy of waves and storm tides and slows the erosion. And if a community feels itself dependent on tourism so that they have to constantly rebuild, then it makes sense for them to be flexible."
The first boardwalk in this country was built in Atlantic City in the 1870's, said Phillip Correll, the manager of the National Park Service's New Jersey Coastal Heritage Trail Route. And it was not long before the once narrow, removable wooden walkways grew to wide, raised promenades that all but replaced the Atlantic Ocean as the resort city's major attraction.
In the Victorian era, people took a grand view of the healthful properties of fresh air and walking at coastal resorts that were touted as the cure for everything from consumption to "nervous affections and mild cases of mental disease," as one brochure of the time suggested. But the motives for building Atlantic City's boardwalk had little to do with that.
It actually was prompted by more mundane considerations. According to several histories of the city, a railroad conductor and a hotel proprietor petitioned the city's officials to build the walkway to keep patrons and bathers from tracking sand into lobbies and rail cars.
But it was not long before the boardwalk became a staple of the New Jersey shore, whether it was the wide, nearly desolate promenades of Spring Lake and Long Branch or the commercial and carnival atmosphere of Atlantic City and Asbury Park. They snaked their way north up the 127-mile-long New Jersey coast, cropping up like dune grass in one community after another from the turn of the century on to the 1920's.
In 1923, the first New York City boardwalk was built at Coney Island -- arguably the country's second most famous ocean front promenade, after Atlantic City's.
"While it began as a way to prevent people from tracking sand inside, they soon became extensions of the community and its economic activity," said John Cunningham, who has written several books on New Jersey history.
For this reason, Mr. Pringle, the Mayor of Belmar, said it was inconceivable for the town not to replace a quarter-mile section of the boardwalk and two public restrooms that were battered by the 1992 storm. Even in good years the boardwalk was the town's No. 1 maintenance item, he said, costing as much as $60,000 for simple timber replacement and renailing along the entire length. To rebuild that one section more than doubled the annual cost, the Mayor said. So the removable sections made sense. Today the sections are stacked in a municipal parking lot six blocks inland from the beach.
"Beach replenishment has been a promise for more than 40 years but never a sure thing," Mr. Pringle said. "We hedged our bets so that we could maintain the boardwalk at the minimum cost by making it removable if beach replenishment doesn't happen soon."
In an unexpected bonus, said Mayor Pringle, the annual removal of the boardwalk sections is spawning a new tradition in town, that while not as gold-plated as Victorian-era boardwalk promenading, has its own postmodern allure. Year-round residents have begun to turn out to watch the heavy equipment take up the removable boardwalk decking and haul it inland for storage.
Belmar considered rebuilding with new materials, the Mayor said, but in the end reasoned that "what you make a stationary boardwalk out of was sort of like a debate over the material you use to make the deck chairs on the Titanic."
Spring Lake's Mayor, Thomas J. Byrne 3d, disagreed. A milelong stretch of the boardwalk in his affluent town, where Victorian-style houses abound, is made of sawdust and recycled plastic. The product, called Trex, was more expensive to install than normal wood, he said, but it requires far less maintenance because it does not splinter, split, warp or attract termites. And he noted that the weathered gray Trex timbers were less likely to shatter into thousands of splintery shards in a storm and were fastened to pilings in such a way that they would be upended in sections rather than timber by timber.
Because the wood in the old boardwalk was chemically treated, storm-damaged timbers had to be disposed of at great cost at hazardous waste landfills. The Trex material is environmentally safe for regular landfill disposal, the Mayor said. And what is more, he said, the town has avoided scores of lawsuits from joggers or walkers who claimed injuries from exposed nails or splinters on the old timber boardwalk.
On a recent morning as a frigid wind whipped along the Spring Lake boardwalk, Bill Woodruff, a Point Pleasant resident who regularly walks the several miles of boardwalks from his home north through Manasquan, Spring Lake, Belmar and Bradley Beach, graded the various surfaces. The wood he encountered in Belmar was "bumpy, has no give and sometimes you trip," he said. In Bradley Beach "the paving stones look nice" but were hard on the knees. But he said the Trex, without the inconvenience of knots, warping and nails, was springy and flexible to the step.
That was endorsement enough for Mayor Byrne.
"They come to Belmar to watch them move their boardwalk, but they come to Spring Lake to walk on ours," he said with satisfaction. "I'll accept that."

HEADLINE: Treasury Prices Fall on Strong Jobs Report

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury prices tumbled yesterday after an employment report that was stronger than expected.
The data showed that the economy was still vibrant, raising expectations in the bond market that the Federal Reserve would soon need to raise short-term interest rates to prevent inflation from accelerating. 
 The price of the 30-year Treasury bond dropped 27/32 , to 9522/32 . The bond's yield -- an important benchmark for corporate and consumer interest rates -- rose to 6.84 percent, from 6.75 percent on Thursday. Bond prices and their yields move in opposite directions.
Bond prices fell by more than one and a half points in the morning reaction to the jobs report before recovering more than a third of their losses.
The drop in prices meant that bondholders lost about $8.44 for every $1,000 invested.
The Labor Department reported that 262,000 jobs were added to the nation's payrolls last month, way above the 175,000 expected in the market consensus.
"The number seemed to confirm two things today," said Donald J. Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Securities, "that growth in the fourth quarter was clearly stronger than the third quarter and that the market has now conclusively once again built in the concept that the next Fed move is a tightening."
While some market participants say they expect the Fed to raise short-term rates next month, many others say they believe that the central bank will want more evidence that the strength from the fourth quarter has carried over into the first quarter. That would mean the Fed may decide to put off any action until the March meeting of policy makers.
Indeed, the central issue now confronting the market, Mr. Fine said, is whether growth in the first quarter will continue at such a strong clip or ease back to its pace of the third quarter.
Anthony Chan, vice president and chief economist at the Banc One Investment Advisers Corporation in Columbus, Ohio, agreed that the employment data should generate more serious discussion about a possible rate increase in the near term.
"Although the Fed may not have enough support within its ranks for an immediate hike," Mr. Chan said, "any additional evidence of the type found in this report could quickly change the sentiment at the Fed and lead to a tightening that takes place sooner rather than later."
The market's fears were eased somewhat, Mr. Chan said, by a report on the Market News service that argued that it would be more plausible for the Fed to wait until its March 25 meeting to push rates higher rather than to do so on Feb. 5.
"This story," Mr. Chan said, "held out the hope the Fed may have read this report as being somewhat out of line with true economic trends. And with this reasoning, some investors may have assumed that if the Fed wasn't about to panic, why should they?"

HEADLINE: Stocks Plunge, Then Soar, As Dow Finishes Up 78.12

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA 

 BODY:
Stock prices went on a wild ride yesterday, first plunging and then leaping. The swings came after the Government reported that jobs grew more strongly than expected last month.
The Dow Jones industrial average surpassed 6,700 for the first time and notched its fourth record in a week, closing at 6,703.79, up 78.12 points in heavy trading. For the week, the Dow was up 159.70 points, or about 2.4 percent. 
 Other market indexes also set records. The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks rose 4.65 points, to 759.50, and the Nasdaq composite index gained 5.82 points, to 1,332.02.
The Russell 2000 index rose for the second consecutive day, closing at a record 366.09, up 0.50 point. The New York Stock Exchange composite rose 2.18 points, at 400.76.
Stocks tumbled at the opening of the market on the Labor Department's report on December employment, which showed higher-than-expected job growth.
Bond prices fell even more sharply in the morning, dropping by more than a point and a half before recovering somewhat.
The Dow was down 67 points in early trading, restricting trading on the New York Stock Exchange, but by early afternoon blue-chip stocks bounced back on what was to become a 150-point turnaround.
"Stocks had a very, very wild day," said Matthew F. Alexy, chief market strategist at Credit Suisse First Boston. "Days like this embolden investors. They see a day where the Dow comes back from what looks like a death spiral and then it goes on to make a record high."
Analysts said that cash flowing in from foreign investors and larger- than-expected investments in mutual funds had helped bolster the stock market.
There is also increasing confidence in the economy and the strength of the dollar.
"What the stock market is beginning to reflect is that maybe we can have a strong economy without a strong rise in inflation," said Byron Wien, chief United States investment strategist at Morgan Stanley. 'There's a feeling out there that nothing can go wrong. It's a dangerous attitude but it's out there."
Indeed, investors continue to focus on prospects for growth, despite fears of inflation that have unnerved investors in the bond market, analysts said.
"There's a view the economy is firm," Mr. Alexy said. "Right now, the equity market is saying earnings will be O.K."
Mr. Wien and other analysts said that the advance in stocks was broad. Of the Dow's 30 component stocks, only 4 declined in trading yesterday, and cyclical stocks were particularly strong.
Oil stocks again were a significant part of the rally. Shares of Texaco closed at 107 3/8, up 2 3/8. And shares of Exxon rose to 105 3/4, up 2 7/8.
Allied Signal was one of the Dow's big gainers, rising to 70 1/2, up 2 3/8.
Shares of General Motors closed at 61 1/8, up 1 7/8, and Caterpillar was up 1 7/8 to close at 78.
With those gains, the Dow has risen nearly 4 percent since the beginning of the year.
Some analysts said that despite a plunge in Japanese stocks and weakness in the bond market, investors and speculators continued to favor equities.
"A bull market celebrates good news and ignores bad news," said Eric Miller, chief investment officer at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. "There's the so-called January barometer, when people look at how the market performs. Strength encourages people, weakness discourages them. This month tends to suggest a bull market."

HEADLINE: Winning N.F.L. Team Gives Jacksonville a Sense of Itself

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK 

DATELINE: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Jan. 7

 BODY:
Two Saturdays ago, after becoming the first N.F.L. team to win a playoff game in only its second year, the Jacksonville Jaguars made a rookie mistake by zipping away from the Jacksonville airport without acknowledging the 5,000 fans who had jammed the terminal to await the team's arrival.
Stung by angry comments from the fans, team and city officials did some serious planning for the Jaguars' next playoff game. And when the team flew home early Sunday after upsetting the Denver Broncos, the plane banked over an illuminated Jacksonville Municipal Stadium so players could see the 40,000 fans who had gathered at 1:30 A.M. for a raucous celebration. 
 They are starting to get the hang of winning around here.
And not just here. There may be no greater testament to the economic, cultural and political ascension of the South than the elevation of its second-tier cities -- Charlotte, Jacksonville and Orlando -- into the major leagues.
With the advance of the Jaguars and their two-year-old counterparts, the Carolina Panthers, to Sunday's conference championship games, football is being embraced and promoted by those upstart towns as a metaphor for civic momentum.
In the eyes of the rest of the country, professional sports uncomplemented by other cultural assets may not singlehandedly move a city into the first tier. People in Jacksonville and its sister cities understand that. But they also firmly believe that pro teams, especially underdog teams that continually defy expectations, can captivate a nation and make people remember your name.
"There are 13 Jacksonvilles in America, and now when you say you're from Jacksonville, you don't have to say Florida," said Laurence J. DuBow, a Jacksonville businessman and part owner of the Jaguars.
Jacksonville's leaders believe that the recognition and respect that follow a winning sports franchise can help lure new employers and create the sense of community needed to attack problems like racial tension.
"What we hope is that the sense of good will that comes with this will help us address some of our lingering problems," said Jacksonville's Mayor, John A. Delaney.
This sprawling northeast Florida city, known for its port on the broad St. John's River, its military bases, and its insurance and banking industries, has rapidly grown in the last two decades. The metropolitan area's population is now about one million.
But Jacksonville's mentality has always seemed far smaller than its size, and the city, while by far the most populous in Florida, has never been able to compete for national attention with cities like Atlanta, Houston, Miami, New Orleans, Orlando and Tampa.
For years, Jacksonville was known to those passing through to South Florida as a city whose air was fouled by the sulfur dioxide emissions of its pulp and paper mills and whose Interstates were clogged by quarter-gobbling toll booths. It consistently finished second or third in the competition for companies relocating to the South and in the hunt for professional football teams, whose owners used Jacksonville's recruitment efforts to win better deals from other cities.
When the city made national news, it was because snipers were firing at motorists from Interstate overpasses or because its chief judge was being sanctioned for making racially insensitive remarks.
Now football -- winning football -- has given Jacksonville the means to shake off what its leaders characterize as a civic inferiority complex.
"The Jaguars make people feel good about themselves who haven't felt good about themselves in a long time," said James B. Crooks, a local historian who teaches at the University of North Florida.
This visually striking city had already started to clean up its air and water, had leveled its toll booths and had become one of the country's 10 fastest-growing job markets, thanks to the arrival of prestigious businesses like the Mayo Clinic and Merrill Lynch. But the most potent transfusion of pride came on Nov. 30, 1993, when the National Football League announced its decision to place an expansion team in Jacksonville.
Some critics complained that the city gave the team a sweetheart deal by spending more than $100 million on stadium improvements. But the 73,000-seat stadium was quickly sold out, and the city's golf courses and thoroughfares now empty whenever the Jaguars appear on televison. More people greeted the returning Jaguars in Sunday's wee hours than watched many actual football games in Atlanta and Houston this year.
"Self-esteem is a funny thing," said Thomas F. Petway, a minority owner of the Jaguars. "In this instance, I think Jacksonville needed something to call its own, something to rally around."
To a degree probably possible only in the South locals view the essence of the Jaguars' success as a matter of overdue respect.
When a Denver sportswriter, Woody Paige, made the mistake of disrespecting both the Jaguars and their hometown in a game-day column, he incited not only the team but also much of northeastern Florida. "How do you get worked up to play somebody called Jacksonville, with a bunch of nobodies?" he asked.
Jacksonville residents clogged his e-mail with angry rebuttals and painted their car windows with impolite suggestions for Mr. Paige.
How closely linked is the city's image with the Jaguars? Suffice it to say that the newly elected chairman of the Chamber of Commerce is Daniel W. Connell Jr., the senior vice president of marketing for the team. Since the team's arrival, the chamber has been promoting Jacksonville as "the expansion city."
The city has gone Jaguar crazy in the last two weeks. After the Broncos game, Dana Romano, the manager of Authentic Pro Gear, sold nearly 2,000 commemorative T-shirts at $18.99 in just two days. Karen A. Sinclair, a 47-year-old teacher, felt right at home at a sports bar on Monday night wearing a Jaguar-spot blouse, Jaguar-spot earrings, a gold Jaguar choker and a Jaguar pin.
Even those who are normally disinterested in football have become converts. During last Saturday's game, Helene Baker, an artist, found herself watching the Jaguars on a muted television in her studio while listening to a radio broadcast of her favorite opera, "Tosca."
"The next thing I know," Ms. Baker said, "I'm beginning to turn the opera down slowly and turning the TV louder. I finally decided I knew what was going to happen at the end of the opera but I didn't know what was going to happen to the Jaguars, and I turned the radio off."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Job Growth Is Strong, Raising Inflation Fears
Jobs and paychecks grew with unexpected vigor in December, powerful evidence that the economy was gathering fresh momentum as 1996 ended, Labor Department figures showed.
Although the unemployment rate was unchanged at 5.3 percent, the 262,000 jobs created last month were far more than economists had predicted. Analysts said the robust report raised the specter of higher inflation and of a decision by the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates. [Page 1.]

Stocks Rise and Bonds Fall
The employment report sent stock and bond prices down, but only stocks recovered. The Dow Jones industrial average surpassed 6,700 for the first time and notched its fourth record in a week, closing at 6,703.79, up 78.12 points in heavy trading. Other market indexes also set records. The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks rose 4.65 points, to 759.50, and the Nasdaq composite index gained 5.82 points, to 1,332.02. The Dow was down 67 points in early trading, but blue-chip stocks bounced back on what was to become a 150-point turnaround. [47.]

Treasury prices tumbled after the employment report as bond traders took the strong numbers to mean inflation was a greater risk and that the Fed might raise interest rates to counter it. The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond rose to 6.84 percent, from 6.75 percent on Thursday. Interest rates are now nearly a half-point higher than in early December, when indications of economic resurgence first emerged. [47.]

Shares of 2 Drug Companies Fall
Shares of Regeneron Pharmaceuticals and Amgen fell sharply after the companies disclosed that their jointly developed drug for the treatment of Lou Gehrig's disease had failed in clinical trials. [38.]

Breast Implant Settlement Opposed
Stepping up their opposition to Dow Corning's proposal to settle all silicone breast implant claims and other debts, committees representing both the implant claimants and Dow Corning's commercial creditors asked a Federal bankruptcy judge for permission to file a competing payment plan. [9.]
 
Utility Plans to Sell Plants
Massachusetts regulators approved a plan by the New England Electric System, a huge utility in the Northeast, to sell its generating plants and offer customers a choice in buying their electricity by January 1998. [50.]

Airbus in Talks on Jumbo Jet
At least two South Korean companies said they are talking with Airbus Industrie about becoming partners on its jumbo jet project, which is aimed at breaking Boeing's monopoly in large airliners. Spokesmen for the Samsung Aerospace Industries Company and Korean Air said their companies and several others were involved in the talks to build an aircraft capable of carrying 550 passengers. [38.]
 
Fed Governor to Resign
A Federal Reserve governor, Lawrence B. Lindsey, announced that he would resign on Feb. 5, creating a second vacancy on the central bank's board. [38.]
 
A High Price for Seinfeld
The most valuable show in television is about to become the most expensive as "Seinfeld" moves toward a deal with NBC for one more season at a price that could reach as much as
$5 million an episode, by far the highest for any show in television history. But no matter what the price, the network is expected to make a deal because "Seinfeld" is, by every reckoning, NBC's indispensable, irreplaceable program. [11.]

Jobs Report Sends Dollar Higher
The dollar rose against most currencies after robust December employment figures, reinforcing the view that the United States economy is growing while Japan and much of Europe struggle with resilient weakness. [40.]
 
Corn and Soybean Prices Rise
A Government projection of tighter corn and soybean supplies sent futures prices soaring on the Chicago Board of Trade. [40.]

NEW YORK
 
Mayor Raises $1.2 Million
Outpacing his Democratic challengers by nearly two-to-one, Mayor Giuliani has raised nearly $1.2 million for a re-election campaign since July 12. Combined with money he had collected earlier as well as matching funds he will request from the city, his campaign fund totals $8.5 million, aides say. That means that with 11 months until Election Day, the Mayor has almost reached the point where he will be spared the time-consuming obligation of further fund-raising. Under the city campaign finance laws, he is allowed to spend $9.7 million. [Page 27.] 

Seeking Solidarity in Workfare
Traveling through Brooklyn, Sharon Bush distributes forms that authorize her group, known as Acorn, to represent workfare crews in their dealings with the city. "They have rights, but it's degrading how they're treated," she said. "But I never heard one of them say they didn't want to work for their public assistance check." About New York by David Gonzalez. [27.]

Building Better Boardwalks
After a ferocious northeaster raked the New Jersey coast in 1992, some hard-hit towns followed tradition and rebuilt their boardwalks. On Karma and the Environment
It has long been a custom among some Buddhists to liberate animals whose destiny would otherwise involve a lifetime of captivity or worse -- dinner. Setting animals free is considered an act of compassion that will be rewarded with good karma. But to some environmentalists, it is also a practice that threatens native species. [27.]

 BODY:

Hawaiian Hula Festival
Q. Do you have information about a hula-dancing competition in Hawaii in the spring? -- Sheila Miller, Richmond
A. The competition you are probably referring to is the Merrie Monarch Festival, an extremely popular annual event, in which about 30 hula halau, or hula troops, gather in Hilo. Two styles of hula are judged: kahiko (ancient hula) and auana (modern hula). The 1997 Merrie Monarch Festival is scheduled for March 30 to April 5. 
 The competition is one of the grandest hula-dancing spectacles in the world, with kahiko dancers wearing traditional costumes of native plant material, including hau tree bark and ferns, and auana performers in more elaborate apparel, including Victorian-influenced costumes of velvet and feathered hats.
The event, which dates from 1964, is named after the 19th-century "Merrie Monarch" David Kalakaua, the last King of Hawaii. The King was an avid supporter of hula, the ancient Hawaiian tradition that combines dance, legend, religion, story-telling and music.
Besides dancing, there are displays of traditional Hawaiian crafts, a parade and free Hawaiian entertainment (including hula dancing) at various places in Hilo.
The actual competitive performances are staged at Hilo's tennis stadium, which is situated near the Hilo airport, on April 3, 4 and 5. The competition is expected to attract about 6,000 viewers.
Since 1981, tickets have sold out, typically by the end of January or the beginning of February, so you'll want to attain your ticket soon. Prices range from $5 for a single performance to $23 for three nights. Tickets are limited to two per person. To request tickets, send a money order or cashier's check payable to the Merrie Monarch Festival, and a self-addressed stamped evelope to: Merrie Monarch Festival, Hawaii Naniloa Hotel, 93 Banyan Drive, Hilo, Hawaii 96720. Orders will not be taken by telephone. For information, call the Merrie Monarch Festival office, (808) 935-9168.
 
Visiting the Aeolians
Q. Next summer, I will be renting a house on Salina, one of the Aeolian Islands. What is the most efficient and economic way to reach the island? Is there background information I should know? -- Joan Arcari, New York, N.Y.
A. The natural beauty of Salina, the second largest of the Aeolian Islands, is already familiar to those who saw the 1995 Italian movie "Il Postino," which was shot there. The island, with its terraced hillsides, dramatic coastline and a permanent population of less than 3,000, is one of the less popular sites on Italy's tourist trail; indeed Salina's reputation as a tourist spot is probably surpassed by its reputation as a producer of exceptional wine, capers and raisins.
There are three main towns -- Santa Marina Salina, Malfa and Leni -- which are linked by decent roads. Santa Marina, a cluster of small white houses on the east coast, is the largest town. Roman ruins are still visible near the town's beach. In the nearby volcanic grotto of the Saracen, carved altars and Christian emblems indicate the presence of an ancient Christian cult that may have dated to the third century.
From Santa Marina, you can drive to Lingua, on the south coast, and from there drive to the top of the 3,156-foot Monte Fossa delle Felci volcanic crater where you can view the surrounding islands. Monte Fossa delle Felci is one of the island's six inactive volcanoes.
Other sites on the four-mile-long, three-mile-wide island include the Sanctuary of the Madonna del Terzito where, according to tradition, the Madonna appeared on July 23, 1622.
The only way to reach the island is by sea. There are ferries and hydrofoils leaving both Naples and the Sicilian port of Milazzo almost on a daily basis throughout the summer.Last summer, from June 1 to Sept. 3 the SNAV company in Naples operated its hydrofoils daily, departing at 2:30 PM and arriving in Salina at 7:30 P.M. The schedule has yet to be set for next summer. Last summer's one-way tickets cost about $70. Information: (39-81) 761 2348. Another navigation company, Siremar-Agenzia Genovese has daily ferries (excluding Wednesday) departing Naples at 9 P.M. and arriving in Salina at 8:30 A.M. the following day. Tickets cost $78. Prices and schedule are subject to change.
 
Globe Theater Schedule
Q. I will be in London for several weeks next summer, and would like to attend a performance at the Globe Theater. What plays will be performed, and how I may get tickets? -- Louis Schmidt, Seattle
After 10 years of construction, Shakespeare's Globe Theater on London's South Bank at Southwark will open for its first full season next summer. Four plays will be performed in repertory during the 1997 season, two of which will be "Henry V" and "The Winter's Tale." The other two are expected to be announced in February.
The plays will be performed by the Globe Theater Company, consisting of 30 actors, including 4 Americans. Richard Olivier, son of Joan Plowright and the late Lord Olivier, will direct "Henry V" and the Globe's artistic director, Mark Rylance, will play the lead role. David Freeman, associate artist of the English National Opera and founder of the Opera Factory in Sydney, Zurich and London, will direct "The Winter's Tale."
Previews will run from May 27 to June 7. The regular theater season will recommence on June 24 and will run until Sept. 21.
Tickets for the general public will go on sale on March 3. Prices range from $8.50 to $34. Information: (44-171) 401 9919.
The plays will be staged in the new "wooden O" theater, which seats about 1,000, with 500 places for "groundlings" who stand in the open air yard around the stage. The theater's permanent stage and tiring house (the backstage area where actors attire themselves) are still under construction. It is possible to visit the exhibition and tour the theater to see master craftsmen, thatchers and plasterers at work, using 400-year-old techniques and materials. The tours, which are offered throughout the year, cost $8.50. The entire project, which will include a 300-seat indoor theater modeled after a 1617 design by Inigo Jones, a restaurant, shopping area and a Shakespeare exhibition to be housed beneath the complex, is expected to be completed in 1999. SUZANNE MacNEILLE
