HEADLINE: It's Not Easy Being Green

BYLINE: By John Horgan; John Horgan, a senior writer at Scientific American, is the author of "The End of Science."

 BODY:

THE IDEA OF BIODIVERSITY
 Philosophies of Paradise.
 By David Takacs.
 393 pp. Baltimore:
 The Johns Hopkins University Press. $35.95. 
 PRACTITIONERS of science studies are feeling a bit beleaguered these days. These scholars scrutinize scientists as though they were merely members of another tribe, like teen-age mall rats or the Taliban, compelled by their own peculiar cultural influences. Needless to say, some scientists have not taken kindly to this treatment. In recent meetings and books, scientists have denounced science studies as pretentious gibberish at best, and at worst as a left-wing plot to undermine science.
Some science studies invite such criticism simply by choice of topics. There seems little point to probing the cultural soil within which, say, the theory of stellar fusion took root; the salient fact is that the theory is true. But when applied to the right field and carefully done, science studies more than proves its worth. It points the way to a science that is more self-aware and thus more capable of achieving what the philosopher Sandra Harding calls "strong objectivity." "The Idea of Biodiversity" demonstrates the genre's potential. The author, David Takacs, who obtained a joint degree in science studies and environmental science from Cornell University and who now teaches at California State University, Monterey Bay, scrutinizes conservation biology, whose adherents are attempting both to document humanity's destruction of nature and to arrest it. This analysis is timely, coming as it does when an anti-environmental "brownlash" has the green movement on its heels. In the confessional mode that post-modern anthropologists call "I-witnessing," Mr. Takacs emphasizes that his is a biased account. He believes that the questions raised by conservation biologists are the most important facing humanity today, and he shares their passionate love of nature. Yet he also thinks conservation biologists need to be more self-critical, especially since they mix scientific aims -- the discovery of truths about nature -- with political ones.
Early on, he shows how proto-conservation biologists like Aldo Leopold and Rachel Carson placed their facts at the service of their beliefs to persuade society to take better care of nature. He includes extended profiles of Inbio, a Costa Rican preserve that has become a kind of laboratory for testing conservation strategies, and of Edward O. Wilson, who has transformed himself over the last two decades from the dark prince of sociobiology into the archangel of the environmental movement.
But the core of the book consists of Mr. Takacs's interviews with more than a score of conservation biologists, ranging from the tough-talking Cassandra Paul Ehrlich, who has been warning about the dangers of overpopulation for decades, to Thomas Eisner, the St. Francis of bugs. Mr. Takacs asks his sources various questions: What is biodiversity? How should it best be protected? Can science achieve complete objectivity? Then he ponders the responses. His goal is not to play "Gotcha!" or to flaunt his own cleverness, as some scurrilous science critics do, but to reveal tensions and contradictions that he believes should be recognized, if not resolved. He shows, for example, how Mr. Wilson, Mr. Eisner and others manufactured the buzzword "biodiversity" during the 1980's to serve their political ends. The word conveys much the same meaning as "nature" or "wildlife" but adds a glossy scientific sheen. As Mr. Takacs puts it, the term "is a tool for a zealous defense of a particular social construction of nature."
Unfortunately, as science evolves, the meaning of such terms may change in ways that are not always politically expedient. Ecologists once implied that nature exists in a state of equilibrium and harmony disrupted only by human intervention, but they now depict nature as dynamic, mutable; it is a process rather than a collection of things. This shift in perspective has spurred a debate over whether the Endangered Species Act should be abandoned for a more "holistic" approach that focuses on "habitats" or "ecosystems" rather than on individual species. But as one biologist notes drily, ecosystems "have no big, brown eyes to endear themselves to the public." Environmentalists are also deeply divided over the degree to which their programs should respect the cultures of indigenous people, and all people, for that matter. Some advocate policies -- such as mandatory birth control and restrictions on the rights of Indians to convert jungle into farmland -- that would sharply curtail human diversity.
One of Mr. Takacs's central concerns is the increasingly popular proposal that preserving biodiversity makes economic sense; a nameless weed or beetle in that patch of threatened rain forest may contain an enzyme that can cure cancer or the common cold. Some biologists admit that they adopt this argument not because they believe it, but because it helps to enlist governments and companies in the cause. Mr. Takacs fears that if the claims are shown to be exaggerated, they may backfire. Moreover, he writes, "these economic arguments allow the hubristic, violent way we treat the earth to continue."
"The Idea of Biodiversity" does not have the flair of, say, one of Mr. Wilson's lyrical polemics. I wish Mr. Takacs had reworked his manuscript once more to prune redundancies and jargon. (Stephen Hawking once said that every formula in a science book reduces its potential readership by half; surely the same is true of the awful word "normative," which Mr. Takacs and other academics unaccountably find irresistible.)
Mr. Takacs beats some rather obvious points to death -- like the squishiness of such terms as "biodiversity" and "nature" -- and the long, unedited excerpts from his interviews become wearying at times. On the other hand, the rawness of the material allows -- even invites -- readers to draw their own conclusions rather than merely to submit to those presented by Mr. Takacs. My own reading left me rather ambivalent. Although I try to color myself green, I was disturbed by the self-righteousness and absolutism of conservationists like Hugh Iltis, who declares we must do all we can to save every species on earth. This goal seems neither realistic nor reasonable. I'm delighted that my children do not encounter wolves in our backyard, or elephants, or malaria, as inhabitants of less developed regions do. The declaration that "biodiversity is good" recalls the antiwar axiom that "nuclear war is bad." No sane person would disagree with either sentiment. Contention arises when one considers how these values should be reconciled with others, like our desire for freedom or comfort or consumer products. And, as David Takacs shows, knowing how to balance these competing values can be extremely difficult.
That said, I'm not sure I agree with Mr. Takacs that conservation biologists should spend more time examining their motives and assumptions. Would the world really be better off if eco-warriors like Mr. Ehrlich or Mr. Wilson began indulging in Hamlet-style introspection, given that their opponents are hardly likely to do the same? In some areas of science, as in the law, the adversary system may be a necessary evil.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 10; Column 1; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1062 words

HEADLINE: Where the Money Is

BYLINE: By Peter Passell; Peter Passell writes about economics for The New York Times.

 BODY:

THE BANKERS
 The Next Generation.
 By Martin Mayer.
 514 pp. New York:
 Truman Talley Books/Dutton. $29.95. 
 Martin Mayer isn't just a business writer, he's a phenomenon. He has churned out a slew of popular nonfiction books about money and the people who rake it in. And hardly a month goes by without some smart, tart opinion piece appearing under his byline. Moreover, he apparently thinks he can do just about anything well, and he's gone a long way toward proving it.
He has published three novels, including a thriller and a political potboiler. He has analyzed social studies curriculums for the American Council of Learned Societies and was chairman of a district school board in New York City. He has dabbled at television criticism, and crossed party lines to serve as a member of Ronald Reagan's National Commission on Housing. And he has still found the time to write about music, currently serving as the New York critic for Opera magazine in London.
"The Bankers: The Next Generation," written from his perch as a guest scholar at the Brookings Institution, is nominally an update of his 1975 best seller. In fact, it is an excuse for Mr. Mayer to share his latest erudite, witty and only occasionally jargon-choked observations about the industry that makes the world go round.
Mr. Mayer understands that banking is not everyone's cup of tea. So he laces the dreary parts with oddball facts and believe-it-or-not history. Between lessons on how the payments system underpins capitalism, we learn that Chief Justice Salmon P. Chase (as in the Chase bank) decided to give Ulysses S. Grant a break, deferring a ruling that paper currency was unconstitutional until the President had a chance to pack the Supreme Court with friendly faces. That A. P. Giannini, founder of the Bank of America, lent money to Walt Disney to make the first animated feature, "Snow White," over the protests of the banker's brother and son. That thousands of people who challenged their credit card bills from Macy's in its last days before bankruptcy walked away without paying.
By the same token, Mr. Mayer never hesitates to digress on the trail of a delicious put-down. When Darla Moore, a vice president of Chemical Bank, was told by the octogenarian Prentice Hale of the Carter Hawley Hale department stores, "You are unlike any banker I have ever met. So lovely -- and bright," she replied, "There are lots of lovely girls at Chemical Bank, and we're all bright."
Or take Jimmy Lee, a superstar at the Chase Bank, on why it's still necessary to schmooze the corporate clients in an era of whiz-kid deal making: "People don't do business with you because you're a geek and you can do regressions in your head. They come to do business with you because they like you."
Nor does Mr. Mayer pass up opportunities to dish the high and mighty. We discover that Leo Melamed, the child of Yiddish teachers who created the financial futures markets, "made his first real money in the pork-bellies pit." And we are reminded that Alan Greenspan, keeper of the nation's money supply, was once a devotee of Ayn Rand. "I have a precious copy of a truly nutty piece he wrote for her magazine," Mr. Mayer says, and he cannot resist quoting from it: "In the absence of the gold standard, there is no way to protect savings from confiscation through inflation. . . . This is the shabby secret of the welfare statists' tirades against gold."
But the meat and potatoes of "The Bankers" is often so satisfying that the fancy plating is a lagniappe. Mr. Mayer devotes a hefty chapter to the 1995 fiasco of Barings Bank, in which the 233-year-old, oh-so-British institution was brought down by Nicholas Leeson, a 27-year-old clerk newly promoted to trader in its Singapore office. While the story has been told before, nobody tells it more archly.
It seems that Mr. Leeson was supposed to be "arbitraging" differences in prices between very similar securities traded on the Singapore, Osaka and Tokyo exchanges. The idea, reduced to essentials, was to buy the cheap version and sell the expensive one, locking in a profit at the end of each trading day. But Barings, for all its blue blood, was very green in the trading of the synthetic securities (called derivatives) that have made it possible for bankers to bet on practically anything from the difference on the interest paid on United States Treasury bills and bonds to the number of eggs it will take to buy a share of each stock in the Dow Jones Transportation Index. And nobody in London -- not the directors of Barings, not the stuffed shirts at its regulator, the Bank of England -- bothered to ask why Mr. Leeson was borrowing money, until he was in the hole to the tune of $1.1 billion, or twice the bank's net worth.
Even more impressive is the account of America's $300 billion savings-and-loan debacle, whose causes Mr. Mayer probably understands as well as anyone on the planet. He traces the disaster from its origins in the irresponsible decision of the state of California to let the thrifts lend money to real estate hustlers to the appointment of Danny Wall, a former architect without a lick of knowledge about banking, as the chief S. & L. regulator. Thus, while most commentators have focused on the bounders, Mr. Mayer sees the story primarily as one of bad government -- of "the systematic, sometimes ignorant and sometimes deliberate misdiagnosis of the disease that was wasting the business, and the administration of quack remedies in response."
But certainly the most original analysis in this book is of the revolution in banking that is being driven by technology. Mr. Mayer explains how credit cards, automated teller machines, electronic funds transfers, Internet transactions and "smart cards" that substitute for money are eroding the ground under the financial establishment and turning banking into a competitive free-for-all. The promise: $40 billion in annual savings in the United States alone. The worry: a global payments system that is beyond the capacity of governments to understand, let alone regulate wisely.
"The Bankers" can be heavy going for the uninitiated. But that's just Mr. Mayer showing off. Follow his usually delightful ramble though the board rooms and byways of high finance, and you'll learn more about banking than you ever thought you wanted to know.

SECTION: Section 5; Page 4; Column 5; Travel Desk 

LENGTH: 1195 words

HEADLINE: PRACTICAL TRAVELER;
Generations On the Move

BYLINE: By BETSY WADE 

 BODY:
INTERGENERATIONAL travel sounds a bit like intergalactic travel, and in some ways it may be that far out: grandparents and grandchildren who may not know each other well set out on a trip to an unfamiliar place, often where the language is unknown.
The combination of 55-plus and 17-minus, while not nearly so common as family travel -- parents traveling with their children -- has grown in importance in the last 10 years. Its increase is linked to the large number of children of divorce and of families in which both parents work outside the home, leaving little time for vacations. The increase in the number of grandparents who retire before 65 also means there are more active people who can handle vacationing children and who may be better able to pay the bills. 
 The rub with intergenerational travel is that grandparent and grandchild may live far apart and almost certainly have different life styles. Custody decisions may mean that a grandparent is seldom even discussed. Turning these relatives into roommates for 10 or 14 nights is not accomplished by benevolence and money alone.
Dr. Robert P. McCaffery of the Familyhostel program, which operates summer overseas trips for adults and children related to them, warns that 24-hour-a-day togetherness can sour fast. Travel in groups, he says, provides time for adults to take a break while the children are involved in other activities.
"Children need to relate to children," said Helena T. Koenig, the owner of Grandtravel in Washington. "There is only so much beauty you can impart to a child at once."
Both of these group travel sponsors provide time for children to be with children, particularly at the end of the day, and to get vigorous exercise. Dr. McCaffery said that his organization had tested staying in suburbs to provide more space, or perhaps a pool at the hotel, but discovered that the travelers still preferred the convenience of lodgings downtown for urban destinations.
The Familyhostel program was spun off by the University of New Hampshire, sponsor of Interhostel. For this seventh year, it is offering six 10-day educational trips for grandparents or parents -- sometimes both -- and children 8 to 15 years old. The maximum group is 40 people; the minimum is 17.
The trips are to Provence and Paris; Paris and Normandy; Vienna; Switzerland; Wales and London. The adult prices range from $1,925 to $2,975; for the children, from $1,665 to $2,895, all with air fare included, in multiple-occupancy rooms. Familyhostel, 6 Garrison Avenue, Durham, N.H. 03824; (800) 733-9753 or (603) 862-1147.

Worldwide Destinations
Grandtravel is offering 17 tours this year. When Ms. Koenig created this company in 1987 as a division of the Ticket Counter, her Chevy Chase, Md., travel agency, she offered a trip to Washington, one to the Southwest and a safari to Kenya. She still has these three, plus the 14 others, most with two departure dates. Although the recession a few years ago brought a patch of no growth -- Grandtravel's offerings are expensive -- Ms. Koenig says that as she has added trips, they have continued to fill with her usual maximum of 26.
Other Grandtravel offerings are in the Pacific Northwest, the Grand Canyon, Montana, Wyoming and South Dakota; Hawaii; Ireland, England and Scotland, London and Paris; the French countryside; Italy; Munich, Salzburg, Vienna and Prague; Spain and Australia. The cost for nine nights in Hawaii, without air fare, is $4,590 for an adult in a double, $4,380 for a child. Grand travel, 6900 Wisconsin Avenue, Suite 706, Chevy Chase, Md. 20815; (800) 247-7651; (301) 986-0790.
Both Familyhostel and Interhostel use teachers as escorts. "We thought we wanted experts in the area or the material," Dr. McCaffery, a historian, said, "but we really needed the middle-school or elementary teacher who knew the kids' span of attention and level of understanding."
In the pure adventure category is a high-priced company, Rascals in Paradise, a division of Adventure Express in San Francisco. It is in its 10th year of "distinctive family vacations," with yacht charters in Turkey and Tahiti and trips to Africa, Hawaii, Alaska and Australia. The adults are more often parents than grandparents, but grandparents who enjoy things like scuba diving will find opportunities here. The prices are still being set, but as an example, a Tahiti charter for up to eight people is quoted at $2,090 a day. Rascals in Paradise, 650 Fifth Street, Suite 505, San Francisco, Calif. 94107; (800) 872-7225 or (415) 978-9800.
Ms. Koenig's typical clients are a grandmother and a child whose parents are divorced. Sometimes two grandparents will take two children. The overall boy-girl ratio is 50-50, although some trips attract more of one sex than the other.
The Grandtravel ages are 7 to 17, and often one departure of a trip will be designed for the 7 to 11's, the other for 12 to 17's. Grandtravel has booked grandchildren going up in steps in succeeding years; younger children may hear from older ones and want the same trip exactly.

Establishing Who's Boss
Whether inside the rather firm structure provided by an intergenerational tour or moving at will, the travel companions need to reach basic agreements early on.
It must be established who is in charge. "Once it's clear that it is to be done Grandma's way," Ms. Koe nig said, "then everything falls into place." At the packing stage, for example, if a child resists taking a raincoat, the parent says that the raincoat must be packed because otherwise it will be too much stress for the grandparent. Rules about leaving the group and getting permission for certain things need to be made clear.
The "days at leisure" found so frequently in itineraries for adults are not found in intergenerational schedules. Grandfather may be buckling, but the kids are still going like Energizer bunnies.
Helen Richer of Laguna Hills, Calif., who took her 15-year-old grandson, Ian Richer, to Japan in 1991 on a conventional escorted tour, did not use the word stress, but said, "You take on a huge responsibility." She said she offered Ian a trip anywhere he wanted because her husband had recently died, she wanted to resume traveling, and Ian is her oldest grandchild. She had never been to Japan, and it was expensive -- $10,000 for the two of them -- but Ian loved the trip, and was always the first off the bus with his camera. Only one other child, a boy of 13, was along.
On Grandtravel tours, no child stays in a room without an adult, so the issue of how late the light or television stays on is to be resolved by the grandparent and grandchild. Mrs. Richer was usually ready to turn in by evening, so often her grandson did exploring on his own, with a card in hand bearing the hotel name and address in Japanese.
Ms. Koenig said that grandparents needed to realize that "it is no longer a crisis when a child misses a meal." When Mrs. Richer and Ian craved familiar food, they went together to McDonald's.
What do the grandparents get from the trip? "They are energized, they come alive." Ms. Koenig said. "They have that responsibility again."

 BODY:
An article on Dec. 29 about the closing of the American Velvet Company in Stonington referred incorrectly to the difference in labor costs at its mills in Connecticut and Virginia. Unemployment compensation alone is 20 times as high in Connecticut as in Virginia; it is not all personnel costs that are 20 times as high.
A picture caption with the article also misidentified a worker inspecting sheets of velvet. She was Carla Leandro, not Maria Amaral.

195 of 669 DOCUMENTS

Copyright 1997 The New York Times Company 
The New York Times

 

PUB-DATE: January 12, 1997

SECTION: Section 2; Page 45; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk 

LENGTH: 1605 words

HEADLINE: ARCHITECTURE VIEW;
A Crystal Palace of Culture and Commerce

BYLINE: By Herbert Muschamp 

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
JAPAN'S NEW TOKYO International Forum is such a perfectly realized building that you may actually find yourself hoping that a flaw will turn up. Everything about this complex of theaters and convention halls has been thought through with precision. The only thing it can be faulted for is a pursuit of excellence so unyielding that it seems to not quite deserve a place in our world of scintillating compromise.
Designed by the New York architect Rafael Vinoly, the $1.5 billion Forum opened on Friday. His design was selected in 1989 from among 395 entries in Japan's first international competition. The architect may be best known in the United States for the sports center at Lehman College in the Bronx (his most important New York project to date). A current project is the design for a new sports stadium for Princeton University to replace Palmer Stadium. 
 Vinoly's design for the monumental Forum flies in the face of architectural history, or at least runs against the current preoccupations of many leading contemporary architects. It is lucid, whole and completely straightforward, qualities that have not enjoyed wide favor in architecture for some time. A text is not needed to comprehend it. It does not speak in codes. Some will call it modern, but it is a tribute to this building's strength that one wants to protect it from standard appellations of style and taste. In a lecture, Vinoly once said that architecture is "an art of dealing with heaviness," and that is what you get here: a feat of creativity in which floors, ceilings and walls have been made to soar.
The Forum occupies a privileged site in the heart of Tokyo, steps away from the city's main train station and a five-minute walk from the Imperial Palace Gardens. Though built with private money, the Forum is a civic, indeed a national, symbol, a monument to Japan's global economic power.
It is a hybrid building: a place where concerts and other performing arts events will take place amid trade fairs and conventions: Lincoln Center crossed with the Javits Center, in effect. Americans can be discomforted by the mixing of culture and commerce, but in Japan, the most progressive art is typically displayed in department stores. There's nothing contrary about a building that brings Kabuki, Beethoven and cars together under the same roof.
And what a roof! Hagia Sophia, the Guggenheim Museum and Grand Central Terminal have a new cousin. By day a glittering crystal, at night a glowing lantern, the Forum's Glass Hall joins the ranks of the world's great spaces. Like some lighter-than-air vessel, the hall's shipshape roofing slices through the Tokyo cityscape. The atrium roof of metal and glass was designed in collaboration with the structural engineer Kunio Watanabe. It is wonderful to see that even in a built-up contemporary city, a strong horizontal arc can become a landmark as emphatically as a skyscraper.
As you approach, the Forum divides itself into two structures joined by a public plaza. The Glass Hall rises on one side, tapering to a blade-sharp corner at both ends. On the other side, the Forum's four main meeting halls occupy a graduated row of gray concrete cubes. The plaza is actually more like a two-blocklong pedestrian promenade. Beautifully landscaped and furnished with seating, the plaza is meant to be an oasis for office workers in the financial district nearby. The visual effect of this outdoor space is of a man-made ravine, a portage between rippling glass reflections and a cliff of faceted gray stone.
You will want to go into the Glass Hall immediately, but first you ought to look at the fire stairs set between the concrete cubes. These are the Rolex of fire stairs, immaculately engineered cascades of open-mesh steel that rise without a crude or wasted motion. If you climb a flight or two of them, you will get the key to the whole building.
It's almost unheard of for architects today to devote themselves to this level of detail. We pretend not to mind, because if we did we'd go crazy. We accept that architects develop concepts, sketches, drawings and models, and then hand the project over to an "associated" firm to create the physical object in space. Here we're dealing with a radically different economy of mind. The bolt beneath our feet emerged from the same esthetic intelligence that conceived the space around it. An architect is making architecture, and we almost can't stand it. It is dizzying to realize that excellence is a polite term for obsession.
And these are just the back stairs. Officially, people arriving to attend functions at the forum will enter from the opposite side, facing the street. Once inside, you grasp that Vinoly has chosen to celebrate Japan's power with a lavish display of the country's scarcest commodity: space. There hasn't been a spatial sweep like this since the Paris Opera House: wide lobbies with floors of white glass illuminated from below lead to escalator banks of such glamour that you may have to squelch the impulse to ride them twice. Or give into it. At the top of the escalators are mezzanines with glass walls that look out to the plaza and back down to the entrance lobbies. The play of reflections infinitely expands the interior's already sizable three dimensions.
The Forum's four meeting halls are misnamed. They go by letters of the alphabet and ought to start out small, but Hall D is the smallest. This is a screening room intended mostly for showing movies about Tokyo and Japan to foreign visitors. Black leather seats, luxurious darkness. Hall C is the gem of the lot, startlingly warm in the midst of so much glass, steel and concrete, a resonant interior of wood, related to the rest of the building by the rectilinear geometry of the sculptured walls. The impression is of being inside a Cubist violin.
Hall B is a banquet hall, a showplace for the wedding reception that went to heaven but still in the end a banquet hall, its impressively high ceilings functionally justified by the hot air destined to rise nightly from the rostrum. Hall A: Unimaginably huge, said to be Japan's largest theater. Kabuki time. Ice-skating spectaculars. Madonna. Michael Jackson. The walls here, too, are of illuminated glass, set at mind-bending angles that make you feel giddy but somehow bring the last row closer to the stage. The point is, it all works.
Now go into the Glass Hall. The moment of entrance recalls a visitor's first sight of the upper chapel of Ste.-Chapelle. The Glass Hall is not a church, and this is 20th-century Japan, not 13th-century France. But this is as good as space gets without age and religion to mold its character. And the sense of it is Gothic: just two slim columns support the skeletal frame from which the structure is hung. The impression is of watching trapeze artists at work within the world's largest marquise diamond.
THE AWESOME IMPRESSION isn't solely due to the hall's height and transparency. It also comes from the discovery that a transparent object can hold so much surprise.
Just inside the entrance, the floor drops away from ground level to reveal the third major component of the Forum: an underground exposition hall that runs nearly the full length of the site. The plaza is this hall's roof. In a master stroke of space craft, what appeared to be solid ground is flattened into a thin horizontal plane. Conference rooms for the conventioneers are ranged in rows along the wall opposite the plaza. Like the entire hall these spaces muffle the noise from the curving train tracks from which the hall takes it shape.
The Forum has been criticized by Japanese architects. They are careful to point out that what bothers them is not the building's design but its commercial function in the center of the city. The Tokyo Forum went up around the same time as a new museum of contemporary art, a building on Tokyo's outskirts. Arata Isozaki, Japan's leading architect, among others, thinks that the locations should have been reversed. He regards the Forum as the symbol of Japan's bloated bubble economy.
Isozaki's view is part of the soul-searching going on throughout Japan today following the bubble's collapse. But the Tokyo Forum is a very bad symbol of the excesses of the bubble economy. Not even Tadao Ando has produced a building with greater moral and esthetic integrity. And it's that rigor, I suspect, that disturbs some architects.
This is an absolutist building. The scrupulousness of Vinoly's detailing and the clarity of his esthetic are of a piece. It has the authority of a True Faith. And we're not supposed to believe in that concept anymore. We're supposed to be allergic to the sort of canons laid down by the modern movement.
And yet this building possesses none of the shortcomings for which modernist buildings were faulted. It is not visually impoverished. It does not lack delight. No major public building designed by a post-modern architect is as elegant or as full of surprise. Walking through it, you don't even think "modernism," "functionalism" or "machines for living." You think about George Balanchine. Or a thoroughbred race horse. Or ancient Greece. You think about physical poise.
Perhaps this building's disturbing power is that it challenges the True Faith of relativism, pluralism and the mediocrities that those beliefs have sent spinning in the world. It upholds a belief in reason that predates the modern movement. It is 18th century, not 20th, in its outlook, and the outlook is fine. The enduring value of European Enlightenment: that is what's right about Vinoly's contribution to modern Japan.

HEADLINE: CLASSICAL MUSIC;
A Maestro Takes Fond Leave of an Old Love

BYLINE: By JAMES R. OESTREICH 

DATELINE: LEIPZIG, Germany

 BODY:
EVEN IN NEW YORK, THE 6 foot-3-inch figure of Kurt Masur looms large. Just ask the members of the New York Philharmonic, who have toiled in his shadow for the last five and a half years. Mr. Masur's diminutive Japanese wife, Tomoko Sakurai, and her family call him the Elephant and give him elephant tchotchkes. But in Leipzig, a storied cultural capital, where memories of Bach and Mendelssohn, Goethe and Schiller have been fitfully preserved, Mr. Masur is regarded as a peer among giants, and his physical size is only a part of his stature.
"He is a great personality, a good human being," said a taxi driver here who, having learned that his passenger was a music critic, was eager to discuss Mr. Masur's most recent concert. 
 He is known everywhere. Museum administrators rush to welcome him, waiving admission fees despite his protestations. Autograph hunters besiege him in restaurants. Heads follow him on the street. A commanding "Masur here" on the telephone is enough to make a baggage tracer at the airport leap into action if not necessarily produce results.
It is against this backdrop of esteem, even love, that Mr. Masur, now 69, begins to sever his ties to the city to concentrate his energies more fully in New York. "To these people, he is like Michael Jordan in the States," said the American tenor John Aler, who recently joined Mr. Masur and the Gewandhaus Orchestra in Beethoven's Ninth Symphony.
Year-end performances of that work are traditional in Leipzig, where Schiller wrote his "Ode to Joy," which is used in its choral finale. The legendary maestro Arthur Nikisch set the precedent on New Year's Eve, 1918, with a concert in the name of peace and freedom, causes that were highly charged at the time.
The four performances this season took on added significance as Mr. Masur's official farewell to the Gewandhaus, a 253-year-old orchestral association named for the fabric trading house it came to occupy in 1781. In his 26-year tenure as Kapellmeister, he raised the orchestra to new levels of execution and spurred construction of a magnificent new concert hall in 1981. He also thrust the institution into the center of the city's -- indeed, the nation's -- consciousness with his role as a mediator in the peaceful revolution of 1989, which led to the reunification of Germany and a variety of unforeseen consequences, not all of them good.
Since becoming music director of the New York Philharmonic in 1991, Mr. Masur has divided his time equally between the two organizations in alternating three-week periods. But he gave his last performance as Kapellmeister of the Gewandhaus on New Year's Eve. At its end, he was named the orchestra's honorary conductor in an emotional ceremony on stage, and he gave his first performance in that capacity on New Year's Day. Then he quietly handed his master key for the building, which he had conceived and ruled in virtually every detail, to his deft and devoted assistant, Christa Heyner.
If ever a mere human faced the daunting task of replacing an institution, it is the Swedish conductor Herbert Blomstedt, formerly of the San Francisco Symphony, who will conduct the Beethoven concerts at the Gewandhaus next December and take over as Kapellmeister in 1998. Mr. Masur, meanwhile, will maintain a presence in the city and tend to its cultural legacy in ways that he outlined in a series of leisurely conversations. In particular, he will continue his campaign to rehabilitate Mendelssohn's house and reinforce his reputation, emulating Mendelssohn's own activities in the city a century and a half ago on behalf of Bach.
BUT HERE BEETHOVEN was the concern, and Mr. Masur's performance of the Ninth Symphony on New Year's Eve, attended by many of his family members, friends and colleagues, and televised in the region, was especially powerful, with the conductor holding the audience in stunned silence for half a minute at its end. At the big statement of Schiller's phrase "All men will become brothers under your gentle wing," Mr. Masur opened the music out in an expansive, bearlike embrace.
"I was never only conducting music," Mr. Masur said in a reminiscent mood in his bright, spacious corner office at the Gewandhaus. "I always thought that we musicians have a role which is much more meaningful. We can make people understand each other. We can make people understand that on the other side of the world there is also culture."
Mr. Masur was certainly more than a conductor in the events of 1989. By his account, a resistance movement had been building in East Germany for a decade, eventually including 70 percent of the population. In Leipzig, it centered on Monday evening peace prayers in the historic Nikolaikirche, or St. Nicholas Church.
On Oct. 9, after a weekend during which the Government had flexed its repressive muscles in Dresden and Berlin, it mounted a show of force in Leipzig, complete with army tanks and water trucks full of tear gas. A group of concerned citizens including Mr. Masur -- the Leipzig Six, as they came to be known -- met at his house and formulated a plea for calm and order and a promise to hold public discussions. Mr. Masur read the statement over a loudspeaker system covering the entire center of the city. In response, some 70,000 demonstrators mustered peacefully outside the Gewandhaus at concert time, carrying candles and chanting Mr. Masur's name.
"They only made me a kind of hero because it was my voice that read the message," said Mr. Masur, who for a time was touted as a possible Presidential candidate, a notion he denies ever having seriously entertained.
"Even the soldiers retreated, and not a window was broken," he added. "No one could have believed that this would be a signal for the whole country."
NOR COULD ANYONE IN East Germany have anticipated the myriad effects of sudden reunification with the West and a return to a free-market economy. The unified Government, which has yet to unite the country spiritually, missed a golden opportunity, Mr. Masur explained, sounding like the politician he professes not to be. For the good of the nation and the region, it could have allowed the former East Germany to continue supplying Eastern European countries, which had come to depend on its production. Instead, fearing that bad old attitudes and alliances might linger, it shut industries down.
As a result, Leipzig has become a poor city again, Mr. Masur noted as he revisited old haunts, his and those of historic luminaries. Its population has shrunk from 500,000 to 400,000 in recent years, he said, with young people fleeing in droves. Although the cranes and scaffolding of new construction and reconstruction are everywhere, the unemployment rate is 17 percent.
Things could be worse, of course. Mr. Masur vividly described the last great wave of deprivation and reconstruction in the city, after it had been bombed out in World War II. Born in Brieg, Silesia (now in Poland), in 1927, he came here in 1946 to study at the conservatory. Heat and food were scarce, and the students took their teachers lumps of coal as partial payment, he said. But spirits were often high, as he and his fellows played in swing clubs and discovered a wheat beer that could keep them drunk for three days running. Even the new political regime inspired optimism for a time.
What seems to disturb him most now are cavalier and Philistine attitudes emanating from the West. After so many years of despair produced by Stalinism and its aftermath, the recent burst of optimism has already faded. Under a new lord mayor from the West, the city has come to treat its wondrous cultural legacy as a burden, said Mr. Masur, who has become one of its prime spokesmen and defenders.
He had intended to leave the Gewandhaus after its 250th-anniversary season, in 1994, he explained, but he agreed to stay through last year to continue fighting for the institution, as the Government withdrew a subsidy of $1.3 million. "There was a great danger for the Gewandhaus to be reduced to just another local orchestra," he said. He even considered staying on until Mr. Blomstedt's arrival next year, but he found the terms offered by the city demeaning and decided to call it quits.
"Masur is a figure inextricably linked with musical life in Leipzig," said Georg Christoph Biller, the latest successor to Bach here as cantor of the Thomaskirche, which, along with the Leipzig Opera, is also served by the 187-member Gewandhaus Orchestra. "He has come to symbolize the integration of its various aspects, for he studied here and his artistic biography is closely tied to the city. He means very much to the Leipzig tradition, which also means very much to him, and he gives it direction. His departure will be a serious loss."
Although Mr. Masur plans to spend more time in New York now, he and his wife, a professional soprano and former violist, are keeping their rambling house here, complete with a Japanese-style garden and a heated outdoor swimming pool. His pet project at the moment is the reconstruction of the house Mendelssohn used to live in.
The building is now "in criminal condition," he said, and a quick tour gave confirmation. But he had just coaxed $650,000 out of city coffers and a commitment of $2 million more, leaving another $650,000 to be raised privately. Work is well under way, and a Mendelssohn festival is planned around the reopening of the house as a museum in November.
"What you very often hear in this city," Mr. Masur said, "is: 'We have to care for Bach. He is more famous than Mendelssohn.' And I become furious about that crazy, stupid idea. For Leipzig, Bach was important only 100 years after he died. Even then, the ministers wouldn't let his music be performed in the Thomaskirche until they discovered that Bach brought the people into the church. But Mendelssohn was important here during his lifetime."
Indeed, Bach was largely forgotten in Leipzig until Mendelssohn himself took up his cause, conducting the "St. Matthew Passion" in the Thomaskirche in 1841 and erecting a monument two years later. (That monument, dominated by its pedestal, is not to be confused with the more familiar statue, installed early in this century near the Thomaskirche.) In addition to founding the city's conservatory, in 1843, and enriching musical life with his adventurous programming as Kapellmeister of the Gewandhaus, Mendelssohn was largely responsible for instilling the historical sensibility to which Mr. Masur has fallen heir.
Now the Thomaskirche, like so many of Leipzig's treasures, is run down, and restoration stalled recently when city funds ran out. One end is anomalously clean. "We like the other part better," Mr. Masur said, "because it is nice and old."
Still, for all his attentions to Mendelssohn, Mr. Masur is by no means insensitive to the cause of Bach. In February 1998, he will expand on his already distinguished series of Bach performances with the New York Philharmonic by importing the choir of the Thomaskirche, for its first appearance in the United States. And to judge from performances heard here, that group of young men and boys may be finer now than when it was led by a ceaselessly harassed and frustrated Bach.
So now the Philharmonic has Mr. Masur's full attention, and it is a house in at least slight disarray: a project for a man ever in search of one. After reports of grumbling among the players a few years ago, Mr. Masur recently crossed swords with the management.
"We still have to find each other in the kind of openness and communication which I believe is necessary," Mr. Masur said, choosing his words more carefully than he sometimes has. "We have had difficulties and different ideas, and this is dangerous, especially if someone is accused of not understanding box-office needs because he is not American.
"It limits your fantasy to ask first, 'Does it sell?' and only second, 'Is this what the New York Philharmonic wants to bring out?' We have to find a way that we all have the same direction in mind."
When Mr. Masur took over the Philharmonic, he disclosed hopes, perhaps a bit naive, that the orchestra could achieve a kind of centrality in the life of its city comparable to that of the Gewandhaus in Leipzig. He has made strides and envisions others, still hoping to install something like the summer London Proms concerts in the Seventh Regiment Armory on the East Side of Manhattan. Still, with the differences between the cities, a situation like that in Leipzig was probably never possible in New York.
It may be too bad, because to see Mr. Masur sweep all before him here to good effect is to realize that New York has yet to see the full measure of the man.

HEADLINE: OUT OF ORDER;
Oh, How I Missed Long Island

BYLINE: By DAVID BOUCHIER; David Bouchier of Wading River is an essayist and commentator heard regularly on public radio.

 BODY:
I AM still in recovery from our trip to Florida over the holidays.
Just three hours from MacArthur Airport, we arrived on what might have been an alien planet. 
Driving the rental car out of the futuristic bowels of Tampa International, we found ourselves on a wide, almost empty highway lined with palm trees. The sun blazed down out of a blue sky. The air-conditioner had to be found and switched on.
Adults were seen strolling in public places, wearing shorts. If it had not been for the reassuring landscape of signs that said 7-Eleven, Burger King, Pizza Hut, McDonald's and so on, we might have panicked and taken the next flight back to Islip.
Our destination, the City of St. Petersburg Beach, added to the feeling of unreality. The beach is dominated by a grandiose pink castle in the Moorish taste called the Don Cesar Hotel.
None of the hotels along the beach conform to the standard Long Island pattern. They are shaped like birthday cakes, rocket ships or illustrations from geometry textbooks. When we arrived at our room, in a hotel shaped like a chef's hat, we stepped onto a balcony that overlooked the beach, which curved away brilliant and white in both directions.
Inadequately dressed young women were strolling on the sand. Bronzed youths were out in the ocean, windsailing and roaring around on power skis.
This was glamour! We had escaped from the mundane world of cold and sleet, overflowing cesspools and long delays at Exit 48.
It seemed right to begin the vacation with a sophisticated meal. We dressed with some care. But the hotel restaurant had a large sign that said, "Any Apparel Acceptable," and the customers had taken that seriously.
This was not the trendy New York dining crowd. This was "The Muppet Show" in human form. The menu had four tired dishes -- chicken, fish, meat and pasta -- and two wines, red and white.
Obviously we had not hit the precisely right spot for a glamorous beachfront meal. But that evening we decided to experience the high point of St. Petersburg Beach nightlife, the revolving bar on top of the tower.
Alas, the revolving bar was tired and tacky, and it creaked uneasily as it turned. Gloomy waitresses, bulging out of their miniskirts, delivered watery drinks at astronomical prices.
A four-piece band played in the center, rising to ear-splitting volume as our revolving table passed them and then mercifully faded away. The advertised sunset spectacular was somewhat eclipsed by the view from the other side, an all-night beachwear store lighted in such brilliant green and yellow neon that it put the sunset to shame.
The glamour of Florida was beginning to wear a bit thin. But any graduate of Travel and Tourism 101 will say glamour is all in the mind. Its called "the Trump effect," and it works only at a distance. As soon as you go there and do it yourself, the glamour evaporates like a snowball in the microwave.
But if it works so well for the Florida State Tourist Board, surely we can make it work for us here?
Half the citizens of Long Island flee to Florida every winter, taking money and business with them. How can we make Floridians abandon their comfortable style of life and visit Long Island in the dead of winter?
The Florida travel brochures suggest several strategies. Like any tourist promoter, we have to emphasize the positive and eliminate the negative. First, the absence of Walt Disney World will be a big plus.
Almost everybody who goes to Florida feels obliged and blackmailed to spend a small fortune visiting that fabled plastic wonderland.
Come to Long Island, and you can put that money in the bank and watch television instead. We do have at least minimal dress codes in most of our restaurants. So you will not have the impression of dining in the circus commissary.
And our bars do not revolve, although some customers may think so. Visitors can have quiet drinks without enduring alternating views of, say, Hempstead, Levittown, Uniondale and Westbury.
Our beaches in winter are not crowded with annoyingly slender women and bronzed young athletes who make us all feel old. Our beaches are delightfully empty and quiet at this time of year, and they can be enjoyed in peace by anyone who remembers to take along Arctic exploration gear.
Sunblock is not needed. We have our ski bowl at Bald Hill, offering exhilarating downhill runs of up to 300 feet.
We can guarantee that all our hotels will look exactly the same and have the same view -- expressway on one side and parking lot on the other. So visitors do not need to spend hours agonizing over where to stay. And we can offer spectacular savings on shopping, not because prices are low, but because the walk from the parking lot to the mall entrance is enough to put off all but the most determined spenders.
Florida is for wimps who just cannot face our special brand of flu viruses or our refreshing breezes straight from Canada. The image that Long Island needs to promote winter tourism is the kind that induces people to go on mountain-climbing holidays in Nepal or dog sledding in Alaska.
A winter vacation here has to be sold as a feat of endurance and triumphant survival or, at worst, the brave acceptance of death from pneumonia. If we can sell Long Island as a winter vacation paradise, the whole local economy will benefit.
So let's get this campaign off the ground. Our sales logo will be crossed ice scrapers on a background of dead automobile batteries, and the slogan, "Long Island in Winter: It's Really Cool."

GRAPHIC: Drawing. (P. C. Vey)

SECTION: Section 13LI; Page 4; Column 3; Long Island Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 1633 words

HEADLINE: Glen Cove Puts Faith in Waterfront Plan

BYLINE: By LISA PULITZER 

 BODY:
IF you build it, they will come," says Glen Cove Mayor Thomas R. Suozzi of his city's proposed seaport village, a multimillion-dollar waterfront revitalization project that calls for the redevelopment of a 214-acre industrial site on both sides of Glen Cove Creek.
The property, behind the Glen Cove firehouse on Glen Cove Road, is one of three historical waterfront communities situated along Nassau County's North Shore and is accessible to motorists by Shore Road. 
 Under the proposal, several environmentally hazardous sections of the Glen Cove property would be cleaned up and the area would be transformed into a tourist destination, like Mystic Seaport in Connecticut and South Street Seaport in Manhattan, with waterfront restaurants, boutiques, maritime attractions, a pedestrian promenade and a high-speed ferry to Manhattan and Connecticut.
Currently, a handful of light industrial and public service businesses, as well as three commercial marinas, occupy the waterfront site. But it is also home to many environmental problems that stem from an inactive landfill, a recently closed garbage incinerator and two Federal Superfund sites: the 68-acre Li Tungsten property, once the site of a carbide tungsten producing plant, and the 1.9-acre Mattice Petrochemical property.
"It is our intent to establish realistic uses for this area which will be capable of substantially contributing to the economic base of Glen Cove and the neighboring region," Mr. Suozzi said in an interview this month. "Imagine a place where people can go with their families and enjoy a fresh lobster or clams on the half shell while watching the sun set over Hempstead Harbor."
The third in his family to run Glen Cove, Mr. Suozzi is widely seen as having done more to revitalize the land-locked North Shore community and reinvigorate its flagging economy in a few short years than the last several mayors combined. Some storefronts are still shuttered, but Mr. Suozzi has lured some new businesses into town, among them Acclaim Entertainment, a video games manufacturer that has moved its corporate headquarters and several hundred employees to vacant offices on School Street.
His current project, one he hopes will help in a possible bid to unseat Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, is his Waterfront Revitalization Plan: a seven-step proposal that incorporates the environmental cleanup of several hazardous waste sites together with an economic business plan for the area's polluted waterfront property.
The plan requires the cooperation of a 40 Federal, state, and county agencies, including the Department of Environmental Conservation, the Environmental Protection Agency and the Department of Transportation.
But competing interests, bureaucratic sluggishness and a lack of government money threaten the plan. Mr. Suozzi, who is serving his second term, has projected the plan will take five years to realize and says he will tackle it in stages.
Mr. Suozzi has already got a variety of agencies to commit more than $1 million to environmental cleanup. The first phase began last month with the arrival of the Army Corps of Engineers.
In November, the agency began dredging the creek's 1.1 mile navigation channel, something not done since 1965. More than 30 years of neglect has left the waterway almost unnavigable, because of the layers of silt and sand at the creek bottom.
In December, the Mayor celebrated yet another victory, winning money toward a cleanup of a severely contaminated piece of land at the heart of the waterfront project. The 32-acre tract, known as Captain's Cove, is the site of a shell of an abandoned condominium complex that has been repossessed by the Maryland Insurance Deposit Fund. Last week, the Mayor struck a deal with the fund that, along with financing from the state, will pay for the cleanup of the polluted property and result in the acquisition by the city of 25 percent of the land.
"It's been a coordinated effort," said George Stafford, the Secretary of State. His department awarded a $227,000 grant for an environmental impact study of several of the contaminated sites. "The process is long and complicated," he said. "People have inhabited these areas for two or three hundred years, so you never really know what you will find."
Most residents agree that the area's environmental problems must indeed be resolved, but there are those who say it is fantasy to think that people will trek up the peninsula on the already overcrowded Glen Cove Road to frequent an out-of-the-way seafood restaurant or another as-yet undetermined lure. Glen Cove is 20 minutes to the north of the Long Island Expressway.
"I don't know if this is the panacea that this city needs to cure its ills," said Jeffrey Lang, who has lived across from the Glen Cove Creek for more than 10 years. "I don't know if it will bring any glory or significant improvement to Glen Cove. I think it's an ambitious project, but you'd have to be honest and say you'd need a tourist base to begin with."
Mr. Suozzi disagrees. Alluding to unidentified economic analysis, the Mayor says people are attracted to waterfront areas.
"Look at Mamaroneck, Port Jefferson and Port Washington," said the Mayor, who says his waterfront project will entice day-trippers from Manhattan, Queens, Nassau and Suffolk. "People go to those areas because they can see water, walk along the shore, and have a nice meal."
"At one time, Glen Cove was the Gold Coast," the Mayor said, looking back to the 1920's, when Glen Cove was home to wealthy industrial barons like F. W. Woolworth, Charles Pratt and Henry Morgan.
"It was the place where people like the Pratts and the Morgans built their mansions. The Woolworth mansion, with its 18-karat gold staircase, is no less of an estate than the mansions that people visit in Newport, R.I. Not everyone wants to drive out to Montauk Point or the Hamptons for the weekend."
The city of Glen Cove has tried to revitalize in the past. During Mr. Suozzi's first term as mayor, the city poured millions of dollars into an urban redevelopment project aimed at breathing new life into the financially depressed downtown. The city received a makeover that included new sidewalks and fancy street lamps, and the construction of a multilevel parking garage.
While there has been some improvement, like the arrival of a Starbucks coffee house and a six-screen Cineplex Odeon theater, the downtown is hardly the thriving community that officials had anticipated.
Mr. Suozzi and other local officials now think the remedy may be a revitalized waterfront. They point to places like Norwalk and Mystic, Conn., and Newport, R.I., where waterfront maritime centers have proved successful.
"Norwalk, Conn., is an excellent example of the direction Glen Cove is heading," said Jim Frayer, incoming president of the Glen Cove Chamber of Commerce. "We want to revive Glen Cove's maritime history. Glen Cove's downtown has not been an economic growth area. But we believe the waterfront revitalization plan can stimulate the downtown area as well. "
In November, members of the Long Island Regional Planning Board visited Glen Cove to hear the Mayor's plan.
"We endorsed the concept," said Lee E. Koppelman, the board's chairman. "We think the city is moving in a correct direction, and we are encouraging its implementation. There are a lot of problems in Glen Cove. Part depends on private investment, but it is a complex, imaginative plan."
Mr. Koppelman cited Port Jefferson in Suffolk County. "It has become a tourist Mecca," he said of the bustling waterfront village. "The Glen Cove plan not only would revitalize the City of Glen Cove, but I think it has positive economic aspects for the whole of Nassau County, and from an esthetic point of view, the challenge of being able to revitalize the village concept is a direction that Long Island communities should be taking."
He cautioned, however, that the plan will require cooperation from every branch of government. "The key element of this is improvement of road access down to the waterfront," Mr. Koppelman said, referring to the need for the construction of a road that, because of the wetlands must be traversed, will involve input from the Department of Transportation and the Department of Environmental Conservation. "It will be a challenge, but it is not insurmountable."
The first renderings of the still evolving master plan, which included several vehicular and pedestrian roadways that bridged the existing downtown area to the waterfront area, were shown at an informal public meeting in December.
Mark Strauss, a principal of Jambhekar Strauss, the New York consulting firm preparing the plan, reviewed the schematic and spoke of the maritime center and village to be constructed on the Captain's Cove property. Restaurants, retail shops, a hotel and family recreational center, as well as a proposed high-speed commuter ferry terminal, currently under study by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, are all part of the grand plan.
The plan was met with wide support from the more than 300 residents at the meeting.
"The project does make a lot of sense," said Chris Guides, an environmental consultant who lives in Glen Cove. "It's a good idea to put money back into an area that right now is not generating any revenue for the City."
"It will be a long process," the Mayor told his constituents, vowing to remove the contaminated tanks from the Li Tungsten property within five months and to demolish the plant's black smokestack within 18 months.
"It will take a lot of public input along the way. The object is to try and develop a place that is beneficial to residents of Glen Cove. We want to make the Gold Coast glitter again."

SECTION: Section 13WC; Page 10; Column 3; Westchester Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 1002 words

HEADLINE: Hospitals Unite for Savings and Care

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER 

 BODY:
EIGHT and one-half million dollars. That is the projected savings that hospitals in the Westchester area expect to achieve this year by joining forces and becoming members of the Health Star Network in Armonk.
Health Star, organized to help community hospitals deal with the sharp changes in the industry, became the first major health care network in the area last September as the result of the alliance of Northern Westchester Hospital in Mount Kisco and White Plains Hospital Medical Center. In November, Putnam Hospital Center in Carmel, Putnam County's largest health care organization and Putnam County's largest employer, became a member. And Jan. 3, Lawrence Hospital in Bronxville announced its plans to join, too. 
 "The objective of Health Star allows participating hospitals to share resources in a way that helps them deliver high-quality health care services while keeping community control of their hospitals," said Jon B. Schandler, president and chief executive officer of the White Plains Hospital Medical Center. "It also gives member hospitals greater financial leverage in everything from buying supplies to sharing data-processing services to negotiating with managed-care companies."
Donald W. Davis, president and chief executive officer of Northern Westchester Hospital, said: "And it is invisible to the patient." Each Health Star member hospital remains independent to deliver the same level of care to its patients as before. This is not a situation where a large New York City hospital absorbs a local hospital. We're a locally based alliance of financially strong hospitals, each retaining community control of our own organization."
Rodney N. Huebbers, president and chief executive officer of Putnam Hospital Center, added: "Economically, we certainly feel we will benefit from our membership in Health Star. But we also look forward to sharing resources. For example, we have a strong outpatient renal-dialysis program we can make available to patients of our member hospitals."
In turn, Mr. Davis observed that Northern Westchester Hospital's new neonatology program for premature babies would be accessible to Health Star participants.
And the White Plains Hospital Medical Center's Breast Imagery Center, a state-of-the-art screening and diagnostic program for breast cancer, will also be available to patients at the other hospitals, Mr. Schandler said.
"We complement one another," he said. "We're all bringing something of value to the table. This is a major benefit of the alliance, sharing resources in a way that allows us to give the highest quality of health care to patients in a community setting."
After Lawrence Hospital had explored several options, its president, Roger Dvorak, said: "We were convinced that Health Star was the right course for us to take. Health Star offers Lawrence Hospital the economic benefits of a large health care network while allowing us to retain our tradition as a community-based hospital. By bringing together the finest and financially strongest hospitals in our region, Health Star is taking the lead in making sure that we can deliver the highest quality of health care services."
With the addition of Lawrence Hospital, the Health Star Network now extends from southern Westchester to Putnam County and has expanded into an organization with a total of 1,387 doctors, 1,010 licensed hospital beds, 3,584 full-time employees and total operating revenue of almost $310 million.
"With numbers like that, we become a major player with clout needed to negotiate with insurance companies and other payers," said Dr. Peter C. Welch, Health Star senior vice president for Medical Affairs.
Dr. Welch was referring to the change in the law on Jan. 1, which abolished, after 15 years, state price control of hospital procedures .
Last year, the State Legislature voted to end state price controls in favor of having the rates set through negotiations between hospitals and insurance companies and other payers, which is the way prices are set in 48 states.
Negotiations with the eight major managed-care insurance companies in the area are continuing, said Kevin G. Murphy, Health Star's chief financial officer.
"We have already come to terms with two of them and expect to sign contracts shortly," Mr. Murphy said. "And we have reached agreements with three others, which demonstrates how Health Star has strengthened its member hospitals' ability to compete effectively in a tough, key market."
Dr. Welch said: "Our combined medical staffs alone is impressive by any standards. As a physician, I appreciated the value of a strong community hospital. I am involved with the medical staffs of all member hospitals and oversee communication between the physicians and the network. Although each hospital will still offer a full range of health care service to their own patients, we have plans for a joint state-of-the art information system. In this rapidly changing health care environment, sharing the cost makes it possible."
The buying power of Health Star is a bargaining tool with vendors, Mr. Schandler said. "Before Lawrence Hospital joined us," he said, "we figured that the combined spending on supplies for the three of us amounted to $40 million annually, which makes us a very desirable customer and will result in a purchasing savings to each of us of at least 10 percent."
Dr. Welch observed: "It's a win-win for the patient. Savings will be reinvested in our hospitals' clinical care services."
Other hospitals are welcome to join, Mr. Davis said. "The criteria is that they have a reputation for quality care," he said, "are financially strong and located within our natural market, which is Westchester County and environs."
The board of directors is made up of 20 members with equal representation from the four hospitals. Day-to-day management of the alliance is handled by a committee consisting of the chief executives of the participating hospitals and Dr. Welch and Mr. Murphy.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Health Star officers and heads of member hospitals at a meeting, are from left, Kevin G. Murray, Donald W. Davis, Jon B. Schandler, Peter C. Welch and Rodney N. Huebbers. (Joyce Dopkeen/The New York Times)
